BEGIN NOW  Vauquer (_nee_ de Conflans) is an elderly person, who for the past forty years has kept a lodging-house in the Rue Nueve-Sainte-Genevieve, in the district that lies between the Latin Quarter and the Faubourg Saint-Marcel. END
BEGIN NOW Her house (known in the neighborhood as the _Maison Vauquer_) receives men and women, old and young, and no word has ever been breathed against her respectable establishment; but, at the same time, it must be said that as a matter of fact no young woman has been under her roof for thirty years, and that if a young man stays there for any length of time it is a sure sign that his allowance must be of the slenderest. END
BEGIN NOW In , however, the time when this drama opens, there was an almost penniless young girl among Vauquer's boarders. END
BEGIN NOW That word drama has been somewhat discredited of late; it has been overworked and twisted to strange uses in these days of dolorous literature; but it must do service again here, not because this story is dramatic in the restricted sense of the word, but because some tears may perhaps be shed _intra et extra muros_ before it is over. END
BEGIN NOW Will any one without the walls of Paris understand it? END
BEGIN NOW It is open to doubt. END
BEGIN NOW The only audience who could appreciate the results of close observation, the careful reproduction of minute detail and local color, are dwellers between the heights of Montrouge and Montmartre, in a vale of crumbling stucco watered by streams of black mud, a vale of sorrows which are real and joys too often hollow; but this audience is so accustomed to terrible sensations, that only some unimaginable and well-neigh impossible woe could produce any lasting impression there. END
BEGIN NOW Now and again there are tragedies so awful and so grand by reason of the complication of virtues and vices that bring them about, that egotism and selfishness are forced to pause and are moved to pity; but the impression that they receive is like a luscious fruit, soon consumed. END
BEGIN NOW Civilization, like the car of Juggernaut, is scarcely stayed perceptibly in its progress by a heart less easy to break than the others that lie in its course; this also is broken, and Civilization continues on her course triumphant. END
BEGIN NOW And you, too, will do the like; you who with this book in your white hand will sink back among the cushions of your armchair, and say to yourself, Perhaps this may amuse me. END
BEGIN NOW You will read the story of Father Goriot's secret woes, and, dining thereafter with an unspoiled appetite, will lay the blame of your insensibility upon the writer, and accuse him of exaggeration, of writing romances. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW once for all, this drama is neither a fiction nor a romance! END
BEGIN NOW _All is true_,&mdash;so true, that every one can discern the elements of the tragedy in his own house, perhaps in his own heart. END
BEGIN NOW The lodging-house is Vauquer's own property. END
BEGIN NOW It is still standing in the lower end of the Rue Nueve-Sainte-Genevieve, just where the road slopes so sharply down to the Rue de l'Arbalete, that wheeled traffic seldom passes that way, because it is so stony and steep. END
BEGIN NOW This position is sufficient to account for the silence prevalent in the streets shut in between the dome of the Pantheon and the dome of the Val-de-Grace, two conspicuous public buildings which give a yellowish tone to the landscape and darken the whole district that lies beneath the shadow of their leaden-hued cupolas. END
BEGIN NOW In that district the pavements are clean and dry, there is neither mud nor water in the gutters, grass grows in the chinks of the walls. END
BEGIN NOW The most heedless passer-by feels the depressing influences of a place where the sound of wheels creates a sensation; there is a grim look about the houses, a suggestion of a jail about those high garden walls. END
BEGIN NOW A Parisian straying into a suburb apparently composed of lodging-houses and public institutions would see poverty and dullness, old age lying down to die, and joyous youth condemned to drudgery. END
BEGIN NOW It is the ugliest quarter of Paris, and, it may be added, the least known. END
BEGIN NOW But, before all things, the Rue Nueve-Sainte-Genevieve is like a bronze frame for a picture for which the mind cannot be too well prepared by the contemplation of sad hues and sober images. END
BEGIN NOW Even so, step by step the daylight decreases, and the cicerone's droning voice grows hollower as the traveler descends into the Catacombs. END
BEGIN NOW The comparison holds good! END
BEGIN NOW Who shall say which is more ghastly, the sight of the bleached skulls or of dried-up human hearts? END
BEGIN NOW The front of the lodging-house is at right angles to the road, and looks out upon a little garden, so that you see the side of the house in section, as it were, from the Rue Nueve-Sainte-Genevieve. END
BEGIN NOW Beneath the wall of the house front there lies a channel, a fathom wide, paved with cobble-stones, and beside it runs a graveled walk bordered by geraniums and oleanders and pomegranates set in great blue and white glazed earthenware pots. END
BEGIN NOW Access into the graveled walk is afforded by a door, above which the words MAISON VAUQUER may be read, and beneath, in rather smaller letters, _Lodgings for both sexes, etc._ During the day a glimpse into the garden is easily obtained through a wicket to which a bell is attached. END
BEGIN NOW On the opposite wall, at the further end of the graveled walk, a green marble arch was painted once upon a time by a local artist, and in this semblance of a shrine a statue representing Cupid is installed; a Parisian Cupid, so blistered and disfigured that he looks like a candidate for one of the adjacent hospitals, and might suggest an allegory to lovers of symbolism. END
BEGIN NOW The half-obliterated inscription on the pedestal beneath determines the date of this work of art, for it bears witness to the widespread enthusiasm felt for Voltaire on his return to Paris in : Whoe'er thou art, thy master see; He is, or was, or ought to be. END
BEGIN NOW At night the wicket gate is replaced by a solid door. END
BEGIN NOW The little garden is no wider than the front of the house; it is shut in between the wall of the street and the partition wall of the neighboring house. END
BEGIN NOW A mantle of ivy conceals the bricks and attracts the eyes of passers-by to an effect which is picturesque in Paris, for each of the walls is covered with trellised vines that yield a scanty dusty crop of fruit, and furnish besides a subject of conversation for Vauquer and her lodgers; every year the widow trembles for her vintage. END
BEGIN NOW A straight path beneath the walls on either side of the garden leads to a clump of lime-trees at the further end of it; _line_-trees, as Vauquer persists in calling them, in spite of the fact that she was a de Conflans, and regardless of repeated corrections from her lodgers. END
BEGIN NOW The central space between the walls is filled with artichokes and rows of pyramid fruit-trees, and surrounded by a border of lettuce, pot-herbs, and parsley. END
BEGIN NOW Under the lime-trees there are a few green-painted garden seats and a wooden table, and hither, during the dog-days, such of the lodgers as are rich enough to indulge in a cup of coffee come to take their pleasure, though it is hot enough to roast eggs even in the shade. END
BEGIN NOW The house itself is three stories high, without counting the attics under the roof. END
BEGIN NOW It is built of rough stone, and covered with the yellowish stucco that gives a mean appearance to almost every house in Paris. END
BEGIN NOW There are five windows in each story in the front of the house; all the blinds visible through the small square panes are drawn up awry, so that the lines are all at cross purposes. END
BEGIN NOW At the side of the house there are but two windows on each floor, and the lowest of all are adorned with a heavy iron grating. END
BEGIN NOW Behind the house a yard extends for some twenty feet, a space inhabited by a happy family of pigs, poultry, and rabbits; the wood-shed is situated on the further side, and on the wall between the wood-shed and the kitchen window hangs the meat-safe, just above the place where the sink discharges its greasy streams. END
BEGIN NOW The cook sweeps all the refuse out through a little door into the Rue Nueve-Sainte-Genevieve, and frequently cleanses the yard with copious supplies of water, under pain of pestilence. END
BEGIN NOW The house might have been built on purpose for its present uses. END
BEGIN NOW Access is given by a French window to the first room on the ground floor, a sitting-room which looks out upon the street through the two barred windows already mentioned. END
BEGIN NOW Another door opens out of it into the dining-room, which is separated from the kitchen by the well of the staircase, the steps being constructed partly of wood, partly of tiles, which are colored and beeswaxed. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing can be more depressing than the sight of that sitting-room. END
BEGIN NOW The furniture is covered with horse hair woven in alternate dull and glossy stripes. END
BEGIN NOW There is a round table in the middle, with a purplish-red marble top, on which there stands, by way of ornament, the inevitable white china tea-service, covered with a half-effaced gilt network. END
BEGIN NOW The floor is sufficiently uneven, the wainscot rises to elbow height, and the rest of the wall space is decorated with a varnished paper, on which the principal scenes from _Telemaque_ are depicted, the various classical personages being colored. END
BEGIN NOW The subject between the two windows is the banquet given by Calypso to the son of Ulysses, displayed thereon for the admiration of the boarders, and has furnished jokes these forty years to the young men who show themselves superior to their position by making fun of the dinners to which poverty condemns them. END
BEGIN NOW The hearth is always so clean and neat that it is evident that a fire is only kindled there on great occasions; the stone chimney-piece is adorned by a couple of vases filled with faded artificial flowers imprisoned under glass shades, on either side of a bluish marble clock in the very worst taste. END
BEGIN NOW The first room exhales an odor for which there is no name in the language, and which should be called the _odeur de pension_. END
BEGIN NOW The damp atmosphere sends a chill through you as you breathe it; it has a stuffy, musty, and rancid quality; it permeates your clothing; after-dinner scents seem to be mingled in it with smells from the kitchen and scullery and the reek of a hospital. END
BEGIN NOW It might be possible to describe it if some one should discover a process by which to distil from the atmosphere all the nauseating elements with which it is charged by the catarrhal exhalations of every individual lodger, young or old. END
BEGIN NOW Yet, in spite of these stale horrors, the sitting-room is as charming and as delicately perfumed as a boudoir, when compared with the adjoining dining-room. END
BEGIN NOW The paneled walls of that apartment were once painted some color, now a matter of conjecture, for the surface is incrusted with accumulated layers of grimy deposit, which cover it with fantastic outlines. END
BEGIN NOW A collection of dim-ribbed glass decanters, metal discs with a satin sheen on them, and piles of blue-edged earthenware plates of Touraine ware cover the sticky surfaces of the sideboards that line the room. END
BEGIN NOW In a corner stands a box containing a set of numbered pigeon-holes, in which the lodgers' table napkins, more or less soiled and stained with wine, are kept. END
BEGIN NOW Here you see that indestructible furniture never met with elsewhere, which finds its way into lodging-houses much as the wrecks of our civilization drift into hospitals for incurables. END
BEGIN NOW You expect in such places as these to find the weather-house whence a Capuchin issues on wet days; you look to find the execrable engravings which spoil your appetite, framed every one in a black varnished frame, with a gilt beading round it; you know the sort of tortoise-shell clock-case, inlaid with brass; the green stove, the Argand lamps, covered with oil and dust, have met your eyes before. END
BEGIN NOW The oilcloth which covers the long table is so greasy that a waggish _externe_ will write his name on the surface, using his thumb-nail as a style. END
BEGIN NOW The chairs are broken-down invalids; the wretched little hempen mats slip away from under your feet without slipping away for good; and finally, the foot-warmers are miserable wrecks, hingeless, charred, broken away about the holes. END
BEGIN NOW It would be impossible to give an idea of the old, rotten, shaky, cranky, worm-eaten, halt, maimed, one-eyed, rickety, and ramshackle condition of the furniture without an exhaustive description, which would delay the progress of the story to an extent that impatient people would not pardon. END
BEGIN NOW The red tiles of the floor are full of depressions brought about by scouring and periodical renewings of color. END
BEGIN NOW In short, there is no illusory grace left to the poverty that reigns here; it is dire, parsimonious, concentrated, threadbare poverty; as yet it has not sunk into the mire, it is only splashed by it, and though not in rags as yet, its clothing is ready to drop to pieces. END
BEGIN NOW This apartment is in all its glory at seven o'clock in the morning, when Vauquer's cat appears, announcing the near approach of his mistress, and jumps upon the sideboards to sniff at the milk in the bowls, each protected by a plate, while he purrs his morning greeting to the world. END
BEGIN NOW A moment later the widow shows her face; she is tricked out in a net cap attached to a false front set on awry, and shuffles into the room in her slipshod fashion. END
BEGIN NOW She is an oldish woman, with a bloated countenance, and a nose like a parrot's beak set in the middle of it; her fat little hands (she is as sleek as a church rat) and her shapeless, slouching figure are in keeping with the room that reeks of misfortune, where hope is reduced to speculate for the meanest stakes. END
BEGIN NOW Vauquer alone can breathe that tainted air without being disheartened by it. END
BEGIN NOW Her face is as fresh as a frosty morning in autumn; there are wrinkles about the eyes that vary in their expression from the set smile of a ballet-dancer to the dark, suspicious scowl of a discounter of bills; in short, she is at once the embodiment and interpretation of her lodging-house, as surely as her lodging-house implies the existence of its mistress. END
BEGIN NOW You can no more imagine the one without the other, than you can think of a jail without a turnkey. END
BEGIN NOW The unwholesome corpulence of the little woman is produced by the life she leads, just as typhus fever is bred in the tainted air of a hospital. END
BEGIN NOW The very knitted woolen petticoat that she wears beneath a skirt made of an old gown, with the wadding protruding through the rents in the material, is a sort of epitome of the sitting-room, the dining-room, and the little garden; it discovers the cook, it foreshadows the lodgers&mdash;the picture of the house is completed by the portrait of its mistress. END
BEGIN NOW Vauquer at the age of fifty is like all women who have seen a deal of trouble. END
BEGIN NOW She has the glassy eyes and innocent air of a trafficker in flesh and blood, who will wax virtuously indignant to obtain a higher price for her services, but who is quite ready to betray a Georges or a Pichegru, if a Georges or a Pichegru were in hiding and still to be betrayed, or for any other expedient that may alleviate her lot. END
BEGIN NOW Still, she is a good woman at bottom, said the lodgers who believed that the widow was wholly dependent upon the money that they paid her, and sympathized when they heard her cough and groan like one of themselves. END
BEGIN NOW What had M. Vauquer been? END
BEGIN NOW The lady was never very explicit on this head. END
BEGIN NOW How had she lost her money? END
BEGIN NOW Through trouble, was her answer. END
BEGIN NOW He had treated her badly, had left her nothing but her eyes to cry over his cruelty, the house she lived in, and the privilege of pitying nobody, because, so she was wont to say, she herself had been through every possible misfortune. END
BEGIN NOW Sylvie, the stout cook, hearing her mistress' shuffling footsteps, hastened to serve the lodgers' breakfasts. END
BEGIN NOW Beside those who lived in the house, Vauquer took boarders who came for their meals; but these _externes_ usually only came to dinner, for which they paid thirty francs a month. END
BEGIN NOW At the time when this story begins, the lodging-house contained seven inmates. END
BEGIN NOW The best rooms in the house were on the first story, Vauquer herself occupying the least important, while the rest were let to a Couture, the widow of a commissary-general in the service of the Republic. END
BEGIN NOW With her lived Victorine Taillefer, a schoolgirl, to whom she filled the place of mother. END
BEGIN NOW These two ladies paid eighteen hundred francs a year. END
BEGIN NOW The two sets of rooms on the second floor were respectively occupied by an old man named Poiret and a man of forty or thereabouts, the wearer of a black wig and dyed whiskers, who gave out that he was a retired merchant, and was addressed as M. Vautrin. END
BEGIN NOW Two of the four rooms on the third floor were also let&mdash;one to an elderly spinster, a Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau, and the other to a retired manufacturer of vermicelli, Italian paste and starch, who allowed the others to address him as Father Goriot. END
BEGIN NOW The remaining rooms were allotted to various birds of passage, to impecunious students, who like Father Goriot and Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau, could only muster forty-five francs a month to pay for their board and lodging. END
BEGIN NOW Vauquer had little desire for lodgers of this sort; they ate too much bread, and she only took them in default of better. END
BEGIN NOW At that time one of the rooms was tenanted by a law student, a young man from the neighborhood of Angouleme, one of a large family who pinched and starved themselves to spare twelve hundred francs a year for him. END
BEGIN NOW Misfortune had accustomed Eugene de Rastignac, for that was his name, to work. END
BEGIN NOW He belonged to the number of young men who know as children that their parents' hopes are centered on them, and deliberately prepare themselves for a great career, subordinating their studies from the first to this end, carefully watching the indications of the course of events, calculating the probable turn that affairs will take, that they may be the first to profit by them. END
BEGIN NOW But for his observant curiosity, and the skill with which he managed to introduce himself into the salons of Paris, this story would not have been colored by the tones of truth which it certainly owes to him, for they are entirely due to his penetrating sagacity and desire to fathom the mysteries of an appalling condition of things, which was concealed as carefully by the victim as by those who had brought it to pass. END
BEGIN NOW Above the third story there was a garret where the linen was hung to dry, and a couple of attics. END
BEGIN NOW Christophe, the man-of-all-work, slept in one, and Sylvie, the stout cook, in the other. END
BEGIN NOW Beside the seven inmates thus enumerated, taking one year with another, some eight law or medical students dined in the house, as well as two or three regular comers who lived in the neighborhood. END
BEGIN NOW There were usually eighteen people at dinner, and there was room, if need be, for twenty at Vauquer's table; at breakfast, however, only the seven lodgers appeared. END
BEGIN NOW It was almost like a family party. END
BEGIN NOW Every one came down in dressing-gown and slippers, and the conversation usually turned on anything that had happened the evening before; comments on the dress or appearance of the dinner contingent were exchanged in friendly confidence. END
BEGIN NOW These seven lodgers were Vauquer's spoiled children. END
BEGIN NOW Among them she distributed, with astronomical precision, the exact proportion of respect and attention due to the varying amounts they paid for their board. END
BEGIN NOW One single consideration influenced all these human beings thrown together by chance. END
BEGIN NOW The two second-floor lodgers only paid seventy-two francs a month. END
BEGIN NOW Such prices as these are confined to the Faubourg Saint-Marcel and the district between La Bourbe and the Salpetriere; and, as might be expected, poverty, more or less apparent, weighed upon them all, Couture being the sole exception to the rule. END
BEGIN NOW The dreary surroundings were reflected in the costumes of the inmates of the house; all were alike threadbare. END
BEGIN NOW The color of the men's coats were problematical; such shoes, in more fashionable quarters, are only to be seen lying in the gutter; the cuffs and collars were worn and frayed at the edges; every limp article of clothing looked like the ghost of its former self. END
BEGIN NOW The women's dresses were faded, old-fashioned, dyed and re-dyed; they wore gloves that were glazed with hard wear, much-mended lace, dingy ruffles, crumpled muslin fichus. END
BEGIN NOW So much for their clothing; but, for the most part, their frames were solid enough; their constitutions had weathered the storms of life; their cold, hard faces were worn like coins that have been withdrawn from circulation, but there were greedy teeth behind the withered lips. END
BEGIN NOW Dramas brought to a close or still in progress are foreshadowed by the sight of such actors as these, not the dramas that are played before the footlights and against a background of painted canvas, but dumb dramas of life, frost-bound dramas that sere hearts like fire, dramas that do not end with the actors' lives. END
BEGIN NOW Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau, that elderly young lady, screened her weak eyes from the daylight by a soiled green silk shade with a rim of brass, an object fit to scare away the Angel of Pity himself. END
BEGIN NOW Her shawl, with its scanty, draggled fringe, might have covered a skeleton, so meagre and angular was the form beneath it. END
BEGIN NOW Yet she must have been pretty and shapely once. END
BEGIN NOW What corrosive had destroyed the feminine outlines? END
BEGIN NOW Was it trouble, or vice, or greed? END
BEGIN NOW Had she loved too well? END
BEGIN NOW Had she been a second-hand clothes dealer, a frequenter of the backstairs of great houses, or had she been merely a courtesan? END
BEGIN NOW Was she expiating the flaunting triumphs of a youth overcrowded with pleasures by an old age in which she was shunned by every passer-by? END
BEGIN NOW Her vacant gaze sent a chill through you; her shriveled face seemed like a menace. END
BEGIN NOW Her voice was like the shrill, thin note of the grasshopper sounding from the thicket when winter is at hand. END
BEGIN NOW She said that she had nursed an old gentleman, ill of catarrh of the bladder, and left to die by his children, who thought that he had nothing left. END
BEGIN NOW His bequest to her, a life annuity of a thousand francs, was periodically disputed by his heirs, who mingled slander with their persecutions. END
BEGIN NOW In spite of the ravages of conflicting passions, her face retained some traces of its former fairness and fineness of tissue, some vestiges of the physical charms of her youth still survived. END
BEGIN NOW M. Poiret was a sort of automaton. END
BEGIN NOW He might be seen any day sailing like a gray shadow along the walks of the Jardin des Plantes, on his head a shabby cap, a cane with an old yellow ivory handle in the tips of his thin fingers; the outspread skirts of his threadbare overcoat failed to conceal his meagre figure; his breeches hung loosely on his shrunken limbs; the thin, blue-stockinged legs trembled like those of a drunken man; there was a notable breach of continuity between the dingy white waistcoat and crumpled shirt frills and the cravat twisted about a throat like a turkey gobbler's; altogether, his appearance set people wondering whether this outlandish ghost belonged to the audacious race of the sons of Japhet who flutter about on the Boulevard Italien. END
BEGIN NOW What devouring kind of toil could have so shriveled him? END
BEGIN NOW What devouring passions had darkened that bulbous countenance, which would have seemed outrageous as a caricature? END
BEGIN NOW What had he been? END
BEGIN NOW Well, perhaps he had been part of the machinery of justice, a clerk in the office to which the executioner sends in his accounts,&mdash;so much for providing black veils for parricides, so much for sawdust, so much for pulleys and cord for the knife. END
BEGIN NOW Or he might have been a receiver at the door of a public slaughter-house, or a sub-inspector of nuisances. END
BEGIN NOW Indeed, the man appeared to have been one of the beasts of burden in our great social mill; one of those Parisian Ratons whom their Bertrands do not even know by sight; a pivot in the obscure machinery that disposes of misery and things unclean; one of those men, in short, at sight of whom we are prompted to remark that, After all, we cannot do without them. END
BEGIN NOW Stately Paris ignores the existence of these faces bleached by moral or physical suffering; but, then, Paris is in truth an ocean that no line can plumb. END
BEGIN NOW You may survey its surface and describe it; but no matter how numerous and painstaking the toilers in this sea, there will always be lonely and unexplored regions in its depths, caverns unknown, flowers and pearls and monsters of the deep overlooked or forgotten by the divers of literature. END
BEGIN NOW The Maison Vauquer is one of these curious monstrosities. END
BEGIN NOW Two, however, of Vauquer's boarders formed a striking contrast to the rest. END
BEGIN NOW There was a sickly pallor, such as is often seen in anaemic girls, in Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Victorine Taillefer's face; and her unvarying expression of sadness, like her embarrassed manner and pinched look, was in keeping with the general wretchedness of the establishment in the Rue Nueve-Saint-Genevieve, which forms a background to this picture; but her face was young, there was youthfulness in her voice and elasticity in her movements. END
BEGIN NOW This young misfortune was not unlike a shrub, newly planted in an uncongenial soil, where its leaves have already begun to wither. END
BEGIN NOW The outlines of her figure, revealed by her dress of the simplest and cheapest materials, were also youthful. END
BEGIN NOW There was the same kind of charm about her too slender form, her faintly colored face and light-brown hair, that modern poets find in mediaeval statuettes; and a sweet expression, a look of Christian resignation in the dark gray eyes. END
BEGIN NOW She was pretty by force of contrast; if she had been happy, she would have been charming. END
BEGIN NOW Happiness is the poetry of woman, as the toilette is her tinsel. END
BEGIN NOW If the delightful excitement of a ball had made the pale face glow with color; if the delights of a luxurious life had brought the color to the wan cheeks that were slightly hollowed already; if love had put light into the sad eyes, then Victorine might have ranked among the fairest; but she lacked the two things which create woman a second time&mdash;pretty dresses and love-letters. END
BEGIN NOW A book might have been made of her story. END
BEGIN NOW Her father was persuaded that he had sufficient reason for declining to acknowledge her, and allowed her a bare six hundred francs a year; he had further taken measures to disinherit his daughter, and had converted all his real estate into personalty, that he might leave it undivided to his son. END
BEGIN NOW Victorine's mother had died broken-hearted in Couture's house; and the latter, who was a near relation, had taken charge of the little orphan. END
BEGIN NOW Unluckily, the widow of the commissary-general to the armies of the Republic had nothing in the world but her jointure and her widow's pension, and some day she might be obliged to leave the helpless, inexperienced girl to the mercy of the world. END
BEGIN NOW The good soul, therefore, took Victorine to mass every Sunday, and to confession once a fortnight, thinking that, in any case, she would bring up her ward to be devout. END
BEGIN NOW She was right; religion offered a solution of the problem of the young girl's future. END
BEGIN NOW The poor child loved the father who refused to acknowledge her. END
BEGIN NOW Once every year she tried to see him to deliver her mother's message of forgiveness, but every year hitherto she had knocked at that door in vain; her father was inexorable. END
BEGIN NOW Her brother, her only means of communication, had not come to see her for four years, and had sent her no assistance; yet she prayed to God to unseal her father's eyes and to soften her brother's heart, and no accusations mingled with her prayers. END
BEGIN NOW Couture and Vauquer exhausted the vocabulary of abuse, and failed to find words that did justice to the banker's iniquitous conduct; but while they heaped execrations on the millionaire, Victorine's words were as gentle as the moan of the wounded dove, and affection found expression even in the cry drawn from her by pain. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene de Rastignac was a thoroughly southern type; he had a fair complexion, blue eyes, black hair. END
BEGIN NOW In his figure, manner, and his whole bearing it was easy to see that he had either come of a noble family, or that, from his earliest childhood, he had been gently bred. END
BEGIN NOW If he was careful of his wardrobe, only taking last year's clothes into daily wear, still upon occasion he could issue forth as a young man of fashion. END
BEGIN NOW Ordinarily he wore a shabby coat and waistcoat, the limp black cravat, untidily knotted, that students affect, trousers that matched the rest of his costume, and boots that had been resoled. END
BEGIN NOW Vautrin (the man of forty with the dyed whiskers) marked a transition stage between these two young people and the others. END
BEGIN NOW He was the kind of man that calls forth the remark: He looks a jovial sort! END
BEGIN NOW He had broad shoulders, a well-developed chest, muscular arms, and strong square-fisted hands; the joints of his fingers were covered with tufts of fiery red hair. END
BEGIN NOW His face was furrowed by premature wrinkles; there was a certain hardness about it in spite of his bland and insinuating manner. END
BEGIN NOW His bass voice was by no means unpleasant, and was in keeping with his boisterous laughter. END
BEGIN NOW He was always obliging, always in good spirits; if anything went wrong with one of the locks, he would soon unscrew it, take it to pieces, file it, oil and clean and set it in order, and put it back in its place again; I am an old hand at it, he used to say. END
BEGIN NOW Not only so, he knew all about ships, the sea, France, foreign countries, men, business, law, great houses and prisons,&mdash;there was nothing that he did not know. END
BEGIN NOW If any one complained rather more than usual, he would offer his services at once. END
BEGIN NOW He had several times lent money to Vauquer, or to the boarders; but, somehow, those whom he obliged felt that they would sooner face death than fail to repay him; a certain resolute look, sometimes seen on his face, inspired fear of him, for all his appearance of easy good-nature. END
BEGIN NOW In the way he spat there was an imperturbable coolness which seemed to indicate that this was a man who would not stick at a crime to extricate himself from a false position. END
BEGIN NOW His eyes, like those of a pitiless judge, seemed to go to the very bottom of all questions, to read all natures, all feelings and thoughts. END
BEGIN NOW His habit of life was very regular; he usually went out after breakfast, returning in time for dinner, and disappeared for the rest of the evening, letting himself in about midnight with a latch key, a privilege that Vauquer accorded to no other boarder. END
BEGIN NOW But then he was on very good terms with the widow; he used to call her mamma, and put his arm round her waist, a piece of flattery perhaps not appreciated to the full! END
BEGIN NOW The worthy woman might imagine this to be an easy feat; but, as a matter of fact, no arm but Vautrin's was long enough to encircle her. END
BEGIN NOW It was a characteristic trait of his generously to pay fifteen francs a month for the cup of coffee with a dash of brandy in it, which he took after dinner. END
BEGIN NOW Less superficial observers than young men engulfed by the whirlpool of Parisian life, or old men, who took no interest in anything that did not directly concern them, would not have stopped short at the vaguely unsatisfactory impression that Vautrin made upon them. END
BEGIN NOW He knew or guessed the concerns of every one about him; but none of them had been able to penetrate his thoughts, or to discover his occupation. END
BEGIN NOW He had deliberately made his apparent good-nature, his unfailing readiness to oblige, and his high spirits into a barrier between himself and the rest of them, but not seldom he gave glimpses of appalling depths of character. END
BEGIN NOW He seemed to delight in scourging the upper classes of society with the lash of his tongue, to take pleasure in convicting it of inconsistency, in mocking at law and order with some grim jest worthy of Juvenal, as if some grudge against the social system rankled in him, as if there were some mystery carefully hidden away in his life. END
BEGIN NOW Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Taillefer felt attracted, perhaps unconsciously, by the strength of the one man, and the good looks of the other; her stolen glances and secret thoughts were divided between them; but neither of them seemed to take any notice of her, although some day a chance might alter her position, and she would be a wealthy heiress. END
BEGIN NOW For that matter, there was not a soul in the house who took any trouble to investigate the various chronicles of misfortunes, real or imaginary, related by the rest. END
BEGIN NOW Each one regarded the others with indifference, tempered by suspicion; it was a natural result of their relative positions. END
BEGIN NOW Practical assistance not one could give, this they all knew, and they had long since exhausted their stock of condolence over previous discussions of their grievances. END
BEGIN NOW They were in something the same position as an elderly couple who have nothing left to say to each other. END
BEGIN NOW The routine of existence kept them in contact, but they were parts of a mechanism which wanted oil. END
BEGIN NOW There was not one of them but would have passed a blind man begging in the street, not one that felt moved to pity by a tale of misfortune, not one who did not see in death the solution of the all-absorbing problem of misery which left them cold to the most terrible anguish in others. END
BEGIN NOW The happiest of these hapless beings was certainly Vauquer, who reigned supreme over this hospital supported by voluntary contributions. END
BEGIN NOW For her, the little garden, which silence, and cold, and rain, and drought combined to make as dreary as an Asian _steppe_, was a pleasant shaded nook; the gaunt yellow house, the musty odors of a back shop had charms for her, and for her alone. END
BEGIN NOW Those cells belonged to her. END
BEGIN NOW She fed those convicts condemned to penal servitude for life, and her authority was recognized among them. END
BEGIN NOW Where else in Paris would they have found wholesome food in sufficient quantity at the prices she charged them, and rooms which they were at liberty to make, if not exactly elegant or comfortable, at any rate clean and healthy? END
BEGIN NOW If she had committed some flagrant act of injustice, the victim would have borne it in silence. END
BEGIN NOW Such a gathering contained, as might have been expected, the elements out of which a complete society might be constructed. END
BEGIN NOW And, as in a school, as in the world itself, there was among the eighteen men and women who met round the dinner table a poor creature, despised by all the others, condemned to be the butt of all their jokes. END
BEGIN NOW At the beginning of Eugene de Rastignac's second twelvemonth, this figure suddenly started out into bold relief against the background of human forms and faces among which the law student was yet to live for another two years to come. END
BEGIN NOW This laughing-stock was the retired vermicelli-merchant, Father Goriot, upon whose face a painter, like the historian, would have concentrated all the light in his picture. END
BEGIN NOW How had it come about that the boarders regarded him with a half-malignant contempt? END
BEGIN NOW Why did they subject the oldest among their number to a kind of persecution, in which there was mingled some pity, but no respect for his misfortunes? END
BEGIN NOW Had he brought it on himself by some eccentricity or absurdity, which is less easily forgiven or forgotten than more serious defects? END
BEGIN NOW The question strikes at the root of many a social injustice. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps it is only human nature to inflict suffering on anything that will endure suffering, whether by reason of its genuine humility, or indifference, or sheer helplessness. END
BEGIN NOW Do we not, one and all, like to feel our strength even at the expense of some one or of something? END
BEGIN NOW The poorest sample of humanity, the street arab, will pull the bell handle at every street door in bitter weather, and scramble up to write his name on the unsullied marble of a monument. END
BEGIN NOW In the year , at the age of sixty-nine or thereabouts, Father Goriot had sold his business and retired&mdash;to Vauquer's boarding house. END
BEGIN NOW When he first came there he had taken the rooms now occupied by Couture; he had paid twelve hundred francs a year like a man to whom five louis more or less was a mere trifle. END
BEGIN NOW For him Vauquer had made various improvements in the three rooms destined for his use, in consideration of a certain sum paid in advance, so it was said, for the miserable furniture, that is to say, for some yellow cotton curtains, a few chairs of stained wood covered with Utrecht velvet, several wretched colored prints in frames, and wall papers that a little suburban tavern would have disdained. END
BEGIN NOW Possibly it was the careless generosity with which Father Goriot allowed himself to be overreached at this period of his life (they called him Monsieur Goriot very respectfully then) that gave Vauquer the meanest opinion of his business abilities; she looked on him as an imbecile where money was concerned. END
BEGIN NOW Goriot had brought with him a considerable wardrobe, the gorgeous outfit of a retired tradesman who denies himself nothing. END
BEGIN NOW Vauquer's astonished eyes beheld no less than eighteen cambric-fronted shirts, the splendor of their fineness being enhanced by a pair of pins each bearing a large diamond, and connected by a short chain, an ornament which adorned the vermicelli-maker's shirt front. END
BEGIN NOW He usually wore a coat of corn-flower blue; his rotund and portly person was still further set off by a clean white waistcoat, and a gold chain and seals which dangled over that broad expanse. END
BEGIN NOW When his hostess accused him of being a bit of a beau, he smiled with the vanity of a citizen whose foible is gratified. END
BEGIN NOW His cupboards (_ormoires_, as he called them in the popular dialect) were filled with a quantity of plate that he brought with him. END
BEGIN NOW The widow's eyes gleamed as she obligingly helped him to unpack the soup ladles, table-spoons, forks, cruet-stands, tureens, dishes, and breakfast services&mdash;all of silver, which were duly arranged upon shelves, besides a few more or less handsome pieces of plate, all weighing no inconsiderable number of ounces; he could not bring himself to part with these gifts that reminded him of past domestic festivals. END
BEGIN NOW This was my wife's present to me on the first anniversary of our wedding day, he said to Vauquer, as he put away a little silver posset dish, with two turtle-doves billing on the cover. END
BEGIN NOW Poor dear! END
BEGIN NOW she spent on it all the money she had saved before we were married. END
BEGIN NOW Do you know, I would sooner scratch the earth with my nails for a living, madame, than part with that. END
BEGIN NOW But I shall be able to take my coffee out of it every morning for the rest of my days, thank the Lord! END
BEGIN NOW I am not to be pitied. END
BEGIN NOW There's not much fear of my starving for some time to come. END
BEGIN NOW Finally, Vauquer's magpie's eye had discovered and read certain entries in the list of shareholders in the funds, and, after a rough calculation, was disposed to credit Goriot (worthy man) with something like ten thousand francs a year. END
BEGIN NOW From that day forward Vauquer (_nee_ de Conflans), who, as a matter of fact, had seen forty-eight summers, though she would only own to thirty-nine of them&mdash; Vauquer had her own ideas. END
BEGIN NOW Though Goriot's eyes seemed to have shrunk in their sockets, though they were weak and watery, owing to some glandular affection which compelled him to wipe them continually, she considered him to be a very gentlemanly and pleasant-looking man. END
BEGIN NOW Moreover, the widow saw favorable indications of character in the well-developed calves of his legs and in his square-shaped nose, indications still further borne out by the worthy man's full-moon countenance and look of stupid good-nature. END
BEGIN NOW This, in all probability, was a strongly-build animal, whose brains mostly consisted in a capacity for affection. END
BEGIN NOW His hair, worn in _ailes de pigeon_, and duly powdered every morning by the barber from the Ecole Polytechnique, described five points on his low forehead, and made an elegant setting to his face. END
BEGIN NOW Though his manners were somewhat boorish, he was always as neat as a new pin and he took his snuff in a lordly way, like a man who knows that his snuff-box is always likely to be filled with maccaboy, so that when Vauquer lay down to rest on the day of M. Goriot's installation, her heart, like a larded partridge, sweltered before the fire of a burning desire to shake off the shroud of Vauquer and rise again as Goriot. END
BEGIN NOW She would marry again, sell her boarding-house, give her hand to this fine flower of citizenship, become a lady of consequence in the quarter, and ask for subscriptions for charitable purposes; she would make little Sunday excursions to Choisy, Soissy, Gentilly; she would have a box at the theatre when she liked, instead of waiting for the author's tickets that one of her boarders sometimes gave her, in July; the whole Eldorado of a little Parisian household rose up before Vauquer in her dreams. END
BEGIN NOW Nobody knew that she herself possessed forty thousand francs, accumulated _sou by sou_, that was her secret; surely as far as money was concerned she was a very tolerable match. END
BEGIN NOW And in other respects, I am quite his equal, she said to herself, turning as if to assure herself of the charms of a form that the portly Sylvie found moulded in down feathers every morning. END
BEGIN NOW For three months from that day Veuve Vauquer availed herself of the services of M. Goriot's coiffeur, and went to some expense over her toilette, expense justifiable on the ground that she owed it to herself and her establishment to pay some attention to appearances when such highly-respectable persons honored her house with their presence. END
BEGIN NOW She expended no small amount of ingenuity in a sort of weeding process of her lodgers, announcing her intention of receiving henceforward none but people who were in every way select. END
BEGIN NOW If a stranger presented himself, she let him know that M. Goriot, one of the best known and most highly-respected merchants in Paris, had singled out her boarding-house for a residence. END
BEGIN NOW She drew up a prospectus headed MAISON VAUQUER, in which it was asserted that hers was _one of the oldest and most highly recommended boarding-houses in the Latin Quarter_. END
BEGIN NOW From the windows of the house, thus ran the prospectus, there is a charming view of the Vallee des Gobelins (so there is&mdash;from the third floor), and a _beautiful_ garden, _extending_ down to _an avenue of lindens_ at the further end. END
BEGIN NOW Mention was made of the bracing air of the place and its quiet situation. END
BEGIN NOW It was this prospectus that attracted la Comtesse de l'Ambermesnil, a widow of six and thirty, who was awaiting the final settlement of her husband's affairs, and of another matter regarding a pension due to her as the wife of a general who had died on the field of battle. END
BEGIN NOW On this Vauquer saw to her table, lighted a fire daily in the sitting-room for nearly six months, and kept the promise of her prospectus, even going to some expense to do so. END
BEGIN NOW And the Countess, on her side, addressed Vauquer as my dear, and promised her two more boarders, the Baronne de Vaumerland and the widow of a colonel, the late Comte de Picquoisie, who were about to leave a boarding-house in the Marais, where the terms were higher than at the Maison Vauquer. END
BEGIN NOW Both these ladies, moreover, would be very well to do when the people at the War Office had come to an end of their formalities. END
BEGIN NOW But Government departments are always so dilatory, the lady added. END
BEGIN NOW After dinner the two widows went together up to Vauquer's room, and had a snug little chat over some cordial and various delicacies reserved for the mistress of the house. END
BEGIN NOW Vauquer's ideas as to Goriot were cordially approved by de l'Ambermesnil; it was a capital notion, which for that matter she had guessed from the very first; in her opinion the vermicelli maker was an excellent man. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW my dear lady, such a well-preserved man of his age, as sound as my eyesight&mdash;a man who might make a woman happy! END
BEGIN NOW said the widow. END
BEGIN NOW The good-natured Countess turned to the subject of Vauquer's dress, which was not in harmony with her projects. END
BEGIN NOW You must put yourself on a war footing, said she. END
BEGIN NOW After much serious consideration the two widows went shopping together&mdash;they purchased a hat adorned with ostrich feathers and a cap at the Palais Royal, and the Countess took her friend to the Magasin de la Petite Jeannette, where they chose a dress and a scarf. END
BEGIN NOW Thus equipped for the campaign, the widow looked exactly like the prize animal hung out for a sign above an a la mode beef shop; but she herself was so much pleased with the improvement, as she considered it, in her appearance, that she felt that she lay under some obligation to the Countess; and, though by no means open-handed, she begged that lady to accept a hat that cost twenty francs. END
BEGIN NOW The fact was that she needed the Countess' services on the delicate mission of sounding Goriot; the countess must sing her praises in his ears. END
BEGIN NOW de l'Ambermesnil lent herself very good-naturedly to this manoeuvre, began her operations, and succeeded in obtaining a private interview; but the overtures that she made, with a view to securing him for herself, were received with embarrassment, not to say a repulse. END
BEGIN NOW She left him, revolted by his coarseness. END
BEGIN NOW My angel, said she to her dear friend, you will make nothing of that man yonder. END
BEGIN NOW He is absurdly suspicious, and he is a mean curmudgeon, an idiot, a fool; you would never be happy with him. END
BEGIN NOW After what had passed between M. Goriot and de l'Ambermesnil, the Countess would no longer live under the same roof. END
BEGIN NOW She left the next day, forgot to pay for six months' board, and left behind her wardrobe, cast-off clothing to the value of five francs. END
BEGIN NOW Eagerly and persistently as Vauquer sought her quondam lodger, the Comtesse de l'Ambermesnil was never heard of again in Paris. END
BEGIN NOW The widow often talked of this deplorable business, and regretted her own too confiding disposition. END
BEGIN NOW As a matter of fact, she was as suspicious as a cat; but she was like many other people, who cannot trust their own kin and put themselves at the mercy of the next chance comer&mdash;an odd but common phenomenon, whose causes may readily be traced to the depths of the human heart. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps there are people who know that they have nothing more to look for from those with whom they live; they have shown the emptiness of their hearts to their housemates, and in their secret selves they are conscious that they are severely judged, and that they deserve to be judged severely; but still they feel an unconquerable craving for praises that they do not hear, or they are consumed by a desire to appear to possess, in the eyes of a new audience, the qualities which they have not, hoping to win the admiration or affection of strangers at the risk of forfeiting it again some day. END
BEGIN NOW Or, once more, there are other mercenary natures who never do a kindness to a friend or a relation simply because these have a claim upon them, while a service done to a stranger brings its reward to self-love. END
BEGIN NOW Such natures feel but little affection for those who are nearest to them; they keep their kindness for remoter circles of acquaintance, and show most to those who dwell on its utmost limits. END
BEGIN NOW Vauquer belonged to both these essentially mean, false, and execrable classes. END
BEGIN NOW If I had been there at the time, Vautrin would say at the end of the story, I would have shown her up, and that misfortune would not have befallen you. END
BEGIN NOW I know that kind of phiz! END
BEGIN NOW Like all narrow natures, Vauquer was wont to confine her attention to events, and did not go very deeply into the causes that brought them about; she likewise preferred to throw the blame of her own mistakes on other people, so she chose to consider that the honest vermicelli maker was responsible for her misfortune. END
BEGIN NOW It had opened her eyes, so she said, with regard to him. END
BEGIN NOW As soon as she saw that her blandishments were in vain, and that her outlay on her toilette was money thrown away, she was not slow to discover the reason of his indifference. END
BEGIN NOW It became plain to her at once that there was _some other attraction_, to use her own expression. END
BEGIN NOW In short, it was evident that the hope she had so fondly cherished was a baseless delusion, and that she would never make anything out of that man yonder, in the Countess' forcible phrase. END
BEGIN NOW The Countess seemed to have been a judge of character. END
BEGIN NOW Vauquer's aversion was naturally more energetic than her friendship, for her hatred was not in proportion to her love, but to her disappointed expectations. END
BEGIN NOW The human heart may find here and there a resting-place short of the highest height of affection, but we seldom stop in the steep, downward slope of hatred. END
BEGIN NOW Still, M. Goriot was a lodger, and the widow's wounded self-love could not vent itself in an explosion of wrath; like a monk harassed by the prior of his convent, she was forced to stifle her sighs of disappointment, and to gulp down her craving for revenge. END
BEGIN NOW Little minds find gratification for their feelings, benevolent or otherwise, by a constant exercise of petty ingenuity. END
BEGIN NOW The widow employed her woman's malice to devise a system of covert persecution. END
BEGIN NOW She began by a course of retrenchment&mdash;various luxuries which had found their way to the table appeared there no more. END
BEGIN NOW No more gherkins, no more anchovies; they have made a fool of me! END
BEGIN NOW she said to Sylvie one morning, and they returned to the old bill of fare. END
BEGIN NOW The thrifty frugality necessary to those who mean to make their way in the world had become an inveterate habit of life with M. Goriot. END
BEGIN NOW Soup, boiled beef, and a dish of vegetables had been, and always would be, the dinner he liked best, so Vauquer found it very difficult to annoy a boarder whose tastes were so simple. END
BEGIN NOW He was proof against her malice, and in desperation she spoke to him and of him slightingly before the other lodgers, who began to amuse themselves at his expense, and so gratified her desire for revenge. END
BEGIN NOW Towards the end of the first year the widow's suspicions had reached such a pitch that she began to wonder how it was that a retired merchant with a secure income of seven or eight thousand livres, the owner of such magnificent plate and jewelry handsome enough for a kept mistress, should be living in her house. END
BEGIN NOW Why should he devote so small a proportion of his money to his expenses? END
BEGIN NOW Until the first year was nearly at an end, Goriot had dined out once or twice every week, but these occasions came less frequently, and at last he was scarcely absent from the dinner-table twice a month. END
BEGIN NOW It was hardly expected that Vauquer should regard the increased regularity of her boarder's habits with complacency, when those little excursions of his had been so much to her interest. END
BEGIN NOW She attributed the change not so much to a gradual diminution of fortune as to a spiteful wish to annoy his hostess. END
BEGIN NOW It is one of the most detestable habits of a Liliputian mind to credit other people with its own malignant pettiness. END
BEGIN NOW Unluckily, towards the end of the second year, M. Goriot's conduct gave some color to the idle talk about him. END
BEGIN NOW He asked Vauquer to give him a room on the second floor, and to make a corresponding reduction in her charges. END
BEGIN NOW Apparently, such strict economy was called for, that he did without a fire all through the winter. END
BEGIN NOW Vauquer asked to be paid in advance, an arrangement to which M. Goriot consented, and thenceforward she spoke of him as Father Goriot. END
BEGIN NOW What had brought about this decline and fall? END
BEGIN NOW Conjecture was keen, but investigation was difficult. END
BEGIN NOW Father Goriot was not communicative; in the sham countess' phrase he was a curmudgeon. END
BEGIN NOW Empty-headed people who babble about their own affairs because they have nothing else to occupy them, naturally conclude that if people say nothing of their doings it is because their doings will not bear being talked about; so the highly respectable merchant became a scoundrel, and the late beau was an old rogue. END
BEGIN NOW Opinion fluctuated. END
BEGIN NOW Sometimes, according to Vautrin, who came about this time to live in the Maison Vauquer, Father Goriot was a man who went on 'Change and _dabbled_ (to use the sufficiently expressive language of the Stock Exchange) in stocks and shares after he had ruined himself by heavy speculation. END
BEGIN NOW Sometimes it was held that he was one of those petty gamblers who nightly play for small stakes until they win a few francs. END
BEGIN NOW A theory that he was a detective in the employ of the Home Office found favor at one time, but Vautrin urged that Goriot was not sharp enough for one of that sort. END
BEGIN NOW There were yet other solutions; Father Goriot was a skinflint, a shark of a money-lender, a man who lived by selling lottery tickets. END
BEGIN NOW He was by turns all the most mysterious brood of vice and shame and misery; yet, however vile his life might be, the feeling of repulsion which he aroused in others was not so strong that he must be banished from their society&mdash;he paid his way. END
BEGIN NOW Besides, Goriot had his uses, every one vented his spleen or sharpened his wit on him; he was pelted with jokes and belabored with hard words. END
BEGIN NOW The general consensus of opinion was in favor of a theory which seemed the most likely; this was Vauquer's view. END
BEGIN NOW According to her, the man so well preserved at his time of life, as sound as her eyesight, with whom a woman might be very happy, was a libertine who had strange tastes. END
BEGIN NOW These are the facts upon which Vauquer's slanders were based. END
BEGIN NOW Early one morning, some few months after the departure of the unlucky Countess who had managed to live for six months at the widow's expense, Vauquer (not yet dressed) heard the rustle of a silk dress and a young woman's light footstep on the stair; some one was going to Goriot's room. END
BEGIN NOW He seemed to expect the visit, for his door stood ajar. END
BEGIN NOW The portly Sylvie presently came up to tell her mistress that a girl too pretty to be honest, dressed like a goddess, and not a speck of mud on her laced cashmere boots, had glided in from the street like a snake, had found the kitchen, and asked for M. Goriot's room. END
BEGIN NOW Vauquer and the cook, listening, overheard several words affectionately spoken during the visit, which lasted for some time. END
BEGIN NOW When M. Goriot went downstairs with the lady, the stout Sylvie forthwith took her basket and followed the lover-like couple, under pretext of going to do her marketing. END
BEGIN NOW M. Goriot must be awfully rich, all the same, madame, she reported on her return, to keep her in such style. END
BEGIN NOW Just imagine it! END
BEGIN NOW There was a splendid carriage waiting at the corner of the Place de l'Estrapade, and _she_ got into it. END
BEGIN NOW While they were at dinner that evening, Vauquer went to the window and drew the curtain, as the sun was shining into Goriot's eyes. END
BEGIN NOW You are beloved of fair ladies, M. Goriot&mdash;the sun seeks you out, she said, alluding to his visitor. END
BEGIN NOW _Peste!_ you have good taste; she was very pretty. END
BEGIN NOW That was my daughter, he said, with a kind of pride in his voice, and the rest chose to consider this as the fatuity of an old man who wishes to save appearances. END
BEGIN NOW A month after this visit M. Goriot received another. END
BEGIN NOW The same daughter who had come to see him that morning came again after dinner, this time in evening dress. END
BEGIN NOW The boarders, in deep discussion in the dining-room, caught a glimpse of a lovely, fair-haired woman, slender, graceful, and much too distinguished-looking to be a daughter of Father Goriot's. END
BEGIN NOW Two of them! END
BEGIN NOW cried the portly Sylvie, who did not recognize the lady of the first visit. END
BEGIN NOW A few days later, and another young lady&mdash;a tall, well-moulded brunette, with dark hair and bright eyes&mdash;came to ask for M. Goriot. END
BEGIN NOW Three of them! END
BEGIN NOW said Sylvie. END
BEGIN NOW Then the second daughter, who had first come in the morning to see her father, came shortly afterwards in the evening. END
BEGIN NOW She wore a ball dress, and came in a carriage. END
BEGIN NOW Four of them! END
BEGIN NOW commented Vauquer and her plump handmaid. END
BEGIN NOW Sylvie saw not a trace of resemblance between this great lady and the girl in her simple morning dress who had entered her kitchen on the occasion of her first visit. END
BEGIN NOW At that time Goriot was paying twelve hundred francs a year to his landlady, and Vauquer saw nothing out of the common in the fact that a rich man had four or five mistresses; nay, she thought it very knowing of him to pass them off as his daughters. END
BEGIN NOW She was not at all inclined to draw a hard-and-fast line, or to take umbrage at his sending for them to the Maison Vauquer; yet, inasmuch as these visits explained her boarder's indifference to her, she went so far (at the end of the second year) as to speak of him as an ugly old wretch. END
BEGIN NOW When at length her boarder declined to nine hundred francs a year, she asked him very insolently what he took her house to be, after meeting one of these ladies on the stairs. END
BEGIN NOW Father Goriot answered that the lady was his eldest daughter. END
BEGIN NOW So you have two or three dozen daughters, have you? END
BEGIN NOW said Vauquer sharply. END
BEGIN NOW I have only two, her boarder answered meekly, like a ruined man who is broken in to all the cruel usage of misfortune. END
BEGIN NOW Towards the end of the third year Father Goriot reduced his expenses still further; he went up to the third story, and now paid forty-five francs a month. END
BEGIN NOW He did without snuff, told his hairdresser that he no longer required his services, and gave up wearing powder. END
BEGIN NOW When Goriot appeared for the first time in this condition, an exclamation of astonishment broke from his hostess at the color of his hair&mdash;a dingy olive gray. END
BEGIN NOW He had grown sadder day by day under the influence of some hidden trouble; among all the faces round the table, his was the most woe-begone. END
BEGIN NOW There was no longer any doubt. END
BEGIN NOW Goriot was an elderly libertine, whose eyes had only been preserved by the skill of the physician from the malign influence of the remedies necessitated by the state of his health. END
BEGIN NOW The disgusting color of his hair was a result of his excesses and of the drugs which he had taken that he might continue his career. END
BEGIN NOW The poor old man's mental and physical condition afforded some grounds for the absurd rubbish talked about him. END
BEGIN NOW When his outfit was worn out, he replaced the fine linen by calico at fourteen _sous_ the ell. END
BEGIN NOW His diamonds, his gold snuff-box, watch-chain and trinkets, disappeared one by one. END
BEGIN NOW He had left off wearing the corn-flower blue coat, and was sumptuously arrayed, summer as well as winter, in a coarse chestnut-brown coat, a plush waistcoat, and doeskin breeches. END
BEGIN NOW He grew thinner and thinner; his legs were shrunken, his cheeks, once so puffed out by contented bourgeois prosperity, were covered with wrinkles, and the outlines of the jawbones were distinctly visible; there were deep furrows in his forehead. END
BEGIN NOW In the fourth year of his residence in the Rue Neuve-Sainte-Genevieve he was no longer like his former self. END
BEGIN NOW The hale vermicelli manufacturer, sixty-two years of age, who had looked scarce forty, the stout, comfortable, prosperous tradesman, with an almost bucolic air, and such a brisk demeanor that it did you good to look at him; the man with something boyish in his smile, had suddenly sunk into his dotage, and had become a feeble, vacillating septuagenarian. END
BEGIN NOW The keen, bright blue eyes had grown dull, and faded to a steel-gray color; the red inflamed rims looked as though they had shed tears of blood. END
BEGIN NOW He excited feelings of repulsion in some, and of pity in others. END
BEGIN NOW The young medical students who came to the house noticed the drooping of his lower lip and the conformation of the facial angle; and, after teasing him for some time to no purpose, they declared that cretinism was setting in. END
BEGIN NOW One evening after dinner Vauquer said half banteringly to him, So those daughters of yours don't come to see you any more, eh? END
BEGIN NOW meaning to imply her doubts as to his paternity; but Father Goriot shrank as if his hostess had touched him with a sword-point. END
BEGIN NOW They come sometimes, he said in a tremulous voice. END
BEGIN NOW Aha! END
BEGIN NOW you still see them sometimes? END
BEGIN NOW cried the students. END
BEGIN NOW Bravo, Father Goriot! END
BEGIN NOW The old man scarcely seemed to hear the witticisms at his expense that followed on the words; he had relapsed into the dreamy state of mind that these superficial observers took for senile torpor, due to his lack of intelligence. END
BEGIN NOW If they had only known, they might have been deeply interested by the problem of his condition; but few problems were more obscure. END
BEGIN NOW It was easy, of course, to find out whether Goriot had really been a vermicelli manufacturer; the amount of his fortune was readily discoverable; but the old people, who were most inquisitive as to his concerns, never went beyond the limits of the Quarter, and lived in the lodging-house much as oysters cling to a rock. END
BEGIN NOW As for the rest, the current of life in Paris daily awaited them, and swept them away with it; so soon as they left the Rue Neuve-Sainte-Genevieve, they forgot the existence of the old man, their butt at dinner. END
BEGIN NOW For those narrow souls, or for careless youth, the misery in Father Goriot's withered face and its dull apathy were quite incompatible with wealth or any sort of intelligence. END
BEGIN NOW As for the creatures whom he called his daughters, all Vauquer's boarders were of her opinion. END
BEGIN NOW With the faculty for severe logic sedulously cultivated by elderly women during long evenings of gossip till they can always find an hypothesis to fit all circumstances, she was wont to reason thus: If Father Goriot had daughters of his own as rich as those ladies who came here seemed to be, he would not be lodging in my house, on the third floor, at forty-five francs a month; and he would not go about dressed like a poor man. END
BEGIN NOW No objection could be raised to these inferences. END
BEGIN NOW So by the end of the month of November , at the time when the curtain rises on this drama, every one in the house had come to have a very decided opinion as to the poor old man. END
BEGIN NOW He had never had either wife or daughter; excesses had reduced him to this sluggish condition; he was a sort of human mollusk who should be classed among the capulidoe, so one of the dinner contingent, an _employe_ at the Museum, who had a pretty wit of his own. END
BEGIN NOW Poiret was an eagle, a gentleman, compared with Goriot. END
BEGIN NOW Poiret would join the talk, argue, answer when he was spoken to; as a matter of fact, his talk, arguments, and responses contributed nothing to the conversation, for Poiret had a habit of repeating what the others said in different words; still, he did join in the talk; he was alive, and seemed capable of feeling; while Father Goriot (to quote the Museum official again) was invariably at zero degrees&mdash;Reaumur. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene de Rastignac had just returned to Paris in a state of mind not unknown to young men who are conscious of unusual powers, and to those whose faculties are so stimulated by a difficult position, that for the time being they rise above the ordinary level. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac's first year of study for the preliminary examinations in law had left him free to see the sights of Paris and to enjoy some of its amusements. END
BEGIN NOW A student has not much time on his hands if he sets himself to learn the repertory of every theatre, and to study the ins and outs of the labyrinth of Paris. END
BEGIN NOW To know its customs; to learn the language, and become familiar with the amusements of the capital, he must explore its recesses, good and bad, follow the studies that please him best, and form some idea of the treasures contained in galleries and museums. END
BEGIN NOW At this stage of his career a student grows eager and excited about all sorts of follies that seem to him to be of immense importance. END
BEGIN NOW He has his hero, his great man, a professor at the College de France, paid to talk down to the level of his audience. END
BEGIN NOW He adjusts his cravat, and strikes various attitudes for the benefit of the women in the first galleries at the Opera-Comique. END
BEGIN NOW As he passes through all these successive initiations, and breaks out of his sheath, the horizons of life widen around him, and at length he grasps the plan of society with the different human strata of which it is composed. END
BEGIN NOW If he begins by admiring the procession of carriages on sunny afternoons in the Champs-Elysees, he soon reaches the further stage of envying their owners. END
BEGIN NOW Unconsciously, Eugene had served his apprenticeship before he went back to Angouleme for the long vacation after taking his degrees as bachelor of arts and bachelor of law. END
BEGIN NOW The illusions of childhood had vanished, so also had the ideas he brought with him from the provinces; he had returned thither with an intelligence developed, with loftier ambitions, and saw things as they were at home in the old manor house. END
BEGIN NOW His father and mother, his two brothers and two sisters, with an aged aunt, whose whole fortune consisted in annuities, lived on the little estate of Rastignac. END
BEGIN NOW The whole property brought in about three thousand francs; and though the amount varied with the season (as must always be the case in a vine-growing district), they were obliged to spare an unvarying twelve hundred francs out of their income for him. END
BEGIN NOW He saw how constantly the poverty, which they had generously hidden from him, weighed upon them; he could not help comparing the sisters, who had seemed so beautiful to his boyish eyes, with women in Paris, who had realized the beauty of his dreams. END
BEGIN NOW The uncertain future of the whole family depended upon him. END
BEGIN NOW It did not escape his eyes that not a crumb was wasted in the house, nor that the wine they drank was made from the second pressing; a multitude of small things, which it is useless to speak of in detail here, made him burn to distinguish himself, and his ambition to succeed increased tenfold. END
BEGIN NOW He meant, like all great souls, that his success should be owing entirely to his merits; but his was pre-eminently a southern temperament, the execution of his plans was sure to be marred by the vertigo that seizes on youth when youth sees itself alone in a wide sea, uncertain how to spend its energies, whither to steer its course, how to adapt its sails to the winds. END
BEGIN NOW At first he determined to fling himself heart and soul into his work, but he was diverted from this purpose by the need of society and connections; then he saw how great an influence women exert in social life, and suddenly made up his mind to go out into this world to seek a protectress there. END
BEGIN NOW Surely a clever and high-spirited young man, whose wit and courage were set off to advantage by a graceful figure and the vigorous kind of beauty that readily strikes a woman's imagination, need not despair of finding a protectress. END
BEGIN NOW These ideas occurred to him in his country walks with his sisters, whom he had once joined so gaily. END
BEGIN NOW The girls thought him very much changed. END
BEGIN NOW His aunt, de Marcillac, had been presented at court, and had moved among the brightest heights of that lofty region. END
BEGIN NOW Suddenly the young man's ambition discerned in those recollections of hers, which had been like nursery fairy tales to her nephews and nieces, the elements of a social success at least as important as the success which he had achieved at the Ecole de Droit. END
BEGIN NOW He began to ask his aunt about those relations; some of the old ties might still hold good. END
BEGIN NOW After much shaking of the branches of the family tree, the old lady came to the conclusion that of all persons who could be useful to her nephew among the selfish genus of rich relations, the Vicomtesse de Beauseant was the least likely to refuse. END
BEGIN NOW To this lady, therefore, she wrote in the old-fashioned style, recommending Eugene to her; pointing out to her nephew that if he succeeded in pleasing de Beauseant, the Vicomtesse would introduce him to other relations. END
BEGIN NOW A few days after his return to Paris, therefore, Rastignac sent his aunt's letter to de Beauseant. END
BEGIN NOW The Vicomtesse replied by an invitation to a ball for the following evening. END
BEGIN NOW This was the position of affairs at the Maison Vauquer at the end of November A few days later, after de Beauseant's ball, Eugene came in at two o'clock in the morning. END
BEGIN NOW The persevering student meant to make up for the lost time by working until daylight. END
BEGIN NOW It was the first time that he had attempted to spend the night in this way in that silent quarter. END
BEGIN NOW The spell of a factitious energy was upon him; he had beheld the pomp and splendor of the world. END
BEGIN NOW He had not dined at the Maison Vauquer; the boarders probably would think that he would walk home at daybreak from the dance, as he had done sometimes on former occasions, after a fete at the Prado, or a ball at the Odeon, splashing his silk stockings thereby, and ruining his pumps. END
BEGIN NOW It so happened that Christophe took a look into the street before drawing the bolts of the door; and Rastignac, coming in at that moment, could go up to his room without making any noise, followed by Christophe, who made a great deal. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene exchanged his dress suit for a shabby overcoat and slippers, kindled a fire with some blocks of patent fuel, and prepared for his night's work in such a sort that the faint sounds he made were drowned by Christophe's heavy tramp on the stairs. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene sat absorbed in thought for a few moments before plunging into his law books. END
BEGIN NOW He had just become aware of the fact that the Vicomtesse de Beauseant was one of the queens of fashion, that her house was thought to be the pleasantest in the Faubourg Saint-Germain. END
BEGIN NOW And not only so, she was, by right of her fortune, and the name she bore, one of the most conspicuous figures in that aristocratic world. END
BEGIN NOW Thanks to the aunt, thanks to de Marcillac's letter of introduction, the poor student had been kindly received in that house before he knew the extent of the favor thus shown to him. END
BEGIN NOW It was almost like a patent of nobility to be admitted to those gilded salons; he had appeared in the most exclusive circle in Paris, and now all doors were open for him. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene had been dazzled at first by the brilliant assembly, and had scarcely exchanged a few words with the Vicomtesse; he had been content to single out a goddess among this throng of Parisian divinities, one of those women who are sure to attract a young man's fancy. END
BEGIN NOW The Comtesse Anastasie de Restaud was tall and gracefully made; she had one of the prettiest figures in Paris. END
BEGIN NOW Imagine a pair of great dark eyes, a magnificently moulded hand, a shapely foot. END
BEGIN NOW There was a fiery energy in her movements; the Marquis de Ronquerolles had called her a thoroughbred, a pure pedigree, these figures of speech have replaced the heavenly angel and Ossianic nomenclature; the old mythology of love is extinct, doomed to perish by modern dandyism. END
BEGIN NOW But for Rastignac, Anastasie de Restaud was the woman for whom he had sighed. END
BEGIN NOW He had contrived to write his name twice upon the list of partners upon her fan, and had snatched a few words with her during the first quadrille. END
BEGIN NOW Where shall I meet you again, Madame? END
BEGIN NOW he asked abruptly, and the tones of his voice were full of the vehement energy that women like so well. END
BEGIN NOW Oh, everywhere! END
BEGIN NOW said she, in the Bois, at the Bouffons, in my own house. END
BEGIN NOW With the impetuosity of his adventurous southern temper, he did all he could to cultivate an acquaintance with this lovely countess, making the best of his opportunities in the quadrille and during a waltz that she gave him. END
BEGIN NOW When he told her that he was a cousin of de Beauseant's, the Countess, whom he took for a great lady, asked him to call at her house, and after her parting smile, Rastignac felt convinced that he must make this visit. END
BEGIN NOW He was so lucky as to light upon some one who did not laugh at his ignorance, a fatal defect among the gilded and insolent youth of that period; the coterie of Maulincourts, Maximes de Trailles, de Marsays, Ronquerolles, Ajuda-Pintos, and Vandenesses who shone there in all the glory of coxcombry among the best-dressed women of fashion in Paris&mdash;Lady Brandon, the Duchesse de Langeais, the Comtesse de Kergarouet, de Serizy, the Duchesse de Carigliano, the Comtesse Ferraud, de Lanty, the Marquise d'Aiglemont, Firmiani, the Marquise de Listomere and the Marquise d'Espard, the Duchesse de Maufrigneuse and the Grandlieus. END
BEGIN NOW Luckily, therefore, for him, the novice happened upon the Marquis de Montriveau, the lover of the Duchesse de Langeais, a general as simple as a child; from him Rastignac learned that the Comtesse lived in the Rue du Helder. END
BEGIN NOW Ah, what it is to be young, eager to see the world, greedily on the watch for any chance that brings you nearer the woman of your dreams, and behold two houses open their doors to you! END
BEGIN NOW To set foot in the Vicomtesse de Beauseant's house in the Faubourg Saint-Germain; to fall on your knees before a Comtesse de Restaud in the Chaussee d'Antin; to look at one glance across a vista of Paris drawing-rooms, conscious that, possessing sufficient good looks, you may hope to find aid and protection there in a feminine heart! END
BEGIN NOW To feel ambitious enough to spurn the tight-rope on which you must walk with the steady head of an acrobat for whom a fall is impossible, and to find in a charming woman the best of all balancing poles. END
BEGIN NOW He sat there with his thoughts for a while, Law on the one hand, and Poverty on the other, beholding a radiant vision of a woman rise above the dull, smouldering fire. END
BEGIN NOW Who would not have paused and questioned the future as Eugene was doing? END
BEGIN NOW who would not have pictured it full of success? END
BEGIN NOW His wondering thoughts took wings; he was transported out of the present into that blissful future; he was sitting by de Restaud's side, when a sort of sigh, like the grunt of an overburdened St. Joseph, broke the silence of the night. END
BEGIN NOW It vibrated through the student, who took the sound for a death groan. END
BEGIN NOW He opened his door noiselessly, went out upon the landing, and saw a thin streak of light under Father Goriot's door. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene feared that his neighbor had been taken ill; he went over and looked through the keyhole; the old man was busily engaged in an occupation so singular and so suspicious that Rastignac thought he was only doing a piece of necessary service to society to watch the self-styled vermicelli maker's nocturnal industries. END
BEGIN NOW The table was upturned, and Goriot had doubtless in some way secured a silver plate and cup to the bar before knotting a thick rope round them; he was pulling at this rope with such enormous force that they were being crushed and twisted out of shape; to all appearance he meant to convert the richly wrought metal into ingots. END
BEGIN NOW _Peste!_ what a man! END
BEGIN NOW said Rastignac, as he watched Goriot's muscular arms; there was not a sound in the room while the old man, with the aid of the rope, was kneading the silver like dough. END
