BEGIN NOW Was he then, indeed, a thief, or a receiver of stolen goods, who affected imbecility and decrepitude, and lived like a beggar that he might carry on his pursuits the more securely? END
BEGIN NOW Eugene stood for a moment revolving these questions, then he looked again through the keyhole. END
BEGIN NOW Father Goriot had unwound his coil of rope; he had covered the table with a blanket, and was now employed in rolling the flattened mass of silver into a bar, an operation which he performed with marvelous dexterity. END
BEGIN NOW Why, he must be as strong as Augustus, King of Poland! END
BEGIN NOW said Eugene to himself when the bar was nearly finished. END
BEGIN NOW Father Goriot looked sadly at his handiwork, tears fell from his eyes, he blew out the dip which had served him for a light while he manipulated the silver, and Eugene heard him sigh as he lay down again. END
BEGIN NOW He is mad, thought the student. END
BEGIN NOW _Poor child!_ Father Goriot said aloud. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac, hearing those words, concluded to keep silence; he would not hastily condemn his neighbor. END
BEGIN NOW He was just in the doorway of his room when a strange sound from the staircase below reached his ears; it might have been made by two men coming up in list slippers. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene listened; two men there certainly were, he could hear their breathing. END
BEGIN NOW Yet there had been no sound of opening the street door, no footsteps in the passage. END
BEGIN NOW Suddenly, too, he saw a faint gleam of light on the second story; it came from M. Vautrin's room. END
BEGIN NOW There are a good many mysteries here for a lodging-house! END
BEGIN NOW he said to himself. END
BEGIN NOW He went part of the way downstairs and listened again. END
BEGIN NOW The rattle of gold reached his ears. END
BEGIN NOW In another moment the light was put out, and again he distinctly heard the breathing of two men, but no sound of a door being opened or shut. END
BEGIN NOW The two men went downstairs, the faint sounds growing fainter as they went. END
BEGIN NOW Who is there? END
BEGIN NOW cried Vauquer out of her bedroom window. END
BEGIN NOW I, Vauquer, answered Vautrin's deep bass voice. END
BEGIN NOW I am coming in. END
BEGIN NOW That is odd! END
BEGIN NOW Christophe drew the bolts, said Eugene, going back to his room. END
BEGIN NOW You have to sit up at night, it seems, if you really mean to know all that is going on about you in Paris. END
BEGIN NOW These incidents turned his thought from his ambitious dreams; he betook himself to his work, but his thought wandered back to Father Goriot's suspicious occupation; de Restaud's face swam again and again before his eyes like a vision of a brilliant future; and at last he lay down and slept with clenched fists. END
BEGIN NOW When a young man makes up his mind that he will work all night, the chances are that seven times out of ten he will sleep till morning. END
BEGIN NOW Such vigils do not begin before we are turned twenty. END
BEGIN NOW The next morning Paris was wrapped in one of the dense fogs that throw the most punctual people out in their calculations as to the time; even the most business-like folk fail to keep their appointments in such weather, and ordinary mortals wake up at noon and fancy it is eight o'clock. END
BEGIN NOW On this morning it was half-past nine, and Vauquer still lay abed. END
BEGIN NOW Christophe was late, Sylvie was late, but the two sat comfortably taking their coffee as usual. END
BEGIN NOW It was Sylvie's custom to take the cream off the milk destined for the boarders' breakfast for her own, and to boil the remainder for some time, so that madame should not discover this illegal exaction. END
BEGIN NOW Sylvie, said Christophe, as he dipped a piece of toast into the coffee, M. Vautrin, who is not such a bad sort, all the same, had two people come to see him again last night. END
BEGIN NOW If madame says anything, mind you say nothing about it. END
BEGIN NOW Has he given you something? END
BEGIN NOW He gave me a five-franc piece this month, which is as good as saying, 'Hold your tongue.' END
BEGIN NOW Except him and Couture, who doesn't look twice at every penny, there's no one in the house that doesn't try to get back with the left hand all that they give with the right at New Year, said Sylvie. END
BEGIN NOW And, after all, said Christophe, what do they give you? END
BEGIN NOW A miserable five-franc piece. END
BEGIN NOW There is Father Goriot, who has cleaned his shoes himself these two years past. END
BEGIN NOW There is that old beggar Poiret, who goes without blacking altogether; he would sooner drink it than put it on his boots. END
BEGIN NOW Then there is that whipper-snapper of a student, who gives me a couple of francs. END
BEGIN NOW Two francs will not pay for my brushes, and he sells his old clothes, and gets more for them than they are worth. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW they're a shabby lot! END
BEGIN NOW Pooh! END
BEGIN NOW said Sylvie, sipping her coffee, our places are the best in the Quarter, that I know. END
BEGIN NOW But about that great big chap Vautrin, Christophe; has any one told you anything about him? END
BEGIN NOW Yes. END
BEGIN NOW I met a gentleman in the street a few days ago; he said to me, 'There's a gentleman in your place, isn't there? END
BEGIN NOW a tall man that dyes his whiskers?' END
BEGIN NOW I told him, 'No, sir; they aren't dyed. END
BEGIN NOW A gay fellow like him hasn't the time to do it.' END
BEGIN NOW And when I told M. Vautrin about it afterwards, he said, 'Quite right, my boy. END
BEGIN NOW That is the way to answer them. END
BEGIN NOW There is nothing more unpleasant than to have your little weaknesses known; it might spoil many a match.' END
BEGIN NOW Well, and for my part, said Sylvie, a man tried to humbug me at the market wanting to know if I had seen him put on his shirt. END
BEGIN NOW Such bosh! END
BEGIN NOW There, she cried, interrupting herself, that's a quarter to ten striking at the Val-de-Grace, and not a soul stirring! END
BEGIN NOW Pooh! END
BEGIN NOW they are all gone out. END
BEGIN NOW Couture and the girl went out at eight o'clock to take the wafer at Saint-Etienne. END
BEGIN NOW Father Goriot started off somewhere with a parcel, and the student won't be back from his lecture till ten o'clock. END
BEGIN NOW I saw them go while I was sweeping the stairs; Father Goriot knocked up against me, and his parcel was as hard as iron. END
BEGIN NOW What is the old fellow up to, I wonder? END
BEGIN NOW He is as good as a plaything for the rest of them; they can never let him alone; but he is a good man, all the same, and worth more than all of them put together. END
BEGIN NOW He doesn't give you much himself, but he sometimes sends you with a message to ladies who fork out famous tips; they are dressed grandly, too. END
BEGIN NOW His daughters, as he calls them, eh? END
BEGIN NOW There are a dozen of them. END
BEGIN NOW I have never been to more than two&mdash;the two who came here. END
BEGIN NOW There is madame moving overhead; I shall have to go, or she will raise a fine racket. END
BEGIN NOW Just keep an eye on the milk, Christophe; don't let the cat get at it. END
BEGIN NOW Sylvie went up to her mistress' room. END
BEGIN NOW Sylvie! END
BEGIN NOW How is this? END
BEGIN NOW It's nearly ten o'clock, and you let me sleep like a dormouse! END
BEGIN NOW Such a thing has never happened before. END
BEGIN NOW It's the fog; it is that thick, you could cut it with a knife. END
BEGIN NOW But how about breakfast? END
BEGIN NOW Bah! END
BEGIN NOW the boarders are possessed, I'm sure. END
BEGIN NOW They all cleared out before there was a wink of daylight. END
BEGIN NOW Do speak properly, Sylvie, Vauquer retorted; say a blink of daylight. END
BEGIN NOW Ah, well, madame, whichever you please. END
BEGIN NOW Anyhow, you can have breakfast at ten o'clock. END
BEGIN NOW La Michonnette and Poiret have neither of them stirred. END
BEGIN NOW There are only those two upstairs, and they are sleeping like the logs they are. END
BEGIN NOW But, Sylvie, you put their names together as if&mdash;- As if what? END
BEGIN NOW said Sylvie, bursting into a guffaw. END
BEGIN NOW The two of them make a pair. END
BEGIN NOW It is a strange thing, isn't it, Sylvie, how M. Vautrin got in last night after Christophe had bolted the door? END
BEGIN NOW Not at all, madame. END
BEGIN NOW Christophe heard M. Vautrin, and went down and undid the door. END
BEGIN NOW And here are you imagining that&mdash;-? END
BEGIN NOW Give me my bodice, and be quick and get breakfast ready. END
BEGIN NOW Dish up the rest of the mutton with the potatoes, and you can put the stewed pears on the table, those at five a penny. END
BEGIN NOW A few moments later Vauquer came down, just in time to see the cat knock down a plate that covered a bowl of milk, and begin to lap in all haste. END
BEGIN NOW Mistigris! END
BEGIN NOW she cried. END
BEGIN NOW The cat fled, but promptly returned to rub against her ankles. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW yes, you can wheedle, you old hypocrite! END
BEGIN NOW she said. END
BEGIN NOW Sylvie! END
BEGIN NOW Sylvie! END
BEGIN NOW Yes, madame; what is it? END
BEGIN NOW Just see what the cat has done! END
BEGIN NOW It is all that stupid Christophe's fault. END
BEGIN NOW I told him to stop and lay the table. END
BEGIN NOW What has become of him? END
BEGIN NOW Don't you worry, madame; Father Goriot shall have it. END
BEGIN NOW I will fill it up with water, and he won't know the difference; he never notices anything, not even what he eats. END
BEGIN NOW I wonder where the old heathen can have gone? END
BEGIN NOW said Vauquer, setting the plates round the table. END
BEGIN NOW Who knows? END
BEGIN NOW He is up to all sorts of tricks. END
BEGIN NOW I have overslept myself, said Vauquer. END
BEGIN NOW But madame looks as fresh as a rose, all the same. END
BEGIN NOW The door bell rang at that moment, and Vautrin came through the sitting-room, singing loudly: 'Tis the same old story everywhere, A roving heart and a roving glance. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW Mamma Vauquer! END
BEGIN NOW good-morning! END
BEGIN NOW he cried at the sight of his hostess, and he put his arm gaily round her waist. END
BEGIN NOW There! END
BEGIN NOW have done&mdash;- 'Impertinence!' END
BEGIN NOW Say it! END
BEGIN NOW he answered. END
BEGIN NOW Come, say it! END
BEGIN NOW Now, isn't that what you really mean? END
BEGIN NOW Stop a bit, I will help you to set the table. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW I am a nice man, am I not? END
BEGIN NOW For the locks of brown and the golden hair A sighing lover... Oh! END
BEGIN NOW I have just seen something so funny&mdash;-\.... led by chance. END
BEGIN NOW What? END
BEGIN NOW asked the widow. END
BEGIN NOW Father Goriot in the goldsmith's shop in the Rue Dauphine at half-past eight this morning. END
BEGIN NOW They buy old spoons and forks and gold lace there, and Goriot sold a piece of silver plate for a good round sum. END
BEGIN NOW It had been twisted out of shape very neatly for a man that's not used to the trade. END
BEGIN NOW Really? END
BEGIN NOW You don't say so? END
BEGIN NOW Yes. END
BEGIN NOW One of my friends is expatriating himself; I had been to see him off on board the Royal Mail steamer, and was coming back here. END
BEGIN NOW I waited after that to see what Father Goriot would do; it is a comical affair. END
BEGIN NOW He came back to this quarter of the world, to the Rue des Gres, and went into a money-lender's house; everybody knows him, Gobseck, a stuck-up rascal, that would make dominoes out of his father's bones, a Turk, a heathen, an old Jew, a Greek; it would be a difficult matter to rob _him_, for he puts all his coin into the Bank. END
BEGIN NOW Then what was Father Goriot doing there? END

BEGIN NOW said Vautrin. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing; he was bent on his own undoing. END

BEGIN NOW No. END

BEGIN NOW he cried. END
BEGIN NOW My word! END
BEGIN NOW 'tis a gallant old dotard. END

BEGIN NOW By this time the table was set. END
BEGIN NOW Sylvie was boiling the milk, Vauquer was lighting a fire in the stove with some assistance from Vautrin, who kept humming to himself: The same old story everywhere, A roving heart and a roving glance. END

BEGIN NOW What you want is a friend who will give the monster a piece of his mind; a barbarian that has three millions (so they say), and will not give you a dowry; and a pretty girl needs a dowry nowadays. END

BEGIN NOW Never mind, my pet, your wretch of a father is going just the way to bring trouble upon himself. END

BEGIN NOW said the Commissary-General's widow; if I could speak to him myself and give him his wife's last letter! END

BEGIN NOW exclaimed Vautrin, breaking in upon her. END
BEGIN NOW So that is how you are, is it? END
BEGIN NOW In a few days' time I will look into your affairs, and it will be all right, you shall see. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW sir, said Victorine, with a tearful but eager glance at Vautrin, who showed no sign of being touched by it, if you know of any way of communicating with my father, please be sure and tell him that his affection and my mother's honor are more to me than all the money in the world. END
BEGIN NOW If you can induce him to relent a little towards me, I will pray to God for you. END

BEGIN NOW Michonneau, and Poiret came downstairs together; possibly the scent of the gravy which Sylvie was making to serve with the mutton had announced breakfast. END
BEGIN NOW The seven people thus assembled bade each other good-morning, and took their places at the table; the clock struck ten, and the student's footstep was heard outside. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END

BEGIN NOW The student exchanged greetings with the lodgers, and sat down beside Goriot. END

BEGIN NOW queried Poiret. END

BEGIN NOW Vautrin asked of Poiret. END
BEGIN NOW M. Eugene is cut out for that kind of thing. END
BEGIN NOW Mlle. END

BEGIN NOW demanded M. Vautrin. END
BEGIN NOW Yesterday evening I went to a ball given by a cousin of mine, the Vicomtesse de Beauseant. END
BEGIN NOW She has a magnificent house; the rooms are hung with silk&mdash;in short, it was a splendid affair, and I was as happy as a king&mdash; Fisher, put in Vautrin, interrupting. END
BEGIN NOW What do you mean, sir? END
BEGIN NOW said Eugene sharply. END
BEGIN NOW I said 'fisher,' because kingfishers see a good deal more fun than kings. END
BEGIN NOW Quite true; I would much rather be the little careless bird than a king, said Poiret the ditto-ist, because&mdash;- In fact &mdash;the law-student cut him short&mdash; I danced with one of the handsomest women in the room, a charming countess, the most exquisite creature I have ever seen. END
BEGIN NOW There was peach blossom in her hair, and she had the loveliest bouquet of flowers&mdash;real flowers, that scented the air&mdash;-but there! END
BEGIN NOW it is no use trying to describe a woman glowing with the dance. END
BEGIN NOW You ought to have seen her! END
BEGIN NOW Well, and this morning I met this divine countess about nine o'clock, on foot in the Rue de Gres. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW how my heart beat! END

BEGIN NOW I expect that she was going to call on old Gobseck, a money-lender. END
BEGIN NOW If ever you explore a Parisian woman's heart, you will find the money-lender first, and the lover afterwards. END

BEGIN NOW Aha! END

BEGIN NOW answered Vautrin. END
BEGIN NOW Old Father Goriot there knew it quite well! END
BEGIN NOW and why should I not know it too? END
BEGIN NOW M. Goriot? END
BEGIN NOW the student cried. END
BEGIN NOW What is it? END
BEGIN NOW asked the old man. END
BEGIN NOW So she was very beautiful, was she, yesterday night? END
BEGIN NOW Who? END
BEGIN NOW de Restaud. END
BEGIN NOW Look at the old wretch, said Vauquer, speaking to Vautrin; how his eyes light up! END
BEGIN NOW Then does he really keep her? END
BEGIN NOW said Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau, in a whisper to the student. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END

BEGIN NOW If de Beauseant had not been there, my divine countess would have been the queen of the ball; none of the younger men had eyes for any one else. END
BEGIN NOW I was the twelfth on her list, and she danced every quadrille. END
BEGIN NOW The other women were furious. END
BEGIN NOW She must have enjoyed herself, if ever creature did! END
BEGIN NOW It is a true saying that there is no more beautiful sight than a frigate in full sail, a galloping horse, or a woman dancing. END
BEGIN NOW So the wheel turns, said Vautrin; yesterday night at a duchess' ball, this morning in a money-lender's office, on the lowest rung of the ladder&mdash;just like a Parisienne! END
BEGIN NOW If their husbands cannot afford to pay for their frantic extravagance, they will sell themselves. END
BEGIN NOW Or if they cannot do that, they will tear out their mothers' hearts to find something to pay for their splendor. END
BEGIN NOW They will turn the world upside down. END
BEGIN NOW Just a Parisienne through and through! END
BEGIN NOW Father Goriot's face, which had shone at the student's words like the sun on a bright day, clouded over all at once at this cruel speech of Vautrin's. END

BEGIN NOW Did you speak to her? END
BEGIN NOW Did you ask her if she wanted to study law? END
BEGIN NOW She did not see me, said Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW But only think of meeting one of the prettiest women in Paris in the Rue des Gres at nine o'clock! END
BEGIN NOW She could not have reached home after the ball till two o'clock this morning. END
BEGIN NOW Wasn't it queer? END
BEGIN NOW There is no place like Paris for this sort of adventures. END
BEGIN NOW Pshaw! END
BEGIN NOW much funnier things than _that_ happen here! END
BEGIN NOW exclaimed Vautrin. END
BEGIN NOW Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Taillefer had scarcely heeded the talk, she was so absorbed by the thought of the new attempt that she was about to make. END
BEGIN NOW Couture made a sign that it was time to go upstairs and dress; the two ladies went out, and Father Goriot followed their example. END
BEGIN NOW Well, did you see? END
BEGIN NOW said Vauquer, addressing Vautrin and the rest of the circle. END
BEGIN NOW He is ruining himself for those women, that is plain. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing will ever make me believe that that beautiful Comtesse de Restaud is anything to Father Goriot, cried the student. END
BEGIN NOW Well, and if you don't, broke in Vautrin, we are not set on convincing you. END
BEGIN NOW You are too young to know Paris thoroughly yet; later on you will find out that there are what we call men with a passion&mdash;- Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau gave Vautrin a quick glance at these words. END
BEGIN NOW They seemed to be like the sound of a trumpet to a trooper's horse. END
BEGIN NOW Aha! END
BEGIN NOW said Vautrin, stopping in his speech to give her a searching glance, so we have had our little experiences, have we? END
BEGIN NOW The old maid lowered her eyes like a nun who sees a statue. END
BEGIN NOW Well, he went on, when folk of that kind get a notion into their heads, they cannot drop it. END
BEGIN NOW They must drink the water from some particular spring&mdash;it is stagnant as often as not; but they will sell their wives and families, they will sell their own souls to the devil to get it. END
BEGIN NOW For some this spring is play, or the stock-exchange, or music, or a collection of pictures or insects; for others it is some woman who can give them the dainties they like. END
BEGIN NOW You might offer these last all the women on earth&mdash;they would turn up their noses; they will have the only one who can gratify their passion. END
BEGIN NOW It often happens that the woman does not care for them at all, and treats them cruelly; they buy their morsels of satisfaction very dear; but no matter, the fools are never tired of it; they will take their last blanket to the pawnbroker's to give their last five-franc piece to her. END
BEGIN NOW Father Goriot here is one of that sort. END
BEGIN NOW He is discreet, so the Countess exploits him&mdash;just the way of the gay world. END
BEGIN NOW The poor old fellow thinks of her and of nothing else. END
BEGIN NOW In all other respects you see he is a stupid animal; but get him on that subject, and his eyes sparkle like diamonds. END
BEGIN NOW That secret is not difficult to guess. END
BEGIN NOW He took some plate himself this morning to the melting-pot, and I saw him at Daddy Gobseck's in the Rue des Gres. END
BEGIN NOW And now, mark what follows&mdash;he came back here, and gave a letter for the Comtesse de Restaud to that noodle of a Christophe, who showed us the address; there was a receipted bill inside it. END
BEGIN NOW It is clear that it was an urgent matter if the Countess also went herself to the old money lender. END
BEGIN NOW Father Goriot has financed her handsomely. END
BEGIN NOW There is no need to tack a tale together; the thing is self-evident. END
BEGIN NOW So that shows you, sir student, that all the time your Countess was smiling, dancing, flirting, swaying her peach-flower crowned head, with her gown gathered into her hand, her slippers were pinching her, as they say; she was thinking of her protested bills, or her lover's protested bills. END
BEGIN NOW You have made me wild to know the truth, cried Eugene; I will go to call on de Restaud to-morrow. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, echoed Poiret; you must go and call on de Restaud. END
BEGIN NOW And perhaps you will find Father Goriot there, who will take payment for the assistance he politely rendered. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene looked disgusted. END
BEGIN NOW Why, then, this Paris of yours is a slough. END
BEGIN NOW And an uncommonly queer slough, too, replied Vautrin. END
BEGIN NOW The mud splashes you as you drive through it in your carriage&mdash;you are a respectable person; you go afoot and are splashed&mdash;you are a scoundrel. END
BEGIN NOW You are so unlucky as to walk off with something or other belonging to somebody else, and they exhibit you as a curiosity in the Place du Palais-de-Justice; you steal a million, and you are pointed out in every salon as a model of virtue. END
BEGIN NOW And you pay thirty millions for the police and the courts of justice, for the maintenance of law and order! END
BEGIN NOW A pretty slate of things it is! END
BEGIN NOW What, cried Vauquer, has Father Goriot really melted down his silver posset-dish? END
BEGIN NOW There were two turtle-doves on the lid, were there not? END
BEGIN NOW asked Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, that there were. END
BEGIN NOW Then, was he fond of it? END
BEGIN NOW said Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW He cried while he was breaking up the cup and plate. END
BEGIN NOW I happened to see him by accident. END
BEGIN NOW It was dear to him as his own life, answered the widow. END
BEGIN NOW There! END
BEGIN NOW you see how infatuated the old fellow is! END
BEGIN NOW cried Vautrin. END
BEGIN NOW The woman yonder can coax the soul out of him. END
BEGIN NOW The student went up to his room. END
BEGIN NOW Vautrin went out, and a few moments later Couture and Victorine drove away in a cab which Sylvie had called for them. END
BEGIN NOW Poiret gave his arm to Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau, and they went together to spend the two sunniest hours of the day in the Jardin des Plantes. END
BEGIN NOW Well, those two are as good as married, was the portly Sylvie's comment. END

BEGIN NOW Keep clear of Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau's shawl, then, said Vauquer, laughing; it would flare up like tinder. END
BEGIN NOW At four o'clock that evening, when Goriot came in, he saw, by the light of two smoky lamps, that Victorine's eyes were red. END
BEGIN NOW Vauquer was listening to the history of the visit made that morning to M. Taillefer; it had been made in vain. END
BEGIN NOW Taillefer was tired of the annual application made by his daughter and her elderly friend; he gave them a personal interview in order to arrive at an understanding with them. END
BEGIN NOW My dear lady, said Couture, addressing Vauquer, just imagine it; he did not even ask Victorine to sit down, she was standing the whole time. END
BEGIN NOW He said to me quite coolly, without putting himself in a passion, that we might spare ourselves the trouble of going there; that the young lady (he would not call her his daughter) was injuring her cause by importuning him (_importuning!_ once a year, the wretch! END
BEGIN NOW ); that as Victorine's mother had nothing when he married her, Victorine ought not to expect anything from him; in fact, he said the most cruel things, that made the poor child burst out crying. END
BEGIN NOW The little thing threw herself at her father's feet and spoke up bravely; she said that she only persevered in her visits for her mother's sake; that she would obey him without a murmur, but that she begged him to read her poor dead mother's farewell letter. END
BEGIN NOW She took it up and gave it to him, saying the most beautiful things in the world, most beautifully expressed; I do not know where she learned them; God must have put them into her head, for the poor child was inspired to speak so nicely that it made me cry like a fool to hear her talk. END
BEGIN NOW And what do you think the monster was doing all the time? END
BEGIN NOW Cutting his nails! END
BEGIN NOW He took the letter that poor Taillefer had soaked with tears, and flung it on to the chimney-piece. END
BEGIN NOW 'That is all right,' he said. END
BEGIN NOW He held out his hands to raise his daughter, but she covered them with kisses, and he drew them away again. END
BEGIN NOW Scandalous, isn't it? END
BEGIN NOW And his great booby of a son came in and took no notice of his sister. END
BEGIN NOW What inhuman wretches they must be! END
BEGIN NOW said Father Goriot. END
BEGIN NOW And then they both went out of the room, Couture went on, without heeding the worthy vermicelli maker's exclamation; father and son bowed to me, and asked me to excuse them on account of urgent business! END
BEGIN NOW That is the history of our call. END
BEGIN NOW Well, he has seen his daughter at any rate. END
BEGIN NOW How he can refuse to acknowledge her I cannot think, for they are as alike as two peas. END
BEGIN NOW The boarders dropped in one after another, interchanging greetings and empty jokes that certain classes of Parisians regard as humorous and witty. END
BEGIN NOW Dulness is their prevailing ingredient, and the whole point consists in mispronouncing a word or a gesture. END
BEGIN NOW This kind of argot is always changing. END
BEGIN NOW The essence of the jest consists in some catchword suggested by a political event, an incident in the police courts, a street song, or a bit of burlesque at some theatre, and forgotten in a month. END
BEGIN NOW Anything and everything serves to keep up a game of battledore and shuttlecock with words and ideas. END
BEGIN NOW The diorama, a recent invention, which carried an optical illusion a degree further than panoramas, had given rise to a mania among art students for ending every word with _rama_. END
BEGIN NOW The Maison Vauquer had caught the infection from a young artist among the boarders. END
BEGIN NOW Well, Monsieur-r-r Poiret, said the _employe_ from the Museum, how is your health-orama? END
BEGIN NOW Then, without waiting for an answer, he turned to Couture and Victorine with a Ladies, you seem melancholy. END
BEGIN NOW Is dinner ready? END
BEGIN NOW cried Horace Bianchon, a medical student, and a friend of Rastignac's; my stomach is sinking _usque ad talones_. END
BEGIN NOW There is an uncommon _frozerama_ outside, said Vautrin. END
BEGIN NOW Make room there, Father Goriot! END
BEGIN NOW Confound it, your foot covers the whole front of the stove. END
BEGIN NOW Illustrious M. Vautrin, put in Bianchon, why do you say _frozerama_? END
BEGIN NOW It is incorrect; it should be _frozenrama_. END
BEGIN NOW No, it shouldn't, said the official from the Museum; _frozerama_ is right by the same rule that you say 'My feet are _froze_.' END

BEGIN NOW ah! END

BEGIN NOW hallo! END
BEGIN NOW Mlle. END

BEGIN NOW Upon my word, that ghastly old maid looks just like one of the long worms that will gnaw a beam through, give them time enough. END

BEGIN NOW Milord Gaoriotte, they air talking about yoo-o-ou! END
BEGIN NOW Father Goriot, seated at the lower end of the table, close to the door through which the servant entered, raised his face; he had smelt at a scrap of bread that lay under his table napkin, an old trick acquired in his commercial capacity, that still showed itself at times. END

BEGIN NOW Nothing whatever, madame, he answered; on the contrary, it is made of the best quality of corn; flour from Etampes. END

BEGIN NOW asked Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW By the color, by the flavor. END

BEGIN NOW You have grown so economical, you will find out how to live on the smell of cooking at last. END
BEGIN NOW Take out a patent for it, then, cried the Museum official; you would make a handsome fortune. END
BEGIN NOW Never mind him, said the artist; he does that sort of thing to delude us into thinking that he was a vermicelli maker. END

BEGIN NOW inquired the official. END
BEGIN NOW Corn _what_? END
BEGIN NOW asked Bianchon. END
BEGIN NOW Corn-el. END
BEGIN NOW Corn-et. END
BEGIN NOW Corn-elian. END
BEGIN NOW Corn-ice. END
BEGIN NOW Corn-ucopia. END
BEGIN NOW Corn-crake. END

BEGIN NOW The eight responses came like a rolling fire from every part of the room, and the laughter that followed was the more uproarious because poor Father Goriot stared at the others with a puzzled look, like a foreigner trying to catch the meaning of words in a language which he does not understand. END
BEGIN NOW Corn?... END
BEGIN NOW he said, turning to Vautrin, his next neighbor. END

BEGIN NOW Mademoiselle might make application for aliment pending her suit; she is not eating anything. END

BEGIN NOW just see how Father Goriot is staring at Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Victorine. END
BEGIN NOW The old man had forgotten his dinner, he was so absorbed in gazing at the poor girl; the sorrow in her face was unmistakable,&mdash;the slighted love of a child whose father would not recognize her. END
BEGIN NOW We are mistaken about Father Goriot, my dear boy, said Eugene in a low voice. END
BEGIN NOW He is not an idiot, nor wanting in energy. END
BEGIN NOW Try your Gall system on him, and let me know what you think. END
BEGIN NOW I saw him crush a silver dish last night as if it had been made of wax; there seems to be something extraordinary going on in his mind just now, to judge by his face. END
BEGIN NOW His life is so mysterious that it must be worth studying. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW you may laugh, Bianchon; I am not joking. END
BEGIN NOW The man is a subject, is he? END
BEGIN NOW said Bianchon; all right! END
BEGIN NOW I will dissect him, if he will give me the chance. END
BEGIN NOW No; feel his bumps. END
BEGIN NOW Hm!&mdash;his stupidity might perhaps be contagious. END
BEGIN NOW The next day Rastignac dressed himself very elegantly, and about three o'clock in the afternoon went to call on de Restaud. END
BEGIN NOW On the way thither he indulged in the wild intoxicating dreams which fill a young head so full of delicious excitement. END
BEGIN NOW Young men at his age take no account of obstacles nor of dangers; they see success in every direction; imagination has free play, and turns their lives into a romance; they are saddened or discouraged by the collapse of one of the visionary schemes that have no existence save in their heated fancy. END
BEGIN NOW If youth were not ignorant and timid, civilization would be impossible. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene took unheard-of pains to keep himself in a spotless condition, but on his way through the streets he began to think about de Restaud and what he should say to her. END
BEGIN NOW He equipped himself with wit, rehearsed repartees in the course of an imaginary conversation, and prepared certain neat speeches a la Talleyrand, conjuring up a series of small events which should prepare the way for the declaration on which he had based his future; and during these musings the law student was bespattered with mud, and by the time he reached the Palais Royal he was obliged to have his boots blacked and his trousers brushed. END
BEGIN NOW If I were rich, he said, as he changed the five-franc piece he had brought with him in case anything might happen, I would take a cab, then I could think at my ease. END
BEGIN NOW At last he reached the Rue du Helder, and asked for the Comtesse de Restaud. END
BEGIN NOW He bore the contemptuous glances of the servants, who had seen him cross the court on foot, with the cold fury of a man who knows that he will succeed some day. END
BEGIN NOW He understood the meaning of their glances at once, for he had felt his inferiority as soon as he entered the court, where a smart cab was waiting. END
BEGIN NOW All the delights of life in Paris seemed to be implied by this visible and manifest sign of luxury and extravagance. END
BEGIN NOW A fine horse, in magnificent harness, was pawing the ground, and all at once the law student felt out of humor with himself. END
BEGIN NOW Every compartment in his brain which he had thought to find so full of wit was bolted fast; he grew positively stupid. END
BEGIN NOW He sent up his name to the Countess, and waited in the ante-chamber, standing on one foot before a window that looked out upon the court; mechanically he leaned his elbow against the sash, and stared before him. END
BEGIN NOW The time seemed long; he would have left the house but for the southern tenacity of purpose which works miracles when it is single-minded. END
BEGIN NOW Madame is in her boudoir, and cannot see any one at present, sir, said the servant. END
BEGIN NOW She gave me no answer; but if you will go into the dining-room, there is some one already there. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac was impressed with a sense of the formidable power of the lackey who can accuse or condemn his masters by a word; he coolly opened the door by which the man had just entered the ante-chamber, meaning, no doubt, to show these insolent flunkeys that he was familiar with the house; but he found that he had thoughtlessly precipitated himself into a small room full of dressers, where lamps were standing, and hot-water pipes, on which towels were being dried; a dark passage and a back staircase lay beyond it. END
BEGIN NOW Stifled laughter from the ante-chamber added to his confusion. END
BEGIN NOW This way to the drawing-room, sir, said the servant, with the exaggerated respect which seemed to be one more jest at his expense. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene turned so quickly that he stumbled against a bath. END
BEGIN NOW By good luck, he managed to keep his hat on his head, and saved it from immersion in the water; but just as he turned, a door opened at the further end of the dark passage, dimly lighted by a small lamp. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac heard voices and the sound of a kiss; one of the speakers was de Restaud, the other was Father Goriot. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene followed the servant through the dining-room into the drawing-room; he went to a window that looked out into the courtyard, and stood there for a while. END
BEGIN NOW He meant to know whether this Goriot was really the Goriot that he knew. END
BEGIN NOW His heart beat unwontedly fast; he remembered Vautrin's hideous insinuations. END
BEGIN NOW A well-dressed young man suddenly emerged from the room almost as Eugene entered it, saying impatiently to the servant who stood at the door: I am going, Maurice. END
BEGIN NOW Tell Madame la Comtesse that I waited more than half an hour for her. END
BEGIN NOW Whereupon this insolent being, who, doubtless, had a right to be insolent, sang an Italian trill, and went towards the window where Eugene was standing, moved thereto quite as much by a desire to see the student's face as by a wish to look out into the courtyard. END
BEGIN NOW But M. le Comte had better wait a moment longer; madame is disengaged, said Maurice, as he returned to the ante-chamber. END
BEGIN NOW Just at that moment Father Goriot appeared close to the gate; he had emerged from a door at the foot of the back staircase. END
BEGIN NOW The worthy soul was preparing to open his umbrella regardless of the fact that the great gate had opened to admit a tilbury, in which a young man with a ribbon at his button-hole was seated. END
BEGIN NOW Father Goriot had scarcely time to start back and save himself. END
BEGIN NOW The horse took fright at the umbrella, swerved, and dashed forward towards the flight of steps. END
BEGIN NOW The young man looked round in annoyance, saw Father Goriot, and greeted him as he went out with constrained courtesy, such as people usually show to a money-lender so long as they require his services, or the sort of respect they feel it necessary to show for some one whose reputation has been blown upon, so that they blush to acknowledge his acquaintance. END
BEGIN NOW Father Goriot gave him a little friendly nod and a good-natured smile. END
BEGIN NOW All this happened with lightning speed. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene was so deeply interested that he forgot that he was not alone till he suddenly heard the Countess' voice. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW Maxime, were you going away? END
BEGIN NOW she said reproachfully, with a shade of pique in her manner. END
BEGIN NOW The Countess had not seen the incident nor the entrance of the tilbury. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac turned abruptly and saw her standing before him, coquettishly dressed in a loose white cashmere gown with knots of rose-colored ribbon here and there; her hair was carelessly coiled about her head, as is the wont of Parisian women in the morning; there was a soft fragrance about her&mdash;doubtless she was fresh from a bath;&mdash;her graceful form seemed more flexible, her beauty more luxuriant. END
BEGIN NOW Her eyes glistened. END
BEGIN NOW A young man can see everything at a glance; he feels the radiant influence of woman as a plant discerns and absorbs its nutriment from the air; he did not need to touch her hands to feel their cool freshness. END
BEGIN NOW He saw faint rose tints through the cashmere of the dressing gown; it had fallen slightly open, giving glimpses of a bare throat, on which the student's eyes rested. END
BEGIN NOW The Countess had no need of the adventitious aid of corsets; her girdle defined the outlines of her slender waist; her throat was a challenge to love; her feet, thrust into slippers, were daintily small. END
BEGIN NOW As Maxime took her hand and kissed it, Eugene became aware of Maxime's existence, and the Countess saw Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW is that you M. de Rastignac? END
BEGIN NOW I am very glad to see you, she said, but there was something in her manner that a shrewd observer would have taken as a hint to depart. END
BEGIN NOW Maxime, as the Countess Anastasie had called the young man with the haughty insolence of bearing, looked from Eugene to the lady, and from the lady to Eugene; it was sufficiently evident that he wished to be rid of the latter. END
BEGIN NOW An exact and faithful rendering of the glance might be given in the words: Look here, my dear; I hope you intend to send this little whipper-snapper about his business. END
BEGIN NOW The Countess consulted the young man's face with an intent submissiveness that betrays all the secrets of a woman's heart, and Rastignac all at once began to hate him violently. END
BEGIN NOW To begin with, the sight of the fair carefully arranged curls on the other's comely head had convinced him that his own crop was hideous; Maxime's boots, moreover, were elegant and spotless, while his own, in spite of all his care, bore some traces of his recent walk; and, finally, Maxime's overcoat fitted the outline of his figure gracefully, he looked like a pretty woman, while Eugene was wearing a black coat at half-past two. END
BEGIN NOW The quick-witted child of the Charente felt the disadvantage at which he was placed beside this tall, slender dandy, with the clear gaze and the pale face, one of those men who would ruin orphan children without scruple. END
BEGIN NOW de Restaud fled into the next room without waiting for Eugene to speak; shaking out the skirts of her dressing-gown in her flight, so that she looked like a white butterfly, and Maxime hurried after her. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene, in a fury, followed Maxime and the Countess, and the three stood once more face to face by the hearth in the large drawing-room. END
BEGIN NOW The law student felt quite sure that the odious Maxime found him in the way, and even at the risk of displeasing de Restaud, he meant to annoy the dandy. END
BEGIN NOW It had struck him all at once that he had seen the young man before at de Beauseant's ball; he guessed the relation between Maxime and de Restaud; and with the youthful audacity that commits prodigious blunders or achieves signal success, he said to himself, This is my rival; I mean to cut him out. END
BEGIN NOW Rash resolve! END
BEGIN NOW He did not know that M. le Comte Maxime de Trailles would wait till he was insulted, so as to fire first and kill his man. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene was a sportsman and a good shot, but he had not yet hit the bulls's eye twenty times out of twenty-two. END
BEGIN NOW The young Count dropped into a low chair by the hearth, took up the tongs, and made up the fire so violently and so sulkily, that Anastasie's fair face suddenly clouded over. END
BEGIN NOW She turned to Eugene, with a cool, questioning glance that asked plainly, Why do you not go? END
BEGIN NOW a glance which well-bred people regard as a cue to make their exit. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene assumed an amiable expression. END
BEGIN NOW Madame, he began, I hastened to call upon you&mdash;- He stopped short. END
BEGIN NOW The door opened, and the owner of the tilbury suddenly appeared. END
BEGIN NOW He had left his hat outside, and did not greet the Countess; he looked meditatively at Rastignac, and held out his hand to Maxime with a cordial Good morning, that astonished Eugene not a little. END
BEGIN NOW The young provincial did not understand the amenities of a triple alliance. END
BEGIN NOW M. de Restaud, said the Countess, introducing her husband to the law student. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene bowed profoundly. END
BEGIN NOW This gentleman, she continued, presenting Eugene to her husband, is M. de Rastignac; he is related to la Vicomtesse de Beauseant through the Marcillacs; I had the pleasure of meeting him at her last ball. END
BEGIN NOW _Related to la Vicomtesse de Beauseant through the Marcillacs!_ These words, on which the countess threw ever so slight an emphasis, by reason of the pride that the mistress of a house takes in showing that she only receives people of distinction as visitors in her house, produced a magical effect. END
BEGIN NOW The Count's stiff manner relaxed at once as he returned the student's bow. END
BEGIN NOW Delighted to have an opportunity of making your acquaintance, he said. END
BEGIN NOW Maxime de Trailles himself gave Eugene an uneasy glance, and suddenly dropped his insolent manner. END
BEGIN NOW The mighty name had all the power of a fairy's wand; those closed compartments in the southern brain flew open again; Rastignac's carefully drilled faculties returned. END
BEGIN NOW It was as if a sudden light had pierced the obscurity of this upper world of Paris, and he began to see, though everything was indistinct as yet. END
BEGIN NOW Vauquer's lodging-house and Father Goriot were very far remote from his thoughts. END
BEGIN NOW I thought that the Marcillacs were extinct, the Comte de Restaud said, addressing Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, they are extinct, answered the law student. END
BEGIN NOW My great-uncle, the Chevalier de Rastignac, married the heiress of the Marcillac family. END
BEGIN NOW They had only one daughter, who married the Marechal de Clarimbault, de Beauseant's grandfather on the mother's side. END
BEGIN NOW We are the younger branch of the family, and the younger branch is all the poorer because my great-uncle, the Vice-Admiral, lost all that he had in the King's service. END
BEGIN NOW The Government during the Revolution refused to admit our claims when the Compagnie des Indes was liquidated. END
BEGIN NOW Was not your great-uncle in command of the _Vengeur_ before ? END
BEGIN NOW Yes. END
BEGIN NOW Then he would be acquainted with my grandfather, who commanded the _Warwick_. END
BEGIN NOW Maxime looked at de Restaud and shrugged his shoulders, as who should say, If he is going to discuss nautical matters with that fellow, it is all over with us. END
BEGIN NOW Anastasie understood the glance that M. de Trailles gave her. END
BEGIN NOW With a woman's admirable tact, she began to smile and said: Come with me, Maxime; I have something to say to you. END
BEGIN NOW We will leave you two gentlemen to sail in company on board the _Warwick_ and the _Vengeur_. END
BEGIN NOW She rose to her feet and signed to Maxime to follow her, mirth and mischief in her whole attitude, and the two went in the direction of the boudoir. END
BEGIN NOW The _morganatic_ couple (to use a convenient German expression which has no exact equivalent) had reached the door, when the Count interrupted himself in his talk with Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW Anastasie! END
BEGIN NOW he cried pettishly, just stay a moment, dear; you know very well that&mdash;- I am coming back in a minute, she interrupted; I have a commission for Maxime to execute, and I want to tell him about it. END
BEGIN NOW She came back almost immediately. END
BEGIN NOW She had noticed the inflection in her husband's voice, and knew that it would not be safe to retire to the boudoir; like all women who are compelled to study their husbands' characters in order to have their own way, and whose business it is to know exactly how far they can go without endangering a good understanding, she was very careful to avoid petty collisions in domestic life. END
BEGIN NOW It was Eugene who had brought about this untoward incident; so the Countess looked at Maxime and indicated the law student with an air of exasperation. END
BEGIN NOW M. de Trailles addressed the Count, the Countess, and Eugene with the pointed remark, You are busy, I do not want to interrupt you; good-day, and he went. END
BEGIN NOW Just wait a moment, Maxime! END
BEGIN NOW the Count called after him. END
BEGIN NOW Come and dine with us, said the Countess, leaving Eugene and her husband together once more. END
BEGIN NOW She followed Maxime into the little drawing-room, where they sat together sufficiently long to feel sure that Rastignac had taken his leave. END
BEGIN NOW The law student heard their laughter, and their voices, and the pauses in their talk; he grew malicious, exerted his conversational powers for M. de Restaud, flattered him, and drew him into discussions, to the end that he might see the Countess again and discover the nature of her relations with Father Goriot. END
BEGIN NOW This Countess with a husband and a lover, for Maxime clearly was her lover, was a mystery. END
BEGIN NOW What was the secret tie that bound her to the old tradesman? END
BEGIN NOW This mystery he meant to penetrate, hoping by its means to gain a sovereign ascendency over this fair typical Parisian. END
BEGIN NOW Anastasie! END
BEGIN NOW the Count called again to his wife. END
BEGIN NOW Poor Maxime! END
BEGIN NOW she said, addressing the young man. END
BEGIN NOW Come, we must resign ourselves. END
BEGIN NOW This evening&mdash;- I hope, Nasie, he said in her ear, that you will give orders not to admit that youngster, whose eyes light up like live coals when he looks at you. END
BEGIN NOW He will make you a declaration, and compromise you, and then you will compel me to kill him. END
BEGIN NOW Are you mad, Maxime? END
BEGIN NOW she said. END
BEGIN NOW A young lad of a student is, on the contrary, a capital lightning-conductor; is not that so? END
BEGIN NOW Of course, I mean to make Restaud furiously jealous of him. END
BEGIN NOW Maxime burst out laughing, and went out, followed by the Countess, who stood at the window to watch him into his carriage; he shook his whip, and made his horse prance. END
BEGIN NOW She only returned when the great gate had been closed after him. END
BEGIN NOW What do you think, dear? END
BEGIN NOW cried the Count, her husband, this gentleman's family estate is not far from Verteuil, on the Charente; his great-uncle and my grandfather were acquainted. END
BEGIN NOW Delighted to find that we have acquaintances in common, said the Countess, with a preoccupied manner. END
BEGIN NOW More than you think, said Eugene, in a low voice. END
BEGIN NOW What do you mean? END
BEGIN NOW she asked quickly. END
BEGIN NOW Why, only just now, said the student, I saw a gentleman go out at the gate, Father Goriot, my next door neighbor in the house where I am lodging. END
BEGIN NOW At the sound of this name, and the prefix that embellished it, the Count, who was stirring the fire, let the tongs fall as though they had burned his fingers, and rose to his feet. END
BEGIN NOW Sir, he cried, you might have called him 'Monsieur Goriot'! END
BEGIN NOW The Countess turned pale at first at the sight of her husband's vexation, then she reddened; clearly she was embarrassed, her answer was made in a tone that she tried to make natural, and with an air of assumed carelessness: You could not know any one who is dearer to us both... She broke off, glanced at the piano as if some fancy had crossed her mind, and asked, Are you fond of music, M. de Rastignac? END
BEGIN NOW Exceedingly, answered Eugene, flushing, and disconcerted by a dim suspicion that he had somehow been guilty of a clumsy piece of folly. END
BEGIN NOW Do you sing? END
BEGIN NOW she cried, going to the piano, and, sitting down before it, she swept her fingers over the keyboard from end to end. END
BEGIN NOW R-r-r-rah! END
BEGIN NOW No, madame. END
BEGIN NOW The Comte de Restaud walked to and fro. END
BEGIN NOW That is a pity; you are without one great means of success.&mdash;_Ca-ro, ca-a-ro, ca-a-a-ro, non du-bi-ta-re_, sang the Countess. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene had a second time waved a magic wand when he uttered Goriot's name, but the effect seemed to be entirely opposite to that produced by the formula related to de Beauseant. END
BEGIN NOW His position was not unlike that of some visitor permitted as a favor to inspect a private collection of curiosities, when by inadvertence he comes into collision with a glass case full of sculptured figures, and three or four heads, imperfectly secured, fall at the shock. END
BEGIN NOW He wished the earth would open and swallow him. END
BEGIN NOW de Restaud's expression was reserved and chilly, her eyes had grown indifferent, and sedulously avoided meeting those of the unlucky student of law. END
BEGIN NOW Madame, he said, you wish to talk with M. de Restaud; permit me to wish you good-day&mdash;- The Countess interrupted him by a gesture, saying hastily, Whenever you come to see us, both M. de Restaud and I shall be delighted to see you. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene made a profound bow and took his leave, followed by M. de Restaud, who insisted, in spite of his remonstrances, on accompanying him into the hall. END
BEGIN NOW Neither your mistress nor I are at home to that gentleman when he calls, the Count said to Maurice. END
BEGIN NOW As Eugene set foot on the steps, he saw that it was raining. END
BEGIN NOW Come, said he to himself, somehow I have just made a mess of it, I do not know how. END
BEGIN NOW And now I am going to spoil my hat and coat into the bargain. END
BEGIN NOW I ought to stop in my corner, grind away at law, and never look to be anything but a boorish country magistrate. END
BEGIN NOW How can I go into society, when to manage properly you want a lot of cabs, varnished boots, gold watch chains, and all sorts of things; you have to wear white doeskin gloves that cost six francs in the morning, and primrose kid gloves every evening? END
BEGIN NOW A fig for that old humbug of a Goriot! END
BEGIN NOW When he reached the street door, the driver of a hackney coach, who had probably just deposited a wedding party at their door, and asked nothing better than a chance of making a little money for himself without his employer's knowledge, saw that Eugene had no umbrella, remarked his black coat, white waistcoat, yellow gloves, and varnished boots, and stopped and looked at him inquiringly. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene, in the blind desperation that drives a young man to plunge deeper and deeper into an abyss, as if he might hope to find a fortunate issue in its lowest depths, nodded in reply to the driver's signal, and stepped into the cab; a few stray petals of orange blossom and scraps of wire bore witness to its recent occupation by a wedding party. END
BEGIN NOW Where am I to drive, sir? END
BEGIN NOW demanded the man, who, by this time, had taken off his white gloves. END
BEGIN NOW Confound it! END
BEGIN NOW Eugene said to himself, I am in for it now, and at least I will not spend cab-hire for nothing!&mdash;Drive to the Hotel Beauseant, he said aloud. END
BEGIN NOW Which? END
BEGIN NOW asked the man, a portentous word that reduced Eugene to confusion. END
BEGIN NOW This young man of fashion, species incerta, did not know that there were two Hotels Beauseant; he was not aware how rich he was in relations who did not care about him. END
BEGIN NOW The Vicomte de Beauseant, Rue&mdash;- De Grenelle, interrupted the driver, with a jerk of his head. END
BEGIN NOW You see, there are the hotels of the Marquis and Comte de Beauseant in the Rue Saint-Dominique, he added, drawing up the step. END
BEGIN NOW I know all about that, said Eugene, severely.&mdash; Everybody is laughing at me to-day, it seems! END
BEGIN NOW he said to himself, as he deposited his hat on the opposite seat. END
BEGIN NOW This escapade will cost me a king's ransom, but, at any rate, I shall call on my so-called cousin in a thoroughly aristocratic fashion. END
BEGIN NOW Goriot has cost me ten francs already, the old scoundrel. END
BEGIN NOW My word! END
BEGIN NOW I will tell de Beauseant about my adventure; perhaps it may amuse her. END
BEGIN NOW Doubtless she will know the secret of the criminal relation between that handsome woman and the old rat without a tail. END
BEGIN NOW It would be better to find favor in my cousin's eyes than to come in contact with that shameless woman, who seems to me to have very expensive tastes. END
BEGIN NOW Surely the beautiful Vicomtesse's personal interest would turn the scale for me, when the mere mention of her name produces such an effect. END
BEGIN NOW Let us look higher. END
BEGIN NOW If you set yourself to carry the heights of heaven, you must face God. END
BEGIN NOW The innumerable thoughts that surged through his brain might be summed up in these phrases. END
BEGIN NOW He grew calmer, and recovered something of his assurance as he watched the falling rain. END
BEGIN NOW He told himself that though he was about to squander two of the precious five-franc pieces that remained to him, the money was well laid out in preserving his coat, boots, and hat; and his cabman's cry of Gate, if you please, almost put him in spirits. END
BEGIN NOW A Swiss, in scarlet and gold, appeared, the great door groaned on its hinges, and Rastignac, with sweet satisfaction, beheld his equipage pass under the archway and stop before the flight of steps beneath the awning. END
BEGIN NOW The driver, in a blue-and-red greatcoat, dismounted and let down the step. END
BEGIN NOW As Eugene stepped out of the cab, he heard smothered laughter from the peristyle. END
BEGIN NOW Three or four lackeys were making merry over the festal appearance of the vehicle. END
BEGIN NOW In another moment the law student was enlightened as to the cause of their hilarity; he felt the full force of the contrast between his equipage and one of the smartest broughams in Paris; a coachman, with powdered hair, seemed to find it difficult to hold a pair of spirited horses, who stood chafing the bit. END
BEGIN NOW In de Restaud's courtyard, in the Chaussee d'Antin, he had seen the neat turnout of a young man of six-and-twenty; in the Faubourg Saint-Germain he found the luxurious equipage of a man of rank; thirty thousand francs would not have purchased it. END
BEGIN NOW Who can be here? END
BEGIN NOW said Eugene to himself. END
BEGIN NOW He began to understand, though somewhat tardily, that he must not expect to find many women in Paris who were not already appropriated, and that the capture of one of these queens would be likely to cost something more than bloodshed. END
BEGIN NOW Confound it all! END
BEGIN NOW I expect my cousin also has her Maxime. END
BEGIN NOW He went up the steps, feeling that he was a blighted being. END
BEGIN NOW The glass door was opened for him; the servants were as solemn as jackasses under the curry comb. END
BEGIN NOW So far, Eugene had only been in the ballroom on the ground floor of the Hotel Beauseant; the fete had followed so closely on the invitation, that he had not had time to call on his cousin, and had therefore never seen de Beauseant's apartments; he was about to behold for the first time a great lady among the wonderful and elegant surroundings that reveal her character and reflect her daily life. END
BEGIN NOW He was the more curious, because de Restaud's drawing-room had provided him with a standard of comparison. END
BEGIN NOW At half-past four the Vicomtesse de Beauseant was visible. END
BEGIN NOW Five minutes earlier she would not have received her cousin, but Eugene knew nothing of the recognized routine of various houses in Paris. END
BEGIN NOW He was conducted up the wide, white-painted, crimson-carpeted staircase, between the gilded balusters and masses of flowering plants, to de Beauseant's apartments. END
BEGIN NOW He did not know the rumor current about de Beauseant, one of the biographies told, with variations, in whispers, every evening in the salons of Paris. END
BEGIN NOW For three years past her name had been spoken of in connection with that of one of the most wealthy and distinguished Portuguese nobles, the Marquis d'Ajuda-Pinto. END
BEGIN NOW It was one of those innocent _liaisons_ which possess so much charm for the two thus attached to each other that they find the presence of a third person intolerable. END
BEGIN NOW The Vicomte de Beauseant, therefore, had himself set an example to the rest of the world by respecting, with as good a grace as might be, this morganatic union. END
BEGIN NOW Any one who came to call on the Vicomtesse in the early days of this friendship was sure to find the Marquis d'Ajuda-Pinto there. END
BEGIN NOW As, under the circumstances, de Beauseant could not very well shut her door against these visitors, she gave them such a cold reception, and showed so much interest in the study of the ceiling, that no one could fail to understand how much he bored her; and when it became known in Paris that de Beauseant was bored by callers between two and four o'clock, she was left in perfect solitude during that interval. END
BEGIN NOW She went to the Bouffons or to the Opera with M. de Beauseant and M. d'Ajuda-Pinto; and M. de Beauseant, like a well-bred man of the world, always left his wife and the Portuguese as soon as he had installed them. END
BEGIN NOW But M. d'Ajuda-Pinto must marry, and a Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW de Rochefide was the young lady. END
BEGIN NOW In the whole fashionable world there was but one person who as yet knew nothing of the arrangement, and that was de Beauseant. END
BEGIN NOW Some of her friends had hinted at the possibility, and she had laughed at them, believing that envy had prompted those ladies to try to make mischief. END
BEGIN NOW And now, though the bans were about to be published, and although the handsome Portuguese had come that day to break the news to the Vicomtesse, he had not found courage as yet to say one word about his treachery. END
BEGIN NOW How was it? END
BEGIN NOW Nothing is doubtless more difficult than the notification of an ultimatum of this kind. END
BEGIN NOW There are men who feel more at their ease when they stand up before another man who threatens their lives with sword or pistol than in the presence of a woman who, after two hours of lamentations and reproaches, falls into a dead swoon and requires salts. END
BEGIN NOW At this moment, therefore, M. d'Ajuda-Pinto was on thorns, and anxious to take his leave. END
BEGIN NOW He told himself that in some way or other the news would reach de Beauseant; he would write, it would be much better to do it by letter, and not to utter the words that should stab her to the heart. END
BEGIN NOW So when the servant announced M. Eugene de Rastignac, the Marquis d'Ajuda-Pinto trembled with joy. END
BEGIN NOW To be sure, a loving woman shows even more ingenuity in inventing doubts of her lover than in varying the monotony of his happiness; and when she is about to be forsaken, she instinctively interprets every gesture as rapidly as Virgil's courser detected the presence of his companion by snuffing the breeze. END
BEGIN NOW It was impossible, therefore, that de Beauseant should not detect that involuntary thrill of satisfaction; slight though it was, it was appalling in its artlessness. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene had yet to learn that no one in Paris should present himself in any house without first making himself acquainted with the whole history of its owner, and of its owner's wife and family, so that he may avoid making any of the terrible blunders which in Poland draw forth the picturesque exclamation, Harness five bullocks to your cart! END
BEGIN NOW probably because you will need them all to pull you out of the quagmire into which a false step has plunged you. END
BEGIN NOW If, down to the present day, our language has no name for these conversational disasters, it is probably because they are believed to be impossible, the publicity given in Paris to every scandal is so prodigious. END
BEGIN NOW After the awkward incident at de Restaud's, no one but Eugene could have reappeared in his character of bullock-driver in de Beauseant's drawing-room. END
BEGIN NOW But if de Restaud and M. de Trailles had found him horribly in the way, M. d'Ajuda hailed his coming with relief. END
BEGIN NOW Good-bye, said the Portuguese, hurrying to the door, as Eugene made his entrance into a dainty little pink-and-gray drawing-room, where luxury seemed nothing more than good taste. END
BEGIN NOW Until this evening, said de Beauseant, turning her head to give the Marquis a glance. END
BEGIN NOW We are going to the Bouffons, are we not? END
BEGIN NOW I cannot go, he said, with his fingers on the door handle. END
BEGIN NOW de Beauseant rose and beckoned to him to return. END
BEGIN NOW She did not pay the slightest attention to Eugene, who stood there dazzled by the sparkling marvels around him; he began to think that this was some story out of the Arabian Nights made real, and did not know where to hide himself, when the woman before him seemed to be unconscious of his existence. END
BEGIN NOW The Vicomtesse had raised the forefinger of her right hand, and gracefully signed to the Marquis to seat himself beside her. END
BEGIN NOW The Marquis felt the imperious sway of passion in her gesture; he came back towards her. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene watched him, not without a feeling of envy. END
BEGIN NOW That is the owner of the brougham! END
BEGIN NOW he said to himself. END
BEGIN NOW But is it necessary to have a pair of spirited horses, servants in livery, and torrents of gold to draw a glance from a woman here in Paris? END
BEGIN NOW The demon of luxury gnawed at his heart, greed burned in his veins, his throat was parched with the thirst of gold. END
BEGIN NOW He had a hundred and thirty francs every quarter. END
BEGIN NOW His father, mother, brothers, sisters, and aunt did not spend two hundred francs a month among them. END
BEGIN NOW This swift comparison between his present condition and the aims he had in view helped to benumb his faculties. END
BEGIN NOW Why not? END
BEGIN NOW the Vicomtesse was saying, as she smiled at the Portuguese. END
BEGIN NOW Why cannot you come to the Italiens? END
BEGIN NOW Affairs! END
BEGIN NOW I am to dine with the English Ambassador. END
BEGIN NOW Throw him over. END
BEGIN NOW When a man once enters on a course of deception, he is compelled to add lie to lie. END
BEGIN NOW M. d'Ajuda therefore said, smiling, Do you lay your commands on me? END
BEGIN NOW Yes, certainly. END
BEGIN NOW That was what I wanted to have you say to me, he answered, dissembling his feelings in a glance which would have reassured any other woman. END
BEGIN NOW He took the Vicomtesse's hand, kissed it, and went. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene ran his fingers through his hair, and constrained himself to bow. END
BEGIN NOW He thought that now de Beauseant would give him her attention; but suddenly she sprang forward, rushed to a window in the gallery, and watched M. d'Ajuda step into his carriage; she listened to the order that he gave, and heard the Swiss repeat it to the coachman: To M. de Rochefide's house. END
BEGIN NOW Those words, and the way in which M. d'Ajuda flung himself back in the carriage, were like a lightning flash and a thunderbolt for her; she walked back again with a deadly fear gnawing at her heart. END
BEGIN NOW The most terrible catastrophes only happen among the heights. END
BEGIN NOW The Vicomtesse went to her own room, sat down at a table, and took up a sheet of dainty notepaper. END
BEGIN NOW When, instead of dining with the English Ambassador, she wrote, you go to the Rochefides, you owe me an explanation, which I am waiting to hear. END
BEGIN NOW She retraced several of the letters, for her hand was trembling so that they were indistinct; then she signed the note with an initial C for Claire de Bourgogne, and rang the bell. END
BEGIN NOW Jacques, she said to the servant, who appeared immediately, take this note to M. de Rochefide's house at half-past seven and ask for the Marquis d'Ajuda. END
BEGIN NOW If M. d'Ajuda is there, leave the note without waiting for an answer; if he is not there, bring the note back to me. END
BEGIN NOW Madame la Vicomtess, there is a visitor in the drawing-room. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW yes, of course, she said, opening the door. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene was beginning to feel very uncomfortable, but at last the Vicomtesse appeared; she spoke to him, and the tremulous tones of her voice vibrated through his heart. END
BEGIN NOW Pardon me, monsieur, she said; I had a letter to write. END
BEGIN NOW Now I am quite at liberty. END
BEGIN NOW She scarcely knew what she was saying, for even as she spoke she thought, Ah! END
BEGIN NOW he means to marry Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW de Rochefide? END
BEGIN NOW But is he still free? END
BEGIN NOW This evening the marriage shall be broken off, or else... END
BEGIN NOW But before to-morrow I shall know. END
BEGIN NOW Cousin... the student replied. END
BEGIN NOW Eh? END
BEGIN NOW said the Countess, with an insolent glance that sent a cold shudder through Eugene; he understood what that Eh? END
BEGIN NOW meant; he had learned a great deal in three hours, and his wits were on the alert. END
BEGIN NOW He reddened: Madame... he began; he hesitated a moment, and then went on. END
BEGIN NOW Pardon me; I am in such need of protection that the nearest scrap of relationship could do me no harm. END
BEGIN NOW de Beauseant smiled but there was sadness in her smile; even now she felt forebodings of the coming pain, the air she breathed was heavy with the storm that was about to burst. END
BEGIN NOW If you knew how my family are situated, he went on, you would love to play the part of a beneficent fairy godmother who graciously clears the obstacles from the path of her protege. END

BEGIN NOW Two, said Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW You, child. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, you are a child, she said, keeping back the tears that came to her eyes; you would love sincerely. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW he cried, flinging up his head. END
BEGIN NOW The audacity of the student's answer interested the Vicomtesse in him. END
BEGIN NOW The southern brain was beginning to scheme for the first time. END
BEGIN NOW Between de Restaud's blue boudoir and de Beauseant's rose-colored drawing-room he had made a three years' advance in a kind of law which is not a recognized study in Paris, although it is a sort of higher jurisprudence, and, when well understood, is a highroad to success of every kind. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW that is what I meant to say! END

BEGIN NOW Henceforward I shall have two protectresses; those two women are great friends, no doubt, and this newcomer will doubtless interest herself in her friend's cousin. END

BEGIN NOW This thrust was too cruel; the Vicomtesse's face grew white, but she answered, laughing, One of those rumors that fools amuse themselves with. END

BEGIN NOW The Rochefides were only ennobled yesterday. END

BEGIN NOW M. d'Ajuda is too wealthy to marry for money. END

BEGIN NOW de Rochefide is a charming girl. END
BEGIN NOW Indeed? END
BEGIN NOW And, as a matter of fact, he is dining with them to-day; the thing is settled. END

BEGIN NOW de Beauseant turned to Rastignac. END
BEGIN NOW What was the blunder that you made, monsieur? END
BEGIN NOW she asked. END
BEGIN NOW The poor boy is only just launched into the world, Antoinette, so that he understands nothing of all this that we are speaking of. END

BEGIN NOW Everything will be announced to-morrow, you know, and your kind informal communication can be accompanied by official confirmation. END
BEGIN NOW The Duchess gave Eugene one of those insolent glances that measure a man from head to foot, and leave him crushed and annihilated. END
BEGIN NOW Madame, I have unwittingly plunged a dagger into de Restaud's heart; unwittingly&mdash;therein lies my offence, said the student of law, whose keen brain had served him sufficiently well, for he had detected the biting epigrams that lurked beneath this friendly talk. END
BEGIN NOW You continue to receive, possibly you fear, those who know the amount of pain that they deliberately inflict; but a clumsy blunderer who has no idea how deeply he wounds is looked upon as a fool who does not know how to make use of his opportunities, and every one despises him. END
BEGIN NOW de Beauseant gave the student a glance, one of those glances in which a great soul can mingle dignity and gratitude. END

BEGIN NOW Imagine, too, that I had just made some progress with the Comte de Restaud; for I should tell you, madame, he went on, turning to the Duchess with a mixture of humility and malice in his manner, that as yet I am only a poor devil of a student, very much alone in the world, and very poor&mdash;- You should not tell us that, M. de Rastignac. END
BEGIN NOW We women never care about anything that no one else will take. END
BEGIN NOW Bah! END
BEGIN NOW said Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW I am only two-and-twenty, and I must make up my mind to the drawbacks of my time of life. END
BEGIN NOW Besides, I am confessing my sins, and it would be impossible to kneel in a more charming confessional; you commit your sins in one drawing-room, and receive absolution for them in another. END
BEGIN NOW The Duchess' expression grew colder, she did not like the flippant tone of these remarks, and showed that she considered them to be in bad taste by turning to the Vicomtesse with&mdash; This gentleman has only just come&mdash;- de Beauseant began to laugh outright at her cousin and at the Duchess both. END
BEGIN NOW He has only just come to Paris, dear, and is in search of some one who will give him lessons in good taste. END
BEGIN NOW la Duchesse, said Eugene, is it not natural to wish to be initiated into the mysteries which charm us? END
BEGIN NOW ( Come, now, he said to himself, my language is superfinely elegant, I'm sure. ) END

BEGIN NOW Of that I had no idea, madame, answered the law student, so I rashly came between them. END
BEGIN NOW In fact, I got on very well with the lady's husband, and his wife tolerated me for a time until I took it into my head to tell them that I knew some one of whom I had just caught a glimpse as he went out by a back staircase, a man who had given the Countess a kiss at the end of a passage. END
BEGIN NOW Who was it? END
BEGIN NOW both women asked together. END
BEGIN NOW An old man who lives at the rate of two louis a month in the Faubourg Saint-Marceau, where I, a poor student, lodge likewise. END
BEGIN NOW He is a truly unfortunate creature, everybody laughs at him&mdash;we all call him 'Father Goriot.' END
BEGIN NOW Why, child that you are, cried the Vicomtesse, de Restaud was a Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Goriot! END
BEGIN NOW The daughter of a vermicelli manufacturer, the Duchess added; and when the little creature went to Court, the daughter of a pastry-cook was presented on the same day. END
BEGIN NOW Do you remember, Claire? END
BEGIN NOW The King began to laugh, and made some joke in Latin about flour. END
BEGIN NOW People&mdash;what was it?&mdash;people&mdash;- _Ejusdem farinoe_, said Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, that was it, said the Duchess. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW is that her father? END
BEGIN NOW the law student continued, aghast. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, certainly; the old man had two daughters; he dotes on them, so to speak, though they will scarcely acknowledge him. END
BEGIN NOW Didn't the second daughter marry a banker with a German name? END
BEGIN NOW the Vicomtesse asked, turning to de Langeais, a Baron de Nucingen? END
BEGIN NOW And her name is Delphine, is it not? END
BEGIN NOW Isn't she a fair-haired woman who has a side-box at the Opera? END
BEGIN NOW She comes sometimes to the Bouffons, and laughs loudly to attract attention. END
BEGIN NOW The Duchess smiled and said: I wonder at you, dear. END
BEGIN NOW Why do you take so much interest in people of that kind? END
BEGIN NOW One must have been as madly in love as Restaud was, to be infatuated with Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Anastasie and her flour sacks. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW he will not find her a good bargain! END
BEGIN NOW She is in M. de Trailles' hands, and he will ruin her. END
BEGIN NOW And they do not acknowledge their father! END
BEGIN NOW Eugene repeated. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW well, yes, their father, the father, a father, replied the Vicomtesse, a kind father who gave them each five or six hundred thousand francs, it is said, to secure their happiness by marrying them well; while he only kept eight or ten thousand livres a year for himself, thinking that his daughters would always be his daughters, thinking that in them he would live his life twice over again, that in their houses he should find two homes, where he would be loved and looked up to, and made much of. END
BEGIN NOW And in two years' time both his sons-in-law had turned him out of their houses as if he were one of the lowest outcasts. END
BEGIN NOW Tears came into Eugene's eyes. END
BEGIN NOW He was still under the spell of youthful beliefs, he had just left home, pure and sacred feelings had been stirred within him, and this was his first day on the battlefield of civilization in Paris. END
BEGIN NOW Genuine feeling is so infectious that for a moment the three looked at each other in silence. END
BEGIN NOW _Eh, mon Dieu!_ said de Langeais; yes, it seems very horrible, and yet we see such things every day. END
BEGIN NOW Is there not a reason for it? END
BEGIN NOW Tell me, dear, have you ever really thought what a son-in-law is? END
BEGIN NOW A son-in-law is the man for whom we bring up, you and I, a dear little one, bound to us very closely in innumerable ways; for seventeen years she will be the joy of her family, its 'white soul,' as Lamartine says, and suddenly she will become its scourge. END
BEGIN NOW When HE comes and takes her from us, his love from the very beginning is like an axe laid to the root of all the old affection in our darling's heart, and all the ties that bound her to her family are severed. END
BEGIN NOW But yesterday our little daughter thought of no one but her mother and father, as we had no thought that was not for her; by to-morrow she will have become a hostile stranger. END
BEGIN NOW The tragedy is always going on under our eyes. END
BEGIN NOW On the one hand you see a father who has sacrificed himself to his son, and his daughter-in-law shows him the last degree of insolence. END
BEGIN NOW On the other hand, it is the son-in-law who turns his wife's mother out of the house. END
BEGIN NOW I sometimes hear it said that there is nothing dramatic about society in these days; but the Drama of the Son-in-law is appalling, to say nothing of our marriages, which have come to be very poor farces. END
BEGIN NOW I can explain how it all came about in the old vermicelli maker's case. END
BEGIN NOW I think I recollect that Foriot&mdash;- Goriot, madame. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, that Moriot was once President of his Section during the Revolution. END
BEGIN NOW He was in the secret of the famous scarcity of grain, and laid the foundation of his fortune in those days by selling flour for ten times its cost. END
BEGIN NOW He had as much flour as he wanted. END
BEGIN NOW My grandmother's steward sold him immense quantities. END
BEGIN NOW No doubt Noriot shared the plunder with the Committee of Public Salvation, as that sort of person always did. END
BEGIN NOW I recollect the steward telling my grandmother that she might live at Grandvilliers in complete security, because her corn was as good as a certificate of civism. END
BEGIN NOW Well, then, this Loriot, who sold corn to those butchers, has never had but one passion, they say&mdash;he idolizes his daughters. END
BEGIN NOW He settled one of them under Restaud's roof, and grafted the other into the Nucingen family tree, the Baron de Nucingen being a rich banker who had turned Royalist. END
BEGIN NOW You can quite understand that so long as Bonaparte was Emperor, the two sons-in-law could manage to put up with the old Ninety-three; but after the restoration of the Bourbons, M. de Restaud felt bored by the old man's society, and the banker was still more tired of it. END
BEGIN NOW His daughters were still fond of him; they wanted 'to keep the goat and the cabbage,' so they used to see Joriot whenever there was no one there, under pretence of affection. END
BEGIN NOW 'Come to-day, papa, we shall have you all to ourselves, and that will be much nicer!' END

BEGIN NOW As for me, dear, I believe that love has second-sight: poor Ninety-three; his heart must have bled. END
BEGIN NOW He saw that his daughters were ashamed of him, that if they loved their husbands his visits must make mischief. END
BEGIN NOW So he immolated himself. END
BEGIN NOW He made the sacrifice because he was a father; he went into voluntary exile. END
BEGIN NOW His daughters were satisfied, so he thought that he had done the best thing he could; but it was a family crime, and father and daughters were accomplices. END
BEGIN NOW You see this sort of thing everywhere. END
BEGIN NOW What could this old Doriot have been but a splash of mud in his daughters' drawing-rooms? END
BEGIN NOW He would only have been in the way, and bored other people, besides being bored himself. END
BEGIN NOW And this that happened between father and daughters may happen to the prettiest woman in Paris and the man she loves the best; if her love grows tiresome, he will go; he will descend to the basest trickery to leave her. END
BEGIN NOW It is the same with all love and friendship. END
BEGIN NOW Our heart is a treasury; if you pour out all its wealth at once, you are bankrupt. END
BEGIN NOW We show no more mercy to the affection that reveals its utmost extent than we do to another kind of prodigal who has not a penny left. END
