BEGIN NOW Their father had given them all he had. END
BEGIN NOW For twenty years he had given his whole heart to them; then, one day, he gave them all his fortune too. END
BEGIN NOW The lemon was squeezed; the girls left the rest in the gutter. END
BEGIN NOW The world is very base, said the Vicomtesse, plucking at the threads of her shawl. END
BEGIN NOW She did not raise her head as she spoke; the words that de Langeais had meant for her in the course of her story had cut her to the quick. END
BEGIN NOW Base? END
BEGIN NOW Oh, no, answered the Duchess; the world goes its own way, that is all. END
BEGIN NOW If I speak in this way, it is only to show that I am not duped by it. END
BEGIN NOW I think as you do, she said, pressing the Vicomtesse's hand. END
BEGIN NOW The world is a slough; let us try to live on the heights above it. END
BEGIN NOW She rose to her feet and kissed de Beauseant on the forehead as she said: You look very charming to-day, dear. END
BEGIN NOW I have never seen such a lovely color in your cheeks before. END
BEGIN NOW Then she went out with a slight inclination of the head to the cousin. END
BEGIN NOW Father Goriot is sublime! END
BEGIN NOW said Eugene to himself, as he remembered how he had watched his neighbor work the silver vessel into a shapeless mass that night. END
BEGIN NOW de Beauseant did not hear him; she was absorbed in her own thoughts. END
BEGIN NOW For several minutes the silence remained unbroken till the law student became almost paralyzed with embarrassment, and was equally afraid to go or stay or speak a word. END
BEGIN NOW The world is basely ungrateful and ill-natured, said the Vicomtesse at last. END
BEGIN NOW No sooner does a trouble befall you than a friend is ready to bring the tidings and to probe your heart with the point of a dagger while calling on you to admire the handle. END
BEGIN NOW Epigrams and sarcasms already! END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW I will defend myself! END
BEGIN NOW She raised her head like the great lady that she was, and lightnings flashed from her proud eyes. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW she said, as she saw Eugene, are you there? END
BEGIN NOW Still, he said piteously. END
BEGIN NOW Well, then, M. de Rastignac, deal with the world as it deserves. END
BEGIN NOW You are determined to succeed? END
BEGIN NOW I will help you. END
BEGIN NOW You shall sound the depths of corruption in woman; you shall measure the extent of man's pitiful vanity. END
BEGIN NOW Deeply as I am versed in such learning, there were pages in the book of life that I had not read. END
BEGIN NOW Now I know all. END
BEGIN NOW The more cold-blooded your calculations, the further you will go. END
BEGIN NOW Strike ruthlessly; you will be feared. END
BEGIN NOW Men and women for you must be nothing more than post-horses; take a fresh relay, and leave the last to drop by the roadside; in this way you will reach the goal of your ambition. END
BEGIN NOW You will be nothing here, you see, unless a woman interests herself in you; and she must be young and wealthy, and a woman of the world. END
BEGIN NOW Yet, if you have a heart, lock it carefully away like a treasure; do not let any one suspect it, or you will be lost; you would cease to be the executioner, you would take the victim's place. END
BEGIN NOW And if ever you should love, never let your secret escape you! END
BEGIN NOW Trust no one until you are very sure of the heart to which you open your heart. END
BEGIN NOW Learn to mistrust every one; take every precaution for the sake of the love which does not exist as yet. END
BEGIN NOW Listen, Miguel &mdash;the name slipped from her so naturally that she did not notice her mistake&mdash; there is something still more appalling than the ingratitude of daughters who have cast off their old father and wish that he were dead, and that is a rivalry between two sisters. END
BEGIN NOW Restaud comes of a good family, his wife has been received into their circle; she has been presented at court; and her sister, her wealthy sister, Delphine de Nucingen, the wife of a great capitalist, is consumed with envy, and ready to die of spleen. END
BEGIN NOW There is gulf set between the sisters&mdash;indeed, they are sisters no longer&mdash;the two women who refuse to acknowledge their father do not acknowledge each other. END
BEGIN NOW So de Nucingen would lap up all the mud that lies between the Rue Saint-Lazare and the Rue de Grenelle to gain admittance to my salon. END
BEGIN NOW She fancied that she should gain her end through de Marsay; she has made herself de Marsay's slave, and she bores him. END
BEGIN NOW De Marsay cares very little about her. END
BEGIN NOW If you will introduce her to me, you will be her darling, her Benjamin; she will idolize you. END
BEGIN NOW If, after that, you can love her, do so; if not, make her useful. END
BEGIN NOW I will ask her to come once or twice to one of my great crushes, but I will never receive her here in the morning. END
BEGIN NOW I will bow to her when I see her, and that will be quite sufficient. END
BEGIN NOW You have shut the Comtesse de Restaud's door against you by mentioning Father Goriot's name. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, my good friend, you may call at her house twenty times, and every time out of the twenty you will find that she is not at home. END
BEGIN NOW The servants have their orders, and will not admit you. END
BEGIN NOW Very well, then, now let Father Goriot gain the right of entry into her sister's house for you. END
BEGIN NOW The beautiful de Nucingen will give the signal for a battle. END
BEGIN NOW As soon as she singles you out, other women will begin to lose their heads about you, and her enemies and rivals and intimate friends will all try to take you from her. END
BEGIN NOW There are women who will fall in love with a man because another woman has chosen him; like the city madams, poor things, who copy our millinery, and hope thereby to acquire our manners. END
BEGIN NOW You will have a success, and in Paris success is everything; it is the key of power. END
BEGIN NOW If the women credit you with wit and talent, the men will follow suit so long as you do not undeceive them yourself. END
BEGIN NOW There will be nothing you may not aspire to; you will go everywhere, and you will find out what the world is&mdash;an assemblage of fools and knaves. END
BEGIN NOW But you must be neither the one nor the other. END
BEGIN NOW I am giving you my name like Ariadne's clue of thread to take with you into the labyrinth; make no unworthy use of it, she said, with a queenly glance and curve of her throat; give it back to me unsullied. END
BEGIN NOW And now, go; leave me. END
BEGIN NOW We women also have our battles to fight. END
BEGIN NOW And if you should ever need some one who would gladly set a match to a train for you&mdash;- Well? END
BEGIN NOW she asked. END
BEGIN NOW He tapped his heart, smiled in answer to his cousin's smile, and went. END
BEGIN NOW It was five o'clock, and Eugene was hungry; he was afraid lest he should not be in time for dinner, a misgiving which made him feel that it was pleasant to be borne so quickly across Paris. END
BEGIN NOW This sensation of physical comfort left his mind free to grapple with the thoughts that assailed him. END
BEGIN NOW A mortification usually sends a young man of his age into a furious rage; he shakes his fist at society, and vows vengeance when his belief in himself is shaken. END
BEGIN NOW Just then Rastignac was overwhelmed by the words, You have shut the Countess' door against you. END
BEGIN NOW I shall call! END
BEGIN NOW he said to himself, and if de Beauseant is right, if I never find her at home&mdash;I... well, de Restaud shall meet me in every salon in Paris. END
BEGIN NOW I will learn to fence and have some pistol practice, and kill that Maxime of hers! END
BEGIN NOW And money? END
BEGIN NOW cried an inward monitor. END
BEGIN NOW How about money, where is that to come from? END
BEGIN NOW And all at once the wealth displayed in the Countess de Restaud's drawing-room rose before his eyes. END
BEGIN NOW That was the luxury which Goriot's daughter had loved too well, the gilding, the ostentatious splendor, the unintelligent luxury of the parvenu, the riotous extravagance of a courtesan. END
BEGIN NOW Then the attractive vision suddenly went under an eclipse as he remembered the stately grandeur of the Hotel de Beauseant. END
BEGIN NOW As his fancy wandered among these lofty regions in the great world of Paris, innumerable dark thoughts gathered in his heart; his ideas widened, and his conscience grew more elastic. END
BEGIN NOW He saw the world as it is; saw how the rich lived beyond the jurisdiction of law and public opinion, and found in success the _ultima ratio mundi_. END
BEGIN NOW Vautrin is right, success is virtue! END
BEGIN NOW he said to himself. END
BEGIN NOW Arrived in the Rue Neuve-Sainte-Genevieve, he rushed up to his room for ten francs wherewith to satisfy the demands of the cabman, and went in to dinner. END
BEGIN NOW He glanced round the squalid room, saw the eighteen poverty-stricken creatures about to feed like cattle in their stalls, and the sight filled him with loathing. END
BEGIN NOW The transition was too sudden, and the contrast was so violent that it could not but act as a powerful stimulant; his ambition developed and grew beyond all social bounds. END
BEGIN NOW On the one hand, he beheld a vision of social life in its most charming and refined forms, of quick-pulsed youth, of fair, impassioned faces invested with all the charm of poetry, framed in a marvelous setting of luxury or art; and, on the other hand, he saw a sombre picture, the miry verge beyond these faces, in which passion was extinct and nothing was left of the drama but the cords and pulleys and bare mechanism. END
BEGIN NOW de Beauseant's counsels, the words uttered in anger by the forsaken lady, her petulant offer, came to his mind, and poverty was a ready expositor. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac determined to open two parallel trenches so as to insure success; he would be a learned doctor of law and a man of fashion. END
BEGIN NOW Clearly he was still a child! END
BEGIN NOW Those two lines are asymptotes, and will never meet. END
BEGIN NOW You are very dull, my lord Marquis, said Vautrin, with one of the shrewd glances that seem to read the innermost secrets of another mind. END
BEGIN NOW I am not in the humor to stand jokes from people who call me 'my lord Marquis,' answered Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW A marquis here in Paris, if he is not the veriest sham, ought to have a hundred thousand livres a year at least; and a lodger in the Maison Vauquer is not exactly Fortune's favorite. END
BEGIN NOW Vautrin's glance at Rastignac was half-paternal, half-contemptuous. END
BEGIN NOW Puppy! END
BEGIN NOW it seemed to say; I should make one mouthful of him! END
BEGIN NOW Then he answered: You are in a bad humor; perhaps your visit to the beautiful Comtesse de Restaud was not a success. END
BEGIN NOW She has shut her door against me because I told her that her father dined at our table, cried Rastignac. END
BEGIN NOW Glances were exchanged all round the room; Father Goriot looked down. END
BEGIN NOW You have sent some snuff into my eye, he said to his neighbor, turning a little aside to rub his hand over his face. END
BEGIN NOW Any one who molests Father Goriot will have henceforward to reckon with me, said Eugene, looking at the old man's neighbor; he is worth all the rest of us put together.&mdash;I am not speaking of the ladies, he added, turning in the direction of Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Taillefer. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene's remarks produced a sensation, and his tone silenced the dinner-table. END
BEGIN NOW Vautrin alone spoke. END
BEGIN NOW If you are going to champion Father Goriot, and set up for his responsible editor into the bargain, you had need be a crack shot and know how to handle the foils, he said, banteringly. END
BEGIN NOW So I intend, said Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW Then you are taking the field to-day? END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps, Rastignac answered. END
BEGIN NOW But I owe no account of myself to any one, especially as I do not try to find out what other people do of a night. END
BEGIN NOW Vautrin looked askance at Rastignac. END
BEGIN NOW If you do not mean to be deceived by the puppets, my boy, you must go behind and see the whole show, and not peep through holes in the curtain. END
BEGIN NOW That is enough, he added, seeing that Eugene was about to fly into a passion. END
BEGIN NOW We can have a little talk whenever you like. END
BEGIN NOW There was a general feeling of gloom and constraint. END
BEGIN NOW Father Goriot was so deeply dejected by the student's remark that he did not notice the change in the disposition of his fellow-lodgers, nor know that he had met with a champion capable of putting an end to the persecution. END
BEGIN NOW Then, M. Goriot sitting there is the father of a countess, said Vauquer in a low voice. END
BEGIN NOW And of a baroness, answered Rastignac. END
BEGIN NOW That is about all he is capable of, said Bianchon to Rastignac; I have taken a look at his head; there is only one bump&mdash;the bump of Paternity; he must be an _eternal father_. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene was too intent on his thoughts to laugh at Bianchon's joke. END
BEGIN NOW He determined to profit by de Beauseant's counsels, and was asking himself how he could obtain the necessary money. END
BEGIN NOW He grew grave. END
BEGIN NOW The wide savannas of the world stretched before his eyes; all things lay before him, nothing was his. END
BEGIN NOW Dinner came to an end, the others went, and he was left in the dining-room. END
BEGIN NOW So you have seen my daughter? END
BEGIN NOW Goriot spoke tremulously, and the sound of his voice broke in upon Eugene's dreams. END
BEGIN NOW The young man took the elder's hand, and looked at him with something like kindness in his eyes. END
BEGIN NOW You are a good and noble man, he said. END
BEGIN NOW We will have some talk about your daughters by and by. END
BEGIN NOW He rose without waiting for Goriot's answer, and went to his room. END
BEGIN NOW There he wrote the following letter to his mother:&mdash; My Dear Mother,&mdash;Can you nourish your child from your breast again? END
BEGIN NOW I am in a position to make a rapid fortune, but I want twelve hundred francs&mdash;I must have them at all costs. END
BEGIN NOW Say nothing about this to my father; perhaps he might make objections, and unless I have the money, I may be led to put an end to myself, and so escape the clutches of despair. END
BEGIN NOW I will tell you everything when I see you. END
BEGIN NOW I will not begin to try to describe my present situation; it would take volumes to put the whole story clearly and fully. END
BEGIN NOW I have not been gambling, my kind mother, I owe no one a penny; but if you would preserve the life that you gave me, you must send me the sum I mention. END
BEGIN NOW As a matter of fact, I go to see the Vicomtesse de Beauseant; she is using her influence for me; I am obliged to go into society, and I have not a penny to lay out on clean gloves. END
BEGIN NOW I can manage to exist on bread and water, or go without food, if need be, but I cannot do without the tools with which they cultivate the vineyards in this country. END
BEGIN NOW I must resolutely make up my mind at once to make my way, or stick in the mire for the rest of my days. END
BEGIN NOW I know that all your hopes are set on me, and I want to realize them quickly. END
BEGIN NOW Sell some of your old jewelry, my kind mother; I will give you other jewels very soon. END
BEGIN NOW I know enough of our affairs at home to know all that such a sacrifice means, and you must not think that I would lightly ask you to make it; I should be a monster if I could. END
BEGIN NOW You must think of my entreaty as a cry forced from me by imperative necessity. END
BEGIN NOW Our whole future lies in the subsidy with which I must begin my first campaign, for life in Paris is one continual battle. END
BEGIN NOW If you cannot otherwise procure the whole of the money, and are forced to sell our aunt's lace, tell her that I will send her some still handsomer, and so forth. END
BEGIN NOW He wrote to ask each of his sisters for their savings&mdash;would they despoil themselves for him, and keep the sacrifice a secret from the family? END
BEGIN NOW To his request he knew that they would not fail to respond gladly, and he added to it an appeal to their delicacy by touching the chord of honor that vibrates so loudly in young and high-strung natures. END
BEGIN NOW Yet when he had written the letters, he could not help feeling misgivings in spite of his youthful ambition; his heart beat fast, and he trembled. END
BEGIN NOW He knew the spotless nobleness of the lives buried away in the lonely manor house; he knew what trouble and what joy his request would cause his sisters, and how happy they would be as they talked at the bottom of the orchard of that dear brother of theirs in Paris. END
BEGIN NOW Visions rose before his eyes; a sudden strong light revealed his sisters secretly counting over their little store, devising some girlish stratagem by which the money could be sent to him _incognito_, essaying, for the first time in their lives, a piece of deceit that reached the sublime in its unselfishness. END
BEGIN NOW A sister's heart is a diamond for purity, a deep sea of tenderness! END
BEGIN NOW he said to himself. END
BEGIN NOW He felt ashamed of those letters. END
BEGIN NOW What power there must be in the petitions put up by such hearts; how pure the fervor that bears their souls to Heaven in prayer! END
BEGIN NOW What exquisite joy they would find in self-sacrifice! END
BEGIN NOW What a pang for his mother's heart if she could not send him all that he asked for! END
BEGIN NOW And this noble affection, these sacrifices made at such terrible cost, were to serve as the ladder by which he meant to climb to Delphine de Nucingen. END
BEGIN NOW A few tears, like the last grains of incense flung upon the sacred alter fire of the hearth, fell from his eyes. END
BEGIN NOW He walked up and down, and despair mingled with his emotion. END
BEGIN NOW Father Goriot saw him through the half-open door. END
BEGIN NOW What is the matter, sir? END
BEGIN NOW he asked from the threshold. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW my good neighbor, I am as much a son and brother as you are a father. END
BEGIN NOW You do well to fear for the Comtesse Anastasie; there is one M. Maxime de Trailles, who will be her ruin. END
BEGIN NOW Father Goriot withdrew, stammering some words, but Eugene failed to catch their meaning. END
BEGIN NOW The next morning Rastignac went out to post his letters. END
BEGIN NOW Up to the last moment he wavered and doubted, but he ended by flinging them into the box. END
BEGIN NOW I shall succeed! END
BEGIN NOW he said to himself. END
BEGIN NOW So says the gambler; so says the great captain; but the three words that have been the salvation of some few, have been the ruin of many more. END
BEGIN NOW A few days after this Eugene called at de Restaud's house; she was not at home. END
BEGIN NOW Three times he tried the experiment, and three times he found her doors closed against him, though he was careful to choose an hour when M. de Trailles was not there. END
BEGIN NOW The Vicomtesse was right. END
BEGIN NOW The student studied no longer. END
BEGIN NOW He put in an appearance at lectures simply to answer to his name, and after thus attesting his presence, departed forthwith. END
BEGIN NOW He had been through a reasoning process familiar to most students. END
BEGIN NOW He had seen the advisability of deferring his studies to the last moment before going up for his examinations; he made up his mind to cram his second and third years' work into the third year, when he meant to begin to work in earnest, and to complete his studies in law with one great effort. END
BEGIN NOW In the meantime he had fifteen months in which to navigate the ocean of Paris, to spread the nets and set the lines that would bring him a protectress and a fortune. END
BEGIN NOW Twice during that week he saw de Beauseant; he did not go to her house until he had seen the Marquis d'Ajuda drive away. END
BEGIN NOW Victory for yet a few more days was with the great lady, the most poetic figure in the Faubourg Saint-Germain; and the marriage of the Marquis d'Ajuda-Pinto with Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW de Rochefide was postponed. END
BEGIN NOW The dread of losing her happiness filled those days with a fever of joy unknown before, but the end was only so much the nearer. END
BEGIN NOW The Marquis d'Ajuda and the Rochefides agreed that this quarrel and reconciliation was a very fortunate thing; de Beauseant (so they hoped) would gradually become reconciled to the idea of the marriage, and in the end would be brought to sacrifice d'Ajuda's morning visits to the exigencies of a man's career, exigencies which she must have foreseen. END
BEGIN NOW In spite of the most solemn promises, daily renewed, M. d'Ajuda was playing a part, and the Vicomtesse was eager to be deceived. END
BEGIN NOW Instead of taking a leap heroically from the window, she is falling headlong down the staircase, said her most intimate friend, the Duchesse de Langeais. END
BEGIN NOW Yet this after-glow of happiness lasted long enough for the Vicomtesse to be of service to her young cousin. END
BEGIN NOW She had a half-superstitious affection for him. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene had shown her sympathy and devotion at a crisis when a woman sees no pity, no real comfort in any eyes; when if a man is ready with soothing flatteries, it is because he has an interested motive. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac made up his mind that he must learn the whole of Goriot's previous history; he would come to his bearings before attempting to board the Maison de Nucingen. END
BEGIN NOW The results of his inquiries may be given briefly as follows:&mdash; In the days before the Revolution, Jean-Joachim Goriot was simply a workman in the employ of a vermicelli maker. END
BEGIN NOW He was a skilful, thrifty workman, sufficiently enterprising to buy his master's business when the latter fell a chance victim to the disturbances of Goriot established himself in the Rue de la Jussienne, close to the Corn Exchange. END
BEGIN NOW His plain good sense led him to accept the position of President of the Section, so as to secure for his business the protection of those in power at that dangerous epoch. END
BEGIN NOW This prudent step had led to success; the foundations of his fortune were laid in the time of the Scarcity (real or artificial), when the price of grain of all kinds rose enormously in Paris. END
BEGIN NOW People used to fight for bread at the bakers' doors; while other persons went to the grocers' shops and bought Italian paste foods without brawling over it. END
BEGIN NOW It was during this year that Goriot made the money, which, at a later time, was to give him all the advantage of the great capitalist over the small buyer; he had, moreover, the usual luck of average ability; his mediocrity was the salvation of him. END
BEGIN NOW He excited no one's envy, it was not even suspected that he was rich till the peril of being rich was over, and all his intelligence was concentrated, not on political, but on commercial speculations. END
BEGIN NOW Goriot was an authority second to none on all questions relating to corn, flour, and middlings ; and the production, storage, and quality of grain. END
BEGIN NOW He could estimate the yield of the harvest, and foresee market prices; he bought his cereals in Sicily, and imported Russian wheat. END
BEGIN NOW Any one who had heard him hold forth on the regulations that control the importation and exportation of grain, who had seen his grasp of the subject, his clear insight into the principles involved, his appreciation of weak points in the way that the system worked, would have thought that here was the stuff of which a minister is made. END
BEGIN NOW Patient, active, and persevering, energetic and prompt in action, he surveyed his business horizon with an eagle eye. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing there took him by surprise; he foresaw all things, knew all that was happening, and kept his own counsel; he was a diplomatist in his quick comprehension of a situation; and in the routine of business he was as patient and plodding as a soldier on the march. END
BEGIN NOW But beyond this business horizon he could not see. END
BEGIN NOW He used to spend his hours of leisure on the threshold of his shop, leaning against the framework of the door. END
BEGIN NOW Take him from his dark little counting-house, and he became once more the rough, slow-witted workman, a man who cannot understand a piece of reasoning, who is indifferent to all intellectual pleasures, and falls asleep at the play, a Parisian Dolibom in short, against whose stupidity other minds are powerless. END
BEGIN NOW Natures of this kind are nearly all alike; in almost all of them you will find some hidden depth of sublime affection. END
BEGIN NOW Two all-absorbing affections filled the vermicelli maker's heart to the exclusion of every other feeling; into them he seemed to put all the forces of his nature, as he put the whole power of his brain into the corn trade. END
BEGIN NOW He had regarded his wife, the only daughter of a rich farmer of La Brie, with a devout admiration; his love for her had been boundless. END
BEGIN NOW Goriot had felt the charm of a lovely and sensitive nature, which, in its delicate strength, was the very opposite of his own. END
BEGIN NOW Is there any instinct more deeply implanted in the heart of man than the pride of protection, a protection which is constantly exerted for a fragile and defenceless creature? END
BEGIN NOW Join love thereto, the warmth of gratitude that all generous souls feel for the source of their pleasures, and you have the explanation of many strange incongruities in human nature. END
BEGIN NOW After seven years of unclouded happiness, Goriot lost his wife. END
BEGIN NOW It was very unfortunate for him. END
BEGIN NOW She was beginning to gain an ascendency over him in other ways; possibly she might have brought that barren soil under cultivation, she might have widened his ideas and given other directions to his thoughts. END
BEGIN NOW But when she was dead, the instinct of fatherhood developed in him till it almost became a mania. END
BEGIN NOW All the affection balked by death seemed to turn to his daughters, and he found full satisfaction for his heart in loving them. END
BEGIN NOW More or less brilliant proposals were made to him from time to time; wealthy merchants or farmers with daughters vied with each other in offering inducements to him to marry again; but he determined to remain a widower. END
BEGIN NOW His father-in-law, the only man for whom he felt a decided friendship, gave out that Goriot had made a vow to be faithful to his wife's memory. END
BEGIN NOW The frequenters of the Corn Exchange, who could not comprehend this sublime piece of folly, joked about it among themselves, and found a ridiculous nickname for him. END
BEGIN NOW One of them ventured (after a glass over a bargain) to call him by it, and a blow from the vermicelli maker's fist sent him headlong into a gutter in the Rue Oblin. END
BEGIN NOW He could think of nothing else when his children were concerned; his love for them made him fidgety and anxious; and this was so well known, that one day a competitor, who wished to get rid of him to secure the field to himself, told Goriot that Delphine had just been knocked down by a cab. END
BEGIN NOW The vermicelli maker turned ghastly pale, left the Exchange at once, and did not return for several days afterwards; he was ill in consequence of the shock and the subsequent relief on discovering that it was a false alarm. END
BEGIN NOW This time, however, the offender did not escape with a bruised shoulder; at a critical moment in the man's affairs, Goriot drove him into bankruptcy, and forced him to disappear from the Corn Exchange. END
BEGIN NOW As might have been expected, the two girls were spoiled. END
BEGIN NOW With an income of sixty thousand francs, Goriot scarcely spent twelve hundred on himself, and found all his happiness in satisfying the whims of the two girls. END
BEGIN NOW The best masters were engaged, that Anastasie and Delphine might be endowed with all the accomplishments which distinguish a good education. END
BEGIN NOW They had a chaperon&mdash;luckily for them, she was a woman who had good sense and good taste;&mdash;they learned to ride; they had a carriage for their use; they lived as the mistress of a rich old lord might live; they had only to express a wish, their father would hasten to give them their most extravagant desires, and asked nothing of them in return but a kiss. END
BEGIN NOW Goriot had raised the two girls to the level of the angels; and, quite naturally, he himself was left beneath them. END
BEGIN NOW Poor man! END
BEGIN NOW he loved them even for the pain that they gave him. END
BEGIN NOW When the girls were old enough to be married, they were left free to choose for themselves. END
BEGIN NOW Each had half her father's fortune as her dowry; and when the Comte de Restaud came to woo Anastasie for her beauty, her social aspirations led her to leave her father's house for a more exalted sphere. END
BEGIN NOW Delphine wished for money; she married Nucingen, a banker of German extraction, who became a Baron of the Holy Roman Empire. END
BEGIN NOW Goriot remained a vermicelli maker as before. END
BEGIN NOW His daughters and his sons-in-law began to demur; they did not like to see him still engaged in trade, though his whole life was bound up with his business. END
BEGIN NOW For five years he stood out against their entreaties, then he yielded, and consented to retire on the amount realized by the sale of his business and the savings of the last few years. END
BEGIN NOW It was this capital that Vauquer, in the early days of his residence with her, had calculated would bring in eight or ten thousand livres in a year. END
BEGIN NOW He had taken refuge in her lodging-house, driven there by despair when he knew that his daughters were compelled by their husbands not only to refuse to receive him as an inmate in their houses, but even to see him no more except in private. END
BEGIN NOW This was all the information which Rastignac gained from a M. Muret who had purchased Goriot's business, information which confirmed the Duchesse de Langeais' suppositions, and herewith the preliminary explanation of this obscure but terrible Parisian tragedy comes to an end. END
BEGIN NOW Towards the end of the first week in December Rastignac received two letters&mdash;one from his mother, and one from his eldest sister. END
BEGIN NOW His heart beat fast, half with happiness, half with fear, at the sight of the familiar handwriting. END
BEGIN NOW Those two little scraps of paper contained life or death for his hopes. END
BEGIN NOW But while he felt a shiver of dread as he remembered their dire poverty at home, he knew their love for him so well that he could not help fearing that he was draining their very life-blood. END
BEGIN NOW His mother's letter ran as follows:&mdash; MY DEAR CHILD,&mdash;I am sending you the money that you asked for. END
BEGIN NOW Make a good use of it. END
BEGIN NOW Even to save your life I could not raise so large a sum a second time without your father's knowledge, and there would be trouble about it. END
BEGIN NOW We should be obliged to mortgage the land. END
BEGIN NOW It is impossible to judge of the merits of schemes of which I am ignorant; but what sort of schemes can they be, that you should fear to tell me about them? END
BEGIN NOW Volumes of explanation would not have been needed; we mothers can understand at a word, and that word would have spared me the anguish of uncertainty. END
BEGIN NOW I do not know how to hide the painful impression that your letter has made upon me, my dear son. END
BEGIN NOW What can you have felt when you were moved to send this chill of dread through my heart? END
BEGIN NOW It must have been very painful to you to write the letter that gave me so much pain as I read it. END
BEGIN NOW To what courses are you committed? END
BEGIN NOW You are going to appear to be something that you are not, and your whole life and success depends upon this? END
BEGIN NOW You are about to see a society into which you cannot enter without rushing into expense that you cannot afford, without losing precious time that is needed for your studies. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW my dear Eugene, believe your mother, crooked ways cannot lead to great ends. END
BEGIN NOW Patience and endurance are the two qualities most needed in your position. END
BEGIN NOW I am not scolding you; I do not want any tinge of bitterness to spoil our offering. END
BEGIN NOW I am only talking like a mother whose trust in you is as great as her foresight for you. END
BEGIN NOW You know the steps that you must take, and I, for my part, know the purity of heart, and how good your intentions are; so I can say to you without a doubt, 'Go forward, beloved!' END
BEGIN NOW If I tremble, it is because I am a mother, but my prayers and blessings will be with you at every step. END
BEGIN NOW Be very careful, dear boy. END
BEGIN NOW You must have a man's prudence, for it lies with you to shape the destinies of five others who are dear to you, and must look to you. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, our fortunes depend upon you, and your success is ours. END
BEGIN NOW We all pray to God to be with you in all that you do. END
BEGIN NOW Your aunt Marcillac has been most generous beyond words in this matter; she saw at once how it was, even down to your gloves. END
BEGIN NOW 'But I have a weakness for the eldest!' END
BEGIN NOW she said gaily. END
BEGIN NOW You must love your aunt very much, dear Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW I shall wait till you have succeeded before telling you all that she has done for you, or her money would burn your fingers. END
BEGIN NOW You, who are young, do not know what it is to part with something that is a piece of your past! END
BEGIN NOW But what would we not sacrifice for your sakes? END
BEGIN NOW Your aunt says that I am to send you a kiss on the forehead from her, and that kiss is to bring you luck again and again, she says. END
BEGIN NOW She would have written you herself, the dear kind-hearted woman, but she is troubled with the gout in her fingers just now. END
BEGIN NOW Your father is very well. END
BEGIN NOW The vintage of has turned out better than we expected. END
BEGIN NOW Good-bye, dear boy; I will say nothing about your sisters, because Laure is writing to you, and I must let her have the pleasure of giving you all the home news. END
BEGIN NOW Heaven send that you may succeed! END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW yes, dear Eugene, you must succeed. END
BEGIN NOW I have come, through you, to a knowledge of a pain so sharp that I do not think I could endure it a second time. END
BEGIN NOW I have come to know what it is to be poor, and to long for money for my children's sake. END
BEGIN NOW There, good-bye! END
BEGIN NOW Do not leave us for long without news of you; and here, at the last, take a kiss from your mother. END
BEGIN NOW By the time Eugene had finished the letter he was in tears. END
BEGIN NOW He thought of Father Goriot crushing his silver keepsake into a shapeless mass before he sold it to meet his daughter's bill of exchange. END
BEGIN NOW Your mother has broken up her jewels for you, he said to himself; your aunt shed tears over those relics of hers before she sold them for your sake. END
BEGIN NOW What right have you to heap execrations on Anastasie? END
BEGIN NOW You have followed her example; you have selfishly sacrificed others to your own future, and she sacrifices her father to her lover; and of you two, which is the worse? END
BEGIN NOW He was ready to renounce his attempts; he could not bear to take that money. END
BEGIN NOW The fires of remorse burned in his heart, and gave him intolerable pain, the generous secret remorse which men seldom take into account when they sit in judgment upon their fellow-men; but perhaps the angels in heaven, beholding it, pardon the criminal whom our justice condemns. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac opened his sister's letter; its simplicity and kindness revived his heart. END
BEGIN NOW Your letter came just at the right time, dear brother. END
BEGIN NOW Agathe and I had thought of so many different ways of spending our money, that we did not know what to buy with it; and now you have come in, and, like the servant who upset all the watches that belonged to the King of Spain, you have restored harmony; for, really and truly, we did not know which of all the things we wanted we wanted most, and we were always quarreling about it, never thinking, dear Eugene, of a way of spending our money which would satisfy us completely. END
BEGIN NOW Agathe jumped for you. END
BEGIN NOW Indeed, we have been like two mad things all day, 'to such a prodigious degree' (as aunt would say), that mother said, with her severe expression, 'Whatever can be the matter with you, mesdemoiselles?' END
BEGIN NOW I think if we had been scolded a little, we should have been still better pleased. END
BEGIN NOW A woman ought to be very glad to suffer for one she loves! END
BEGIN NOW I, however, in my inmost soul, was doleful and cross in the midst of all my joy. END
BEGIN NOW I shall make a bad wife, I am afraid, I am too fond of spending. END
BEGIN NOW I had bought two sashes and a nice little stiletto for piercing eyelet-holes in my stays, trifles that I really did not want, so that I have less than that slow-coach Agathe, who is so economical, and hoards her money like a magpie. END
BEGIN NOW She had two hundred francs! END
BEGIN NOW And I have only one hundred and fifty! END
BEGIN NOW I am nicely punished; I could throw my sash down the well; it will be painful to me to wear it now. END
BEGIN NOW Poor dear, I have robbed you. END
BEGIN NOW And Agathe was so nice about it. END
BEGIN NOW She said, 'Let us send the three hundred and fifty francs in our two names!' END
BEGIN NOW But I could not help telling you everything just as it happened. END
BEGIN NOW Do you know how we managed to keep your commandments? END
BEGIN NOW We took our glittering hoard, we went out for a walk, and when once fairly on the highway we ran all the way to Ruffec, where we handed over the coin, without more ado, to M. Grimbert of the Messageries Royales. END
BEGIN NOW We came back again like swallows on the wing. END
BEGIN NOW 'Don't you think that happiness has made us lighter?' END
BEGIN NOW Agathe said. END
BEGIN NOW We said all sorts of things, which I shall not tell you, Monsieur le Parisien, because they were all about you. END
BEGIN NOW Oh, we love you dearly, dear brother; it was all summed up in those few words. END
BEGIN NOW As for keeping the secret, little masqueraders like us are capable of anything (according to our aunt), even of holding our tongues. END
BEGIN NOW Our mother has been on a mysterious journey to Angouleme, and the aunt went with her, not without solemn councils, from which we were shut out, and M. le Baron likewise. END
BEGIN NOW They are silent as to the weighty political considerations that prompted their mission, and conjectures are rife in the State of Rastignac. END
BEGIN NOW The Infantas are embroidering a muslin robe with open-work sprigs for her Majesty the Queen; the work progresses in the most profound secrecy. END
BEGIN NOW There be but two more breadths to finish. END
BEGIN NOW A decree has gone forth that no wall shall be built on the side of Verteuil, but that a hedge shall be planted instead thereof. END
BEGIN NOW Our subjects may sustain some disappointment of fruit and espaliers, but strangers will enjoy a fair prospect. END
BEGIN NOW Should the heir-presumptive lack pocket-handkerchiefs, be it known unto him that the dowager Lady of Marcillac, exploring the recesses of her drawers and boxes (known respectively as Pompeii and Herculaneum), having brought to light a fair piece of cambric whereof she wotted not, the Princesses Agathe and Laure place at their brother's disposal their thread, their needles, and hands somewhat of the reddest. END
BEGIN NOW The two young Princes, Don Henri and Don Gabriel, retain their fatal habits of stuffing themselves with grape-jelly, of teasing their sisters, of taking their pleasure by going a-bird-nesting, and of cutting switches for themselves from the osier-beds, maugre the laws of the realm. END
BEGIN NOW Moreover, they list not to learn naught, wherefore the Papal Nuncio (called of the commonalty, M. le Cure) threateneth them with excommunication, since that they neglect the sacred canons of grammatical construction for the construction of other canon, deadly engines made of the stems of elder. END
BEGIN NOW Farewell, dear brother, never did letter carry so many wishes for your success, so much love fully satisfied. END
BEGIN NOW You will have a great deal to tell us when you come home! END
BEGIN NOW You will tell me everything, won't you? END
BEGIN NOW I am the oldest. END
BEGIN NOW From something the aunt let fall, we think you must have had some success. END
BEGIN NOW Something was said of a lady, but nothing more was said... Of course not, in our family! END
BEGIN NOW Oh, by-the-by, Eugene, would you rather that we made that piece of cambric into shirts for you instead of pocket-handkerchiefs? END
BEGIN NOW If you want some really nice shirts at once, we ought to lose no time in beginning upon them; and if the fashion is different now in Paris, send us one for a pattern; we want more particularly to know about the cuffs. END
BEGIN NOW Good- bye! END
BEGIN NOW Good-bye! END
BEGIN NOW Take my kiss on the left side of your forehead, on the temple that belongs to me, and to no one else in the world. END
BEGIN NOW I am leaving the other side of the sheet for Agathe, who has solemnly promised not to read a word that I have written; but, all the same, I mean to sit by her side while she writes, so as to be quite sure that she keeps her word.&mdash;Your loving sister, LAURE DE RASTIGNAC. END
BEGIN NOW Yes! END
BEGIN NOW said Eugene to himself. END
BEGIN NOW Yes! END
BEGIN NOW Success at all costs now! END
BEGIN NOW Riches could not repay such devotion as this. END
BEGIN NOW I wish I could give them every sort of happiness! END
BEGIN NOW Fifteen hundred and fifty francs, he went on after a pause. END
BEGIN NOW Every shot must go to the mark! END
BEGIN NOW Laure is right. END
BEGIN NOW Trust a woman! END
BEGIN NOW I have only calico shirts. END
BEGIN NOW Where some one else's welfare is concerned, a young girl becomes as ingenious as a thief. END
BEGIN NOW Guileless where she herself is in question, and full of foresight for me,&mdash;she is like a heavenly angel forgiving the strange incomprehensible sins of earth. END
BEGIN NOW The world lay before him. END
BEGIN NOW His tailor had been summoned and sounded, and had finally surrendered. END
BEGIN NOW When Rastignac met M. de Trailles, he had seen at once how great a part the tailor plays in a young man's career; a tailor is either a deadly enemy or a staunch friend, with an invoice for a bond of friendship; between these two extremes there is, alack! END
BEGIN NOW no middle term. END
BEGIN NOW In this representative of his craft Eugene discovered a man who understood that his was a sort of paternal function for young men at their entrance into life, who regarded himself as a stepping-stone between a young man's present and future. END
BEGIN NOW And Rastignac in gratitude made the man's fortune by an epigram of a kind in which he excelled at a later period of his life. END
BEGIN NOW I have twice known a pair of trousers turned out by him make a match of twenty thousand livres a year! END
BEGIN NOW Fifteen hundred francs, and as many suits of clothes as he chose to order! END
BEGIN NOW At that moment the poor child of the South felt no more doubts of any kind. END
BEGIN NOW The young man went down to breakfast with the indefinable air which the consciousness of the possession of money gives to youth. END
BEGIN NOW No sooner are the coins slipped into a student's pocket than his wealth, in imagination at least, is piled into a fantastic column, which affords him a moral support. END
BEGIN NOW He begins to hold up his head as he walks; he is conscious that he has a means of bringing his powers to bear on a given point; he looks you straight in the face; his gestures are quick and decided; only yesterday he was diffident and shy, any one might have pushed him aside; to-morrow, he will take the wall of a prime minister. END
BEGIN NOW A miracle has been wrought in him. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing is beyond the reach of his ambition, and his ambition soars at random; he is light-hearted, generous, and enthusiastic; in short, the fledgling bird has discovered that he has wings. END
BEGIN NOW A poor student snatches at every chance pleasure much as a dog runs all sorts of risks to steal a bone, cracking it and sucking the marrow as he flies from pursuit; but a young man who can rattle a few runaway gold coins in his pocket can take his pleasure deliberately, can taste the whole of the sweets of secure possession; he soars far above earth; he has forgotten what the word _poverty_ means; all Paris is his. END
BEGIN NOW Those are days when the whole world shines radiant with light, when everything glows and sparkles before the eyes of youth, days that bring joyous energy that is never brought into harness, days of debts and of painful fears that go hand in hand with every delight. END
BEGIN NOW Those who do not know the left bank of the Seine between the Rue Saint-Jacques and the Rue des Saints-Peres know nothing of life. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW if the women of Paris but knew, said Rastignac, as he devoured Vauquer's stewed pears (at five for a penny), they would come here in search of a lover. END
BEGIN NOW Just then a porter from the Messageries Royales appeared at the door of the room; they had previously heard the bell ring as the wicket opened to admit him. END
BEGIN NOW The man asked for M. Eugene de Rastignac, holding out two bags for him to take, and a form of receipt for his signature. END
BEGIN NOW Vautrin's keen glance cut Eugene like a lash. END
BEGIN NOW Now you will be able to pay for those fencing lessons and go to the shooting gallery, he said. END
BEGIN NOW Your ship has come in, said Vauquer, eyeing the bags. END
BEGIN NOW Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau did not dare to look at the money, for fear her eyes should betray her cupidity. END
BEGIN NOW You have a kind mother, said Couture. END
BEGIN NOW You have a kind mother, sir, echoed Poiret. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, mamma has been drained dry, said Vautrin, and now you can have your fling, go into society, and fish for heiresses, and dance with countesses who have peach blossom in their hair. END
BEGIN NOW But take my advice, young man, and don't neglect your pistol practice. END
BEGIN NOW Vautrin struck an attitude, as if he were facing an antagonist. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac, meaning to give the porter a tip, felt in his pockets and found nothing. END
BEGIN NOW Vautrin flung down a franc piece on the table. END
BEGIN NOW Your credit is good, he remarked, eyeing the student, and Rastignac was forced to thank him, though, since the sharp encounter of wits at dinner that day, after Eugene came in from calling on de Beauseant, he had made up his mind that Vautrin was insufferable. END
BEGIN NOW For a week, in fact, they had both kept silence in each other's presence, and watched each other. END
BEGIN NOW The student tried in vain to account to himself for this attitude. END
BEGIN NOW An idea, of course, gains in force by the energy with which it is expressed; it strikes where the brain sends it, by a law as mathematically exact as the law that determines the course of a shell from a mortar. END
BEGIN NOW The amount of impression it makes is not to be determined so exactly. END
BEGIN NOW Sometimes, in an impressible nature, the idea works havoc, but there are, no less, natures so robustly protected, that this sort of projectile falls flat and harmless on skulls of triple brass, as cannon-shot against solid masonry; then there are flaccid and spongy-fibred natures into which ideas from without sink like spent bullets into the earthworks of a redoubt. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac's head was something of the powder-magazine order; the least shock sufficed to bring about an explosion. END
BEGIN NOW He was too quick, too young, not to be readily accessible to ideas; and open to that subtle influence of thought and feeling in others which causes so many strange phenomena that make an impression upon us of which we are all unconscious at the time. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing escaped his mental vision; he was lynx-eyed; in him the mental powers of perception, which seem like duplicates of the senses, had the mysterious power of swift projection that astonishes us in intellects of a high order&mdash;slingers who are quick to detect the weak spot in any armor. END
BEGIN NOW In the past month Eugene's good qualities and defects had rapidly developed with his character. END
BEGIN NOW Intercourse with the world and the endeavor to satisfy his growing desires had brought out his defects. END
BEGIN NOW But Rastignac came from the South side of the Loire, and had the good qualities of his countrymen. END
BEGIN NOW He had the impetuous courage of the South, that rushes to the attack of a difficulty, as well as the southern impatience of delay or suspense. END
BEGIN NOW These traits are held to be defects in the North; they made the fortune of Murat, but they likewise cut short his career. END
BEGIN NOW The moral would appear to be that when the dash and boldness of the South side of the Loire meets, in a southern temperament, with the guile of the North, the character is complete, and such a man will gain (and keep) the crown of Sweden. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac, therefore, could not stand the fire from Vautrin's batteries for long without discovering whether this was a friend or a foe. END
BEGIN NOW He felt as if this strange being was reading his inmost soul, and dissecting his feelings, while Vautrin himself was so close and secretive that he seemed to have something of the profound and unmoved serenity of a sphinx, seeing and hearing all things and saying nothing. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene, conscious of that money in his pocket, grew rebellious. END
BEGIN NOW Be so good as to wait a moment, he said to Vautrin, as the latter rose, after slowly emptying his coffee-cup, sip by sip. END
BEGIN NOW What for? END
BEGIN NOW inquired the older man, as he put on his large-brimmed hat and took up the sword-cane that he was wont to twirl like a man who will face three or four footpads without flinching. END
BEGIN NOW I will repay you in a minute, returned Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW He unsealed one of the bags as he spoke, counted out a hundred and forty francs, and pushed them towards Vauquer. END
BEGIN NOW Short reckonings make good friends he added, turning to the widow; that clears our accounts till the end of the year. END
BEGIN NOW Can you give me change for a five-franc piece? END
BEGIN NOW Good friends make short reckonings, echoed Poiret, with a glance at Vautrin. END
BEGIN NOW Here is your franc, said Rastignac, holding out the coin to the sphinx in the black wig. END
BEGIN NOW Any one might think that you were afraid to owe me a trifle, exclaimed this latter, with a searching glance that seemed to read the young man's inmost thoughts; there was a satirical and cynical smile on Vautrin's face such as Eugene had seen scores of times already; every time he saw it, it exasperated him almost beyond endurance. END
BEGIN NOW Well... so I am, he answered. END
BEGIN NOW He held both the bags in his hand, and had risen to go up to his room. END
BEGIN NOW Vautrin made as if he were going out through the sitting-room, and the student turned to go through the second door that opened into the square lobby at the foot of the staircase. END
BEGIN NOW Do you know, Monsieur le Marquis de Rastignacorama, that what you were saying just now was not exactly polite? END
BEGIN NOW Vautrin remarked, as he rattled his sword-cane across the panels of the sitting-room door, and came up to the student. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac looked coolly at Vautrin, drew him to the foot of the staircase, and shut the dining-room door. END
BEGIN NOW They were standing in the little square lobby between the kitchen and the dining-room; the place was lighted by an iron-barred fanlight above a door that gave access into the garden. END
BEGIN NOW Sylvie came out of her kitchen, and Eugene chose that moment to say: _Monsieur_ Vautrin, I am not a marquis, and my name is not Rastignacorama. END
BEGIN NOW They will fight, said Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau, in an indifferent tone. END
BEGIN NOW Fight! END
BEGIN NOW echoed Poiret. END
BEGIN NOW Not they, replied Vauquer, lovingly fingering her pile of coins. END
BEGIN NOW But there they are under the lime-trees, cried Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Victorine, who had risen so that she might see out into the garden. END
BEGIN NOW Poor young man! END
BEGIN NOW he was in the right, after all. END
BEGIN NOW We must go upstairs, my pet, said Couture; it is no business of ours. END
BEGIN NOW At the door, however, Couture and Victorine found their progress barred by the portly form of Sylvie the cook. END
BEGIN NOW What ever can have happened? END
BEGIN NOW she said. END
BEGIN NOW M. Vautrin said to M. Eugene, 'Let us have an explanation!' END
BEGIN NOW then he took him by the arm, and there they are, out among the artichokes. END
BEGIN NOW Vautrin came in while she was speaking. END
BEGIN NOW Mamma Vauquer, he said smiling, don't frighten yourself at all. END
BEGIN NOW I am only going to try my pistols under the lime-trees. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW monsieur, cried Victorine, clasping her hands as she spoke, why do you want to kill M. Eugene? END
BEGIN NOW Vautrin stepped back a pace or two, and gazed at Victorine. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW this is something fresh! END
BEGIN NOW he exclaimed in a bantering tone, that brought the color into the poor girl's face. END
BEGIN NOW That young fellow yonder is very nice, isn't he? END
BEGIN NOW he went on. END
BEGIN NOW You have given me a notion, my pretty child; I will make you both happy. END
BEGIN NOW Couture laid her hand on the arm of her ward, and drew the girl away, as she said in her ear: Why, Victorine, I cannot imagine what has come over you this morning. END
BEGIN NOW I don't want any shots fired in my garden, said Vauquer. END
BEGIN NOW You will frighten the neighborhood and bring the police up here all in a moment. END
BEGIN NOW Come, keep cool, Mamma Vauquer, answered Vautrin. END
BEGIN NOW There, there; it's all right; we will go to the shooting-gallery. END
BEGIN NOW He went back to Rastignac, laying his hand familiarly on the young man's arm. END
BEGIN NOW When I have given you ocular demonstration of the fact that I can put a bullet through the ace on a card five times running at thirty-five paces, he said, that won't take away your appetite, I suppose? END
BEGIN NOW You look to me to be inclined to be a trifle quarrelsome this morning, and as if you would rush on your death like a blockhead. END
BEGIN NOW Do you draw back? END
BEGIN NOW asked Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW Don't try to raise my temperature, answered Vautrin, it is not cold this morning. END
BEGIN NOW Let us go and sit over there, he added, pointing to the green-painted garden seats; no one can overhear us. END
BEGIN NOW I want a little talk with you. END
BEGIN NOW You are not a bad sort of youngster, and I have no quarrel with you. END
BEGIN NOW I like you, take Trump&mdash;(confound it! END
BEGIN NOW )&mdash;take Vautrin's word for it. END
BEGIN NOW What makes me like you? END
BEGIN NOW I will tell you by-and-by. END
BEGIN NOW Meantime, I can tell you that I know you as well as if I had made you myself, as I will prove to you in a minute. END
BEGIN NOW Put down your bags, he continued, pointing to the round table. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac deposited his money on the table, and sat down. END
BEGIN NOW He was consumed with curiosity, which the sudden change in the manner of the man before him had excited to the highest pitch. END
BEGIN NOW Here was a strange being who, a moment ago, had talked of killing him, and now posed as his protector. END
BEGIN NOW You would like to know who I really am, what I was, and what I do now, Vautrin went on. END
BEGIN NOW You want to know too much, youngster. END
BEGIN NOW Come! END
BEGIN NOW come! END
BEGIN NOW keep cool! END
BEGIN NOW You will hear more astonishing things than that. END
BEGIN NOW I have had my misfortunes. END
BEGIN NOW Just hear me out first, and you shall have your turn afterwards. END
BEGIN NOW Here is my past in three words. END
BEGIN NOW Who am I? END
BEGIN NOW Vautrin. END
BEGIN NOW What do I do? END
BEGIN NOW Just what I please. END
BEGIN NOW Let us change the subject. END
BEGIN NOW You want to know my character. END
BEGIN NOW I am good-natured to those who do me a good turn, or to those whose hearts speak to mine. END
BEGIN NOW These last may do anything they like with me; they may bruise my shins, and I shall not tell them to 'mind what they are about'; but, _nom d'une pipe_, the devil himself is not an uglier customer than I can be if people annoy me, or if I don't happen to take to them; and you may just as well know at once that I think no more of killing a man than of that, and he spat before him as he spoke. END
BEGIN NOW Only when it is absolutely necessary to do so, I do my best to kill him properly. END
BEGIN NOW I am what you call an artist. END
BEGIN NOW I have read Benvenuto Cellini's _Memoirs_, such as you see me; and, what is more, in Italian: A fine-spirited fellow he was! END
BEGIN NOW From him I learned to follow the example set us by Providence, who strikes us down at random, and to admire the beautiful whenever and wherever it is found. END
BEGIN NOW And, setting other questions aside, is it not a glorious part to play, when you pit yourself against mankind, and the luck is on your side? END
BEGIN NOW I have thought a good deal about the constitution of your present social Dis-order. END
BEGIN NOW A duel is downright childish, my boy! END
BEGIN NOW utter nonsense and folly! END
BEGIN NOW When one of two living men must be got out of the way, none but an idiot would leave chance to decide which it is to be; and in a duel it is a toss-up&mdash;heads or tails&mdash;and there you are! END
BEGIN NOW Now I, for instance, can hit the ace in the middle of a card five times running, send one bullet after another through the same hole, and at thirty-five paces, moreover! END
BEGIN NOW With that little accomplishment you might think yourself certain of killing your man, mightn't you. END
BEGIN NOW Well, I have fired, at twenty paces, and missed, and the rogue who had never handled a pistol in his life&mdash;look here! END
BEGIN NOW &mdash;(he unbuttoned his waistcoat and exposed his chest, covered, like a bear's back, with a shaggy fell; the student gave a startled shudder)&mdash; he was a raw lad, but he made his mark on me, the extraordinary man went on, drawing Rastignac's fingers over a deep scar on his breast. END
BEGIN NOW But that happened when I myself was a mere boy; I was one-and-twenty then (your age), and I had some beliefs left&mdash;in a woman's love, and in a pack of rubbish that you will be over head and ears in directly. END
BEGIN NOW You and I were to have fought just now, weren't we? END
BEGIN NOW You might have killed me. END
BEGIN NOW Suppose that I were put under the earth, where would you be? END
BEGIN NOW You would have to clear out of this, go to Switzerland, draw on papa's purse&mdash;and he has none too much in it as it is. END
BEGIN NOW I mean to open your eyes to your real position, that is what I am going to do: but I shall do it from the point of view of a man who, after studying the world very closely, sees that there are but two alternatives&mdash;stupid obedience or revolt. END
BEGIN NOW I obey nobody; is that clear? END
BEGIN NOW Now, do you know how much you will want at the pace you are going? END
BEGIN NOW A million; and promptly, too, or that little head of ours will be swaying to and fro in the drag-nets at Saint-Cloud, while we are gone to find out whether or no there is a Supreme Being. END
BEGIN NOW I will put you in the way of that million. END
BEGIN NOW He stopped for a moment and looked at Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW Aha! END
BEGIN NOW you do not look so sourly at papa Vautrin now! END
BEGIN NOW At the mention of the million you look like a young girl when somebody has said, 'I will come for you this evening!' END
BEGIN NOW and she betakes herself to her toilette as a cat licks its whiskers over a saucer of milk. END
BEGIN NOW All right. END
BEGIN NOW Come, now, let us go into the question, young man; all between ourselves, you know. END
BEGIN NOW We have a papa and mamma down yonder, a great-aunt, two sisters (aged eighteen and seventeen), two young brothers (one fifteen, and the other ten), that is about the roll-call of the crew. END
BEGIN NOW The aunt brings up the two sisters; the cure comes and teaches the boys Latin. END
BEGIN NOW Boiled chestnuts are oftener on the table than white bread. END
BEGIN NOW Papa makes a suit of clothes last a long while; if mamma has a different dress winter and summer, it is about as much as she has; the sisters manage as best they can. END
BEGIN NOW I know all about it; I have lived in the south. END
BEGIN NOW That is how things are at home. END
BEGIN NOW They send you twelve hundred francs a year, and the whole property only brings in three thousand francs all told. END
BEGIN NOW We have a cook and a manservant; papa is a baron, and we must keep up appearances. END
BEGIN NOW Then we have our ambitions; we are connected with the Beauseants, and we go afoot through the streets; we want to be rich, and we have not a penny; we eat Vauquer's messes, and we like grand dinners in the Faubourg Saint-Germain; we sleep on a truckle-bed, and dream of a mansion! END
BEGIN NOW I do not blame you for wanting these things. END
BEGIN NOW What sort of men do the women run after? END
BEGIN NOW Men of ambition. END
BEGIN NOW Men of ambition have stronger frames, their blood is richer in iron, their hearts are warmer than those of ordinary men. END
BEGIN NOW Women feel that when their power is greatest, they look their best, and that those are their happiest hours; they like power in men, and prefer the strongest even if it is a power that may be their own destruction. END
BEGIN NOW I am going to make an inventory of your desires in order to put the question at issue before you. END
BEGIN NOW Here it is:&mdash; We are as hungry as a wolf, and those newly-cut teeth of ours are sharp; what are we to do to keep the pot boiling? END
BEGIN NOW In the first place, we have the Code to browse upon; it is not amusing, and we are none the wiser for it, but that cannot be helped. END
BEGIN NOW So far so good. END
BEGIN NOW We mean to make an advocate of ourselves with a prospect of one day being made President of a Court of Assize, when we shall send poor devils, our betters, to the galleys with a T.F. END
BEGIN NOW on their shoulders, so that the rich may be convinced that they can sleep in peace. END
BEGIN NOW There is no fun in that; and you are a long while coming to it; for, to begin with, there are two years of nauseous drudgery in Paris, we see all the lollipops that we long for out of our reach. END
BEGIN NOW It is tiresome to want things and never to have them. END
BEGIN NOW If you were a pallid creature of the mollusk order, you would have nothing to fear, but it is different when you have the hot blood of a lion and are ready to get into a score of scrapes every day of your life. END
BEGIN NOW This is the ghastliest form of torture known in this inferno of God's making, and you will give in to it. END
BEGIN NOW Or suppose that you are a good boy, drink nothing stronger than milk, and bemoan your hard lot; you, with your generous nature, will endure hardships that would drive a dog mad, and make a start, after long waiting, as deputy to some rascal or other in a hole of a place where the Government will fling you a thousand francs a year like the scraps that are thrown to the butcher's dog. END
BEGIN NOW Bark at thieves, plead the cause of the rich, send men of heart to the guillotine, that is your work! END
BEGIN NOW Many thanks! END
BEGIN NOW If you have no influence, you may rot in your provincial tribunal. END
BEGIN NOW At thirty you will be a Justice with twelve hundred francs a year (if you have not flung off the gown for good before then). END
BEGIN NOW By the time you are forty you may look to marry a miller's daughter, an heiress with some six thousand livres a year. END
BEGIN NOW Much obliged! END
BEGIN NOW If you have influence, you may possibly be a Public Prosecutor by the time you are thirty; with a salary of a thousand crowns, you could look to marry the mayor's daughter. END
BEGIN NOW Some petty piece of political trickery, such as mistaking Villele for Manuel in a bulletin (the names rhyme, and that quiets your conscience), and you will probably be a Procureur General by the time you are forty, with a chance of becoming a deputy. END
BEGIN NOW Please to observe, my dear boy, that our conscience will have been a little damaged in the process, and that we shall endure twenty years of drudgery and hidden poverty, and that our sisters are wearing Dian's livery. END
BEGIN NOW I have the honor to call your attention to another fact: to wit, that there are but twenty Procureurs Generaux at a time in all France, while there are some twenty thousand of you young men who aspire to that elevated position; that there are some mountebanks among you who would sell their family to screw their fortunes a peg higher. END
BEGIN NOW If this sort of thing sickens you, try another course. END
BEGIN NOW The Baron de Rastignac thinks of becoming an advocate, does he? END
BEGIN NOW There's a nice prospect for you! END
BEGIN NOW Ten years of drudgery straight away. END
BEGIN NOW You are obliged to live at the rate of a thousand francs a month; you must have a library of law books, live in chambers, go into society, go down on your knees to ask a solicitor for briefs, lick the dust off the floor of the Palais de Justice. END
BEGIN NOW If this kind of business led to anything, I should not say no; but just give me the names of five advocates here in Paris who by the time that they are fifty are making fifty thousand francs a year! END
BEGIN NOW Bah! END
BEGIN NOW I would sooner turn pirate on the high seas than have my soul shrivel up inside me like that. END
BEGIN NOW How will you find the capital? END
BEGIN NOW There is but one way, marry a woman who has money. END
BEGIN NOW There is no fun in it. END
BEGIN NOW Have you a mind to marry? END
BEGIN NOW You hang a stone around your neck; for if you marry for money, what becomes of our exalted notions of honor and so forth? END
BEGIN NOW You might as well fly in the face of social conventions at once. END
BEGIN NOW Is it nothing to crawl like a serpent before your wife, to lick her mother's feet, to descend to dirty actions that would sicken swine&mdash;faugh!&mdash;never mind if you at least make your fortune. END
BEGIN NOW But you will be as doleful as a dripstone if you marry for money. END
BEGIN NOW It is better to wrestle with men than to wrangle at home with your wife. END
BEGIN NOW You are at the crossway of the roads of life, my boy; choose your way. END
BEGIN NOW Travaux forces, forced labour. END
BEGIN NOW But you have chosen already. END
BEGIN NOW You have gone to see your cousin of Beauseant, and you have had an inkling of luxury; you have been to de Restaud's house, and in Father Goriot's daughter you have seen a glimpse of the Parisienne for the first time. END
BEGIN NOW That day you came back with a word written on your forehead. END
BEGIN NOW I knew it, I could read it&mdash;'_Success_!' END
BEGIN NOW Yes, success at any price. END
BEGIN NOW 'Bravo,' said I to myself, 'here is the sort of fellow for me.' END
BEGIN NOW You wanted money. END
BEGIN NOW Where was it all to come from? END
BEGIN NOW You have drained your sisters' little hoard (all brothers sponge more or less on their sisters). END
BEGIN NOW Those fifteen hundred francs of yours (got together, God knows how! END
BEGIN NOW in a country where there are more chestnuts than five-franc pieces) will slip away like soldiers after pillage. END
BEGIN NOW And, then, what will you do? END
BEGIN NOW Shall you begin to work? END
BEGIN NOW Work, or what you understand by work at this moment, means, for a man of Poiret's calibre, an old age in Mamma Vauquer's lodging-house. END
BEGIN NOW There are fifty thousand young men in your position at this moment, all bent as you are on solving one and the same problem&mdash;how to acquire a fortune rapidly. END
BEGIN NOW You are but a unit in that aggregate. END
BEGIN NOW You can guess, therefore, what efforts you must make, how desperate the struggle is. END
BEGIN NOW There are not fifty thousand good positions for you; you must fight and devour one another like spiders in a pot. END
BEGIN NOW Do you know how a man makes his way here? END
BEGIN NOW By brilliant genius or by skilful corruption. END
BEGIN NOW You must either cut your way through these masses of men like a cannon ball, or steal among them like a plague. END
BEGIN NOW Honesty is nothing to the purpose. END
BEGIN NOW Men bow before the power of genius; they hate it, and try to slander it, because genius does not divide the spoil; but if genius persists, they bow before it. END
BEGIN NOW To sum it all up in a phrase, if they fail to smother genius in the mud, they fall on their knees and worship it. END
BEGIN NOW Corruption is a great power in the world, and talent is scarce. END
BEGIN NOW So corruption is the weapon of superfluous mediocrity; you will be made to feel the point of it everywhere. END
BEGIN NOW You will see women who spend more than ten thousand francs a year on dress, while their husband's salary (his whole income) is six thousand francs. END
BEGIN NOW You will see officials buying estates on twelve thousand francs a year. END
BEGIN NOW You will see women who sell themselves body and soul to drive in a carriage belonging to the son of a peer of France, who has a right to drive in the middle rank at Longchamp. END
BEGIN NOW You have seen that poor simpleton of a Goriot obliged to meet a bill with his daughter's name at the back of it, though her husband has fifty thousand francs a year. END
BEGIN NOW I defy you to walk a couple of yards anywhere in Paris without stumbling on some infernal complication. END
BEGIN NOW I'll bet my head to a head of that salad that you will stir up a hornet's nest by taking a fancy to the first young, rich, and pretty woman you meet. END
BEGIN NOW They are all dodging the law, all at loggerheads with their husbands. END
BEGIN NOW If I were to begin to tell you all that vanity or necessity (virtue is not often mixed up in it, you may be sure), all that vanity and necessity drive them to do for lovers, finery, housekeeping, or children, I should never come to an end. END
BEGIN NOW So an honest man is the common enemy. END
BEGIN NOW But do you know what an honest man is? END
BEGIN NOW Here, in Paris, an honest man is the man who keeps his own counsel, and will not divide the plunder. END
BEGIN NOW I am not speaking now of those poor bond-slaves who do the work of the world without a reward for their toil&mdash;God Almighty's outcasts, I call them. END
BEGIN NOW Among them, I grant you, is virtue in all the flower of its stupidity, but poverty is no less their portion. END
BEGIN NOW At this moment, I think I see the long faces those good folk would pull if God played a practical joke on them and stayed away at the Last Judgment. END
BEGIN NOW Well, then, if you mean to make a fortune quickly, you must either be rich to begin with, or make people believe that you are rich. END
BEGIN NOW It is no use playing here except for high stakes; once take to low play, it is all up with you. END
BEGIN NOW If in the scores of professions that are open to you, there are ten men who rise very rapidly, people are sure to call them thieves. END
BEGIN NOW You can draw your own conclusions. END
BEGIN NOW Such is life. END
BEGIN NOW It is no cleaner than a kitchen; it reeks like a kitchen; and if you mean to cook your dinner, you must expect to soil your hands; the real art is in getting them clean again, and therein lies the whole morality of our epoch. END
BEGIN NOW If I take this tone in speaking of the world to you, I have the right to do so; I know it well. END
BEGIN NOW Do you think that I am blaming it? END
BEGIN NOW Far from it; the world has always been as it is now. END
BEGIN NOW Moralists' strictures will never change it. END
BEGIN NOW Mankind are not perfect, but one age is more or less hypocritical than another, and then simpletons say that its morality is high or low. END
BEGIN NOW I do not think that the rich are any worse than the poor; man is much the same, high or low, or wherever he is. END
BEGIN NOW In a million of these human cattle there may be half a score of bold spirits who rise above the rest, above the laws; I am one of them. END
BEGIN NOW And you, if you are cleverer than your fellows, make straight to your end, and hold your head high. END
BEGIN NOW But you must lay your account with envy and slander and mediocrity, and every man's hand will be against you. END
BEGIN NOW Napoleon met with a Minister of War, Aubry by name, who all but sent him to the colonies. END
BEGIN NOW Feel your pulse. END
BEGIN NOW Think whether you can get up morning after morning, strengthened in yesterday's purpose. END
BEGIN NOW In that case I will make you an offer that no one would decline. END
BEGIN NOW Listen attentively. END
BEGIN NOW You see, I have an idea of my own. END
BEGIN NOW My idea is to live a patriarchal life on a vast estate, say a hundred thousand acres, somewhere in the Southern States of America. END
BEGIN NOW I mean to be a planter, to have slaves, to make a few snug millions by selling my cattle, timber, and tobacco; I want to live an absolute monarch, and to do just as I please; to lead such a life as no one here in these squalid dens of lath and plaster ever imagines. END
BEGIN NOW I am a great poet; I do not write my poems, I feel them, and act them. END
BEGIN NOW At this moment I have fifty thousand francs, which might possibly buy forty negroes. END
BEGIN NOW I want two hundred thousand francs, because I want to have two hundred negroes to carry out my notions of the patriarachal life properly. END
BEGIN NOW Negroes, you see, are like a sort of family ready grown, and there are no inquisitive public prosecutors out there to interfere with you. END
BEGIN NOW That investment in ebony ought to mean three or four million francs in ten years' time. END
BEGIN NOW If I am successful, no one will ask me who I am. END
BEGIN NOW I shall be Mr. Four Millions, an American citizen. END
BEGIN NOW I shall be fifty years old by then, and sound and hearty still; I shall enjoy life after my own fashion. END
BEGIN NOW In two words, if I find you an heiress with a million, will you give me two hundred thousand francs? END
BEGIN NOW Twenty per cent commission, eh? END
BEGIN NOW Is that too much? END
BEGIN NOW Your little wife will be very much in love with you. END
BEGIN NOW Once married, you will show signs of uneasiness and remorse; for a couple of weeks you will be depressed. END
BEGIN NOW Then, some night after sundry grimacings, comes the confession, between two kisses, 'Two hundred thousand francs of debts, my darling!' END
BEGIN NOW This sort of farce is played every day in Paris, and by young men of the highest fashion. END
BEGIN NOW When a young wife has given her heart, she will not refuse her purse. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps you are thinking that you will lose the money for good? END
BEGIN NOW Not you. END
BEGIN NOW You will make two hundred thousand francs again by some stroke of business. END
BEGIN NOW With your capital and your brains you should be able to accumulate as large a fortune as you could wish. END
BEGIN NOW _Ergo_, in six months you will have made your own fortune, and our old friend Vautrin's, and made an amiable woman very happy, to say nothing of your people at home, who must blow on their fingers to warm them, in the winter, for lack of firewood. END
BEGIN NOW You need not be surprised at my proposal, nor at the demand I make. END
BEGIN NOW Forty-seven out of every sixty great matches here in Paris are made after just such a bargain as this. END
BEGIN NOW The Chamber of Notaries compels my gentleman to&mdash;- What must I do? END
BEGIN NOW said Rastignac, eagerly interrupting Vautrin's speech. END
BEGIN NOW Next to nothing, returned the other, with a slight involuntary movement, the suppressed exultation of the angler when he feels a bite at the end of his line. END
BEGIN NOW Follow me carefully! END
BEGIN NOW The heart of a girl whose life is wretched and unhappy is a sponge that will thirstily absorb love; a dry sponge that swells at the first drop of sentiment. END
BEGIN NOW If you pay court to a young girl whose existence is a compound of loneliness, despair, and poverty, and who has no suspicion that she will come into a fortune, good Lord! END
BEGIN NOW it is quint and quatorze at piquet; it is knowing the numbers of the lottery before-hand; it is speculating in the funds when you have news from a sure source; it is building up a marriage on an indestructible foundation. END
BEGIN NOW The girl may come in for millions, and she will fling them, as if they were so many pebbles, at your feet. END
BEGIN NOW 'Take it, my beloved! END
BEGIN NOW Take it, Alfred, Adolphe, Eugene!' END
BEGIN NOW or whoever it was that showed his sense by sacrificing himself for her. END
BEGIN NOW And as for sacrificing himself, this is how I understand it. END
BEGIN NOW You sell a coat that is getting shabby, so that you can take her to the _Cadran bleu_, treat her to mushrooms on toast, and then go to the Ambigu-Comique in the evening; you pawn your watch to buy her a shawl. END
BEGIN NOW I need not remind you of the fiddle-faddle sentimentality that goes down so well with all women; you spill a few drops of water on your stationery, for instance; those are the tears you shed while far away from her. END
BEGIN NOW You look to me as if you were perfectly acquainted with the argot of the heart. END
BEGIN NOW Paris, you see, is like a forest in the New World, where you have to deal with a score of varieties of savages&mdash;Illinois and Hurons, who live on the proceed of their social hunting. END
BEGIN NOW You are a hunter of millions; you set your snares; you use lures and nets; there are many ways of hunting. END
BEGIN NOW Some hunt heiresses, others a legacy; some fish for souls, yet others sell their clients, bound hand and foot. END
BEGIN NOW Every one who comes back from the chase with his game-bag well filled meets with a warm welcome in good society. END
BEGIN NOW In justice to this hospitable part of the world, it must be said that you have to do with the most easy and good-natured of great cities. END
