BEGIN NOW If the proud aristocracies of the rest of Europe refuse admittance among their ranks to a disreputable millionaire, Paris stretches out a hand to him, goes to his banquets, eats his dinners, and hobnobs with his infamy. END
BEGIN NOW But where is such a girl to be found? END
BEGIN NOW asked Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW Under your eyes; she is yours already. END
BEGIN NOW Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Victorine? END
BEGIN NOW Precisely. END
BEGIN NOW And what was that you said? END
BEGIN NOW She is in love with you already, your little Baronne de Rastignac! END
BEGIN NOW She has not a penny, Eugene continued, much mystified. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW now we are coming to it! END
BEGIN NOW Just another word or two, and it will all be clear enough. END
BEGIN NOW Her father, Taillefer, is an old scoundrel; it is said that he murdered one of his friends at the time of the Revolution. END
BEGIN NOW He is one of your comedians that sets up to have opinions of his own. END
BEGIN NOW He is a banker&mdash;senior partner in the house of Frederic Taillefer and Company. END
BEGIN NOW He has one son, and means to leave all he has to the boy, to the prejudice of Victorine. END
BEGIN NOW For my part, I don't like to see injustice of this sort. END
BEGIN NOW I am like Don Quixote, I have a fancy for defending the weak against the strong. END
BEGIN NOW If it should please God to take that youth away from him, Taillefer would have only his daughter left; he would want to leave his money to some one or other; an absurd notion, but it is only human nature, and he is not likely to have any more children, as I know. END
BEGIN NOW Victorine is gentle and amiable; she will soon twist her father round her fingers, and set his head spinning like a German top by plying him with sentiment! END
BEGIN NOW She will be too much touched by your devotion to forget you; you will marry her. END
BEGIN NOW I mean to play Providence for you, and Providence is to do my will. END
BEGIN NOW I have a friend whom I have attached closely to myself, a colonel in the Army of the Loire, who has just been transferred into the _garde royale_. END
BEGIN NOW He has taken my advice and turned ultra-royalist; he is not one of those fools who never change their opinions. END
BEGIN NOW Of all pieces of advice, my cherub, I would give you this&mdash;don't stick to your opinions any more than to your words. END
BEGIN NOW If any one asks you for them, let him have them&mdash;at a price. END
BEGIN NOW A man who prides himself on going in a straight line through life is an idiot who believes in infallibility. END
BEGIN NOW There are no such things as principles; there are only events, and there are no laws but those of expediency: a man of talent accepts events and the circumstances in which he finds himself, and turns everything to his own ends. END
BEGIN NOW If laws and principles were fixed and invariable, nations would not change them as readily as we change our shirts. END
BEGIN NOW The individual is not obliged to be more particular than the nation. END
BEGIN NOW A man whose services to France have been of the very slightest is a fetich looked on with superstitious awe because he has always seen everything in red; but he is good, at the most, to be put into the Museum of Arts and Crafts, among the automatic machines, and labeled La Fayette; while the prince at whom everybody flings a stone, the man who despises humanity so much that he spits as many oaths as he is asked for in the face of humanity, saved France from being torn in pieces at the Congress of Vienna; and they who should have given him laurels fling mud at him. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW I know something of affairs, I can tell you; I have the secrets of many men! END
BEGIN NOW Enough. END
BEGIN NOW When I find three minds in agreement as to the application of a principle, I shall have a fixed and immovable opinion&mdash;I shall have to wait a long while first. END
BEGIN NOW In the Tribunals you will not find three judges of the same opinion on a single point of law. END
BEGIN NOW To return to the man I was telling you of. END
BEGIN NOW He would crucify Jesus Christ again, if I bade him. END
BEGIN NOW At a word from his old chum Vautrin he will pick a quarrel with a scamp that will not send so much as five francs to his sister, poor girl, and (here Vautrin rose to his feet and stood like a fencing-master about to lunge)&mdash; turn him off into the dark! END
BEGIN NOW he added. END
BEGIN NOW How frightful! END
BEGIN NOW said Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW You do not really mean it? END
BEGIN NOW M. Vautrin, you are joking! END
BEGIN NOW There! END
BEGIN NOW there! END
BEGIN NOW Keep cool! END
BEGIN NOW said the other. END
BEGIN NOW Don't behave like a baby. END
BEGIN NOW But if you find any amusement in it, be indignant, flare up! END
BEGIN NOW Say that I am a scoundrel, a rascal, a rogue, a bandit; but do not call me a blackleg nor a spy! END
BEGIN NOW There, out with it, fire away! END
BEGIN NOW I forgive you; it is quite natural at your age. END
BEGIN NOW I was like that myself once. END
BEGIN NOW Only remember this, you will do worse things yourself some day. END
BEGIN NOW You will flirt with some pretty woman and take her money. END
BEGIN NOW You have thought of that, of course, said Vautrin, for how are you to succeed unless love is laid under contribution? END
BEGIN NOW There are no two ways about virtue, my dear student; it either is, or it is not. END
BEGIN NOW Talk of doing penance for your sins! END
BEGIN NOW It is a nice system of business, when you pay for your crime by an act of contrition! END
BEGIN NOW You seduce a woman that you may set your foot on such and such a rung of the social ladder; you sow dissension among the children of a family; you descend, in short, to every base action that can be committed at home or abroad, to gain your own ends for your own pleasure or your profit; and can you imagine that these are acts of faith, hope, or charity? END
BEGIN NOW How is it that a dandy, who in a night has robbed a boy of half his fortune, gets only a couple of months in prison; while a poor devil who steals a banknote for a thousand francs, with aggravating circumstances, is condemned to penal servitude? END
BEGIN NOW Those are your laws. END
BEGIN NOW Not a single provision but lands you in some absurdity. END
BEGIN NOW That man with yellow gloves and a golden tongue commits many a murder; he sheds no blood, but he drains his victim's veins as surely; a desperado forces open a door with a crowbar, dark deeds both of them! END
BEGIN NOW You yourself will do every one of those things that I suggest to you to-day, bar the bloodshed. END
BEGIN NOW Do you believe that there is any absolute standard in this world? END
BEGIN NOW Despise mankind and find out the meshes that you can slip through in the net of the Code. END
BEGIN NOW The secret of a great success for which you are at a loss to account is a crime that has never been found out, because it was properly executed. END
BEGIN NOW Silence, sir! END
BEGIN NOW I will not hear any more; you make me doubt myself. END
BEGIN NOW At this moment my sentiments are all my science. END
BEGIN NOW Just as you please, my fine fellow; I did think you were so weak-minded, said Vautrin, I shall say no more about it. END
BEGIN NOW One last word, however, and he looked hard at the student&mdash; you have my secret, he said. END
BEGIN NOW A young man who refuses your offer knows that he must forget it. END
BEGIN NOW Quite right, quite right; I am glad to hear you say so. END
BEGIN NOW Somebody else might not be so scrupulous, you see. END
BEGIN NOW Keep in mind what I want to do for you. END
BEGIN NOW I will give you a fortnight. END
BEGIN NOW The offer is still open. END
BEGIN NOW What a head of iron the man has! END
BEGIN NOW said Eugene to himself, as he watched Vautrin walk unconcernedly away with his cane under his arm. END
BEGIN NOW Yet de Beauseant said as much more gracefully; he has only stated the case in cruder language. END
BEGIN NOW He would tear my heart with claws of steel. END
BEGIN NOW What made me think of going to de Nucingen? END
BEGIN NOW He guessed my motives before I knew them myself. END
BEGIN NOW To sum it up, that outlaw has told me more about virtue than all I have learned from men and books. END
BEGIN NOW If virtue admits of no compromises, I have certainly robbed my sisters, he said, throwing down the bags on the table. END
BEGIN NOW He sat down again and fell, unconscious of his surroundings, into deep thought. END
BEGIN NOW To be faithful to an ideal of virtue! END
BEGIN NOW A heroic martyrdom! END
BEGIN NOW Pshaw! END
BEGIN NOW every one believes in virtue, but who is virtuous? END
BEGIN NOW Nations have made an idol of Liberty, but what nation on the face of the earth is free? END
BEGIN NOW My youth is still like a blue and cloudless sky. END
BEGIN NOW If I set myself to obtain wealth or power, does it mean that I must make up my mind to lie, and fawn, and cringe, and swagger, and flatter, and dissemble? END
BEGIN NOW To consent to be the servant of others who have likewise fawned, and lied, and flattered? END
BEGIN NOW Must I cringe to them before I can hope to be their accomplice? END
BEGIN NOW Well, then, I decline. END
BEGIN NOW I mean to work nobly and with a single heart. END
BEGIN NOW I will work day and night; I will owe my fortune to nothing but my own exertions. END
BEGIN NOW It may be the slowest of all roads to success, but I shall lay my head on the pillow at night untroubled by evil thoughts. END
BEGIN NOW Is there a greater thing than this&mdash;to look back over your life and know that it is stainless as a lily? END
BEGIN NOW I and my life are like a young man and his betrothed. END
BEGIN NOW Vautrin has put before me all that comes after ten years of marriage. END
BEGIN NOW The devil! END
BEGIN NOW my head is swimming. END
BEGIN NOW I do not want to think at all; the heart is a sure guide. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene was roused from his musings by the voice of the stout Sylvie, who announced that the tailor had come, and Eugene therefore made his appearance before the man with the two money bags, and was not ill pleased that it should be so. END
BEGIN NOW When he had tried on his dress suit, he put on his new morning costume, which completely metamorphosed him. END
BEGIN NOW I am quite equal to M. de Trailles, he said to himself. END
BEGIN NOW In short, I look like a gentleman. END
BEGIN NOW You asked me, sir, if I knew the houses where de Nucingen goes, Father Goriot's voice spoke from the doorway of Eugene's room. END
BEGIN NOW Yes. END
BEGIN NOW Very well then, she is going to the Marechale Carigliano's ball on Monday. END
BEGIN NOW If you can manage to be there, I shall hear from you whether my two girls enjoyed themselves, and how they were dressed, and all about it in fact. END
BEGIN NOW How did you find that out, my good Goriot? END
BEGIN NOW said Eugene, putting a chair by the fire for his visitor. END
BEGIN NOW Her maid told me. END
BEGIN NOW I hear all about their doings from Therese and Constance, he added gleefully. END
BEGIN NOW The old man looked like a lover who is still young enough to be made happy by the discovery of some little stratagem which brings him information of his lady-love without her knowledge. END
BEGIN NOW _You_ will see them both! END
BEGIN NOW he said, giving artless expression to a pang of jealousy. END
BEGIN NOW I do not know, answered Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW I will go to de Beauseant and ask her for an introduction to the Marechale. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene felt a thrill of pleasure at the thought of appearing before the Vicomtesse, dressed as henceforward he always meant to be. END
BEGIN NOW The abysses of the human heart, in the moralists' phrase, are only insidious thoughts, involuntary promptings of personal interest. END
BEGIN NOW The instinct of enjoyment turns the scale; those rapid changes of purpose which have furnished the text for so much rhetoric are calculations prompted by the hope of pleasure. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac beholding himself well dressed and impeccable as to gloves and boots, forgot his virtuous resolutions. END
BEGIN NOW Youth, moreover, when bent upon wrongdoing does not dare to behold himself in the mirror of consciousness; mature age has seen itself; and therein lies the whole difference between these two phases of life. END
BEGIN NOW A friendship between Eugene and his neighbor, Father Goriot, had been growing up for several days past. END
BEGIN NOW This secret friendship and the antipathy that the student had begun to entertain for Vautrin arose from the same psychological causes. END
BEGIN NOW The bold philosopher who shall investigate the effects of mental action upon the physical world will doubtless find more than one proof of the material nature of our sentiments in other animals. END
BEGIN NOW What physiognomist is as quick to discern character as a dog is to discover from a stranger's face whether this is a friend or no? END
BEGIN NOW Those by-words&mdash; atoms, affinities &mdash;are facts surviving in modern languages for the confusion of philosophic wiseacres who amuse themselves by winnowing the chaff of language to find its grammatical roots. END
BEGIN NOW We _feel_ that we are loved. END
BEGIN NOW Our sentiments make themselves felt in everything, even at a great distance. END
BEGIN NOW A letter is a living soul, and so faithful an echo of the voice that speaks in it, that finer natures look upon a letter as one of love's most precious treasures. END
BEGIN NOW Father Goriot's affection was of the instinctive order, a canine affection raised to a sublime pitch; he had scented compassion in the air, and the kindly respect and youthful sympathy in the student's heart. END
BEGIN NOW This friendship had, however, scarcely reached the stage at which confidences are made. END
BEGIN NOW Though Eugene had spoken of his wish to meet de Nucingen, it was not because he counted on the old man to introduce him to her house, for he hoped that his own audacity might stand him in good stead. END
BEGIN NOW All that Father Goriot had said as yet about his daughters had referred to the remarks that the student had made so freely in public on that day of the two visits. END
BEGIN NOW How could you think that de Restaud bore you a grudge for mentioning my name? END
BEGIN NOW he had said on the day following that scene at dinner. END
BEGIN NOW My daughters are very fond of me; I am a happy father; but my sons-in-law have behaved badly to me, and rather than make trouble between my darlings and their husbands, I choose to see my daughters secretly. END
BEGIN NOW Fathers who can see their daughters at any time have no idea of all the pleasure that all this mystery gives me; I cannot always see mine when I wish, do you understand? END
BEGIN NOW So when it is fine I walk out in the Champs-Elysees, after finding out from their waiting-maids whether my daughters mean to go out. END
BEGIN NOW I wait near the entrance; my heart beats fast when the carriages begin to come; I admire them in their dresses, and as they pass they give me a little smile, and it seems as if everything was lighted up for me by a ray of bright sunlight. END
BEGIN NOW I wait, for they always go back the same way, and then I see them again; the fresh air has done them good and brought color into their cheeks; all about me people say, 'What a beautiful woman that is!' END
BEGIN NOW and it does my heart good to hear them. END
BEGIN NOW Are they not my own flesh and blood? END
BEGIN NOW I love the very horses that draw them; I envy the little lap-dog on their knees. END
BEGIN NOW Their happiness is my life. END
BEGIN NOW Every one loves after his own fashion, and mine does no one any harm; why should people trouble their heads about me? END
BEGIN NOW I am happy in my own way. END
BEGIN NOW Is there any law against going to see my girls in the evening when they are going out to a ball? END
BEGIN NOW And what a disappointment it is when I get there too late, and am told that 'Madame has gone out!' END
BEGIN NOW Once I waited till three o'clock in the morning for Nasie; I had not seen her for two whole days. END
BEGIN NOW I was so pleased, that it was almost too much for me! END
BEGIN NOW Please do not speak of me unless it is to say how good my daughters are to me. END
BEGIN NOW They are always wanting to heap presents upon me, but I will not have it. END
BEGIN NOW 'Just keep your money,' I tell them. END
BEGIN NOW 'What should I do with it? END
BEGIN NOW I want nothing.' END
BEGIN NOW And what am I, sir, after all? END
BEGIN NOW An old carcase, whose soul is always where my daughters are. END
BEGIN NOW When you have seen de Nucingen, tell me which you like the most, said the old man after a moment's pause, while Eugene put the last touches to his toilette. END
BEGIN NOW The student was about to go out to walk in the Garden of the Tuileries until the hour when he could venture to appear in de Beauseant's drawing-room. END
BEGIN NOW That walk was a turning-point in Eugene's career. END
BEGIN NOW Several women noticed him; he looked so handsome, so young, and so well dressed. END
BEGIN NOW This almost admiring attention gave a new turn to his thoughts. END
BEGIN NOW He forgot his sisters and the aunt who had robbed herself for him; he no longer remembered his own virtuous scruples. END
BEGIN NOW He had seen hovering above his head the fiend so easy to mistake for an angel, the Devil with rainbow wings, who scatters rubies, and aims his golden shafts at palace fronts, who invests women with purple, and thrones with a glory that dazzles the eyes of fools till they forget the simple origins of royal dominion; he had heard the rustle of that Vanity whose tinsel seems to us to be the symbol of power. END
BEGIN NOW However cynical Vautrin's words had been, they had made an impression on his mind, as the sordid features of the old crone who whispers, A lover, and gold in torrents, remain engraven on a young girl's memory. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene lounged about the walks till it was nearly five o'clock, then he went to de Beauseant, and received one of the terrible blows against which young hearts are defenceless. END
BEGIN NOW Hitherto the Vicomtesse had received him with the kindly urbanity, the bland grace of manner that is the result of fine breeding, but is only complete when it comes from the heart. END
BEGIN NOW To-day de Beauseant bowed constrainedly, and spoke curtly: M. de Rastignac, I cannot possibly see you, at least not at this moment. END
BEGIN NOW I am engaged... An observer, and Rastignac instantly became an observer, could read the whole history, the character and customs of caste, in the phrase, in the tones of her voice, in her glance and bearing. END
BEGIN NOW He caught a glimpse of the iron hand beneath the velvet glove&mdash;the personality, the egoism beneath the manner, the wood beneath the varnish. END
BEGIN NOW In short, he heard that unmistakable I THE KING that issues from the plumed canopy of the throne, and finds its last echo under the crest of the simplest gentleman. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene had trusted too implicitly to the generosity of a woman; he could not believe in her haughtiness. END
BEGIN NOW Like all the unfortunate, he had subscribed, in all good faith, the generous compact which should bind the benefactor to the recipient, and the first article in that bond, between two large-hearted natures, is a perfect equality. END
BEGIN NOW The kindness which knits two souls together is as rare, as divine, and as little understood as the passion of love, for both love and kindness are the lavish generosity of noble natures. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac was set upon going to the Duchesse de Carigliano's ball, so he swallowed down this rebuff. END
BEGIN NOW Madame, he faltered out, I would not have come to trouble you about a trifling matter; be so kind as to permit me to see you later, I can wait. END
BEGIN NOW Very well, come and dine with me, she said, a little confused by the harsh way in which she had spoken, for this lady was as genuinely kind-hearted as she was high-born. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene was touched by this sudden relenting, but none the less he said to himself as he went away, Crawl in the dust, put up with every kind of treatment. END
BEGIN NOW What must the rest of the world be like when one of the kindest of women forgets all her promises of befriending me in a moment, and tosses me aside like an old shoe? END
BEGIN NOW So it is every one for himself? END
BEGIN NOW It is true that her house is not a shop, and I have put myself in the wrong by needing her help. END
BEGIN NOW You should cut your way through the world like a cannon ball, as Vautrin said. END
BEGIN NOW But the student's bitter thoughts were soon dissipated by the pleasure which he promised himself in this dinner with the Vicomtesse. END
BEGIN NOW Fate seemed to determine that the smallest accidents in his life should combine to urge him into a career, which the terrible sphinx of the Maison Vauquer had described as a field of battle where you must either slay or be slain, and cheat to avoid being cheated. END
BEGIN NOW You leave your conscience and your heart at the barriers, and wear a mask on entering into this game of grim earnest, where, as in ancient Sparta, you must snatch your prize without being detected if you would deserve the crown. END
BEGIN NOW On his return he found the Vicomtesse gracious and kindly, as she had always been to him. END
BEGIN NOW They went together to the dining-room, where the Vicomte was waiting for his wife. END
BEGIN NOW In the time of the Restoration the luxury of the table was carried, as is well known, to the highest degree, and M. de Beauseant, like many jaded men of the world, had few pleasures left but those of good cheer; in this matter, in fact, he was a gourmand of the schools of Louis XVIII. END
BEGIN NOW and of the Duc d'Escars, and luxury was supplemented by splendor. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene, dining for the first time in a house where the traditions of grandeur had descended through many generations, had never seen any spectacle like this that now met his eyes. END
BEGIN NOW In the time of the Empire, balls had always ended with a supper, because the officers who took part in them must be fortified for immediate service, and even in Paris might be called upon to leave the ballroom for the battlefield. END
BEGIN NOW This arrangement had gone out of fashion under the Monarchy, and Eugene had so far only been asked to dances. END
BEGIN NOW The self-possession which pre-eminently distinguished him in later life already stood him in good stead, and he did not betray his amazement. END
BEGIN NOW Yet as he saw for the first time the finely wrought silver plate, the completeness of every detail, the sumptuous dinner, noiselessly served, it was difficult for such an ardent imagination not to prefer this life of studied and refined luxury to the hardships of the life which he had chosen only that morning. END
BEGIN NOW His thoughts went back for a moment to the lodging-house, and with a feeling of profound loathing, he vowed to himself that at New Year he would go; prompted at least as much by a desire to live among cleaner surroundings as by a wish to shake off Vautrin, whose huge hand he seemed to feel on his shoulder at that moment. END
BEGIN NOW When you consider the numberless forms, clamorous or mute, that corruption takes in Paris, common-sense begins to wonder what mental aberration prompted the State to establish great colleges and schools there, and assemble young men in the capital; how it is that pretty women are respected, or that the gold coin displayed in the money-changer's wooden saucers does not take to itself wings in the twinkling of an eye; and when you come to think further, how comparatively few cases of crime there are, and to count up the misdemeanors committed by youth, is there not a certain amount of respect due to these patient Tantaluses who wrestle with themselves and nearly always come off victorious? END
BEGIN NOW The struggles of the poor student in Paris, if skilfully drawn, would furnish a most dramatic picture of modern civilization. END
BEGIN NOW In vain de Beauseant looked at Eugene as if asking him to speak; the student was tongue-tied in the Vicomte's presence. END
BEGIN NOW Are you going to take me to the Italiens this evening? END
BEGIN NOW the Vicomtesse asked her husband. END
BEGIN NOW You cannot doubt that I should obey you with pleasure, he answered, and there was a sarcastic tinge in his politeness which Eugene did not detect, but I ought to go to meet some one at the Varietes. END
BEGIN NOW His mistress, said she to herself. END
BEGIN NOW Then, is not Ajuda coming for you this evening? END
BEGIN NOW inquired the Vicomte. END
BEGIN NOW No, she answered, petulantly. END
BEGIN NOW Very well, then, if you really must have an arm, take that of M. de Rastignac. END
BEGIN NOW The Vicomtess turned to Eugene with a smile. END
BEGIN NOW That would be a very compromising step for you, she said. END
BEGIN NOW 'A Frenchman loves danger, because in danger there is glory,' to quote M. de Chateaubriand, said Rastignac, with a bow. END
BEGIN NOW A few moments later he was sitting beside de Beauseant in a brougham, that whirled them through the streets of Paris to a fashionable theatre. END
BEGIN NOW It seemed to him that some fairy magic had suddenly transported him into a box facing the stage. END
BEGIN NOW All the lorgnettes of the house were pointed at him as he entered, and at the Vicomtesse in her charming toilette. END
BEGIN NOW He went from enchantment to enchantment. END
BEGIN NOW You must talk to me, you know, said de Beauseant. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW look! END
BEGIN NOW There is de Nucingen in the third box from ours. END
BEGIN NOW Her sister and M. de Trailles are on the other side. END
BEGIN NOW The Vicomtesse glanced as she spoke at the box where Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW de Rochefide should have been; M. d'Ajuda was not there, and de Beauseant's face lighted up in a marvelous way. END
BEGIN NOW She is charming, said Eugene, after looking at de Nucingen. END
BEGIN NOW She has white eyelashes. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, but she has such a pretty slender figure! END
BEGIN NOW Her hands are large. END
BEGIN NOW Such beautiful eyes! END
BEGIN NOW Her face is long. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, but length gives distinction. END
BEGIN NOW It is lucky for her that she has some distinction in her face. END
BEGIN NOW Just see how she fidgets with her opera-glass! END
BEGIN NOW The Goriot blood shows itself in every movement, said the Vicomtesse, much to Eugene's astonishment. END
BEGIN NOW Indeed, de Beauseant seemed to be engaged in making a survey of the house, and to be unconscious of Nucingen's existence; but no movement made by the latter was lost upon the Vicomtesse. END
BEGIN NOW The house was full of the loveliest women in Paris, so that Delphine de Nucingen was not a little flattered to receive the undivided attention of de Beauseant's young, handsome, and well-dressed cousin, who seemed to have no eyes for any one else. END
BEGIN NOW If you look at her so persistently, you will make people talk, M. de Rastignac. END
BEGIN NOW You will never succeed if you fling yourself at any one's head like that. END
BEGIN NOW My dear cousin, said Eugene, you have protected me indeed so far, and now if you would complete your work, I only ask of you a favor which will cost you but little, and be of very great service to me. END
BEGIN NOW I have lost my heart. END
BEGIN NOW Already! END
BEGIN NOW Yes. END
BEGIN NOW And to that woman! END
BEGIN NOW How could I aspire to find any one else to listen to me? END
BEGIN NOW he asked, with a keen glance at his cousin. END
BEGIN NOW Her Grace the Duchesse de Carigliano is a friend of the Duchesse de Berri, he went on, after a pause; you are sure to see her, will you be so kind as to present me to her, and to take me to her ball on Monday? END
BEGIN NOW I shall meet de Nucingen there, and enter into my first skirmish. END
BEGIN NOW Willingly, she said. END
BEGIN NOW If you have a liking for her already, your affairs of the heart are like to prosper. END
BEGIN NOW That is de Marsay over there in the Princesse Galathionne's box. END
BEGIN NOW de Nucingen is racked with jealousy. END
BEGIN NOW There is no better time for approaching a woman, especially if she happens to be a banker's wife. END
BEGIN NOW All those ladies of the Chaussee-d'Antin love revenge. END
BEGIN NOW Then, what would you do yourself in such a case? END
BEGIN NOW I should suffer in silence. END
BEGIN NOW At this point the Marquis d'Ajuda appeared in de Beauseant's box. END
BEGIN NOW I have made a muddle of my affairs to come to you, he said, and I am telling you about it, so that it may not be a sacrifice. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene saw the glow of joy on the Vicomtesse's face, and knew that this was love, and learned the difference between love and the affectations of Parisian coquetry. END
BEGIN NOW He admired his cousin, grew mute, and yielded his place to M. d'Ajuda with a sigh. END
BEGIN NOW How noble, how sublime a woman is when she loves like that! END
BEGIN NOW he said to himself. END
BEGIN NOW And _he_ could forsake her for a doll! END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW how could any one forsake her? END
BEGIN NOW There was a boy's passionate indignation in his heart. END
BEGIN NOW He could have flung himself at de Beauseant's feet; he longed for the power of the devil if he could snatch her away and hide her in his heart, as an eagle snatches up some white yearling from the plains and bears it to its eyrie. END
BEGIN NOW It was humiliating to him to think that in all this gallery of fair pictures he had not one picture of his own. END
BEGIN NOW To have a mistress and an almost royal position is a sign of power, he said to himself. END
BEGIN NOW And he looked at de Nucingen as a man measures another who has insulted him. END
BEGIN NOW The Vicomtesse turned to him, and the expression of her eyes thanked him a thousand times for his discretion. END
BEGIN NOW The first act came to an end just then. END
BEGIN NOW Do you know de Nucingen well enough to present M. de Rastignac to her? END
BEGIN NOW she asked of the Marquis d'Ajuda. END
BEGIN NOW She will be delighted, said the Marquis. END
BEGIN NOW The handsome Portuguese rose as he spoke and took the student's arm, and in another moment Eugene found himself in de Nucingen's box. END
BEGIN NOW Madame, said the Marquis, I have the honor of presenting to you the Chevalier Eugene de Rastignac; he is a cousin of de Beauseant's. END
BEGIN NOW You have made so deep an impression upon him, that I thought I would fill up the measure of his happiness by bringing him nearer to his divinity. END
BEGIN NOW Words spoken half jestingly to cover their somewhat disrespectful import; but such an implication, if carefully disguised, never gives offence to a woman. END
BEGIN NOW de Nucingen smiled, and offered Eugene the place which her husband had just left. END
BEGIN NOW I do not venture to suggest that you should stay with me, monsieur, she said. END
BEGIN NOW Those who are so fortunate as to be in de Beauseant's company do not desire to leave it. END
BEGIN NOW Madame, Eugene said, lowering his voice, I think that to please my cousin I should remain with you. END
BEGIN NOW Before my lord Marquis came we were speaking of you and of your exceedingly distinguished appearance, he added aloud. END
BEGIN NOW M. d'Ajuda turned and left them. END
BEGIN NOW Are you really going to stay with me, monsieur? END
BEGIN NOW asked the Baroness. END
BEGIN NOW Then we shall make each other's acquaintance. END
BEGIN NOW de Restaud told me about you, and has made me anxious to meet you. END
BEGIN NOW She must be very insincere, then, for she has shut her door on me. END
BEGIN NOW What? END
BEGIN NOW Madame, I will tell you honestly the reason why; but I must crave your indulgence before confiding such a secret to you. END
BEGIN NOW I am your father's neighbor; I had no idea that de Restaud was his daughter. END
BEGIN NOW I was rash enough to mention his name; I meant no harm, but I annoyed your sister and her husband very much. END
BEGIN NOW You cannot think how severely the Duchesse de Langeais and my cousin blamed this apostasy on a daughter's part, as a piece of bad taste. END
BEGIN NOW I told them all about it, and they both burst out laughing. END
BEGIN NOW Then de Beauseant made some comparison between you and your sister, speaking in high terms of you, and saying how very fond you were of my neighbor, M. Goriot. END
BEGIN NOW And, indeed, how could you help loving him? END
BEGIN NOW He adores you so passionately that I am jealous already. END
BEGIN NOW We talked about you this morning for two hours. END
BEGIN NOW So this evening I was quite full of all that your father had told me, and while I was dining with my cousin I said that you could not be as beautiful as affectionate. END
BEGIN NOW de Beauseant meant to gratify such warm admiration, I think, when she brought me here, telling me, in her gracious way, that I should see you. END
BEGIN NOW Then, even now, I owe you a debt of gratitude, monsieur, said the banker's wife. END
BEGIN NOW We shall be quite old friends in a little while. END
BEGIN NOW Although a friendship with you could not be like an ordinary friendship, said Rastignac; I should never wish to be your friend. END
BEGIN NOW Such stereotyped phrases as these, in the mouths of beginners, possess an unfailing charm for women, and are insipid only when read coldly; for a young man's tone, glance and attitude give a surpassing eloquence to the banal phrases. END
BEGIN NOW de Nucingen thought that Rastignac was adorable. END
BEGIN NOW Then, woman-like, being at a loss how to reply to the student's outspoken admiration, she answered a previous remark. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, it is very wrong of my sister to treat our poor father as she does, she said; he has been a Providence to us. END
BEGIN NOW It was not until M. de Nucingen positively ordered me only to receive him in the mornings that I yielded the point. END
BEGIN NOW But I have been unhappy about it for a long while; I have shed many tears over it. END
BEGIN NOW This violence to my feelings, with my husband's brutal treatment, have been two causes of my unhappy married life. END
BEGIN NOW There is certainly no woman in Paris whose lot seems more enviable than mine, and yet, in reality, there is not one so much to be pitied. END
BEGIN NOW You will think I must be out of my senses to talk to you like this; but you know my father, and I cannot regard you as a stranger. END
BEGIN NOW You will find no one, said Eugene, who longs as eagerly as I do to be yours. END
BEGIN NOW What do all women seek? END
BEGIN NOW Happiness. END
BEGIN NOW (He answered his own question in low, vibrating tones.) END
BEGIN NOW And if happiness for a woman means that she is to be loved and adored, to have a friend to whom she can pour out her wishes, her fancies, her sorrows and joys; to whom she can lay bare her heart and soul, and all her fair defects and her gracious virtues, without fear of a betrayal; believe me, the devotion and the warmth that never fails can only be found in the heart of a young man who, at a bare sign from you, would go to his death, who neither knows nor cares to know anything as yet of the world, because you will be all the world to him. END
BEGIN NOW I myself, you see (you will laugh at my simplicity), have just come from a remote country district; I am quite new to this world of Paris; I have only known true and loving hearts; and I made up my mind that here I should find no love. END
BEGIN NOW Then I chanced to meet my cousin, and to see my cousin's heart from very near; I have divined the inexhaustible treasures of passion, and, like Cherubino, I am the lover of all women, until the day comes when I find _the_ woman to whom I may devote myself. END
BEGIN NOW As soon as I saw you, as soon as I came into the theatre this evening, I felt myself borne towards you as if by the current of a stream. END
BEGIN NOW I had so often thought of you already, but I had never dreamed that you would be so beautiful! END
BEGIN NOW de Beauseant told me that I must not look so much at you. END
BEGIN NOW She does not know the charm of your red lips, your fair face, nor see how soft your eyes are.... END
BEGIN NOW I also am beginning to talk nonsense; but let me talk. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing pleases a woman better than to listen to such whispered words as these; the most puritanical among them listens even when she ought not to reply to them; and Rastignac, having once begun, continued to pour out his story, dropping his voice, that she might lean and listen; and de Nucingen, smiling, glanced from time to time at de Marsay, who still sat in the Princesse Galathionne's box. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac did not leave de Nucingen till her husband came to take her home. END
BEGIN NOW Madame, Eugene said, I shall have the pleasure of calling upon you before the Duchesse de Carigliano's ball. END
BEGIN NOW If Matame infites you to come, said the Baron, a thickset Alsatian, with indications of a sinister cunning in his full-moon countenance, you are quide sure of being well receifed. END
BEGIN NOW My affairs seem to be in a promising way, said Eugene to himself.&mdash; 'Can you love me?' END
BEGIN NOW I asked her, and she did not resent it. END
BEGIN NOW The bit is in the horse's mouth, and I have only to mount and ride; and with that he went to pay his respects to de Beauseant, who was leaving the theatre on d'Ajuda's arm. END
BEGIN NOW The student did not know that the Baroness' thoughts had been wandering; that she was even then expecting a letter from de Marsay, one of those letters that bring about a rupture that rends the soul; so, happy in his delusion, Eugene went with the Vicomtesse to the peristyle, where people were waiting till their carriages were announced. END
BEGIN NOW That cousin of yours is hardly recognizable for the same man, said the Portuguese laughingly to the Vicomtesse, when Eugene had taken leave of them. END
BEGIN NOW He will break the bank. END
BEGIN NOW He is as supple as an eel; he will go a long way, of that I am sure. END
BEGIN NOW Who else could have picked out a woman for him, as you did, just when she needed consolation? END
BEGIN NOW But it is not certain that she does not still love the faithless lover, said de Beauseant. END
BEGIN NOW The student meanwhile walked back from the Theatre-Italien to the Rue Neuve-Sainte-Genevieve, making the most delightful plans as he went. END
BEGIN NOW He had noticed how closely de Restaud had scrutinized him when he sat beside de Nucingen, and inferred that the Countess' doors would not be closed in the future. END
BEGIN NOW Four important houses were now open to him&mdash;for he meant to stand well with the Marechale; he had four supporters in the inmost circle of society in Paris. END
BEGIN NOW Even now it was clear to him that, once involved in this intricate social machinery, he must attach himself to a spoke of the wheel that was to turn and raise his fortunes; he would not examine himself too curiously as to the methods, but he was certain of the end, and conscious of the power to gain and keep his hold. END
BEGIN NOW If de Nucingen takes an interest in me, I will teach her how to manage her husband. END
BEGIN NOW That husband of hers is a great speculator; he might put me in the way of making a fortune by a single stroke. END
BEGIN NOW He did not say this bluntly in so many words; as yet, indeed, he was not sufficient of a diplomatist to sum up a situation, to see its possibilities at a glance, and calculate the chances in his favor. END
BEGIN NOW These were nothing but hazy ideas that floated over his mental horizon; they were less cynical than Vautrin's notions; but if they had been tried in the crucible of conscience, no very pure result would have issued from the test. END
BEGIN NOW It is by a succession of such like transactions that men sink at last to the level of the relaxed morality of this epoch, when there have never been so few of those who square their courses with their theories, so few of those noble characters who do not yield to temptation, for whom the slightest deviation from the line of rectitude is a crime. END
BEGIN NOW To these magnificent types of uncompromising Right we owe two masterpieces&mdash;the Alceste of Moliere, and, in our own day, the characters of Jeanie Deans and her father in Sir Walter Scott's novel. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps a work which should chronicle the opposite course, which should trace out all the devious courses through which a man of the world, a man of ambitions, drags his conscience, just steering clear of crime that he may gain his end and yet save appearances, such a chronicle would be no less edifying and no less dramatic. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac went home. END
BEGIN NOW He was fascinated by de Nucingen; he seemed to see her before him, slender and graceful as a swallow. END
BEGIN NOW He recalled the intoxicating sweetness of her eyes, her fair hair, the delicate silken tissue of the skin, beneath which it almost seemed to him that he could see the blood coursing; the tones of her voice still exerted a spell over him; he had forgotten nothing; his walk perhaps heated his imagination by sending a glow of warmth through his veins. END
BEGIN NOW He knocked unceremoniously at Goriot's door. END
BEGIN NOW I have seen Delphine, neighbor, said he. END
BEGIN NOW Where? END
BEGIN NOW At the Italiens. END
BEGIN NOW Did she enjoy it?.... END
BEGIN NOW Just come inside, and the old man left his bed, unlocked the door, and promptly returned again. END
BEGIN NOW It was the first time that Eugene had been in Father Goriot's room, and he could not control his feeling of amazement at the contrast between the den in which the father lived and the costume of the daughter whom he had just beheld. END
BEGIN NOW The window was curtainless, the walls were damp, in places the varnished wall-paper had come away and gave glimpses of the grimy yellow plaster beneath. END
BEGIN NOW The wretched bed on which the old man lay boasted but one thin blanket, and a wadded quilt made out of large pieces of Vauquer's old dresses. END
BEGIN NOW The floor was damp and gritty. END
BEGIN NOW Opposite the window stood a chest of drawers made of rosewood, one of the old-fashioned kind with a curving front and brass handles, shaped like rings of twisted vine stems covered with flowers and leaves. END
BEGIN NOW On a venerable piece of furniture with a wooden shelf stood a ewer and basin and shaving apparatus. END
BEGIN NOW A pair of shoes stood in one corner; a night-table by the bed had neither a door nor marble slab. END
BEGIN NOW There was not a trace of a fire in the empty grate; the square walnut table with the crossbar against which Father Goriot had crushed and twisted his posset-dish stood near the hearth. END
BEGIN NOW The old man's hat was lying on a broken-down bureau. END
BEGIN NOW An armchair stuffed with straw and a couple of chairs completed the list of ramshackle furniture. END
BEGIN NOW From the tester of the bed, tied to the ceiling by a piece of rag, hung a strip of some cheap material in large red and black checks. END
BEGIN NOW No poor drudge in a garret could be worse lodged than Father Goriot in Vauquer's lodging-house. END
BEGIN NOW The mere sight of the room sent a chill through you and a sense of oppression; it was like the worst cell in a prison. END
BEGIN NOW Luckily, Goriot could not see the effect that his surroundings produced on Eugene as the latter deposited his candle on the night-table. END
BEGIN NOW The old man turned round, keeping the bedclothes huddled up to his chin. END
BEGIN NOW Well, he said, and which do you like the best, de Restaud or de Nucingen? END
BEGIN NOW I like Delphine the best, said the law student, because she loves you the best. END
BEGIN NOW At the words so heartily spoken the old man's hand slipped out from under the bedclothes and grasped Eugene's. END
BEGIN NOW Thank you, thank you, he said, gratefully. END
BEGIN NOW Then what did she say about me? END
BEGIN NOW The student repeated the Baroness' remarks with some embellishments of his own, the old man listening the while as though he heard a voice from Heaven. END
BEGIN NOW Dear child! END
BEGIN NOW he said. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, yes, she is very fond of me. END
BEGIN NOW But you must not believe all that she tells you about Anastasie. END
BEGIN NOW The two sisters are jealous of each other, you see, another proof of their affection. END
BEGIN NOW de Restaud is very fond of me too. END
BEGIN NOW I know she is. END
BEGIN NOW A father sees his children as God sees all of us; he looks into the very depths of their hearts; he knows their intentions; and both of them are so loving. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW if I only had good sons-in-law, I should be too happy, and I dare say there is no perfect happiness here below. END
BEGIN NOW If I might live with them&mdash;simply hear their voices, know that they are there, see them go and come as I used to do at home when they were still with me; why, my heart bounds at the thought.... END
BEGIN NOW Were they nicely dressed? END
BEGIN NOW Yes, said Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW But, M. Goriot, how is it that your daughters have such fine houses, while you live in such a den as this? END
BEGIN NOW Dear me, why should I want anything better? END
BEGIN NOW he replied, with seeming carelessness. END
BEGIN NOW I can't quite explain to you how it is; I am not used to stringing words together properly, but it all lies there&mdash;- he said, tapping his heart. END
BEGIN NOW My real life is in my two girls, you see; and so long as they are happy, and smartly dressed, and have soft carpets under their feet, what does it matter what clothes I wear or where I lie down of a night? END
BEGIN NOW I shall never feel cold so long as they are warm; I shall never feel dull if they are laughing. END
BEGIN NOW I have no troubles but theirs. END
BEGIN NOW When you, too, are a father, and you hear your children's little voices, you will say to yourself, 'That has all come from me.' END
BEGIN NOW You will feel that those little ones are akin to every drop in your veins, that they are the very flower of your life (and what else are they? END
BEGIN NOW ); you will cleave so closely to them that you seem to feel every movement that they make. END
BEGIN NOW Everywhere I hear their voices sounding in my ears. END
BEGIN NOW If they are sad, the look in their eyes freezes my blood. END
BEGIN NOW Some day you will find out that there is far more happiness in another's happiness than in your own. END
BEGIN NOW It is something that I cannot explain, something within that sends a glow of warmth all through you. END
BEGIN NOW In short, I live my life three times over. END
BEGIN NOW Shall I tell you something funny? END
BEGIN NOW Well, then, since I have been a father, I have come to understand God. END
BEGIN NOW He is everywhere in the world, because the whole world comes from Him. END
BEGIN NOW And it is just the same with my children, monsieur. END
BEGIN NOW Only, I love my daughters better than God loves the world, for the world is not so beautiful as God Himself is, but my children are more beautiful than I am. END
BEGIN NOW Their lives are so bound up with mine that I felt somehow that you would see them this evening. END
BEGIN NOW Great Heaven! END
BEGIN NOW If any man would make my little Delphine as happy as a wife is when she is loved, I would black his boots and run on his errands. END
BEGIN NOW That miserable M. de Marsay is a cur; I know all about him from her maid. END
BEGIN NOW A longing to wring his neck comes over me now and then. END
BEGIN NOW He does not love her! END
BEGIN NOW does not love a pearl of a woman, with a voice like a nightingale and shaped like a model. END
BEGIN NOW Where can her eyes have been when she married that great lump of an Alsatian? END
BEGIN NOW They ought both of them to have married young men, good-looking and good-tempered&mdash;but, after all, they had their own way. END
BEGIN NOW Father Goriot was sublime. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene had never yet seen his face light up as it did now with the passionate fervor of a father's love. END
BEGIN NOW It is worthy of remark that strong feeling has a very subtle and pervasive power; the roughest nature, in the endeavor to express a deep and sincere affection, communicates to others the influence that has put resonance into the voice, and eloquence into every gesture, wrought a change in the very features of the speaker; for under the inspiration of passion the stupidest human being attains to the highest eloquence of ideas, if not of language, and seems to move in some sphere of light. END
BEGIN NOW In the old man's tones and gesture there was something just then of the same spell that a great actor exerts over his audience. END
BEGIN NOW But does not the poet in us find expression in our affections? END
BEGIN NOW Well, said Eugene, perhaps you will not be sorry to hear that she is pretty sure to break with de Marsay before long. END
BEGIN NOW That sprig of fashion has left her for the Princesse Galathionne. END
BEGIN NOW For my part, I fell in love with Delphine this evening. END
BEGIN NOW Stuff! END
BEGIN NOW said Father Goriot. END
BEGIN NOW I did indeed, and she did not regard me with aversion. END
BEGIN NOW For a whole hour we talked of love, and I am to go to call on her on Saturday, the day after to-morrow. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW how I should love you, if she should like you. END
BEGIN NOW You are kind-hearted; you would never make her miserable. END
BEGIN NOW If you were to forsake her, I would cut your throat at once. END
BEGIN NOW A woman does not love twice, you see! END
BEGIN NOW Good heavens! END
BEGIN NOW what nonsense I am talking, M. Eugene! END
BEGIN NOW It is cold; you ought not to stay here. END
BEGIN NOW _Mon Dieu!_ so you have heard her speak? END
BEGIN NOW What message did she give you for me? END
BEGIN NOW None at all, said Eugene to himself; aloud he answered, She told me to tell you that your daughter sends you a good kiss. END
BEGIN NOW Good-night, neighbor! END
BEGIN NOW Sleep well, and pleasant dreams to you! END
BEGIN NOW I have mine already made for me by that message from her. END
BEGIN NOW May God grant you all your desires! END
BEGIN NOW You have come in like a good angel on me to-night, and brought with you the air that my daughter breathes. END
BEGIN NOW Poor old fellow! END
BEGIN NOW said Eugene as he lay down. END
BEGIN NOW It is enough to melt a heart of stone. END
BEGIN NOW His daughter no more thought of him than of the Grand Turk. END
BEGIN NOW Ever after this conference Goriot looked upon his neighbor as a friend, a confidant such as he had never hoped to find; and there was established between the two the only relationship that could attach this old man to another man. END
BEGIN NOW The passions never miscalculate. END
BEGIN NOW Father Goriot felt that this friendship brought him closer to his daughter Delphine; he thought that he should find a warmer welcome for himself if the Baroness should care for Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW Moreover, he had confided one of his troubles to the younger man. END
BEGIN NOW de Nucingen, for whose happiness he prayed a thousand times daily, had never known the joys of love. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene was certainly (to make use of his own expression) one of the nicest young men that he had ever seen, and some prophetic instinct seemed to tell him that Eugene was to give her the happiness which had not been hers. END
BEGIN NOW These were the beginnings of a friendship that grew up between the old man and his neighbor; but for this friendship the catastrophe of the drama must have remained a mystery. END
BEGIN NOW The affection with which Father Goriot regarded Eugene, by whom he seated himself at breakfast, the change in Goriot's face, which as a rule, looked as expressionless as a plaster cast, and a few words that passed between the two, surprised the other lodgers. END
BEGIN NOW Vautrin, who saw Eugene for the first time since their interview, seemed as if he would fain read the student's very soul. END
BEGIN NOW During the night Eugene had had some time in which to scan the vast field which lay before him; and now, as he remembered yesterday's proposal, the thought of Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Taillefer's dowry came, of course, to his mind, and he could not help thinking of Victorine as the most exemplary youth may think of an heiress. END
BEGIN NOW It chanced that their eyes met. END
BEGIN NOW The poor girl did not fail to see that Eugene looked very handsome in his new clothes. END
BEGIN NOW So much was said in the glance, thus exchanged, that Eugene could not doubt but that he was associated in her mind with the vague hopes that lie dormant in a girl's heart and gather round the first attractive newcomer. END
BEGIN NOW Eight hundred thousand francs! END
BEGIN NOW a voice cried in his ears, but suddenly he took refuge in the memories of yesterday evening, thinking that his extemporized passion for de Nucingen was a talisman that would preserve him from this temptation. END
BEGIN NOW They gave Rossini's _Barber of Seville_ at the Italiens yesterday evening, he remarked. END
BEGIN NOW I never heard such delicious music. END
BEGIN NOW Good gracious! END
BEGIN NOW how lucky people are to have a box at the Italiens! END
BEGIN NOW Father Goriot drank in every word that Eugene let fall, and watched him as a dog watches his master's slightest movement. END
BEGIN NOW You men are like fighting cocks, said Vauquer; you do what you like. END
BEGIN NOW How did you get back? END
BEGIN NOW inquired Vautrin. END
BEGIN NOW I walked, answered Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW For my own part, remarked the tempter, I do not care about doing things by halves. END
BEGIN NOW If I want to enjoy myself that way, I should prefer to go in my carriage, sit in my own box, and do the thing comfortably. END
BEGIN NOW Everything or nothing; that is my motto. END
BEGIN NOW And a good one, too, commented Vauquer. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps you will see de Nucingen to-day, said Eugene, addressing Goriot in an undertone. END
BEGIN NOW She will welcome you with open arms, I am sure; she would want to ask you for all sorts of little details about me. END
BEGIN NOW I have found out that she will do anything in the world to be known by my cousin de Beauseant; don't forget to tell her that I love her too well not to think of trying to arrange this. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac went at once to the Ecole de Droit. END
BEGIN NOW He had no mind to stay a moment longer than was necessary in that odious house. END
BEGIN NOW He wasted his time that day; he had fallen a victim to that fever of the brain that accompanies the too vivid hopes of youth. END
BEGIN NOW Vautrin's arguments had set him meditating on social life, and he was deep in these reflections when he happened on his friend Bianchon in the Jardin du Luxembourg. END
BEGIN NOW What makes you look so solemn? END
BEGIN NOW said the medical student, putting an arm through Eugene's as they went towards the Palais. END
BEGIN NOW I am tormented by temptations. END
BEGIN NOW What kind? END
BEGIN NOW There is a cure for temptation. END
BEGIN NOW What? END
BEGIN NOW Yielding to it. END
BEGIN NOW You laugh, but you don't know what it is all about. END
BEGIN NOW Have you read Rousseau? END
BEGIN NOW Yes. END
BEGIN NOW Do you remember that he asks the reader somewhere what he would do if he could make a fortune by killing an old mandarin somewhere in China by mere force of wishing it, and without stirring from Paris? END
BEGIN NOW Yes. END
BEGIN NOW Well, then? END
BEGIN NOW Pshaw! END
BEGIN NOW I am at my thirty-third mandarin. END
BEGIN NOW Seriously, though. END
BEGIN NOW Look here, suppose you were sure that you could do it, and had only to give a nod. END
BEGIN NOW Would you do it? END
BEGIN NOW Is he well stricken in years, this mandarin of yours? END
BEGIN NOW Pshaw! END
BEGIN NOW after all, young or old, paralytic, or well and sound, my word for it.\... Well, then. END
BEGIN NOW Hang it, no! END
BEGIN NOW You are a good fellow, Bianchon. END
BEGIN NOW But suppose you loved a woman well enough to lose your soul in hell for her, and that she wanted money for dresses and a carriage, and all her whims, in fact? END
BEGIN NOW Why, here you are taking away my reason, and want me to reason! END
BEGIN NOW Well, then, Bianchon, I am mad; bring me to my senses. END
BEGIN NOW I have two sisters as beautiful and innocent as angels, and I want them to be happy. END
BEGIN NOW How am I to find two hundred thousand francs apiece for them in the next five years? END
BEGIN NOW Now and then in life, you see, you must play for heavy stakes, and it is no use wasting your luck on low play. END
BEGIN NOW But you are only stating the problem that lies before every one at the outset of his life, and you want to cut the Gordian knot with a sword. END
BEGIN NOW If that is the way of it, dear boy, you must be an Alexander, or to the hulks you go. END
BEGIN NOW For my own part, I am quite contented with the little lot I mean to make for myself somewhere in the country, when I mean to step into my father's shoes and plod along. END
BEGIN NOW A man's affections are just as fully satisfied by the smallest circle as they can be by a vast circumference. END
BEGIN NOW Napoleon himself could only dine once, and he could not have more mistresses than a house student at the Capuchins. END
BEGIN NOW Happiness, old man, depends on what lies between the sole of your foot and the crown of your head; and whether it costs a million or a hundred louis, the actual amount of pleasure that you receive rests entirely with you, and is just exactly the same in any case. END
BEGIN NOW I am for letting that Chinaman live. END
BEGIN NOW Thank you, Bianchon; you have done me good. END
BEGIN NOW We will always be friends. END
BEGIN NOW I say, remarked the medical student, as they came to the end of a broad walk in the Jardin des Plantes, I saw the Michonneau and Poiret a few minutes ago on a bench chatting with a gentleman whom I used to see in last year's troubles hanging about the Chamber of Deputies; he seems to me, in fact, to be a detective dressed up like a decent retired tradesman. END
BEGIN NOW Let us keep an eye on that couple; I will tell you why some time. END
BEGIN NOW Good-bye; it is nearly four o'clock, and I must be in to answer to my name. END
BEGIN NOW When Eugene reached the lodging-house, he found Father Goriot waiting for him. END
BEGIN NOW Here, cried the old man, here is a letter from her. END
BEGIN NOW Pretty handwriting, eh? END
BEGIN NOW Eugene broke the seal and read:&mdash; Sir,&mdash;I have heard from my father that you are fond of Italian music. END
BEGIN NOW I shall be delighted if you will do me the pleasure of accepting a seat in my box. END
BEGIN NOW La Fodor and Pellegrini will sing on Saturday, so I am sure that you will not refuse me. END
BEGIN NOW M. de Nucingen and I shall be pleased if you will dine with us; we shall be quite by ourselves. END
BEGIN NOW If you will come and be my escort, my husband will be glad to be relieved from his conjugal duties. END
BEGIN NOW Do not answer, but simply come.&mdash;Yours sincerely, D. DE N. Let me see it, said Father Goriot, when Eugene had read the letter. END
BEGIN NOW You are going, aren't you? END
BEGIN NOW he added, when he had smelled the writing-paper. END
BEGIN NOW How nice it smells! END
BEGIN NOW Her fingers have touched it, that is certain. END
BEGIN NOW A woman does not fling herself at a man's head in this way, the student was thinking. END
BEGIN NOW She wants to use me to bring back de Marsay; nothing but pique makes a woman do a thing like this. END
BEGIN NOW Well, said Father Goriot, what are you thinking about? END
BEGIN NOW Eugene did not know the fever or vanity that possessed some women in those days; how should he imagine that to open a door in the Faubourg Saint-Germain a banker's wife would go to almost any length. END
BEGIN NOW For the coterie of the Faubourg Saint-Germain was a charmed circle, and the women who moved in it were at that time the queens of society; and among the greatest of these _Dames du Petit-Chateau_, as they were called, were de Beauseant and her friends the Duchesse de Langeais and the Duchesse de Maufrigneause. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac was alone in his ignorance of the frantic efforts made by women who lived in the Chausee-d'Antin to enter this seventh heaven and shine among the brightest constellations of their sex. END
BEGIN NOW But his cautious disposition stood him in good stead, and kept his judgment cool, and the not altogether enviable power of imposing instead of accepting conditions. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, I am going, he replied. END
BEGIN NOW So it was curiosity that drew him to de Nucingen; while, if she had treated him disdainfully, passion perhaps might have brought him to her feet. END
BEGIN NOW Still he waited almost impatiently for to-morrow, and the hour when he could go to her. END
BEGIN NOW There is almost as much charm for a young man in a first flirtation as there is in first love. END
BEGIN NOW The certainty of success is a source of happiness to which men do not confess, and all the charm of certain women lies in this. END
BEGIN NOW The desire of conquest springs no less from the easiness than from the difficulty of triumph, and every passion is excited or sustained by one or the other of these two motives which divide the empire of love. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps this division is one result of the great question of temperaments; which, after all, dominates social life. END
BEGIN NOW The melancholic temperament may stand in need of the tonic of coquetry, while those of nervous or sanguine complexion withdraw if they meet with a too stubborn resistance. END
BEGIN NOW In other words, the lymphatic temperament is essentially despondent, and the rhapsodic is bilious. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene lingered over his toilette with an enjoyment of all its little details that is grateful to a young man's self-love, though he will not own to it for fear of being laughed at. END
BEGIN NOW He thought, as he arranged his hair, that a pretty woman's glances would wander through the dark curls. END
BEGIN NOW He indulged in childish tricks like any young girl dressing for a dance, and gazed complacently at his graceful figure while he smoothed out the creases of his coat. END
BEGIN NOW There are worse figures, that is certain, he said to himself. END
BEGIN NOW Then he went downstairs, just as the rest of the household were sitting down to dinner, and took with good humor the boisterous applause excited by his elegant appearance. END
BEGIN NOW The amazement with which any attention to dress is regarded in a lodging-house is a very characteristic trait. END
BEGIN NOW No one can put on a new coat but every one else must say his say about it. END
BEGIN NOW Clk! END
BEGIN NOW clk! END
BEGIN NOW clk! END
BEGIN NOW cried Bianchon, making the sound with his tongue against the roof of his mouth, like a driver urging on a horse. END
BEGIN NOW He holds himself like a duke and a peer of France, said Vauquer. END
BEGIN NOW Are you going a-courting? END
BEGIN NOW inquired Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau. END
BEGIN NOW Cock-a-doodle-doo! END
BEGIN NOW cried the artist. END
BEGIN NOW My compliments to my lady your wife, from the _employe_ at the Museum. END
BEGIN NOW Your wife; have you a wife? END
BEGIN NOW asked Poiret. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, in compartments, water-tight and floats, guaranteed fast color, all prices from twenty-five to forty sous, neat check patterns in the latest fashion and best taste, will wash, half-linen, half-cotton, half-wool; a certain cure for toothache and other complaints under the patronage of the Royal College of Physicians! END
BEGIN NOW children like it! END
BEGIN NOW a remedy for headache, indigestion, and all other diseases affecting the throat, eyes, and ears! END

BEGIN NOW And how much shall we say for this marvel, gentlemen? END
BEGIN NOW Twopence? END
BEGIN NOW No. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing of the sort. END
BEGIN NOW All that is left in stock after supplying the Great Mogul. END
BEGIN NOW All the crowned heads of Europe, including the Gr-r-rand Duke of Baden, have been anxious to get a sight of it. END

BEGIN NOW walk up! END
BEGIN NOW gentlemen! END
BEGIN NOW Pay at the desk as you go in! END

BEGIN NOW la, la, boum! END
BEGIN NOW boum! END

BEGIN NOW he added gruffly; I will rap your knuckles for you! END
BEGIN NOW Goodness! END
BEGIN NOW what an amusing man! END
BEGIN NOW said Vauquer to Couture; I should never feel dull with him in the house. END

BEGIN NOW The cab is at the door, announced Sylvie. END
BEGIN NOW But where is he going to dine? END
BEGIN NOW asked Bianchon. END
BEGIN NOW With Madame la Baronne de Nucingen. END
BEGIN NOW M. Goriot's daughter, said the law student. END
BEGIN NOW At this, all eyes turned to the old vermicelli maker; he was gazing at Eugene with something like envy in his eyes. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac reached the house in the Rue Saint-Lazare, one of those many-windowed houses with a mean-looking portico and slender columns, which are considered the thing in Paris, a typical banker's house, decorated in the most ostentatious fashion; the walls lined with stucco, the landings of marble mosaic. END
BEGIN NOW de Nucingen was sitting in a little drawing-room; the room was painted in the Italian fashion, and decorated like a restaurant. END
BEGIN NOW The Baroness seemed depressed. END
BEGIN NOW The effort that she made to hide her feelings aroused Eugene's interest; it was plain that she was not playing a part. END
BEGIN NOW He had expected a little flutter of excitement at his coming, and he found her dispirited and sad. END
BEGIN NOW The disappointment piqued his vanity. END
BEGIN NOW My claim to your confidence is very small, madame, he said, after rallying her on her abstracted mood; but if I am in the way, please tell me so frankly; I count on your good faith. END
BEGIN NOW No, stay with me, she said; I shall be all alone if you go. END
BEGIN NOW Nucingen is dining in town, and I do not want to be alone; I want to be taken out of myself. END
BEGIN NOW But what is the matter? END
BEGIN NOW You are the very last person whom I should tell, she exclaimed. END
BEGIN NOW Then I am connected in some way in this secret. END
BEGIN NOW I wonder what it is? END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps. END
BEGIN NOW Yet, no, she went on; it is a domestic quarrel, which ought to be buried in the depths of the heart. END
BEGIN NOW I am very unhappy; did I not tell you so the day before yesterday? END
BEGIN NOW Golden chains are the heaviest of all fetters. END
BEGIN NOW When a woman tells a young man that she is very unhappy, and when the young man is clever, and well dressed, and has fifteen hundred francs lying idle in his pocket, he is sure to think as Eugene said, and he becomes a coxcomb. END
BEGIN NOW What can you have left to wish for? END
BEGIN NOW he answered. END
BEGIN NOW You are young, beautiful, beloved, and rich. END
BEGIN NOW Do not let us talk of my affairs, she said shaking her head mournfully. END
BEGIN NOW We will dine together _tete-a-tete_, and afterwards we will go to hear the most exquisite music. END
BEGIN NOW Am I to your taste? END
BEGIN NOW she went on, rising and displaying her gown of white cashmere, covered with Persian designs in the most superb taste. END
BEGIN NOW I wish that you were altogether mine, said Eugene; you are charming. END
BEGIN NOW You would have a forlorn piece of property, she said, smiling bitterly. END
BEGIN NOW There is nothing about me that betrays my wretchedness; and yet, in spite of appearances, I am in despair. END
BEGIN NOW I cannot sleep; my troubles have broken my night's rest; I shall grow ugly. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW that is impossible, cried the law student; but I am curious to know what these troubles can be that a devoted love cannot efface. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW if I were to tell you about them, you would shun me, she said. END
BEGIN NOW Your love for me is as yet only the conventional gallantry that men use to masquerade in; and, if you really loved me, you would be driven to despair. END
BEGIN NOW I must keep silence, you see. END
BEGIN NOW Let us talk of something else, for pity's sake, she added. END
BEGIN NOW Let me show you my rooms. END
BEGIN NOW No; let us stay here, answered Eugene; he sat down on the sofa before the fire, and boldly took de Nucingen's hand in his. END
BEGIN NOW She surrendered it to him; he even felt the pressure of her fingers in one of the spasmodic clutches that betray terrible agitation. END
BEGIN NOW Listen, said Rastignac; if you are in trouble, you ought to tell me about it. END

BEGIN NOW You must speak to me frankly about your troubles, so that I can put an end to them, even if I have to kill half-a-dozen men; or I shall go, never to return. END

BEGIN NOW She rang the bell. END
BEGIN NOW Are the horses put in for the master? END
BEGIN NOW she asked of the servant. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, madame. END

BEGIN NOW He can have mine and my horses. END

BEGIN NOW When the carriage stopped at last, the Baroness gave the law student a glance that silenced his wild words, for he was almost beside himself. END
BEGIN NOW Is it true that you love me? END
BEGIN NOW she asked. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, he answered, and in his manner and tone there was no trace of the uneasiness that he felt. END

BEGIN NOW No. END
BEGIN NOW Are you ready to do my bidding? END
BEGIN NOW Blindly. END
BEGIN NOW Have you ever been to a gaming-house? END
BEGIN NOW she asked in a tremulous voice. END
BEGIN NOW Never. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW now I can breathe. END
BEGIN NOW You will have luck. END
BEGIN NOW Here is my purse, she said. END
BEGIN NOW Take it! END
BEGIN NOW there are a hundred francs in it, all that such a fortunate woman as I can call her own. END
BEGIN NOW Go up into one of the gaming-houses&mdash;I do not know where they are, but there are some near the Palais-Royal. END

BEGIN NOW Devil take me, I'm sure, if I have a glimmer of a notion of what I am about, but I will obey you, he added, with inward exultation, as he thought, She has gone too far to draw back&mdash;she can refuse me nothing now! END
BEGIN NOW Eugene took the dainty little purse, inquired the way of a second-hand clothes-dealer, and hurried to number , which happened to be the nearest gaming-house. END
BEGIN NOW He mounted the staircase, surrendered his hat, and asked the way to the roulette-table, whither the attendant took him, not a little to the astonishment of the regular comers. END
BEGIN NOW All eyes were fixed on Eugene as he asked, without bashfulness, where he was to deposit his stakes. END
BEGIN NOW If you put a louis on one only of those thirty-six numbers, and it turns up, you will win thirty-six louis, said a respectable-looking, white-haired old man in answer to his inquiry. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene staked the whole of his money on the number (his own age). END
BEGIN NOW There was a cry of surprise; before he knew what he had done, he had won. END
BEGIN NOW Take your money off, sir, said the old gentleman; you don't often win twice running by that system. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene took the rake that the old man handed to him, and drew in his three thousand six hundred francs, and, still perfectly ignorant of what he was about, staked again on the red. END
BEGIN NOW The bystanders watched him enviously as they saw him continue to play. END
BEGIN NOW The disc turned, and again he won; the banker threw him three thousand six hundred francs once more. END
BEGIN NOW You have seven thousand, two hundred francs of your own, the old gentleman said in his ear. END
BEGIN NOW Take my advice and go away with your winnings; red has turned up eight times already. END
BEGIN NOW If you are charitable, you will show your gratitude for sound counsel by giving a trifle to an old prefect of Napoleon who is down on his luck. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac's head was swimming; he saw ten of his louis pass into the white-haired man's possession, and went down-stairs with his seven thousand francs; he was still ignorant of the game, and stupefied by his luck. END
BEGIN NOW So, that is over; and now where will you take me? END
BEGIN NOW he asked, as soon as the door was closed, and he showed the seven thousand francs to de Nucingen. END
BEGIN NOW Delphine flung her arms about him, but there was no passion in that wild embrace. END
BEGIN NOW You have saved me! END
BEGIN NOW she cried, and tears of joy flowed fast. END
BEGIN NOW I will tell you everything, my friend. END
BEGIN NOW For you will be my friend, will you not? END
BEGIN NOW I am rich, you think, very rich; I have everything I want, or I seem as if I had everything. END
BEGIN NOW Very well, you must know that M. de Nucingen does not allow me the control of a single penny; he pays all the bills for the house expenses; he pays for my carriages and opera box; he does not give me enough to pay for my dress, and he reduces me to poverty in secret on purpose. END
BEGIN NOW I am too proud to beg from him. END
BEGIN NOW I should be the vilest of women if I could take his money at the price at which he offers it. END
BEGIN NOW Do you ask how I, with seven hundred thousand francs of my own, could let myself be robbed? END

BEGIN NOW We are so young, so artless when our married life begins! END
BEGIN NOW I never could bring myself to ask my husband for money; the words would have made my lips bleed, I did not dare to ask; I spent my savings first, and then the money that my poor father gave me, then I ran into debt. END
BEGIN NOW Marriage for me is a hideous farce; I cannot talk about it, let it suffice to say that Nucingen and I have separate rooms, and that I would fling myself out of the window sooner than consent to any other manner of life. END
BEGIN NOW I suffered agonies when I had to confess to my girlish extravagance, my debts for jewelry and trifles (for our poor father had never refused us anything, and spoiled us), but at last I found courage to tell him about them. END
BEGIN NOW After all, I had a fortune of my own. END
BEGIN NOW Nucingen flew into a rage; he said that I should be the ruin of him, and used frightful language! END
BEGIN NOW I wished myself a hundred feet down in the earth. END
BEGIN NOW He had my dowry, so he paid my debts, but he stipulated at the same time that my expenses in future must not exceed a certain fixed sum, and I gave way for the sake of peace. END
BEGIN NOW And then, she went on, I wanted to gratify the self-love of some one whom you know. END
BEGIN NOW He may have deceived me, but I should do him the justice to say that there was nothing petty in his character. END
BEGIN NOW But, after all, he threw me over disgracefully. END
BEGIN NOW If, at a woman's utmost need, _somebody_ heaps gold upon her, he ought never to forsake her; that love should last for ever! END
BEGIN NOW But you, at one-and-twenty, you, the soul of honor, with the unsullied conscience of youth, will ask me how a woman can bring herself to accept money in such a way? END
BEGIN NOW _Mon Dieu_! END
BEGIN NOW is it not natural to share everything with the one to whom we owe our happiness? END
BEGIN NOW When all has been given, why should we pause and hesitate over a part? END
BEGIN NOW Money is as nothing between us until the moment when the sentiment that bound us together ceases to exist. END
BEGIN NOW Were we not bound to each other for life? END
BEGIN NOW Who that believes in love foresees such an end to love? END
BEGIN NOW You swear to love us eternally; how, then, can our interests be separate? END
BEGIN NOW You do not know how I suffered to-day when Nucingen refused to give me six thousand francs; he spends as much as that every month on his mistress, an opera dancer! END
BEGIN NOW I thought of killing myself. END
BEGIN NOW The wildest thoughts came into my head. END
BEGIN NOW There have been moments in my life when I have envied my servants, and would have changed places with my maid. END
BEGIN NOW It was madness to think of going to our father, Anastasie and I have bled him dry; our poor father would have sold himself if he could have raised six thousand francs that way. END
BEGIN NOW I should have driven him frantic to no purpose. END
BEGIN NOW You have saved me from shame and death; I was beside myself with anguish. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW monsieur, I owed you this explanation after my mad ravings. END
BEGIN NOW When you left me just now, as soon as you were out of sight, I longed to escape, to run away... where, I did not know. END
BEGIN NOW Half the women in Paris lead such lives as mine; they live in apparent luxury, and in their souls are tormented by anxiety. END
BEGIN NOW I know of poor creatures even more miserable than I; there are women who are driven to ask their tradespeople to make out false bills, women who rob their husbands. END
BEGIN NOW Some men believe that an Indian shawl worth a thousand louis only cost five hundred francs, others that a shawl costing five hundred francs is worth a hundred louis. END
BEGIN NOW There are women, too, with narrow incomes, who scrape and save and starve their children to pay for a dress. END
BEGIN NOW I am innocent of these base meannesses. END
BEGIN NOW But this is the last extremity of my torture. END
BEGIN NOW Some women will sell themselves to their husbands, and so obtain their way, but I, at any rate, am free. END
BEGIN NOW If I chose, Nucingen would cover me with gold, but I would rather weep on the breast of a man whom I can respect. END

BEGIN NOW tonight, M. de Marsay will no longer have a right to think of me as a woman whom he has paid. END

BEGIN NOW It is hideous, is it not, she cried, to speak in a breath of money and affection. END
BEGIN NOW You cannot love me after this, she added. END
BEGIN NOW The incongruity between the ideas of honor which make women so great, and the errors in conduct which are forced upon them by the constitution of society, had thrown Eugene's thoughts into confusion; he uttered soothing and consoling words, and wondered at the beautiful woman before him, and at the artless imprudence of her cry of pain. END

BEGIN NOW she asked; promise me that you will not. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END

BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW see what it is to have been well brought up. END

BEGIN NOW Rastignac gave his arm to de Nucingen, she led the way into a pretty dining-room, and again he saw the luxury of the table which he had admired in his cousin's house. END
