BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW you will succeed, she said laughing. END
BEGIN NOW You will see. END
BEGIN NOW All that you wish will come to pass. END
BEGIN NOW _I_ did not expect to be so happy. END
BEGIN NOW It is the wont of women to prove the impossible by the possible, and to annihilate facts by presentiments. END
BEGIN NOW When de Nucingen and Rastignac took their places in her box at the Bouffons, her face wore a look of happiness that made her so lovely that every one indulged in those small slanders against which women are defenceless; for the scandal that is uttered lightly is often seriously believed. END
BEGIN NOW Those who know Paris, believe nothing that is said, and say nothing of what is done there. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene took the Baroness' hand in his, and by some light pressure of the fingers, or a closer grasp of the hand, they found a language in which to express the sensations which the music gave them. END
BEGIN NOW It was an evening of intoxicating delight for both; and when it ended, and they went out together, de Nucingen insisted on taking Eugene with her as far as the Pont Neuf, he disputing with her the whole of the way for a single kiss after all those that she had showered upon him so passionately at the Palais-Royal; Eugene reproached her with inconsistency. END
BEGIN NOW That was gratitude, she said, for devotion that I did not dare to hope for, but now it would be a promise. END
BEGIN NOW And will you give me no promise, ingrate? END
BEGIN NOW He grew vexed. END
BEGIN NOW Then, with one of those impatient gestures that fill a lover with ecstasy, she gave him her hand to kiss, and he took it with a discontented air that delighted her. END
BEGIN NOW I shall see you at the ball on Monday, she said. END
BEGIN NOW As Eugene went home in the moonlight, he fell to serious reflections. END
BEGIN NOW He was satisfied, and yet dissatisfied. END
BEGIN NOW He was pleased with an adventure which would probably give him his desire, for in the end one of the prettiest and best-dressed women in Paris would be his; but, as a set-off, he saw his hopes of fortune brought to nothing; and as soon as he realized this fact, the vague thoughts of yesterday evening began to take a more decided shape in his mind. END
BEGIN NOW A check is sure to reveal to us the strength of our hopes. END
BEGIN NOW The more Eugene learned of the pleasures of life in Paris, the more impatient he felt of poverty and obscurity. END
BEGIN NOW He crumpled the banknote in his pocket, and found any quantity of plausible excuses for appropriating it. END
BEGIN NOW He reached the Rue Neuve-Sainte-Genevieve at last, and from the stairhead he saw a light in Goriot's room; the old man had lighted a candle, and set the door ajar, lest the student should pass him by, and go to his room without telling him all about his daughter, to use his own expression. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene, accordingly, told him everything without reserve. END
BEGIN NOW Then they think that I am ruined! END
BEGIN NOW cried Father Goriot, in an agony of jealousy and desperation. END
BEGIN NOW Why, I have still thirteen hundred livres a year! END

BEGIN NOW I would have sold my rentes; she should have had some of the principal, and I would have bought a life-annuity with the rest. END

BEGIN NOW Oh! END

BEGIN NOW You will succeed, the old man said. END

BEGIN NOW An honest man! END
BEGIN NOW said Eugene to himself as he lay down. END
BEGIN NOW Upon my word, I think I will be an honest man all my life; it is so pleasant to obey the voice of conscience. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps none but believers in God do good in secret; and Eugene believed in a God. END
BEGIN NOW The next day Rastignac went at the appointed time to de Beauseant, who took him with her to the Duchesse de Carigliano's ball. END
BEGIN NOW The Marechale received Eugene most graciously. END
BEGIN NOW de Nucingen was there. END
BEGIN NOW Delphine's dress seemed to suggest that she wished for the admiration of others, so that she might shine the more in Eugene's eyes; she was eagerly expecting a glance from him, hiding, as she thought, this eagerness from all beholders. END
BEGIN NOW This moment is full of charm for one who can guess all that passes in a woman's mind. END
BEGIN NOW Who has not refrained from giving his opinion, to prolong her suspense, concealing his pleasure from a desire to tantalize, seeking a confession of love in her uneasiness, enjoying the fears that he can dissipate by a smile? END
BEGIN NOW In the course of the evening the law student suddenly comprehended his position; he saw that, as the cousin of de Beauseant, he was a personage in this world. END
BEGIN NOW He was already credited with the conquest of de Nucingen, and for this reason was a conspicuous figure; he caught the envious glances of other young men, and experienced the earliest pleasures of coxcombry. END
BEGIN NOW People wondered at his luck, and scraps of these conversations came to his ears as he went from room to room; all the women prophesied his success; and Delphine, in her dread of losing him, promised that this evening she would not refuse the kiss that all his entreaties could scarcely win yesterday. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac received several invitations. END
BEGIN NOW His cousin presented him to other women who were present; women who could claim to be of the highest fashion; whose houses were looked upon as pleasant; and this was the loftiest and most fashionable society in Paris into which he was launched. END
BEGIN NOW So this evening had all the charm of a brilliant debut; it was an evening that he was to remember even in old age, as a woman looks back upon her first ball and the memories of her girlish triumphs. END
BEGIN NOW The next morning, at breakfast, he related the story of his success for the benefit of Father Goriot and the lodgers. END
BEGIN NOW Vautrin began to smile in a diabolical fashion. END
BEGIN NOW And do you suppose, cried that cold-blooded logician, that a young man of fashion can live here in the Rue Neuve-Sainte-Genevieve, in the Maison Vauquer&mdash;an exceedingly respectable boarding-house in every way, I grant you, but an establishment that, none the less, falls short of being fashionable? END
BEGIN NOW The house is comfortable, it is lordly in its abundance; it is proud to be the temporary abode of a Rastignac; but, after all, it is in the Rue Neuve-Sainte-Genevieve, and luxury would be out of place here, where we only aim at the purely _patriarchalorama_. END
BEGIN NOW If you mean to cut a figure in Paris, my young friend, Vautrin continued, with half-paternal jocularity, you must have three horses, a tilbury for the mornings, and a closed carriage for the evening; you should spend altogether about nine thousand francs on your stables. END
BEGIN NOW You would show yourself unworthy of your destiny if you spent no more than three thousand francs with your tailor, six hundred in perfumery, a hundred crowns to your shoemaker, and a hundred more to your hatter. END
BEGIN NOW As for your laundress, there goes another thousand francs; a young man of fashion must of necessity make a great point of his linen; if your linen comes up to the required standard, people often do not look any further. END
BEGIN NOW Love and the Church demand a fair altar-cloth. END
BEGIN NOW That is fourteen thousand francs. END
BEGIN NOW I am saying nothing of losses at play, bets, and presents; it is impossible to allow less than two thousand francs for pocket money. END
BEGIN NOW I have led that sort of life, and I know all about these expenses. END
BEGIN NOW Add the cost of necessaries next; three hundred louis for provender, a thousand francs for a place to roost in. END
BEGIN NOW Well, my boy, for all these little wants of ours we had need to have twenty-five thousand francs every year in our purse, or we shall find ourselves in the kennel, and people laughing at us, and our career is cut short, good-bye to success, and good-bye to your mistress! END
BEGIN NOW I am forgetting your valet and your groom! END
BEGIN NOW Is Christophe going to carry your _billets-doux_ for you? END
BEGIN NOW Do you mean to employ the stationery you use at present? END
BEGIN NOW Suicidal policy! END
BEGIN NOW Hearken to the wisdom of your elders! END
BEGIN NOW he went on, his bass voice growing louder at each syllable. END
BEGIN NOW Either take up your quarters in a garret, live virtuously, and wed your work, or set about the thing in a different way. END
BEGIN NOW Vautrin winked and leered in the direction of Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Taillefer to enforce his remarks by a look which recalled the late tempting proposals by which he had sought to corrupt the student's mind. END
BEGIN NOW Several days went by, and Rastignac lived in a whirl of gaiety. END
BEGIN NOW He dined almost every day with de Nucingen, and went wherever she went, only returning to the Rue Neuve-Sainte-Genevieve in the small hours. END
BEGIN NOW He rose at mid-day, and dressed to go into the Bois with Delphine if the day was fine, squandering in this way time that was worth far more than he knew. END
BEGIN NOW He turned as eagerly to learn the lessons of luxury, and was as quick to feel its fascination, as the flowers of the date palm to receive the fertilizing pollen. END
BEGIN NOW He played high, lost and won large sums of money, and at last became accustomed to the extravagant life that young men lead in Paris. END
BEGIN NOW He sent fifteen hundred francs out of his first winnings to his mother and sisters, sending handsome presents as well as the money. END
BEGIN NOW He had given out that he meant to leave the Maison Vauquer; but January came and went, and he was still there, still unprepared to go. END
BEGIN NOW One rule holds good of most young men&mdash;whether rich or poor. END
BEGIN NOW They never have money for the necessaries of life, but they have always money to spare for their caprices&mdash;an anomaly which finds its explanation in their youth and in the almost frantic eagerness with which youth grasps at pleasure. END
BEGIN NOW They are reckless with anything obtained on credit, while everything for which they must pay in ready money is made to last as long as possible; if they cannot have all that they want, they make up for it, it would seem, by squandering what they have. END
BEGIN NOW To state the matter simply&mdash;a student is far more careful of his hat than of his coat, because the latter being a comparatively costly article of dress, it is in the nature of things that a tailor should be a creditor; but it is otherwise with the hatter; the sums of money spent with him are so modest, that he is the most independent and unmanageable of his tribe, and it is almost impossible to bring him to terms. END
BEGIN NOW The young man in the balcony of a theatre who displays a gorgeous waistcoat for the benefit of the fair owners of opera glasses, has very probably no socks in his wardrobe, for the hosier is another of the genus of weevils that nibble at the purse. END
BEGIN NOW This was Rastignac's condition. END
BEGIN NOW His purse was always empty for Vauquer, always full at the demand of vanity; there was a periodical ebb and flow in his fortunes, which was seldom favorable to the payment of just debts. END
BEGIN NOW If he was to leave that unsavory and mean abode, where from time to time his pretensions met with humiliation, the first step was to pay his hostess for a month's board and lodging, and the second to purchase furniture worthy of the new lodgings he must take in his quality of dandy, a course that remained impossible. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac, out of his winnings at cards, would pay his jeweler exorbitant prices for gold watches and chains, and then, to meet the exigencies of play, would carry them to the pawnbroker, that discreet and forbidding-looking friend of youth; but when it was a question of paying for board or lodging, or for the necessary implements for the cultivation of his Elysian fields, his imagination and pluck alike deserted him. END
BEGIN NOW There was no inspiration to be found in vulgar necessity, in debts contracted for past requirements. END
BEGIN NOW Like most of those who trust to their luck, he put off till the last moment the payment of debts that among the bourgeoisie are regarded as sacred engagements, acting on the plan of Mirabeau, who never settled his baker's bill until it underwent a formidable transformation into a bill of exchange. END
BEGIN NOW It was about this time when Rastignac was down on his luck and fell into debt, that it became clear to the law student's mind that he must have some more certain source of income if he meant to live as he had been doing. END
BEGIN NOW But while he groaned over the thorny problems of his precarious situation, he felt that he could not bring himself to renounce the pleasures of this extravagant life, and decided that he must continue it at all costs. END
BEGIN NOW His dreams of obtaining a fortune appeared more and more chimerical, and the real obstacles grew more formidable. END
BEGIN NOW His initiation into the secrets of the Nucingen household had revealed to him that if he were to attempt to use this love affair as a means of mending his fortunes, he must swallow down all sense of decency, and renounce all the generous ideas which redeem the sins of youth. END
BEGIN NOW He had chosen this life of apparent splendor, but secretly gnawed by the canker worm of remorse, a life of fleeting pleasure dearly paid for by persistent pain; like _Le Distrait_ of La Bruyere, he had descended so far as to make his bed in a ditch; but (also like _Le Distrait_) he himself was uncontaminated as yet by the mire that stained his garments. END
BEGIN NOW So we have killed our mandarin, have we? END
BEGIN NOW said Bianchon one day as they left the dinner table. END
BEGIN NOW Not yet, he answered, but he is at his last gasp. END
BEGIN NOW The medical student took this for a joke, but it was not a jest. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene had dined in the house that night for the first time for a long while, and had looked thoughtful during the meal. END
BEGIN NOW He had taken his place beside Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Taillefer, and stayed through the dessert, giving his neighbor an expressive glance from time to time. END
BEGIN NOW A few of the boarders discussed the walnuts at the table, and others walked about the room, still taking part in the conversation which had begun among them. END
BEGIN NOW People usually went when they chose; the amount of time that they lingered being determined by the amount of interest that the conversation possessed for them, or by the difficulty of the process of digestion. END
BEGIN NOW In winter-time the room was seldom empty before eight o'clock, when the four women had it all to themselves, and made up for the silence previously imposed upon them by the preponderating masculine element. END
BEGIN NOW This evening Vautrin had noticed Eugene's abstractedness, and stayed in the room, though he had seemed to be in a hurry to finish his dinner and go. END
BEGIN NOW All through the talk afterwards he had kept out of the sight of the law student, who quite believed that Vautrin had left the room. END
BEGIN NOW He now took up his position cunningly in the sitting-room instead of going when the last boarders went. END
BEGIN NOW He had fathomed the young man's thoughts, and felt that a crisis was at hand. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac was, in fact, in a dilemma, which many another young man must have known. END
BEGIN NOW de Nucingen might love him, or might merely be playing with him, but in either case Rastignac had been made to experience all the alternations of hope and despair of genuine passion, and all the diplomatic arts of a Parisienne had been employed on him. END
BEGIN NOW After compromising herself by continually appearing in public with de Beauseant's cousin she still hesitated, and would not give him the lover's privileges which he appeared to enjoy. END
BEGIN NOW For a whole month she had so wrought on his senses, that at last she had made an impression on his heart. END
BEGIN NOW If in the earliest days the student had fancied himself to be master, de Nucingen had since become the stronger of the two, for she had skilfully roused and played upon every instinct, good or bad, in the two or three men comprised in a young student in Paris. END
BEGIN NOW This was not the result of deep design on her part, nor was she playing a part, for women are in a manner true to themselves even through their grossest deceit, because their actions are prompted by a natural impulse. END
BEGIN NOW It may have been that Delphine, who had allowed this young man to gain such an ascendency over her, conscious that she had been too demonstrative, was obeying a sentiment of dignity, and either repented of her concessions, or it pleased her to suspend them. END
BEGIN NOW It is so natural to a Parisienne, even when passion has almost mastered her, to hesitate and pause before taking the plunge; to probe the heart of him to whom she intrusts her future. END
BEGIN NOW And once already de Nucingen's hopes had been betrayed, and her loyalty to a selfish young lover had been despised. END
BEGIN NOW She had good reason to be suspicious. END
BEGIN NOW Or it may have been that something in Eugene's manner (for his rapid success was making a coxcomb of him) had warned her that the grotesque nature of their position had lowered her somewhat in his eyes. END
BEGIN NOW She doubtless wished to assert her dignity; he was young, and she would be great in his eyes; for the lover who had forsaken her had held her so cheap that she was determined that Eugene should not think her an easy conquest, and for this very reason&mdash;he knew that de Marsay had been his predecessor. END
BEGIN NOW Finally, after the degradation of submission to the pleasure of a heartless young rake, it was so sweet to her to wander in the flower-strewn realms of love, that it was not wonderful that she should wish to dwell a while on the prospect, to tremble with the vibrations of love, to feel the freshness of the breath of its dawn. END
BEGIN NOW The true lover was suffering for the sins of the false. END
BEGIN NOW This inconsistency is unfortunately only to be expected so long as men do not know how many flowers are mown down in a young woman's soul by the first stroke of treachery. END
BEGIN NOW Whatever her reasons may have been, Delphine was playing with Rastignac, and took pleasure in playing with him, doubtless because she felt sure of his love, and confident that she could put an end to the torture as soon as it was her royal pleasure to do so. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene's self-love was engaged; he could not suffer his first passage of love to end in a defeat, and persisted in his suit like a sportsman determined to bring down at least one partridge to celebrate his first Feast of Saint-Hubert. END
BEGIN NOW The pressure of anxiety, his wounded self-love, his despair, real or feigned, drew him nearer and nearer to this woman. END
BEGIN NOW All Paris credited him with this conquest, and yet he was conscious that he had made no progress since the day when he saw de Nucingen for the first time. END
BEGIN NOW He did not know as yet that a woman's coquetry is sometimes more delightful than the pleasure of secure possession of her love, and was possessed with helpless rage. END
BEGIN NOW If, at this time, while she denied herself to love, Eugene gathered the springtide spoils of his life, the fruit, somewhat sharp and green, and dearly bought, was no less delicious to the taste. END
BEGIN NOW There were moments when he had not a sou in his pockets, and at such times he thought in spite of his conscience of Vautrin's offer and the possibility of fortune by a marriage with Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Taillefer. END
BEGIN NOW Poverty would clamor so loudly that more than once he was on the point of yielding to the cunning temptations of the terrible sphinx, whose glance had so often exerted a strange spell over him. END
BEGIN NOW Poiret and Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau went up to their rooms; and Rastignac, thinking that he was alone with the women in the dining-room, sat between Vauquer and Couture, who was nodding over the woolen cuffs that she was knitting by the stove, and looked at Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Taillefer so tenderly that she lowered her eyes. END
BEGIN NOW Can you be in trouble, M. Eugene? END
BEGIN NOW Victorine said after a pause. END
BEGIN NOW Who has not his troubles? END
BEGIN NOW answered Rastignac. END
BEGIN NOW If we men were sure of being loved, sure of a devotion which would be our reward for the sacrifices which we are always ready to make, then perhaps we should have no troubles. END
BEGIN NOW For answer Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Taillefer only gave him a glance but it was impossible to mistake its meaning. END
BEGIN NOW You, for instance, mademoiselle; you feel sure of your heart to-day, but are you sure that it will never change? END
BEGIN NOW A smile flitted over the poor girl's lips; it seemed as if a ray of light from her soul had lighted up her face. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene was dismayed at the sudden explosion of feeling caused by his words. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW but suppose, he said, that you should be rich and happy to-morrow, suppose that a vast fortune dropped down from the clouds for you, would you still love the man whom you loved in your days of poverty? END
BEGIN NOW A charming movement of the head was her only answer. END
BEGIN NOW Even if he were very poor? END
BEGIN NOW Again the same mute answer. END
BEGIN NOW What nonsense are you talking, you two? END
BEGIN NOW exclaimed Vauquer. END
BEGIN NOW Never mind, answered Eugene; we understand each other. END
BEGIN NOW So there is to be an engagement of marriage between M. le Chevalier Eugene de Rastignac and Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Victorine Taillefer, is there? END
BEGIN NOW The words were uttered in Vautrin's deep voice, and Vautrin appeared at the door as he spoke. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW how you startled me! END
BEGIN NOW Couture and Vauquer exclaimed together. END
BEGIN NOW I might make a worse choice, said Rastignac, laughing. END
BEGIN NOW Vautrin's voice had thrown him into the most painful agitation that he had yet known. END
BEGIN NOW No bad jokes, gentlemen! END
BEGIN NOW said Couture. END
BEGIN NOW My dear, let us go upstairs. END
BEGIN NOW Vauquer followed the two ladies, meaning to pass the evening in their room, an arrangement that economized fire and candlelight. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene and Vautrin were left alone. END
BEGIN NOW I felt sure you would come round to it, said the elder man with the coolness that nothing seemed to shake. END
BEGIN NOW But stay a moment! END
BEGIN NOW I have as much delicacy as anybody else. END
BEGIN NOW Don't make up your mind on the spur of the moment; you are a little thrown off your balance just now. END
BEGIN NOW You are in debt, and I want you to come over to my way of thinking after sober reflection, and not in a fit of passion or desperation. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps you want a thousand crowns. END
BEGIN NOW There, you can have them if you like. END
BEGIN NOW The tempter took out a pocketbook, and drew thence three banknotes, which he fluttered before the student's eyes. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene was in a most painful dilemma. END
BEGIN NOW He had debts, debts of honor. END
BEGIN NOW He owed a hundred louis to the Marquis d'Ajuda and to the Count de Trailles; he had not the money, and for this reason had not dared to go to de Restaud's house, where he was expected that evening. END
BEGIN NOW It was one of those informal gatherings where tea and little cakes are handed round, but where it is possible to lose six thousand francs at whist in the course of a night. END
BEGIN NOW You must see, said Eugene, struggling to hide a convulsive tremor, that after what has passed between us, I cannot possibly lay myself under any obligation to you. END
BEGIN NOW Quite right; I should be sorry to hear you speak otherwise, answered the tempter. END
BEGIN NOW You are a fine young fellow, honorable, brave as a lion, and as gentle as a young girl. END
BEGIN NOW You would be a fine haul for the devil! END
BEGIN NOW I like youngsters of your sort. END
BEGIN NOW Get rid of one or two more prejudices, and you will see the world as it is. END
BEGIN NOW Make a little scene now and then, and act a virtuous part in it, and a man with a head on his shoulders can do exactly as he likes amid deafening applause from the fools in the gallery. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW a few days yet, and you will be with us; and if you would only be tutored by me, I would put you in the way of achieving all your ambitions. END
BEGIN NOW You should no sooner form a wish than it should be realized to the full; you should have all your desires&mdash;honors, wealth, or women. END
BEGIN NOW Civilization should flow with milk and honey for you. END
BEGIN NOW You should be our pet and favorite, our Benjamin. END
BEGIN NOW We would all work ourselves to death for you with pleasure; every obstacle should be removed from your path. END
BEGIN NOW You have a few prejudices left; so you think that I am a scoundrel, do you? END
BEGIN NOW Well, M. de Turenne, quite as honorable a man as you take yourself to be, had some little private transactions with bandits, and did not feel that his honor was tarnished. END
BEGIN NOW You would rather not lie under any obligation to me, eh? END
BEGIN NOW You need not draw back on that account, Vautrin went on, and a smile stole over his lips. END
BEGIN NOW Take these bits of paper and write across this, he added, producing a piece of stamped paper, _Accepted the sum of three thousand five hundred francs due this day twelvemonth_, and fill in the date. END
BEGIN NOW The rate of interest is stiff enough to silence any scruples on your part; it gives you the right to call me a Jew. END
BEGIN NOW You can call quits with me on the score of gratitude. END
BEGIN NOW I am quite willing that you should despise me to-day, because I am sure that you will have a kindlier feeling towards me later on. END
BEGIN NOW You will find out fathomless depths in my nature, enormous and concentrated forces that weaklings call vices, but you will never find me base or ungrateful. END
BEGIN NOW In short, I am neither a pawn nor a bishop, but a castle, a tower of strength, my boy. END
BEGIN NOW What manner of man are you? END
BEGIN NOW cried Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW Were you created to torment me? END
BEGIN NOW Why no; I am a good-natured fellow, who is willing to do a dirty piece of work to put you high and dry above the mire for the rest of your days. END
BEGIN NOW Do you ask the reason of this devotion? END
BEGIN NOW All right; I will tell you that some of these days. END
BEGIN NOW A word or two in your ear will explain it. END
BEGIN NOW I have begun by shocking you, by showing you the way to ring the changes, and giving you a sight of the mechanism of the social machine; but your first fright will go off like a conscript's terror on the battlefield. END
BEGIN NOW You will grow used to regarding men as common soldiers who have made up their minds to lose their lives for some self-constituted king. END
BEGIN NOW Times have altered strangely. END
BEGIN NOW Once you could say to a bravo, 'Here are a hundred crowns; go and kill Monsieur So-and-so for me,' and you could sup quietly after turning some one off into the dark for the least thing in the world. END
BEGIN NOW But nowadays I propose to put you in the way of a handsome fortune; you have only to nod your head, it won't compromise you in any way, and you hesitate. END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis an effeminate age. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene accepted the draft, and received the banknotes in exchange for it. END
BEGIN NOW Well, well. END
BEGIN NOW Come, now, let us talk rationally, Vautrin continued. END
BEGIN NOW I mean to leave this country in a few months' time for America, and set about planting tobacco. END
BEGIN NOW I will send you the cigars of friendship. END
BEGIN NOW If I make money at it, I will help you in your career. END
BEGIN NOW If I have no children&mdash;which will probably be the case, for I have no anxiety to raise slips of myself here&mdash;you shall inherit my fortune. END
BEGIN NOW That is what you may call standing by a man; but I myself have a liking for you. END
BEGIN NOW I have a mania, too, for devoting myself to some one else. END
BEGIN NOW I have done it before. END
BEGIN NOW You see, my boy, I live in a loftier sphere than other men do; I look on all actions as means to an end, and the end is all that I look at. END
BEGIN NOW What is a man's life to me? END
BEGIN NOW Not _that_, he said, and he snapped his thumb-nail against his teeth. END
BEGIN NOW A man, in short, is everything to me, or just nothing at all. END
BEGIN NOW Less than nothing if his name happens to be Poiret; you can crush him like a bug, he is flat and he is offensive. END
BEGIN NOW But a man is a god when he is like you; he is not a machine covered with a skin, but a theatre in which the greatest sentiments are displayed&mdash;great thoughts and feelings&mdash;and for these, and these only, I live. END
BEGIN NOW A sentiment&mdash;what is that but the whole world in a thought? END
BEGIN NOW Look at Father Goriot. END
BEGIN NOW For him, his two girls are the whole universe; they are the clue by which he finds his way through creation. END
BEGIN NOW Well, for my own part, I have fathomed the depths of life, there is only one real sentiment&mdash;comradeship between man and man. END
BEGIN NOW Pierre and Jaffier, that is my passion. END
BEGIN NOW I knew _Venice Preserved_ by heart. END
BEGIN NOW Have you met many men plucky enough when a comrade says, 'Let us bury a dead body!' END
BEGIN NOW to go and do it without a word or plaguing him by taking a high moral tone? END
BEGIN NOW I have done it myself. END
BEGIN NOW I should not talk like this to just everybody, but you are not like an ordinary man; one can talk to you, you can understand things. END
BEGIN NOW You will not dabble about much longer among the tadpoles in these swamps. END
BEGIN NOW Well, then, it is all settled. END
BEGIN NOW You will marry. END
BEGIN NOW Both of us carry our point. END
BEGIN NOW Mine is made of iron, and will never soften, he! END
BEGIN NOW he! END
BEGIN NOW Vautrin went out. END
BEGIN NOW He would not wait to hear the student's repudiation, he wished to put Eugene at his ease. END
BEGIN NOW He seemed to understand the secret springs of the faint resistance still made by the younger man; the struggles in which men seek to preserve their self-respect by justifying their blameworthy actions to themselves. END
BEGIN NOW He may do as he likes; I shall not marry Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Taillefer, that is certain, said Eugene to himself. END
BEGIN NOW He regarded this man with abhorrence, and yet the very cynicism of Vautrin's ideas, and the audacious way in which he used other men for his own ends, raised him in the student's eyes; but the thought of a compact threw Eugene into a fever of apprehension, and not until he had recovered somewhat did he dress, call for a cab, and go to de Restaud's. END
BEGIN NOW For some days the Countess had paid more and more attention to a young man whose every step seemed a triumphal progress in the great world; it seemed to her that he might be a formidable power before long. END
BEGIN NOW He paid Messieurs de Trailles and d'Ajuda, played at whist for part of the evening, and made good his losses. END
BEGIN NOW Most men who have their way to make are more or less of fatalists, and Eugene was superstitious; he chose to consider that his luck was heaven's reward for his perseverance in the right way. END
BEGIN NOW As soon as possible on the following morning he asked Vautrin whether the bill he had given was still in the other's possession; and on receiving a reply in the affirmative, he repaid the three thousand francs with a not unnatural relief. END
BEGIN NOW Everything is going on well, said Vautrin. END
BEGIN NOW But I am not your accomplice, said Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW I know, I know, Vautrin broke in. END
BEGIN NOW You are still acting like a child. END
BEGIN NOW You are making mountains out of molehills at the outset. END
BEGIN NOW Two days later, Poiret and Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau were sitting together on a bench in the sun. END
BEGIN NOW They had chosen a little frequented alley in the Jardin des Plantes, and a gentleman was chatting with them, the same person, as a matter of fact, about whom the medical student had, not without good reason, his own suspicions. END
BEGIN NOW Mademoiselle, this M. Gondureau was saying, I do not see any cause for your scruples. END
BEGIN NOW His Excellency, Monseigneur the Minister of Police&mdash;- Yes, his Excellency is taking a personal interest in the matter, said Gondureau. END
BEGIN NOW Who would think it probable that Poiret, a retired clerk, doubtless possessed of some notions of civic virtue, though there might be nothing else in his head&mdash;who would think it likely that such a man would continue to lend an ear to this supposed independent gentleman of the Rue de Buffon, when the latter dropped the mask of a decent citizen by that word police, and gave a glimpse of the features of a detective from the Rue de Jerusalem? END
BEGIN NOW And yet nothing was more natural. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps the following remarks from the hitherto unpublished records made by certain observers will throw a light on the particular species to which Poiret belonged in the great family of fools. END
BEGIN NOW There is a race of quill-drivers, confined in the columns of the budget between the first degree of latitude (a kind of administrative Greenland where the salaries begin at twelve hundred francs) to the third degree, a more temperate zone, where incomes grow from three to six thousand francs, a climate where the _bonus_ flourishes like a half-hardy annual in spite of some difficulties of culture. END
BEGIN NOW A characteristic trait that best reveals the feeble narrow-mindedness of these inhabitants of petty officialdom is a kind of involuntary, mechanical, and instinctive reverence for the Grand Lama of every Ministry, known to the rank and file only by his signature (an illegible scrawl) and by his title&mdash; His Excellency Monseigneur le Ministre, five words which produce as much effect as the _il Bondo Cani_ of the _Calife de Bagdad_, five words which in the eyes of this low order of intelligence represent a sacred power from which there is no appeal. END
BEGIN NOW The Minister is administratively infallible for the clerks in the employ of the Government, as the Pope is infallible for good Catholics. END
BEGIN NOW Something of this peculiar radiance invests everything he does or says, or that is said or done in his name; the robe of office covers everything and legalizes everything done by his orders; does not his very title&mdash;His Excellency&mdash;vouch for the purity of his intentions and the righteousness of his will, and serve as a sort of passport and introduction to ideas that otherwise would not be entertained for a moment? END
BEGIN NOW Pronounce the words His Excellency, and these poor folk will forthwith proceed to do what they would not do for their own interests. END
BEGIN NOW Passive obedience is as well known in a Government department as in the army itself; and the administrative system silences consciences, annihilates the individual, and ends (give it time enough) by fashioning a man into a vise or a thumbscrew, and he becomes part of the machinery of Government. END
BEGIN NOW Wherefore, M. Gondureau, who seemed to know something of human nature, recognized Poiret at once as one of those dupes of officialdom, and brought out for his benefit, at the proper moment, the _deus ex machina_, the magical words His Excellency, so as to dazzle Poiret just as he himself unmasked his batteries, for he took Poiret and the Michonneau for the male and female of the same species. END
BEGIN NOW If his Excellency himself, his Excellency the Minister... Ah! END
BEGIN NOW that is quite another thing, said Poiret. END
BEGIN NOW You seem to be guided by this gentleman's opinion, and you hear what he says, said the man of independent means, addressing Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau. END
BEGIN NOW Very well, his Excellency is at this moment absolutely certain that the so-called Vautrin, who lodges at the Maison Vauquer, is a convict who escaped from penal servitude at Toulon, where he is known by the nickname _Trompe-la-Mort_. END
BEGIN NOW Trompe-la-Mort? END
BEGIN NOW said Pioret. END
BEGIN NOW Dear me, he is very lucky if he deserves that nickname. END
BEGIN NOW Well, yes, said the detective. END
BEGIN NOW They call him so because he has been so lucky as not to lose his life in the very risky businesses that he has carried through. END
BEGIN NOW He is a dangerous man, you see! END
BEGIN NOW He has qualities that are out of the common; the thing he is wanted for, in fact, was a matter which gained him no end of credit with his own set&mdash;- Then is he a man of honor? END
BEGIN NOW asked Poiret. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, according to his notions. END
BEGIN NOW He agreed to take another man's crime upon himself&mdash;a forgery committed by a very handsome young fellow that he had taken a great fancy to, a young Italian, a bit of a gambler, who has since gone into the army, where his conduct has been unexceptionable. END
BEGIN NOW But if his Excellency the Minister of Police is certain that M. Vautrin is this _Trompe-la-Mort_, why should he want me? END
BEGIN NOW asked Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau. END
BEGIN NOW Oh yes, said Poiret, if the Minister, as you have been so obliging as to tell us, really knows for a certainty&mdash;- Certainty is not the word; he only suspects. END
BEGIN NOW You will soon understand how things are. END
BEGIN NOW Jacques Collin, nicknamed _Trompe-la-Mort_, is in the confidence of every convict in the three prisons; he is their man of business and their banker. END
BEGIN NOW He makes a very good thing out of managing their affairs, which want a _man of mark_ to see about them. END
BEGIN NOW Ha! END
BEGIN NOW ha! END
BEGIN NOW do you see the pun, mademoiselle? END
BEGIN NOW asked Poiret. END
BEGIN NOW This gentleman calls himself a _man of mark_ because he is a _marked man_&mdash;branded, you know. END
BEGIN NOW This so-called Vautrin, said the detective, receives the money belonging to my lords the convicts, invests it for them, and holds it at the disposal of those who escape, or hands it over to their families if they leave a will, or to their mistresses when they draw upon him for their benefit. END
BEGIN NOW Their mistresses! END
BEGIN NOW You mean their wives, remarked Poiret. END
BEGIN NOW No, sir. END
BEGIN NOW A convict's wife is usually an illegitimate connection. END
BEGIN NOW We call them concubines. END
BEGIN NOW Then they all live in a state of concubinage? END
BEGIN NOW Naturally. END
BEGIN NOW Why, these are abominations that his Excellency ought not to allow. END
BEGIN NOW Since you have the honor of seeing his Excellency, you, who seem to have philanthropic ideas, ought really to enlighten him as to their immoral conduct&mdash;they are setting a shocking example to the rest of society. END
BEGIN NOW But the Government does not hold them up as models of all the virtues, my dear sir&mdash;- Of course not, sir; but still&mdash;- Just let the gentleman say what he has to say, dearie, said Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau. END
BEGIN NOW You see how it is, mademoiselle, Gondureau continued. END
BEGIN NOW The Government may have the strongest reasons for getting this illicit hoard into its hands; it mounts up to something considerable, by all that we can make out. END
BEGIN NOW Trompe-la-Mort not only holds large sums for his friends the convicts, but he has other amounts which are paid over to him by the Society of the Ten Thousand&mdash;- Ten Thousand Thieves! END
BEGIN NOW cried Pioret in alarm. END
BEGIN NOW No. END
BEGIN NOW The Society of the Ten Thousand is not an association of petty offenders, but of people who set about their work on a large scale&mdash;they won't touch a matter unless there are ten thousand francs in it. END
BEGIN NOW It is composed of the most distinguished of the men who are sent straight to the Assize Courts when they come up for trial. END
BEGIN NOW They know the Code too well to risk their necks when they are nabbed. END
BEGIN NOW Collin is their confidential agent and legal adviser. END
BEGIN NOW By means of the large sums of money at his disposal he has established a sort of detective system of his own; it is widespread and mysterious in its workings. END
BEGIN NOW We have had spies all about him for a twelvemonth, and yet we could not manage to fathom his games. END
BEGIN NOW His capital and his cleverness are at the service of vice and crime; this money furnishes the necessary funds for a regular army of blackguards in his pay who wage incessant war against society. END
BEGIN NOW If we can catch Trompe-la-Mort, and take possession of his funds, we should strike at the root of this evil. END
BEGIN NOW So this job is a kind of Government affair&mdash;a State secret&mdash;and likely to redound to the honor of those who bring the thing to a successful conclusion. END
BEGIN NOW You, sir, for instance, might very well be taken into a Government department again; they might make you secretary to a Commissary of Police; you could accept that post without prejudice to your retiring pension. END
BEGIN NOW Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau interposed at this point with, What is there to hinder Trompe-la-Mort from making off with the money? END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW said the detective, a man is told off to follow him everywhere he goes, with orders to kill him if he were to rob the convicts. END
BEGIN NOW Then it is not quite as easy to make off with a lot of money as it is to run away with a young lady of family. END
BEGIN NOW Besides, Collin is not the sort of fellow to play such a trick; he would be disgraced, according to his notions. END
BEGIN NOW You are quite right, sir, said Poiret, utterly disgraced he would be. END
BEGIN NOW But none of all this explains why you do not come and take him without more ado, remarked Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau. END
BEGIN NOW Very well, mademoiselle, I will explain&mdash;but, he added in her ear, keep your companion quiet, or I shall never have done. END
BEGIN NOW The old boy ought to pay people handsomely for listening to him.&mdash;Trompe-la-Mort, when he came back here, he went on aloud slipped into the skin of an honest man; he turned up disguised as a decent Parisian citizen, and took up his quarters in an unpretending lodging-house. END
BEGIN NOW He is cunning, that he is! END
BEGIN NOW You don't catch him napping. END
BEGIN NOW Then M. Vautrin is a man of consequence, who transacts a good deal of business. END
BEGIN NOW Naturally, said Poiret to himself. END
BEGIN NOW And suppose that the Minister were to make a mistake and get hold of the real Vautrin, he would put every one's back up among the business men in Paris, and public opinion would be against him. END
BEGIN NOW M. le Prefet de Police is on slippery ground; he has enemies. END
BEGIN NOW They would take advantage of any mistake. END
BEGIN NOW There would be a fine outcry and fuss made by the Opposition, and he would be sent packing. END
BEGIN NOW We must set about this just as we did about the Coignard affair, the sham Comte de Sainte-Helene; if he had been the real Comte de Sainte-Helene, we should have been in the wrong box. END
BEGIN NOW We want to be quite sure what we are about. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, but what you want is a pretty woman, said Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau briskly. END
BEGIN NOW Trompe-la-Mort would not let a woman come near him, said the detective. END
BEGIN NOW I will tell you a secret&mdash;he does not like them. END
BEGIN NOW Still, I do not see what I can do, supposing that I did agree to identify him for two thousand francs. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing simpler, said the stranger. END
BEGIN NOW I will send you a little bottle containing a dose that will send a rush of blood to the head; it will do him no harm whatever, but he will fall down as if he were in a fit. END
BEGIN NOW The drug can be put into wine or coffee; either will do equally well. END
BEGIN NOW You carry your man to bed at once, and undress him to see that he is not dying. END
BEGIN NOW As soon as you are alone, you give him a slap on the shoulder, and _presto!_ the letters will appear. END
BEGIN NOW Why, that is just nothing at all, said Poiret. END
BEGIN NOW Well, do you agree? END

BEGIN NOW But, my dear sir, suppose there are no letters at all, said Mlle. END

BEGIN NOW No. END
BEGIN NOW What will you give me then? END
BEGIN NOW Five hundred francs. END
BEGIN NOW It is such a thing to do for so little! END
BEGIN NOW It lies on your conscience just the same, and I must quiet my conscience, sir. END
BEGIN NOW I assure you, said Poiret, that mademoiselle has a great deal of conscience, and not only so, she is a very amiable person, and very intelligent. END

BEGIN NOW Michonneau went on, make it three thousand francs if he is Trompe-la-Mort, and nothing at all if he is an ordinary man. END

BEGIN NOW Ask there for M. Gondureau. END
BEGIN NOW Bianchon, on his way back from Cuvier's lecture, overheard the sufficiently striking nickname of _Trompe-la-Mort_, and caught the celebrated chief detective's _Done!_ Why didn't you close with him? END
BEGIN NOW It would be three hundred francs a year, said Poiret to Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau. END
BEGIN NOW Why didn't I? END
BEGIN NOW she asked. END
BEGIN NOW Why, it wants thinking over. END
BEGIN NOW Suppose that M. Vautrin is this Trompe-la-Mort, perhaps we might do better for ourselves with him. END

BEGIN NOW You would spoil everything. END
BEGIN NOW Anyhow, thought Mlle. END

BEGIN NOW He says nothing but disagreeable things to me. END
BEGIN NOW But you can do better than that, Poiret resumed. END
BEGIN NOW As that gentleman said (and he seemed to me to be a very good sort of man, besides being very well got up), it is an act of obedience to the laws to rid society of a criminal, however virtuous he may be. END
BEGIN NOW Once a thief, always a thief. END
BEGIN NOW Suppose he were to take it into his head to murder us all? END
BEGIN NOW The deuce! END
BEGIN NOW We should be guilty of manslaughter, and be the first to fall victims into the bargain! END
BEGIN NOW Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau's musings did not permit her to listen very closely to the remarks that fell one by one from Poiret's lips like water dripping from a leaky tap. END
BEGIN NOW When once this elderly babbler began to talk, he would go on like clockwork unless Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau stopped him. END
BEGIN NOW He started on some subject or other, and wandered on through parenthesis after parenthesis, till he came to regions as remote as possible from his premises without coming to any conclusions by the way. END
BEGIN NOW By the time they reached the Maison Vauquer he had tacked together a whole string of examples and quotations more or less irrelevant to the subject in hand, which led him to give a full account of his own deposition in the case of the Sieur Ragoulleau _versus_ Dame Morin, when he had been summoned as a witness for the defence. END
BEGIN NOW As they entered the dining-room, Eugene de Rastignac was talking apart with Mlle. END

BEGIN NOW None of this was thrown away on Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau. END

BEGIN NOW Yes, he answered. END
BEGIN NOW So she was found guilty. END
BEGIN NOW Who? END
BEGIN NOW Morin. END
BEGIN NOW I am talking about Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Victorine, said Mlle, Michonneau, as she entered Poiret's room with an absent air, and you answer, ' Morin.' END
BEGIN NOW Who may Morin be? END
BEGIN NOW What can Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Victorine be guilty of? END
BEGIN NOW demanded Poiret. END
BEGIN NOW Guilty of falling in love with M. Eugene de Rastignac and going further and further without knowing exactly where she is going, poor innocent! END
BEGIN NOW That morning de Nucingen had driven Eugene to despair. END
BEGIN NOW In his own mind he had completely surrendered himself to Vautrin, and deliberately shut his eyes to the motive for the friendship which that extraordinary man professed for him, nor would he look to the consequences of such an alliance. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing short of a miracle could extricate him now out of the gulf into which he had walked an hour ago, when he exchanged vows in the softest whispers with Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Taillefer. END
BEGIN NOW To Victorine it seemed as if she heard an angel's voice, that heaven was opening above her; the Maison Vauquer took strange and wonderful hues, like a stage fairy-palace. END
BEGIN NOW She loved and she was loved; at any rate, she believed that she was loved; and what woman would not likewise have believed after seeing Rastignac's face and listening to the tones of his voice during that hour snatched under the Argus eyes of the Maison Vauquer? END
BEGIN NOW He had trampled on his conscience; he knew that he was doing wrong, and did it deliberately; he had said to himself that a woman's happiness should atone for this venial sin. END
BEGIN NOW The energy of desperation had lent new beauty to his face; the lurid fire that burned in his heart shone from his eyes. END
BEGIN NOW Luckily for him, the miracle took place. END
BEGIN NOW Vautrin came in in high spirits, and at once read the hearts of these two young creatures whom he had brought together by the combinations of his infernal genius, but his deep voice broke in upon their bliss. END
BEGIN NOW A charming girl is my Fanchette In her simplicity, he sang mockingly. END
BEGIN NOW Victorine fled. END
BEGIN NOW Her heart was more full than it had ever been, but it was full of joy, and not of sorrow. END
BEGIN NOW Poor child! END
BEGIN NOW A pressure of the hand, the light touch of Rastignac's hair against her cheek, a word whispered in her ear so closely that she felt the student's warm breath on her, the pressure of a trembling arm about her waist, a kiss upon her throat&mdash;such had been her betrothal. END
BEGIN NOW The near neighborhood of the stout Sylvie, who might invade that glorified room at any moment, only made these first tokens of love more ardent, more eloquent, more entrancing than the noblest deeds done for love's sake in the most famous romances. END
BEGIN NOW This _plain-song_ of love, to use the pretty expression of our forefathers, seemed almost criminal to the devout young girl who went to confession every fortnight. END
BEGIN NOW In that one hour she had poured out more of the treasures of her soul than she could give in later days of wealth and happiness, when her whole self followed the gift. END
BEGIN NOW The thing is arranged, Vautrin said to Eugene, who remained. END
BEGIN NOW Our two dandies have fallen out. END
BEGIN NOW Everything was done in proper form. END
BEGIN NOW It is a matter of opinion. END
BEGIN NOW Our pigeon has insulted my hawk. END
BEGIN NOW They will meet to-morrow in the redoubt at Clignancourt. END
BEGIN NOW By half-past eight in the morning Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Taillefer, calmly dipping her bread and butter in her coffee cup, will be sole heiress of her father's fortune and affections. END
BEGIN NOW A funny way of putting it, isn't it? END
BEGIN NOW Taillefer's youngster is an expert swordsman, and quite cocksure about it, but he will be bled; I have just invented a thrust for his benefit, a way of raising your sword point and driving it at the forehead. END
BEGIN NOW I must show you that thrust; it is an uncommonly handy thing to know. END

BEGIN NOW He made up his mind that he would go that evening to warn the Taillefers, father and son. END

BEGIN NOW He folded his arms and paced up and down in his cheerless, untidy room. END

BEGIN NOW The Bordeaux wine circulated; the dinner table became a livelier scene than ever, and the fun grew fast and furious. END

BEGIN NOW A few seconds later, and there was a head-splitting racket in the room, a storm of tomfoolery, a sort of cats' concert, with Vautrin as conductor of the orchestra, the latter keeping an eye the while on Eugene and Father Goriot. END
BEGIN NOW The wine seemed to have gone to their heads already. END
BEGIN NOW They leaned back in their chairs, looking at the general confusion with an air of gravity, and drank but little; both of them were absorbed in the thought of what lay before them to do that evening, and yet neither of them felt able to rise and go. END

END

BEGIN NOW The mere mention of the name would have set Vautrin on his guard; for Vautrin, or, to give him his real name, Jacques Collin, was in fact the notorious escaped convict. END

BEGIN NOW Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau had very nearly made up her mind to warn the convict and to throw herself on his generosity, with the idea of making a better bargain for herself by helping him to escape that night; but as it was, she went out escorted by Poiret in search of the famous chief of detectives in the Petite Rue Saint-Anne, still thinking that it was the district superintendent&mdash;one Gondureau&mdash;with whom she had to do. END
BEGIN NOW The head of the department received his visitors courteously. END
BEGIN NOW There was a little talk, and the details were definitely arranged. END
BEGIN NOW Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau asked for the draught that she was to administer in order to set about her investigation. END
BEGIN NOW But the great man's evident satisfaction set Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau thinking; and she began to see that this business involved something more than the mere capture of a runaway convict. END
BEGIN NOW She racked her brains while he looked in a drawer in his desk for the little phial, and it dawned upon her that in consequence of treacherous revelations made by the prisoners the police were hoping to lay their hands on a considerable sum of money. END
BEGIN NOW But on hinting her suspicions to the old fox of the Petite Rue Saint-Anne, that officer began to smile, and tried to put her off the scent. END
BEGIN NOW A delusion, he said. END
BEGIN NOW Collin's _sorbonne_ is the most dangerous that has yet been found among the dangerous classes. END
BEGIN NOW That is all, and the rascals are quite aware of it. END
BEGIN NOW They rally round him; he is the backbone of the federation, its Bonaparte, in short; he is very popular with them all. END
BEGIN NOW The rogue will never leave his _chump_ in the Place de Greve. END
BEGIN NOW As Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW Michonneau seemed mystified, Gondureau explained the two slang words for her benefit. END
BEGIN NOW _Sorbonne_ and _chump_ are two forcible expressions borrowed from thieves' Latin, thieves, of all people, being compelled to consider the human head in its two aspects. END
BEGIN NOW A sorbonne is the head of a living man, his faculty of thinking&mdash;his council; a chump is a contemptuous epithet that implies how little a human head is worth after the axe has done its work. END
BEGIN NOW Collin is playing us off, he continued. END
BEGIN NOW When we come across a man like a bar of steel tempered in the English fashion, there is always one resource left&mdash;we can kill him if he takes it into his head to make the least resistance. END
BEGIN NOW We are reckoning on several methods of killing Collin to-morrow morning. END
BEGIN NOW It saves a trial, and society is rid of him without all the expense of guarding and feeding him. END
BEGIN NOW What with getting up the case, summoning witnesses, paying their expenses, and carrying out the sentence, it costs a lot to go through all the proper formalities before you can get quit of one of these good-for-nothings, over and above the three thousand francs that you are going to have. END
BEGIN NOW There is a saving in time as well. END
BEGIN NOW One good thrust of the bayonet into Trompe-la-Mort's paunch will prevent scores of crimes, and save fifty scoundrels from following his example; they will be very careful to keep themselves out of the police courts. END
BEGIN NOW That is doing the work of the police thoroughly, and true philanthropists will tell you that it is better to prevent crime than to punish it. END
BEGIN NOW And you do a service to our country, said Poiret. END
BEGIN NOW Really, you are talking in a very sensible manner tonight, that you are, said the head of the department. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, of course, we are serving our country, and we are very hardly used too. END
BEGIN NOW We do society very great services that are not recognized. END
BEGIN NOW In fact, a superior man must rise above vulgar prejudices, and a Christian must resign himself to the mishaps that doing right entails, when right is done in an out-of-the-way style. END

BEGIN NOW The next day was destined to be one of the most extraordinary in the annals of the Maison Vauquer. END
BEGIN NOW Hitherto the most startling occurrence in its tranquil existence had been the portentous, meteor-like apparition of the sham Comtesse de l'Ambermesnil. END

BEGIN NOW The _Pilote_ was a Radical sheet, edited by M. Tissot. END
BEGIN NOW It came out several hours later than the morning papers, and was meant for the benefit of country subscribers; for it brought the morning news into provincial districts twenty-four hours sooner than the ordinary local journals. END

BEGIN NOW There was a terrible suggestion of strength mingled with cunning in the short, brick-red crop of hair, the whole head was in harmony with his powerful frame, and at that moment the fires of hell seemed to gleam from his eyes. END
BEGIN NOW In that flash the real Vautrin shone forth, revealed at once before them all; they understood his past, his present, and future, his pitiless doctrines, his actions, the religion of his own good pleasure, the majesty with which his cynicism and contempt for mankind invested him, the physical strength of an organization proof against all trials. END
BEGIN NOW The blood flew to his face, and his eyes glared like the eyes of a wild cat. END

BEGIN NOW The drop of water that cooled his wrathful fury was a reflection that flashed across his brain like lightning. END

BEGIN NOW said he of the Petite Rue Saint-Anne, contemptuously. END

BEGIN NOW By twelve o'clock, when the postman reaches that quarter, Eugene received a letter. END
BEGIN NOW The dainty envelope bore the Beauseant arms on the seal, and contained an invitation to the Vicomtesse's great ball, which had been talked of in Paris for a month. END

BEGIN NOW VICOMTESSE DE BEAUSEANT. END
