BEGIN NOW He had procured this pleasure for her, and doubtless he would receive the price of it. END
BEGIN NOW de Nucingen was dressing. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac waited in her boudoir, enduring as best he might the natural impatience of an eager temperament for the reward desired and withheld for a year. END
BEGIN NOW Such sensations are only known once in a life. END
BEGIN NOW The first woman to whom a man is drawn, if she is really a woman&mdash;that is to say, if she appears to him amid the splendid accessories that form a necessary background to life in the world of Paris&mdash;will never have a rival. END
BEGIN NOW Love in Paris is a thing distinct and apart; for in Paris neither men nor women are the dupes of the commonplaces by which people seek to throw a veil over their motives, or to parade a fine affectation of disinterestedness in their sentiments. END
BEGIN NOW In this country within a country, it is not merely required of a woman that she should satisfy the senses and the soul; she knows perfectly well that she has still greater obligations to discharge, that she must fulfil the countless demands of a vanity that enters into every fibre of that living organism called society. END
BEGIN NOW Love, for her, is above all things, and by its very nature, a vainglorious, brazen-fronted, ostentatious, thriftless charlatan. END
BEGIN NOW If at the Court of Louis XIV. END
BEGIN NOW there was not a woman but envied Mlle. END
BEGIN NOW de la Valliere the reckless devotion of passion that led the grand monarch to tear the priceless ruffles at his wrists in order to assist the entry of a Duc de Vermandois into the world&mdash;what can you expect of the rest of society? END
BEGIN NOW You must have youth and wealth and rank; nay, you must, if possible, have more than these, for the more incense you bring with you to burn at the shrine of the god, the more favorably will he regard the worshiper. END
BEGIN NOW Love is a religion, and his cult must in the nature of things be more costly than those of all other deities; Love the Spoiler stays for a moment, and then passes on; like the urchin of the streets, his course may be traced by the ravages that he has made. END
BEGIN NOW The wealth of feeling and imagination is the poetry of the garret; how should love exist there without that wealth? END
BEGIN NOW If there are exceptions who do not subscribe to these Draconian laws of the Parisian code, they are solitary examples. END
BEGIN NOW Such souls live so far out of the main current that they are not borne away by the doctrines of society; they dwell beside some clear spring of everflowing water, without seeking to leave the green shade; happy to listen to the echoes of the infinite in everything around them and in their own souls, waiting in patience to take their flight for heaven, while they look with pity upon those of earth. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac, like most young men who have been early impressed by the circumstances of power and grandeur, meant to enter the lists fully armed; the burning ambition of conquest possessed him already; perhaps he was conscious of his powers, but as yet he knew neither the end to which his ambition was to be directed, nor the means of attaining it. END
BEGIN NOW In default of the pure and sacred love that fills a life, ambition may become something very noble, subduing to itself every thought of personal interest, and setting as the end&mdash;the greatness, not of one man, but of a whole nation. END
BEGIN NOW But the student had not yet reached the time of life when a man surveys the whole course of existence and judges it soberly. END
BEGIN NOW Hitherto he had scarcely so much as shaken off the spell of the fresh and gracious influences that envelop a childhood in the country, like green leaves and grass. END
BEGIN NOW He had hesitated on the brink of the Parisian Rubicon, and in spite of the prickings of ambition, he still clung to a lingering tradition of an old ideal&mdash;the peaceful life of the noble in his chateau. END
BEGIN NOW But yesterday evening, at the sight of his rooms, those scruples had vanished. END
BEGIN NOW He had learned what it was to enjoy the material advantages of fortune, as he had already enjoyed the social advantages of birth; he ceased to be a provincial from that moment, and slipped naturally and easily into a position which opened up a prospect of a brilliant future. END
BEGIN NOW So, as he waited for Delphine, in the pretty boudoir, where he felt that he had a certain right to be, he felt himself so far away from the Rastignac who came back to Paris a year ago, that, turning some power of inner vision upon this latter, he asked himself whether that past self bore any resemblance to the Rastignac of that moment. END
BEGIN NOW Madame is in her room, Therese came to tell him. END
BEGIN NOW The woman's voice made him start. END
BEGIN NOW He found Delphine lying back in her low chair by the fireside, looking fresh and bright. END
BEGIN NOW The sight of her among the flowing draperies of muslin suggested some beautiful tropical flower, where the fruit is set amid the blossom. END
BEGIN NOW Well, she said, with a tremor in her voice, here you are. END
BEGIN NOW Guess what I bring for you, said Eugene, sitting down beside her. END
BEGIN NOW He took possession of her arm to kiss her hand. END
BEGIN NOW de Nucingen gave a joyful start as she saw the card. END
BEGIN NOW She turned to Eugene; there were tears in her eyes as she flung her arms about his neck, and drew him towards her in a frenzy of gratified vanity. END
BEGIN NOW And I owe this happiness to you&mdash;to _thee_ (she whispered the more intimate word in his ear); but Therese is in my dressing-room, let us be prudent.&mdash;This happiness&mdash;yes, for I may call it so, when it comes to me through _you_&mdash;is surely more than a triumph for self-love? END
BEGIN NOW No one has been willing to introduce me into that set. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps just now I may seem to you to be frivolous, petty, shallow, like a Parisienne, but remember, my friend, that I am ready to give up all for you; and that if I long more than ever for an entrance into the Faubourg Saint-Germain, it is because I shall meet you there. END
BEGIN NOW de Beauseant's note seems to say very plainly that she does not expect to see the _Baron_ de Nucingen at her ball; don't you think so? END
BEGIN NOW said Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW Why, yes, said the Baroness as she returned the letter. END
BEGIN NOW Those women have a talent for insolence. END
BEGIN NOW But it is of no consequence, I shall go. END
BEGIN NOW My sister is sure to be there, and sure to be very beautifully dressed.&mdash;Eugene, she went on, lowering her voice, she will go to dispel ugly suspicions. END
BEGIN NOW You do not know the things that people are saying about her. END
BEGIN NOW Only this morning Nucingen came to tell me that they had been discussing her at the club. END
BEGIN NOW Great heavens! END
BEGIN NOW on what does a woman's character and the honor of a whole family depend! END
BEGIN NOW I feel that I am nearly touched and wounded in my poor sister. END
BEGIN NOW According to some people, M. de Trailles must have put his name to bills for a hundred thousand francs, nearly all of them are overdue, and proceedings are threatened. END
BEGIN NOW In this predicament, it seems that my sister sold her diamonds to a Jew&mdash;the beautiful diamonds that belonged to her husband's mother, de Restaud the elder,&mdash;you have seen her wearing them. END
BEGIN NOW In fact, nothing else has been talked about for the last two days. END
BEGIN NOW So I can see that Anastasie is sure to come to de Beauseant's ball in tissue of gold, and ablaze with diamonds, to draw all eyes upon her; and I will not be outshone. END
BEGIN NOW She has tried to eclipse me all her life, she has never been kind to me, and I have helped her so often, and always had money for her when she had none.&mdash;But never mind other people now, to-day I mean to be perfectly happy. END
BEGIN NOW At one o'clock that morning Eugene was still with de Nucingen. END
BEGIN NOW In the midst of their lovers' farewell, a farewell full of hope of bliss to come, she said in a troubled voice, I am very fearful, superstitious. END
BEGIN NOW Give what name you like to my presentiments, but I am afraid that my happiness will be paid for by some horrible catastrophe. END
BEGIN NOW Child! END
BEGIN NOW said Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW have we changed places, and am I the child to-night? END
BEGIN NOW she asked, laughingly. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene went back to the Maison Vauquer, never doubting but that he should leave it for good on the morrow; and on the way he fell to dreaming the bright dreams of youth, when the cup of happiness has left its sweetness on the lips. END
BEGIN NOW Well? END
BEGIN NOW cried Goriot, as Rastignac passed by his door. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, said Eugene; I will tell you everything to-morrow. END
BEGIN NOW Everything, will you not? END
BEGIN NOW cried the old man. END
BEGIN NOW Go to bed. END
BEGIN NOW To-morrow our happy life will begin. END
BEGIN NOW Next day, Goriot and Rastignac were ready to leave the lodging-house, and only awaited the good pleasure of a porter to move out of it; but towards noon there was a sound of wheels in the Rue Neuve-Sainte-Genevieve, and a carriage stopped before the door of the Maison Vauquer. END
BEGIN NOW de Nucingen alighted, and asked if her father was still in the house, and, receiving an affirmative reply from Sylvie, ran lightly upstairs. END
BEGIN NOW It so happened that Eugene was at home all unknown to his neighbor. END
BEGIN NOW At breakfast time he had asked Goriot to superintend the removal of his goods, saying that he would meet him in the Rue d'Artois at four o'clock; but Rastignac's name had been called early on the list at the Ecole de Droit, and he had gone back at once to the Rue Nueve-Sainte-Genevieve. END
BEGIN NOW No one had seen him come in, for Goriot had gone to find a porter, and the mistress of the house was likewise out. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene had thought to pay her himself, for it struck him that if he left this, Goriot in his zeal would probably pay for him. END
BEGIN NOW As it was, Eugene went up to his room to see that nothing had been forgotten, and blessed his foresight when he saw the blank bill bearing Vautrin's signature lying in the drawer where he had carelessly thrown it on the day when he had repaid the amount. END
BEGIN NOW There was no fire in the grate, so he was about to tear it into little pieces, when he heard a voice speaking in Goriot's room, and the speaker was Delphine! END
BEGIN NOW He made no more noise, and stood still to listen, thinking that she should have no secrets from him; but after the first few words, the conversation between the father and daughter was so strange and interesting that it absorbed all his attention. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW thank heaven that you thought of asking him to give an account of the money settled on me before I was utterly ruined, father. END
BEGIN NOW Is it safe to talk? END
BEGIN NOW she added. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, there is no one in the house, said her father faintly. END
BEGIN NOW What is the matter with you? END
BEGIN NOW asked de Nucingen. END
BEGIN NOW God forgive you! END
BEGIN NOW you have just dealt me a staggering blow, child! END
BEGIN NOW said the old man. END
BEGIN NOW You cannot know how much I love you, or you would not have burst in upon me like this, with such news, especially if all is not lost. END
BEGIN NOW Has something so important happened that you must come here about it? END
BEGIN NOW In a few minutes we should have been in the Rue d'Artois. END
BEGIN NOW Eh! END
BEGIN NOW does one think what one is doing after a catastrophe? END
BEGIN NOW It has turned my head. END
BEGIN NOW Your attorney has found out the state of things now, but it was bound to come out sooner or later. END
BEGIN NOW We shall want your long business experience; and I come to you like a drowning man who catches at a branch. END
BEGIN NOW When M. Derville found that Nucingen was throwing all sorts of difficulties in his way, he threatened him with proceedings, and told him plainly that he would soon obtain an order from the President of the Tribunal. END
BEGIN NOW So Nucingen came to my room this morning, and asked if I meant to ruin us both. END
BEGIN NOW I told him that I knew nothing whatever about it, that I had a fortune, and ought to be put into possession of my fortune, and that my attorney was acting for me in the matter; I said again that I knew absolutely nothing about it, and could not possibly go into the subject with him. END
BEGIN NOW Wasn't that what you told me to tell him? END
BEGIN NOW Yes, quite right, answered Goriot. END
BEGIN NOW Well, then, Delphine continued, he told me all about his affairs. END
BEGIN NOW He had just invested all his capital and mine in business speculations; they have only just been started, and very large sums of money are locked up. END
BEGIN NOW If I were to compel him to refund my dowry now, he would be forced to file his petition; but if I will wait a year, he undertakes, on his honor, to double or treble my fortune, by investing it in building land, and I shall be mistress at last of the whole of my property. END
BEGIN NOW He was speaking the truth, father dear; he frightened me! END
BEGIN NOW He asked my pardon for his conduct; he has given me my liberty; I am free to act as I please on condition that I leave him to carry on my business in my name. END
BEGIN NOW To prove his sincerity, he promised that M. Derville might inspect the accounts as often as I pleased, so that I might be assured that everything was being conducted properly. END
BEGIN NOW In short, he put himself in my power, bound hand and foot. END
BEGIN NOW He wishes the present arrangements as to the expenses of housekeeping to continue for two more years, and entreated me not to exceed my allowance. END
BEGIN NOW He showed me plainly that it was all that he could do to keep up appearances; he has broken with his opera dancer; he will be compelled to practise the most strict economy (in secret) if he is to bide his time with unshaken credit. END
BEGIN NOW I scolded, I did all I could to drive him to desperation, so as to find out more. END
BEGIN NOW He showed me his ledgers&mdash;he broke down and cried at last. END
BEGIN NOW I never saw a man in such a state. END
BEGIN NOW He lost his head completely, talked of killing himself, and raved till I felt quite sorry for him. END
BEGIN NOW Do you really believe that silly rubbish?\... cried her father. END
BEGIN NOW It was all got up for your benefit! END
BEGIN NOW I have had to do with Germans in the way of business, honest and straightforward they are pretty sure to be, but when with their simplicity and frankness they are sharpers and humbugs as well, they are the worst rogues of all. END
BEGIN NOW Your husband is taking advantage of you. END
BEGIN NOW As soon as pressure is brought to bear on him he shams dead; he means to be more the master under your name than in his own. END
BEGIN NOW He will take advantage of the position to secure himself against the risks of business. END
BEGIN NOW He is as sharp as he is treacherous; he is a bad lot! END
BEGIN NOW No, no; I am not going to leave my girls behind me without a penny when I go to Pere-Lachaise. END
BEGIN NOW I know something about business still. END
BEGIN NOW He has sunk his money in speculation, he says; very well then, there is something to show for it&mdash;bills, receipts, papers of some sort. END
BEGIN NOW Let him produce them, and come to an arrangement with you. END
BEGIN NOW We will choose the most promising of his speculations, take them over at our own risk, and have the securities transferred into your name; they shall represent the separate estate of Delphine Goriot, wife of the Baron de Nucingen. END
BEGIN NOW Does that fellow really take us for idiots? END
BEGIN NOW Does he imagine that I could stand the idea of your being without fortune, without bread, for forty-eight hours? END
BEGIN NOW I would not stand it a day&mdash;no, not a night, not a couple of hours! END
BEGIN NOW If there had been any foundation for the idea, I should never get over it. END
BEGIN NOW What! END
BEGIN NOW I have worked hard for forty years, carried sacks on my back, and sweated and pinched and saved all my life for you, my darlings, for you who made the toil and every burden borne for you seem light; and now, my fortune, my whole life, is to vanish in smoke! END
BEGIN NOW I should die raving mad if I believed a word of it. END
BEGIN NOW By all that's holiest in heaven and earth, we will have this cleared up at once; go through the books, have the whole business looked thoroughly into! END
BEGIN NOW I will not sleep, nor rest, nor eat until I have satisfied myself that all your fortune is in existence. END
BEGIN NOW Your money is settled upon you, God be thanked! END
BEGIN NOW and, luckily, your attorney, Maitre Derville, is an honest man. END
BEGIN NOW Good Lord! END
BEGIN NOW you shall have your snug little million, your fifty thousand francs a year, as long as you live, or I will raise a racket in Paris, I will so! END
BEGIN NOW If the Tribunals put upon us, I will appeal to the Chambers. END
BEGIN NOW If I knew that you were well and comfortably off as far as money is concerned, that thought would keep me easy in spite of bad health and troubles. END
BEGIN NOW Money? END
BEGIN NOW why, it is life! END
BEGIN NOW Money does everything. END
BEGIN NOW That great dolt of an Alsatian shall sing to another tune! END
BEGIN NOW Look here, Delphine, don't give way, don't make a concession of half a quarter of a farthing to that fathead, who has ground you down and made you miserable. END
BEGIN NOW If he can't do without you, we will give him a good cudgeling, and keep him in order. END
BEGIN NOW Great heavens! END
BEGIN NOW my brain is on fire; it is as if there were something redhot inside my head. END
BEGIN NOW My Delphine lying on straw! END
BEGIN NOW You! END
BEGIN NOW my Fifine! END
BEGIN NOW Good gracious! END
BEGIN NOW Where are my gloves? END
BEGIN NOW Come, let us go at once; I mean to see everything with my own eyes&mdash;books, cash, and correspondence, the whole business. END
BEGIN NOW I shall have no peace until I know for certain that your fortune is secure. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW father dear, be careful how you set about it! END
BEGIN NOW If there is the least hint of vengeance in the business, if you show yourself openly hostile, it will be all over with me. END
BEGIN NOW He knows whom he has to deal with; he thinks it quite natural that if you put the idea into my head, I should be uneasy about my money; but I swear to you that he has it in his own hands, and that he had meant to keep it. END
BEGIN NOW He is just the man to abscond with all the money and leave us in the lurch, the scoundrel! END
BEGIN NOW He knows quite well that I will not dishonor the name I bear by bringing him into a court of law. END
BEGIN NOW His position is strong and weak at the same time. END
BEGIN NOW If we drive him to despair, I am lost. END
BEGIN NOW Why, then, the man is a rogue? END
BEGIN NOW Well, yes, father, she said, flinging herself into a chair, I wanted to keep it from you to spare your feelings, and she burst into tears; I did not want you to know that you had married me to such a man as he is. END
BEGIN NOW He is just the same in private life&mdash;body and soul and conscience&mdash;the same through and through&mdash;hideous! END
BEGIN NOW I hate him; I despise him! END
BEGIN NOW Yes, after all that that despicable Nucingen has told me, I cannot respect him any longer. END
BEGIN NOW A man capable of mixing himself up in such affairs, and of talking about them to me as he did, without the slightest scruple,&mdash;it is because I have read him through and through that I am afraid of him. END
BEGIN NOW He, my husband, frankly proposed to give me my liberty, and do you know what that means? END
BEGIN NOW It means that if things turn out badly for him, I am to play into his hands, and be his stalking-horse. END
BEGIN NOW But there is law to be had! END
BEGIN NOW There is a Place de Greve for sons-in-law of that sort, cried her father; why, I would guillotine him myself if there was no headsman to do it. END
BEGIN NOW No, father, the law cannot touch him. END
BEGIN NOW Listen, this is what he says, stripped of all his circumlocutions&mdash;'Take your choice, you and no one else can be my accomplice; either everything is lost, you are ruined and have not a farthing, or you will let me carry this business through myself.' END
BEGIN NOW Is that plain speaking? END
BEGIN NOW He _must_ have my assistance. END
BEGIN NOW He is assured that his wife will deal fairly by him; he knows that I shall leave his money to him and be content with my own. END
BEGIN NOW It is an unholy and dishonest compact, and he holds out threats of ruin to compel me to consent to it. END
BEGIN NOW He is buying my conscience, and the price is liberty to be Eugene's wife in all but name. END
BEGIN NOW 'I connive at your errors, and you allow me to commit crimes and ruin poor families!' END
BEGIN NOW Is that sufficiently explicit? END
BEGIN NOW Do you know what he means by speculations? END
BEGIN NOW He buys up land in his own name, then he finds men of straw to run up houses upon it. END
BEGIN NOW These men make a bargain with a contractor to build the houses, paying them by bills at long dates; then in consideration of a small sum they leave my husband in possession of the houses, and finally slip through the fingers of the deluded contractors by going into bankruptcy. END
BEGIN NOW The name of the firm of Nucingen has been used to dazzle the poor contractors. END
BEGIN NOW I saw that. END
BEGIN NOW I noticed, too, that Nucingen had sent bills for large amounts to Amsterdam, London, Naples, and Vienna, in order to prove if necessary that large sums had been paid away by the firm. END
BEGIN NOW How could we get possession of those bills? END
BEGIN NOW Eugene heard a dull thud on the floor; Father Goriot must have fallen on his knees. END
BEGIN NOW Great heavens! END
BEGIN NOW what have I done to you? END
BEGIN NOW Bound my daughter to this scoundrel who does as he likes with her!&mdash;Oh! END
BEGIN NOW my child, my child! END
BEGIN NOW forgive me! END
BEGIN NOW cried the old man. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, if I am in the depths of despair, perhaps you are to blame, said Delphine. END

BEGIN NOW Our fathers should think for us! END
BEGIN NOW Father dear, I am not blaming you in the least, forgive me for what I said. END
BEGIN NOW This is all my own fault. END

BEGIN NOW I shall find my wits and unravel this skein of your husband's winding. END
BEGIN NOW No, let me do that; I shall be able to manage him. END
BEGIN NOW He is fond of me, well and good; I shall use my influence to make him invest my money as soon as possible in landed property in my own name. END
BEGIN NOW Very likely I could get him to buy back Nucingen in Alsace in my name; that has always been a pet idea of his. END
BEGIN NOW Still, come to-morrow and go through the books, and look into the business. END
BEGIN NOW M. Derville knows little of mercantile matters. END
BEGIN NOW No, not to-morrow though. END
BEGIN NOW I do not want to be upset. END
BEGIN NOW de Beauseant's ball will be the day after to-morrow, and I must keep quiet, so as to look my best and freshest, and do honor to my dear Eugene!... END
BEGIN NOW Come, let us see his room. END
BEGIN NOW But as she spoke a carriage stopped in the Rue Nueve-Sainte-Genevieve, and the sound of de Restaud's voice came from the staircase. END
BEGIN NOW Is my father in? END
BEGIN NOW she asked of Sylvie. END
BEGIN NOW This accident was luckily timed for Eugene, whose one idea had been to throw himself down on the bed and pretend to be asleep. END

BEGIN NOW said Delphine, when she heard her sister speak. END
BEGIN NOW It looks as though some strange things had happened in that family. END

BEGIN NOW This is like to be the death of me. END
BEGIN NOW My poor head will not stand a double misfortune. END

BEGIN NOW said de Nucingen, drawing her sister to a chair. END
BEGIN NOW We are the only two people in the world whose love is always sufficient to forgive you everything. END
BEGIN NOW Family affection is the surest, you see. END
BEGIN NOW The Countess inhaled the salts and revived. END
BEGIN NOW This will kill me! END
BEGIN NOW said their father. END
BEGIN NOW There, he went on, stirring the smouldering fire, come nearer, both of you. END

BEGIN NOW Be quick and tell me, this is enough to&mdash;- Well, then, my husband knows everything, said the Countess. END
BEGIN NOW Just imagine it; do you remember, father, that bill of Maxime's some time ago? END
BEGIN NOW Well, that was not the first. END
BEGIN NOW I had paid ever so many before that. END
BEGIN NOW About the beginning of January M. de Trailles seemed very much troubled. END
BEGIN NOW He said nothing to me; but it is so easy to read the hearts of those you love, a mere trifle is enough; and then you feel things instinctively. END
BEGIN NOW Indeed, he was more tender and affectionate than ever, and I was happier than I had ever been before. END

BEGIN NOW The old man gave a startled shudder. END
BEGIN NOW The diamonds only sold for a hundred thousand francs. END

BEGIN NOW He has given me his word that he will be steady and give up play in future. END
BEGIN NOW His love is all that I have left in the world. END
BEGIN NOW I have paid such a fearful price for it that I should die if I lose him now. END
BEGIN NOW I have sacrificed my fortune, my honor, my peace of mind, and my children for him. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW do something, so that at the least Maxime may be at large and live undisgraced in the world, where he will assuredly make a career for himself. END
BEGIN NOW Something more than my happiness is at stake; the children have nothing, and if he is sent to Sainte-Pelagie all his prospects will be ruined. END
BEGIN NOW I haven't the money, Nasie. END
BEGIN NOW I have _nothing_&mdash;nothing left. END
BEGIN NOW This is the end of everything. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, the world is crumbling into ruin, I am sure. END
BEGIN NOW Fly! END
BEGIN NOW Save yourselves! END
BEGIN NOW Ah!&mdash;I have still my silver buckles left, and half-a-dozen silver spoons and forks, the first I ever had in my life. END
BEGIN NOW But I have nothing else except my life annuity, twelve hundred francs... Then what has become of your money in the funds? END
BEGIN NOW I sold out, and only kept a trifle for my wants. END
BEGIN NOW I wanted twelve thousand francs to furnish some rooms for Delphine. END
BEGIN NOW In your own house? END
BEGIN NOW asked de Restaud, looking at her sister. END
BEGIN NOW What does it matter where they were? END
BEGIN NOW asked Goriot. END
BEGIN NOW The money is spent now. END
BEGIN NOW I see how it is, said the Countess. END
BEGIN NOW Rooms for M. de Rastignac. END
BEGIN NOW Poor Delphine, take warning by me! END
BEGIN NOW M. de Rastignac is incapable of ruining the woman he loves, dear. END
BEGIN NOW Thanks! END
BEGIN NOW Delphine. END
BEGIN NOW I thought you would have been kinder to me in my troubles, but you never did love me. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, yes, she loves you, Nasie, cried Goriot; she was saying so only just now. END
BEGIN NOW We were talking about you, and she insisted that you were beautiful, and that she herself was only pretty! END
BEGIN NOW Pretty! END
BEGIN NOW said the Countess. END
BEGIN NOW She is as hard as a marble statue. END
BEGIN NOW And if I am? END
BEGIN NOW cried Delphine, flushing up, how have you treated me? END
BEGIN NOW You would not recognize me; you closed the doors of every house against me; you have never let an opportunity of mortifying me slip by. END
BEGIN NOW And when did I come, as you were always doing, to drain our poor father, a thousand francs at a time, till he is left as you see him now? END
BEGIN NOW That is all your doing, sister! END
BEGIN NOW I myself have seen my father as often as I could. END
BEGIN NOW I have not turned him out of the house, and then come and fawned upon him when I wanted money. END
BEGIN NOW I did not so much as know that he had spent those twelve thousand francs on me. END
BEGIN NOW I am economical, as you know; and when papa has made me presents, it has never been because I came and begged for them. END
BEGIN NOW You were better off than I. M. de Marsay was rich, as you have reason to know. END
BEGIN NOW You always were as slippery as gold. END
BEGIN NOW Good-bye; I have neither sister nor&mdash;- Oh! END

BEGIN NOW cried her father. END
BEGIN NOW Nobody else would repeat what everybody has ceased to believe. END
BEGIN NOW You are an unnatural sister! END
BEGIN NOW cried Delphine. END
BEGIN NOW Oh, children, children! END
BEGIN NOW hush! END
BEGIN NOW hush! END
BEGIN NOW or I will kill myself before your eyes. END
BEGIN NOW There, Nasie, I forgive you, said de Nucingen; you are very unhappy. END
BEGIN NOW But I am kinder than you are. END
BEGIN NOW How could you say _that_ just when I was ready to do anything in the world to help you, even to be reconciled with my husband, which for my own sake I&mdash;-Oh! END
BEGIN NOW it is just like you; you have behaved cruelly to me all through these nine years. END

BEGIN NOW cried the father. END
BEGIN NOW You are angels, both of you. END
BEGIN NOW No. END
BEGIN NOW Let me alone, cried the Countess shaking off the hand that her father had laid on her arm. END
BEGIN NOW She is more merciless than my husband. END
BEGIN NOW Any one might think she was a model of all the virtues herself! END
BEGIN NOW I would rather have people think that I owed money to M. de Marsay than own that M. de Trailles had cost me more than two hundred thousand francs, retorted de Nucingen. END
BEGIN NOW _Delphine!_ cried the Countess, stepping towards her sister. END
BEGIN NOW I shall tell you the truth about yourself if you begin to slander me, said the Baroness coldly. END
BEGIN NOW Delphine! END
BEGIN NOW you are a &mdash;- Father Goriot sprang between them, grasped the Countess' hand, and laid his own over her mouth. END
BEGIN NOW Good heavens, father! END
BEGIN NOW What have you been handling this morning? END
BEGIN NOW said Anastasie. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW well, yes, I ought not to have touched you, said the poor father, wiping his hands on his trousers, but I have been packing up my things; I did not know that you were coming to see me. END
BEGIN NOW He was glad that he had drawn down her wrath upon himself. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END

BEGIN NOW cried the old man in his despair. END

BEGIN NOW he cried, tearing his hair. END
BEGIN NOW If I only knew of a way to steal money, but it is so hard to do it, and then you can't set to work by yourself, and it takes time to rob a bank. END

BEGIN NOW I am no good in the world; I am no longer a father! END

BEGIN NOW She has come to me in her extremity, and, wretch that I am, I have nothing to give her. END

BEGIN NOW Papa! END
BEGIN NOW cried both the young women at once, do, pray, be reasonable! END
BEGIN NOW and they clung to him to prevent him from dashing his head against the wall. END
BEGIN NOW There was a sound of sobbing. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene, greatly alarmed, took the bill that bore Vautrin's signature, saw that the stamp would suffice for a larger sum, altered the figures, made it into a regular bill for twelve thousand francs, payable to Goriot's order, and went to his neighbor's room. END
BEGIN NOW Here is the money, madame, he said, handing the piece of paper to her. END

BEGIN NOW And what are you? END

BEGIN NOW Father Goriot had left his room, and was just sitting down to dinner as he came in. END
BEGIN NOW Bianchon had placed himself where he could watch the old man carefully; and when the old vermicelli maker took up his square of bread and smelled it to find out the quality of the flour, the medical student, studying him closely, saw that the action was purely mechanical, and shook his head. END
BEGIN NOW Just come and sit over here, hospitaller of Cochin, said Eugene. END

BEGIN NOW asked Rastignac. END
BEGIN NOW It is all up with him, or I am much mistaken! END
BEGIN NOW Something very extraordinary must have taken place; he looks to me as if he were in imminent danger of serous apoplexy. END
BEGIN NOW The lower part of his face is composed enough, but the upper part is drawn and distorted. END
BEGIN NOW Then there is that peculiar look about the eyes that indicates an effusion of serum in the brain; they look as though they were covered with a film of fine dust, do you notice? END
BEGIN NOW I shall know more about it by to-morrow morning. END

BEGIN NOW None. END
BEGIN NOW It might be possible to stave death off for a time if a way could be found of setting up a reaction in the lower extremities; but if the symptoms do not abate by to-morrow evening, it will be all over with him, poor old fellow! END

BEGIN NOW There must have been some violent shock, and his mind has given way. END

BEGIN NOW But Delphine at any rate loves her father, he said to himself. END

BEGIN NOW Do not be anxious about him, she said, however, as soon as Eugene began, our father has really a strong constitution, but this morning we gave him a shock. END
BEGIN NOW Our whole fortunes were in peril, so the thing was serious, you see. END
BEGIN NOW I could not live if your affection did not make me insensible to troubles that I should once have thought too hard to bear. END

BEGIN NOW Everything else is as nothing to me compared with our love; I care for nothing else, for you are all the world to me. END

BEGIN NOW I cannot tell you, but all my life is in you. END
BEGIN NOW My father gave me a heart, but you have taught it to beat. END
BEGIN NOW The whole world may condemn me; what does it matter if I stand acquitted in your eyes, for you have no right to think ill of me for the faults which a tyrannous love has forced me to commit for you! END

BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW no, no one could help loving such a dear kind father as ours. END
BEGIN NOW But how could I hide the inevitable consequences of our miserable marriages from him? END

BEGIN NOW There are times in life when everything turns to bitterness. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene was silent, the artless and sincere outpouring made an impression on him. END
BEGIN NOW Parisian women are often false, intoxicated with vanity, selfish and self-absorbed, frivolous and shallow; yet of all women, when they love, they sacrifice their personal feelings to their passion; they rise but so much the higher for all the pettiness overcome in their nature, and become sublime. END
BEGIN NOW Then Eugene was struck by the profound discernment and insight displayed by this woman in judging of natural affection, when a privileged affection had separated and set her at a distance apart. END
BEGIN NOW de Nucingen was piqued by the silence, What are you thinking about? END
BEGIN NOW she asked. END
BEGIN NOW I am thinking about what you said just now. END
BEGIN NOW Hitherto I have always felt sure that I cared far more for you than you did for me. END
BEGIN NOW She smiled, and would not give way to the happiness she felt, lest their talk should exceed the conventional limits of propriety. END
BEGIN NOW She had never heard the vibrating tones of a sincere and youthful love; a few more words, and she feared for her self-control. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene, she said, changing the conversation, I wonder whether you know what has been happening? END
BEGIN NOW All Paris will go to de Beauseant's to-morrow. END
BEGIN NOW The Rochefides and the Marquis d'Ajuda have agreed to keep the matter a profound secret, but to-morrow the king will sign the marriage-contract, and your poor cousin the Vicomtesse knows nothing of it as yet. END

BEGIN NOW We shall know the truth to-morrow. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene did not return to the Maison Vauquer. END
BEGIN NOW He could not forego the pleasure of occupying his new rooms in the Rue d'Artois. END

BEGIN NOW Youth snatches eagerly at these rosy moments of happiness, and Eugene had almost forgotten Goriot's existence. END
BEGIN NOW The pretty things that surrounded him were growing familiar; this domestication in itself was one long festival for him, and de Nucingen was there to glorify it all by her presence. END

BEGIN NOW At any rate, I am some comfort to her in her misery; and that makes up for my unkindness in buying an annuity. END
BEGIN NOW She is in the depths, and I cannot draw her out of them now. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW I will go into business again, I will buy wheat in Odessa; out there, wheat fetches a quarter of the price it sells for here. END
BEGIN NOW There is a law against the importation of grain, but the good folk who made the law forgot to prohibit the introduction of wheat products and food stuffs made from corn. END
BEGIN NOW Hey! END
BEGIN NOW hey!... END
BEGIN NOW That struck me this morning. END
BEGIN NOW There is a fine trade to be done in starch. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene, watching the old man's face, thought that his friend was light-headed. END
BEGIN NOW Come, he said, do not talk any more, you must rest&mdash;- Just then Bianchon came up, and Eugene went down to dinner. END
BEGIN NOW The two students sat up with him that night, relieving each other in turn. END
BEGIN NOW Bianchon brought up his medical books and studied; Eugene wrote letters home to his mother and sisters. END
BEGIN NOW Next morning Bianchon thought the symptoms more hopeful, but the patient's condition demanded continual attention, which the two students alone were willing to give&mdash;a task impossible to describe in the squeamish phraseology of the epoch. END
BEGIN NOW Leeches must be applied to the wasted body, the poultices and hot foot-baths, and other details of the treatment required the physical strength and devotion of the two young men. END
BEGIN NOW de Restaud did not come; but she sent a messenger for the money. END
BEGIN NOW I expected she would come herself; but it would have been a pity for her to come, she would have been anxious about me, said the father, and to all appearances he was well content. END
BEGIN NOW At seven o'clock that evening Therese came with a letter from Delphine. END
BEGIN NOW What are you doing, dear friend? END
BEGIN NOW I have been loved for a very little while, and I am neglected already? END
BEGIN NOW In the confidences of heart and heart, I have learned to know your soul&mdash;you are too noble not to be faithful for ever, for you know that love with all its infinite subtle changes of feeling is never the same. END
BEGIN NOW Once you said, as we were listening to the Prayer in _Mose in Egitto_, 'For some it is the monotony of a single note; for others, it is the infinite of sound.' END

BEGIN NOW Every one knows now that the King signed M. d'Ajuda's marriage-contract this morning, and the poor Vicomtesse knew nothing of it until two o'clock this afternoon. END
BEGIN NOW All Paris will flock to her house, of course, just as a crowd fills the Place de Greve to see an execution. END
BEGIN NOW It is horrible, is it not, to go out of curiosity to see if she will hide her anguish, and whether she will die courageously? END
BEGIN NOW I certainly should not go, my friend, if I had been at her house before; but, of course, she will not receive society any more after this, and all my efforts would be in vain. END
BEGIN NOW My position is a very unusual one, and besides, I am going there partly on your account. END

BEGIN NOW If you are not beside me in less than two hours, I do not know whether I could forgive such treason. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac took up a pen and wrote: I am waiting till the doctor comes to know if there is any hope of your father's life. END
BEGIN NOW He is lying dangerously ill. END
BEGIN NOW I will come and bring you the news, but I am afraid it may be a sentence of death. END
BEGIN NOW When I come you can decide whether you can go to the ball.&mdash;Yours a thousand times. END
BEGIN NOW At half-past eight the doctor arrived. END
BEGIN NOW He did not take a very hopeful view of the case, but thought that there was no immediate danger. END
BEGIN NOW Improvements and relapses might be expected, and the good man's life and reason hung in the balance. END
BEGIN NOW It would be better for him to die at once, the doctor said as he took leave. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene left Goriot to Bianchon's care, and went to carry the sad news to de Nucingen. END
BEGIN NOW Family feeling lingered in her, and this must put an end for the present to her plans of amusement. END
BEGIN NOW Tell her to enjoy her evening as if nothing had happened, cried Goriot. END
BEGIN NOW He had been lying in a sort of stupor, but he suddenly sat upright as Eugene went out. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene, half heartbroken, entered Delphine's. END
BEGIN NOW Her hair had been dressed; she wore her dancing slippers; she had only to put on her ball-dress; but when the artist is giving the finishing stroke to his creation, the last touches require more time than the whole groundwork of the picture. END
BEGIN NOW Why, you are not dressed! END
BEGIN NOW she cried. END
BEGIN NOW Madame, your father&mdash;- My father again! END
BEGIN NOW she exclaimed, breaking in upon him. END
BEGIN NOW You need not teach me what is due to my father, I have known my father this long while. END

BEGIN NOW Do go, Monsieur Eugene, or you will vex madame, said Therese, hurrying him away; and Eugene was too horror-stricken by this elegant parricide to resist. END
BEGIN NOW He went to his rooms and dressed, sad, thoughtful, and dispirited. END
BEGIN NOW The world of Paris was like an ocean of mud for him just then; and it seemed that whoever set foot in that black mire must needs sink into it up to the chin. END
BEGIN NOW Their crimes are paltry, said Eugene to himself. END
BEGIN NOW Vautrin was greater. END
BEGIN NOW He had seen society in its three great phases&mdash;Obedience, Struggle, and Revolt; the Family, the World, and Vautrin; and he hesitated in his choice. END
BEGIN NOW Obedience was dull, Revolt impossible, Struggle hazardous. END
BEGIN NOW His thoughts wandered back to the home circle. END
BEGIN NOW He thought of the quiet uneventful life, the pure happiness of the days spent among those who loved him there. END
BEGIN NOW Those loving and beloved beings passed their lives in obedience to the natural laws of the hearth, and in that obedience found a deep and constant serenity, unvexed by torments such as these. END
BEGIN NOW Yet, for all his good impulses, he could not bring himself to make profession of the religion of pure souls to Delphine, nor to prescribe the duties of piety to her in the name of love. END
BEGIN NOW His education had begun to bear its fruits; he loved selfishly already. END
BEGIN NOW Besides, his tact had discovered to him the real nature of Delphine; he divined instinctively that she was capable of stepping over her father's corpse to go to the ball; and within himself he felt that he had neither the strength of mind to play the part of mentor, nor the strength of character to vex her, nor the courage to leave her to go alone. END
BEGIN NOW She would never forgive me for putting her in the wrong over it, he said to himself. END
BEGIN NOW Then he turned the doctor's dictum over in his mind; he tried to believe that Goriot was not so dangerously ill as he had imagined, and ended by collecting together a sufficient quantity of traitorous excuses for Delphine's conduct. END
BEGIN NOW She did not know how ill her father was; the kind old man himself would have made her go to the ball if she had gone to see him. END
BEGIN NOW So often it happens that this one or that stands condemned by the social laws that govern family relations; and yet there are peculiar circumstances in the case, differences of temperament, divergent interests, innumerable complications of family life that excuse the apparent offence. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene did not wish to see too clearly; he was ready to sacrifice his conscience to his mistress. END
BEGIN NOW Within the last few days his whole life had undergone a change. END
BEGIN NOW Woman had entered into his world and thrown it into chaos, family claims dwindled away before her; she had appropriated all his being to her uses. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac and Delphine found each other at a crisis in their lives when their union gave them the most poignant bliss. END
BEGIN NOW Their passion, so long proved, had only gained in strength by the gratified desire that often extinguishes passion. END
BEGIN NOW This woman was his, and Eugene recognized that not until then had he loved her; perhaps love is only gratitude for pleasure. END
BEGIN NOW This woman, vile or sublime, he adored for the pleasure she had brought as her dower; and Delphine loved Rastignac as Tantalus would have loved some angel who had satisfied his hunger and quenched the burning thirst in his parched throat. END
BEGIN NOW Well, said de Nucingen when he came back in evening dress, how is my father? END
BEGIN NOW Very dangerously ill, he answered; if you will grant me a proof of your affections, we will just go in to see him on the way. END
BEGIN NOW Very well, she said. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, but afterwards. END
BEGIN NOW Dear Eugene, do be nice, and don't preach to me. END
BEGIN NOW Come. END

BEGIN NOW Eugene said nothing for a while. END

BEGIN NOW she asked. END
BEGIN NOW I can hear the death-rattle in your father's throat, he said almost angrily. END
BEGIN NOW And with the hot indignation of youth, he told the story of de Restaud's vanity and cruelty, of her father's final act of self-sacrifice, that had brought about this struggle between life and death, of the price that had been paid for Anastasie's golden embroideries. END

BEGIN NOW The lamps of five hundred carriages lit up the darkness about the Hotel de Beauseant. END
BEGIN NOW A gendarme in all the glory of his uniform stood on either side of the brightly lighted gateway. END
BEGIN NOW The great world was flocking thither that night in its eager curiosity to see the great lady at the moment of her fall, and the rooms on the ground floor were already full to overflowing, when de Nucingen and Rastignac appeared. END
BEGIN NOW Never since Louis XIV. END
BEGIN NOW tore her lover away from La grand Mademoiselle, and the whole court hastened to visit that unfortunate princess, had a disastrous love affair made such a sensation in Paris. END
BEGIN NOW But the youngest daughter of the almost royal house of Burgundy had risen proudly above her pain, and moved till the last moment like a queen in this world&mdash;its vanities had always been valueless for her, save in so far as they contributed to the triumph of her passion. END
BEGIN NOW The salons were filled with the most beautiful women in Paris, resplendent in their toilettes, and radiant with smiles. END
BEGIN NOW Ministers and ambassadors, the most distinguished men at court, men bedizened with decorations, stars, and ribbons, men who bore the most illustrious names in France, had gathered about the Vicomtesse. END

BEGIN NOW Madame de Beauseant stood at the door of the first salon to receive the guests who were styled her friends. END
BEGIN NOW She was dressed in white, and wore no ornament in the plaits of hair braided about her head; her face was calm; there was no sign there of pride, nor of pain, nor of joy that she did not feel. END
BEGIN NOW No one could read her soul; she stood there like some Niobe carved in marble. END
BEGIN NOW For a few intimate friends there was a tinge of satire in her smile; but no scrutiny saw any change in her, nor had she looked otherwise in the days of the glory of her happiness. END

BEGIN NOW she asked him. END

BEGIN NOW It was nearly five o'clock that morning when Rastignac came away. END
BEGIN NOW He had put de Beauseant into her traveling carriage, and received her last farewells, spoken amid fast-falling tears; for no greatness is so great that it can rise above the laws of human affection, or live beyond the jurisdiction of pain, as certain demagogues would have the people believe. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene returned on foot to the Maison Vauquer through the cold and darkness. END
BEGIN NOW His education was nearly complete. END
BEGIN NOW There is no hope for poor Father Goriot, said Bianchon, as Rastignac came into the room. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene looked for a while at the sleeping man, then he turned to his friend. END
BEGIN NOW Dear fellow, you are content with the modest career you have marked out for yourself; keep to it. END

BEGIN NOW Believe everything that you hear said of the world, nothing is too impossibly bad. END
BEGIN NOW No Juvenal could paint the horrors hidden away under the covering of gems and gold. END
BEGIN NOW At two o'clock in the afternoon Bianchon came to wake Rastignac, and begged him to take charge of Goriot, who had grown worse as the day wore on. END
BEGIN NOW The medical student was obliged to go out. END
BEGIN NOW Poor old man, he has not two days to live, maybe not many hours, he said; but we must do our utmost, all the same, to fight the disease. END

BEGIN NOW A surgeon, a pupil of Gall's came, and our house surgeon, and the head physician from the Hotel-Dieu. END
BEGIN NOW Those gentlemen considered that the symptoms were very unusual and interesting; the case must be carefully watched, for it throws a light on several obscure and rather important scientific problems. END
BEGIN NOW One of the authorities says that if there is more pressure of serum on one or other portion of the brain, it should affect his mental capacities in such and such directions. END
BEGIN NOW So if he should talk, notice very carefully what kind of ideas his mind seems to run on; whether memory, or penetration, or the reasoning faculties are exercised; whether sentiments or practical questions fill his thoughts; whether he makes forecasts or dwells on the past; in fact; you must be prepared to give an accurate report of him. END
BEGIN NOW It is quite likely that the extravasation fills the whole brain, in which case he will die in the imbecile state in which he is lying now. END
BEGIN NOW You cannot tell anything about these mysterious nervous diseases. END
BEGIN NOW Suppose the crash came here, said Bianchon, touching the back of the head, very strange things have been known to happen; the brain sometimes partially recovers, and death is delayed. END

BEGIN NOW Well, at least the golden gown was grand, was it not? END

BEGIN NOW what pain this is!) END

BEGIN NOW For a father it is hell to be without your children; I have served my apprenticeship already since they married. END

BEGIN NOW I have heard some such things said. END
BEGIN NOW It is true? END
BEGIN NOW It is as if I could see them at this moment as they used to be when we all lived in the Rue de la Jussienne. END

BEGIN NOW We always had breakfast together, too, every morning, and they had dinner with me&mdash;in fact, I was a father then. END

BEGIN NOW this is agony!) END

END

BEGIN NOW They both of them have hearts of stone. END
BEGIN NOW I loved them too much; it was not likely that they should love me. END

BEGIN NOW If you but knew how much they made of me just after they were married. END
BEGIN NOW (Oh! END
BEGIN NOW this is cruel torture!) END
BEGIN NOW I had just given them each eight hundred thousand francs; they were bound to be civil to me after that, and their husbands too were civil. END
BEGIN NOW I used to go to their houses: it was 'My kind father' here, 'My dear father' there. END

BEGIN NOW I used to dine with their husbands now and then, and they were very respectful to me. END

BEGIN NOW How should they know? END
BEGIN NOW I had not said anything about my affairs. END
BEGIN NOW It is worth while to be civil to a man who has given his daughters eight hundred thousand francs apiece; and they showed me every attention then&mdash;but it was all for my money. END
BEGIN NOW Grand people are not great. END
BEGIN NOW I found that out by experience! END
BEGIN NOW I went to the theatre with them in their carriage; I might stay as long as I cared to stay at their evening parties. END
BEGIN NOW In fact, they acknowledged me their father; publicly they owned that they were my daughters. END
BEGIN NOW But I was always a shrewd one, you see, and nothing was lost upon me. END
BEGIN NOW Everything went straight to the mark and pierced my heart. END
BEGIN NOW I saw quite well that it was all sham and pretence, but there is no help for such things as these. END
BEGIN NOW I felt less at my ease at their dinner-table than I did downstairs here. END

BEGIN NOW they would say, and look again at me with the respect due to my money. END
BEGIN NOW Well, if I was in the way sometimes, I paid dearly for my mistakes. END
BEGIN NOW And besides, who is perfect? END
BEGIN NOW (My head is one sore!) END
BEGIN NOW Dear Monsieur Eugene, I am suffering so now, that a man might die of the pain; but it is nothing to be compared with the pain I endured when Anastasie made me feel, for the first time, that I had said something stupid. END
BEGIN NOW She looked at me, and that glance of hers opened all my veins. END

BEGIN NOW And that was how they both turned me out of the house. END

BEGIN NOW Thou knowest all the misery and anguish that I have endured; Thou hast counted all the wounds that have been dealt to me in these years that have aged and changed me and whitened my hair and drained my life; why dost Thou make me to suffer so to-day? END
BEGIN NOW Have I not more than expiated the sin of loving them too much? END
BEGIN NOW They themselves have been the instruments of vengeance; they have tortured me for my sin of affection. END
BEGIN NOW Ah, well! END
BEGIN NOW fathers know no better; I loved them so; I went back to them as a gambler goes to the gaming table. END

BEGIN NOW That is what comes of having your children well brought up. END
BEGIN NOW I could not go to school again at my time of life. END

BEGIN NOW The country will go to ruin if a father's rights are trampled under foot. END

BEGIN NOW The whole world turns on fatherly love; fatherly love is the foundation of society; it will crumble into ruin when children do not love their fathers. END

BEGIN NOW my friend, my good Monsieur Eugene, you do not know that it is when all the golden light in a glance suddenly turns to a leaden gray. END

BEGIN NOW a father hiding himself to get a glimpse of his children! END

BEGIN NOW There is a God in heaven who avenges us fathers whether we will or no. END

BEGIN NOW It is no one's affair but mine; man's justice and God's justice have nothing to do in it. END

BEGIN NOW I would have humbled myself in the dust for them. END

BEGIN NOW The most beautiful nature, the noblest soul, would have been spoiled by such indulgence. END

BEGIN NOW There is a fire in my bowels. END

BEGIN NOW How you must love your own father and mother! END

BEGIN NOW No, since their marriages they have been dead to me. END

BEGIN NOW It robs us of our daughters; we are left alone upon our deathbeds, and they are not with us then. END

BEGIN NOW Nasie! END
BEGIN NOW Fifine! END

BEGIN NOW the agony of it! END
BEGIN NOW You _shall_ see them. END

BEGIN NOW cried the old man, still wandering. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END

BEGIN NOW Ah! END

BEGIN NOW I met Christophe, he said; he is gone for your cab. END

BEGIN NOW my word, it would! END
BEGIN NOW What is the matter with you? END
BEGIN NOW You are as pale as death. END
BEGIN NOW Dear fellow, the moans and cries that I have just heard.... END

BEGIN NOW Ah! END

BEGIN NOW There, be quick and pawn it. END
BEGIN NOW I do not want to stop on the way to the Rue du Helder; there is not a moment to lose, I am afraid, and I must wait here till Christophe comes back. END

BEGIN NOW Rastignac rushed down the stairs, and drove off to the Rue du Helder. END
BEGIN NOW The awful scene through which he had just passed quickened his imagination, and he grew fiercely indignant. END

BEGIN NOW Eugene waited for a long while. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps her father is dying at this moment, he thought. END
BEGIN NOW Then the man came back, and Eugene followed him to the little drawing-room. END
BEGIN NOW M. de Restaud was standing before the fireless grate, and did not ask his visitor to seat himself. END
BEGIN NOW Monsieur le Comte, said Rastignac, M. Goriot, your father-in-law, is lying at the point of death in a squalid den in the Latin Quarter. END
BEGIN NOW He has not a penny to pay for firewood; he is expected to die at any moment, and keeps calling for his daughter&mdash;- I feel very little affection for M. Goriot, sir, as you probably are aware, the Count answered coolly. END
BEGIN NOW His character has been compromised in connection with de Restaud; he is the author of the misfortunes that have embittered my life and troubled my peace of mind. END
BEGIN NOW It is a matter of perfect indifference to me if he lives or dies. END
BEGIN NOW Now you know my feelings with regard to him. END
BEGIN NOW Public opinion may blame me, but I care nothing for public opinion. END
BEGIN NOW Just now I have other and much more important matters to think about than the things that fools and chatterers may say about me. END
BEGIN NOW As for de Restaud, she cannot leave the house; she is in no condition to do so. END
BEGIN NOW And, besides, I shall not allow her to leave it. END
BEGIN NOW Tell her father that as soon as she has done her duty by her husband and child she shall go to see him. END
BEGIN NOW If she has any love for her father, she can be free to go to him, if she chooses, in a few seconds; it lies entirely with her&mdash;- Monsieur le Comte, it is no business of mine to criticise your conduct; you can do as you please with your wife, but may I count upon your keeping your word with me? END
BEGIN NOW Well, then, promise me to tell her that her father has not twenty-four hours to live; that he looks in vain for her, and has cursed her already as he lies on his deathbed,&mdash;that is all I ask. END
BEGIN NOW You can tell her yourself, the Count answered, impressed by the thrill of indignation in Eugene's voice. END
BEGIN NOW The Count led the way to the room where his wife usually sat. END
BEGIN NOW She was drowned in tears, and lay crouching in the depths of an armchair, as if she were tired of life and longed to die. END
BEGIN NOW It was piteous to see her. END
BEGIN NOW Before venturing to look at Rastignac, she glanced at her husband in evident and abject terror that spoke of complete prostration of body and mind; she seemed crushed by a tyranny both mental and physical. END
BEGIN NOW The Count jerked his head towards her; she construed this as a permission to speak. END
BEGIN NOW I heard all that you said, monsieur. END
BEGIN NOW Tell my father that if he knew all he would forgive me.... END
BEGIN NOW I did not think there was such torture in the world as this; it is more than I can endure, monsieur!&mdash;But I will not give way as long as I live, she said, turning to her husband. END
BEGIN NOW I am a mother.&mdash;Tell my father that I have never sinned against him in spite of appearances! END
BEGIN NOW she cried aloud in her despair. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene bowed to the husband and wife; he guessed the meaning of the scene, and that this was a terrible crisis in the Countess' life. END
BEGIN NOW M. de Restaud's manner had told him that his errand was a fruitless one; he saw that Anastasie had no longer any liberty of action. END
BEGIN NOW He came away mazed and bewildered, and hurried to de Nucingen. END
BEGIN NOW Delphine was in bed. END
BEGIN NOW Poor dear Eugene, I am ill, she said. END
BEGIN NOW I caught cold after the ball, and I am afraid of pneumonia. END
BEGIN NOW I am waiting for the doctor to come. END
BEGIN NOW If you were at death's door, Eugene broke in, you must be carried somehow to your father. END
BEGIN NOW He is calling for you. END
BEGIN NOW If you could hear the faintest of those cries, you would not feel ill any longer. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene, I dare say my father is not quite so ill as you say; but I cannot bear to do anything that you do not approve, so I will do just as you wish. END
BEGIN NOW As for _him_, he would die of grief I know if I went out to see him and brought on a dangerous illness. END
BEGIN NOW Well, I will go as soon as I have seen the doctor.&mdash;Ah! END
BEGIN NOW she cried out, you are not wearing your watch, how is that? END
BEGIN NOW Eugene reddened. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene, Eugene! END
BEGIN NOW if you have sold it already or lost it.... Oh! END
BEGIN NOW it would be very wrong of you! END
BEGIN NOW The student bent over Delphine and said in her ear, Do you want to know? END
BEGIN NOW Very well, then, you shall know. END
BEGIN NOW Your father has nothing left to pay for the shroud that they will lay him in this evening. END
BEGIN NOW Your watch has been pawned, for I had nothing either. END
BEGIN NOW Delphine sprang out of bed, ran to her desk, and took out her purse. END
BEGIN NOW She gave it to Eugene, and rang the bell, crying: I will go, I will go at once, Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW Leave me, I will dress. END
BEGIN NOW Why, I should be an unnatural daughter! END
BEGIN NOW Go back; I will be there before you.&mdash;Therese, she called to the waiting-woman, ask M. de Nucingen to come upstairs at once and speak to me. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene was almost happy when he reached the Rue Nueve-Sainte-Genevieve; he was so glad to bring the news to the dying man that one of his daughters was coming. END
BEGIN NOW He fumbled in Delphine's purse for money, so as to dismiss the cab at once; and discovered that the young, beautiful, and wealthy woman of fashion had only seventy francs in her private purse. END
BEGIN NOW He climbed the stairs and found Bianchon supporting Goriot, while the house surgeon from the hospital was applying moxas to the patient's back&mdash;under the direction of the physician, it was the last expedient of science, and it was tried in vain. END
BEGIN NOW Can you feel them? END
BEGIN NOW asked the physician. END
BEGIN NOW But Goriot had caught sight of Rastignac, and answered, They are coming, are they not? END
BEGIN NOW There is hope yet, said the surgeon; he can speak. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, said Eugene, Delphine is coming. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW that is nothing! END
BEGIN NOW said Bianchon; he has been talking about his daughters all the time. END
BEGIN NOW He calls for them as a man impaled calls for water, they say&mdash;- We may as well give up, said the physician, addressing the surgeon. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing more can be done now; the case is hopeless. END
BEGIN NOW Bianchon and the house surgeon stretched the dying man out again on his loathsome bed. END
BEGIN NOW But the sheets ought to be changed, added the physician. END
BEGIN NOW Even if there is no hope left, something is due to human nature. END
BEGIN NOW I shall come back again, Bianchon, he said, turning to the medical student. END
BEGIN NOW If he complains again, rub some laudanum over the diaphragm. END
BEGIN NOW He went, and the house surgeon went with him. END
BEGIN NOW Come, Eugene, pluck up heart, my boy, said Bianchon, as soon as they were alone; we must set about changing his sheets, and put him into a clean shirt. END
BEGIN NOW Go and tell Sylvie to bring some sheets and come and help us to make the bed. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene went downstairs, and found Vauquer engaged in setting the table; Sylvie was helping her. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene had scarcely opened his mouth before the widow walked up to him with the acidulous sweet smile of a cautious shopkeeper who is anxious neither to lose money nor to offend a customer. END
BEGIN NOW My dear Monsieur Eugene, she said, when he had spoken, you know quite as well as I do that Father Goriot has not a brass farthing left. END
BEGIN NOW If you give out clean linen for a man who is just going to turn up his eyes, you are not likely to see your sheets again, for one is sure to be wanted to wrap him in. END
BEGIN NOW Now, you owe me a hundred and forty-four francs as it is, add forty francs for the pair of sheets, and then there are several little things, besides the candle that Sylvie will give you; altogether it will all mount up to at least two hundred francs, which is more than a poor widow like me can afford to lose. END
BEGIN NOW Lord! END
BEGIN NOW now, Monsieur Eugene, look at it fairly. END
BEGIN NOW I have lost quite enough in these five days since this run of ill-luck set in for me. END
BEGIN NOW I would rather than ten crowns that the old gentlemen had moved out as you said. END
BEGIN NOW It sets the other lodgers against the house. END
BEGIN NOW It would not take much to make me send him to the workhouse. END
BEGIN NOW In short, just put yourself in my place. END
BEGIN NOW I have to think of my establishment first, for I have my own living to make. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene hurried up to Goriot's room. END
BEGIN NOW Bianchon, he cried, the money for the watch? END
BEGIN NOW There it is on the table, or the three hundred and sixty odd francs that are left of it. END
BEGIN NOW I paid up all the old scores out of it before they let me have the things. END
BEGIN NOW The pawn ticket lies there under the money. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac hurried downstairs. END
BEGIN NOW Here, madame he said in disgust, let us square accounts. END
BEGIN NOW M. Goriot will not stay much longer in your house, nor shall I&mdash;- Yes, he will go out feet foremost, poor old gentleman, she said, counting the francs with a half-facetious, half-lugubrious expression. END
BEGIN NOW Let us get this over, said Rastignac. END
BEGIN NOW Sylvie, look out some sheets, and go upstairs to help the gentlemen. END
BEGIN NOW You won't forget Sylvie, said Vauquer in Eugene's ear; she has been sitting up these two nights. END
BEGIN NOW As soon as Eugene's back was turned, the old woman hurried after her handmaid. END
BEGIN NOW Take the sheets that have had the sides turned into the middle, number Lord! END
BEGIN NOW they are plenty good enough for a corpse, she said in Sylvie's ear. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene, by this time, was part of the way upstairs, and did not overhear the elderly economist. END
BEGIN NOW Quick, said Bianchon, let us change his shirt. END
BEGIN NOW Hold him upright. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene went to the head of the bed and supported the dying man, while Bianchon drew off his shirt; and then Goriot made a movement as if he tried to clutch something to his breast, uttering a low inarticulate moaning the while, like some dumb animal in mortal pain. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW yes! END
BEGIN NOW cried Bianchon. END
BEGIN NOW It is the little locket and the chain made of hair that he wants; we took it off a while ago when we put the blisters on him. END
BEGIN NOW Poor fellow! END
BEGIN NOW he must have it again. END
BEGIN NOW There it lies on the chimney-piece. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene went to the chimney-piece and found the little plait of faded golden hair&mdash; Goriot's hair, no doubt. END
BEGIN NOW He read the name on the little round locket, ANASTASIE on the one side, DELPHINE on the other. END
BEGIN NOW It was the symbol of his own heart that the father always wore on his breast. END
BEGIN NOW The curls of hair inside the locket were so fine and soft that is was plain they had been taken from two childish heads. END
BEGIN NOW When the old man felt the locket once more, his chest heaved with a long deep sigh of satisfaction, like a groan. END
BEGIN NOW It was something terrible to see, for it seemed as if the last quiver of the nerves were laid bare to their eyes, the last communication of sense to the mysterious point within whence our sympathies come and whither they go. END
BEGIN NOW A delirious joy lighted up the distorted face. END
BEGIN NOW The terrific and vivid force of the feeling that had survived the power of thought made such an impression on the students, that the dying man felt their hot tears falling on him, and gave a shrill cry of delight. END
BEGIN NOW Nasie! END
BEGIN NOW Fifine! END
BEGIN NOW There is life in him yet, said Bianchon. END
BEGIN NOW What does he go on living for? END
BEGIN NOW said Sylvie. END
BEGIN NOW To suffer, answered Rastignac. END
BEGIN NOW Bianchon made a sign to his friend to follow his example, knelt down and pressed his arms under the sick man, and Rastignac on the other side did the same, so that Sylvie, standing in readiness, might draw the sheet from beneath and replace it with the one that she had brought. END
BEGIN NOW Those tears, no doubt, had misled Goriot; for he gathered up all his remaining strength in a last effort, stretched out his hands, groped for the students' heads, and as his fingers caught convulsively at their hair, they heard a faint whisper: Ah! END
BEGIN NOW my angels! END
BEGIN NOW Two words, two inarticulate murmurs, shaped into words by the soul which fled forth with them as they left his lips. END
BEGIN NOW Poor dear! END
BEGIN NOW cried Sylvie, melted by that exclamation; the expression of the great love raised for the last time to a sublime height by that most ghastly and involuntary of lies. END
BEGIN NOW The father's last breath must have been a sigh of joy, and in that sigh his whole life was summed up; he was cheated even at the last. END
BEGIN NOW They laid Father Goriot upon his wretched bed with reverent hands. END
BEGIN NOW Thenceforward there was no expression on his face, only the painful traces of the struggle between life and death that was going on in the machine; for that kind of cerebral consciousness that distinguishes between pleasure and pain in a human being was extinguished; it was only a question of time&mdash;and the mechanism itself would be destroyed. END
BEGIN NOW He will lie like this for several hours, and die so quietly at last, that we shall not know when he goes; there will be no rattle in the throat. END
BEGIN NOW The brain must be completely suffused. END
BEGIN NOW As he spoke there was a footstep on the staircase, and a young woman hastened up, panting for breath. END
BEGIN NOW She has come too late, said Rastignac. END
BEGIN NOW But it was not Delphine; it was Therese, her waiting-woman, who stood in the doorway. END
BEGIN NOW Monsieur Eugene, she said, monsieur and madame have had a terrible scene about some money that Madame (poor thing!) END
BEGIN NOW wanted for her father. END
BEGIN NOW She fainted, and the doctor came, and she had to be bled, calling out all the while, 'My father is dying; I want to see papa!' END
BEGIN NOW It was heartbreaking to hear her&mdash;- That will do, Therese. END
BEGIN NOW If she came now, it would be trouble thrown away. END
BEGIN NOW M. Goriot cannot recognize any one now. END
BEGIN NOW Poor, dear gentleman, is he as bad at that? END
BEGIN NOW said Therese. END
BEGIN NOW You don't want me now, I must go and look after my dinner; it is half-past four, remarked Sylvie. END
BEGIN NOW The next instant she all but collided with de Restaud on the landing outside. END
BEGIN NOW There was something awful and appalling in the sudden apparition of the Countess. END
BEGIN NOW She saw the bed of death by the dim light of the single candle, and her tears flowed at the sight of her father's passive features, from which the life had almost ebbed. END
BEGIN NOW Bianchon with thoughtful tact left the room. END
BEGIN NOW I could not escape soon enough, she said to Rastignac. END
BEGIN NOW The student bowed sadly in reply. END
BEGIN NOW de Restaud took her father's hand and kissed it. END
BEGIN NOW Forgive me, father! END
BEGIN NOW You used to say that my voice would call you back from the grave; ah! END
BEGIN NOW come back for one moment to bless your penitent daughter. END
BEGIN NOW Do you hear me? END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW this is fearful! END
BEGIN NOW No one on earth will ever bless me henceforth; every one hates me; no one loves me but you in all the world. END
BEGIN NOW My own children will hate me. END
BEGIN NOW Take me with you, father; I will love you, I will take care of you. END
BEGIN NOW He does not hear me\... END
BEGIN NOW I am mad... She fell on her knees, and gazed wildly at the human wreck before her. END
BEGIN NOW My cup of misery is full, she said, turning her eyes upon Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW M. de Trailles has fled, leaving enormous debts behind him, and I have found out that he was deceiving me. END
BEGIN NOW My husband will never forgive me, and I have left my fortune in his hands. END
BEGIN NOW I have lost all my illusions. END
BEGIN NOW Alas! END
BEGIN NOW I have forsaken the one heart that loved me (she pointed to her father as she spoke), and for whom? END
BEGIN NOW I have held his kindness cheap, and slighted his affection; many and many a time I have given him pain, ungrateful wretch that I am! END
BEGIN NOW He knew it, said Rastignac. END
BEGIN NOW Just then Goriot's eyelids unclosed; it was only a muscular contraction, but the Countess' sudden start of reviving hope was no less dreadful than the dying eyes. END
BEGIN NOW Is it possible that he can hear me? END
BEGIN NOW cried the Countess. END
BEGIN NOW No, she answered herself, and sat down beside the bed. END
BEGIN NOW As de Restaud seemed to wish to sit by her father, Eugene went down to take a little food. END
BEGIN NOW The boarders were already assembled. END
BEGIN NOW Well, remarked the painter, as he joined them, it seems that there is to be a death-orama upstairs. END
BEGIN NOW Charles, I think you might find something less painful to joke about, said Eugene. END
BEGIN NOW So we may not laugh here? END
BEGIN NOW returned the painter. END
BEGIN NOW What harm does it do? END
BEGIN NOW Bianchon said that the old man was quite insensible. END
BEGIN NOW Well, then, said the _employe_ from the Museum, he will die as he has lived. END
BEGIN NOW My father is dead! END
BEGIN NOW shrieked the Countess. END
BEGIN NOW The terrible cry brought Sylvie, Rastignac, and Bianchon; de Restaud had fainted away. END
BEGIN NOW When she recovered they carried her downstairs, and put her into the cab that stood waiting at the door. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene sent Therese with her, and bade the maid take the Countess to de Nucingen. END
BEGIN NOW Bianchon came down to them. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, he is dead, he said. END
BEGIN NOW Come, sit down to dinner, gentlemen, said Vauquer, or the soup will be cold. END
BEGIN NOW The two students sat down together. END
BEGIN NOW What is the next thing to be done? END
BEGIN NOW Eugene asked of Bianchon. END
BEGIN NOW I have closed his eyes and composed his limbs, said Bianchon. END
BEGIN NOW When the certificate has been officially registered at the Mayor's office, we will sew him in his winding sheet and bury him somewhere. END
BEGIN NOW What do you think we ought to do? END
BEGIN NOW He will not smell at his bread like this any more, said the painter, mimicking the old man's little trick. END
BEGIN NOW Oh, hang it all! END
BEGIN NOW cried the tutor, let Father Goriot drop, and let us have something else for a change. END
BEGIN NOW He is a standing dish, and we have had him with every sauce this hour or more. END
BEGIN NOW It is one of the privileges of the good city of Paris that anybody may be born, or live, or die there without attracting any attention whatsoever. END
BEGIN NOW Let us profit by the advantages of civilization. END
BEGIN NOW There are fifty or sixty deaths every day; if you have a mind to do it, you can sit down at any time and wail over whole hecatombs of dead in Paris. END
BEGIN NOW Father Goriot has gone off the hooks, has he? END
BEGIN NOW So much the better for him. END
BEGIN NOW If you venerate his memory, keep it to yourselves, and let the rest of us feed in peace. END
BEGIN NOW Oh, to be sure, said the widow, it is all the better for him that he is dead. END
BEGIN NOW It looks as though he had had trouble enough, poor soul, while he was alive. END
BEGIN NOW And this was all the funeral oration delivered over him who had been for Eugene the type and embodiment of Fatherhood. END
BEGIN NOW The fifteen lodgers began to talk as usual. END
BEGIN NOW When Bianchon and Eugene had satisfied their hunger, the rattle of spoons and forks, the boisterous conversation, the expressions on the faces that bespoke various degrees of want of feeling, gluttony, or indifference, everything about them made them shiver with loathing. END
BEGIN NOW They went out to find a priest to watch that night with the dead. END
BEGIN NOW It was necessary to measure their last pious cares by the scanty sum of money that remained. END
BEGIN NOW Before nine o'clock that evening the body was laid out on the bare sacking of the bedstead in the desolate room; a lighted candle stood on either side, and the priest watched at the foot. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac made inquiries of this latter as to the expenses of the funeral, and wrote to the Baron de Nucingen and the Comte de Restaud, entreating both gentlemen to authorize their man of business to defray the charges of laying their father-in-law in the grave. END
BEGIN NOW He sent Christophe with the letters; then he went to bed, tired out, and slept. END
BEGIN NOW Next day Bianchon and Rastignac were obliged to take the certificate to the registrar themselves, and by twelve o'clock the formalities were completed. END
BEGIN NOW Two hours went by, no word came from the Count nor from the Baron; nobody appeared to act for them, and Rastignac had already been obliged to pay the priest. END
BEGIN NOW Sylvie asked ten francs for sewing the old man in his winding-sheet and making him ready for the grave, and Eugene and Bianchon calculated that they had scarcely sufficient to pay for the funeral, if nothing was forthcoming from the dead man's family. END
BEGIN NOW So it was the medical student who laid him in a pauper's coffin, despatched from Bianchon's hospital, whence he obtained it at a cheaper rate. END
BEGIN NOW Let us play those wretches a trick, said he. END
BEGIN NOW Go to the cemetery, buy a grave for five years at Pere-Lachaise, and arrange with the Church and the undertaker to have a third-class funeral. END
BEGIN NOW If the daughters and their husbands decline to repay you, you can carve this on the headstone&mdash;'_Here lies M. Goriot, father of the Comtesse de Restaud and the Baronne de Nucingen, interred at the expense of two students_.' END
BEGIN NOW Eugene took part of his friend's advice, but only after he had gone in person first to M. and de Nucingen, and then to M. and de Restaud&mdash;a fruitless errand. END
BEGIN NOW He went no further than the doorstep in either house. END
BEGIN NOW The servants had received strict orders to admit no one. END
BEGIN NOW Monsieur and Madame can see no visitors. END
BEGIN NOW They have just lost their father, and are in deep grief over their loss. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene's Parisian experience told him that it was idle to press the point. END
BEGIN NOW Something clutched strangely at his heart when he saw that it was impossible to reach Delphine. END
BEGIN NOW Sell some of your ornaments, he wrote hastily in the porter's room, so that your father may be decently laid in his last resting-place. END
BEGIN NOW He sealed the note, and begged the porter to give it to Therese for her mistress; but the man took it to the Baron de Nucingen, who flung the note into the fire. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene, having finished his errands, returned to the lodging-house about three o'clock. END
BEGIN NOW In spite of himself, the tears came into his eyes. END
BEGIN NOW The coffin, in its scanty covering of black cloth, was standing there on the pavement before the gate, on two chairs. END
