BEGIN NOW A withered sprig of hyssop was soaking in the holy water bowl of silver-plated copper; there was not a soul in the street, not a passer-by had stopped to sprinkle the coffin; there was not even an attempt at a black drapery over the wicket. END
BEGIN NOW It was a pauper who lay there; no one made a pretence of mourning for him; he had neither friends nor kindred&mdash;there was no one to follow him to the grave. END
BEGIN NOW Bianchon's duties compelled him to be at the hospital, but he had left a few lines for Eugene, telling his friend about the arrangements he had made for the burial service. END
BEGIN NOW The house student's note told Rastignac that a mass was beyond their means, that the ordinary office for the dead was cheaper, and must suffice, and that he had sent word to the undertaker by Christophe. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene had scarcely finished reading Bianchon's scrawl, when he looked up and saw the little circular gold locket that contained the hair of Goriot's two daughters in Vauquer's hands. END
BEGIN NOW How dared you take it? END
BEGIN NOW he asked. END
BEGIN NOW Good Lord! END
BEGIN NOW is that to be buried along with him? END
BEGIN NOW retorted Sylvie. END
BEGIN NOW It is gold. END
BEGIN NOW Of course it shall! END
BEGIN NOW Eugene answered indignantly; he shall at any rate take one thing that may represent his daughters into the grave with him. END
BEGIN NOW When the hearse came, Eugene had the coffin carried into the house again, unscrewed the lid, and reverently laid on the old man's breast the token that recalled the days when Delphine and Anastasie were innocent little maidens, before they began to think for themselves, as he had moaned out in his agony. END
BEGIN NOW Rastignac and Christophe and the two undertaker's men were the only followers of the funeral. END
BEGIN NOW The Church of Saint-Etienne du Mont was only a little distance from the Rue Nueve-Sainte-Genevieve. END
BEGIN NOW When the coffin had been deposited in a low, dark, little chapel, the law student looked round in vain for Goriot's two daughters or their husbands. END
BEGIN NOW Christophe was his only fellow-mourner; Christophe, who appeared to think it was his duty to attend the funeral of the man who had put him in the way of such handsome tips. END
BEGIN NOW As they waited there in the chapel for the two priests, the chorister, and the beadle, Rastignac grasped Christophe's hand. END
BEGIN NOW He could not utter a word just then. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, Monsieur Eugene, said Christophe, he was a good and worthy man, who never said one word louder than another; he never did any one any harm, and gave nobody any trouble. END
BEGIN NOW The two priests, the chorister, and the beadle came, and said and did as much as could be expected for seventy francs in an age when religion cannot afford to say prayers for nothing. END
BEGIN NOW The ecclesiatics chanted a psalm, the _Libera nos_ and the _De profundis_. END
BEGIN NOW The whole service lasted about twenty minutes. END
BEGIN NOW There was but one mourning coach, which the priest and chorister agreed to share with Eugene and Christophe. END
BEGIN NOW There is no one else to follow us, remarked the priest, so we may as well go quickly, and so save time; it is half-past five. END
BEGIN NOW But just as the coffin was put in the hearse, two empty carriages, with the armorial bearings of the Comte de Restaud and the Baron de Nucingen, arrived and followed in the procession to Pere-Lachaise. END
BEGIN NOW At six o'clock Goriot's coffin was lowered into the grave, his daughters' servants standing round the while. END
BEGIN NOW The ecclesiastic recited the short prayer that the students could afford to pay for, and then both priest and lackeys disappeared at once. END
BEGIN NOW The two grave diggers flung in several spadefuls of earth, and then stopped and asked Rastignac for their fee. END
BEGIN NOW Eugene felt in vain in his pocket, and was obliged to borrow five francs of Christophe. END
BEGIN NOW This thing, so trifling in itself, gave Rastignac a terrible pang of distress. END
BEGIN NOW It was growing dusk, the damp twilight fretted his nerves; he gazed down into the grave and the tears he shed were drawn from him by the sacred emotion, a single-hearted sorrow. END
BEGIN NOW When such tears fall on earth, their radiance reaches heaven. END
BEGIN NOW And with that tear that fell on Father Goriot's grave, Eugene Rastignac's youth ended. END
BEGIN NOW He folded his arms and gazed at the clouded sky; and Christophe, after a glance at him, turned and went&mdash;Rastignac was left alone. END
BEGIN NOW He went a few paces further, to the highest point of the cemetery, and looked out over Paris and the windings of the Seine; the lamps were beginning to shine on either side of the river. END
BEGIN NOW His eyes turned almost eagerly to the space between the column of the Place Vendome and the cupola of the Invalides; there lay the shining world that he had wished to reach. END
BEGIN NOW He glanced over that humming hive, seeming to draw a foretaste of its honey, and said magniloquently: Henceforth there is war between us. END
BEGIN NOW And by way of throwing down the glove to Society, Rastignac went to dine with de Nucingen.  END
BEGIN NOW  The family of Dashwood had long been settled in Sussex. END
BEGIN NOW Their estate was large, and their residence was at Norland Park, in the centre of their property, where, for many generations, they had lived in so respectable a manner as to engage the general good opinion of their surrounding acquaintance. END
BEGIN NOW The late owner of this estate was a single man, who lived to a very advanced age, and who for many years of his life, had a constant companion and housekeeper in his sister. END
BEGIN NOW But her death, which happened ten years before his own, produced a great alteration in his home; for to supply her loss, he invited and received into his house the family of his nephew Mr. Henry Dashwood, the legal inheritor of the Norland estate, and the person to whom he intended to bequeath it. END
BEGIN NOW In the society of his nephew and niece, and their children, the old Gentleman's days were comfortably spent. END
BEGIN NOW His attachment to them all increased. END
BEGIN NOW The constant attention of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Dashwood to his wishes, which proceeded not merely from interest, but from goodness of heart, gave him every degree of solid comfort which his age could receive; and the cheerfulness of the children added a relish to his existence. END
BEGIN NOW By a former marriage, Mr. Henry Dashwood had one son: by his present lady, three daughters. END
BEGIN NOW The son, a steady respectable young man, was amply provided for by the fortune of his mother, which had been large, and half of which devolved on him on his coming of age. END
BEGIN NOW By his own marriage, likewise, which happened soon afterwards, he added to his wealth. END
BEGIN NOW To him therefore the succession to the Norland estate was not so really important as to his sisters; for their fortune, independent of what might arise to them from their father's inheriting that property, could be but small. END
BEGIN NOW Their mother had nothing, and their father only seven thousand pounds in his own disposal; for the remaining moiety of his first wife's fortune was also secured to her child, and he had only a life-interest in it. END
BEGIN NOW The old gentleman died: his will was read, and like almost every other will, gave as much disappointment as pleasure. END
BEGIN NOW He was neither so unjust, nor so ungrateful, as to leave his estate from his nephew;&mdash;but he left it to him on such terms as destroyed half the value of the bequest. END
BEGIN NOW Mr. Dashwood had wished for it more for the sake of his wife and daughters than for himself or his son;&mdash;but to his son, and his son's son, a child of four years old, it was secured, in such a way, as to leave to himself no power of providing for those who were most dear to him, and who most needed a provision by any charge on the estate, or by any sale of its valuable woods. END
BEGIN NOW The whole was tied up for the benefit of this child, who, in occasional visits with his father and mother at Norland, had so far gained on the affections of his uncle, by such attractions as are by no means unusual in children of two or three years old; an imperfect articulation, an earnest desire of having his own way, many cunning tricks, and a great deal of noise, as to outweigh all the value of all the attention which, for years, he had received from his niece and her daughters. END
BEGIN NOW He meant not to be unkind, however, and, as a mark of his affection for the three girls, he left them a thousand pounds a-piece. END
BEGIN NOW Mr. Dashwood's disappointment was, at first, severe; but his temper was cheerful and sanguine; and he might reasonably hope to live many years, and by living economically, lay by a considerable sum from the produce of an estate already large, and capable of almost immediate improvement. END
BEGIN NOW But the fortune, which had been so tardy in coming, was his only one twelvemonth. END
BEGIN NOW He survived his uncle no longer; and ten thousand pounds, including the late legacies, was all that remained for his widow and daughters. END
BEGIN NOW His son was sent for as soon as his danger was known, and to him Mr. Dashwood recommended, with all the strength and urgency which illness could command, the interest of his mother-in-law and sisters. END
BEGIN NOW Mr. John Dashwood had not the strong feelings of the rest of the family; but he was affected by a recommendation of such a nature at such a time, and he promised to do every thing in his power to make them comfortable. END
BEGIN NOW His father was rendered easy by such an assurance, and Mr. John Dashwood had then leisure to consider how much there might prudently be in his power to do for them. END
BEGIN NOW He was not an ill-disposed young man, unless to be rather cold hearted and rather selfish is to be ill-disposed: but he was, in general, well respected; for he conducted himself with propriety in the discharge of his ordinary duties. END
BEGIN NOW Had he married a more amiable woman, he might have been made still more respectable than he was:&mdash;he might even have been made amiable himself; for he was very young when he married, and very fond of his wife. END
BEGIN NOW But Mrs. John Dashwood was a strong caricature of himself;&mdash;more narrow-minded and selfish. END
BEGIN NOW When he gave his promise to his father, he meditated within himself to increase the fortunes of his sisters by the present of a thousand pounds a-piece. END
BEGIN NOW He then really thought himself equal to it. END
BEGIN NOW The prospect of four thousand a-year, in addition to his present income, besides the remaining half of his own mother's fortune, warmed his heart, and made him feel capable of generosity.&mdash; Yes, he would give them three thousand pounds: it would be liberal and handsome! END
BEGIN NOW It would be enough to make them completely easy. END
BEGIN NOW Three thousand pounds! END
BEGIN NOW he could spare so considerable a sum with little inconvenience. END
BEGIN NOW &mdash; He thought of it all day long, and for many days successively, and he did not repent. END
BEGIN NOW No sooner was his father's funeral over, than Mrs. John Dashwood, without sending any notice of her intention to her mother-in-law, arrived with her child and their attendants. END
BEGIN NOW No one could dispute her right to come; the house was her husband's from the moment of his father's decease; but the indelicacy of her conduct was so much the greater, and to a woman in Mrs. Dashwood's situation, with only common feelings, must have been highly unpleasing;&mdash;but in HER mind there was a sense of honor so keen, a generosity so romantic, that any offence of the kind, by whomsoever given or received, was to her a source of immovable disgust. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. John Dashwood had never been a favourite with any of her husband's family; but she had had no opportunity, till the present, of shewing them with how little attention to the comfort of other people she could act when occasion required it. END
BEGIN NOW So acutely did Mrs. Dashwood feel this ungracious behaviour, and so earnestly did she despise her daughter-in-law for it, that, on the arrival of the latter, she would have quitted the house for ever, had not the entreaty of her eldest girl induced her first to reflect on the propriety of going, and her own tender love for all her three children determined her afterwards to stay, and for their sakes avoid a breach with their brother. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor, this eldest daughter, whose advice was so effectual, possessed a strength of understanding, and coolness of judgment, which qualified her, though only nineteen, to be the counsellor of her mother, and enabled her frequently to counteract, to the advantage of them all, that eagerness of mind in Mrs. Dashwood which must generally have led to imprudence. END
BEGIN NOW She had an excellent heart;&mdash;her disposition was affectionate, and her feelings were strong; but she knew how to govern them: it was a knowledge which her mother had yet to learn; and which one of her sisters had resolved never to be taught. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne's abilities were, in many respects, quite equal to Elinor's. END
BEGIN NOW She was sensible and clever; but eager in everything: her sorrows, her joys, could have no moderation. END
BEGIN NOW She was generous, amiable, interesting: she was everything but prudent. END
BEGIN NOW The resemblance between her and her mother was strikingly great. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor saw, with concern, the excess of her sister's sensibility; but by Mrs. Dashwood it was valued and cherished. END
BEGIN NOW They encouraged each other now in the violence of their affliction. END
BEGIN NOW The agony of grief which overpowered them at first, was voluntarily renewed, was sought for, was created again and again. END
BEGIN NOW They gave themselves up wholly to their sorrow, seeking increase of wretchedness in every reflection that could afford it, and resolved against ever admitting consolation in future. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor, too, was deeply afflicted; but still she could struggle, she could exert herself. END
BEGIN NOW She could consult with her brother, could receive her sister-in-law on her arrival, and treat her with proper attention; and could strive to rouse her mother to similar exertion, and encourage her to similar forbearance. END
BEGIN NOW Margaret, the other sister, was a good-humored, well-disposed girl; but as she had already imbibed a good deal of Marianne's romance, without having much of her sense, she did not, at thirteen, bid fair to equal her sisters at a more advanced period of life. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. John Dashwood now installed herself mistress of Norland; and her mother and sisters-in-law were degraded to the condition of visitors. END
BEGIN NOW As such, however, they were treated by her with quiet civility; and by her husband with as much kindness as he could feel towards anybody beyond himself, his wife, and their child. END
BEGIN NOW He really pressed them, with some earnestness, to consider Norland as their home; and, as no plan appeared so eligible to Mrs. Dashwood as remaining there till she could accommodate herself with a house in the neighbourhood, his invitation was accepted. END
BEGIN NOW A continuance in a place where everything reminded her of former delight, was exactly what suited her mind. END
BEGIN NOW In seasons of cheerfulness, no temper could be more cheerful than hers, or possess, in a greater degree, that sanguine expectation of happiness which is happiness itself. END
BEGIN NOW But in sorrow she must be equally carried away by her fancy, and as far beyond consolation as in pleasure she was beyond alloy. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. John Dashwood did not at all approve of what her husband intended to do for his sisters. END
BEGIN NOW To take three thousand pounds from the fortune of their dear little boy would be impoverishing him to the most dreadful degree. END
BEGIN NOW She begged him to think again on the subject. END
BEGIN NOW How could he answer it to himself to rob his child, and his only child too, of so large a sum? END
BEGIN NOW And what possible claim could the Miss Dashwoods, who were related to him only by half blood, which she considered as no relationship at all, have on his generosity to so large an amount. END
BEGIN NOW It was very well known that no affection was ever supposed to exist between the children of any man by different marriages; and why was he to ruin himself, and their poor little Harry, by giving away all his money to his half sisters? END
BEGIN NOW It was my father's last request to me, replied her husband, that I should assist his widow and daughters. END
BEGIN NOW He did not know what he was talking of, I dare say; ten to one but he was light-headed at the time. END
BEGIN NOW Had he been in his right senses, he could not have thought of such a thing as begging you to give away half your fortune from your own child. END
BEGIN NOW He did not stipulate for any particular sum, my dear Fanny; he only requested me, in general terms, to assist them, and make their situation more comfortable than it was in his power to do. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps it would have been as well if he had left it wholly to myself. END
BEGIN NOW He could hardly suppose I should neglect them. END
BEGIN NOW But as he required the promise, I could not do less than give it; at least I thought so at the time. END
BEGIN NOW The promise, therefore, was given, and must be performed. END
BEGIN NOW Something must be done for them whenever they leave Norland and settle in a new home. END
BEGIN NOW Well, then, LET something be done for them; but THAT something need not be three thousand pounds. END
BEGIN NOW Consider, she added, that when the money is once parted with, it never can return. END
BEGIN NOW Your sisters will marry, and it will be gone for ever. END
BEGIN NOW If, indeed, it could be restored to our poor little boy&mdash; Why, to be sure, said her husband, very gravely, that would make great difference. END
BEGIN NOW The time may come when Harry will regret that so large a sum was parted with. END
BEGIN NOW If he should have a numerous family, for instance, it would be a very convenient addition. END
BEGIN NOW To be sure it would. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps, then, it would be better for all parties, if the sum were diminished one half.&mdash;Five hundred pounds would be a prodigious increase to their fortunes! END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW beyond anything great! END
BEGIN NOW What brother on earth would do half so much for his sisters, even if REALLY his sisters! END
BEGIN NOW And as it is&mdash;only half blood!&mdash;But you have such a generous spirit! END
BEGIN NOW I would not wish to do any thing mean, he replied. END
BEGIN NOW One had rather, on such occasions, do too much than too little. END
BEGIN NOW No one, at least, can think I have not done enough for them: even themselves, they can hardly expect more. END
BEGIN NOW There is no knowing what THEY may expect, said the lady, but we are not to think of their expectations: the question is, what you can afford to do. END
BEGIN NOW Certainly&mdash;and I think I may afford to give them five hundred pounds a-piece. END
BEGIN NOW As it is, without any addition of mine, they will each have about three thousand pounds on their mother's death&mdash;a very comfortable fortune for any young woman. END
BEGIN NOW To be sure it is; and, indeed, it strikes me that they can want no addition at all. END
BEGIN NOW They will have ten thousand pounds divided amongst them. END
BEGIN NOW If they marry, they will be sure of doing well, and if they do not, they may all live very comfortably together on the interest of ten thousand pounds. END
BEGIN NOW That is very true, and, therefore, I do not know whether, upon the whole, it would not be more advisable to do something for their mother while she lives, rather than for them&mdash;something of the annuity kind I mean.&mdash;My sisters would feel the good effects of it as well as herself. END
BEGIN NOW A hundred a year would make them all perfectly comfortable. END
BEGIN NOW His wife hesitated a little, however, in giving her consent to this plan. END
BEGIN NOW To be sure, said she, it is better than parting with fifteen hundred pounds at once. END
BEGIN NOW But, then, if Mrs. Dashwood should live fifteen years we shall be completely taken in. END
BEGIN NOW Fifteen years! END
BEGIN NOW my dear Fanny; her life cannot be worth half that purchase. END
BEGIN NOW Certainly not; but if you observe, people always live for ever when there is an annuity to be paid them; and she is very stout and healthy, and hardly forty. END
BEGIN NOW An annuity is a very serious business; it comes over and over every year, and there is no getting rid of it. END
BEGIN NOW You are not aware of what you are doing. END
BEGIN NOW I have known a great deal of the trouble of annuities; for my mother was clogged with the payment of three to old superannuated servants by my father's will, and it is amazing how disagreeable she found it. END
BEGIN NOW Twice every year these annuities were to be paid; and then there was the trouble of getting it to them; and then one of them was said to have died, and afterwards it turned out to be no such thing. END
BEGIN NOW My mother was quite sick of it. END
BEGIN NOW Her income was not her own, she said, with such perpetual claims on it; and it was the more unkind in my father, because, otherwise, the money would have been entirely at my mother's disposal, without any restriction whatever. END
BEGIN NOW It has given me such an abhorrence of annuities, that I am sure I would not pin myself down to the payment of one for all the world. END
BEGIN NOW It is certainly an unpleasant thing, replied Mr. Dashwood, to have those kind of yearly drains on one's income. END
BEGIN NOW One's fortune, as your mother justly says, is NOT one's own. END
BEGIN NOW To be tied down to the regular payment of such a sum, on every rent day, is by no means desirable: it takes away one's independence. END
BEGIN NOW Undoubtedly; and after all you have no thanks for it. END
BEGIN NOW They think themselves secure, you do no more than what is expected, and it raises no gratitude at all. END
BEGIN NOW If I were you, whatever I did should be done at my own discretion entirely. END
BEGIN NOW I would not bind myself to allow them any thing yearly. END
BEGIN NOW It may be very inconvenient some years to spare a hundred, or even fifty pounds from our own expenses. END
BEGIN NOW I believe you are right, my love; it will be better that there should be no annuity in the case; whatever I may give them occasionally will be of far greater assistance than a yearly allowance, because they would only enlarge their style of living if they felt sure of a larger income, and would not be sixpence the richer for it at the end of the year. END
BEGIN NOW It will certainly be much the best way. END
BEGIN NOW A present of fifty pounds, now and then, will prevent their ever being distressed for money, and will, I think, be amply discharging my promise to my father. END
BEGIN NOW To be sure it will. END
BEGIN NOW Indeed, to say the truth, I am convinced within myself that your father had no idea of your giving them any money at all. END
BEGIN NOW The assistance he thought of, I dare say, was only such as might be reasonably expected of you; for instance, such as looking out for a comfortable small house for them, helping them to move their things, and sending them presents of fish and game, and so forth, whenever they are in season. END
BEGIN NOW I'll lay my life that he meant nothing farther; indeed, it would be very strange and unreasonable if he did. END
BEGIN NOW Do but consider, my dear Mr. Dashwood, how excessively comfortable your mother-in-law and her daughters may live on the interest of seven thousand pounds, besides the thousand pounds belonging to each of the girls, which brings them in fifty pounds a year a-piece, and, of course, they will pay their mother for their board out of it. END
BEGIN NOW Altogether, they will have five hundred a-year amongst them, and what on earth can four women want for more than that?&mdash;They will live so cheap! END
BEGIN NOW Their housekeeping will be nothing at all. END
BEGIN NOW They will have no carriage, no horses, and hardly any servants; they will keep no company, and can have no expenses of any kind! END
BEGIN NOW Only conceive how comfortable they will be! END
BEGIN NOW Five hundred a year! END
BEGIN NOW I am sure I cannot imagine how they will spend half of it; and as to your giving them more, it is quite absurd to think of it. END
BEGIN NOW They will be much more able to give YOU something. END
BEGIN NOW Upon my word, said Mr. Dashwood, I believe you are perfectly right. END
BEGIN NOW My father certainly could mean nothing more by his request to me than what you say. END
BEGIN NOW I clearly understand it now, and I will strictly fulfil my engagement by such acts of assistance and kindness to them as you have described. END
BEGIN NOW When my mother removes into another house my services shall be readily given to accommodate her as far as I can. END
BEGIN NOW Some little present of furniture too may be acceptable then. END
BEGIN NOW Certainly, returned Mrs. John Dashwood. END
BEGIN NOW But, however, ONE thing must be considered. END
BEGIN NOW When your father and mother moved to Norland, though the furniture of Stanhill was sold, all the china, plate, and linen was saved, and is now left to your mother. END
BEGIN NOW Her house will therefore be almost completely fitted up as soon as she takes it. END
BEGIN NOW That is a material consideration undoubtedly. END
BEGIN NOW A valuable legacy indeed! END
BEGIN NOW And yet some of the plate would have been a very pleasant addition to our own stock here. END
BEGIN NOW Yes; and the set of breakfast china is twice as handsome as what belongs to this house. END
BEGIN NOW A great deal too handsome, in my opinion, for any place THEY can ever afford to live in. END
BEGIN NOW But, however, so it is. END
BEGIN NOW Your father thought only of THEM. END
BEGIN NOW And I must say this: that you owe no particular gratitude to him, nor attention to his wishes; for we very well know that if he could, he would have left almost everything in the world to THEM. END
BEGIN NOW This argument was irresistible. END
BEGIN NOW It gave to his intentions whatever of decision was wanting before; and he finally resolved, that it would be absolutely unnecessary, if not highly indecorous, to do more for the widow and children of his father, than such kind of neighbourly acts as his own wife pointed out. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Dashwood remained at Norland several months; not from any disinclination to move when the sight of every well known spot ceased to raise the violent emotion which it produced for a while; for when her spirits began to revive, and her mind became capable of some other exertion than that of heightening its affliction by melancholy remembrances, she was impatient to be gone, and indefatigable in her inquiries for a suitable dwelling in the neighbourhood of Norland; for to remove far from that beloved spot was impossible. END
BEGIN NOW But she could hear of no situation that at once answered her notions of comfort and ease, and suited the prudence of her eldest daughter, whose steadier judgment rejected several houses as too large for their income, which her mother would have approved. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Dashwood had been informed by her husband of the solemn promise on the part of his son in their favour, which gave comfort to his last earthly reflections. END
BEGIN NOW She doubted the sincerity of this assurance no more than he had doubted it himself, and she thought of it for her daughters' sake with satisfaction, though as for herself she was persuaded that a much smaller provision than L would support her in affluence. END
BEGIN NOW For their brother's sake, too, for the sake of his own heart, she rejoiced; and she reproached herself for being unjust to his merit before, in believing him incapable of generosity. END
BEGIN NOW His attentive behaviour to herself and his sisters convinced her that their welfare was dear to him, and, for a long time, she firmly relied on the liberality of his intentions. END
BEGIN NOW The contempt which she had, very early in their acquaintance, felt for her daughter-in-law, was very much increased by the farther knowledge of her character, which half a year's residence in her family afforded; and perhaps in spite of every consideration of politeness or maternal affection on the side of the former, the two ladies might have found it impossible to have lived together so long, had not a particular circumstance occurred to give still greater eligibility, according to the opinions of Mrs. Dashwood, to her daughters' continuance at Norland. END
BEGIN NOW This circumstance was a growing attachment between her eldest girl and the brother of Mrs. John Dashwood, a gentleman-like and pleasing young man, who was introduced to their acquaintance soon after his sister's establishment at Norland, and who had since spent the greatest part of his time there. END
BEGIN NOW Some mothers might have encouraged the intimacy from motives of interest, for Edward Ferrars was the eldest son of a man who had died very rich; and some might have repressed it from motives of prudence, for, except a trifling sum, the whole of his fortune depended on the will of his mother. END
BEGIN NOW But Mrs. Dashwood was alike uninfluenced by either consideration. END
BEGIN NOW It was enough for her that he appeared to be amiable, that he loved her daughter, and that Elinor returned the partiality. END
BEGIN NOW It was contrary to every doctrine of hers that difference of fortune should keep any couple asunder who were attracted by resemblance of disposition; and that Elinor's merit should not be acknowledged by every one who knew her, was to her comprehension impossible. END
BEGIN NOW Edward Ferrars was not recommended to their good opinion by any peculiar graces of person or address. END
BEGIN NOW He was not handsome, and his manners required intimacy to make them pleasing. END
BEGIN NOW He was too diffident to do justice to himself; but when his natural shyness was overcome, his behaviour gave every indication of an open, affectionate heart. END
BEGIN NOW His understanding was good, and his education had given it solid improvement. END
BEGIN NOW But he was neither fitted by abilities nor disposition to answer the wishes of his mother and sister, who longed to see him distinguished&mdash;as&mdash;they hardly knew what. END
BEGIN NOW They wanted him to make a fine figure in the world in some manner or other. END
BEGIN NOW His mother wished to interest him in political concerns, to get him into parliament, or to see him connected with some of the great men of the day. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. John Dashwood wished it likewise; but in the mean while, till one of these superior blessings could be attained, it would have quieted her ambition to see him driving a barouche. END
BEGIN NOW But Edward had no turn for great men or barouches. END
BEGIN NOW All his wishes centered in domestic comfort and the quiet of private life. END
BEGIN NOW Fortunately he had a younger brother who was more promising. END
BEGIN NOW Edward had been staying several weeks in the house before he engaged much of Mrs. Dashwood's attention; for she was, at that time, in such affliction as rendered her careless of surrounding objects. END
BEGIN NOW She saw only that he was quiet and unobtrusive, and she liked him for it. END
BEGIN NOW He did not disturb the wretchedness of her mind by ill-timed conversation. END
BEGIN NOW She was first called to observe and approve him farther, by a reflection which Elinor chanced one day to make on the difference between him and his sister. END
BEGIN NOW It was a contrast which recommended him most forcibly to her mother. END
BEGIN NOW It is enough, said she; to say that he is unlike Fanny is enough. END
BEGIN NOW It implies everything amiable. END
BEGIN NOW I love him already. END
BEGIN NOW I think you will like him, said Elinor, when you know more of him. END
BEGIN NOW Like him! END
BEGIN NOW replied her mother with a smile. END
BEGIN NOW I feel no sentiment of approbation inferior to love. END
BEGIN NOW You may esteem him. END
BEGIN NOW I have never yet known what it was to separate esteem and love. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Dashwood now took pains to get acquainted with him. END
BEGIN NOW Her manners were attaching, and soon banished his reserve. END
BEGIN NOW She speedily comprehended all his merits; the persuasion of his regard for Elinor perhaps assisted her penetration; but she really felt assured of his worth: and even that quietness of manner, which militated against all her established ideas of what a young man's address ought to be, was no longer uninteresting when she knew his heart to be warm and his temper affectionate. END
BEGIN NOW No sooner did she perceive any symptom of love in his behaviour to Elinor, than she considered their serious attachment as certain, and looked forward to their marriage as rapidly approaching. END
BEGIN NOW In a few months, my dear Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW said she, Elinor will, in all probability be settled for life. END
BEGIN NOW We shall miss her; but SHE will be happy. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW Mama, how shall we do without her? END
BEGIN NOW My love, it will be scarcely a separation. END
BEGIN NOW We shall live within a few miles of each other, and shall meet every day of our lives. END
BEGIN NOW You will gain a brother, a real, affectionate brother. END
BEGIN NOW I have the highest opinion in the world of Edward's heart. END
BEGIN NOW But you look grave, Marianne; do you disapprove your sister's choice? END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps, said Marianne, I may consider it with some surprise. END
BEGIN NOW Edward is very amiable, and I love him tenderly. END
BEGIN NOW But yet&mdash;he is not the kind of young man&mdash;there is something wanting&mdash;his figure is not striking; it has none of that grace which I should expect in the man who could seriously attach my sister. END
BEGIN NOW His eyes want all that spirit, that fire, which at once announce virtue and intelligence. END
BEGIN NOW And besides all this, I am afraid, Mama, he has no real taste. END
BEGIN NOW Music seems scarcely to attract him, and though he admires Elinor's drawings very much, it is not the admiration of a person who can understand their worth. END
BEGIN NOW It is evident, in spite of his frequent attention to her while she draws, that in fact he knows nothing of the matter. END
BEGIN NOW He admires as a lover, not as a connoisseur. END
BEGIN NOW To satisfy me, those characters must be united. END
BEGIN NOW I could not be happy with a man whose taste did not in every point coincide with my own. END
BEGIN NOW He must enter into all my feelings; the same books, the same music must charm us both. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW mama, how spiritless, how tame was Edward's manner in reading to us last night! END
BEGIN NOW I felt for my sister most severely. END
BEGIN NOW Yet she bore it with so much composure, she seemed scarcely to notice it. END
BEGIN NOW I could hardly keep my seat. END
BEGIN NOW To hear those beautiful lines which have frequently almost driven me wild, pronounced with such impenetrable calmness, such dreadful indifference! END
BEGIN NOW He would certainly have done more justice to simple and elegant prose. END
BEGIN NOW I thought so at the time; but you WOULD give him Cowper. END
BEGIN NOW Nay, Mama, if he is not to be animated by Cowper!&mdash;but we must allow for difference of taste. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor has not my feelings, and therefore she may overlook it, and be happy with him. END
BEGIN NOW But it would have broke MY heart, had I loved him, to hear him read with so little sensibility. END
BEGIN NOW Mama, the more I know of the world, the more am I convinced that I shall never see a man whom I can really love. END
BEGIN NOW I require so much! END
BEGIN NOW He must have all Edward's virtues, and his person and manners must ornament his goodness with every possible charm. END
BEGIN NOW Remember, my love, that you are not seventeen. END
BEGIN NOW It is yet too early in life to despair of such a happiness. END
BEGIN NOW Why should you be less fortunate than your mother? END
BEGIN NOW In one circumstance only, my Marianne, may your destiny be different from hers! END
BEGIN NOW What a pity it is, Elinor, said Marianne, that Edward should have no taste for drawing. END
BEGIN NOW No taste for drawing! END
BEGIN NOW replied Elinor, why should you think so? END
BEGIN NOW He does not draw himself, indeed, but he has great pleasure in seeing the performances of other people, and I assure you he is by no means deficient in natural taste, though he has not had opportunities of improving it. END
BEGIN NOW Had he ever been in the way of learning, I think he would have drawn very well. END
BEGIN NOW He distrusts his own judgment in such matters so much, that he is always unwilling to give his opinion on any picture; but he has an innate propriety and simplicity of taste, which in general direct him perfectly right. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne was afraid of offending, and said no more on the subject; but the kind of approbation which Elinor described as excited in him by the drawings of other people, was very far from that rapturous delight, which, in her opinion, could alone be called taste. END
BEGIN NOW Yet, though smiling within herself at the mistake, she honoured her sister for that blind partiality to Edward which produced it. END
BEGIN NOW I hope, Marianne, continued Elinor, you do not consider him as deficient in general taste. END
BEGIN NOW Indeed, I think I may say that you cannot, for your behaviour to him is perfectly cordial, and if THAT were your opinion, I am sure you could never be civil to him. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne hardly knew what to say. END
BEGIN NOW She would not wound the feelings of her sister on any account, and yet to say what she did not believe was impossible. END
BEGIN NOW At length she replied: Do not be offended, Elinor, if my praise of him is not in every thing equal to your sense of his merits. END
BEGIN NOW I have not had so many opportunities of estimating the minuter propensities of his mind, his inclinations and tastes, as you have; but I have the highest opinion in the world of his goodness and sense. END
BEGIN NOW I think him every thing that is worthy and amiable. END
BEGIN NOW I am sure, replied Elinor, with a smile, that his dearest friends could not be dissatisfied with such commendation as that. END
BEGIN NOW I do not perceive how you could express yourself more warmly. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne was rejoiced to find her sister so easily pleased. END
BEGIN NOW Of his sense and his goodness, continued Elinor, no one can, I think, be in doubt, who has seen him often enough to engage him in unreserved conversation. END
BEGIN NOW The excellence of his understanding and his principles can be concealed only by that shyness which too often keeps him silent. END
BEGIN NOW You know enough of him to do justice to his solid worth. END
BEGIN NOW But of his minuter propensities, as you call them you have from peculiar circumstances been kept more ignorant than myself. END
BEGIN NOW He and I have been at times thrown a good deal together, while you have been wholly engrossed on the most affectionate principle by my mother. END
BEGIN NOW I have seen a great deal of him, have studied his sentiments and heard his opinion on subjects of literature and taste; and, upon the whole, I venture to pronounce that his mind is well-informed, enjoyment of books exceedingly great, his imagination lively, his observation just and correct, and his taste delicate and pure. END
BEGIN NOW His abilities in every respect improve as much upon acquaintance as his manners and person. END
BEGIN NOW At first sight, his address is certainly not striking; and his person can hardly be called handsome, till the expression of his eyes, which are uncommonly good, and the general sweetness of his countenance, is perceived. END
BEGIN NOW At present, I know him so well, that I think him really handsome; or at least, almost so. END
BEGIN NOW What say you, Marianne? END
BEGIN NOW I shall very soon think him handsome, Elinor, if I do not now. END
BEGIN NOW When you tell me to love him as a brother, I shall no more see imperfection in his face, than I now do in his heart. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor started at this declaration, and was sorry for the warmth she had been betrayed into, in speaking of him. END
BEGIN NOW She felt that Edward stood very high in her opinion. END
BEGIN NOW She believed the regard to be mutual; but she required greater certainty of it to make Marianne's conviction of their attachment agreeable to her. END
BEGIN NOW She knew that what Marianne and her mother conjectured one moment, they believed the next&mdash;that with them, to wish was to hope, and to hope was to expect. END
BEGIN NOW She tried to explain the real state of the case to her sister. END
BEGIN NOW I do not attempt to deny, said she, that I think very highly of him&mdash;that I greatly esteem, that I like him. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne here burst forth with indignation&mdash; Esteem him! END
BEGIN NOW Like him! END
BEGIN NOW Cold-hearted Elinor! END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW worse than cold-hearted! END
BEGIN NOW Ashamed of being otherwise. END
BEGIN NOW Use those words again, and I will leave the room this moment. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor could not help laughing. END
BEGIN NOW Excuse me, said she; and be assured that I meant no offence to you, by speaking, in so quiet a way, of my own feelings. END
BEGIN NOW Believe them to be stronger than I have declared; believe them, in short, to be such as his merit, and the suspicion&mdash;the hope of his affection for me may warrant, without imprudence or folly. END
BEGIN NOW But farther than this you must not believe. END
BEGIN NOW I am by no means assured of his regard for me. END
BEGIN NOW There are moments when the extent of it seems doubtful; and till his sentiments are fully known, you cannot wonder at my wishing to avoid any encouragement of my own partiality, by believing or calling it more than it is. END
BEGIN NOW In my heart I feel little&mdash;scarcely any doubt of his preference. END
BEGIN NOW But there are other points to be considered besides his inclination. END
BEGIN NOW He is very far from being independent. END
BEGIN NOW What his mother really is we cannot know; but, from Fanny's occasional mention of her conduct and opinions, we have never been disposed to think her amiable; and I am very much mistaken if Edward is not himself aware that there would be many difficulties in his way, if he were to wish to marry a woman who had not either a great fortune or high rank. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne was astonished to find how much the imagination of her mother and herself had outstripped the truth. END
BEGIN NOW And you really are not engaged to him! END
BEGIN NOW said she. END
BEGIN NOW Yet it certainly soon will happen. END
BEGIN NOW But two advantages will proceed from this delay. END
BEGIN NOW I shall not lose you so soon, and Edward will have greater opportunity of improving that natural taste for your favourite pursuit which must be so indispensably necessary to your future felicity. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW if he should be so far stimulated by your genius as to learn to draw himself, how delightful it would be! END
BEGIN NOW Elinor had given her real opinion to her sister. END
BEGIN NOW She could not consider her partiality for Edward in so prosperous a state as Marianne had believed it. END
BEGIN NOW There was, at times, a want of spirits about him which, if it did not denote indifference, spoke of something almost as unpromising. END
BEGIN NOW A doubt of her regard, supposing him to feel it, need not give him more than inquietude. END
BEGIN NOW It would not be likely to produce that dejection of mind which frequently attended him. END
BEGIN NOW A more reasonable cause might be found in the dependent situation which forbade the indulgence of his affection. END
BEGIN NOW She knew that his mother neither behaved to him so as to make his home comfortable at present, nor to give him any assurance that he might form a home for himself, without strictly attending to her views for his aggrandizement. END
BEGIN NOW With such a knowledge as this, it was impossible for Elinor to feel easy on the subject. END
BEGIN NOW She was far from depending on that result of his preference of her, which her mother and sister still considered as certain. END
BEGIN NOW Nay, the longer they were together the more doubtful seemed the nature of his regard; and sometimes, for a few painful minutes, she believed it to be no more than friendship. END
BEGIN NOW But, whatever might really be its limits, it was enough, when perceived by his sister, to make her uneasy, and at the same time, (which was still more common,) to make her uncivil. END
BEGIN NOW She took the first opportunity of affronting her mother-in-law on the occasion, talking to her so expressively of her brother's great expectations, of Mrs. Ferrars's resolution that both her sons should marry well, and of the danger attending any young woman who attempted to DRAW HIM IN; that Mrs. Dashwood could neither pretend to be unconscious, nor endeavor to be calm. END
BEGIN NOW She gave her an answer which marked her contempt, and instantly left the room, resolving that, whatever might be the inconvenience or expense of so sudden a removal, her beloved Elinor should not be exposed another week to such insinuations. END
BEGIN NOW In this state of her spirits, a letter was delivered to her from the post, which contained a proposal particularly well timed. END
BEGIN NOW It was the offer of a small house, on very easy terms, belonging to a relation of her own, a gentleman of consequence and property in Devonshire. END
BEGIN NOW The letter was from this gentleman himself, and written in the true spirit of friendly accommodation. END
BEGIN NOW He understood that she was in need of a dwelling; and though the house he now offered her was merely a cottage, he assured her that everything should be done to it which she might think necessary, if the situation pleased her. END
BEGIN NOW He earnestly pressed her, after giving the particulars of the house and garden, to come with her daughters to Barton Park, the place of his own residence, from whence she might judge, herself, whether Barton Cottage, for the houses were in the same parish, could, by any alteration, be made comfortable to her. END
BEGIN NOW He seemed really anxious to accommodate them and the whole of his letter was written in so friendly a style as could not fail of giving pleasure to his cousin; more especially at a moment when she was suffering under the cold and unfeeling behaviour of her nearer connections. END
BEGIN NOW She needed no time for deliberation or inquiry. END
BEGIN NOW Her resolution was formed as she read. END
BEGIN NOW The situation of Barton, in a county so far distant from Sussex as Devonshire, which, but a few hours before, would have been a sufficient objection to outweigh every possible advantage belonging to the place, was now its first recommendation. END
BEGIN NOW To quit the neighbourhood of Norland was no longer an evil; it was an object of desire; it was a blessing, in comparison of the misery of continuing her daughter-in-law's guest; and to remove for ever from that beloved place would be less painful than to inhabit or visit it while such a woman was its mistress. END
BEGIN NOW She instantly wrote Sir John Middleton her acknowledgment of his kindness, and her acceptance of his proposal; and then hastened to shew both letters to her daughters, that she might be secure of their approbation before her answer were sent. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor had always thought it would be more prudent for them to settle at some distance from Norland, than immediately amongst their present acquaintance. END
BEGIN NOW On THAT head, therefore, it was not for her to oppose her mother's intention of removing into Devonshire. END
BEGIN NOW The house, too, as described by Sir John, was on so simple a scale, and the rent so uncommonly moderate, as to leave her no right of objection on either point; and, therefore, though it was not a plan which brought any charm to her fancy, though it was a removal from the vicinity of Norland beyond her wishes, she made no attempt to dissuade her mother from sending a letter of acquiescence. END
BEGIN NOW No sooner was her answer dispatched, than Mrs. Dashwood indulged herself in the pleasure of announcing to her son-in-law and his wife that she was provided with a house, and should incommode them no longer than till every thing were ready for her inhabiting it. END
BEGIN NOW They heard her with surprise. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. John Dashwood said nothing; but her husband civilly hoped that she would not be settled far from Norland. END
BEGIN NOW She had great satisfaction in replying that she was going into Devonshire.&mdash;Edward turned hastily towards her, on hearing this, and, in a voice of surprise and concern, which required no explanation to her, repeated, Devonshire! END
BEGIN NOW Are you, indeed, going there? END
BEGIN NOW So far from hence! END
BEGIN NOW And to what part of it? END
BEGIN NOW She explained the situation. END
BEGIN NOW It was within four miles northward of Exeter. END
BEGIN NOW It is but a cottage, she continued, but I hope to see many of my friends in it. END
BEGIN NOW A room or two can easily be added; and if my friends find no difficulty in travelling so far to see me, I am sure I will find none in accommodating them. END
BEGIN NOW She concluded with a very kind invitation to Mr. and Mrs. John Dashwood to visit her at Barton; and to Edward she gave one with still greater affection. END
BEGIN NOW Though her late conversation with her daughter-in-law had made her resolve on remaining at Norland no longer than was unavoidable, it had not produced the smallest effect on her in that point to which it principally tended. END
BEGIN NOW To separate Edward and Elinor was as far from being her object as ever; and she wished to show Mrs. John Dashwood, by this pointed invitation to her brother, how totally she disregarded her disapprobation of the match. END
BEGIN NOW Mr. John Dashwood told his mother again and again how exceedingly sorry he was that she had taken a house at such a distance from Norland as to prevent his being of any service to her in removing her furniture. END
BEGIN NOW He really felt conscientiously vexed on the occasion; for the very exertion to which he had limited the performance of his promise to his father was by this arrangement rendered impracticable.&mdash; The furniture was all sent around by water. END
BEGIN NOW It chiefly consisted of household linen, plate, china, and books, with a handsome pianoforte of Marianne's. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. John Dashwood saw the packages depart with a sigh: she could not help feeling it hard that as Mrs. Dashwood's income would be so trifling in comparison with their own, she should have any handsome article of furniture. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Dashwood took the house for a twelvemonth; it was ready furnished, and she might have immediate possession. END
BEGIN NOW No difficulty arose on either side in the agreement; and she waited only for the disposal of her effects at Norland, and to determine her future household, before she set off for the west; and this, as she was exceedingly rapid in the performance of everything that interested her, was soon done.&mdash;The horses which were left her by her husband had been sold soon after his death, and an opportunity now offering of disposing of her carriage, she agreed to sell that likewise at the earnest advice of her eldest daughter. END
BEGIN NOW For the comfort of her children, had she consulted only her own wishes, she would have kept it; but the discretion of Elinor prevailed. END
BEGIN NOW HER wisdom too limited the number of their servants to three; two maids and a man, with whom they were speedily provided from amongst those who had formed their establishment at Norland. END
BEGIN NOW The man and one of the maids were sent off immediately into Devonshire, to prepare the house for their mistress's arrival; for as Lady Middleton was entirely unknown to Mrs. Dashwood, she preferred going directly to the cottage to being a visitor at Barton Park; and she relied so undoubtingly on Sir John's description of the house, as to feel no curiosity to examine it herself till she entered it as her own. END
BEGIN NOW Her eagerness to be gone from Norland was preserved from diminution by the evident satisfaction of her daughter-in-law in the prospect of her removal; a satisfaction which was but feebly attempted to be concealed under a cold invitation to her to defer her departure. END
BEGIN NOW Now was the time when her son-in-law's promise to his father might with particular propriety be fulfilled. END
BEGIN NOW Since he had neglected to do it on first coming to the estate, their quitting his house might be looked on as the most suitable period for its accomplishment. END
BEGIN NOW But Mrs. Dashwood began shortly to give over every hope of the kind, and to be convinced, from the general drift of his discourse, that his assistance extended no farther than their maintenance for six months at Norland. END
BEGIN NOW He so frequently talked of the increasing expenses of housekeeping, and of the perpetual demands upon his purse, which a man of any consequence in the world was beyond calculation exposed to, that he seemed rather to stand in need of more money himself than to have any design of giving money away. END
BEGIN NOW In a very few weeks from the day which brought Sir John Middleton's first letter to Norland, every thing was so far settled in their future abode as to enable Mrs. Dashwood and her daughters to begin their journey. END
BEGIN NOW Many were the tears shed by them in their last adieus to a place so much beloved. END
BEGIN NOW Dear, dear Norland! END
BEGIN NOW said Marianne, as she wandered alone before the house, on the last evening of their being there; when shall I cease to regret you!&mdash;when learn to feel a home elsewhere!&mdash;Oh! END
BEGIN NOW happy house, could you know what I suffer in now viewing you from this spot, from whence perhaps I may view you no more!&mdash;And you, ye well-known trees!&mdash;but you will continue the same.&mdash;No leaf will decay because we are removed, nor any branch become motionless although we can observe you no longer!&mdash;No; you will continue the same; unconscious of the pleasure or the regret you occasion, and insensible of any change in those who walk under your shade!&mdash;But who will remain to enjoy you? END
BEGIN NOW The first part of their journey was performed in too melancholy a disposition to be otherwise than tedious and unpleasant. END
BEGIN NOW But as they drew towards the end of it, their interest in the appearance of a country which they were to inhabit overcame their dejection, and a view of Barton Valley as they entered it gave them cheerfulness. END
BEGIN NOW It was a pleasant fertile spot, well wooded, and rich in pasture. END
BEGIN NOW After winding along it for more than a mile, they reached their own house. END
BEGIN NOW A small green court was the whole of its demesne in front; and a neat wicket gate admitted them into it. END
BEGIN NOW As a house, Barton Cottage, though small, was comfortable and compact; but as a cottage it was defective, for the building was regular, the roof was tiled, the window shutters were not painted green, nor were the walls covered with honeysuckles. END
BEGIN NOW A narrow passage led directly through the house into the garden behind. END
BEGIN NOW On each side of the entrance was a sitting room, about sixteen feet square; and beyond them were the offices and the stairs. END
BEGIN NOW Four bed-rooms and two garrets formed the rest of the house. END
BEGIN NOW It had not been built many years and was in good repair. END
BEGIN NOW In comparison of Norland, it was poor and small indeed!&mdash;but the tears which recollection called forth as they entered the house were soon dried away. END
BEGIN NOW They were cheered by the joy of the servants on their arrival, and each for the sake of the others resolved to appear happy. END
BEGIN NOW It was very early in September; the season was fine, and from first seeing the place under the advantage of good weather, they received an impression in its favour which was of material service in recommending it to their lasting approbation. END
BEGIN NOW The situation of the house was good. END
BEGIN NOW High hills rose immediately behind, and at no great distance on each side; some of which were open downs, the others cultivated and woody. END
BEGIN NOW The village of Barton was chiefly on one of these hills, and formed a pleasant view from the cottage windows. END
BEGIN NOW The prospect in front was more extensive; it commanded the whole of the valley, and reached into the country beyond. END
BEGIN NOW The hills which surrounded the cottage terminated the valley in that direction; under another name, and in another course, it branched out again between two of the steepest of them. END
BEGIN NOW With the size and furniture of the house Mrs. Dashwood was upon the whole well satisfied; for though her former style of life rendered many additions to the latter indispensable, yet to add and improve was a delight to her; and she had at this time ready money enough to supply all that was wanted of greater elegance to the apartments. END
BEGIN NOW As for the house itself, to be sure, said she, it is too small for our family, but we will make ourselves tolerably comfortable for the present, as it is too late in the year for improvements. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps in the spring, if I have plenty of money, as I dare say I shall, we may think about building. END
BEGIN NOW These parlors are both too small for such parties of our friends as I hope to see often collected here; and I have some thoughts of throwing the passage into one of them with perhaps a part of the other, and so leave the remainder of that other for an entrance; this, with a new drawing room which may be easily added, and a bed-chamber and garret above, will make it a very snug little cottage. END
BEGIN NOW I could wish the stairs were handsome. END
BEGIN NOW But one must not expect every thing; though I suppose it would be no difficult matter to widen them. END
BEGIN NOW I shall see how much I am before-hand with the world in the spring, and we will plan our improvements accordingly. END
BEGIN NOW In the mean time, till all these alterations could be made from the savings of an income of five hundred a-year by a woman who never saved in her life, they were wise enough to be contented with the house as it was; and each of them was busy in arranging their particular concerns, and endeavoring, by placing around them books and other possessions, to form themselves a home. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne's pianoforte was unpacked and properly disposed of; and Elinor's drawings were affixed to the walls of their sitting room. END
BEGIN NOW In such employments as these they were interrupted soon after breakfast the next day by the entrance of their landlord, who called to welcome them to Barton, and to offer them every accommodation from his own house and garden in which theirs might at present be deficient. END
BEGIN NOW Sir John Middleton was a good looking man about forty. END
BEGIN NOW He had formerly visited at Stanhill, but it was too long for his young cousins to remember him. END
BEGIN NOW His countenance was thoroughly good-humoured; and his manners were as friendly as the style of his letter. END
BEGIN NOW Their arrival seemed to afford him real satisfaction, and their comfort to be an object of real solicitude to him. END
BEGIN NOW He said much of his earnest desire of their living in the most sociable terms with his family, and pressed them so cordially to dine at Barton Park every day till they were better settled at home, that, though his entreaties were carried to a point of perseverance beyond civility, they could not give offence. END
BEGIN NOW His kindness was not confined to words; for within an hour after he left them, a large basket full of garden stuff and fruit arrived from the park, which was followed before the end of the day by a present of game. END
BEGIN NOW He insisted, moreover, on conveying all their letters to and from the post for them, and would not be denied the satisfaction of sending them his newspaper every day. END
BEGIN NOW Lady Middleton had sent a very civil message by him, denoting her intention of waiting on Mrs. Dashwood as soon as she could be assured that her visit would be no inconvenience; and as this message was answered by an invitation equally polite, her ladyship was introduced to them the next day. END
BEGIN NOW They were, of course, very anxious to see a person on whom so much of their comfort at Barton must depend; and the elegance of her appearance was favourable to their wishes. END
BEGIN NOW Lady Middleton was not more than six or seven and twenty; her face was handsome, her figure tall and striking, and her address graceful. END
BEGIN NOW Her manners had all the elegance which her husband's wanted. END
BEGIN NOW But they would have been improved by some share of his frankness and warmth; and her visit was long enough to detract something from their first admiration, by shewing that, though perfectly well-bred, she was reserved, cold, and had nothing to say for herself beyond the most common-place inquiry or remark. END
BEGIN NOW Conversation however was not wanted, for Sir John was very chatty, and Lady Middleton had taken the wise precaution of bringing with her their eldest child, a fine little boy about six years old, by which means there was one subject always to be recurred to by the ladies in case of extremity, for they had to enquire his name and age, admire his beauty, and ask him questions which his mother answered for him, while he hung about her and held down his head, to the great surprise of her ladyship, who wondered at his being so shy before company, as he could make noise enough at home. END
BEGIN NOW On every formal visit a child ought to be of the party, by way of provision for discourse. END
BEGIN NOW In the present case it took up ten minutes to determine whether the boy were most like his father or mother, and in what particular he resembled either, for of course every body differed, and every body was astonished at the opinion of the others. END
BEGIN NOW An opportunity was soon to be given to the Dashwoods of debating on the rest of the children, as Sir John would not leave the house without securing their promise of dining at the park the next day. END
BEGIN NOW Barton Park was about half a mile from the cottage. END
BEGIN NOW The ladies had passed near it in their way along the valley, but it was screened from their view at home by the projection of a hill. END
BEGIN NOW The house was large and handsome; and the Middletons lived in a style of equal hospitality and elegance. END
BEGIN NOW The former was for Sir John's gratification, the latter for that of his lady. END
BEGIN NOW They were scarcely ever without some friends staying with them in the house, and they kept more company of every kind than any other family in the neighbourhood. END
BEGIN NOW It was necessary to the happiness of both; for however dissimilar in temper and outward behaviour, they strongly resembled each other in that total want of talent and taste which confined their employments, unconnected with such as society produced, within a very narrow compass. END
BEGIN NOW Sir John was a sportsman, Lady Middleton a mother. END
BEGIN NOW He hunted and shot, and she humoured her children; and these were their only resources. END
BEGIN NOW Lady Middleton had the advantage of being able to spoil her children all the year round, while Sir John's independent employments were in existence only half the time. END
BEGIN NOW Continual engagements at home and abroad, however, supplied all the deficiencies of nature and education; supported the good spirits of Sir John, and gave exercise to the good breeding of his wife. END
BEGIN NOW Lady Middleton piqued herself upon the elegance of her table, and of all her domestic arrangements; and from this kind of vanity was her greatest enjoyment in any of their parties. END
BEGIN NOW But Sir John's satisfaction in society was much more real; he delighted in collecting about him more young people than his house would hold, and the noisier they were the better was he pleased. END
BEGIN NOW He was a blessing to all the juvenile part of the neighbourhood, for in summer he was for ever forming parties to eat cold ham and chicken out of doors, and in winter his private balls were numerous enough for any young lady who was not suffering under the unsatiable appetite of fifteen. END
BEGIN NOW The arrival of a new family in the country was always a matter of joy to him, and in every point of view he was charmed with the inhabitants he had now procured for his cottage at Barton. END
BEGIN NOW The Miss Dashwoods were young, pretty, and unaffected. END
BEGIN NOW It was enough to secure his good opinion; for to be unaffected was all that a pretty girl could want to make her mind as captivating as her person. END
BEGIN NOW The friendliness of his disposition made him happy in accommodating those, whose situation might be considered, in comparison with the past, as unfortunate. END
BEGIN NOW In showing kindness to his cousins therefore he had the real satisfaction of a good heart; and in settling a family of females only in his cottage, he had all the satisfaction of a sportsman; for a sportsman, though he esteems only those of his sex who are sportsmen likewise, is not often desirous of encouraging their taste by admitting them to a residence within his own manor. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Dashwood and her daughters were met at the door of the house by Sir John, who welcomed them to Barton Park with unaffected sincerity; and as he attended them to the drawing room repeated to the young ladies the concern which the same subject had drawn from him the day before, at being unable to get any smart young men to meet them. END
BEGIN NOW They would see, he said, only one gentleman there besides himself; a particular friend who was staying at the park, but who was neither very young nor very gay. END
BEGIN NOW He hoped they would all excuse the smallness of the party, and could assure them it should never happen so again. END
BEGIN NOW He had been to several families that morning in hopes of procuring some addition to their number, but it was moonlight and every body was full of engagements. END
BEGIN NOW Luckily Lady Middleton's mother had arrived at Barton within the last hour, and as she was a very cheerful agreeable woman, he hoped the young ladies would not find it so very dull as they might imagine. END
BEGIN NOW The young ladies, as well as their mother, were perfectly satisfied with having two entire strangers of the party, and wished for no more. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings, Lady Middleton's mother, was a good-humoured, merry, fat, elderly woman, who talked a great deal, seemed very happy, and rather vulgar. END
BEGIN NOW She was full of jokes and laughter, and before dinner was over had said many witty things on the subject of lovers and husbands; hoped they had not left their hearts behind them in Sussex, and pretended to see them blush whether they did or not. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne was vexed at it for her sister's sake, and turned her eyes towards Elinor to see how she bore these attacks, with an earnestness which gave Elinor far more pain than could arise from such common-place raillery as Mrs. Jennings's. END
BEGIN NOW Colonel Brandon, the friend of Sir John, seemed no more adapted by resemblance of manner to be his friend, than Lady Middleton was to be his wife, or Mrs. Jennings to be Lady Middleton's mother. END
BEGIN NOW He was silent and grave. END
BEGIN NOW His appearance however was not unpleasing, in spite of his being in the opinion of Marianne and Margaret an absolute old bachelor, for he was on the wrong side of five and thirty; but though his face was not handsome, his countenance was sensible, and his address was particularly gentlemanlike. END
BEGIN NOW There was nothing in any of the party which could recommend them as companions to the Dashwoods; but the cold insipidity of Lady Middleton was so particularly repulsive, that in comparison of it the gravity of Colonel Brandon, and even the boisterous mirth of Sir John and his mother-in-law was interesting. END
BEGIN NOW Lady Middleton seemed to be roused to enjoyment only by the entrance of her four noisy children after dinner, who pulled her about, tore her clothes, and put an end to every kind of discourse except what related to themselves. END
BEGIN NOW In the evening, as Marianne was discovered to be musical, she was invited to play. END
BEGIN NOW The instrument was unlocked, every body prepared to be charmed, and Marianne, who sang very well, at their request went through the chief of the songs which Lady Middleton had brought into the family on her marriage, and which perhaps had lain ever since in the same position on the pianoforte, for her ladyship had celebrated that event by giving up music, although by her mother's account, she had played extremely well, and by her own was very fond of it. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne's performance was highly applauded. END
BEGIN NOW Sir John was loud in his admiration at the end of every song, and as loud in his conversation with the others while every song lasted. END
BEGIN NOW Lady Middleton frequently called him to order, wondered how any one's attention could be diverted from music for a moment, and asked Marianne to sing a particular song which Marianne had just finished. END
BEGIN NOW Colonel Brandon alone, of all the party, heard her without being in raptures. END
BEGIN NOW He paid her only the compliment of attention; and she felt a respect for him on the occasion, which the others had reasonably forfeited by their shameless want of taste. END
BEGIN NOW His pleasure in music, though it amounted not to that ecstatic delight which alone could sympathize with her own, was estimable when contrasted against the horrible insensibility of the others; and she was reasonable enough to allow that a man of five and thirty might well have outlived all acuteness of feeling and every exquisite power of enjoyment. END
BEGIN NOW She was perfectly disposed to make every allowance for the colonel's advanced state of life which humanity required. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings was a widow with an ample jointure. END
BEGIN NOW She had only two daughters, both of whom she had lived to see respectably married, and she had now therefore nothing to do but to marry all the rest of the world. END
BEGIN NOW In the promotion of this object she was zealously active, as far as her ability reached; and missed no opportunity of projecting weddings among all the young people of her acquaintance. END
BEGIN NOW She was remarkably quick in the discovery of attachments, and had enjoyed the advantage of raising the blushes and the vanity of many a young lady by insinuations of her power over such a young man; and this kind of discernment enabled her soon after her arrival at Barton decisively to pronounce that Colonel Brandon was very much in love with Marianne Dashwood. END
BEGIN NOW She rather suspected it to be so, on the very first evening of their being together, from his listening so attentively while she sang to them; and when the visit was returned by the Middletons' dining at the cottage, the fact was ascertained by his listening to her again. END
BEGIN NOW It must be so. END
BEGIN NOW She was perfectly convinced of it. END
BEGIN NOW It would be an excellent match, for HE was rich, and SHE was handsome. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings had been anxious to see Colonel Brandon well married, ever since her connection with Sir John first brought him to her knowledge; and she was always anxious to get a good husband for every pretty girl. END
BEGIN NOW The immediate advantage to herself was by no means inconsiderable, for it supplied her with endless jokes against them both. END
BEGIN NOW At the park she laughed at the colonel, and in the cottage at Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW To the former her raillery was probably, as far as it regarded only himself, perfectly indifferent; but to the latter it was at first incomprehensible; and when its object was understood, she hardly knew whether most to laugh at its absurdity, or censure its impertinence, for she considered it as an unfeeling reflection on the colonel's advanced years, and on his forlorn condition as an old bachelor. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Dashwood, who could not think a man five years younger than herself, so exceedingly ancient as he appeared to the youthful fancy of her daughter, ventured to clear Mrs. Jennings from the probability of wishing to throw ridicule on his age. END
BEGIN NOW But at least, Mama, you cannot deny the absurdity of the accusation, though you may not think it intentionally ill-natured. END
BEGIN NOW Colonel Brandon is certainly younger than Mrs. Jennings, but he is old enough to be MY father; and if he were ever animated enough to be in love, must have long outlived every sensation of the kind. END
BEGIN NOW It is too ridiculous! END
BEGIN NOW When is a man to be safe from such wit, if age and infirmity will not protect him? END
BEGIN NOW Infirmity! END
BEGIN NOW said Elinor, do you call Colonel Brandon infirm? END
BEGIN NOW I can easily suppose that his age may appear much greater to you than to my mother; but you can hardly deceive yourself as to his having the use of his limbs! END
BEGIN NOW Did not you hear him complain of the rheumatism? END
BEGIN NOW and is not that the commonest infirmity of declining life? END
BEGIN NOW My dearest child, said her mother, laughing, at this rate you must be in continual terror of MY decay; and it must seem to you a miracle that my life has been extended to the advanced age of forty. END
BEGIN NOW Mama, you are not doing me justice. END
BEGIN NOW I know very well that Colonel Brandon is not old enough to make his friends yet apprehensive of losing him in the course of nature. END
BEGIN NOW He may live twenty years longer. END
BEGIN NOW But thirty-five has nothing to do with matrimony. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps, said Elinor, thirty-five and seventeen had better not have any thing to do with matrimony together. END
BEGIN NOW But if there should by any chance happen to be a woman who is single at seven and twenty, I should not think Colonel Brandon's being thirty-five any objection to his marrying HER. END
BEGIN NOW A woman of seven and twenty, said Marianne, after pausing a moment, can never hope to feel or inspire affection again, and if her home be uncomfortable, or her fortune small, I can suppose that she might bring herself to submit to the offices of a nurse, for the sake of the provision and security of a wife. END
BEGIN NOW In his marrying such a woman therefore there would be nothing unsuitable. END
BEGIN NOW It would be a compact of convenience, and the world would be satisfied. END
BEGIN NOW In my eyes it would be no marriage at all, but that would be nothing. END
BEGIN NOW To me it would seem only a commercial exchange, in which each wished to be benefited at the expense of the other. END
BEGIN NOW It would be impossible, I know, replied Elinor, to convince you that a woman of seven and twenty could feel for a man of thirty-five anything near enough to love, to make him a desirable companion to her. END
BEGIN NOW But I must object to your dooming Colonel Brandon and his wife to the constant confinement of a sick chamber, merely because he chanced to complain yesterday (a very cold damp day) of a slight rheumatic feel in one of his shoulders. END
BEGIN NOW But he talked of flannel waistcoats, said Marianne; and with me a flannel waistcoat is invariably connected with aches, cramps, rheumatisms, and every species of ailment that can afflict the old and the feeble. END
BEGIN NOW Had he been only in a violent fever, you would not have despised him half so much. END
BEGIN NOW Confess, Marianne, is not there something interesting to you in the flushed cheek, hollow eye, and quick pulse of a fever? END
BEGIN NOW Soon after this, upon Elinor's leaving the room, Mama, said Marianne, I have an alarm on the subject of illness which I cannot conceal from you. END
BEGIN NOW I am sure Edward Ferrars is not well. END
BEGIN NOW We have now been here almost a fortnight, and yet he does not come. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing but real indisposition could occasion this extraordinary delay. END
BEGIN NOW What else can detain him at Norland? END
BEGIN NOW Had you any idea of his coming so soon? END
BEGIN NOW said Mrs. Dashwood. END
BEGIN NOW I had none. END
BEGIN NOW On the contrary, if I have felt any anxiety at all on the subject, it has been in recollecting that he sometimes showed a want of pleasure and readiness in accepting my invitation, when I talked of his coming to Barton. END
BEGIN NOW Does Elinor expect him already? END
BEGIN NOW I have never mentioned it to her, but of course she must. END
BEGIN NOW I rather think you are mistaken, for when I was talking to her yesterday of getting a new grate for the spare bedchamber, she observed that there was no immediate hurry for it, as it was not likely that the room would be wanted for some time. END
BEGIN NOW How strange this is! END
BEGIN NOW what can be the meaning of it! END
BEGIN NOW But the whole of their behaviour to each other has been unaccountable! END
BEGIN NOW How cold, how composed were their last adieus! END
BEGIN NOW How languid their conversation the last evening of their being together! END
BEGIN NOW In Edward's farewell there was no distinction between Elinor and me: it was the good wishes of an affectionate brother to both. END
BEGIN NOW Twice did I leave them purposely together in the course of the last morning, and each time did he most unaccountably follow me out of the room. END
BEGIN NOW And Elinor, in quitting Norland and Edward, cried not as I did. END
BEGIN NOW Even now her self-command is invariable. END
BEGIN NOW When is she dejected or melancholy? END
BEGIN NOW When does she try to avoid society, or appear restless and dissatisfied in it? END
BEGIN NOW The Dashwoods were now settled at Barton with tolerable comfort to themselves. END
BEGIN NOW The house and the garden, with all the objects surrounding them, were now become familiar, and the ordinary pursuits which had given to Norland half its charms were engaged in again with far greater enjoyment than Norland had been able to afford, since the loss of their father. END
BEGIN NOW Sir John Middleton, who called on them every day for the first fortnight, and who was not in the habit of seeing much occupation at home, could not conceal his amazement on finding them always employed. END
