BEGIN NOW Their visitors, except those from Barton Park, were not many; for, in spite of Sir John's urgent entreaties that they would mix more in the neighbourhood, and repeated assurances of his carriage being always at their service, the independence of Mrs. Dashwood's spirit overcame the wish of society for her children; and she was resolute in declining to visit any family beyond the distance of a walk. END
BEGIN NOW There were but few who could be so classed; and it was not all of them that were attainable. END
BEGIN NOW About a mile and a half from the cottage, along the narrow winding valley of Allenham, which issued from that of Barton, as formerly described, the girls had, in one of their earliest walks, discovered an ancient respectable looking mansion which, by reminding them a little of Norland, interested their imagination and made them wish to be better acquainted with it. END
BEGIN NOW But they learnt, on enquiry, that its possessor, an elderly lady of very good character, was unfortunately too infirm to mix with the world, and never stirred from home. END
BEGIN NOW The whole country about them abounded in beautiful walks. END
BEGIN NOW The high downs which invited them from almost every window of the cottage to seek the exquisite enjoyment of air on their summits, were a happy alternative when the dirt of the valleys beneath shut up their superior beauties; and towards one of these hills did Marianne and Margaret one memorable morning direct their steps, attracted by the partial sunshine of a showery sky, and unable longer to bear the confinement which the settled rain of the two preceding days had occasioned. END
BEGIN NOW The weather was not tempting enough to draw the two others from their pencil and their book, in spite of Marianne's declaration that the day would be lastingly fair, and that every threatening cloud would be drawn off from their hills; and the two girls set off together. END
BEGIN NOW They gaily ascended the downs, rejoicing in their own penetration at every glimpse of blue sky; and when they caught in their faces the animating gales of a high south-westerly wind, they pitied the fears which had prevented their mother and Elinor from sharing such delightful sensations. END
BEGIN NOW Is there a felicity in the world, said Marianne, superior to this?&mdash;Margaret, we will walk here at least two hours. END
BEGIN NOW Margaret agreed, and they pursued their way against the wind, resisting it with laughing delight for about twenty minutes longer, when suddenly the clouds united over their heads, and a driving rain set full in their face.&mdash; Chagrined and surprised, they were obliged, though unwillingly, to turn back, for no shelter was nearer than their own house. END
BEGIN NOW One consolation however remained for them, to which the exigence of the moment gave more than usual propriety; it was that of running with all possible speed down the steep side of the hill which led immediately to their garden gate. END
BEGIN NOW They set off. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne had at first the advantage, but a false step brought her suddenly to the ground; and Margaret, unable to stop herself to assist her, was involuntarily hurried along, and reached the bottom in safety. END
BEGIN NOW A gentleman carrying a gun, with two pointers playing round him, was passing up the hill and within a few yards of Marianne, when her accident happened. END
BEGIN NOW He put down his gun and ran to her assistance. END
BEGIN NOW She had raised herself from the ground, but her foot had been twisted in her fall, and she was scarcely able to stand. END
BEGIN NOW The gentleman offered his services; and perceiving that her modesty declined what her situation rendered necessary, took her up in his arms without farther delay, and carried her down the hill. END
BEGIN NOW Then passing through the garden, the gate of which had been left open by Margaret, he bore her directly into the house, whither Margaret was just arrived, and quitted not his hold till he had seated her in a chair in the parlour. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor and her mother rose up in amazement at their entrance, and while the eyes of both were fixed on him with an evident wonder and a secret admiration which equally sprung from his appearance, he apologized for his intrusion by relating its cause, in a manner so frank and so graceful that his person, which was uncommonly handsome, received additional charms from his voice and expression. END
BEGIN NOW Had he been even old, ugly, and vulgar, the gratitude and kindness of Mrs. Dashwood would have been secured by any act of attention to her child; but the influence of youth, beauty, and elegance, gave an interest to the action which came home to her feelings. END
BEGIN NOW She thanked him again and again; and, with a sweetness of address which always attended her, invited him to be seated. END
BEGIN NOW But this he declined, as he was dirty and wet. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Dashwood then begged to know to whom she was obliged. END
BEGIN NOW His name, he replied, was Willoughby, and his present home was at Allenham, from whence he hoped she would allow him the honour of calling tomorrow to enquire after Miss Dashwood. END
BEGIN NOW The honour was readily granted, and he then departed, to make himself still more interesting, in the midst of a heavy rain. END
BEGIN NOW His manly beauty and more than common gracefulness were instantly the theme of general admiration, and the laugh which his gallantry raised against Marianne received particular spirit from his exterior attractions.&mdash; Marianne herself had seen less of his Mama the rest, for the confusion which crimsoned over her face, on his lifting her up, had robbed her of the power of regarding him after their entering the house. END
BEGIN NOW But she had seen enough of him to join in all the admiration of the others, and with an energy which always adorned her praise. END
BEGIN NOW His person and air were equal to what her fancy had ever drawn for the hero of a favourite story; and in his carrying her into the house with so little previous formality, there was a rapidity of thought which particularly recommended the action to her. END
BEGIN NOW Every circumstance belonging to him was interesting. END
BEGIN NOW His name was good, his residence was in their favourite village, and she soon found out that of all manly dresses a shooting-jacket was the most becoming. END
BEGIN NOW Her imagination was busy, her reflections were pleasant, and the pain of a sprained ankle was disregarded. END
BEGIN NOW Sir John called on them as soon as the next interval of fair weather that morning allowed him to get out of doors; and Marianne's accident being related to him, he was eagerly asked whether he knew any gentleman of the name of Willoughby at Allenham. END
BEGIN NOW Willoughby! END
BEGIN NOW cried Sir John; what, is HE in the country? END
BEGIN NOW That is good news however; I will ride over tomorrow, and ask him to dinner on Thursday. END
BEGIN NOW You know him then, said Mrs. Dashwood. END
BEGIN NOW Know him! END
BEGIN NOW to be sure I do. END
BEGIN NOW Why, he is down here every year. END
BEGIN NOW And what sort of a young man is he? END
BEGIN NOW As good a kind of fellow as ever lived, I assure you. END
BEGIN NOW A very decent shot, and there is not a bolder rider in England. END
BEGIN NOW And is that all you can say for him? END
BEGIN NOW cried Marianne, indignantly. END
BEGIN NOW But what are his manners on more intimate acquaintance? END
BEGIN NOW What his pursuits, his talents, and genius? END
BEGIN NOW Sir John was rather puzzled. END
BEGIN NOW Upon my soul, said he, I do not know much about him as to all THAT. END
BEGIN NOW But he is a pleasant, good humoured fellow, and has got the nicest little black bitch of a pointer I ever saw. END
BEGIN NOW Was she out with him today? END
BEGIN NOW But Marianne could no more satisfy him as to the colour of Mr. Willoughby's pointer, than he could describe to her the shades of his mind. END
BEGIN NOW But who is he? END
BEGIN NOW said Elinor. END
BEGIN NOW Where does he come from? END
BEGIN NOW Has he a house at Allenham? END
BEGIN NOW On this point Sir John could give more certain intelligence; and he told them that Mr. Willoughby had no property of his own in the country; that he resided there only while he was visiting the old lady at Allenham Court, to whom he was related, and whose possessions he was to inherit; adding, Yes, yes, he is very well worth catching I can tell you, Miss Dashwood; he has a pretty little estate of his own in Somersetshire besides; and if I were you, I would not give him up to my younger sister, in spite of all this tumbling down hills. END
BEGIN NOW Miss Marianne must not expect to have all the men to herself. END
BEGIN NOW Brandon will be jealous, if she does not take care. END
BEGIN NOW I do not believe, said Mrs. Dashwood, with a good humoured smile, that Mr. Willoughby will be incommoded by the attempts of either of MY daughters towards what you call CATCHING him. END
BEGIN NOW It is not an employment to which they have been brought up. END
BEGIN NOW Men are very safe with us, let them be ever so rich. END
BEGIN NOW I am glad to find, however, from what you say, that he is a respectable young man, and one whose acquaintance will not be ineligible. END
BEGIN NOW He is as good a sort of fellow, I believe, as ever lived, repeated Sir John. END
BEGIN NOW I remember last Christmas at a little hop at the park, he danced from eight o'clock till four, without once sitting down. END
BEGIN NOW Did he indeed? END
BEGIN NOW cried Marianne with sparkling eyes, and with elegance, with spirit? END
BEGIN NOW Yes; and he was up again at eight to ride to covert. END
BEGIN NOW That is what I like; that is what a young man ought to be. END
BEGIN NOW Whatever be his pursuits, his eagerness in them should know no moderation, and leave him no sense of fatigue. END
BEGIN NOW Aye, aye, I see how it will be, said Sir John, I see how it will be. END
BEGIN NOW You will be setting your cap at him now, and never think of poor Brandon. END
BEGIN NOW That is an expression, Sir John, said Marianne, warmly, which I particularly dislike. END
BEGIN NOW I abhor every common-place phrase by which wit is intended; and 'setting one's cap at a man,' or 'making a conquest,' are the most odious of all. END
BEGIN NOW Their tendency is gross and illiberal; and if their construction could ever be deemed clever, time has long ago destroyed all its ingenuity. END
BEGIN NOW Sir John did not much understand this reproof; but he laughed as heartily as if he did, and then replied, Ay, you will make conquests enough, I dare say, one way or other. END
BEGIN NOW Poor Brandon! END
BEGIN NOW he is quite smitten already, and he is very well worth setting your cap at, I can tell you, in spite of all this tumbling about and spraining of ankles. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne's preserver, as Margaret, with more elegance than precision, styled Willoughby, called at the cottage early the next morning to make his personal enquiries. END
BEGIN NOW He was received by Mrs. Dashwood with more than politeness; with a kindness which Sir John's account of him and her own gratitude prompted; and every thing that passed during the visit tended to assure him of the sense, elegance, mutual affection, and domestic comfort of the family to whom accident had now introduced him. END
BEGIN NOW Of their personal charms he had not required a second interview to be convinced. END
BEGIN NOW Miss Dashwood had a delicate complexion, regular features, and a remarkably pretty figure. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne was still handsomer. END
BEGIN NOW Her form, though not so correct as her sister's, in having the advantage of height, was more striking; and her face was so lovely, that when in the common cant of praise, she was called a beautiful girl, truth was less violently outraged than usually happens. END
BEGIN NOW Her skin was very brown, but, from its transparency, her complexion was uncommonly brilliant; her features were all good; her smile was sweet and attractive; and in her eyes, which were very dark, there was a life, a spirit, an eagerness, which could hardily be seen without delight. END
BEGIN NOW From Willoughby their expression was at first held back, by the embarrassment which the remembrance of his assistance created. END
BEGIN NOW But when this passed away, when her spirits became collected, when she saw that to the perfect good-breeding of the gentleman, he united frankness and vivacity, and above all, when she heard him declare, that of music and dancing he was passionately fond, she gave him such a look of approbation as secured the largest share of his discourse to herself for the rest of his stay. END
BEGIN NOW It was only necessary to mention any favourite amusement to engage her to talk. END
BEGIN NOW She could not be silent when such points were introduced, and she had neither shyness nor reserve in their discussion. END
BEGIN NOW They speedily discovered that their enjoyment of dancing and music was mutual, and that it arose from a general conformity of judgment in all that related to either. END
BEGIN NOW Encouraged by this to a further examination of his opinions, she proceeded to question him on the subject of books; her favourite authors were brought forward and dwelt upon with so rapturous a delight, that any young man of five and twenty must have been insensible indeed, not to become an immediate convert to the excellence of such works, however disregarded before. END
BEGIN NOW Their taste was strikingly alike. END
BEGIN NOW The same books, the same passages were idolized by each&mdash;or if any difference appeared, any objection arose, it lasted no longer than till the force of her arguments and the brightness of her eyes could be displayed. END
BEGIN NOW He acquiesced in all her decisions, caught all her enthusiasm; and long before his visit concluded, they conversed with the familiarity of a long-established acquaintance. END
BEGIN NOW Well, Marianne, said Elinor, as soon as he had left them, for ONE morning I think you have done pretty well. END
BEGIN NOW You have already ascertained Mr. Willoughby's opinion in almost every matter of importance. END
BEGIN NOW You know what he thinks of Cowper and Scott; you are certain of his estimating their beauties as he ought, and you have received every assurance of his admiring Pope no more than is proper. END
BEGIN NOW But how is your acquaintance to be long supported, under such extraordinary despatch of every subject for discourse? END
BEGIN NOW You will soon have exhausted each favourite topic. END
BEGIN NOW Another meeting will suffice to explain his sentiments on picturesque beauty, and second marriages, and then you can have nothing farther to ask. END
BEGIN NOW &mdash; Elinor, cried Marianne, is this fair? END
BEGIN NOW is this just? END
BEGIN NOW are my ideas so scanty? END
BEGIN NOW But I see what you mean. END
BEGIN NOW I have been too much at my ease, too happy, too frank. END
BEGIN NOW I have erred against every common-place notion of decorum; I have been open and sincere where I ought to have been reserved, spiritless, dull, and deceitful&mdash;had I talked only of the weather and the roads, and had I spoken only once in ten minutes, this reproach would have been spared. END
BEGIN NOW My love, said her mother, you must not be offended with Elinor&mdash;she was only in jest. END
BEGIN NOW I should scold her myself, if she were capable of wishing to check the delight of your conversation with our new friend. END
BEGIN NOW &mdash; Marianne was softened in a moment. END
BEGIN NOW Willoughby, on his side, gave every proof of his pleasure in their acquaintance, which an evident wish of improving it could offer. END
BEGIN NOW He came to them every day. END
BEGIN NOW To enquire after Marianne was at first his excuse; but the encouragement of his reception, to which every day gave greater kindness, made such an excuse unnecessary before it had ceased to be possible, by Marianne's perfect recovery. END
BEGIN NOW She was confined for some days to the house; but never had any confinement been less irksome. END
BEGIN NOW Willoughby was a young man of good abilities, quick imagination, lively spirits, and open, affectionate manners. END
BEGIN NOW He was exactly formed to engage Marianne's heart, for with all this, he joined not only a captivating person, but a natural ardour of mind which was now roused and increased by the example of her own, and which recommended him to her affection beyond every thing else. END
BEGIN NOW His society became gradually her most exquisite enjoyment. END
BEGIN NOW They read, they talked, they sang together; his musical talents were considerable; and he read with all the sensibility and spirit which Edward had unfortunately wanted. END
BEGIN NOW In Mrs. Dashwood's estimation he was as faultless as in Marianne's; and Elinor saw nothing to censure in him but a propensity, in which he strongly resembled and peculiarly delighted her sister, of saying too much what he thought on every occasion, without attention to persons or circumstances. END
BEGIN NOW In hastily forming and giving his opinion of other people, in sacrificing general politeness to the enjoyment of undivided attention where his heart was engaged, and in slighting too easily the forms of worldly propriety, he displayed a want of caution which Elinor could not approve, in spite of all that he and Marianne could say in its support. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne began now to perceive that the desperation which had seized her at sixteen and a half, of ever seeing a man who could satisfy her ideas of perfection, had been rash and unjustifiable. END
BEGIN NOW Willoughby was all that her fancy had delineated in that unhappy hour and in every brighter period, as capable of attaching her; and his behaviour declared his wishes to be in that respect as earnest, as his abilities were strong. END
BEGIN NOW Her mother too, in whose mind not one speculative thought of their marriage had been raised, by his prospect of riches, was led before the end of a week to hope and expect it; and secretly to congratulate herself on having gained two such sons-in-law as Edward and Willoughby. END
BEGIN NOW Colonel Brandon's partiality for Marianne, which had so early been discovered by his friends, now first became perceptible to Elinor, when it ceased to be noticed by them. END
BEGIN NOW Their attention and wit were drawn off to his more fortunate rival; and the raillery which the other had incurred before any partiality arose, was removed when his feelings began really to call for the ridicule so justly annexed to sensibility. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor was obliged, though unwillingly, to believe that the sentiments which Mrs. Jennings had assigned him for her own satisfaction, were now actually excited by her sister; and that however a general resemblance of disposition between the parties might forward the affection of Mr. Willoughby, an equally striking opposition of character was no hindrance to the regard of Colonel Brandon. END
BEGIN NOW She saw it with concern; for what could a silent man of five and thirty hope, when opposed to a very lively one of five and twenty? END
BEGIN NOW and as she could not even wish him successful, she heartily wished him indifferent. END
BEGIN NOW She liked him&mdash;in spite of his gravity and reserve, she beheld in him an object of interest. END
BEGIN NOW His manners, though serious, were mild; and his reserve appeared rather the result of some oppression of spirits than of any natural gloominess of temper. END
BEGIN NOW Sir John had dropped hints of past injuries and disappointments, which justified her belief of his being an unfortunate man, and she regarded him with respect and compassion. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps she pitied and esteemed him the more because he was slighted by Willoughby and Marianne, who, prejudiced against him for being neither lively nor young, seemed resolved to undervalue his merits. END
BEGIN NOW Brandon is just the kind of man, said Willoughby one day, when they were talking of him together, whom every body speaks well of, and nobody cares about; whom all are delighted to see, and nobody remembers to talk to. END
BEGIN NOW That is exactly what I think of him, cried Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW Do not boast of it, however, said Elinor, for it is injustice in both of you. END
BEGIN NOW He is highly esteemed by all the family at the park, and I never see him myself without taking pains to converse with him. END
BEGIN NOW That he is patronised by YOU, replied Willoughby, is certainly in his favour; but as for the esteem of the others, it is a reproach in itself. END
BEGIN NOW Who would submit to the indignity of being approved by such a woman as Lady Middleton and Mrs. Jennings, that could command the indifference of any body else? END
BEGIN NOW But perhaps the abuse of such people as yourself and Marianne will make amends for the regard of Lady Middleton and her mother. END
BEGIN NOW If their praise is censure, your censure may be praise, for they are not more undiscerning, than you are prejudiced and unjust. END
BEGIN NOW In defence of your protege you can even be saucy. END
BEGIN NOW My protege, as you call him, is a sensible man; and sense will always have attractions for me. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, Marianne, even in a man between thirty and forty. END
BEGIN NOW He has seen a great deal of the world; has been abroad, has read, and has a thinking mind. END
BEGIN NOW I have found him capable of giving me much information on various subjects; and he has always answered my inquiries with readiness of good-breeding and good nature. END
BEGIN NOW That is to say, cried Marianne contemptuously, he has told you, that in the East Indies the climate is hot, and the mosquitoes are troublesome. END
BEGIN NOW He WOULD have told me so, I doubt not, had I made any such inquiries, but they happened to be points on which I had been previously informed. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps, said Willoughby, his observations may have extended to the existence of nabobs, gold mohrs, and palanquins. END
BEGIN NOW I may venture to say that HIS observations have stretched much further than your candour. END
BEGIN NOW But why should you dislike him? END
BEGIN NOW I do not dislike him. END
BEGIN NOW I consider him, on the contrary, as a very respectable man, who has every body's good word, and nobody's notice; who, has more money than he can spend, more time than he knows how to employ, and two new coats every year. END
BEGIN NOW Add to which, cried Marianne, that he has neither genius, taste, nor spirit. END
BEGIN NOW That his understanding has no brilliancy, his feelings no ardour, and his voice no expression. END
BEGIN NOW You decide on his imperfections so much in the mass, replied Elinor, and so much on the strength of your own imagination, that the commendation I am able to give of him is comparatively cold and insipid. END
BEGIN NOW I can only pronounce him to be a sensible man, well-bred, well-informed, of gentle address, and, I believe, possessing an amiable heart. END
BEGIN NOW Miss Dashwood, cried Willoughby, you are now using me unkindly. END
BEGIN NOW You are endeavouring to disarm me by reason, and to convince me against my will. END
BEGIN NOW But it will not do. END
BEGIN NOW You shall find me as stubborn as you can be artful. END
BEGIN NOW I have three unanswerable reasons for disliking Colonel Brandon; he threatened me with rain when I wanted it to be fine; he has found fault with the hanging of my curricle, and I cannot persuade him to buy my brown mare. END
BEGIN NOW If it will be any satisfaction to you, however, to be told, that I believe his character to be in other respects irreproachable, I am ready to confess it. END
BEGIN NOW And in return for an acknowledgment, which must give me some pain, you cannot deny me the privilege of disliking him as much as ever. END
BEGIN NOW Little had Mrs. Dashwood or her daughters imagined when they first came into Devonshire, that so many engagements would arise to occupy their time as shortly presented themselves, or that they should have such frequent invitations and such constant visitors as to leave them little leisure for serious employment. END
BEGIN NOW Yet such was the case. END
BEGIN NOW When Marianne was recovered, the schemes of amusement at home and abroad, which Sir John had been previously forming, were put into execution. END
BEGIN NOW The private balls at the park then began; and parties on the water were made and accomplished as often as a showery October would allow. END
BEGIN NOW In every meeting of the kind Willoughby was included; and the ease and familiarity which naturally attended these parties were exactly calculated to give increasing intimacy to his acquaintance with the Dashwoods, to afford him opportunity of witnessing the excellencies of Marianne, of marking his animated admiration of her, and of receiving, in her behaviour to himself, the most pointed assurance of her affection. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor could not be surprised at their attachment. END
BEGIN NOW She only wished that it were less openly shewn; and once or twice did venture to suggest the propriety of some self-command to Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW But Marianne abhorred all concealment where no real disgrace could attend unreserve; and to aim at the restraint of sentiments which were not in themselves illaudable, appeared to her not merely an unnecessary effort, but a disgraceful subjection of reason to common-place and mistaken notions. END
BEGIN NOW Willoughby thought the same; and their behaviour at all times, was an illustration of their opinions. END
BEGIN NOW When he was present she had no eyes for any one else. END
BEGIN NOW Every thing he did, was right. END
BEGIN NOW Every thing he said, was clever. END
BEGIN NOW If their evenings at the park were concluded with cards, he cheated himself and all the rest of the party to get her a good hand. END
BEGIN NOW If dancing formed the amusement of the night, they were partners for half the time; and when obliged to separate for a couple of dances, were careful to stand together and scarcely spoke a word to any body else. END
BEGIN NOW Such conduct made them of course most exceedingly laughed at; but ridicule could not shame, and seemed hardly to provoke them. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Dashwood entered into all their feelings with a warmth which left her no inclination for checking this excessive display of them. END
BEGIN NOW To her it was but the natural consequence of a strong affection in a young and ardent mind. END
BEGIN NOW This was the season of happiness to Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW Her heart was devoted to Willoughby, and the fond attachment to Norland, which she brought with her from Sussex, was more likely to be softened than she had thought it possible before, by the charms which his society bestowed on her present home. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor's happiness was not so great. END
BEGIN NOW Her heart was not so much at ease, nor her satisfaction in their amusements so pure. END
BEGIN NOW They afforded her no companion that could make amends for what she had left behind, nor that could teach her to think of Norland with less regret than ever. END
BEGIN NOW Neither Lady Middleton nor Mrs. Jennings could supply to her the conversation she missed; although the latter was an everlasting talker, and from the first had regarded her with a kindness which ensured her a large share of her discourse. END
BEGIN NOW She had already repeated her own history to Elinor three or four times; and had Elinor's memory been equal to her means of improvement, she might have known very early in their acquaintance all the particulars of Mr. Jennings's last illness, and what he said to his wife a few minutes before he died. END
BEGIN NOW Lady Middleton was more agreeable than her mother only in being more silent. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor needed little observation to perceive that her reserve was a mere calmness of manner with which sense had nothing to do. END
BEGIN NOW Towards her husband and mother she was the same as to them; and intimacy was therefore neither to be looked for nor desired. END
BEGIN NOW She had nothing to say one day that she had not said the day before. END
BEGIN NOW Her insipidity was invariable, for even her spirits were always the same; and though she did not oppose the parties arranged by her husband, provided every thing were conducted in style and her two eldest children attended her, she never appeared to receive more enjoyment from them than she might have experienced in sitting at home;&mdash;and so little did her presence add to the pleasure of the others, by any share in their conversation, that they were sometimes only reminded of her being amongst them by her solicitude about her troublesome boys. END
BEGIN NOW In Colonel Brandon alone, of all her new acquaintance, did Elinor find a person who could in any degree claim the respect of abilities, excite the interest of friendship, or give pleasure as a companion. END
BEGIN NOW Willoughby was out of the question. END
BEGIN NOW Her admiration and regard, even her sisterly regard, was all his own; but he was a lover; his attentions were wholly Marianne's, and a far less agreeable man might have been more generally pleasing. END
BEGIN NOW Colonel Brandon, unfortunately for himself, had no such encouragement to think only of Marianne, and in conversing with Elinor he found the greatest consolation for the indifference of her sister. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor's compassion for him increased, as she had reason to suspect that the misery of disappointed love had already been known to him. END
BEGIN NOW This suspicion was given by some words which accidentally dropped from him one evening at the park, when they were sitting down together by mutual consent, while the others were dancing. END
BEGIN NOW His eyes were fixed on Marianne, and, after a silence of some minutes, he said, with a faint smile, Your sister, I understand, does not approve of second attachments. END
BEGIN NOW No, replied Elinor, her opinions are all romantic. END
BEGIN NOW Or rather, as I believe, she considers them impossible to exist. END
BEGIN NOW I believe she does. END
BEGIN NOW But how she contrives it without reflecting on the character of her own father, who had himself two wives, I know not. END
BEGIN NOW A few years however will settle her opinions on the reasonable basis of common sense and observation; and then they may be more easy to define and to justify than they now are, by any body but herself. END
BEGIN NOW This will probably be the case, he replied; and yet there is something so amiable in the prejudices of a young mind, that one is sorry to see them give way to the reception of more general opinions. END
BEGIN NOW I cannot agree with you there, said Elinor. END
BEGIN NOW There are inconveniences attending such feelings as Marianne's, which all the charms of enthusiasm and ignorance of the world cannot atone for. END
BEGIN NOW Her systems have all the unfortunate tendency of setting propriety at nought; and a better acquaintance with the world is what I look forward to as her greatest possible advantage. END
BEGIN NOW After a short pause he resumed the conversation by saying,&mdash; Does your sister make no distinction in her objections against a second attachment? END
BEGIN NOW or is it equally criminal in every body? END
BEGIN NOW Are those who have been disappointed in their first choice, whether from the inconstancy of its object, or the perverseness of circumstances, to be equally indifferent during the rest of their lives? END
BEGIN NOW Upon my word, I am not acquainted with the minutiae of her principles. END
BEGIN NOW I only know that I never yet heard her admit any instance of a second attachment's being pardonable. END
BEGIN NOW This, said he, cannot hold; but a change, a total change of sentiments&mdash;No, no, do not desire it; for when the romantic refinements of a young mind are obliged to give way, how frequently are they succeeded by such opinions as are but too common, and too dangerous! END
BEGIN NOW I speak from experience. END
BEGIN NOW I once knew a lady who in temper and mind greatly resembled your sister, who thought and judged like her, but who from an inforced change&mdash;from a series of unfortunate circumstances &mdash; Here he stopt suddenly; appeared to think that he had said too much, and by his countenance gave rise to conjectures, which might not otherwise have entered Elinor's head. END
BEGIN NOW The lady would probably have passed without suspicion, had he not convinced Miss Dashwood that what concerned her ought not to escape his lips. END
BEGIN NOW As it was, it required but a slight effort of fancy to connect his emotion with the tender recollection of past regard. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor attempted no more. END
BEGIN NOW But Marianne, in her place, would not have done so little. END
BEGIN NOW The whole story would have been speedily formed under her active imagination; and every thing established in the most melancholy order of disastrous love. END
BEGIN NOW As Elinor and Marianne were walking together the next morning the latter communicated a piece of news to her sister, which in spite of all that she knew before of Marianne's imprudence and want of thought, surprised her by its extravagant testimony of both. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne told her, with the greatest delight, that Willoughby had given her a horse, one that he had bred himself on his estate in Somersetshire, and which was exactly calculated to carry a woman. END
BEGIN NOW Without considering that it was not in her mother's plan to keep any horse, that if she were to alter her resolution in favour of this gift, she must buy another for the servant, and keep a servant to ride it, and after all, build a stable to receive them, she had accepted the present without hesitation, and told her sister of it in raptures. END
BEGIN NOW He intends to send his groom into Somersetshire immediately for it, she added, and when it arrives we will ride every day. END
BEGIN NOW You shall share its use with me. END
BEGIN NOW Imagine to yourself, my dear Elinor, the delight of a gallop on some of these downs. END
BEGIN NOW Most unwilling was she to awaken from such a dream of felicity to comprehend all the unhappy truths which attended the affair; and for some time she refused to submit to them. END
BEGIN NOW As to an additional servant, the expense would be a trifle; Mama she was sure would never object to it; and any horse would do for HIM; he might always get one at the park; as to a stable, the merest shed would be sufficient. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor then ventured to doubt the propriety of her receiving such a present from a man so little, or at least so lately known to her. END
BEGIN NOW This was too much. END
BEGIN NOW You are mistaken, Elinor, said she warmly, in supposing I know very little of Willoughby. END
BEGIN NOW I have not known him long indeed, but I am much better acquainted with him, than I am with any other creature in the world, except yourself and mama. END
BEGIN NOW It is not time or opportunity that is to determine intimacy;&mdash;it is disposition alone. END
BEGIN NOW Seven years would be insufficient to make some people acquainted with each other, and seven days are more than enough for others. END
BEGIN NOW I should hold myself guilty of greater impropriety in accepting a horse from my brother, than from Willoughby. END
BEGIN NOW Of John I know very little, though we have lived together for years; but of Willoughby my judgment has long been formed. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor thought it wisest to touch that point no more. END
BEGIN NOW She knew her sister's temper. END
BEGIN NOW Opposition on so tender a subject would only attach her the more to her own opinion. END
BEGIN NOW But by an appeal to her affection for her mother, by representing the inconveniences which that indulgent mother must draw on herself, if (as would probably be the case) she consented to this increase of establishment, Marianne was shortly subdued; and she promised not to tempt her mother to such imprudent kindness by mentioning the offer, and to tell Willoughby when she saw him next, that it must be declined. END
BEGIN NOW She was faithful to her word; and when Willoughby called at the cottage, the same day, Elinor heard her express her disappointment to him in a low voice, on being obliged to forego the acceptance of his present. END
BEGIN NOW The reasons for this alteration were at the same time related, and they were such as to make further entreaty on his side impossible. END
BEGIN NOW His concern however was very apparent; and after expressing it with earnestness, he added, in the same low voice,&mdash; But, Marianne, the horse is still yours, though you cannot use it now. END
BEGIN NOW I shall keep it only till you can claim it. END
BEGIN NOW When you leave Barton to form your own establishment in a more lasting home, Queen Mab shall receive you. END
BEGIN NOW This was all overheard by Miss Dashwood; and in the whole of the sentence, in his manner of pronouncing it, and in his addressing her sister by her Christian name alone, she instantly saw an intimacy so decided, a meaning so direct, as marked a perfect agreement between them. END
BEGIN NOW From that moment she doubted not of their being engaged to each other; and the belief of it created no other surprise than that she, or any of their friends, should be left by tempers so frank, to discover it by accident. END
BEGIN NOW Margaret related something to her the next day, which placed this matter in a still clearer light. END
BEGIN NOW Willoughby had spent the preceding evening with them, and Margaret, by being left some time in the parlour with only him and Marianne, had had opportunity for observations, which, with a most important face, she communicated to her eldest sister, when they were next by themselves. END
BEGIN NOW Oh, Elinor! END
BEGIN NOW she cried, I have such a secret to tell you about Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW I am sure she will be married to Mr. Willoughby very soon. END
BEGIN NOW You have said so, replied Elinor, almost every day since they first met on High-church Down; and they had not known each other a week, I believe, before you were certain that Marianne wore his picture round her neck; but it turned out to be only the miniature of our great uncle. END
BEGIN NOW But indeed this is quite another thing. END
BEGIN NOW I am sure they will be married very soon, for he has got a lock of her hair. END
BEGIN NOW Take care, Margaret. END
BEGIN NOW It may be only the hair of some great uncle of HIS. END
BEGIN NOW But, indeed, Elinor, it is Marianne's. END
BEGIN NOW I am almost sure it is, for I saw him cut it off. END
BEGIN NOW Last night after tea, when you and mama went out of the room, they were whispering and talking together as fast as could be, and he seemed to be begging something of her, and presently he took up her scissors and cut off a long lock of her hair, for it was all tumbled down her back; and he kissed it, and folded it up in a piece of white paper; and put it into his pocket-book. END
BEGIN NOW For such particulars, stated on such authority, Elinor could not withhold her credit; nor was she disposed to it, for the circumstance was in perfect unison with what she had heard and seen herself. END
BEGIN NOW Margaret's sagacity was not always displayed in a way so satisfactory to her sister. END
BEGIN NOW When Mrs. Jennings attacked her one evening at the park, to give the name of the young man who was Elinor's particular favourite, which had been long a matter of great curiosity to her, Margaret answered by looking at her sister, and saying, I must not tell, may I, Elinor? END
BEGIN NOW This of course made every body laugh; and Elinor tried to laugh too. END
BEGIN NOW But the effort was painful. END
BEGIN NOW She was convinced that Margaret had fixed on a person whose name she could not bear with composure to become a standing joke with Mrs. Jennings. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne felt for her most sincerely; but she did more harm than good to the cause, by turning very red and saying in an angry manner to Margaret, Remember that whatever your conjectures may be, you have no right to repeat them. END
BEGIN NOW I never had any conjectures about it, replied Margaret; it was you who told me of it yourself. END
BEGIN NOW This increased the mirth of the company, and Margaret was eagerly pressed to say something more. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW pray, Miss Margaret, let us know all about it, said Mrs. Jennings. END
BEGIN NOW What is the gentleman's name? END
BEGIN NOW I must not tell, ma'am. END
BEGIN NOW But I know very well what it is; and I know where he is too. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, yes, we can guess where he is; at his own house at Norland to be sure. END
BEGIN NOW He is the curate of the parish I dare say. END
BEGIN NOW No, THAT he is not. END
BEGIN NOW He is of no profession at all. END
BEGIN NOW Margaret, said Marianne with great warmth, you know that all this is an invention of your own, and that there is no such person in existence. END
BEGIN NOW Well, then, he is lately dead, Marianne, for I am sure there was such a man once, and his name begins with an F. Most grateful did Elinor feel to Lady Middleton for observing, at this moment, that it rained very hard, though she believed the interruption to proceed less from any attention to her, than from her ladyship's great dislike of all such inelegant subjects of raillery as delighted her husband and mother. END
BEGIN NOW The idea however started by her, was immediately pursued by Colonel Brandon, who was on every occasion mindful of the feelings of others; and much was said on the subject of rain by both of them. END
BEGIN NOW Willoughby opened the piano-forte, and asked Marianne to sit down to it; and thus amidst the various endeavours of different people to quit the topic, it fell to the ground. END
BEGIN NOW But not so easily did Elinor recover from the alarm into which it had thrown her. END
BEGIN NOW A party was formed this evening for going on the following day to see a very fine place about twelve miles from Barton, belonging to a brother-in-law of Colonel Brandon, without whose interest it could not be seen, as the proprietor, who was then abroad, had left strict orders on that head. END
BEGIN NOW The grounds were declared to be highly beautiful, and Sir John, who was particularly warm in their praise, might be allowed to be a tolerable judge, for he had formed parties to visit them, at least, twice every summer for the last ten years. END
BEGIN NOW They contained a noble piece of water; a sail on which was to a form a great part of the morning's amusement; cold provisions were to be taken, open carriages only to be employed, and every thing conducted in the usual style of a complete party of pleasure. END
BEGIN NOW To some few of the company it appeared rather a bold undertaking, considering the time of year, and that it had rained every day for the last fortnight;&mdash;and Mrs. Dashwood, who had already a cold, was persuaded by Elinor to stay at home. END
BEGIN NOW Their intended excursion to Whitwell turned out very different from what Elinor had expected. END
BEGIN NOW She was prepared to be wet through, fatigued, and frightened; but the event was still more unfortunate, for they did not go at all. END
BEGIN NOW By ten o'clock the whole party was assembled at the park, where they were to breakfast. END
BEGIN NOW The morning was rather favourable, though it had rained all night, as the clouds were then dispersing across the sky, and the sun frequently appeared. END
BEGIN NOW They were all in high spirits and good humour, eager to be happy, and determined to submit to the greatest inconveniences and hardships rather than be otherwise. END
BEGIN NOW While they were at breakfast the letters were brought in. END
BEGIN NOW Among the rest there was one for Colonel Brandon;&mdash;he took it, looked at the direction, changed colour, and immediately left the room. END
BEGIN NOW What is the matter with Brandon? END
BEGIN NOW said Sir John. END
BEGIN NOW Nobody could tell. END
BEGIN NOW I hope he has had no bad news, said Lady Middleton. END
BEGIN NOW It must be something extraordinary that could make Colonel Brandon leave my breakfast table so suddenly. END
BEGIN NOW In about five minutes he returned. END
BEGIN NOW No bad news, Colonel, I hope; said Mrs. Jennings, as soon as he entered the room. END
BEGIN NOW None at all, ma'am, I thank you. END
BEGIN NOW Was it from Avignon? END
BEGIN NOW I hope it is not to say that your sister is worse. END
BEGIN NOW No, ma'am. END
BEGIN NOW It came from town, and is merely a letter of business. END
BEGIN NOW But how came the hand to discompose you so much, if it was only a letter of business? END
BEGIN NOW Come, come, this won't do, Colonel; so let us hear the truth of it. END
BEGIN NOW My dear madam, said Lady Middleton, recollect what you are saying. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps it is to tell you that your cousin Fanny is married? END
BEGIN NOW said Mrs. Jennings, without attending to her daughter's reproof. END
BEGIN NOW No, indeed, it is not. END
BEGIN NOW Well, then, I know who it is from, Colonel. END
BEGIN NOW And I hope she is well. END
BEGIN NOW Whom do you mean, ma'am? END
BEGIN NOW said he, colouring a little. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW you know who I mean. END
BEGIN NOW I am particularly sorry, ma'am, said he, addressing Lady Middleton, that I should receive this letter today, for it is on business which requires my immediate attendance in town. END
BEGIN NOW In town! END
BEGIN NOW cried Mrs. Jennings. END
BEGIN NOW What can you have to do in town at this time of year? END
BEGIN NOW My own loss is great, he continued, in being obliged to leave so agreeable a party; but I am the more concerned, as I fear my presence is necessary to gain your admittance at Whitwell. END
BEGIN NOW What a blow upon them all was this! END
BEGIN NOW But if you write a note to the housekeeper, Mr. Brandon, said Marianne, eagerly, will it not be sufficient? END
BEGIN NOW He shook his head. END
BEGIN NOW We must go, said Sir John.&mdash; It shall not be put off when we are so near it. END
BEGIN NOW You cannot go to town till tomorrow, Brandon, that is all. END
BEGIN NOW I wish it could be so easily settled. END
BEGIN NOW But it is not in my power to delay my journey for one day! END
BEGIN NOW If you would but let us know what your business is, said Mrs. Jennings, we might see whether it could be put off or not. END
BEGIN NOW You would not be six hours later, said Willoughby, if you were to defer your journey till our return. END
BEGIN NOW I cannot afford to lose ONE hour. END
BEGIN NOW &mdash; Elinor then heard Willoughby say, in a low voice to Marianne, There are some people who cannot bear a party of pleasure. END
BEGIN NOW Brandon is one of them. END
BEGIN NOW He was afraid of catching cold I dare say, and invented this trick for getting out of it. END
BEGIN NOW I would lay fifty guineas the letter was of his own writing. END
BEGIN NOW I have no doubt of it, replied Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW There is no persuading you to change your mind, Brandon, I know of old, said Sir John, when once you are determined on anything. END
BEGIN NOW But, however, I hope you will think better of it. END
BEGIN NOW Consider, here are the two Miss Careys come over from Newton, the three Miss Dashwoods walked up from the cottage, and Mr. Willoughby got up two hours before his usual time, on purpose to go to Whitwell. END
BEGIN NOW Colonel Brandon again repeated his sorrow at being the cause of disappointing the party; but at the same time declared it to be unavoidable. END
BEGIN NOW Well, then, when will you come back again? END
BEGIN NOW I hope we shall see you at Barton, added her ladyship, as soon as you can conveniently leave town; and we must put off the party to Whitwell till you return. END
BEGIN NOW You are very obliging. END
BEGIN NOW But it is so uncertain, when I may have it in my power to return, that I dare not engage for it at all. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW he must and shall come back, cried Sir John. END
BEGIN NOW If he is not here by the end of the week, I shall go after him. END
BEGIN NOW Ay, so do, Sir John, cried Mrs. Jennings, and then perhaps you may find out what his business is. END
BEGIN NOW I do not want to pry into other men's concerns. END
BEGIN NOW I suppose it is something he is ashamed of. END
BEGIN NOW Colonel Brandon's horses were announced. END
BEGIN NOW You do not go to town on horseback, do you? END
BEGIN NOW added Sir John. END
BEGIN NOW No. END
BEGIN NOW Only to Honiton. END
BEGIN NOW I shall then go post. END
BEGIN NOW Well, as you are resolved to go, I wish you a good journey. END
BEGIN NOW But you had better change your mind. END
BEGIN NOW I assure you it is not in my power. END
BEGIN NOW He then took leave of the whole party. END
BEGIN NOW Is there no chance of my seeing you and your sisters in town this winter, Miss Dashwood? END
BEGIN NOW I am afraid, none at all. END
BEGIN NOW Then I must bid you farewell for a longer time than I should wish to do. END
BEGIN NOW To Marianne, he merely bowed and said nothing. END
BEGIN NOW Come Colonel, said Mrs. Jennings, before you go, do let us know what you are going about. END
BEGIN NOW He wished her a good morning, and, attended by Sir John, left the room. END
BEGIN NOW The complaints and lamentations which politeness had hitherto restrained, now burst forth universally; and they all agreed again and again how provoking it was to be so disappointed. END
BEGIN NOW I can guess what his business is, however, said Mrs. Jennings exultingly. END
BEGIN NOW Can you, ma'am? END
BEGIN NOW said almost every body. END
BEGIN NOW Yes; it is about Miss Williams, I am sure. END
BEGIN NOW And who is Miss Williams? END
BEGIN NOW asked Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW What! END
BEGIN NOW do not you know who Miss Williams is? END
BEGIN NOW I am sure you must have heard of her before. END
BEGIN NOW She is a relation of the Colonel's, my dear; a very near relation. END
BEGIN NOW We will not say how near, for fear of shocking the young ladies. END
BEGIN NOW Then, lowering her voice a little, she said to Elinor, She is his natural daughter. END
BEGIN NOW Indeed! END
BEGIN NOW Oh, yes; and as like him as she can stare. END
BEGIN NOW I dare say the Colonel will leave her all his fortune. END
BEGIN NOW When Sir John returned, he joined most heartily in the general regret on so unfortunate an event; concluding however by observing, that as they were all got together, they must do something by way of being happy; and after some consultation it was agreed, that although happiness could only be enjoyed at Whitwell, they might procure a tolerable composure of mind by driving about the country. END
BEGIN NOW The carriages were then ordered; Willoughby's was first, and Marianne never looked happier than when she got into it. END
BEGIN NOW He drove through the park very fast, and they were soon out of sight; and nothing more of them was seen till their return, which did not happen till after the return of all the rest. END
BEGIN NOW They both seemed delighted with their drive; but said only in general terms that they had kept in the lanes, while the others went on the downs. END
BEGIN NOW It was settled that there should be a dance in the evening, and that every body should be extremely merry all day long. END
BEGIN NOW Some more of the Careys came to dinner, and they had the pleasure of sitting down nearly twenty to table, which Sir John observed with great contentment. END
BEGIN NOW Willoughby took his usual place between the two elder Miss Dashwoods. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings sat on Elinor's right hand; and they had not been long seated, before she leant behind her and Willoughby, and said to Marianne, loud enough for them both to hear, I have found you out in spite of all your tricks. END
BEGIN NOW I know where you spent the morning. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne coloured, and replied very hastily, Where, pray? END
BEGIN NOW &mdash; Did not you know, said Willoughby, that we had been out in my curricle? END
BEGIN NOW Yes, yes, Mr. Impudence, I know that very well, and I was determined to find out WHERE you had been to.&mdash; I hope you like your house, Miss Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW It is a very large one, I know; and when I come to see you, I hope you will have new-furnished it, for it wanted it very much when I was there six years ago. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne turned away in great confusion. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings laughed heartily; and Elinor found that in her resolution to know where they had been, she had actually made her own woman enquire of Mr. Willoughby's groom; and that she had by that method been informed that they had gone to Allenham, and spent a considerable time there in walking about the garden and going all over the house. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor could hardly believe this to be true, as it seemed very unlikely that Willoughby should propose, or Marianne consent, to enter the house while Mrs. Smith was in it, with whom Marianne had not the smallest acquaintance. END
BEGIN NOW As soon as they left the dining-room, Elinor enquired of her about it; and great was her surprise when she found that every circumstance related by Mrs. Jennings was perfectly true. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne was quite angry with her for doubting it. END
BEGIN NOW Why should you imagine, Elinor, that we did not go there, or that we did not see the house? END
BEGIN NOW Is not it what you have often wished to do yourself? END
BEGIN NOW Yes, Marianne, but I would not go while Mrs. Smith was there, and with no other companion than Mr. Willoughby. END
BEGIN NOW Mr. Willoughby however is the only person who can have a right to shew that house; and as he went in an open carriage, it was impossible to have any other companion. END
BEGIN NOW I never spent a pleasanter morning in my life. END
BEGIN NOW I am afraid, replied Elinor, that the pleasantness of an employment does not always evince its propriety. END
BEGIN NOW On the contrary, nothing can be a stronger proof of it, Elinor; for if there had been any real impropriety in what I did, I should have been sensible of it at the time, for we always know when we are acting wrong, and with such a conviction I could have had no pleasure. END
BEGIN NOW But, my dear Marianne, as it has already exposed you to some very impertinent remarks, do you not now begin to doubt the discretion of your own conduct? END
BEGIN NOW If the impertinent remarks of Mrs. Jennings are to be the proof of impropriety in conduct, we are all offending every moment of our lives. END
BEGIN NOW I value not her censure any more than I should do her commendation. END
BEGIN NOW I am not sensible of having done anything wrong in walking over Mrs. Smith's grounds, or in seeing her house. END
BEGIN NOW They will one day be Mr. Willoughby's, and&mdash; If they were one day to be your own, Marianne, you would not be justified in what you have done. END
BEGIN NOW She blushed at this hint; but it was even visibly gratifying to her; and after a ten minutes' interval of earnest thought, she came to her sister again, and said with great good humour, Perhaps, Elinor, it WAS rather ill-judged in me to go to Allenham; but Mr. Willoughby wanted particularly to shew me the place; and it is a charming house, I assure you.&mdash;There is one remarkably pretty sitting room up stairs; of a nice comfortable size for constant use, and with modern furniture it would be delightful. END
BEGIN NOW It is a corner room, and has windows on two sides. END
BEGIN NOW On one side you look across the bowling-green, behind the house, to a beautiful hanging wood, and on the other you have a view of the church and village, and, beyond them, of those fine bold hills that we have so often admired. END
BEGIN NOW I did not see it to advantage, for nothing could be more forlorn than the furniture,&mdash;but if it were newly fitted up&mdash;a couple of hundred pounds, Willoughby says, would make it one of the pleasantest summer-rooms in England. END
BEGIN NOW Could Elinor have listened to her without interruption from the others, she would have described every room in the house with equal delight. END
BEGIN NOW The sudden termination of Colonel Brandon's visit at the park, with his steadiness in concealing its cause, filled the mind, and raised the wonder of Mrs. Jennings for two or three days; she was a great wonderer, as every one must be who takes a very lively interest in all the comings and goings of all their acquaintance. END
BEGIN NOW She wondered, with little intermission what could be the reason of it; was sure there must be some bad news, and thought over every kind of distress that could have befallen him, with a fixed determination that he should not escape them all. END
BEGIN NOW Something very melancholy must be the matter, I am sure, said she. END
BEGIN NOW I could see it in his face. END
BEGIN NOW Poor man! END
BEGIN NOW I am afraid his circumstances may be bad. END
BEGIN NOW The estate at Delaford was never reckoned more than two thousand a year, and his brother left everything sadly involved. END
BEGIN NOW I do think he must have been sent for about money matters, for what else can it be? END
BEGIN NOW I wonder whether it is so. END
BEGIN NOW I would give anything to know the truth of it. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps it is about Miss Williams and, by the bye, I dare say it is, because he looked so conscious when I mentioned her. END
BEGIN NOW May be she is ill in town; nothing in the world more likely, for I have a notion she is always rather sickly. END
BEGIN NOW I would lay any wager it is about Miss Williams. END
BEGIN NOW It is not so very likely he should be distressed in his circumstances NOW, for he is a very prudent man, and to be sure must have cleared the estate by this time. END
BEGIN NOW I wonder what it can be! END
BEGIN NOW May be his sister is worse at Avignon, and has sent for him over. END
BEGIN NOW His setting off in such a hurry seems very like it. END
BEGIN NOW Well, I wish him out of all his trouble with all my heart, and a good wife into the bargain. END
BEGIN NOW So wondered, so talked Mrs. Jennings. END
BEGIN NOW Her opinion varying with every fresh conjecture, and all seeming equally probable as they arose. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor, though she felt really interested in the welfare of Colonel Brandon, could not bestow all the wonder on his going so suddenly away, which Mrs. Jennings was desirous of her feeling; for besides that the circumstance did not in her opinion justify such lasting amazement or variety of speculation, her wonder was otherwise disposed of. END
BEGIN NOW It was engrossed by the extraordinary silence of her sister and Willoughby on the subject, which they must know to be peculiarly interesting to them all. END
BEGIN NOW As this silence continued, every day made it appear more strange and more incompatible with the disposition of both. END
BEGIN NOW Why they should not openly acknowledge to her mother and herself, what their constant behaviour to each other declared to have taken place, Elinor could not imagine. END
BEGIN NOW She could easily conceive that marriage might not be immediately in their power; for though Willoughby was independent, there was no reason to believe him rich. END
BEGIN NOW His estate had been rated by Sir John at about six or seven hundred a year; but he lived at an expense to which that income could hardly be equal, and he had himself often complained of his poverty. END
BEGIN NOW But for this strange kind of secrecy maintained by them relative to their engagement, which in fact concealed nothing at all, she could not account; and it was so wholly contradictory to their general opinions and practice, that a doubt sometimes entered her mind of their being really engaged, and this doubt was enough to prevent her making any inquiry of Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing could be more expressive of attachment to them all, than Willoughby's behaviour. END
BEGIN NOW To Marianne it had all the distinguishing tenderness which a lover's heart could give, and to the rest of the family it was the affectionate attention of a son and a brother. END
BEGIN NOW The cottage seemed to be considered and loved by him as his home; many more of his hours were spent there than at Allenham; and if no general engagement collected them at the park, the exercise which called him out in the morning was almost certain of ending there, where the rest of the day was spent by himself at the side of Marianne, and by his favourite pointer at her feet. END
BEGIN NOW One evening in particular, about a week after Colonel Brandon left the country, his heart seemed more than usually open to every feeling of attachment to the objects around him; and on Mrs. Dashwood's happening to mention her design of improving the cottage in the spring, he warmly opposed every alteration of a place which affection had established as perfect with him. END
BEGIN NOW What! END
BEGIN NOW he exclaimed&mdash; Improve this dear cottage! END
BEGIN NOW No. END
BEGIN NOW THAT I will never consent to. END
BEGIN NOW Not a stone must be added to its walls, not an inch to its size, if my feelings are regarded. END
BEGIN NOW Do not be alarmed, said Miss Dashwood, nothing of the kind will be done; for my mother will never have money enough to attempt it. END
BEGIN NOW I am heartily glad of it, he cried. END
BEGIN NOW May she always be poor, if she can employ her riches no better. END
BEGIN NOW Thank you, Willoughby. END
BEGIN NOW But you may be assured that I would not sacrifice one sentiment of local attachment of yours, or of any one whom I loved, for all the improvements in the world. END
BEGIN NOW Depend upon it that whatever unemployed sum may remain, when I make up my accounts in the spring, I would even rather lay it uselessly by than dispose of it in a manner so painful to you. END
BEGIN NOW But are you really so attached to this place as to see no defect in it? END
BEGIN NOW I am, said he. END
BEGIN NOW To me it is faultless. END
BEGIN NOW Nay, more, I consider it as the only form of building in which happiness is attainable, and were I rich enough I would instantly pull Combe down, and build it up again in the exact plan of this cottage. END
BEGIN NOW With dark narrow stairs and a kitchen that smokes, I suppose, said Elinor. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, cried he in the same eager tone, with all and every thing belonging to it;&mdash;in no one convenience or INconvenience about it, should the least variation be perceptible. END
BEGIN NOW Then, and then only, under such a roof, I might perhaps be as happy at Combe as I have been at Barton. END
BEGIN NOW I flatter myself, replied Elinor, that even under the disadvantage of better rooms and a broader staircase, you will hereafter find your own house as faultless as you now do this. END
BEGIN NOW There certainly are circumstances, said Willoughby, which might greatly endear it to me; but this place will always have one claim of my affection, which no other can possibly share. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Dashwood looked with pleasure at Marianne, whose fine eyes were fixed so expressively on Willoughby, as plainly denoted how well she understood him. END
BEGIN NOW How often did I wish, added he, when I was at Allenham this time twelvemonth, that Barton cottage were inhabited! END
BEGIN NOW I never passed within view of it without admiring its situation, and grieving that no one should live in it. END
BEGIN NOW How little did I then think that the very first news I should hear from Mrs. Smith, when I next came into the country, would be that Barton cottage was taken: and I felt an immediate satisfaction and interest in the event, which nothing but a kind of prescience of what happiness I should experience from it, can account for. END
BEGIN NOW Must it not have been so, Marianne? END
BEGIN NOW speaking to her in a lowered voice. END
BEGIN NOW Then continuing his former tone, he said, And yet this house you would spoil, Mrs. Dashwood? END
BEGIN NOW You would rob it of its simplicity by imaginary improvement! END
BEGIN NOW and this dear parlour in which our acquaintance first began, and in which so many happy hours have been since spent by us together, you would degrade to the condition of a common entrance, and every body would be eager to pass through the room which has hitherto contained within itself more real accommodation and comfort than any other apartment of the handsomest dimensions in the world could possibly afford. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Dashwood again assured him that no alteration of the kind should be attempted. END
BEGIN NOW You are a good woman, he warmly replied. END
BEGIN NOW Your promise makes me easy. END
BEGIN NOW Extend it a little farther, and it will make me happy. END
BEGIN NOW Tell me that not only your house will remain the same, but that I shall ever find you and yours as unchanged as your dwelling; and that you will always consider me with the kindness which has made everything belonging to you so dear to me. END
BEGIN NOW The promise was readily given, and Willoughby's behaviour during the whole of the evening declared at once his affection and happiness. END
BEGIN NOW Shall we see you tomorrow to dinner? END
BEGIN NOW said Mrs. Dashwood, when he was leaving them. END
BEGIN NOW I do not ask you to come in the morning, for we must walk to the park, to call on Lady Middleton. END
BEGIN NOW He engaged to be with them by four o'clock. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Dashwood's visit to Lady Middleton took place the next day, and two of her daughters went with her; but Marianne excused herself from being of the party, under some trifling pretext of employment; and her mother, who concluded that a promise had been made by Willoughby the night before of calling on her while they were absent, was perfectly satisfied with her remaining at home. END
BEGIN NOW On their return from the park they found Willoughby's curricle and servant in waiting at the cottage, and Mrs. Dashwood was convinced that her conjecture had been just. END
BEGIN NOW So far it was all as she had foreseen; but on entering the house she beheld what no foresight had taught her to expect. END
BEGIN NOW They were no sooner in the passage than Marianne came hastily out of the parlour apparently in violent affliction, with her handkerchief at her eyes; and without noticing them ran up stairs. END
BEGIN NOW Surprised and alarmed they proceeded directly into the room she had just quitted, where they found only Willoughby, who was leaning against the mantel-piece with his back towards them. END
BEGIN NOW He turned round on their coming in, and his countenance shewed that he strongly partook of the emotion which over-powered Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW Is anything the matter with her? END
BEGIN NOW cried Mrs. Dashwood as she entered&mdash; is she ill? END
BEGIN NOW I hope not, he replied, trying to look cheerful; and with a forced smile presently added, It is I who may rather expect to be ill&mdash;for I am now suffering under a very heavy disappointment! END
BEGIN NOW Disappointment? END
BEGIN NOW Yes, for I am unable to keep my engagement with you. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Smith has this morning exercised the privilege of riches upon a poor dependent cousin, by sending me on business to London. END
BEGIN NOW I have just received my dispatches, and taken my farewell of Allenham; and by way of exhilaration I am now come to take my farewell of you. END
BEGIN NOW To London!&mdash;and are you going this morning? END
BEGIN NOW Almost this moment. END
BEGIN NOW This is very unfortunate. END
BEGIN NOW But Mrs. Smith must be obliged;&mdash;and her business will not detain you from us long I hope. END
BEGIN NOW He coloured as he replied, You are very kind, but I have no idea of returning into Devonshire immediately. END
BEGIN NOW My visits to Mrs. Smith are never repeated within the twelvemonth. END
BEGIN NOW And is Mrs. Smith your only friend? END
BEGIN NOW Is Allenham the only house in the neighbourhood to which you will be welcome? END
BEGIN NOW For shame, Willoughby, can you wait for an invitation here? END
BEGIN NOW His colour increased; and with his eyes fixed on the ground he only replied, You are too good. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Dashwood looked at Elinor with surprise. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor felt equal amazement. END
BEGIN NOW For a few moments every one was silent. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Dashwood first spoke. END
BEGIN NOW I have only to add, my dear Willoughby, that at Barton cottage you will always be welcome; for I will not press you to return here immediately, because you only can judge how far THAT might be pleasing to Mrs. Smith; and on this head I shall be no more disposed to question your judgment than to doubt your inclination. END
BEGIN NOW My engagements at present, replied Willoughby, confusedly, are of such a nature&mdash;that&mdash;I dare not flatter myself &mdash; He stopt. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Dashwood was too much astonished to speak, and another pause succeeded. END
BEGIN NOW This was broken by Willoughby, who said with a faint smile, It is folly to linger in this manner. END
BEGIN NOW I will not torment myself any longer by remaining among friends whose society it is impossible for me now to enjoy. END
BEGIN NOW He then hastily took leave of them all and left the room. END
BEGIN NOW They saw him step into his carriage, and in a minute it was out of sight. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Dashwood felt too much for speech, and instantly quitted the parlour to give way in solitude to the concern and alarm which this sudden departure occasioned. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor's uneasiness was at least equal to her mother's. END
BEGIN NOW She thought of what had just passed with anxiety and distrust. END
BEGIN NOW Willoughby's behaviour in taking leave of them, his embarrassment, and affectation of cheerfulness, and, above all, his unwillingness to accept her mother's invitation, a backwardness so unlike a lover, so unlike himself, greatly disturbed her. END
BEGIN NOW One moment she feared that no serious design had ever been formed on his side; and the next that some unfortunate quarrel had taken place between him and her sister;&mdash;the distress in which Marianne had quitted the room was such as a serious quarrel could most reasonably account for, though when she considered what Marianne's love for him was, a quarrel seemed almost impossible. END
BEGIN NOW But whatever might be the particulars of their separation, her sister's affliction was indubitable; and she thought with the tenderest compassion of that violent sorrow which Marianne was in all probability not merely giving way to as a relief, but feeding and encouraging as a duty. END
BEGIN NOW In about half an hour her mother returned, and though her eyes were red, her countenance was not uncheerful. END
BEGIN NOW Our dear Willoughby is now some miles from Barton, Elinor, said she, as she sat down to work, and with how heavy a heart does he travel? END
BEGIN NOW It is all very strange. END
BEGIN NOW So suddenly to be gone! END
BEGIN NOW It seems but the work of a moment. END
BEGIN NOW And last night he was with us so happy, so cheerful, so affectionate? END
BEGIN NOW And now, after only ten minutes notice&mdash;Gone too without intending to return!&mdash;Something more than what he owned to us must have happened. END
BEGIN NOW He did not speak, he did not behave like himself. END
BEGIN NOW YOU must have seen the difference as well as I. END
BEGIN NOW What can it be? END
BEGIN NOW Can they have quarrelled? END
BEGIN NOW Why else should he have shewn such unwillingness to accept your invitation here? END
BEGIN NOW &mdash; It was not inclination that he wanted, Elinor; I could plainly see THAT. END
BEGIN NOW He had not the power of accepting it. END
BEGIN NOW I have thought it all over I assure you, and I can perfectly account for every thing that at first seemed strange to me as well as to you. END
BEGIN NOW Can you, indeed! END
BEGIN NOW Yes. END
BEGIN NOW I have explained it to myself in the most satisfactory way;&mdash;but you, Elinor, who love to doubt where you can&mdash;it will not satisfy YOU, I know; but you shall not talk ME out of my trust in it. END
BEGIN NOW I am persuaded that Mrs. Smith suspects his regard for Marianne, disapproves of it, (perhaps because she has other views for him,) and on that account is eager to get him away;&mdash;and that the business which she sends him off to transact is invented as an excuse to dismiss him. END
BEGIN NOW This is what I believe to have happened. END
BEGIN NOW He is, moreover, aware that she DOES disapprove the connection, he dares not therefore at present confess to her his engagement with Marianne, and he feels himself obliged, from his dependent situation, to give into her schemes, and absent himself from Devonshire for a while. END
BEGIN NOW You will tell me, I know, that this may or may NOT have happened; but I will listen to no cavil, unless you can point out any other method of understanding the affair as satisfactory at this. END
BEGIN NOW And now, Elinor, what have you to say? END
BEGIN NOW Nothing, for you have anticipated my answer. END
BEGIN NOW Then you would have told me, that it might or might not have happened. END
BEGIN NOW Oh, Elinor, how incomprehensible are your feelings! END
BEGIN NOW You had rather take evil upon credit than good. END
BEGIN NOW You had rather look out for misery for Marianne, and guilt for poor Willoughby, than an apology for the latter. END
BEGIN NOW You are resolved to think him blameable, because he took leave of us with less affection than his usual behaviour has shewn. END
BEGIN NOW And is no allowance to be made for inadvertence, or for spirits depressed by recent disappointment? END
BEGIN NOW Are no probabilities to be accepted, merely because they are not certainties? END
BEGIN NOW Is nothing due to the man whom we have all such reason to love, and no reason in the world to think ill of? END
BEGIN NOW To the possibility of motives unanswerable in themselves, though unavoidably secret for a while? END
BEGIN NOW And, after all, what is it you suspect him of? END
BEGIN NOW I can hardly tell myself. END
BEGIN NOW But suspicion of something unpleasant is the inevitable consequence of such an alteration as we just witnessed in him. END
BEGIN NOW There is great truth, however, in what you have now urged of the allowances which ought to be made for him, and it is my wish to be candid in my judgment of every body. END
BEGIN NOW Willoughby may undoubtedly have very sufficient reasons for his conduct, and I will hope that he has. END
BEGIN NOW But it would have been more like Willoughby to acknowledge them at once. END
BEGIN NOW Secrecy may be advisable; but still I cannot help wondering at its being practiced by him. END
BEGIN NOW Do not blame him, however, for departing from his character, where the deviation is necessary. END
BEGIN NOW But you really do admit the justice of what I have said in his defence?&mdash;I am happy&mdash;and he is acquitted. END
BEGIN NOW Not entirely. END
BEGIN NOW It may be proper to conceal their engagement (if they ARE engaged) from Mrs. Smith&mdash;and if that is the case, it must be highly expedient for Willoughby to be but little in Devonshire at present. END
BEGIN NOW But this is no excuse for their concealing it from us. END
BEGIN NOW Concealing it from us! END
BEGIN NOW my dear child, do you accuse Willoughby and Marianne of concealment? END
BEGIN NOW This is strange indeed, when your eyes have been reproaching them every day for incautiousness. END
BEGIN NOW I want no proof of their affection, said Elinor; but of their engagement I do. END
BEGIN NOW I am perfectly satisfied of both. END
BEGIN NOW Yet not a syllable has been said to you on the subject, by either of them. END
BEGIN NOW I have not wanted syllables where actions have spoken so plainly. END
BEGIN NOW Has not his behaviour to Marianne and to all of us, for at least the last fortnight, declared that he loved and considered her as his future wife, and that he felt for us the attachment of the nearest relation? END
BEGIN NOW Have we not perfectly understood each other? END
BEGIN NOW Has not my consent been daily asked by his looks, his manner, his attentive and affectionate respect? END
BEGIN NOW My Elinor, is it possible to doubt their engagement? END
BEGIN NOW How could such a thought occur to you? END
BEGIN NOW How is it to be supposed that Willoughby, persuaded as he must be of your sister's love, should leave her, and leave her perhaps for months, without telling her of his affection;&mdash;that they should part without a mutual exchange of confidence? END
BEGIN NOW I confess, replied Elinor, that every circumstance except ONE is in favour of their engagement; but that ONE is the total silence of both on the subject, and with me it almost outweighs every other. END
BEGIN NOW How strange this is! END
BEGIN NOW You must think wretchedly indeed of Willoughby, if, after all that has openly passed between them, you can doubt the nature of the terms on which they are together. END
BEGIN NOW Has he been acting a part in his behaviour to your sister all this time? END
BEGIN NOW Do you suppose him really indifferent to her? END
BEGIN NOW No, I cannot think that. END
BEGIN NOW He must and does love her I am sure. END
BEGIN NOW But with a strange kind of tenderness, if he can leave her with such indifference, such carelessness of the future, as you attribute to him. END
BEGIN NOW You must remember, my dear mother, that I have never considered this matter as certain. END
BEGIN NOW I have had my doubts, I confess; but they are fainter than they were, and they may soon be entirely done away. END
BEGIN NOW If we find they correspond, every fear of mine will be removed. END
BEGIN NOW A mighty concession indeed! END
BEGIN NOW If you were to see them at the altar, you would suppose they were going to be married. END
BEGIN NOW Ungracious girl! END
BEGIN NOW But I require no such proof. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing in my opinion has ever passed to justify doubt; no secrecy has been attempted; all has been uniformly open and unreserved. END
BEGIN NOW You cannot doubt your sister's wishes. END
BEGIN NOW It must be Willoughby therefore whom you suspect. END
BEGIN NOW But why? END
BEGIN NOW Is he not a man of honour and feeling? END
BEGIN NOW Has there been any inconsistency on his side to create alarm? END
BEGIN NOW can he be deceitful? END
BEGIN NOW I hope not, I believe not, cried Elinor. END
BEGIN NOW I love Willoughby, sincerely love him; and suspicion of his integrity cannot be more painful to yourself than to me. END
BEGIN NOW It has been involuntary, and I will not encourage it. END
BEGIN NOW I was startled, I confess, by the alteration in his manners this morning;&mdash;he did not speak like himself, and did not return your kindness with any cordiality. END
BEGIN NOW But all this may be explained by such a situation of his affairs as you have supposed. END
BEGIN NOW He had just parted from my sister, had seen her leave him in the greatest affliction; and if he felt obliged, from a fear of offending Mrs. Smith, to resist the temptation of returning here soon, and yet aware that by declining your invitation, by saying that he was going away for some time, he should seem to act an ungenerous, a suspicious part by our family, he might well be embarrassed and disturbed. END
