BEGIN NOW In such a case, a plain and open avowal of his difficulties would have been more to his honour I think, as well as more consistent with his general character;&mdash;but I will not raise objections against any one's conduct on so illiberal a foundation, as a difference in judgment from myself, or a deviation from what I may think right and consistent. END
BEGIN NOW You speak very properly. END
BEGIN NOW Willoughby certainly does not deserve to be suspected. END
BEGIN NOW Though WE have not known him long, he is no stranger in this part of the world; and who has ever spoken to his disadvantage? END
BEGIN NOW Had he been in a situation to act independently and marry immediately, it might have been odd that he should leave us without acknowledging everything to me at once: but this is not the case. END
BEGIN NOW It is an engagement in some respects not prosperously begun, for their marriage must be at a very uncertain distance; and even secrecy, as far as it can be observed, may now be very advisable. END
BEGIN NOW They were interrupted by the entrance of Margaret; and Elinor was then at liberty to think over the representations of her mother, to acknowledge the probability of many, and hope for the justice of all. END
BEGIN NOW They saw nothing of Marianne till dinner time, when she entered the room and took her place at the table without saying a word. END
BEGIN NOW Her eyes were red and swollen; and it seemed as if her tears were even then restrained with difficulty. END
BEGIN NOW She avoided the looks of them all, could neither eat nor speak, and after some time, on her mother's silently pressing her hand with tender compassion, her small degree of fortitude was quite overcome, she burst into tears and left the room. END
BEGIN NOW This violent oppression of spirits continued the whole evening. END
BEGIN NOW She was without any power, because she was without any desire of command over herself. END
BEGIN NOW The slightest mention of anything relative to Willoughby overpowered her in an instant; and though her family were most anxiously attentive to her comfort, it was impossible for them, if they spoke at all, to keep clear of every subject which her feelings connected with him. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne would have thought herself very inexcusable had she been able to sleep at all the first night after parting from Willoughby. END
BEGIN NOW She would have been ashamed to look her family in the face the next morning, had she not risen from her bed in more need of repose than when she lay down in it. END
BEGIN NOW But the feelings which made such composure a disgrace, left her in no danger of incurring it. END
BEGIN NOW She was awake the whole night, and she wept the greatest part of it. END
BEGIN NOW She got up with a headache, was unable to talk, and unwilling to take any nourishment; giving pain every moment to her mother and sisters, and forbidding all attempt at consolation from either. END
BEGIN NOW Her sensibility was potent enough! END
BEGIN NOW When breakfast was over she walked out by herself, and wandered about the village of Allenham, indulging the recollection of past enjoyment and crying over the present reverse for the chief of the morning. END
BEGIN NOW The evening passed off in the equal indulgence of feeling. END
BEGIN NOW She played over every favourite song that she had been used to play to Willoughby, every air in which their voices had been oftenest joined, and sat at the instrument gazing on every line of music that he had written out for her, till her heart was so heavy that no farther sadness could be gained; and this nourishment of grief was every day applied. END
BEGIN NOW She spent whole hours at the pianoforte alternately singing and crying; her voice often totally suspended by her tears. END
BEGIN NOW In books too, as well as in music, she courted the misery which a contrast between the past and present was certain of giving. END
BEGIN NOW She read nothing but what they had been used to read together. END
BEGIN NOW Such violence of affliction indeed could not be supported for ever; it sunk within a few days into a calmer melancholy; but these employments, to which she daily recurred, her solitary walks and silent meditations, still produced occasional effusions of sorrow as lively as ever. END
BEGIN NOW No letter from Willoughby came; and none seemed expected by Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW Her mother was surprised, and Elinor again became uneasy. END
BEGIN NOW But Mrs. Dashwood could find explanations whenever she wanted them, which at least satisfied herself. END
BEGIN NOW Remember, Elinor, said she, how very often Sir John fetches our letters himself from the post, and carries them to it. END
BEGIN NOW We have already agreed that secrecy may be necessary, and we must acknowledge that it could not be maintained if their correspondence were to pass through Sir John's hands. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor could not deny the truth of this, and she tried to find in it a motive sufficient for their silence. END
BEGIN NOW But there was one method so direct, so simple, and in her opinion so eligible of knowing the real state of the affair, and of instantly removing all mystery, that she could not help suggesting it to her mother. END
BEGIN NOW Why do you not ask Marianne at once, said she, whether she is or she is not engaged to Willoughby? END
BEGIN NOW From you, her mother, and so kind, so indulgent a mother, the question could not give offence. END
BEGIN NOW It would be the natural result of your affection for her. END
BEGIN NOW She used to be all unreserve, and to you more especially. END
BEGIN NOW I would not ask such a question for the world. END
BEGIN NOW Supposing it possible that they are not engaged, what distress would not such an enquiry inflict! END
BEGIN NOW At any rate it would be most ungenerous. END
BEGIN NOW I should never deserve her confidence again, after forcing from her a confession of what is meant at present to be unacknowledged to any one. END
BEGIN NOW I know Marianne's heart: I know that she dearly loves me, and that I shall not be the last to whom the affair is made known, when circumstances make the revealment of it eligible. END
BEGIN NOW I would not attempt to force the confidence of any one; of a child much less; because a sense of duty would prevent the denial which her wishes might direct. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor thought this generosity overstrained, considering her sister's youth, and urged the matter farther, but in vain; common sense, common care, common prudence, were all sunk in Mrs. Dashwood's romantic delicacy. END
BEGIN NOW It was several days before Willoughby's name was mentioned before Marianne by any of her family; Sir John and Mrs. Jennings, indeed, were not so nice; their witticisms added pain to many a painful hour;&mdash;but one evening, Mrs. Dashwood, accidentally taking up a volume of Shakespeare, exclaimed, We have never finished Hamlet, Marianne; our dear Willoughby went away before we could get through it. END
BEGIN NOW We will put it by, that when he comes again...But it may be months, perhaps, before THAT happens. END
BEGIN NOW Months! END
BEGIN NOW cried Marianne, with strong surprise. END
BEGIN NOW No&mdash;nor many weeks. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Dashwood was sorry for what she had said; but it gave Elinor pleasure, as it produced a reply from Marianne so expressive of confidence in Willoughby and knowledge of his intentions. END
BEGIN NOW One morning, about a week after his leaving the country, Marianne was prevailed on to join her sisters in their usual walk, instead of wandering away by herself. END
BEGIN NOW Hitherto she had carefully avoided every companion in her rambles. END
BEGIN NOW If her sisters intended to walk on the downs, she directly stole away towards the lanes; if they talked of the valley, she was as speedy in climbing the hills, and could never be found when the others set off. END
BEGIN NOW But at length she was secured by the exertions of Elinor, who greatly disapproved such continual seclusion. END
BEGIN NOW They walked along the road through the valley, and chiefly in silence, for Marianne's MIND could not be controlled, and Elinor, satisfied with gaining one point, would not then attempt more. END
BEGIN NOW Beyond the entrance of the valley, where the country, though still rich, was less wild and more open, a long stretch of the road which they had travelled on first coming to Barton, lay before them; and on reaching that point, they stopped to look around them, and examine a prospect which formed the distance of their view from the cottage, from a spot which they had never happened to reach in any of their walks before. END
BEGIN NOW Amongst the objects in the scene, they soon discovered an animated one; it was a man on horseback riding towards them. END
BEGIN NOW In a few minutes they could distinguish him to be a gentleman; and in a moment afterwards Marianne rapturously exclaimed, It is he; it is indeed;&mdash;I know it is! END
BEGIN NOW &mdash;and was hastening to meet him, when Elinor cried out, Indeed, Marianne, I think you are mistaken. END
BEGIN NOW It is not Willoughby. END
BEGIN NOW The person is not tall enough for him, and has not his air. END
BEGIN NOW He has, he has, cried Marianne, I am sure he has. END
BEGIN NOW His air, his coat, his horse. END
BEGIN NOW I knew how soon he would come. END
BEGIN NOW She walked eagerly on as she spoke; and Elinor, to screen Marianne from particularity, as she felt almost certain of its not being Willoughby, quickened her pace and kept up with her. END
BEGIN NOW They were soon within thirty yards of the gentleman. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne looked again; her heart sunk within her; and abruptly turning round, she was hurrying back, when the voices of both her sisters were raised to detain her; a third, almost as well known as Willoughby's, joined them in begging her to stop, and she turned round with surprise to see and welcome Edward Ferrars. END
BEGIN NOW He was the only person in the world who could at that moment be forgiven for not being Willoughby; the only one who could have gained a smile from her; but she dispersed her tears to smile on HIM, and in her sister's happiness forgot for a time her own disappointment. END
BEGIN NOW He dismounted, and giving his horse to his servant, walked back with them to Barton, whither he was purposely coming to visit them. END
BEGIN NOW He was welcomed by them all with great cordiality, but especially by Marianne, who showed more warmth of regard in her reception of him than even Elinor herself. END
BEGIN NOW To Marianne, indeed, the meeting between Edward and her sister was but a continuation of that unaccountable coldness which she had often observed at Norland in their mutual behaviour. END
BEGIN NOW On Edward's side, more particularly, there was a deficiency of all that a lover ought to look and say on such an occasion. END
BEGIN NOW He was confused, seemed scarcely sensible of pleasure in seeing them, looked neither rapturous nor gay, said little but what was forced from him by questions, and distinguished Elinor by no mark of affection. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne saw and listened with increasing surprise. END
BEGIN NOW She began almost to feel a dislike of Edward; and it ended, as every feeling must end with her, by carrying back her thoughts to Willoughby, whose manners formed a contrast sufficiently striking to those of his brother elect. END
BEGIN NOW After a short silence which succeeded the first surprise and enquiries of meeting, Marianne asked Edward if he came directly from London. END
BEGIN NOW No, he had been in Devonshire a fortnight. END
BEGIN NOW A fortnight! END
BEGIN NOW she repeated, surprised at his being so long in the same county with Elinor without seeing her before. END
BEGIN NOW He looked rather distressed as he added, that he had been staying with some friends near Plymouth. END
BEGIN NOW Have you been lately in Sussex? END
BEGIN NOW said Elinor. END
BEGIN NOW I was at Norland about a month ago. END
BEGIN NOW And how does dear, dear Norland look? END
BEGIN NOW cried Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW Dear, dear Norland, said Elinor, probably looks much as it always does at this time of the year. END
BEGIN NOW The woods and walks thickly covered with dead leaves. END
BEGIN NOW Oh, cried Marianne, with what transporting sensation have I formerly seen them fall! END
BEGIN NOW How have I delighted, as I walked, to see them driven in showers about me by the wind! END
BEGIN NOW What feelings have they, the season, the air altogether inspired! END
BEGIN NOW Now there is no one to regard them. END
BEGIN NOW They are seen only as a nuisance, swept hastily off, and driven as much as possible from the sight. END
BEGIN NOW It is not every one, said Elinor, who has your passion for dead leaves. END
BEGIN NOW No; my feelings are not often shared, not often understood. END
BEGIN NOW But SOMETIMES they are. END
BEGIN NOW &mdash;As she said this, she sunk into a reverie for a few moments;&mdash;but rousing herself again, Now, Edward, said she, calling his attention to the prospect, here is Barton valley. END
BEGIN NOW Look up to it, and be tranquil if you can. END
BEGIN NOW Look at those hills! END
BEGIN NOW Did you ever see their equals? END
BEGIN NOW To the left is Barton park, amongst those woods and plantations. END
BEGIN NOW You may see the end of the house. END
BEGIN NOW And there, beneath that farthest hill, which rises with such grandeur, is our cottage. END
BEGIN NOW It is a beautiful country, he replied; but these bottoms must be dirty in winter. END
BEGIN NOW How can you think of dirt, with such objects before you? END
BEGIN NOW Because, replied he, smiling, among the rest of the objects before me, I see a very dirty lane. END
BEGIN NOW How strange! END
BEGIN NOW said Marianne to herself as she walked on. END
BEGIN NOW Have you an agreeable neighbourhood here? END
BEGIN NOW Are the Middletons pleasant people? END
BEGIN NOW No, not all, answered Marianne; we could not be more unfortunately situated. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne, cried her sister, how can you say so? END
BEGIN NOW How can you be so unjust? END
BEGIN NOW They are a very respectable family, Mr. Ferrars; and towards us have behaved in the friendliest manner. END
BEGIN NOW Have you forgot, Marianne, how many pleasant days we have owed to them? END
BEGIN NOW No, said Marianne, in a low voice, nor how many painful moments. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor took no notice of this; and directing her attention to their visitor, endeavoured to support something like discourse with him, by talking of their present residence, its conveniences, &c. extorting from him occasional questions and remarks. END
BEGIN NOW His coldness and reserve mortified her severely; she was vexed and half angry; but resolving to regulate her behaviour to him by the past rather than the present, she avoided every appearance of resentment or displeasure, and treated him as she thought he ought to be treated from the family connection. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Dashwood was surprised only for a moment at seeing him; for his coming to Barton was, in her opinion, of all things the most natural. END
BEGIN NOW Her joy and expression of regard long outlived her wonder. END
BEGIN NOW He received the kindest welcome from her; and shyness, coldness, reserve could not stand against such a reception. END
BEGIN NOW They had begun to fail him before he entered the house, and they were quite overcome by the captivating manners of Mrs. Dashwood. END
BEGIN NOW Indeed a man could not very well be in love with either of her daughters, without extending the passion to her; and Elinor had the satisfaction of seeing him soon become more like himself. END
BEGIN NOW His affections seemed to reanimate towards them all, and his interest in their welfare again became perceptible. END
BEGIN NOW He was not in spirits, however; he praised their house, admired its prospect, was attentive, and kind; but still he was not in spirits. END
BEGIN NOW The whole family perceived it, and Mrs. Dashwood, attributing it to some want of liberality in his mother, sat down to table indignant against all selfish parents. END
BEGIN NOW What are Mrs. Ferrars's views for you at present, Edward? END
BEGIN NOW said she, when dinner was over and they had drawn round the fire; are you still to be a great orator in spite of yourself? END
BEGIN NOW No. END
BEGIN NOW I hope my mother is now convinced that I have no more talents than inclination for a public life! END
BEGIN NOW But how is your fame to be established? END
BEGIN NOW for famous you must be to satisfy all your family; and with no inclination for expense, no affection for strangers, no profession, and no assurance, you may find it a difficult matter. END
BEGIN NOW I shall not attempt it. END
BEGIN NOW I have no wish to be distinguished; and have every reason to hope I never shall. END
BEGIN NOW Thank Heaven! END
BEGIN NOW I cannot be forced into genius and eloquence. END
BEGIN NOW You have no ambition, I well know. END
BEGIN NOW Your wishes are all moderate. END
BEGIN NOW As moderate as those of the rest of the world, I believe. END
BEGIN NOW I wish as well as every body else to be perfectly happy; but, like every body else it must be in my own way. END
BEGIN NOW Greatness will not make me so. END
BEGIN NOW Strange that it would! END
BEGIN NOW cried Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW What have wealth or grandeur to do with happiness? END
BEGIN NOW Grandeur has but little, said Elinor, but wealth has much to do with it. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor, for shame! END
BEGIN NOW said Marianne, money can only give happiness where there is nothing else to give it. END
BEGIN NOW Beyond a competence, it can afford no real satisfaction, as far as mere self is concerned. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps, said Elinor, smiling, we may come to the same point. END
BEGIN NOW YOUR competence and MY wealth are very much alike, I dare say; and without them, as the world goes now, we shall both agree that every kind of external comfort must be wanting. END
BEGIN NOW Your ideas are only more noble than mine. END
BEGIN NOW Come, what is your competence? END
BEGIN NOW About eighteen hundred or two thousand a year; not more than THAT. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor laughed. END
BEGIN NOW TWO thousand a year! END
BEGIN NOW ONE is my wealth! END
BEGIN NOW I guessed how it would end. END
BEGIN NOW And yet two thousand a-year is a very moderate income, said Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW A family cannot well be maintained on a smaller. END
BEGIN NOW I am sure I am not extravagant in my demands. END
BEGIN NOW A proper establishment of servants, a carriage, perhaps two, and hunters, cannot be supported on less. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor smiled again, to hear her sister describing so accurately their future expenses at Combe Magna. END
BEGIN NOW Hunters! END
BEGIN NOW repeated Edward&mdash; but why must you have hunters? END
BEGIN NOW Every body does not hunt. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne coloured as she replied, But most people do. END
BEGIN NOW I wish, said Margaret, striking out a novel thought, that somebody would give us all a large fortune apiece! END
BEGIN NOW Oh that they would! END
BEGIN NOW cried Marianne, her eyes sparkling with animation, and her cheeks glowing with the delight of such imaginary happiness. END
BEGIN NOW We are all unanimous in that wish, I suppose, said Elinor, in spite of the insufficiency of wealth. END
BEGIN NOW Oh dear! END
BEGIN NOW cried Margaret, how happy I should be! END
BEGIN NOW I wonder what I should do with it! END
BEGIN NOW Marianne looked as if she had no doubt on that point. END
BEGIN NOW I should be puzzled to spend so large a fortune myself, said Mrs. Dashwood, if my children were all to be rich without my help. END
BEGIN NOW You must begin your improvements on this house, observed Elinor, and your difficulties will soon vanish. END
BEGIN NOW What magnificent orders would travel from this family to London, said Edward, in such an event! END
BEGIN NOW What a happy day for booksellers, music-sellers, and print-shops! END
BEGIN NOW You, Miss Dashwood, would give a general commission for every new print of merit to be sent you&mdash;and as for Marianne, I know her greatness of soul, there would not be music enough in London to content her. END
BEGIN NOW And books!&mdash;Thomson, Cowper, Scott&mdash;she would buy them all over and over again: she would buy up every copy, I believe, to prevent their falling into unworthy hands; and she would have every book that tells her how to admire an old twisted tree. END
BEGIN NOW Should not you, Marianne? END
BEGIN NOW Forgive me, if I am very saucy. END
BEGIN NOW But I was willing to shew you that I had not forgot our old disputes. END
BEGIN NOW I love to be reminded of the past, Edward&mdash;whether it be melancholy or gay, I love to recall it&mdash;and you will never offend me by talking of former times. END
BEGIN NOW You are very right in supposing how my money would be spent&mdash;some of it, at least&mdash;my loose cash would certainly be employed in improving my collection of music and books. END
BEGIN NOW And the bulk of your fortune would be laid out in annuities on the authors or their heirs. END
BEGIN NOW No, Edward, I should have something else to do with it. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps, then, you would bestow it as a reward on that person who wrote the ablest defence of your favourite maxim, that no one can ever be in love more than once in their life&mdash;your opinion on that point is unchanged, I presume? END
BEGIN NOW Undoubtedly. END
BEGIN NOW At my time of life opinions are tolerably fixed. END
BEGIN NOW It is not likely that I should now see or hear any thing to change them. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne is as steadfast as ever, you see, said Elinor, she is not at all altered. END
BEGIN NOW She is only grown a little more grave than she was. END
BEGIN NOW Nay, Edward, said Marianne, you need not reproach me. END
BEGIN NOW You are not very gay yourself. END
BEGIN NOW Why should you think so! END
BEGIN NOW replied he, with a sigh. END
BEGIN NOW But gaiety never was a part of MY character. END
BEGIN NOW Nor do I think it a part of Marianne's, said Elinor; I should hardly call her a lively girl&mdash;she is very earnest, very eager in all she does&mdash;sometimes talks a great deal and always with animation&mdash;but she is not often really merry. END
BEGIN NOW I believe you are right, he replied, and yet I have always set her down as a lively girl. END
BEGIN NOW I have frequently detected myself in such kind of mistakes, said Elinor, in a total misapprehension of character in some point or other: fancying people so much more gay or grave, or ingenious or stupid than they really are, and I can hardly tell why or in what the deception originated. END
BEGIN NOW Sometimes one is guided by what they say of themselves, and very frequently by what other people say of them, without giving oneself time to deliberate and judge. END
BEGIN NOW But I thought it was right, Elinor, said Marianne, to be guided wholly by the opinion of other people. END
BEGIN NOW I thought our judgments were given us merely to be subservient to those of neighbours. END
BEGIN NOW This has always been your doctrine, I am sure. END
BEGIN NOW No, Marianne, never. END
BEGIN NOW My doctrine has never aimed at the subjection of the understanding. END
BEGIN NOW All I have ever attempted to influence has been the behaviour. END
BEGIN NOW You must not confound my meaning. END
BEGIN NOW I am guilty, I confess, of having often wished you to treat our acquaintance in general with greater attention; but when have I advised you to adopt their sentiments or to conform to their judgment in serious matters? END
BEGIN NOW You have not been able to bring your sister over to your plan of general civility, said Edward to Elinor. END
BEGIN NOW Do you gain no ground? END
BEGIN NOW Quite the contrary, replied Elinor, looking expressively at Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW My judgment, he returned, is all on your side of the question; but I am afraid my practice is much more on your sister's. END
BEGIN NOW I never wish to offend, but I am so foolishly shy, that I often seem negligent, when I am only kept back by my natural awkwardness. END
BEGIN NOW I have frequently thought that I must have been intended by nature to be fond of low company, I am so little at my ease among strangers of gentility! END
BEGIN NOW Marianne has not shyness to excuse any inattention of hers, said Elinor. END
BEGIN NOW She knows her own worth too well for false shame, replied Edward. END
BEGIN NOW Shyness is only the effect of a sense of inferiority in some way or other. END
BEGIN NOW If I could persuade myself that my manners were perfectly easy and graceful, I should not be shy. END
BEGIN NOW But you would still be reserved, said Marianne, and that is worse. END
BEGIN NOW Edward started&mdash; Reserved! END
BEGIN NOW Am I reserved, Marianne? END
BEGIN NOW Yes, very. END
BEGIN NOW I do not understand you, replied he, colouring. END
BEGIN NOW Reserved!&mdash;how, in what manner? END
BEGIN NOW What am I to tell you? END
BEGIN NOW What can you suppose? END
BEGIN NOW Elinor looked surprised at his emotion; but trying to laugh off the subject, she said to him, Do not you know my sister well enough to understand what she means? END
BEGIN NOW Do not you know she calls every one reserved who does not talk as fast, and admire what she admires as rapturously as herself? END
BEGIN NOW Edward made no answer. END
BEGIN NOW His gravity and thoughtfulness returned on him in their fullest extent&mdash;and he sat for some time silent and dull. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor saw, with great uneasiness the low spirits of her friend. END
BEGIN NOW His visit afforded her but a very partial satisfaction, while his own enjoyment in it appeared so imperfect. END
BEGIN NOW It was evident that he was unhappy; she wished it were equally evident that he still distinguished her by the same affection which once she had felt no doubt of inspiring; but hitherto the continuance of his preference seemed very uncertain; and the reservedness of his manner towards her contradicted one moment what a more animated look had intimated the preceding one. END
BEGIN NOW He joined her and Marianne in the breakfast-room the next morning before the others were down; and Marianne, who was always eager to promote their happiness as far as she could, soon left them to themselves. END
BEGIN NOW But before she was half way upstairs she heard the parlour door open, and, turning round, was astonished to see Edward himself come out. END
BEGIN NOW I am going into the village to see my horses, said he, as you are not yet ready for breakfast; I shall be back again presently. END
BEGIN NOW *** Edward returned to them with fresh admiration of the surrounding country; in his walk to the village, he had seen many parts of the valley to advantage; and the village itself, in a much higher situation than the cottage, afforded a general view of the whole, which had exceedingly pleased him. END
BEGIN NOW This was a subject which ensured Marianne's attention, and she was beginning to describe her own admiration of these scenes, and to question him more minutely on the objects that had particularly struck him, when Edward interrupted her by saying, You must not enquire too far, Marianne&mdash;remember I have no knowledge in the picturesque, and I shall offend you by my ignorance and want of taste if we come to particulars. END
BEGIN NOW I shall call hills steep, which ought to be bold; surfaces strange and uncouth, which ought to be irregular and rugged; and distant objects out of sight, which ought only to be indistinct through the soft medium of a hazy atmosphere. END
BEGIN NOW You must be satisfied with such admiration as I can honestly give. END
BEGIN NOW I call it a very fine country&mdash;the hills are steep, the woods seem full of fine timber, and the valley looks comfortable and snug&mdash;with rich meadows and several neat farm houses scattered here and there. END
BEGIN NOW It exactly answers my idea of a fine country, because it unites beauty with utility&mdash;and I dare say it is a picturesque one too, because you admire it; I can easily believe it to be full of rocks and promontories, grey moss and brush wood, but these are all lost on me. END
BEGIN NOW I know nothing of the picturesque. END
BEGIN NOW I am afraid it is but too true, said Marianne; but why should you boast of it? END
BEGIN NOW I suspect, said Elinor, that to avoid one kind of affectation, Edward here falls into another. END
BEGIN NOW Because he believes many people pretend to more admiration of the beauties of nature than they really feel, and is disgusted with such pretensions, he affects greater indifference and less discrimination in viewing them himself than he possesses. END
BEGIN NOW He is fastidious and will have an affectation of his own. END
BEGIN NOW It is very true, said Marianne, that admiration of landscape scenery is become a mere jargon. END
BEGIN NOW Every body pretends to feel and tries to describe with the taste and elegance of him who first defined what picturesque beauty was. END
BEGIN NOW I detest jargon of every kind, and sometimes I have kept my feelings to myself, because I could find no language to describe them in but what was worn and hackneyed out of all sense and meaning. END
BEGIN NOW I am convinced, said Edward, that you really feel all the delight in a fine prospect which you profess to feel. END
BEGIN NOW But, in return, your sister must allow me to feel no more than I profess. END
BEGIN NOW I like a fine prospect, but not on picturesque principles. END
BEGIN NOW I do not like crooked, twisted, blasted trees. END
BEGIN NOW I admire them much more if they are tall, straight, and flourishing. END
BEGIN NOW I do not like ruined, tattered cottages. END
BEGIN NOW I am not fond of nettles or thistles, or heath blossoms. END
BEGIN NOW I have more pleasure in a snug farm-house than a watch-tower&mdash;and a troop of tidy, happy villages please me better than the finest banditti in the world. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne looked with amazement at Edward, with compassion at her sister. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor only laughed. END
BEGIN NOW The subject was continued no farther; and Marianne remained thoughtfully silent, till a new object suddenly engaged her attention. END
BEGIN NOW She was sitting by Edward, and in taking his tea from Mrs. Dashwood, his hand passed so directly before her, as to make a ring, with a plait of hair in the centre, very conspicuous on one of his fingers. END
BEGIN NOW I never saw you wear a ring before, Edward, she cried. END
BEGIN NOW Is that Fanny's hair? END
BEGIN NOW I remember her promising to give you some. END
BEGIN NOW But I should have thought her hair had been darker. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne spoke inconsiderately what she really felt&mdash;but when she saw how much she had pained Edward, her own vexation at her want of thought could not be surpassed by his. END
BEGIN NOW He coloured very deeply, and giving a momentary glance at Elinor, replied, Yes; it is my sister's hair. END
BEGIN NOW The setting always casts a different shade on it, you know. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor had met his eye, and looked conscious likewise. END
BEGIN NOW That the hair was her own, she instantaneously felt as well satisfied as Marianne; the only difference in their conclusions was, that what Marianne considered as a free gift from her sister, Elinor was conscious must have been procured by some theft or contrivance unknown to herself. END
BEGIN NOW She was not in a humour, however, to regard it as an affront, and affecting to take no notice of what passed, by instantly talking of something else, she internally resolved henceforward to catch every opportunity of eyeing the hair and of satisfying herself, beyond all doubt, that it was exactly the shade of her own. END
BEGIN NOW Edward's embarrassment lasted some time, and it ended in an absence of mind still more settled. END
BEGIN NOW He was particularly grave the whole morning. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne severely censured herself for what she had said; but her own forgiveness might have been more speedy, had she known how little offence it had given her sister. END
BEGIN NOW Before the middle of the day, they were visited by Sir John and Mrs. Jennings, who, having heard of the arrival of a gentleman at the cottage, came to take a survey of the guest. END
BEGIN NOW With the assistance of his mother-in-law, Sir John was not long in discovering that the name of Ferrars began with an F. and this prepared a future mine of raillery against the devoted Elinor, which nothing but the newness of their acquaintance with Edward could have prevented from being immediately sprung. END
BEGIN NOW But, as it was, she only learned, from some very significant looks, how far their penetration, founded on Margaret's instructions, extended. END
BEGIN NOW Sir John never came to the Dashwoods without either inviting them to dine at the park the next day, or to drink tea with them that evening. END
BEGIN NOW On the present occasion, for the better entertainment of their visitor, towards whose amusement he felt himself bound to contribute, he wished to engage them for both. END
BEGIN NOW You MUST drink tea with us to night, said he, for we shall be quite alone&mdash;and tomorrow you must absolutely dine with us, for we shall be a large party. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings enforced the necessity. END
BEGIN NOW And who knows but you may raise a dance, said she. END
BEGIN NOW And that will tempt YOU, Miss Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW A dance! END
BEGIN NOW cried Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW Impossible! END
BEGIN NOW Who is to dance? END
BEGIN NOW Who! END
BEGIN NOW why yourselves, and the Careys, and Whitakers to be sure.&mdash;What! END
BEGIN NOW you thought nobody could dance because a certain person that shall be nameless is gone! END
BEGIN NOW I wish with all my soul, cried Sir John, that Willoughby were among us again. END
BEGIN NOW This, and Marianne's blushing, gave new suspicions to Edward. END
BEGIN NOW And who is Willoughby? END
BEGIN NOW said he, in a low voice, to Miss Dashwood, by whom he was sitting. END
BEGIN NOW She gave him a brief reply. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne's countenance was more communicative. END
BEGIN NOW Edward saw enough to comprehend, not only the meaning of others, but such of Marianne's expressions as had puzzled him before; and when their visitors left them, he went immediately round her, and said, in a whisper, I have been guessing. END
BEGIN NOW Shall I tell you my guess? END
BEGIN NOW What do you mean? END
BEGIN NOW Shall I tell you. END
BEGIN NOW Certainly. END
BEGIN NOW Well then; I guess that Mr. Willoughby hunts. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne was surprised and confused, yet she could not help smiling at the quiet archness of his manner, and after a moment's silence, said, Oh, Edward! END
BEGIN NOW How can you?&mdash;But the time will come I hope...I am sure you will like him. END
BEGIN NOW I do not doubt it, replied he, rather astonished at her earnestness and warmth; for had he not imagined it to be a joke for the good of her acquaintance in general, founded only on a something or a nothing between Mr. Willoughby and herself, he would not have ventured to mention it. END
BEGIN NOW Edward remained a week at the cottage; he was earnestly pressed by Mrs. Dashwood to stay longer; but, as if he were bent only on self-mortification, he seemed resolved to be gone when his enjoyment among his friends was at the height. END
BEGIN NOW His spirits, during the last two or three days, though still very unequal, were greatly improved&mdash;he grew more and more partial to the house and environs&mdash;never spoke of going away without a sigh&mdash;declared his time to be wholly disengaged&mdash;even doubted to what place he should go when he left them&mdash;but still, go he must. END
BEGIN NOW Never had any week passed so quickly&mdash;he could hardly believe it to be gone. END
BEGIN NOW He said so repeatedly; other things he said too, which marked the turn of his feelings and gave the lie to his actions. END
BEGIN NOW He had no pleasure at Norland; he detested being in town; but either to Norland or London, he must go. END
BEGIN NOW He valued their kindness beyond any thing, and his greatest happiness was in being with them. END
BEGIN NOW Yet, he must leave them at the end of a week, in spite of their wishes and his own, and without any restraint on his time. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor placed all that was astonishing in this way of acting to his mother's account; and it was happy for her that he had a mother whose character was so imperfectly known to her, as to be the general excuse for every thing strange on the part of her son. END
BEGIN NOW Disappointed, however, and vexed as she was, and sometimes displeased with his uncertain behaviour to herself, she was very well disposed on the whole to regard his actions with all the candid allowances and generous qualifications, which had been rather more painfully extorted from her, for Willoughby's service, by her mother. END
BEGIN NOW His want of spirits, of openness, and of consistency, were most usually attributed to his want of independence, and his better knowledge of Mrs. Ferrars's disposition and designs. END
BEGIN NOW The shortness of his visit, the steadiness of his purpose in leaving them, originated in the same fettered inclination, the same inevitable necessity of temporizing with his mother. END
BEGIN NOW The old well-established grievance of duty against will, parent against child, was the cause of all. END
BEGIN NOW She would have been glad to know when these difficulties were to cease, this opposition was to yield,&mdash;when Mrs. Ferrars would be reformed, and her son be at liberty to be happy. END
BEGIN NOW But from such vain wishes she was forced to turn for comfort to the renewal of her confidence in Edward's affection, to the remembrance of every mark of regard in look or word which fell from him while at Barton, and above all to that flattering proof of it which he constantly wore round his finger. END
BEGIN NOW I think, Edward, said Mrs. Dashwood, as they were at breakfast the last morning, you would be a happier man if you had any profession to engage your time and give an interest to your plans and actions. END
BEGIN NOW Some inconvenience to your friends, indeed, might result from it&mdash;you would not be able to give them so much of your time. END
BEGIN NOW But (with a smile) you would be materially benefited in one particular at least&mdash;you would know where to go when you left them. END
BEGIN NOW I do assure you, he replied, that I have long thought on this point, as you think now. END
BEGIN NOW It has been, and is, and probably will always be a heavy misfortune to me, that I have had no necessary business to engage me, no profession to give me employment, or afford me any thing like independence. END
BEGIN NOW But unfortunately my own nicety, and the nicety of my friends, have made me what I am, an idle, helpless being. END
BEGIN NOW We never could agree in our choice of a profession. END
BEGIN NOW I always preferred the church, as I still do. END
BEGIN NOW But that was not smart enough for my family. END
BEGIN NOW They recommended the army. END
BEGIN NOW That was a great deal too smart for me. END
BEGIN NOW The law was allowed to be genteel enough; many young men, who had chambers in the Temple, made a very good appearance in the first circles, and drove about town in very knowing gigs. END
BEGIN NOW But I had no inclination for the law, even in this less abstruse study of it, which my family approved. END
BEGIN NOW As for the navy, it had fashion on its side, but I was too old when the subject was first started to enter it&mdash;and, at length, as there was no necessity for my having any profession at all, as I might be as dashing and expensive without a red coat on my back as with one, idleness was pronounced on the whole to be most advantageous and honourable, and a young man of eighteen is not in general so earnestly bent on being busy as to resist the solicitations of his friends to do nothing. END
BEGIN NOW I was therefore entered at Oxford and have been properly idle ever since. END
BEGIN NOW The consequence of which, I suppose, will be, said Mrs. Dashwood, since leisure has not promoted your own happiness, that your sons will be brought up to as many pursuits, employments, professions, and trades as Columella's. END
BEGIN NOW They will be brought up, said he, in a serious accent, to be as unlike myself as is possible. END
BEGIN NOW In feeling, in action, in condition, in every thing. END
BEGIN NOW Come, come; this is all an effusion of immediate want of spirits, Edward. END
BEGIN NOW You are in a melancholy humour, and fancy that any one unlike yourself must be happy. END
BEGIN NOW But remember that the pain of parting from friends will be felt by every body at times, whatever be their education or state. END
BEGIN NOW Know your own happiness. END
BEGIN NOW You want nothing but patience&mdash;or give it a more fascinating name, call it hope. END
BEGIN NOW Your mother will secure to you, in time, that independence you are so anxious for; it is her duty, and it will, it must ere long become her happiness to prevent your whole youth from being wasted in discontent. END
BEGIN NOW How much may not a few months do? END
BEGIN NOW I think, replied Edward, that I may defy many months to produce any good to me. END
BEGIN NOW This desponding turn of mind, though it could not be communicated to Mrs. Dashwood, gave additional pain to them all in the parting, which shortly took place, and left an uncomfortable impression on Elinor's feelings especially, which required some trouble and time to subdue. END
BEGIN NOW But as it was her determination to subdue it, and to prevent herself from appearing to suffer more than what all her family suffered on his going away, she did not adopt the method so judiciously employed by Marianne, on a similar occasion, to augment and fix her sorrow, by seeking silence, solitude and idleness. END
BEGIN NOW Their means were as different as their objects, and equally suited to the advancement of each. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor sat down to her drawing-table as soon as he was out of the house, busily employed herself the whole day, neither sought nor avoided the mention of his name, appeared to interest herself almost as much as ever in the general concerns of the family, and if, by this conduct, she did not lessen her own grief, it was at least prevented from unnecessary increase, and her mother and sisters were spared much solicitude on her account. END
BEGIN NOW Such behaviour as this, so exactly the reverse of her own, appeared no more meritorious to Marianne, than her own had seemed faulty to her. END
BEGIN NOW The business of self-command she settled very easily;&mdash;with strong affections it was impossible, with calm ones it could have no merit. END
BEGIN NOW That her sister's affections WERE calm, she dared not deny, though she blushed to acknowledge it; and of the strength of her own, she gave a very striking proof, by still loving and respecting that sister, in spite of this mortifying conviction. END
BEGIN NOW Without shutting herself up from her family, or leaving the house in determined solitude to avoid them, or lying awake the whole night to indulge meditation, Elinor found every day afforded her leisure enough to think of Edward, and of Edward's behaviour, in every possible variety which the different state of her spirits at different times could produce,&mdash;with tenderness, pity, approbation, censure, and doubt. END
BEGIN NOW There were moments in abundance, when, if not by the absence of her mother and sisters, at least by the nature of their employments, conversation was forbidden among them, and every effect of solitude was produced. END
BEGIN NOW Her mind was inevitably at liberty; her thoughts could not be chained elsewhere; and the past and the future, on a subject so interesting, must be before her, must force her attention, and engross her memory, her reflection, and her fancy. END
BEGIN NOW From a reverie of this kind, as she sat at her drawing-table, she was roused one morning, soon after Edward's leaving them, by the arrival of company. END
BEGIN NOW She happened to be quite alone. END
BEGIN NOW The closing of the little gate, at the entrance of the green court in front of the house, drew her eyes to the window, and she saw a large party walking up to the door. END
BEGIN NOW Amongst them were Sir John and Lady Middleton and Mrs. Jennings, but there were two others, a gentleman and lady, who were quite unknown to her. END
BEGIN NOW She was sitting near the window, and as soon as Sir John perceived her, he left the rest of the party to the ceremony of knocking at the door, and stepping across the turf, obliged her to open the casement to speak to him, though the space was so short between the door and the window, as to make it hardly possible to speak at one without being heard at the other. END
BEGIN NOW Well, said he, we have brought you some strangers. END
BEGIN NOW How do you like them? END
BEGIN NOW Hush! END
BEGIN NOW they will hear you. END
BEGIN NOW Never mind if they do. END
BEGIN NOW It is only the Palmers. END
BEGIN NOW Charlotte is very pretty, I can tell you. END
BEGIN NOW You may see her if you look this way. END
BEGIN NOW As Elinor was certain of seeing her in a couple of minutes, without taking that liberty, she begged to be excused. END
BEGIN NOW Where is Marianne? END
BEGIN NOW Has she run away because we are come? END
BEGIN NOW I see her instrument is open. END
BEGIN NOW She is walking, I believe. END
BEGIN NOW They were now joined by Mrs. Jennings, who had not patience enough to wait till the door was opened before she told HER story. END
BEGIN NOW She came hallooing to the window, How do you do, my dear? END
BEGIN NOW How does Mrs. Dashwood do? END
BEGIN NOW And where are your sisters? END
BEGIN NOW What! END
BEGIN NOW all alone! END
BEGIN NOW you will be glad of a little company to sit with you. END
BEGIN NOW I have brought my other son and daughter to see you. END
BEGIN NOW Only think of their coming so suddenly! END
BEGIN NOW I thought I heard a carriage last night, while we were drinking our tea, but it never entered my head that it could be them. END
BEGIN NOW I thought of nothing but whether it might not be Colonel Brandon come back again; so I said to Sir John, I do think I hear a carriage; perhaps it is Colonel Brandon come back again &mdash; Elinor was obliged to turn from her, in the middle of her story, to receive the rest of the party; Lady Middleton introduced the two strangers; Mrs. Dashwood and Margaret came down stairs at the same time, and they all sat down to look at one another, while Mrs. Jennings continued her story as she walked through the passage into the parlour, attended by Sir John. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Palmer was several years younger than Lady Middleton, and totally unlike her in every respect. END
BEGIN NOW She was short and plump, had a very pretty face, and the finest expression of good humour in it that could possibly be. END
BEGIN NOW Her manners were by no means so elegant as her sister's, but they were much more prepossessing. END
BEGIN NOW She came in with a smile, smiled all the time of her visit, except when she laughed, and smiled when she went away. END
BEGIN NOW Her husband was a grave looking young man of five or six and twenty, with an air of more fashion and sense than his wife, but of less willingness to please or be pleased. END
BEGIN NOW He entered the room with a look of self-consequence, slightly bowed to the ladies, without speaking a word, and, after briefly surveying them and their apartments, took up a newspaper from the table, and continued to read it as long as he staid. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Palmer, on the contrary, who was strongly endowed by nature with a turn for being uniformly civil and happy, was hardly seated before her admiration of the parlour and every thing in it burst forth. END
BEGIN NOW Well! END
BEGIN NOW what a delightful room this is! END
BEGIN NOW I never saw anything so charming! END
BEGIN NOW Only think, Mama, how it is improved since I was here last! END
BEGIN NOW I always thought it such a sweet place, ma'am! END
BEGIN NOW (turning to Mrs. Dashwood) but you have made it so charming! END
BEGIN NOW Only look, sister, how delightful every thing is! END
BEGIN NOW How I should like such a house for myself! END
BEGIN NOW Should not you, Mr. Palmer? END
BEGIN NOW Mr. Palmer made her no answer, and did not even raise his eyes from the newspaper. END
BEGIN NOW Mr. Palmer does not hear me, said she, laughing; he never does sometimes. END
BEGIN NOW It is so ridiculous! END
BEGIN NOW This was quite a new idea to Mrs. Dashwood; she had never been used to find wit in the inattention of any one, and could not help looking with surprise at them both. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings, in the meantime, talked on as loud as she could, and continued her account of their surprise, the evening before, on seeing their friends, without ceasing till every thing was told. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Palmer laughed heartily at the recollection of their astonishment, and every body agreed, two or three times over, that it had been quite an agreeable surprise. END
BEGIN NOW You may believe how glad we all were to see them, added Mrs. Jennings, leaning forward towards Elinor, and speaking in a low voice as if she meant to be heard by no one else, though they were seated on different sides of the room; but, however, I can't help wishing they had not travelled quite so fast, nor made such a long journey of it, for they came all round by London upon account of some business, for you know (nodding significantly and pointing to her daughter) it was wrong in her situation. END
BEGIN NOW I wanted her to stay at home and rest this morning, but she would come with us; she longed so much to see you all! END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Palmer laughed, and said it would not do her any harm. END
BEGIN NOW She expects to be confined in February, continued Mrs. Jennings. END
BEGIN NOW Lady Middleton could no longer endure such a conversation, and therefore exerted herself to ask Mr. Palmer if there was any news in the paper. END
BEGIN NOW No, none at all, he replied, and read on. END
BEGIN NOW Here comes Marianne, cried Sir John. END
BEGIN NOW Now, Palmer, you shall see a monstrous pretty girl. END
BEGIN NOW He immediately went into the passage, opened the front door, and ushered her in himself. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings asked her, as soon as she appeared, if she had not been to Allenham; and Mrs. Palmer laughed so heartily at the question, as to show she understood it. END
BEGIN NOW Mr. Palmer looked up on her entering the room, stared at her some minutes, and then returned to his newspaper. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Palmer's eye was now caught by the drawings which hung round the room. END
BEGIN NOW She got up to examine them. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW dear, how beautiful these are! END
BEGIN NOW Well! END
BEGIN NOW how delightful! END
BEGIN NOW Do but look, mama, how sweet! END
BEGIN NOW I declare they are quite charming; I could look at them for ever. END
BEGIN NOW And then sitting down again, she very soon forgot that there were any such things in the room. END
BEGIN NOW When Lady Middleton rose to go away, Mr. Palmer rose also, laid down the newspaper, stretched himself and looked at them all around. END
BEGIN NOW My love, have you been asleep? END
BEGIN NOW said his wife, laughing. END
BEGIN NOW He made her no answer; and only observed, after again examining the room, that it was very low pitched, and that the ceiling was crooked. END
BEGIN NOW He then made his bow, and departed with the rest. END
BEGIN NOW Sir John had been very urgent with them all to spend the next day at the park. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Dashwood, who did not chuse to dine with them oftener than they dined at the cottage, absolutely refused on her own account; her daughters might do as they pleased. END
BEGIN NOW But they had no curiosity to see how Mr. and Mrs. Palmer ate their dinner, and no expectation of pleasure from them in any other way. END
BEGIN NOW They attempted, therefore, likewise, to excuse themselves; the weather was uncertain, and not likely to be good. END
BEGIN NOW But Sir John would not be satisfied&mdash;the carriage should be sent for them and they must come. END
BEGIN NOW Lady Middleton too, though she did not press their mother, pressed them. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings and Mrs. Palmer joined their entreaties, all seemed equally anxious to avoid a family party; and the young ladies were obliged to yield. END
BEGIN NOW Why should they ask us? END
BEGIN NOW said Marianne, as soon as they were gone. END
BEGIN NOW The rent of this cottage is said to be low; but we have it on very hard terms, if we are to dine at the park whenever any one is staying either with them, or with us. END
BEGIN NOW They mean no less to be civil and kind to us now, said Elinor, by these frequent invitations, than by those which we received from them a few weeks ago. END
BEGIN NOW The alteration is not in them, if their parties are grown tedious and dull. END
BEGIN NOW We must look for the change elsewhere. END
BEGIN NOW As the Miss Dashwoods entered the drawing-room of the park the next day, at one door, Mrs. Palmer came running in at the other, looking as good humoured and merry as before. END
BEGIN NOW She took them all most affectionately by the hand, and expressed great delight in seeing them again. END
BEGIN NOW I am so glad to see you! END
BEGIN NOW said she, seating herself between Elinor and Marianne, for it is so bad a day I was afraid you might not come, which would be a shocking thing, as we go away again tomorrow. END
BEGIN NOW We must go, for the Westons come to us next week you know. END
BEGIN NOW It was quite a sudden thing our coming at all, and I knew nothing of it till the carriage was coming to the door, and then Mr. Palmer asked me if I would go with him to Barton. END
BEGIN NOW He is so droll! END
BEGIN NOW He never tells me any thing! END
BEGIN NOW I am so sorry we cannot stay longer; however we shall meet again in town very soon, I hope. END
BEGIN NOW They were obliged to put an end to such an expectation. END
BEGIN NOW Not go to town! END
BEGIN NOW cried Mrs. Palmer, with a laugh, I shall be quite disappointed if you do not. END
BEGIN NOW I could get the nicest house in the world for you, next door to ours, in Hanover-square. END
BEGIN NOW You must come, indeed. END
BEGIN NOW I am sure I shall be very happy to chaperon you at any time till I am confined, if Mrs. Dashwood should not like to go into public. END
BEGIN NOW They thanked her; but were obliged to resist all her entreaties. END
BEGIN NOW Oh, my love, cried Mrs. Palmer to her husband, who just then entered the room&mdash; you must help me to persuade the Miss Dashwoods to go to town this winter. END
BEGIN NOW Her love made no answer; and after slightly bowing to the ladies, began complaining of the weather. END
BEGIN NOW How horrid all this is! END
BEGIN NOW said he. END
BEGIN NOW Such weather makes every thing and every body disgusting. END
BEGIN NOW Dullness is as much produced within doors as without, by rain. END
BEGIN NOW It makes one detest all one's acquaintance. END
BEGIN NOW What the devil does Sir John mean by not having a billiard room in his house? END
BEGIN NOW How few people know what comfort is! END
BEGIN NOW Sir John is as stupid as the weather. END
BEGIN NOW The rest of the company soon dropt in. END
BEGIN NOW I am afraid, Miss Marianne, said Sir John, you have not been able to take your usual walk to Allenham today. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne looked very grave and said nothing. END
BEGIN NOW Oh, don't be so sly before us, said Mrs. Palmer; for we know all about it, I assure you; and I admire your taste very much, for I think he is extremely handsome. END
BEGIN NOW We do not live a great way from him in the country, you know. END
BEGIN NOW Not above ten miles, I dare say. END
BEGIN NOW Much nearer thirty, said her husband. END
BEGIN NOW Ah, well! END
BEGIN NOW there is not much difference. END
BEGIN NOW I never was at his house; but they say it is a sweet pretty place. END
BEGIN NOW As vile a spot as I ever saw in my life, said Mr. Palmer. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne remained perfectly silent, though her countenance betrayed her interest in what was said. END
BEGIN NOW Is it very ugly? END
BEGIN NOW continued Mrs. Palmer&mdash; then it must be some other place that is so pretty I suppose. END
BEGIN NOW When they were seated in the dining room, Sir John observed with regret that they were only eight all together. END
BEGIN NOW My dear, said he to his lady, it is very provoking that we should be so few. END
BEGIN NOW Why did not you ask the Gilberts to come to us today? END
BEGIN NOW Did not I tell you, Sir John, when you spoke to me about it before, that it could not be done? END
BEGIN NOW They dined with us last. END
BEGIN NOW You and I, Sir John, said Mrs. Jennings, should not stand upon such ceremony. END
BEGIN NOW Then you would be very ill-bred, cried Mr. Palmer. END
BEGIN NOW My love you contradict every body, said his wife with her usual laugh. END
BEGIN NOW Do you know that you are quite rude? END
BEGIN NOW I did not know I contradicted any body in calling your mother ill-bred. END
BEGIN NOW Ay, you may abuse me as you please, said the good-natured old lady, you have taken Charlotte off my hands, and cannot give her back again. END
BEGIN NOW So there I have the whip hand of you. END
BEGIN NOW Charlotte laughed heartily to think that her husband could not get rid of her; and exultingly said, she did not care how cross he was to her, as they must live together. END
BEGIN NOW It was impossible for any one to be more thoroughly good-natured, or more determined to be happy than Mrs. Palmer. END
BEGIN NOW The studied indifference, insolence, and discontent of her husband gave her no pain; and when he scolded or abused her, she was highly diverted. END
BEGIN NOW Mr. Palmer is so droll! END
BEGIN NOW said she, in a whisper, to Elinor. END
BEGIN NOW He is always out of humour. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor was not inclined, after a little observation, to give him credit for being so genuinely and unaffectedly ill-natured or ill-bred as he wished to appear. END
BEGIN NOW His temper might perhaps be a little soured by finding, like many others of his sex, that through some unaccountable bias in favour of beauty, he was the husband of a very silly woman,&mdash;but she knew that this kind of blunder was too common for any sensible man to be lastingly hurt by it.&mdash; It was rather a wish of distinction, she believed, which produced his contemptuous treatment of every body, and his general abuse of every thing before him. END
BEGIN NOW It was the desire of appearing superior to other people. END
BEGIN NOW The motive was too common to be wondered at; but the means, however they might succeed by establishing his superiority in ill-breeding, were not likely to attach any one to him except his wife. END
BEGIN NOW Oh, my dear Miss Dashwood, said Mrs. Palmer soon afterwards, I have got such a favour to ask of you and your sister. END
BEGIN NOW Will you come and spend some time at Cleveland this Christmas? END
BEGIN NOW Now, pray do,&mdash;and come while the Westons are with us. END
BEGIN NOW You cannot think how happy I shall be! END
BEGIN NOW It will be quite delightful!&mdash;My love, applying to her husband, don't you long to have the Miss Dashwoods come to Cleveland? END
BEGIN NOW Certainly, he replied, with a sneer&mdash; I came into Devonshire with no other view. END
BEGIN NOW There now, &mdash;said his lady, you see Mr. Palmer expects you; so you cannot refuse to come. END
BEGIN NOW They both eagerly and resolutely declined her invitation. END
BEGIN NOW But indeed you must and shall come. END
BEGIN NOW I am sure you will like it of all things. END
BEGIN NOW The Westons will be with us, and it will be quite delightful. END
BEGIN NOW You cannot think what a sweet place Cleveland is; and we are so gay now, for Mr. Palmer is always going about the country canvassing against the election; and so many people came to dine with us that I never saw before, it is quite charming! END
BEGIN NOW But, poor fellow! END
BEGIN NOW it is very fatiguing to him! END
BEGIN NOW for he is forced to make every body like him. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor could hardly keep her countenance as she assented to the hardship of such an obligation. END
BEGIN NOW How charming it will be, said Charlotte, when he is in Parliament!&mdash;won't it? END
BEGIN NOW How I shall laugh! END
BEGIN NOW It will be so ridiculous to see all his letters directed to him with an M.P.&mdash;But do you know, he says, he will never frank for me? END
BEGIN NOW He declares he won't. END
BEGIN NOW Don't you, Mr. Palmer? END
BEGIN NOW Mr. Palmer took no notice of her. END
BEGIN NOW He cannot bear writing, you know, she continued&mdash; he says it is quite shocking. END
BEGIN NOW No, said he, I never said any thing so irrational. END
BEGIN NOW Don't palm all your abuses of languages upon me. END
BEGIN NOW There now; you see how droll he is. END
BEGIN NOW This is always the way with him! END
BEGIN NOW Sometimes he won't speak to me for half a day together, and then he comes out with something so droll&mdash;all about any thing in the world. END
BEGIN NOW She surprised Elinor very much as they returned into the drawing-room, by asking her whether she did not like Mr. Palmer excessively. END
BEGIN NOW Certainly, said Elinor; he seems very agreeable. END
BEGIN NOW Well&mdash;I am so glad you do. END
BEGIN NOW I thought you would, he is so pleasant; and Mr. Palmer is excessively pleased with you and your sisters I can tell you, and you can't think how disappointed he will be if you don't come to Cleveland.&mdash;I can't imagine why you should object to it. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor was again obliged to decline her invitation; and by changing the subject, put a stop to her entreaties. END
BEGIN NOW She thought it probable that as they lived in the same county, Mrs. Palmer might be able to give some more particular account of Willoughby's general character, than could be gathered from the Middletons' partial acquaintance with him; and she was eager to gain from any one, such a confirmation of his merits as might remove the possibility of fear from Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW She began by inquiring if they saw much of Mr. Willoughby at Cleveland, and whether they were intimately acquainted with him. END
BEGIN NOW Oh dear, yes; I know him extremely well, replied Mrs. Palmer;&mdash; Not that I ever spoke to him, indeed; but I have seen him for ever in town. END
BEGIN NOW Somehow or other I never happened to be staying at Barton while he was at Allenham. END
BEGIN NOW Mama saw him here once before;&mdash;but I was with my uncle at Weymouth. END
BEGIN NOW However, I dare say we should have seen a great deal of him in Somersetshire, if it had not happened very unluckily that we should never have been in the country together. END
BEGIN NOW He is very little at Combe, I believe; but if he were ever so much there, I do not think Mr. Palmer would visit him, for he is in the opposition, you know, and besides it is such a way off. END
BEGIN NOW I know why you inquire about him, very well; your sister is to marry him. END
BEGIN NOW I am monstrous glad of it, for then I shall have her for a neighbour you know. END
BEGIN NOW Upon my word, replied Elinor, you know much more of the matter than I do, if you have any reason to expect such a match. END
BEGIN NOW Don't pretend to deny it, because you know it is what every body talks of. END
BEGIN NOW I assure you I heard of it in my way through town. END
BEGIN NOW My dear Mrs. Palmer! END
BEGIN NOW Upon my honour I did.&mdash;I met Colonel Brandon Monday morning in Bond-street, just before we left town, and he told me of it directly. END
BEGIN NOW You surprise me very much. END
BEGIN NOW Colonel Brandon tell you of it! END
BEGIN NOW Surely you must be mistaken. END
BEGIN NOW To give such intelligence to a person who could not be interested in it, even if it were true, is not what I should expect Colonel Brandon to do. END
BEGIN NOW But I do assure you it was so, for all that, and I will tell you how it happened. END
BEGIN NOW When we met him, he turned back and walked with us; and so we began talking of my brother and sister, and one thing and another, and I said to him, 'So, Colonel, there is a new family come to Barton cottage, I hear, and mama sends me word they are very pretty, and that one of them is going to be married to Mr. Willoughby of Combe Magna. END
BEGIN NOW Is it true, pray? END
BEGIN NOW for of course you must know, as you have been in Devonshire so lately.' END
BEGIN NOW And what did the Colonel say? END
BEGIN NOW Oh&mdash;he did not say much; but he looked as if he knew it to be true, so from that moment I set it down as certain. END
BEGIN NOW It will be quite delightful, I declare! END
BEGIN NOW When is it to take place? END
BEGIN NOW Mr. Brandon was very well I hope? END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW yes, quite well; and so full of your praises, he did nothing but say fine things of you. END
BEGIN NOW I am flattered by his commendation. END
BEGIN NOW He seems an excellent man; and I think him uncommonly pleasing. END
BEGIN NOW So do I.&mdash;He is such a charming man, that it is quite a pity he should be so grave and so dull. END
BEGIN NOW Mama says HE was in love with your sister too.&mdash; I assure you it was a great compliment if he was, for he hardly ever falls in love with any body. END
BEGIN NOW Is Mr. Willoughby much known in your part of Somersetshire? END
BEGIN NOW said Elinor. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW yes, extremely well; that is, I do not believe many people are acquainted with him, because Combe Magna is so far off; but they all think him extremely agreeable I assure you. END
BEGIN NOW Nobody is more liked than Mr. Willoughby wherever he goes, and so you may tell your sister. END
BEGIN NOW She is a monstrous lucky girl to get him, upon my honour; not but that he is much more lucky in getting her, because she is so very handsome and agreeable, that nothing can be good enough for her. END
BEGIN NOW However, I don't think her hardly at all handsomer than you, I assure you; for I think you both excessively pretty, and so does Mr. Palmer too I am sure, though we could not get him to own it last night. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Palmer's information respecting Willoughby was not very material; but any testimony in his favour, however small, was pleasing to her. END
BEGIN NOW I am so glad we are got acquainted at last, continued Charlotte.&mdash; And now I hope we shall always be great friends. END
BEGIN NOW You can't think how much I longed to see you! END
BEGIN NOW It is so delightful that you should live at the cottage! END
BEGIN NOW Nothing can be like it, to be sure! END
BEGIN NOW And I am so glad your sister is going to be well married! END
BEGIN NOW I hope you will be a great deal at Combe Magna. END
BEGIN NOW It is a sweet place, by all accounts. END
BEGIN NOW You have been long acquainted with Colonel Brandon, have not you? END
BEGIN NOW Yes, a great while; ever since my sister married.&mdash; He was a particular friend of Sir John's. END
BEGIN NOW I believe, she added in a low voice, he would have been very glad to have had me, if he could. END
BEGIN NOW Sir John and Lady Middleton wished it very much. END
BEGIN NOW But mama did not think the match good enough for me, otherwise Sir John would have mentioned it to the Colonel, and we should have been married immediately. END
BEGIN NOW Did not Colonel Brandon know of Sir John's proposal to your mother before it was made? END
BEGIN NOW Had he never owned his affection to yourself? END
BEGIN NOW Oh, no; but if mama had not objected to it, I dare say he would have liked it of all things. END
BEGIN NOW He had not seen me then above twice, for it was before I left school. END
BEGIN NOW However, I am much happier as I am. END
BEGIN NOW Mr. Palmer is the kind of man I like. END
BEGIN NOW The Palmers returned to Cleveland the next day, and the two families at Barton were again left to entertain each other. END
BEGIN NOW But this did not last long; Elinor had hardly got their last visitors out of her head, had hardly done wondering at Charlotte's being so happy without a cause, at Mr. Palmer's acting so simply, with good abilities, and at the strange unsuitableness which often existed between husband and wife, before Sir John's and Mrs. Jennings's active zeal in the cause of society, procured her some other new acquaintance to see and observe. END
BEGIN NOW In a morning's excursion to Exeter, they had met with two young ladies, whom Mrs. Jennings had the satisfaction of discovering to be her relations, and this was enough for Sir John to invite them directly to the park, as soon as their present engagements at Exeter were over. END
BEGIN NOW Their engagements at Exeter instantly gave way before such an invitation, and Lady Middleton was thrown into no little alarm on the return of Sir John, by hearing that she was very soon to receive a visit from two girls whom she had never seen in her life, and of whose elegance,&mdash;whose tolerable gentility even, she could have no proof; for the assurances of her husband and mother on that subject went for nothing at all. END
BEGIN NOW Their being her relations too made it so much the worse; and Mrs. Jennings's attempts at consolation were therefore unfortunately founded, when she advised her daughter not to care about their being so fashionable; because they were all cousins and must put up with one another. END
BEGIN NOW As it was impossible, however, now to prevent their coming, Lady Middleton resigned herself to the idea of it, with all the philosophy of a well-bred woman, contenting herself with merely giving her husband a gentle reprimand on the subject five or six times every day. END
BEGIN NOW The young ladies arrived: their appearance was by no means ungenteel or unfashionable. END
BEGIN NOW Their dress was very smart, their manners very civil, they were delighted with the house, and in raptures with the furniture, and they happened to be so doatingly fond of children that Lady Middleton's good opinion was engaged in their favour before they had been an hour at the Park. END
BEGIN NOW She declared them to be very agreeable girls indeed, which for her ladyship was enthusiastic admiration. END
BEGIN NOW Sir John's confidence in his own judgment rose with this animated praise, and he set off directly for the cottage to tell the Miss Dashwoods of the Miss Steeles' arrival, and to assure them of their being the sweetest girls in the world. END
BEGIN NOW From such commendation as this, however, there was not much to be learned; Elinor well knew that the sweetest girls in the world were to be met with in every part of England, under every possible variation of form, face, temper and understanding. END
BEGIN NOW Sir John wanted the whole family to walk to the Park directly and look at his guests. END
BEGIN NOW Benevolent, philanthropic man! END
BEGIN NOW It was painful to him even to keep a third cousin to himself. END
BEGIN NOW Do come now, said he&mdash; pray come&mdash;you must come&mdash;I declare you shall come&mdash;You can't think how you will like them. END
BEGIN NOW Lucy is monstrous pretty, and so good humoured and agreeable! END
BEGIN NOW The children are all hanging about her already, as if she was an old acquaintance. END
BEGIN NOW And they both long to see you of all things, for they have heard at Exeter that you are the most beautiful creatures in the world; and I have told them it is all very true, and a great deal more. END
BEGIN NOW You will be delighted with them I am sure. END
BEGIN NOW They have brought the whole coach full of playthings for the children. END
BEGIN NOW How can you be so cross as not to come? END
BEGIN NOW Why they are your cousins, you know, after a fashion. END
BEGIN NOW YOU are my cousins, and they are my wife's, so you must be related. END
BEGIN NOW But Sir John could not prevail. END
BEGIN NOW He could only obtain a promise of their calling at the Park within a day or two, and then left them in amazement at their indifference, to walk home and boast anew of their attractions to the Miss Steeles, as he had been already boasting of the Miss Steeles to them. END
BEGIN NOW When their promised visit to the Park and consequent introduction to these young ladies took place, they found in the appearance of the eldest, who was nearly thirty, with a very plain and not a sensible face, nothing to admire; but in the other, who was not more than two or three and twenty, they acknowledged considerable beauty; her features were pretty, and she had a sharp quick eye, and a smartness of air, which though it did not give actual elegance or grace, gave distinction to her person.&mdash; Their manners were particularly civil, and Elinor soon allowed them credit for some kind of sense, when she saw with what constant and judicious attention they were making themselves agreeable to Lady Middleton. END
BEGIN NOW With her children they were in continual raptures, extolling their beauty, courting their notice, and humouring their whims; and such of their time as could be spared from the importunate demands which this politeness made on it, was spent in admiration of whatever her ladyship was doing, if she happened to be doing any thing, or in taking patterns of some elegant new dress, in which her appearance the day before had thrown them into unceasing delight. END
BEGIN NOW Fortunately for those who pay their court through such foibles, a fond mother, though, in pursuit of praise for her children, the most rapacious of human beings, is likewise the most credulous; her demands are exorbitant; but she will swallow any thing; and the excessive affection and endurance of the Miss Steeles towards her offspring were viewed therefore by Lady Middleton without the smallest surprise or distrust. END
BEGIN NOW She saw with maternal complacency all the impertinent encroachments and mischievous tricks to which her cousins submitted. END
BEGIN NOW She saw their sashes untied, their hair pulled about their ears, their work-bags searched, and their knives and scissors stolen away, and felt no doubt of its being a reciprocal enjoyment. END
BEGIN NOW It suggested no other surprise than that Elinor and Marianne should sit so composedly by, without claiming a share in what was passing. END
BEGIN NOW John is in such spirits today! END
BEGIN NOW said she, on his taking Miss Steeles's pocket handkerchief, and throwing it out of window&mdash; He is full of monkey tricks. END
BEGIN NOW And soon afterwards, on the second boy's violently pinching one of the same lady's fingers, she fondly observed, How playful William is! END
BEGIN NOW And here is my sweet little Annamaria, she added, tenderly caressing a little girl of three years old, who had not made a noise for the last two minutes; And she is always so gentle and quiet&mdash;Never was there such a quiet little thing! END
BEGIN NOW But unfortunately in bestowing these embraces, a pin in her ladyship's head dress slightly scratching the child's neck, produced from this pattern of gentleness such violent screams, as could hardly be outdone by any creature professedly noisy. END
BEGIN NOW The mother's consternation was excessive; but it could not surpass the alarm of the Miss Steeles, and every thing was done by all three, in so critical an emergency, which affection could suggest as likely to assuage the agonies of the little sufferer. END
BEGIN NOW She was seated in her mother's lap, covered with kisses, her wound bathed with lavender-water, by one of the Miss Steeles, who was on her knees to attend her, and her mouth stuffed with sugar plums by the other. END
BEGIN NOW With such a reward for her tears, the child was too wise to cease crying. END
BEGIN NOW She still screamed and sobbed lustily, kicked her two brothers for offering to touch her, and all their united soothings were ineffectual till Lady Middleton luckily remembering that in a scene of similar distress last week, some apricot marmalade had been successfully applied for a bruised temple, the same remedy was eagerly proposed for this unfortunate scratch, and a slight intermission of screams in the young lady on hearing it, gave them reason to hope that it would not be rejected.&mdash; She was carried out of the room therefore in her mother's arms, in quest of this medicine, and as the two boys chose to follow, though earnestly entreated by their mother to stay behind, the four young ladies were left in a quietness which the room had not known for many hours. END
BEGIN NOW Poor little creatures! END
BEGIN NOW said Miss Steele, as soon as they were gone. END
BEGIN NOW It might have been a very sad accident. END
BEGIN NOW Yet I hardly know how, cried Marianne, unless it had been under totally different circumstances. END
BEGIN NOW But this is the usual way of heightening alarm, where there is nothing to be alarmed at in reality. END
BEGIN NOW What a sweet woman Lady Middleton is! END
BEGIN NOW said Lucy Steele. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne was silent; it was impossible for her to say what she did not feel, however trivial the occasion; and upon Elinor therefore the whole task of telling lies when politeness required it, always fell. END
BEGIN NOW She did her best when thus called on, by speaking of Lady Middleton with more warmth than she felt, though with far less than Miss Lucy. END
BEGIN NOW And Sir John too, cried the elder sister, what a charming man he is! END
BEGIN NOW Here too, Miss Dashwood's commendation, being only simple and just, came in without any eclat. END
BEGIN NOW She merely observed that he was perfectly good humoured and friendly. END
BEGIN NOW And what a charming little family they have! END
BEGIN NOW I never saw such fine children in my life.&mdash;I declare I quite doat upon them already, and indeed I am always distractedly fond of children. END
BEGIN NOW I should guess so, said Elinor, with a smile, from what I have witnessed this morning. END
BEGIN NOW I have a notion, said Lucy, you think the little Middletons rather too much indulged; perhaps they may be the outside of enough; but it is so natural in Lady Middleton; and for my part, I love to see children full of life and spirits; I cannot bear them if they are tame and quiet. END
BEGIN NOW I confess, replied Elinor, that while I am at Barton Park, I never think of tame and quiet children with any abhorrence. END
BEGIN NOW A short pause succeeded this speech, which was first broken by Miss Steele, who seemed very much disposed for conversation, and who now said rather abruptly, And how do you like Devonshire, Miss Dashwood? END
BEGIN NOW I suppose you were very sorry to leave Sussex. END
BEGIN NOW In some surprise at the familiarity of this question, or at least of the manner in which it was spoken, Elinor replied that she was. END
BEGIN NOW Norland is a prodigious beautiful place, is not it? END
BEGIN NOW added Miss Steele. END
BEGIN NOW We have heard Sir John admire it excessively, said Lucy, who seemed to think some apology necessary for the freedom of her sister. END
BEGIN NOW I think every one MUST admire it, replied Elinor, who ever saw the place; though it is not to be supposed that any one can estimate its beauties as we do. END
BEGIN NOW And had you a great many smart beaux there? END
BEGIN NOW I suppose you have not so many in this part of the world; for my part, I think they are a vast addition always. END
