BEGIN NOW Whatever the truth of it might be, and far as Elinor was from feeling thorough contentment about it, yet while she saw Marianne in spirits, she could not be very uncomfortable herself. END
BEGIN NOW And Marianne was in spirits; happy in the mildness of the weather, and still happier in her expectation of a frost. END
BEGIN NOW The morning was chiefly spent in leaving cards at the houses of Mrs. Jennings's acquaintance to inform them of her being in town; and Marianne was all the time busy in observing the direction of the wind, watching the variations of the sky and imagining an alteration in the air. END
BEGIN NOW Don't you find it colder than it was in the morning, Elinor? END
BEGIN NOW There seems to me a very decided difference. END
BEGIN NOW I can hardly keep my hands warm even in my muff. END
BEGIN NOW It was not so yesterday, I think. END
BEGIN NOW The clouds seem parting too, the sun will be out in a moment, and we shall have a clear afternoon. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor was alternately diverted and pained; but Marianne persevered, and saw every night in the brightness of the fire, and every morning in the appearance of the atmosphere, the certain symptoms of approaching frost. END
BEGIN NOW The Miss Dashwoods had no greater reason to be dissatisfied with Mrs. Jennings's style of living, and set of acquaintance, than with her behaviour to themselves, which was invariably kind. END
BEGIN NOW Every thing in her household arrangements was conducted on the most liberal plan, and excepting a few old city friends, whom, to Lady Middleton's regret, she had never dropped, she visited no one to whom an introduction could at all discompose the feelings of her young companions. END
BEGIN NOW Pleased to find herself more comfortably situated in that particular than she had expected, Elinor was very willing to compound for the want of much real enjoyment from any of their evening parties, which, whether at home or abroad, formed only for cards, could have little to amuse her. END
BEGIN NOW Colonel Brandon, who had a general invitation to the house, was with them almost every day; he came to look at Marianne and talk to Elinor, who often derived more satisfaction from conversing with him than from any other daily occurrence, but who saw at the same time with much concern his continued regard for her sister. END
BEGIN NOW She feared it was a strengthening regard. END
BEGIN NOW It grieved her to see the earnestness with which he often watched Marianne, and his spirits were certainly worse than when at Barton. END
BEGIN NOW About a week after their arrival, it became certain that Willoughby was also arrived. END
BEGIN NOW His card was on the table when they came in from the morning's drive. END
BEGIN NOW Good God! END
BEGIN NOW cried Marianne, he has been here while we were out. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor, rejoiced to be assured of his being in London, now ventured to say, Depend upon it, he will call again tomorrow. END
BEGIN NOW But Marianne seemed hardly to hear her, and on Mrs. Jennings's entrance, escaped with the precious card. END
BEGIN NOW This event, while it raised the spirits of Elinor, restored to those of her sister all, and more than all, their former agitation. END
BEGIN NOW From this moment her mind was never quiet; the expectation of seeing him every hour of the day, made her unfit for any thing. END
BEGIN NOW She insisted on being left behind, the next morning, when the others went out. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor's thoughts were full of what might be passing in Berkeley Street during their absence; but a moment's glance at her sister when they returned was enough to inform her, that Willoughby had paid no second visit there. END
BEGIN NOW A note was just then brought in, and laid on the table. END
BEGIN NOW For me! END
BEGIN NOW cried Marianne, stepping hastily forward. END
BEGIN NOW No, ma'am, for my mistress. END
BEGIN NOW But Marianne, not convinced, took it instantly up. END
BEGIN NOW It is indeed for Mrs. Jennings; how provoking! END
BEGIN NOW You are expecting a letter, then? END
BEGIN NOW said Elinor, unable to be longer silent. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, a little&mdash;not much. END
BEGIN NOW After a short pause. END
BEGIN NOW You have no confidence in me, Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW Nay, Elinor, this reproach from YOU&mdash;you who have confidence in no one! END
BEGIN NOW Me! END
BEGIN NOW returned Elinor in some confusion; indeed, Marianne, I have nothing to tell. END
BEGIN NOW Nor I, answered Marianne with energy, our situations then are alike. END
BEGIN NOW We have neither of us any thing to tell; you, because you do not communicate, and I, because I conceal nothing. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor, distressed by this charge of reserve in herself, which she was not at liberty to do away, knew not how, under such circumstances, to press for greater openness in Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings soon appeared, and the note being given her, she read it aloud. END
BEGIN NOW It was from Lady Middleton, announcing their arrival in Conduit Street the night before, and requesting the company of her mother and cousins the following evening. END
BEGIN NOW Business on Sir John's part, and a violent cold on her own, prevented their calling in Berkeley Street. END
BEGIN NOW The invitation was accepted; but when the hour of appointment drew near, necessary as it was in common civility to Mrs. Jennings, that they should both attend her on such a visit, Elinor had some difficulty in persuading her sister to go, for still she had seen nothing of Willoughby; and therefore was not more indisposed for amusement abroad, than unwilling to run the risk of his calling again in her absence. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor found, when the evening was over, that disposition is not materially altered by a change of abode, for although scarcely settled in town, Sir John had contrived to collect around him, nearly twenty young people, and to amuse them with a ball. END
BEGIN NOW This was an affair, however, of which Lady Middleton did not approve. END
BEGIN NOW In the country, an unpremeditated dance was very allowable; but in London, where the reputation of elegance was more important and less easily attained, it was risking too much for the gratification of a few girls, to have it known that Lady Middleton had given a small dance of eight or nine couple, with two violins, and a mere side-board collation. END
BEGIN NOW Mr. and Mrs. Palmer were of the party; from the former, whom they had not seen before since their arrival in town, as he was careful to avoid the appearance of any attention to his mother-in-law, and therefore never came near her, they received no mark of recognition on their entrance. END
BEGIN NOW He looked at them slightly, without seeming to know who they were, and merely nodded to Mrs. Jennings from the other side of the room. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne gave one glance round the apartment as she entered: it was enough&mdash;HE was not there&mdash;and she sat down, equally ill-disposed to receive or communicate pleasure. END
BEGIN NOW After they had been assembled about an hour, Mr. Palmer sauntered towards the Miss Dashwoods to express his surprise on seeing them in town, though Colonel Brandon had been first informed of their arrival at his house, and he had himself said something very droll on hearing that they were to come. END
BEGIN NOW I thought you were both in Devonshire, said he. END
BEGIN NOW Did you? END
BEGIN NOW replied Elinor. END
BEGIN NOW When do you go back again? END
BEGIN NOW I do not know. END
BEGIN NOW And thus ended their discourse. END
BEGIN NOW Never had Marianne been so unwilling to dance in her life, as she was that evening, and never so much fatigued by the exercise. END
BEGIN NOW She complained of it as they returned to Berkeley Street. END
BEGIN NOW Aye, aye, said Mrs. Jennings, we know the reason of all that very well; if a certain person who shall be nameless, had been there, you would not have been a bit tired: and to say the truth it was not very pretty of him not to give you the meeting when he was invited. END
BEGIN NOW Invited! END
BEGIN NOW cried Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW So my daughter Middleton told me, for it seems Sir John met him somewhere in the street this morning. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne said no more, but looked exceedingly hurt. END
BEGIN NOW Impatient in this situation to be doing something that might lead to her sister's relief, Elinor resolved to write the next morning to her mother, and hoped by awakening her fears for the health of Marianne, to procure those inquiries which had been so long delayed; and she was still more eagerly bent on this measure by perceiving after breakfast on the morrow, that Marianne was again writing to Willoughby, for she could not suppose it to be to any other person. END
BEGIN NOW About the middle of the day, Mrs. Jennings went out by herself on business, and Elinor began her letter directly, while Marianne, too restless for employment, too anxious for conversation, walked from one window to the other, or sat down by the fire in melancholy meditation. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor was very earnest in her application to her mother, relating all that had passed, her suspicions of Willoughby's inconstancy, urging her by every plea of duty and affection to demand from Marianne an account of her real situation with respect to him. END
BEGIN NOW Her letter was scarcely finished, when a rap foretold a visitor, and Colonel Brandon was announced. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne, who had seen him from the window, and who hated company of any kind, left the room before he entered it. END
BEGIN NOW He looked more than usually grave, and though expressing satisfaction at finding Miss Dashwood alone, as if he had somewhat in particular to tell her, sat for some time without saying a word. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor, persuaded that he had some communication to make in which her sister was concerned, impatiently expected its opening. END
BEGIN NOW It was not the first time of her feeling the same kind of conviction; for, more than once before, beginning with the observation of your sister looks unwell to-day, or your sister seems out of spirits, he had appeared on the point, either of disclosing, or of inquiring, something particular about her. END
BEGIN NOW After a pause of several minutes, their silence was broken, by his asking her in a voice of some agitation, when he was to congratulate her on the acquisition of a brother? END
BEGIN NOW Elinor was not prepared for such a question, and having no answer ready, was obliged to adopt the simple and common expedient, of asking what he meant? END
BEGIN NOW He tried to smile as he replied, your sister's engagement to Mr. Willoughby is very generally known. END
BEGIN NOW It cannot be generally known, returned Elinor, for her own family do not know it. END
BEGIN NOW He looked surprised and said, I beg your pardon, I am afraid my inquiry has been impertinent; but I had not supposed any secrecy intended, as they openly correspond, and their marriage is universally talked of. END
BEGIN NOW How can that be? END
BEGIN NOW By whom can you have heard it mentioned? END
BEGIN NOW By many&mdash;by some of whom you know nothing, by others with whom you are most intimate, Mrs. Jennings, Mrs. Palmer, and the Middletons. END
BEGIN NOW But still I might not have believed it, for where the mind is perhaps rather unwilling to be convinced, it will always find something to support its doubts, if I had not, when the servant let me in today, accidentally seen a letter in his hand, directed to Mr. Willoughby in your sister's writing. END
BEGIN NOW I came to inquire, but I was convinced before I could ask the question. END
BEGIN NOW Is every thing finally settled? END
BEGIN NOW Is it impossible to-? END
BEGIN NOW But I have no right, and I could have no chance of succeeding. END
BEGIN NOW Excuse me, Miss Dashwood. END
BEGIN NOW I believe I have been wrong in saying so much, but I hardly know what to do, and on your prudence I have the strongest dependence. END
BEGIN NOW Tell me that it is all absolutely resolved on, that any attempt, that in short concealment, if concealment be possible, is all that remains. END
BEGIN NOW These words, which conveyed to Elinor a direct avowal of his love for her sister, affected her very much. END
BEGIN NOW She was not immediately able to say anything, and even when her spirits were recovered, she debated for a short time, on the answer it would be most proper to give. END
BEGIN NOW The real state of things between Willoughby and her sister was so little known to herself, that in endeavouring to explain it, she might be as liable to say too much as too little. END
BEGIN NOW Yet as she was convinced that Marianne's affection for Willoughby, could leave no hope of Colonel Brandon's success, whatever the event of that affection might be, and at the same time wished to shield her conduct from censure, she thought it most prudent and kind, after some consideration, to say more than she really knew or believed. END
BEGIN NOW She acknowledged, therefore, that though she had never been informed by themselves of the terms on which they stood with each other, of their mutual affection she had no doubt, and of their correspondence she was not astonished to hear. END
BEGIN NOW He listened to her with silent attention, and on her ceasing to speak, rose directly from his seat, and after saying in a voice of emotion, to your sister I wish all imaginable happiness; to Willoughby that he may endeavour to deserve her, &mdash;took leave, and went away. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor derived no comfortable feelings from this conversation, to lessen the uneasiness of her mind on other points; she was left, on the contrary, with a melancholy impression of Colonel Brandon's unhappiness, and was prevented even from wishing it removed, by her anxiety for the very event that must confirm it. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing occurred during the next three or four days, to make Elinor regret what she had done, in applying to her mother; for Willoughby neither came nor wrote. END
BEGIN NOW They were engaged about the end of that time to attend Lady Middleton to a party, from which Mrs. Jennings was kept away by the indisposition of her youngest daughter; and for this party, Marianne, wholly dispirited, careless of her appearance, and seeming equally indifferent whether she went or staid, prepared, without one look of hope or one expression of pleasure. END
BEGIN NOW She sat by the drawing-room fire after tea, till the moment of Lady Middleton's arrival, without once stirring from her seat, or altering her attitude, lost in her own thoughts, and insensible of her sister's presence; and when at last they were told that Lady Middleton waited for them at the door, she started as if she had forgotten that any one was expected. END
BEGIN NOW They arrived in due time at the place of destination, and as soon as the string of carriages before them would allow, alighted, ascended the stairs, heard their names announced from one landing-place to another in an audible voice, and entered a room splendidly lit up, quite full of company, and insufferably hot. END
BEGIN NOW When they had paid their tribute of politeness by curtsying to the lady of the house, they were permitted to mingle in the crowd, and take their share of the heat and inconvenience, to which their arrival must necessarily add. END
BEGIN NOW After some time spent in saying little or doing less, Lady Middleton sat down to Cassino, and as Marianne was not in spirits for moving about, she and Elinor luckily succeeding to chairs, placed themselves at no great distance from the table. END
BEGIN NOW They had not remained in this manner long, before Elinor perceived Willoughby, standing within a few yards of them, in earnest conversation with a very fashionable looking young woman. END
BEGIN NOW She soon caught his eye, and he immediately bowed, but without attempting to speak to her, or to approach Marianne, though he could not but see her; and then continued his discourse with the same lady. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor turned involuntarily to Marianne, to see whether it could be unobserved by her. END
BEGIN NOW At that moment she first perceived him, and her whole countenance glowing with sudden delight, she would have moved towards him instantly, had not her sister caught hold of her. END
BEGIN NOW Good heavens! END
BEGIN NOW she exclaimed, he is there&mdash;he is there&mdash;Oh! END
BEGIN NOW why does he not look at me? END
BEGIN NOW why cannot I speak to him? END
BEGIN NOW Pray, pray be composed, cried Elinor, and do not betray what you feel to every body present. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps he has not observed you yet. END
BEGIN NOW This however was more than she could believe herself; and to be composed at such a moment was not only beyond the reach of Marianne, it was beyond her wish. END
BEGIN NOW She sat in an agony of impatience which affected every feature. END
BEGIN NOW At last he turned round again, and regarded them both; she started up, and pronouncing his name in a tone of affection, held out her hand to him. END
BEGIN NOW He approached, and addressing himself rather to Elinor than Marianne, as if wishing to avoid her eye, and determined not to observe her attitude, inquired in a hurried manner after Mrs. Dashwood, and asked how long they had been in town. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor was robbed of all presence of mind by such an address, and was unable to say a word. END
BEGIN NOW But the feelings of her sister were instantly expressed. END
BEGIN NOW Her face was crimsoned over, and she exclaimed, in a voice of the greatest emotion, Good God! END
BEGIN NOW Willoughby, what is the meaning of this? END
BEGIN NOW Have you not received my letters? END
BEGIN NOW Will you not shake hands with me? END
BEGIN NOW He could not then avoid it, but her touch seemed painful to him, and he held her hand only for a moment. END
BEGIN NOW During all this time he was evidently struggling for composure. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor watched his countenance and saw its expression becoming more tranquil. END
BEGIN NOW After a moment's pause, he spoke with calmness. END
BEGIN NOW I did myself the honour of calling in Berkeley Street last Tuesday, and very much regretted that I was not fortunate enough to find yourselves and Mrs. Jennings at home. END
BEGIN NOW My card was not lost, I hope. END
BEGIN NOW But have you not received my notes? END
BEGIN NOW cried Marianne in the wildest anxiety. END
BEGIN NOW Here is some mistake I am sure&mdash;some dreadful mistake. END
BEGIN NOW What can be the meaning of it? END
BEGIN NOW Tell me, Willoughby; for heaven's sake tell me, what is the matter? END
BEGIN NOW He made no reply; his complexion changed and all his embarrassment returned; but as if, on catching the eye of the young lady with whom he had been previously talking, he felt the necessity of instant exertion, he recovered himself again, and after saying, Yes, I had the pleasure of receiving the information of your arrival in town, which you were so good as to send me, turned hastily away with a slight bow and joined his friend. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne, now looking dreadfully white, and unable to stand, sunk into her chair, and Elinor, expecting every moment to see her faint, tried to screen her from the observation of others, while reviving her with lavender water. END
BEGIN NOW Go to him, Elinor, she cried, as soon as she could speak, and force him to come to me. END
BEGIN NOW Tell him I must see him again&mdash;must speak to him instantly.&mdash; I cannot rest&mdash;I shall not have a moment's peace till this is explained&mdash;some dreadful misapprehension or other.&mdash; Oh go to him this moment. END
BEGIN NOW How can that be done? END
BEGIN NOW No, my dearest Marianne, you must wait. END
BEGIN NOW This is not the place for explanations. END
BEGIN NOW Wait only till tomorrow. END
BEGIN NOW With difficulty however could she prevent her from following him herself; and to persuade her to check her agitation, to wait, at least, with the appearance of composure, till she might speak to him with more privacy and more effect, was impossible; for Marianne continued incessantly to give way in a low voice to the misery of her feelings, by exclamations of wretchedness. END
BEGIN NOW In a short time Elinor saw Willoughby quit the room by the door towards the staircase, and telling Marianne that he was gone, urged the impossibility of speaking to him again that evening, as a fresh argument for her to be calm. END
BEGIN NOW She instantly begged her sister would entreat Lady Middleton to take them home, as she was too miserable to stay a minute longer. END
BEGIN NOW Lady Middleton, though in the middle of a rubber, on being informed that Marianne was unwell, was too polite to object for a moment to her wish of going away, and making over her cards to a friend, they departed as soon the carriage could be found. END
BEGIN NOW Scarcely a word was spoken during their return to Berkeley Street. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne was in a silent agony, too much oppressed even for tears; but as Mrs. Jennings was luckily not come home, they could go directly to their own room, where hartshorn restored her a little to herself. END
BEGIN NOW She was soon undressed and in bed, and as she seemed desirous of being alone, her sister then left her, and while she waited the return of Mrs. Jennings, had leisure enough for thinking over the past. END
BEGIN NOW That some kind of engagement had subsisted between Willoughby and Marianne she could not doubt, and that Willoughby was weary of it, seemed equally clear; for however Marianne might still feed her own wishes, SHE could not attribute such behaviour to mistake or misapprehension of any kind. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing but a thorough change of sentiment could account for it. END
BEGIN NOW Her indignation would have been still stronger than it was, had she not witnessed that embarrassment which seemed to speak a consciousness of his own misconduct, and prevented her from believing him so unprincipled as to have been sporting with the affections of her sister from the first, without any design that would bear investigation. END
BEGIN NOW Absence might have weakened his regard, and convenience might have determined him to overcome it, but that such a regard had formerly existed she could not bring herself to doubt. END
BEGIN NOW As for Marianne, on the pangs which so unhappy a meeting must already have given her, and on those still more severe which might await her in its probable consequence, she could not reflect without the deepest concern. END
BEGIN NOW Her own situation gained in the comparison; for while she could ESTEEM Edward as much as ever, however they might be divided in future, her mind might be always supported. END
BEGIN NOW But every circumstance that could embitter such an evil seemed uniting to heighten the misery of Marianne in a final separation from Willoughby&mdash;in an immediate and irreconcilable rupture with him. END
BEGIN NOW Before the house-maid had lit their fire the next day, or the sun gained any power over a cold, gloomy morning in January, Marianne, only half dressed, was kneeling against one of the window-seats for the sake of all the little light she could command from it, and writing as fast as a continual flow of tears would permit her. END
BEGIN NOW In this situation, Elinor, roused from sleep by her agitation and sobs, first perceived her; and after observing her for a few moments with silent anxiety, said, in a tone of the most considerate gentleness, Marianne, may I ask-? END
BEGIN NOW No, Elinor, she replied, ask nothing; you will soon know all. END
BEGIN NOW The sort of desperate calmness with which this was said, lasted no longer than while she spoke, and was immediately followed by a return of the same excessive affliction. END
BEGIN NOW It was some minutes before she could go on with her letter, and the frequent bursts of grief which still obliged her, at intervals, to withhold her pen, were proofs enough of her feeling how more than probable it was that she was writing for the last time to Willoughby. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor paid her every quiet and unobtrusive attention in her power; and she would have tried to sooth and tranquilize her still more, had not Marianne entreated her, with all the eagerness of the most nervous irritability, not to speak to her for the world. END
BEGIN NOW In such circumstances, it was better for both that they should not be long together; and the restless state of Marianne's mind not only prevented her from remaining in the room a moment after she was dressed, but requiring at once solitude and continual change of place, made her wander about the house till breakfast time, avoiding the sight of every body. END
BEGIN NOW At breakfast she neither ate, nor attempted to eat any thing; and Elinor's attention was then all employed, not in urging her, not in pitying her, nor in appearing to regard her, but in endeavouring to engage Mrs. Jennings's notice entirely to herself. END
BEGIN NOW As this was a favourite meal with Mrs. Jennings, it lasted a considerable time, and they were just setting themselves, after it, round the common working table, when a letter was delivered to Marianne, which she eagerly caught from the servant, and, turning of a death-like paleness, instantly ran out of the room. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor, who saw as plainly by this, as if she had seen the direction, that it must come from Willoughby, felt immediately such a sickness at heart as made her hardly able to hold up her head, and sat in such a general tremour as made her fear it impossible to escape Mrs. Jennings's notice. END
BEGIN NOW That good lady, however, saw only that Marianne had received a letter from Willoughby, which appeared to her a very good joke, and which she treated accordingly, by hoping, with a laugh, that she would find it to her liking. END
BEGIN NOW Of Elinor's distress, she was too busily employed in measuring lengths of worsted for her rug, to see any thing at all; and calmly continuing her talk, as soon as Marianne disappeared, she said, Upon my word, I never saw a young woman so desperately in love in my life! END
BEGIN NOW MY girls were nothing to her, and yet they used to be foolish enough; but as for Miss Marianne, she is quite an altered creature. END
BEGIN NOW I hope, from the bottom of my heart, he won't keep her waiting much longer, for it is quite grievous to see her look so ill and forlorn. END
BEGIN NOW Pray, when are they to be married? END
BEGIN NOW Elinor, though never less disposed to speak than at that moment, obliged herself to answer such an attack as this, and, therefore, trying to smile, replied, And have you really, Ma'am, talked yourself into a persuasion of my sister's being engaged to Mr. Willoughby? END
BEGIN NOW I thought it had been only a joke, but so serious a question seems to imply more; and I must beg, therefore, that you will not deceive yourself any longer. END
BEGIN NOW I do assure you that nothing would surprise me more than to hear of their being going to be married. END
BEGIN NOW For shame, for shame, Miss Dashwood! END
BEGIN NOW how can you talk so? END
BEGIN NOW Don't we all know that it must be a match, that they were over head and ears in love with each other from the first moment they met? END
BEGIN NOW Did not I see them together in Devonshire every day, and all day long; and did not I know that your sister came to town with me on purpose to buy wedding clothes? END
BEGIN NOW Come, come, this won't do. END
BEGIN NOW Because you are so sly about it yourself, you think nobody else has any senses; but it is no such thing, I can tell you, for it has been known all over town this ever so long. END
BEGIN NOW I tell every body of it and so does Charlotte. END
BEGIN NOW Indeed, Ma'am, said Elinor, very seriously, you are mistaken. END
BEGIN NOW Indeed, you are doing a very unkind thing in spreading the report, and you will find that you have though you will not believe me now. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings laughed again, but Elinor had not spirits to say more, and eager at all events to know what Willoughby had written, hurried away to their room, where, on opening the door, she saw Marianne stretched on the bed, almost choked by grief, one letter in her hand, and two or three others laying by her. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor drew near, but without saying a word; and seating herself on the bed, took her hand, kissed her affectionately several times, and then gave way to a burst of tears, which at first was scarcely less violent than Marianne's. END
BEGIN NOW The latter, though unable to speak, seemed to feel all the tenderness of this behaviour, and after some time thus spent in joint affliction, she put all the letters into Elinor's hands; and then covering her face with her handkerchief, almost screamed with agony. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor, who knew that such grief, shocking as it was to witness it, must have its course, watched by her till this excess of suffering had somewhat spent itself, and then turning eagerly to Willoughby's letter, read as follows: Bond Street, January. END
BEGIN NOW MY DEAR MADAM, I have just had the honour of receiving your letter, for which I beg to return my sincere acknowledgments. END
BEGIN NOW I am much concerned to find there was anything in my behaviour last night that did not meet your approbation; and though I am quite at a loss to discover in what point I could be so unfortunate as to offend you, I entreat your forgiveness of what I can assure you to have been perfectly unintentional. END
BEGIN NOW I shall never reflect on my former acquaintance with your family in Devonshire without the most grateful pleasure, and flatter myself it will not be broken by any mistake or misapprehension of my actions. END
BEGIN NOW My esteem for your whole family is very sincere; but if I have been so unfortunate as to give rise to a belief of more than I felt, or meant to express, I shall reproach myself for not having been more guarded in my professions of that esteem. END
BEGIN NOW That I should ever have meant more you will allow to be impossible, when you understand that my affections have been long engaged elsewhere, and it will not be many weeks, I believe, before this engagement is fulfilled. END
BEGIN NOW It is with great regret that I obey your commands in returning the letters with which I have been honoured from you, and the lock of hair, which you so obligingly bestowed on me. END
BEGIN NOW I am, dear Madam, Your most obedient humble servant, JOHN WILLOUGHBY. END
BEGIN NOW With what indignation such a letter as this must be read by Miss Dashwood, may be imagined. END
BEGIN NOW Though aware, before she began it, that it must bring a confession of his inconstancy, and confirm their separation for ever, she was not aware that such language could be suffered to announce it; nor could she have supposed Willoughby capable of departing so far from the appearance of every honourable and delicate feeling&mdash;so far from the common decorum of a gentleman, as to send a letter so impudently cruel: a letter which, instead of bringing with his desire of a release any professions of regret, acknowledged no breach of faith, denied all peculiar affection whatever&mdash;a letter of which every line was an insult, and which proclaimed its writer to be deep in hardened villainy. END
BEGIN NOW She paused over it for some time with indignant astonishment; then read it again and again; but every perusal only served to increase her abhorrence of the man, and so bitter were her feelings against him, that she dared not trust herself to speak, lest she might wound Marianne still deeper by treating their disengagement, not as a loss to her of any possible good but as an escape from the worst and most irremediable of all evils, a connection, for life, with an unprincipled man, as a deliverance the most real, a blessing the most important. END
BEGIN NOW In her earnest meditations on the contents of the letter, on the depravity of that mind which could dictate it, and probably, on the very different mind of a very different person, who had no other connection whatever with the affair than what her heart gave him with every thing that passed, Elinor forgot the immediate distress of her sister, forgot that she had three letters on her lap yet unread, and so entirely forgot how long she had been in the room, that when on hearing a carriage drive up to the door, she went to the window to see who could be coming so unreasonably early, she was all astonishment to perceive Mrs. Jennings's chariot, which she knew had not been ordered till one. END
BEGIN NOW Determined not to quit Marianne, though hopeless of contributing, at present, to her ease, she hurried away to excuse herself from attending Mrs. Jennings, on account of her sister being indisposed. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings, with a thoroughly good-humoured concern for its cause, admitted the excuse most readily, and Elinor, after seeing her safe off, returned to Marianne, whom she found attempting to rise from the bed, and whom she reached just in time to prevent her from falling on the floor, faint and giddy from a long want of proper rest and food; for it was many days since she had any appetite, and many nights since she had really slept; and now, when her mind was no longer supported by the fever of suspense, the consequence of all this was felt in an aching head, a weakened stomach, and a general nervous faintness. END
BEGIN NOW A glass of wine, which Elinor procured for her directly, made her more comfortable, and she was at last able to express some sense of her kindness, by saying, Poor Elinor! END
BEGIN NOW how unhappy I make you! END
BEGIN NOW I only wish, replied her sister, there were any thing I COULD do, which might be of comfort to you. END
BEGIN NOW This, as every thing else would have been, was too much for Marianne, who could only exclaim, in the anguish of her heart, Oh! END
BEGIN NOW Elinor, I am miserable, indeed, before her voice was entirely lost in sobs. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor could no longer witness this torrent of unresisted grief in silence. END
BEGIN NOW Exert yourself, dear Marianne, she cried, if you would not kill yourself and all who love you. END
BEGIN NOW Think of your mother; think of her misery while YOU suffer: for her sake you must exert yourself. END
BEGIN NOW I cannot, I cannot, cried Marianne; leave me, leave me, if I distress you; leave me, hate me, forget me! END
BEGIN NOW but do not torture me so. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW how easy for those, who have no sorrow of their own to talk of exertion! END
BEGIN NOW Happy, happy Elinor, YOU cannot have an idea of what I suffer. END
BEGIN NOW Do you call ME happy, Marianne? END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW if you knew!&mdash;And can you believe me to be so, while I see you so wretched! END
BEGIN NOW Forgive me, forgive me, throwing her arms round her sister's neck; I know you feel for me; I know what a heart you have; but yet you are&mdash;you must be happy; Edward loves you&mdash;what, oh what, can do away such happiness as that? END
BEGIN NOW Many, many circumstances, said Elinor, solemnly. END
BEGIN NOW No, no, no, cried Marianne wildly, he loves you, and only you. END
BEGIN NOW You CAN have no grief. END
BEGIN NOW I can have no pleasure while I see you in this state. END
BEGIN NOW And you will never see me otherwise. END
BEGIN NOW Mine is a misery which nothing can do away. END
BEGIN NOW You must not talk so, Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW Have you no comforts? END
BEGIN NOW no friends? END
BEGIN NOW Is your loss such as leaves no opening for consolation? END
BEGIN NOW Much as you suffer now, think of what you would have suffered if the discovery of his character had been delayed to a later period&mdash;if your engagement had been carried on for months and months, as it might have been, before he chose to put an end to it. END
BEGIN NOW Every additional day of unhappy confidence, on your side, would have made the blow more dreadful. END
BEGIN NOW Engagement! END
BEGIN NOW cried Marianne, there has been no engagement. END
BEGIN NOW No engagement! END
BEGIN NOW No, he is not so unworthy as you believe him. END
BEGIN NOW He has broken no faith with me. END
BEGIN NOW But he told you that he loved you. END
BEGIN NOW Yes&mdash;no&mdash;never absolutely. END
BEGIN NOW It was every day implied, but never professedly declared. END
BEGIN NOW Sometimes I thought it had been&mdash;but it never was. END
BEGIN NOW Yet you wrote to him? END
BEGIN NOW &mdash; Yes&mdash;could that be wrong after all that had passed?&mdash; But I cannot talk. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor said no more, and turning again to the three letters which now raised a much stronger curiosity than before, directly ran over the contents of all. END
BEGIN NOW The first, which was what her sister had sent him on their arrival in town, was to this effect. END
BEGIN NOW Berkeley Street, January. END
BEGIN NOW How surprised you will be, Willoughby, on receiving this; and I think you will feel something more than surprise, when you know that I am in town. END
BEGIN NOW An opportunity of coming hither, though with Mrs. Jennings, was a temptation we could not resist. END
BEGIN NOW I wish you may receive this in time to come here to-night, but I will not depend on it. END
BEGIN NOW At any rate I shall expect you to-morrow. END
BEGIN NOW For the present, adieu. END
BEGIN NOW M.D. END
BEGIN NOW Her second note, which had been written on the morning after the dance at the Middletons', was in these words:&mdash; I cannot express my disappointment in having missed you the day before yesterday, nor my astonishment at not having received any answer to a note which I sent you above a week ago. END
BEGIN NOW I have been expecting to hear from you, and still more to see you, every hour of the day. END
BEGIN NOW Pray call again as soon as possible, and explain the reason of my having expected this in vain. END
BEGIN NOW You had better come earlier another time, because we are generally out by one. END
BEGIN NOW We were last night at Lady Middleton's, where there was a dance. END
BEGIN NOW I have been told that you were asked to be of the party. END
BEGIN NOW But could it be so? END
BEGIN NOW You must be very much altered indeed since we parted, if that could be the case, and you not there. END
BEGIN NOW But I will not suppose this possible, and I hope very soon to receive your personal assurance of its being otherwise. END
BEGIN NOW M.D. END
BEGIN NOW The contents of her last note to him were these:&mdash; What am I to imagine, Willoughby, by your behaviour last night? END
BEGIN NOW Again I demand an explanation of it. END
BEGIN NOW I was prepared to meet you with the pleasure which our separation naturally produced, with the familiarity which our intimacy at Barton appeared to me to justify. END
BEGIN NOW I was repulsed indeed! END
BEGIN NOW I have passed a wretched night in endeavouring to excuse a conduct which can scarcely be called less than insulting; but though I have not yet been able to form any reasonable apology for your behaviour, I am perfectly ready to hear your justification of it. END
BEGIN NOW You have perhaps been misinformed, or purposely deceived, in something concerning me, which may have lowered me in your opinion. END
BEGIN NOW Tell me what it is, explain the grounds on which you acted, and I shall be satisfied, in being able to satisfy you. END
BEGIN NOW It would grieve me indeed to be obliged to think ill of you; but if I am to do it, if I am to learn that you are not what we have hitherto believed you, that your regard for us all was insincere, that your behaviour to me was intended only to deceive, let it be told as soon as possible. END
BEGIN NOW My feelings are at present in a state of dreadful indecision; I wish to acquit you, but certainty on either side will be ease to what I now suffer. END
BEGIN NOW If your sentiments are no longer what they were, you will return my notes, and the lock of my hair which is in your possession. END
BEGIN NOW M.D. END
BEGIN NOW That such letters, so full of affection and confidence, could have been so answered, Elinor, for Willoughby's sake, would have been unwilling to believe. END
BEGIN NOW But her condemnation of him did not blind her to the impropriety of their having been written at all; and she was silently grieving over the imprudence which had hazarded such unsolicited proofs of tenderness, not warranted by anything preceding, and most severely condemned by the event, when Marianne, perceiving that she had finished the letters, observed to her that they contained nothing but what any one would have written in the same situation. END
BEGIN NOW I felt myself, she added, to be as solemnly engaged to him, as if the strictest legal covenant had bound us to each other. END
BEGIN NOW I can believe it, said Elinor; but unfortunately he did not feel the same. END
BEGIN NOW He DID feel the same, Elinor&mdash;for weeks and weeks he felt it. END
BEGIN NOW I know he did. END
BEGIN NOW Whatever may have changed him now, (and nothing but the blackest art employed against me can have done it), I was once as dear to him as my own soul could wish. END
BEGIN NOW This lock of hair, which now he can so readily give up, was begged of me with the most earnest supplication. END
BEGIN NOW Had you seen his look, his manner, had you heard his voice at that moment! END
BEGIN NOW Have you forgot the last evening of our being together at Barton? END
BEGIN NOW The morning that we parted too! END
BEGIN NOW When he told me that it might be many weeks before we met again&mdash;his distress&mdash;can I ever forget his distress? END
BEGIN NOW For a moment or two she could say no more; but when this emotion had passed away, she added, in a firmer tone, Elinor, I have been cruelly used; but not by Willoughby. END
BEGIN NOW Dearest Marianne, who but himself? END
BEGIN NOW By whom can he have been instigated? END
BEGIN NOW By all the world, rather than by his own heart. END
BEGIN NOW I could rather believe every creature of my acquaintance leagued together to ruin me in his opinion, than believe his nature capable of such cruelty. END
BEGIN NOW This woman of whom he writes&mdash;whoever she be&mdash;or any one, in short, but your own dear self, mama, and Edward, may have been so barbarous to bely me. END
BEGIN NOW Beyond you three, is there a creature in the world whom I would not rather suspect of evil than Willoughby, whose heart I know so well? END
BEGIN NOW Elinor would not contend, and only replied, Whoever may have been so detestably your enemy, let them be cheated of their malignant triumph, my dear sister, by seeing how nobly the consciousness of your own innocence and good intentions supports your spirits. END
BEGIN NOW It is a reasonable and laudable pride which resists such malevolence. END
BEGIN NOW No, no, cried Marianne, misery such as mine has no pride. END
BEGIN NOW I care not who knows that I am wretched. END
BEGIN NOW The triumph of seeing me so may be open to all the world. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor, Elinor, they who suffer little may be proud and independent as they like&mdash;may resist insult, or return mortification&mdash;but I cannot. END
BEGIN NOW I must feel&mdash;I must be wretched&mdash;and they are welcome to enjoy the consciousness of it that can. END
BEGIN NOW But for my mother's sake and mine&mdash; I would do more than for my own. END
BEGIN NOW But to appear happy when I am so miserable&mdash;Oh! END
BEGIN NOW who can require it? END
BEGIN NOW Again they were both silent. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor was employed in walking thoughtfully from the fire to the window, from the window to the fire, without knowing that she received warmth from one, or discerning objects through the other; and Marianne, seated at the foot of the bed, with her head leaning against one of its posts, again took up Willoughby's letter, and, after shuddering over every sentence, exclaimed&mdash; It is too much! END
BEGIN NOW Oh, Willoughby, Willoughby, could this be yours! END
BEGIN NOW Cruel, cruel&mdash;nothing can acquit you. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor, nothing can. END
BEGIN NOW Whatever he might have heard against me&mdash;ought he not to have suspended his belief? END
BEGIN NOW ought he not to have told me of it, to have given me the power of clearing myself? END
BEGIN NOW 'The lock of hair, (repeating it from the letter,) which you so obligingly bestowed on me'&mdash;That is unpardonable. END
BEGIN NOW Willoughby, where was your heart when you wrote those words? END
BEGIN NOW Oh, barbarously insolent!&mdash;Elinor, can he be justified? END
BEGIN NOW No, Marianne, in no possible way. END
BEGIN NOW And yet this woman&mdash;who knows what her art may have been?&mdash;how long it may have been premeditated, and how deeply contrived by her!&mdash;Who is she?&mdash;Who can she be?&mdash;Whom did I ever hear him talk of as young and attractive among his female acquaintance?&mdash;Oh! END
BEGIN NOW no one, no one&mdash;he talked to me only of myself. END
BEGIN NOW Another pause ensued; Marianne was greatly agitated, and it ended thus. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor, I must go home. END
BEGIN NOW I must go and comfort mama. END
BEGIN NOW Can not we be gone to-morrow? END
BEGIN NOW To-morrow, Marianne! END
BEGIN NOW Yes, why should I stay here? END
BEGIN NOW I came only for Willoughby's sake&mdash;and now who cares for me? END
BEGIN NOW Who regards me? END
BEGIN NOW It would be impossible to go to-morrow. END
BEGIN NOW We owe Mrs. Jennings much more than civility; and civility of the commonest kind must prevent such a hasty removal as that. END
BEGIN NOW Well then, another day or two, perhaps; but I cannot stay here long, I cannot stay to endure the questions and remarks of all these people. END
BEGIN NOW The Middletons and Palmers&mdash;how am I to bear their pity? END
BEGIN NOW The pity of such a woman as Lady Middleton! END
BEGIN NOW Oh, what would HE say to that! END
BEGIN NOW Elinor advised her to lie down again, and for a moment she did so; but no attitude could give her ease; and in restless pain of mind and body she moved from one posture to another, till growing more and more hysterical, her sister could with difficulty keep her on the bed at all, and for some time was fearful of being constrained to call for assistance. END
BEGIN NOW Some lavender drops, however, which she was at length persuaded to take, were of use; and from that time till Mrs. Jennings returned, she continued on the bed quiet and motionless. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings came immediately to their room on her return, and without waiting to have her request of admittance answered, opened the door and walked in with a look of real concern. END
BEGIN NOW How do you do my dear? END
BEGIN NOW &mdash;said she in a voice of great compassion to Marianne, who turned away her face without attempting to answer. END
BEGIN NOW How is she, Miss Dashwood?&mdash;Poor thing! END
BEGIN NOW she looks very bad.&mdash; No wonder. END
BEGIN NOW Ay, it is but too true. END
BEGIN NOW He is to be married very soon&mdash;a good-for-nothing fellow! END
BEGIN NOW I have no patience with him. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Taylor told me of it half an hour ago, and she was told it by a particular friend of Miss Grey herself, else I am sure I should not have believed it; and I was almost ready to sink as it was. END
BEGIN NOW Well, said I, all I can say is, that if this be true, he has used a young lady of my acquaintance abominably ill, and I wish with all my soul his wife may plague his heart out. END
BEGIN NOW And so I shall always say, my dear, you may depend on it. END
BEGIN NOW I have no notion of men's going on in this way; and if ever I meet him again, I will give him such a dressing as he has not had this many a day. END
BEGIN NOW But there is one comfort, my dear Miss Marianne; he is not the only young man in the world worth having; and with your pretty face you will never want admirers. END
BEGIN NOW Well, poor thing! END
BEGIN NOW I won't disturb her any longer, for she had better have her cry out at once and have done with. END
BEGIN NOW The Parrys and Sandersons luckily are coming tonight you know, and that will amuse her. END
BEGIN NOW She then went away, walking on tiptoe out of the room, as if she supposed her young friend's affliction could be increased by noise. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne, to the surprise of her sister, determined on dining with them. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor even advised her against it. END
BEGIN NOW But no, she would go down; she could bear it very well, and the bustle about her would be less. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor, pleased to have her governed for a moment by such a motive, though believing it hardly possible that she could sit out the dinner, said no more; and adjusting her dress for her as well as she could, while Marianne still remained on the bed, was ready to assist her into the dining room as soon as they were summoned to it. END
BEGIN NOW When there, though looking most wretchedly, she ate more and was calmer than her sister had expected. END
BEGIN NOW Had she tried to speak, or had she been conscious of half Mrs. Jennings's well-meant but ill-judged attentions to her, this calmness could not have been maintained; but not a syllable escaped her lips; and the abstraction of her thoughts preserved her in ignorance of every thing that was passing before her. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor, who did justice to Mrs. Jennings's kindness, though its effusions were often distressing, and sometimes almost ridiculous, made her those acknowledgments, and returned her those civilities, which her sister could not make or return for herself. END
BEGIN NOW Their good friend saw that Marianne was unhappy, and felt that every thing was due to her which might make her at all less so. END
BEGIN NOW She treated her therefore, with all the indulgent fondness of a parent towards a favourite child on the last day of its holidays. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne was to have the best place by the fire, was to be tempted to eat by every delicacy in the house, and to be amused by the relation of all the news of the day. END
BEGIN NOW Had not Elinor, in the sad countenance of her sister, seen a check to all mirth, she could have been entertained by Mrs. Jennings's endeavours to cure a disappointment in love, by a variety of sweetmeats and olives, and a good fire. END
BEGIN NOW As soon, however, as the consciousness of all this was forced by continual repetition on Marianne, she could stay no longer. END
BEGIN NOW With a hasty exclamation of Misery, and a sign to her sister not to follow her, she directly got up and hurried out of the room. END
BEGIN NOW Poor soul! END
BEGIN NOW cried Mrs. Jennings, as soon as she was gone, how it grieves me to see her! END
BEGIN NOW And I declare if she is not gone away without finishing her wine! END
BEGIN NOW And the dried cherries too! END
BEGIN NOW Lord! END
BEGIN NOW nothing seems to do her any good. END
BEGIN NOW I am sure if I knew of any thing she would like, I would send all over the town for it. END
BEGIN NOW Well, it is the oddest thing to me, that a man should use such a pretty girl so ill! END
BEGIN NOW But when there is plenty of money on one side, and next to none on the other, Lord bless you! END
BEGIN NOW they care no more about such things!&mdash; The lady then&mdash;Miss Grey I think you called her&mdash;is very rich? END
BEGIN NOW Fifty thousand pounds, my dear. END
BEGIN NOW Did you ever see her? END
BEGIN NOW a smart, stylish girl they say, but not handsome. END
BEGIN NOW I remember her aunt very well, Biddy Henshawe; she married a very wealthy man. END
BEGIN NOW But the family are all rich together. END
BEGIN NOW Fifty thousand pounds! END
BEGIN NOW and by all accounts, it won't come before it's wanted; for they say he is all to pieces. END
BEGIN NOW No wonder! END
BEGIN NOW dashing about with his curricle and hunters! END
BEGIN NOW Well, it don't signify talking; but when a young man, be who he will, comes and makes love to a pretty girl, and promises marriage, he has no business to fly off from his word only because he grows poor, and a richer girl is ready to have him. END
BEGIN NOW Why don't he, in such a case, sell his horses, let his house, turn off his servants, and make a thorough reform at once? END
BEGIN NOW I warrant you, Miss Marianne would have been ready to wait till matters came round. END
BEGIN NOW But that won't do now-a-days; nothing in the way of pleasure can ever be given up by the young men of this age. END
BEGIN NOW Do you know what kind of a girl Miss Grey is? END
BEGIN NOW Is she said to be amiable? END
BEGIN NOW I never heard any harm of her; indeed I hardly ever heard her mentioned; except that Mrs. Taylor did say this morning, that one day Miss Walker hinted to her, that she believed Mr. and Mrs. Ellison would not be sorry to have Miss Grey married, for she and Mrs. Ellison could never agree. END
BEGIN NOW &mdash; And who are the Ellisons? END
BEGIN NOW Her guardians, my dear. END
BEGIN NOW But now she is of age and may choose for herself; and a pretty choice she has made!&mdash;What now, after pausing a moment&mdash; your poor sister is gone to her own room, I suppose, to moan by herself. END
BEGIN NOW Is there nothing one can get to comfort her? END
BEGIN NOW Poor dear, it seems quite cruel to let her be alone. END
BEGIN NOW Well, by-and-by we shall have a few friends, and that will amuse her a little. END
BEGIN NOW What shall we play at? END
BEGIN NOW She hates whist I know; but is there no round game she cares for? END
BEGIN NOW Dear ma'am, this kindness is quite unnecessary. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne, I dare say, will not leave her room again this evening. END
BEGIN NOW I shall persuade her if I can to go early to bed, for I am sure she wants rest. END
BEGIN NOW Aye, I believe that will be best for her. END
BEGIN NOW Let her name her own supper, and go to bed. END
BEGIN NOW Lord! END
BEGIN NOW no wonder she has been looking so bad and so cast down this last week or two, for this matter I suppose has been hanging over her head as long as that. END
BEGIN NOW And so the letter that came today finished it! END
BEGIN NOW Poor soul! END
BEGIN NOW I am sure if I had had a notion of it, I would not have joked her about it for all my money. END
BEGIN NOW But then you know, how should I guess such a thing? END
BEGIN NOW I made sure of its being nothing but a common love letter, and you know young people like to be laughed at about them. END
BEGIN NOW Lord! END
BEGIN NOW how concerned Sir John and my daughters will be when they hear it! END
BEGIN NOW If I had my senses about me I might have called in Conduit Street in my way home, and told them of it. END
BEGIN NOW But I shall see them tomorrow. END
BEGIN NOW It would be unnecessary I am sure, for you to caution Mrs. Palmer and Sir John against ever naming Mr. Willoughby, or making the slightest allusion to what has passed, before my sister. END
BEGIN NOW Their own good-nature must point out to them the real cruelty of appearing to know any thing about it when she is present; and the less that may ever be said to myself on the subject, the more my feelings will be spared, as you my dear madam will easily believe. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW Lord! END
BEGIN NOW yes, that I do indeed. END
BEGIN NOW It must be terrible for you to hear it talked of; and as for your sister, I am sure I would not mention a word about it to her for the world. END
BEGIN NOW You saw I did not all dinner time. END
BEGIN NOW No more would Sir John, nor my daughters, for they are all very thoughtful and considerate; especially if I give them a hint, as I certainly will. END
BEGIN NOW For my part, I think the less that is said about such things, the better, the sooner 'tis blown over and forgot. END
BEGIN NOW And what does talking ever do you know? END
BEGIN NOW In this affair it can only do harm; more so perhaps than in many cases of a similar kind, for it has been attended by circumstances which, for the sake of every one concerned in it, make it unfit to become the public conversation. END
BEGIN NOW I must do THIS justice to Mr. Willoughby&mdash;he has broken no positive engagement with my sister. END
BEGIN NOW Law, my dear! END
BEGIN NOW Don't pretend to defend him. END
BEGIN NOW No positive engagement indeed! END
BEGIN NOW after taking her all over Allenham House, and fixing on the very rooms they were to live in hereafter! END
BEGIN NOW Elinor, for her sister's sake, could not press the subject farther, and she hoped it was not required of her for Willoughby's; since, though Marianne might lose much, he could gain very little by the enforcement of the real truth. END
BEGIN NOW After a short silence on both sides, Mrs. Jennings, with all her natural hilarity, burst forth again. END
BEGIN NOW Well, my dear, 'tis a true saying about an ill-wind, for it will be all the better for Colonel Brandon. END
BEGIN NOW He will have her at last; aye, that he will. END
BEGIN NOW Mind me, now, if they an't married by Mid-summer. END
BEGIN NOW Lord! END
BEGIN NOW how he'll chuckle over this news! END
BEGIN NOW I hope he will come tonight. END
BEGIN NOW It will be all to one a better match for your sister. END
BEGIN NOW Two thousand a year without debt or drawback&mdash;except the little love-child, indeed; aye, I had forgot her; but she may be 'prenticed out at a small cost, and then what does it signify? END
BEGIN NOW Delaford is a nice place, I can tell you; exactly what I call a nice old fashioned place, full of comforts and conveniences; quite shut in with great garden walls that are covered with the best fruit-trees in the country; and such a mulberry tree in one corner! END
BEGIN NOW Lord! END
BEGIN NOW how Charlotte and I did stuff the only time we were there! END
BEGIN NOW Then, there is a dove-cote, some delightful stew-ponds, and a very pretty canal; and every thing, in short, that one could wish for; and, moreover, it is close to the church, and only a quarter of a mile from the turnpike-road, so 'tis never dull, for if you only go and sit up in an old yew arbour behind the house, you may see all the carriages that pass along. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW 'tis a nice place! END
BEGIN NOW A butcher hard by in the village, and the parsonage-house within a stone's throw. END
BEGIN NOW To my fancy, a thousand times prettier than Barton Park, where they are forced to send three miles for their meat, and have not a neighbour nearer than your mother. END
BEGIN NOW Well, I shall spirit up the Colonel as soon as I can. END
BEGIN NOW One shoulder of mutton, you know, drives another down. END
BEGIN NOW If we CAN but put Willoughby out of her head! END
BEGIN NOW Ay, if we can do THAT, Ma'am, said Elinor, we shall do very well with or without Colonel Brandon. END
BEGIN NOW And then rising, she went away to join Marianne, whom she found, as she expected, in her own room, leaning, in silent misery, over the small remains of a fire, which, till Elinor's entrance, had been her only light. END
BEGIN NOW You had better leave me, was all the notice that her sister received from her. END
BEGIN NOW I will leave you, said Elinor, if you will go to bed. END
BEGIN NOW But this, from the momentary perverseness of impatient suffering, she at first refused to do. END
BEGIN NOW Her sister's earnest, though gentle persuasion, however, soon softened her to compliance, and Elinor saw her lay her aching head on the pillow, and as she hoped, in a way to get some quiet rest before she left her. END
BEGIN NOW In the drawing-room, whither she then repaired, she was soon joined by Mrs. Jennings, with a wine-glass, full of something, in her hand. END
BEGIN NOW My dear, said she, entering, I have just recollected that I have some of the finest old Constantia wine in the house that ever was tasted, so I have brought a glass of it for your sister. END
BEGIN NOW My poor husband! END
BEGIN NOW how fond he was of it! END
BEGIN NOW Whenever he had a touch of his old colicky gout, he said it did him more good than any thing else in the world. END
BEGIN NOW Do take it to your sister. END
BEGIN NOW Dear Ma'am, replied Elinor, smiling at the difference of the complaints for which it was recommended, how good you are! END
BEGIN NOW But I have just left Marianne in bed, and, I hope, almost asleep; and as I think nothing will be of so much service to her as rest, if you will give me leave, I will drink the wine myself. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings, though regretting that she had not been five minutes earlier, was satisfied with the compromise; and Elinor, as she swallowed the chief of it, reflected, that though its effects on a colicky gout were, at present, of little importance to her, its healing powers, on a disappointed heart might be as reasonably tried on herself as on her sister. END
BEGIN NOW Colonel Brandon came in while the party were at tea, and by his manner of looking round the room for Marianne, Elinor immediately fancied that he neither expected nor wished to see her there, and, in short, that he was already aware of what occasioned her absence. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings was not struck by the same thought; for soon after his entrance, she walked across the room to the tea-table where Elinor presided, and whispered&mdash; The Colonel looks as grave as ever you see. END
BEGIN NOW He knows nothing of it; do tell him, my dear. END
BEGIN NOW He shortly afterwards drew a chair close to hers, and, with a look which perfectly assured her of his good information, inquired after her sister. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne is not well, said she. END
BEGIN NOW She has been indisposed all day, and we have persuaded her to go to bed. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps, then, he hesitatingly replied, what I heard this morning may be&mdash;there may be more truth in it than I could believe possible at first. END
BEGIN NOW What did you hear? END
BEGIN NOW That a gentleman, whom I had reason to think&mdash;in short, that a man, whom I KNEW to be engaged&mdash;but how shall I tell you? END
BEGIN NOW If you know it already, as surely you must, I may be spared. END
BEGIN NOW You mean, answered Elinor, with forced calmness, Mr. Willoughby's marriage with Miss Grey. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, we DO know it all. END
BEGIN NOW This seems to have been a day of general elucidation, for this very morning first unfolded it to us. END
BEGIN NOW Mr. Willoughby is unfathomable! END
BEGIN NOW Where did you hear it? END
BEGIN NOW In a stationer's shop in Pall Mall, where I had business. END
BEGIN NOW Two ladies were waiting for their carriage, and one of them was giving the other an account of the intended match, in a voice so little attempting concealment, that it was impossible for me not to hear all. END
BEGIN NOW The name of Willoughby, John Willoughby, frequently repeated, first caught my attention; and what followed was a positive assertion that every thing was now finally settled respecting his marriage with Miss Grey&mdash;it was no longer to be a secret&mdash;it would take place even within a few weeks, with many particulars of preparations and other matters. END
BEGIN NOW One thing, especially, I remember, because it served to identify the man still more:&mdash;as soon as the ceremony was over, they were to go to Combe Magna, his seat in Somersetshire. END
BEGIN NOW My astonishment!&mdash;but it would be impossible to describe what I felt. END
BEGIN NOW The communicative lady I learnt, on inquiry, for I stayed in the shop till they were gone, was a Mrs. Ellison, and that, as I have been since informed, is the name of Miss Grey's guardian. END
BEGIN NOW It is. END
BEGIN NOW But have you likewise heard that Miss Grey has fifty thousand pounds? END
BEGIN NOW In that, if in any thing, we may find an explanation. END
BEGIN NOW It may be so; but Willoughby is capable&mdash;at least I think &mdash;he stopped a moment; then added in a voice which seemed to distrust itself, And your sister&mdash;how did she&mdash; Her sufferings have been very severe. END
BEGIN NOW I have only to hope that they may be proportionately short. END
BEGIN NOW It has been, it is a most cruel affliction. END
BEGIN NOW Till yesterday, I believe, she never doubted his regard; and even now, perhaps&mdash;but I am almost convinced that he never was really attached to her. END
BEGIN NOW He has been very deceitful! END
BEGIN NOW and, in some points, there seems a hardness of heart about him. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW said Colonel Brandon, there is, indeed! END
BEGIN NOW But your sister does not&mdash;I think you said so&mdash;she does not consider quite as you do? END
BEGIN NOW You know her disposition, and may believe how eagerly she would still justify him if she could. END
BEGIN NOW He made no answer; and soon afterwards, by the removal of the tea-things, and the arrangement of the card parties, the subject was necessarily dropped. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings, who had watched them with pleasure while they were talking, and who expected to see the effect of Miss Dashwood's communication, in such an instantaneous gaiety on Colonel Brandon's side, as might have become a man in the bloom of youth, of hope and happiness, saw him, with amazement, remain the whole evening more serious and thoughtful than usual. END
BEGIN NOW From a night of more sleep than she had expected, Marianne awoke the next morning to the same consciousness of misery in which she had closed her eyes. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor encouraged her as much as possible to talk of what she felt; and before breakfast was ready, they had gone through the subject again and again; and with the same steady conviction and affectionate counsel on Elinor's side, the same impetuous feelings and varying opinions on Marianne's, as before. END
BEGIN NOW Sometimes she could believe Willoughby to be as unfortunate and as innocent as herself, and at others, lost every consolation in the impossibility of acquitting him. END
BEGIN NOW At one moment she was absolutely indifferent to the observation of all the world, at another she would seclude herself from it for ever, and at a third could resist it with energy. END
BEGIN NOW In one thing, however, she was uniform, when it came to the point, in avoiding, where it was possible, the presence of Mrs. Jennings, and in a determined silence when obliged to endure it. END
BEGIN NOW Her heart was hardened against the belief of Mrs. Jennings's entering into her sorrows with any compassion. END
BEGIN NOW No, no, no, it cannot be, she cried; she cannot feel. END
BEGIN NOW Her kindness is not sympathy; her good-nature is not tenderness. END
BEGIN NOW All that she wants is gossip, and she only likes me now because I supply it. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor had not needed this to be assured of the injustice to which her sister was often led in her opinion of others, by the irritable refinement of her own mind, and the too great importance placed by her on the delicacies of a strong sensibility, and the graces of a polished manner. END
BEGIN NOW Like half the rest of the world, if more than half there be that are clever and good, Marianne, with excellent abilities and an excellent disposition, was neither reasonable nor candid. END
BEGIN NOW She expected from other people the same opinions and feelings as her own, and she judged of their motives by the immediate effect of their actions on herself. END
BEGIN NOW Thus a circumstance occurred, while the sisters were together in their own room after breakfast, which sunk the heart of Mrs. Jennings still lower in her estimation; because, through her own weakness, it chanced to prove a source of fresh pain to herself, though Mrs. Jennings was governed in it by an impulse of the utmost goodwill. END
BEGIN NOW With a letter in her outstretched hand, and countenance gaily smiling, from the persuasion of bringing comfort, she entered their room, saying, Now, my dear, I bring you something that I am sure will do you good. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne heard enough. END
BEGIN NOW In one moment her imagination placed before her a letter from Willoughby, full of tenderness and contrition, explanatory of all that had passed, satisfactory, convincing; and instantly followed by Willoughby himself, rushing eagerly into the room to inforce, at her feet, by the eloquence of his eyes, the assurances of his letter. END
BEGIN NOW The work of one moment was destroyed by the next. END
BEGIN NOW The hand writing of her mother, never till then unwelcome, was before her; and, in the acuteness of the disappointment which followed such an ecstasy of more than hope, she felt as if, till that instant, she had never suffered. END
BEGIN NOW The cruelty of Mrs. Jennings no language, within her reach in her moments of happiest eloquence, could have expressed; and now she could reproach her only by the tears which streamed from her eyes with passionate violence&mdash;a reproach, however, so entirely lost on its object, that after many expressions of pity, she withdrew, still referring her to the letter of comfort. END
BEGIN NOW But the letter, when she was calm enough to read it, brought little comfort. END
BEGIN NOW Willoughby filled every page. END
BEGIN NOW Her mother, still confident of their engagement, and relying as warmly as ever on his constancy, had only been roused by Elinor's application, to intreat from Marianne greater openness towards them both; and this, with such tenderness towards her, such affection for Willoughby, and such a conviction of their future happiness in each other, that she wept with agony through the whole of it. END
BEGIN NOW All her impatience to be at home again now returned; her mother was dearer to her than ever; dearer through the very excess of her mistaken confidence in Willoughby, and she was wildly urgent to be gone. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor, unable herself to determine whether it were better for Marianne to be in London or at Barton, offered no counsel of her own except of patience till their mother's wishes could be known; and at length she obtained her sister's consent to wait for that knowledge. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings left them earlier than usual; for she could not be easy till the Middletons and Palmers were able to grieve as much as herself; and positively refusing Elinor's offered attendance, went out alone for the rest of the morning. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor, with a very heavy heart, aware of the pain she was going to communicate, and perceiving, by Marianne's letter, how ill she had succeeded in laying any foundation for it, then sat down to write her mother an account of what had passed, and entreat her directions for the future; while Marianne, who came into the drawing-room on Mrs. Jennings's going away, remained fixed at the table where Elinor wrote, watching the advancement of her pen, grieving over her for the hardship of such a task, and grieving still more fondly over its effect on her mother. END
BEGIN NOW In this manner they had continued about a quarter of an hour, when Marianne, whose nerves could not then bear any sudden noise, was startled by a rap at the door. END
BEGIN NOW Who can this be? END
BEGIN NOW cried Elinor. END
BEGIN NOW So early too! END
BEGIN NOW I thought we HAD been safe. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne moved to the window&mdash; It is Colonel Brandon! END
BEGIN NOW said she, with vexation. END
BEGIN NOW We are never safe from HIM. END
BEGIN NOW He will not come in, as Mrs. Jennings is from home. END
BEGIN NOW I will not trust to THAT, retreating to her own room. END
BEGIN NOW A man who has nothing to do with his own time has no conscience in his intrusion on that of others. END
BEGIN NOW The event proved her conjecture right, though it was founded on injustice and error; for Colonel Brandon DID come in; and Elinor, who was convinced that solicitude for Marianne brought him thither, and who saw THAT solicitude in his disturbed and melancholy look, and in his anxious though brief inquiry after her, could not forgive her sister for esteeming him so lightly. END
BEGIN NOW I met Mrs. Jennings in Bond Street, said he, after the first salutation, and she encouraged me to come on; and I was the more easily encouraged, because I thought it probable that I might find you alone, which I was very desirous of doing. END
BEGIN NOW My object&mdash;my wish&mdash;my sole wish in desiring it&mdash;I hope, I believe it is&mdash;is to be a means of giving comfort;&mdash;no, I must not say comfort&mdash;not present comfort&mdash;but conviction, lasting conviction to your sister's mind. END
BEGIN NOW My regard for her, for yourself, for your mother&mdash;will you allow me to prove it, by relating some circumstances which nothing but a VERY sincere regard&mdash;nothing but an earnest desire of being useful&mdash;I think I am justified&mdash;though where so many hours have been spent in convincing myself that I am right, is there not some reason to fear I may be wrong? END
BEGIN NOW He stopped. END
BEGIN NOW I understand you, said Elinor. END
BEGIN NOW You have something to tell me of Mr. Willoughby, that will open his character farther. END
BEGIN NOW Your telling it will be the greatest act of friendship that can be shewn Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW MY gratitude will be insured immediately by any information tending to that end, and HERS must be gained by it in time. END
BEGIN NOW Pray, pray let me hear it. END
BEGIN NOW You shall; and, to be brief, when I quitted Barton last October,&mdash;but this will give you no idea&mdash;I must go farther back. END
BEGIN NOW You will find me a very awkward narrator, Miss Dashwood; I hardly know where to begin. END
BEGIN NOW A short account of myself, I believe, will be necessary, and it SHALL be a short one. END
BEGIN NOW On such a subject, sighing heavily, can I have little temptation to be diffuse. END
BEGIN NOW He stopt a moment for recollection, and then, with another sigh, went on. END
BEGIN NOW You have probably entirely forgotten a conversation&mdash;(it is not to be supposed that it could make any impression on you)&mdash;a conversation between us one evening at Barton Park&mdash;it was the evening of a dance&mdash;in which I alluded to a lady I had once known, as resembling, in some measure, your sister Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW Indeed, answered Elinor, I have NOT forgotten it. END
BEGIN NOW He looked pleased by this remembrance, and added, If I am not deceived by the uncertainty, the partiality of tender recollection, there is a very strong resemblance between them, as well in mind as person. END
BEGIN NOW The same warmth of heart, the same eagerness of fancy and spirits. END
BEGIN NOW This lady was one of my nearest relations, an orphan from her infancy, and under the guardianship of my father. END
BEGIN NOW Our ages were nearly the same, and from our earliest years we were playfellows and friends. END
BEGIN NOW I cannot remember the time when I did not love Eliza; and my affection for her, as we grew up, was such, as perhaps, judging from my present forlorn and cheerless gravity, you might think me incapable of having ever felt. END
BEGIN NOW Hers, for me, was, I believe, fervent as the attachment of your sister to Mr. Willoughby and it was, though from a different cause, no less unfortunate. END
BEGIN NOW At seventeen she was lost to me for ever. END
BEGIN NOW She was married&mdash;married against her inclination to my brother. END
BEGIN NOW Her fortune was large, and our family estate much encumbered. END
BEGIN NOW And this, I fear, is all that can be said for the conduct of one, who was at once her uncle and guardian. END
BEGIN NOW My brother did not deserve her; he did not even love her. END
BEGIN NOW I had hoped that her regard for me would support her under any difficulty, and for some time it did; but at last the misery of her situation, for she experienced great unkindness, overcame all her resolution, and though she had promised me that nothing&mdash;but how blindly I relate! END
BEGIN NOW I have never told you how this was brought on. END
BEGIN NOW We were within a few hours of eloping together for Scotland. END
BEGIN NOW The treachery, or the folly, of my cousin's maid betrayed us. END
BEGIN NOW I was banished to the house of a relation far distant, and she was allowed no liberty, no society, no amusement, till my father's point was gained. END
BEGIN NOW I had depended on her fortitude too far, and the blow was a severe one&mdash;but had her marriage been happy, so young as I then was, a few months must have reconciled me to it, or at least I should not have now to lament it. END
BEGIN NOW This however was not the case. END
BEGIN NOW My brother had no regard for her; his pleasures were not what they ought to have been, and from the first he treated her unkindly. END
BEGIN NOW The consequence of this, upon a mind so young, so lively, so inexperienced as Mrs. Brandon's, was but too natural. END
BEGIN NOW She resigned herself at first to all the misery of her situation; and happy had it been if she had not lived to overcome those regrets which the remembrance of me occasioned. END
BEGIN NOW But can we wonder that, with such a husband to provoke inconstancy, and without a friend to advise or restrain her (for my father lived only a few months after their marriage, and I was with my regiment in the East Indies) she should fall? END
BEGIN NOW Had I remained in England, perhaps&mdash;but I meant to promote the happiness of both by removing from her for years, and for that purpose had procured my exchange. END
BEGIN NOW The shock which her marriage had given me, he continued, in a voice of great agitation, was of trifling weight&mdash;was nothing to what I felt when I heard, about two years afterwards, of her divorce. END
BEGIN NOW It was THAT which threw this gloom,&mdash;even now the recollection of what I suffered&mdash; He could say no more, and rising hastily walked for a few minutes about the room. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor, affected by his relation, and still more by his distress, could not speak. END
BEGIN NOW He saw her concern, and coming to her, took her hand, pressed it, and kissed it with grateful respect. END
BEGIN NOW A few minutes more of silent exertion enabled him to proceed with composure. END
BEGIN NOW It was nearly three years after this unhappy period before I returned to England. END
BEGIN NOW My first care, when I DID arrive, was of course to seek for her; but the search was as fruitless as it was melancholy. END
BEGIN NOW I could not trace her beyond her first seducer, and there was every reason to fear that she had removed from him only to sink deeper in a life of sin. END
BEGIN NOW Her legal allowance was not adequate to her fortune, nor sufficient for her comfortable maintenance, and I learnt from my brother that the power of receiving it had been made over some months before to another person. END
BEGIN NOW He imagined, and calmly could he imagine it, that her extravagance, and consequent distress, had obliged her to dispose of it for some immediate relief. END
BEGIN NOW At last, however, and after I had been six months in England, I DID find her. END
BEGIN NOW Regard for a former servant of my own, who had since fallen into misfortune, carried me to visit him in a spunging-house, where he was confined for debt; and there, in the same house, under a similar confinement, was my unfortunate sister. END
BEGIN NOW So altered&mdash;so faded&mdash;worn down by acute suffering of every kind! END
BEGIN NOW hardly could I believe the melancholy and sickly figure before me, to be the remains of the lovely, blooming, healthful girl, on whom I had once doted. END
BEGIN NOW What I endured in so beholding her&mdash;but I have no right to wound your feelings by attempting to describe it&mdash;I have pained you too much already. END
