BEGIN NOW That she was, to all appearance, in the last stage of a consumption, was&mdash;yes, in such a situation it was my greatest comfort. END
BEGIN NOW Life could do nothing for her, beyond giving time for a better preparation for death; and that was given. END
BEGIN NOW I saw her placed in comfortable lodgings, and under proper attendants; I visited her every day during the rest of her short life: I was with her in her last moments. END
BEGIN NOW Again he stopped to recover himself; and Elinor spoke her feelings in an exclamation of tender concern, at the fate of his unfortunate friend. END
BEGIN NOW Your sister, I hope, cannot be offended, said he, by the resemblance I have fancied between her and my poor disgraced relation. END
BEGIN NOW Their fates, their fortunes, cannot be the same; and had the natural sweet disposition of the one been guarded by a firmer mind, or a happier marriage, she might have been all that you will live to see the other be. END
BEGIN NOW But to what does all this lead? END
BEGIN NOW I seem to have been distressing you for nothing. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW Miss Dashwood&mdash;a subject such as this&mdash;untouched for fourteen years&mdash;it is dangerous to handle it at all! END
BEGIN NOW I WILL be more collected&mdash;more concise. END
BEGIN NOW She left to my care her only child, a little girl, the offspring of her first guilty connection, who was then about three years old. END
BEGIN NOW She loved the child, and had always kept it with her. END
BEGIN NOW It was a valued, a precious trust to me; and gladly would I have discharged it in the strictest sense, by watching over her education myself, had the nature of our situations allowed it; but I had no family, no home; and my little Eliza was therefore placed at school. END
BEGIN NOW I saw her there whenever I could, and after the death of my brother, (which happened about five years ago, and which left to me the possession of the family property,) she visited me at Delaford. END
BEGIN NOW I called her a distant relation; but I am well aware that I have in general been suspected of a much nearer connection with her. END
BEGIN NOW It is now three years ago (she had just reached her fourteenth year,) that I removed her from school, to place her under the care of a very respectable woman, residing in Dorsetshire, who had the charge of four or five other girls of about the same time of life; and for two years I had every reason to be pleased with her situation. END
BEGIN NOW But last February, almost a twelvemonth back, she suddenly disappeared. END
BEGIN NOW I had allowed her, (imprudently, as it has since turned out,) at her earnest desire, to go to Bath with one of her young friends, who was attending her father there for his health. END
BEGIN NOW I knew him to be a very good sort of man, and I thought well of his daughter&mdash;better than she deserved, for, with a most obstinate and ill-judged secrecy, she would tell nothing, would give no clue, though she certainly knew all. END
BEGIN NOW He, her father, a well-meaning, but not a quick-sighted man, could really, I believe, give no information; for he had been generally confined to the house, while the girls were ranging over the town and making what acquaintance they chose; and he tried to convince me, as thoroughly as he was convinced himself, of his daughter's being entirely unconcerned in the business. END
BEGIN NOW In short, I could learn nothing but that she was gone; all the rest, for eight long months, was left to conjecture. END
BEGIN NOW What I thought, what I feared, may be imagined; and what I suffered too. END
BEGIN NOW Good heavens! END
BEGIN NOW cried Elinor, could it be&mdash;could Willoughby! END
BEGIN NOW &mdash; The first news that reached me of her, he continued, came in a letter from herself, last October. END
BEGIN NOW It was forwarded to me from Delaford, and I received it on the very morning of our intended party to Whitwell; and this was the reason of my leaving Barton so suddenly, which I am sure must at the time have appeared strange to every body, and which I believe gave offence to some. END
BEGIN NOW Little did Mr. Willoughby imagine, I suppose, when his looks censured me for incivility in breaking up the party, that I was called away to the relief of one whom he had made poor and miserable; but HAD he known it, what would it have availed? END
BEGIN NOW Would he have been less gay or less happy in the smiles of your sister? END
BEGIN NOW No, he had already done that, which no man who CAN feel for another would do. END
BEGIN NOW He had left the girl whose youth and innocence he had seduced, in a situation of the utmost distress, with no creditable home, no help, no friends, ignorant of his address! END
BEGIN NOW He had left her, promising to return; he neither returned, nor wrote, nor relieved her. END
BEGIN NOW This is beyond every thing! END
BEGIN NOW exclaimed Elinor. END
BEGIN NOW His character is now before you; expensive, dissipated, and worse than both. END
BEGIN NOW Knowing all this, as I have now known it many weeks, guess what I must have felt on seeing your sister as fond of him as ever, and on being assured that she was to marry him: guess what I must have felt for all your sakes. END
BEGIN NOW When I came to you last week and found you alone, I came determined to know the truth; though irresolute what to do when it WAS known. END
BEGIN NOW My behaviour must have seemed strange to you then; but now you will comprehend it. END
BEGIN NOW To suffer you all to be so deceived; to see your sister&mdash;but what could I do? END
BEGIN NOW I had no hope of interfering with success; and sometimes I thought your sister's influence might yet reclaim him. END
BEGIN NOW But now, after such dishonorable usage, who can tell what were his designs on her. END
BEGIN NOW Whatever they may have been, however, she may now, and hereafter doubtless WILL turn with gratitude towards her own condition, when she compares it with that of my poor Eliza, when she considers the wretched and hopeless situation of this poor girl, and pictures her to herself, with an affection for him so strong, still as strong as her own, and with a mind tormented by self-reproach, which must attend her through life. END
BEGIN NOW Surely this comparison must have its use with her. END
BEGIN NOW She will feel her own sufferings to be nothing. END
BEGIN NOW They proceed from no misconduct, and can bring no disgrace. END
BEGIN NOW On the contrary, every friend must be made still more her friend by them. END
BEGIN NOW Concern for her unhappiness, and respect for her fortitude under it, must strengthen every attachment. END
BEGIN NOW Use your own discretion, however, in communicating to her what I have told you. END
BEGIN NOW You must know best what will be its effect; but had I not seriously, and from my heart believed it might be of service, might lessen her regrets, I would not have suffered myself to trouble you with this account of my family afflictions, with a recital which may seem to have been intended to raise myself at the expense of others. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor's thanks followed this speech with grateful earnestness; attended too with the assurance of her expecting material advantage to Marianne, from the communication of what had passed. END
BEGIN NOW I have been more pained, said she, by her endeavors to acquit him than by all the rest; for it irritates her mind more than the most perfect conviction of his unworthiness can do. END
BEGIN NOW Now, though at first she will suffer much, I am sure she will soon become easier. END
BEGIN NOW Have you, she continued, after a short silence, ever seen Mr. Willoughby since you left him at Barton? END
BEGIN NOW Yes, he replied gravely, once I have. END
BEGIN NOW One meeting was unavoidable. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor, startled by his manner, looked at him anxiously, saying, What? END
BEGIN NOW have you met him to&mdash; I could meet him no other way. END
BEGIN NOW Eliza had confessed to me, though most reluctantly, the name of her lover; and when he returned to town, which was within a fortnight after myself, we met by appointment, he to defend, I to punish his conduct. END
BEGIN NOW We returned unwounded, and the meeting, therefore, never got abroad. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor sighed over the fancied necessity of this; but to a man and a soldier she presumed not to censure it. END
BEGIN NOW Such, said Colonel Brandon, after a pause, has been the unhappy resemblance between the fate of mother and daughter! END
BEGIN NOW and so imperfectly have I discharged my trust! END
BEGIN NOW Is she still in town? END
BEGIN NOW No; as soon as she recovered from her lying-in, for I found her near her delivery, I removed her and her child into the country, and there she remains. END
BEGIN NOW Recollecting, soon afterwards, that he was probably dividing Elinor from her sister, he put an end to his visit, receiving from her again the same grateful acknowledgments, and leaving her full of compassion and esteem for him. END
BEGIN NOW When the particulars of this conversation were repeated by Miss Dashwood to her sister, as they very soon were, the effect on her was not entirely such as the former had hoped to see. END
BEGIN NOW Not that Marianne appeared to distrust the truth of any part of it, for she listened to it all with the most steady and submissive attention, made neither objection nor remark, attempted no vindication of Willoughby, and seemed to shew by her tears that she felt it to be impossible. END
BEGIN NOW But though this behaviour assured Elinor that the conviction of this guilt WAS carried home to her mind, though she saw with satisfaction the effect of it, in her no longer avoiding Colonel Brandon when he called, in her speaking to him, even voluntarily speaking, with a kind of compassionate respect, and though she saw her spirits less violently irritated than before, she did not see her less wretched. END
BEGIN NOW Her mind did become settled, but it was settled in a gloomy dejection. END
BEGIN NOW She felt the loss of Willoughby's character yet more heavily than she had felt the loss of his heart; his seduction and desertion of Miss Williams, the misery of that poor girl, and the doubt of what his designs might ONCE have been on herself, preyed altogether so much on her spirits, that she could not bring herself to speak of what she felt even to Elinor; and, brooding over her sorrows in silence, gave more pain to her sister than could have been communicated by the most open and most frequent confession of them. END
BEGIN NOW To give the feelings or the language of Mrs. Dashwood on receiving and answering Elinor's letter would be only to give a repetition of what her daughters had already felt and said; of a disappointment hardly less painful than Marianne's, and an indignation even greater than Elinor's. END
BEGIN NOW Long letters from her, quickly succeeding each other, arrived to tell all that she suffered and thought; to express her anxious solicitude for Marianne, and entreat she would bear up with fortitude under this misfortune. END
BEGIN NOW Bad indeed must the nature of Marianne's affliction be, when her mother could talk of fortitude! END
BEGIN NOW mortifying and humiliating must be the origin of those regrets, which SHE could wish her not to indulge! END
BEGIN NOW Against the interest of her own individual comfort, Mrs. Dashwood had determined that it would be better for Marianne to be any where, at that time, than at Barton, where every thing within her view would be bringing back the past in the strongest and most afflicting manner, by constantly placing Willoughby before her, such as she had always seen him there. END
BEGIN NOW She recommended it to her daughters, therefore, by all means not to shorten their visit to Mrs. Jennings; the length of which, though never exactly fixed, had been expected by all to comprise at least five or six weeks. END
BEGIN NOW A variety of occupations, of objects, and of company, which could not be procured at Barton, would be inevitable there, and might yet, she hoped, cheat Marianne, at times, into some interest beyond herself, and even into some amusement, much as the ideas of both might now be spurned by her. END
BEGIN NOW From all danger of seeing Willoughby again, her mother considered her to be at least equally safe in town as in the country, since his acquaintance must now be dropped by all who called themselves her friends. END
BEGIN NOW Design could never bring them in each other's way: negligence could never leave them exposed to a surprise; and chance had less in its favour in the crowd of London than even in the retirement of Barton, where it might force him before her while paying that visit at Allenham on his marriage, which Mrs. Dashwood, from foreseeing at first as a probable event, had brought herself to expect as a certain one. END
BEGIN NOW She had yet another reason for wishing her children to remain where they were; a letter from her son-in-law had told her that he and his wife were to be in town before the middle of February, and she judged it right that they should sometimes see their brother. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne had promised to be guided by her mother's opinion, and she submitted to it therefore without opposition, though it proved perfectly different from what she wished and expected, though she felt it to be entirely wrong, formed on mistaken grounds, and that by requiring her longer continuance in London it deprived her of the only possible alleviation of her wretchedness, the personal sympathy of her mother, and doomed her to such society and such scenes as must prevent her ever knowing a moment's rest. END
BEGIN NOW But it was a matter of great consolation to her, that what brought evil to herself would bring good to her sister; and Elinor, on the other hand, suspecting that it would not be in her power to avoid Edward entirely, comforted herself by thinking, that though their longer stay would therefore militate against her own happiness, it would be better for Marianne than an immediate return into Devonshire. END
BEGIN NOW Her carefulness in guarding her sister from ever hearing Willoughby's name mentioned, was not thrown away. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne, though without knowing it herself, reaped all its advantage; for neither Mrs. Jennings, nor Sir John, nor even Mrs. Palmer herself, ever spoke of him before her. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor wished that the same forbearance could have extended towards herself, but that was impossible, and she was obliged to listen day after day to the indignation of them all. END
BEGIN NOW Sir John, could not have thought it possible. END
BEGIN NOW A man of whom he had always had such reason to think well! END
BEGIN NOW Such a good-natured fellow! END
BEGIN NOW He did not believe there was a bolder rider in England! END
BEGIN NOW It was an unaccountable business. END
BEGIN NOW He wished him at the devil with all his heart. END
BEGIN NOW He would not speak another word to him, meet him where he might, for all the world! END
BEGIN NOW No, not if it were to be by the side of Barton covert, and they were kept watching for two hours together. END
BEGIN NOW Such a scoundrel of a fellow! END
BEGIN NOW such a deceitful dog! END
BEGIN NOW It was only the last time they met that he had offered him one of Folly's puppies! END
BEGIN NOW and this was the end of it! END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Palmer, in her way, was equally angry. END
BEGIN NOW She was determined to drop his acquaintance immediately, and she was very thankful that she had never been acquainted with him at all. END
BEGIN NOW She wished with all her heart Combe Magna was not so near Cleveland; but it did not signify, for it was a great deal too far off to visit; she hated him so much that she was resolved never to mention his name again, and she should tell everybody she saw, how good-for-nothing he was. END
BEGIN NOW The rest of Mrs. Palmer's sympathy was shewn in procuring all the particulars in her power of the approaching marriage, and communicating them to Elinor. END
BEGIN NOW She could soon tell at what coachmaker's the new carriage was building, by what painter Mr. Willoughby's portrait was drawn, and at what warehouse Miss Grey's clothes might be seen. END
BEGIN NOW The calm and polite unconcern of Lady Middleton on the occasion was a happy relief to Elinor's spirits, oppressed as they often were by the clamorous kindness of the others. END
BEGIN NOW It was a great comfort to her to be sure of exciting no interest in ONE person at least among their circle of friends: a great comfort to know that there was ONE who would meet her without feeling any curiosity after particulars, or any anxiety for her sister's health. END
BEGIN NOW Every qualification is raised at times, by the circumstances of the moment, to more than its real value; and she was sometimes worried down by officious condolence to rate good-breeding as more indispensable to comfort than good-nature. END
BEGIN NOW Lady Middleton expressed her sense of the affair about once every day, or twice, if the subject occurred very often, by saying, It is very shocking, indeed! END
BEGIN NOW and by the means of this continual though gentle vent, was able not only to see the Miss Dashwoods from the first without the smallest emotion, but very soon to see them without recollecting a word of the matter; and having thus supported the dignity of her own sex, and spoken her decided censure of what was wrong in the other, she thought herself at liberty to attend to the interest of her own assemblies, and therefore determined (though rather against the opinion of Sir John) that as Mrs. Willoughby would at once be a woman of elegance and fortune, to leave her card with her as soon as she married. END
BEGIN NOW Colonel Brandon's delicate, unobtrusive enquiries were never unwelcome to Miss Dashwood. END
BEGIN NOW He had abundantly earned the privilege of intimate discussion of her sister's disappointment, by the friendly zeal with which he had endeavoured to soften it, and they always conversed with confidence. END
BEGIN NOW His chief reward for the painful exertion of disclosing past sorrows and present humiliations, was given in the pitying eye with which Marianne sometimes observed him, and the gentleness of her voice whenever (though it did not often happen) she was obliged, or could oblige herself to speak to him. END
BEGIN NOW THESE assured him that his exertion had produced an increase of good-will towards himself, and THESE gave Elinor hopes of its being farther augmented hereafter; but Mrs. Jennings, who knew nothing of all this, who knew only that the Colonel continued as grave as ever, and that she could neither prevail on him to make the offer himself, nor commission her to make it for him, began, at the end of two days, to think that, instead of Midsummer, they would not be married till Michaelmas, and by the end of a week that it would not be a match at all. END
BEGIN NOW The good understanding between the Colonel and Miss Dashwood seemed rather to declare that the honours of the mulberry-tree, the canal, and the yew arbour, would all be made over to HER; and Mrs. Jennings had, for some time ceased to think at all of Mrs. Ferrars. END
BEGIN NOW Early in February, within a fortnight from the receipt of Willoughby's letter, Elinor had the painful office of informing her sister that he was married. END
BEGIN NOW She had taken care to have the intelligence conveyed to herself, as soon as it was known that the ceremony was over, as she was desirous that Marianne should not receive the first notice of it from the public papers, which she saw her eagerly examining every morning. END
BEGIN NOW She received the news with resolute composure; made no observation on it, and at first shed no tears; but after a short time they would burst out, and for the rest of the day, she was in a state hardly less pitiable than when she first learnt to expect the event. END
BEGIN NOW The Willoughbys left town as soon as they were married; and Elinor now hoped, as there could be no danger of her seeing either of them, to prevail on her sister, who had never yet left the house since the blow first fell, to go out again by degrees as she had done before. END
BEGIN NOW About this time the two Miss Steeles, lately arrived at their cousin's house in Bartlett's Buildings, Holburn, presented themselves again before their more grand relations in Conduit and Berkeley Streets; and were welcomed by them all with great cordiality. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor only was sorry to see them. END
BEGIN NOW Their presence always gave her pain, and she hardly knew how to make a very gracious return to the overpowering delight of Lucy in finding her STILL in town. END
BEGIN NOW I should have been quite disappointed if I had not found you here STILL, said she repeatedly, with a strong emphasis on the word. END
BEGIN NOW But I always thought I SHOULD. END
BEGIN NOW I was almost sure you would not leave London yet awhile; though you TOLD me, you know, at Barton, that you should not stay above a MONTH. END
BEGIN NOW But I thought, at the time, that you would most likely change your mind when it came to the point. END
BEGIN NOW It would have been such a great pity to have went away before your brother and sister came. END
BEGIN NOW And now to be sure you will be in no hurry to be gone. END
BEGIN NOW I am amazingly glad you did not keep to YOUR WORD. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor perfectly understood her, and was forced to use all her self-command to make it appear that she did NOT. END
BEGIN NOW Well, my dear, said Mrs. Jennings, and how did you travel? END
BEGIN NOW Not in the stage, I assure you, replied Miss Steele, with quick exultation; we came post all the way, and had a very smart beau to attend us. END
BEGIN NOW Dr. Davies was coming to town, and so we thought we'd join him in a post-chaise; and he behaved very genteelly, and paid ten or twelve shillings more than we did. END
BEGIN NOW Oh, oh! END
BEGIN NOW cried Mrs. Jennings; very pretty, indeed! END
BEGIN NOW and the Doctor is a single man, I warrant you. END
BEGIN NOW There now, said Miss Steele, affectedly simpering, everybody laughs at me so about the Doctor, and I cannot think why. END
BEGIN NOW My cousins say they are sure I have made a conquest; but for my part I declare I never think about him from one hour's end to another. END
BEGIN NOW 'Lord! END
BEGIN NOW here comes your beau, Nancy,' my cousin said t'other day, when she saw him crossing the street to the house. END
BEGIN NOW My beau, indeed! END
BEGIN NOW said I&mdash;I cannot think who you mean. END
BEGIN NOW The Doctor is no beau of mine. END
BEGIN NOW Aye, aye, that is very pretty talking&mdash;but it won't do&mdash;the Doctor is the man, I see. END
BEGIN NOW No, indeed! END
BEGIN NOW replied her cousin, with affected earnestness, and I beg you will contradict it, if you ever hear it talked of. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings directly gave her the gratifying assurance that she certainly would NOT, and Miss Steele was made completely happy. END
BEGIN NOW I suppose you will go and stay with your brother and sister, Miss Dashwood, when they come to town, said Lucy, returning, after a cessation of hostile hints, to the charge. END
BEGIN NOW No, I do not think we shall. END
BEGIN NOW Oh, yes, I dare say you will. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor would not humour her by farther opposition. END
BEGIN NOW What a charming thing it is that Mrs. Dashwood can spare you both for so long a time together! END
BEGIN NOW Long a time, indeed! END
BEGIN NOW interposed Mrs. Jennings. END
BEGIN NOW Why, their visit is but just begun! END
BEGIN NOW Lucy was silenced. END
BEGIN NOW I am sorry we cannot see your sister, Miss Dashwood, said Miss Steele. END
BEGIN NOW I am sorry she is not well&mdash; for Marianne had left the room on their arrival. END
BEGIN NOW You are very good. END
BEGIN NOW My sister will be equally sorry to miss the pleasure of seeing you; but she has been very much plagued lately with nervous head-aches, which make her unfit for company or conversation. END
BEGIN NOW Oh, dear, that is a great pity! END
BEGIN NOW but such old friends as Lucy and me!&mdash;I think she might see US; and I am sure we would not speak a word. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor, with great civility, declined the proposal. END
BEGIN NOW Her sister was perhaps laid down upon the bed, or in her dressing gown, and therefore not able to come to them. END
BEGIN NOW Oh, if that's all, cried Miss Steele, we can just as well go and see HER. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor began to find this impertinence too much for her temper; but she was saved the trouble of checking it, by Lucy's sharp reprimand, which now, as on many occasions, though it did not give much sweetness to the manners of one sister, was of advantage in governing those of the other. END
BEGIN NOW After some opposition, Marianne yielded to her sister's entreaties, and consented to go out with her and Mrs. Jennings one morning for half an hour. END
BEGIN NOW She expressly conditioned, however, for paying no visits, and would do no more than accompany them to Gray's in Sackville Street, where Elinor was carrying on a negotiation for the exchange of a few old-fashioned jewels of her mother. END
BEGIN NOW When they stopped at the door, Mrs. Jennings recollected that there was a lady at the other end of the street on whom she ought to call; and as she had no business at Gray's, it was resolved, that while her young friends transacted their's, she should pay her visit and return for them. END
BEGIN NOW On ascending the stairs, the Miss Dashwoods found so many people before them in the room, that there was not a person at liberty to tend to their orders; and they were obliged to wait. END
BEGIN NOW All that could be done was, to sit down at that end of the counter which seemed to promise the quickest succession; one gentleman only was standing there, and it is probable that Elinor was not without hope of exciting his politeness to a quicker despatch. END
BEGIN NOW But the correctness of his eye, and the delicacy of his taste, proved to be beyond his politeness. END
BEGIN NOW He was giving orders for a toothpick-case for himself, and till its size, shape, and ornaments were determined, all of which, after examining and debating for a quarter of an hour over every toothpick-case in the shop, were finally arranged by his own inventive fancy, he had no leisure to bestow any other attention on the two ladies, than what was comprised in three or four very broad stares; a kind of notice which served to imprint on Elinor the remembrance of a person and face, of strong, natural, sterling insignificance, though adorned in the first style of fashion. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne was spared from the troublesome feelings of contempt and resentment, on this impertinent examination of their features, and on the puppyism of his manner in deciding on all the different horrors of the different toothpick-cases presented to his inspection, by remaining unconscious of it all; for she was as well able to collect her thoughts within herself, and be as ignorant of what was passing around her, in Mr. Gray's shop, as in her own bedroom. END
BEGIN NOW At last the affair was decided. END
BEGIN NOW The ivory, the gold, and the pearls, all received their appointment, and the gentleman having named the last day on which his existence could be continued without the possession of the toothpick-case, drew on his gloves with leisurely care, and bestowing another glance on the Miss Dashwoods, but such a one as seemed rather to demand than express admiration, walked off with a happy air of real conceit and affected indifference. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor lost no time in bringing her business forward, was on the point of concluding it, when another gentleman presented himself at her side. END
BEGIN NOW She turned her eyes towards his face, and found him with some surprise to be her brother. END
BEGIN NOW Their affection and pleasure in meeting was just enough to make a very creditable appearance in Mr. Gray's shop. END
BEGIN NOW John Dashwood was really far from being sorry to see his sisters again; it rather gave them satisfaction; and his inquiries after their mother were respectful and attentive. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor found that he and Fanny had been in town two days. END
BEGIN NOW I wished very much to call upon you yesterday, said he, but it was impossible, for we were obliged to take Harry to see the wild beasts at Exeter Exchange; and we spent the rest of the day with Mrs. Ferrars. END
BEGIN NOW Harry was vastly pleased. END
BEGIN NOW THIS morning I had fully intended to call on you, if I could possibly find a spare half hour, but one has always so much to do on first coming to town. END
BEGIN NOW I am come here to bespeak Fanny a seal. END
BEGIN NOW But tomorrow I think I shall certainly be able to call in Berkeley Street, and be introduced to your friend Mrs. Jennings. END
BEGIN NOW I understand she is a woman of very good fortune. END
BEGIN NOW And the Middletons too, you must introduce me to THEM. END
BEGIN NOW As my mother-in-law's relations, I shall be happy to show them every respect. END
BEGIN NOW They are excellent neighbours to you in the country, I understand. END
BEGIN NOW Excellent indeed. END
BEGIN NOW Their attention to our comfort, their friendliness in every particular, is more than I can express. END
BEGIN NOW I am extremely glad to hear it, upon my word; extremely glad indeed. END
BEGIN NOW But so it ought to be; they are people of large fortune, they are related to you, and every civility and accommodation that can serve to make your situation pleasant might be reasonably expected. END
BEGIN NOW And so you are most comfortably settled in your little cottage and want for nothing! END
BEGIN NOW Edward brought us a most charming account of the place: the most complete thing of its kind, he said, that ever was, and you all seemed to enjoy it beyond any thing. END
BEGIN NOW It was a great satisfaction to us to hear it, I assure you. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor did feel a little ashamed of her brother; and was not sorry to be spared the necessity of answering him, by the arrival of Mrs. Jennings's servant, who came to tell her that his mistress waited for them at the door. END
BEGIN NOW Mr. Dashwood attended them down stairs, was introduced to Mrs. Jennings at the door of her carriage, and repeating his hope of being able to call on them the next day, took leave. END
BEGIN NOW His visit was duly paid. END
BEGIN NOW He came with a pretence at an apology from their sister-in-law, for not coming too; but she was so much engaged with her mother, that really she had no leisure for going any where. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings, however, assured him directly, that she should not stand upon ceremony, for they were all cousins, or something like it, and she should certainly wait on Mrs. John Dashwood very soon, and bring her sisters to see her. END
BEGIN NOW His manners to THEM, though calm, were perfectly kind; to Mrs. Jennings, most attentively civil; and on Colonel Brandon's coming in soon after himself, he eyed him with a curiosity which seemed to say, that he only wanted to know him to be rich, to be equally civil to HIM. END
BEGIN NOW After staying with them half an hour, he asked Elinor to walk with him to Conduit Street, and introduce him to Sir John and Lady Middleton. END
BEGIN NOW The weather was remarkably fine, and she readily consented. END
BEGIN NOW As soon as they were out of the house, his enquiries began. END
BEGIN NOW Who is Colonel Brandon? END
BEGIN NOW Is he a man of fortune? END
BEGIN NOW Yes; he has very good property in Dorsetshire. END
BEGIN NOW I am glad of it. END
BEGIN NOW He seems a most gentlemanlike man; and I think, Elinor, I may congratulate you on the prospect of a very respectable establishment in life. END
BEGIN NOW Me, brother! END
BEGIN NOW what do you mean? END
BEGIN NOW He likes you. END
BEGIN NOW I observed him narrowly, and am convinced of it. END
BEGIN NOW What is the amount of his fortune? END
BEGIN NOW I believe about two thousand a year. END
BEGIN NOW Two thousand a-year; and then working himself up to a pitch of enthusiastic generosity, he added, Elinor, I wish with all my heart it were TWICE as much, for your sake. END
BEGIN NOW Indeed I believe you, replied Elinor; but I am very sure that Colonel Brandon has not the smallest wish of marrying ME. END
BEGIN NOW You are mistaken, Elinor; you are very much mistaken. END
BEGIN NOW A very little trouble on your side secures him. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps just at present he may be undecided; the smallness of your fortune may make him hang back; his friends may all advise him against it. END
BEGIN NOW But some of those little attentions and encouragements which ladies can so easily give will fix him, in spite of himself. END
BEGIN NOW And there can be no reason why you should not try for him. END
BEGIN NOW It is not to be supposed that any prior attachment on your side&mdash;in short, you know as to an attachment of that kind, it is quite out of the question, the objections are insurmountable&mdash;you have too much sense not to see all that. END
BEGIN NOW Colonel Brandon must be the man; and no civility shall be wanting on my part to make him pleased with you and your family. END
BEGIN NOW It is a match that must give universal satisfaction. END
BEGIN NOW In short, it is a kind of thing that &mdash;lowering his voice to an important whisper&mdash; will be exceedingly welcome to ALL PARTIES. END
BEGIN NOW Recollecting himself, however, he added, That is, I mean to say&mdash;your friends are all truly anxious to see you well settled; Fanny particularly, for she has your interest very much at heart, I assure you. END
BEGIN NOW And her mother too, Mrs. Ferrars, a very good-natured woman, I am sure it would give her great pleasure; she said as much the other day. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor would not vouchsafe any answer. END
BEGIN NOW It would be something remarkable, now, he continued, something droll, if Fanny should have a brother and I a sister settling at the same time. END
BEGIN NOW And yet it is not very unlikely. END
BEGIN NOW Is Mr. Edward Ferrars, said Elinor, with resolution, going to be married? END
BEGIN NOW It is not actually settled, but there is such a thing in agitation. END
BEGIN NOW He has a most excellent mother. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Ferrars, with the utmost liberality, will come forward, and settle on him a thousand a year, if the match takes place. END
BEGIN NOW The lady is the Hon. END
BEGIN NOW Miss Morton, only daughter of the late Lord Morton, with thirty thousand pounds. END
BEGIN NOW A very desirable connection on both sides, and I have not a doubt of its taking place in time. END
BEGIN NOW A thousand a-year is a great deal for a mother to give away, to make over for ever; but Mrs. Ferrars has a noble spirit. END
BEGIN NOW To give you another instance of her liberality:&mdash;The other day, as soon as we came to town, aware that money could not be very plenty with us just now, she put bank-notes into Fanny's hands to the amount of two hundred pounds. END
BEGIN NOW And extremely acceptable it is, for we must live at a great expense while we are here. END
BEGIN NOW He paused for her assent and compassion; and she forced herself to say, Your expenses both in town and country must certainly be considerable; but your income is a large one. END
BEGIN NOW Not so large, I dare say, as many people suppose. END
BEGIN NOW I do not mean to complain, however; it is undoubtedly a comfortable one, and I hope will in time be better. END
BEGIN NOW The enclosure of Norland Common, now carrying on, is a most serious drain. END
BEGIN NOW And then I have made a little purchase within this half year; East Kingham Farm, you must remember the place, where old Gibson used to live. END
BEGIN NOW The land was so very desirable for me in every respect, so immediately adjoining my own property, that I felt it my duty to buy it. END
BEGIN NOW I could not have answered it to my conscience to let it fall into any other hands. END
BEGIN NOW A man must pay for his convenience; and it HAS cost me a vast deal of money. END
BEGIN NOW More than you think it really and intrinsically worth. END
BEGIN NOW Why, I hope not that. END
BEGIN NOW I might have sold it again, the next day, for more than I gave: but, with regard to the purchase-money, I might have been very unfortunate indeed; for the stocks were at that time so low, that if I had not happened to have the necessary sum in my banker's hands, I must have sold out to very great loss. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor could only smile. END
BEGIN NOW Other great and inevitable expenses too we have had on first coming to Norland. END
BEGIN NOW Our respected father, as you well know, bequeathed all the Stanhill effects that remained at Norland (and very valuable they were) to your mother. END
BEGIN NOW Far be it from me to repine at his doing so; he had an undoubted right to dispose of his own property as he chose, but, in consequence of it, we have been obliged to make large purchases of linen, china, &c. to supply the place of what was taken away. END
BEGIN NOW You may guess, after all these expenses, how very far we must be from being rich, and how acceptable Mrs. Ferrars's kindness is. END
BEGIN NOW Certainly, said Elinor; and assisted by her liberality, I hope you may yet live to be in easy circumstances. END
BEGIN NOW Another year or two may do much towards it, he gravely replied; but however there is still a great deal to be done. END
BEGIN NOW There is not a stone laid of Fanny's green-house, and nothing but the plan of the flower-garden marked out. END
BEGIN NOW Where is the green-house to be? END
BEGIN NOW Upon the knoll behind the house. END
BEGIN NOW The old walnut trees are all come down to make room for it. END
BEGIN NOW It will be a very fine object from many parts of the park, and the flower-garden will slope down just before it, and be exceedingly pretty. END
BEGIN NOW We have cleared away all the old thorns that grew in patches over the brow. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor kept her concern and her censure to herself; and was very thankful that Marianne was not present, to share the provocation. END
BEGIN NOW Having now said enough to make his poverty clear, and to do away the necessity of buying a pair of ear-rings for each of his sisters, in his next visit at Gray's his thoughts took a cheerfuller turn, and he began to congratulate Elinor on having such a friend as Mrs. Jennings. END
BEGIN NOW She seems a most valuable woman indeed&mdash;Her house, her style of living, all bespeak an exceeding good income; and it is an acquaintance that has not only been of great use to you hitherto, but in the end may prove materially advantageous.&mdash;Her inviting you to town is certainly a vast thing in your favour; and indeed, it speaks altogether so great a regard for you, that in all probability when she dies you will not be forgotten.&mdash; She must have a great deal to leave. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing at all, I should rather suppose; for she has only her jointure, which will descend to her children. END
BEGIN NOW But it is not to be imagined that she lives up to her income. END
BEGIN NOW Few people of common prudence will do THAT; and whatever she saves, she will be able to dispose of. END
BEGIN NOW And do you not think it more likely that she should leave it to her daughters, than to us? END
BEGIN NOW Her daughters are both exceedingly well married, and therefore I cannot perceive the necessity of her remembering them farther. END
BEGIN NOW Whereas, in my opinion, by her taking so much notice of you, and treating you in this kind of way, she has given you a sort of claim on her future consideration, which a conscientious woman would not disregard. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing can be kinder than her behaviour; and she can hardly do all this, without being aware of the expectation it raises. END
BEGIN NOW But she raises none in those most concerned. END
BEGIN NOW Indeed, brother, your anxiety for our welfare and prosperity carries you too far. END
BEGIN NOW Why, to be sure, said he, seeming to recollect himself, people have little, have very little in their power. END
BEGIN NOW But, my dear Elinor, what is the matter with Marianne?&mdash; she looks very unwell, has lost her colour, and is grown quite thin. END
BEGIN NOW Is she ill? END
BEGIN NOW She is not well, she has had a nervous complaint on her for several weeks. END
BEGIN NOW I am sorry for that. END
BEGIN NOW At her time of life, any thing of an illness destroys the bloom for ever! END
BEGIN NOW Hers has been a very short one! END
BEGIN NOW She was as handsome a girl last September, as I ever saw; and as likely to attract the man. END
BEGIN NOW There was something in her style of beauty, to please them particularly. END
BEGIN NOW I remember Fanny used to say that she would marry sooner and better than you did; not but what she is exceedingly fond of YOU, but so it happened to strike her. END
BEGIN NOW She will be mistaken, however. END
BEGIN NOW I question whether Marianne NOW, will marry a man worth more than five or six hundred a-year, at the utmost, and I am very much deceived if YOU do not do better. END
BEGIN NOW Dorsetshire! END
BEGIN NOW I know very little of Dorsetshire; but, my dear Elinor, I shall be exceedingly glad to know more of it; and I think I can answer for your having Fanny and myself among the earliest and best pleased of your visitors. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor tried very seriously to convince him that there was no likelihood of her marrying Colonel Brandon; but it was an expectation of too much pleasure to himself to be relinquished, and he was really resolved on seeking an intimacy with that gentleman, and promoting the marriage by every possible attention. END
BEGIN NOW He had just compunction enough for having done nothing for his sisters himself, to be exceedingly anxious that everybody else should do a great deal; and an offer from Colonel Brandon, or a legacy from Mrs. Jennings, was the easiest means of atoning for his own neglect. END
BEGIN NOW They were lucky enough to find Lady Middleton at home, and Sir John came in before their visit ended. END
BEGIN NOW Abundance of civilities passed on all sides. END
BEGIN NOW Sir John was ready to like anybody, and though Mr. Dashwood did not seem to know much about horses, he soon set him down as a very good-natured fellow: while Lady Middleton saw enough of fashion in his appearance to think his acquaintance worth having; and Mr. Dashwood went away delighted with both. END
BEGIN NOW I shall have a charming account to carry to Fanny, said he, as he walked back with his sister. END
BEGIN NOW Lady Middleton is really a most elegant woman! END
BEGIN NOW Such a woman as I am sure Fanny will be glad to know. END
BEGIN NOW And Mrs. Jennings too, an exceedingly well-behaved woman, though not so elegant as her daughter. END
BEGIN NOW Your sister need not have any scruple even of visiting HER, which, to say the truth, has been a little the case, and very naturally; for we only knew that Mrs. Jennings was the widow of a man who had got all his money in a low way; and Fanny and Mrs. Ferrars were both strongly prepossessed, that neither she nor her daughters were such kind of women as Fanny would like to associate with. END
BEGIN NOW But now I can carry her a most satisfactory account of both. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. John Dashwood had so much confidence in her husband's judgment, that she waited the very next day both on Mrs. Jennings and her daughter; and her confidence was rewarded by finding even the former, even the woman with whom her sisters were staying, by no means unworthy her notice; and as for Lady Middleton, she found her one of the most charming women in the world! END
BEGIN NOW Lady Middleton was equally pleased with Mrs. Dashwood. END
BEGIN NOW There was a kind of cold hearted selfishness on both sides, which mutually attracted them; and they sympathised with each other in an insipid propriety of demeanor, and a general want of understanding. END
BEGIN NOW The same manners, however, which recommended Mrs. John Dashwood to the good opinion of Lady Middleton did not suit the fancy of Mrs. Jennings, and to HER she appeared nothing more than a little proud-looking woman of uncordial address, who met her husband's sisters without any affection, and almost without having anything to say to them; for of the quarter of an hour bestowed on Berkeley Street, she sat at least seven minutes and a half in silence. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor wanted very much to know, though she did not chuse to ask, whether Edward was then in town; but nothing would have induced Fanny voluntarily to mention his name before her, till able to tell her that his marriage with Miss Morton was resolved on, or till her husband's expectations on Colonel Brandon were answered; because she believed them still so very much attached to each other, that they could not be too sedulously divided in word and deed on every occasion. END
BEGIN NOW The intelligence however, which SHE would not give, soon flowed from another quarter. END
BEGIN NOW Lucy came very shortly to claim Elinor's compassion on being unable to see Edward, though he had arrived in town with Mr. and Mrs. Dashwood. END
BEGIN NOW He dared not come to Bartlett's Buildings for fear of detection, and though their mutual impatience to meet, was not to be told, they could do nothing at present but write. END
BEGIN NOW Edward assured them himself of his being in town, within a very short time, by twice calling in Berkeley Street. END
BEGIN NOW Twice was his card found on the table, when they returned from their morning's engagements. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor was pleased that he had called; and still more pleased that she had missed him. END
BEGIN NOW The Dashwoods were so prodigiously delighted with the Middletons, that, though not much in the habit of giving anything, they determined to give them&mdash;a dinner; and soon after their acquaintance began, invited them to dine in Harley Street, where they had taken a very good house for three months. END
BEGIN NOW Their sisters and Mrs. Jennings were invited likewise, and John Dashwood was careful to secure Colonel Brandon, who, always glad to be where the Miss Dashwoods were, received his eager civilities with some surprise, but much more pleasure. END
BEGIN NOW They were to meet Mrs. Ferrars; but Elinor could not learn whether her sons were to be of the party. END
BEGIN NOW The expectation of seeing HER, however, was enough to make her interested in the engagement; for though she could now meet Edward's mother without that strong anxiety which had once promised to attend such an introduction, though she could now see her with perfect indifference as to her opinion of herself, her desire of being in company with Mrs. Ferrars, her curiosity to know what she was like, was as lively as ever. END
BEGIN NOW The interest with which she thus anticipated the party, was soon afterwards increased, more powerfully than pleasantly, by her hearing that the Miss Steeles were also to be at it. END
BEGIN NOW So well had they recommended themselves to Lady Middleton, so agreeable had their assiduities made them to her, that though Lucy was certainly not so elegant, and her sister not even genteel, she was as ready as Sir John to ask them to spend a week or two in Conduit Street; and it happened to be particularly convenient to the Miss Steeles, as soon as the Dashwoods' invitation was known, that their visit should begin a few days before the party took place. END
BEGIN NOW Their claims to the notice of Mrs. John Dashwood, as the nieces of the gentleman who for many years had had the care of her brother, might not have done much, however, towards procuring them seats at her table; but as Lady Middleton's guests they must be welcome; and Lucy, who had long wanted to be personally known to the family, to have a nearer view of their characters and her own difficulties, and to have an opportunity of endeavouring to please them, had seldom been happier in her life, than she was on receiving Mrs. John Dashwood's card. END
BEGIN NOW On Elinor its effect was very different. END
BEGIN NOW She began immediately to determine, that Edward who lived with his mother, must be asked as his mother was, to a party given by his sister; and to see him for the first time, after all that passed, in the company of Lucy!&mdash;she hardly knew how she could bear it! END
BEGIN NOW These apprehensions, perhaps, were not founded entirely on reason, and certainly not at all on truth. END
BEGIN NOW They were relieved however, not by her own recollection, but by the good will of Lucy, who believed herself to be inflicting a severe disappointment when she told her that Edward certainly would not be in Harley Street on Tuesday, and even hoped to be carrying the pain still farther by persuading her that he was kept away by the extreme affection for herself, which he could not conceal when they were together. END
BEGIN NOW The important Tuesday came that was to introduce the two young ladies to this formidable mother-in-law. END
BEGIN NOW Pity me, dear Miss Dashwood! END
BEGIN NOW said Lucy, as they walked up the stairs together&mdash;for the Middletons arrived so directly after Mrs. Jennings, that they all followed the servant at the same time&mdash; There is nobody here but you, that can feel for me.&mdash;I declare I can hardly stand. END
BEGIN NOW Good gracious!&mdash;In a moment I shall see the person that all my happiness depends on&mdash;that is to be my mother! END
BEGIN NOW &mdash; Elinor could have given her immediate relief by suggesting the possibility of its being Miss Morton's mother, rather than her own, whom they were about to behold; but instead of doing that, she assured her, and with great sincerity, that she did pity her&mdash;to the utter amazement of Lucy, who, though really uncomfortable herself, hoped at least to be an object of irrepressible envy to Elinor. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Ferrars was a little, thin woman, upright, even to formality, in her figure, and serious, even to sourness, in her aspect. END
BEGIN NOW Her complexion was sallow; and her features small, without beauty, and naturally without expression; but a lucky contraction of the brow had rescued her countenance from the disgrace of insipidity, by giving it the strong characters of pride and ill nature. END
BEGIN NOW She was not a woman of many words; for, unlike people in general, she proportioned them to the number of her ideas; and of the few syllables that did escape her, not one fell to the share of Miss Dashwood, whom she eyed with the spirited determination of disliking her at all events. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor could not NOW be made unhappy by this behaviour.&mdash; A few months ago it would have hurt her exceedingly; but it was not in Mrs. Ferrars' power to distress her by it now;&mdash;and the difference of her manners to the Miss Steeles, a difference which seemed purposely made to humble her more, only amused her. END
BEGIN NOW She could not but smile to see the graciousness of both mother and daughter towards the very person&mdash; for Lucy was particularly distinguished&mdash;whom of all others, had they known as much as she did, they would have been most anxious to mortify; while she herself, who had comparatively no power to wound them, sat pointedly slighted by both. END
BEGIN NOW But while she smiled at a graciousness so misapplied, she could not reflect on the mean-spirited folly from which it sprung, nor observe the studied attentions with which the Miss Steeles courted its continuance, without thoroughly despising them all four. END
BEGIN NOW Lucy was all exultation on being so honorably distinguished; and Miss Steele wanted only to be teazed about Dr. Davies to be perfectly happy. END
BEGIN NOW The dinner was a grand one, the servants were numerous, and every thing bespoke the Mistress's inclination for show, and the Master's ability to support it. END
BEGIN NOW In spite of the improvements and additions which were making to the Norland estate, and in spite of its owner having once been within some thousand pounds of being obliged to sell out at a loss, nothing gave any symptom of that indigence which he had tried to infer from it;&mdash;no poverty of any kind, except of conversation, appeared&mdash;but there, the deficiency was considerable. END
BEGIN NOW John Dashwood had not much to say for himself that was worth hearing, and his wife had still less. END
BEGIN NOW But there was no peculiar disgrace in this; for it was very much the case with the chief of their visitors, who almost all laboured under one or other of these disqualifications for being agreeable&mdash;Want of sense, either natural or improved&mdash;want of elegance&mdash;want of spirits&mdash;or want of temper. END
BEGIN NOW When the ladies withdrew to the drawing-room after dinner, this poverty was particularly evident, for the gentlemen HAD supplied the discourse with some variety&mdash;the variety of politics, inclosing land, and breaking horses&mdash;but then it was all over; and one subject only engaged the ladies till coffee came in, which was the comparative heights of Harry Dashwood, and Lady Middleton's second son William, who were nearly of the same age. END
BEGIN NOW Had both the children been there, the affair might have been determined too easily by measuring them at once; but as Harry only was present, it was all conjectural assertion on both sides; and every body had a right to be equally positive in their opinion, and to repeat it over and over again as often as they liked. END
BEGIN NOW The parties stood thus: The two mothers, though each really convinced that her own son was the tallest, politely decided in favour of the other. END
BEGIN NOW The two grandmothers, with not less partiality, but more sincerity, were equally earnest in support of their own descendant. END
BEGIN NOW Lucy, who was hardly less anxious to please one parent than the other, thought the boys were both remarkably tall for their age, and could not conceive that there could be the smallest difference in the world between them; and Miss Steele, with yet greater address gave it, as fast as she could, in favour of each. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor, having once delivered her opinion on William's side, by which she offended Mrs. Ferrars and Fanny still more, did not see the necessity of enforcing it by any farther assertion; and Marianne, when called on for hers, offended them all, by declaring that she had no opinion to give, as she had never thought about it. END
BEGIN NOW Before her removing from Norland, Elinor had painted a very pretty pair of screens for her sister-in-law, which being now just mounted and brought home, ornamented her present drawing room; and these screens, catching the eye of John Dashwood on his following the other gentlemen into the room, were officiously handed by him to Colonel Brandon for his admiration. END
BEGIN NOW These are done by my eldest sister, said he; and you, as a man of taste, will, I dare say, be pleased with them. END
BEGIN NOW I do not know whether you have ever happened to see any of her performances before, but she is in general reckoned to draw extremely well. END
BEGIN NOW The Colonel, though disclaiming all pretensions to connoisseurship, warmly admired the screens, as he would have done any thing painted by Miss Dashwood; and on the curiosity of the others being of course excited, they were handed round for general inspection. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Ferrars, not aware of their being Elinor's work, particularly requested to look at them; and after they had received gratifying testimony of Lady Middletons's approbation, Fanny presented them to her mother, considerately informing her, at the same time, that they were done by Miss Dashwood. END
BEGIN NOW Hum &mdash;said Mrs. Ferrars&mdash; very pretty, &mdash;and without regarding them at all, returned them to her daughter. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps Fanny thought for a moment that her mother had been quite rude enough,&mdash;for, colouring a little, she immediately said, They are very pretty, ma'am&mdash;an't they? END
BEGIN NOW But then again, the dread of having been too civil, too encouraging herself, probably came over her, for she presently added, Do you not think they are something in Miss Morton's style of painting, Ma'am?&mdash;She DOES paint most delightfully!&mdash;How beautifully her last landscape is done! END
BEGIN NOW Beautifully indeed! END
BEGIN NOW But SHE does every thing well. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne could not bear this.&mdash;She was already greatly displeased with Mrs. Ferrars; and such ill-timed praise of another, at Elinor's expense, though she had not any notion of what was principally meant by it, provoked her immediately to say with warmth, This is admiration of a very particular kind!&mdash;what is Miss Morton to us?&mdash;who knows, or who cares, for her?&mdash;it is Elinor of whom WE think and speak. END
BEGIN NOW And so saying, she took the screens out of her sister-in-law's hands, to admire them herself as they ought to be admired. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Ferrars looked exceedingly angry, and drawing herself up more stiffly than ever, pronounced in retort this bitter philippic, Miss Morton is Lord Morton's daughter. END
BEGIN NOW Fanny looked very angry too, and her husband was all in a fright at his sister's audacity. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor was much more hurt by Marianne's warmth than she had been by what produced it; but Colonel Brandon's eyes, as they were fixed on Marianne, declared that he noticed only what was amiable in it, the affectionate heart which could not bear to see a sister slighted in the smallest point. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne's feelings did not stop here. END
BEGIN NOW The cold insolence of Mrs. Ferrars's general behaviour to her sister, seemed, to her, to foretell such difficulties and distresses to Elinor, as her own wounded heart taught her to think of with horror; and urged by a strong impulse of affectionate sensibility, she moved after a moment, to her sister's chair, and putting one arm round her neck, and one cheek close to hers, said in a low, but eager, voice, Dear, dear Elinor, don't mind them. END
BEGIN NOW Don't let them make YOU unhappy. END
BEGIN NOW She could say no more; her spirits were quite overcome, and hiding her face on Elinor's shoulder, she burst into tears. END
BEGIN NOW Every body's attention was called, and almost every body was concerned.&mdash;Colonel Brandon rose up and went to them without knowing what he did.&mdash;Mrs. Jennings, with a very intelligent Ah! END
BEGIN NOW poor dear, immediately gave her her salts; and Sir John felt so desperately enraged against the author of this nervous distress, that he instantly changed his seat to one close by Lucy Steele, and gave her, in a whisper, a brief account of the whole shocking affair. END
BEGIN NOW In a few minutes, however, Marianne was recovered enough to put an end to the bustle, and sit down among the rest; though her spirits retained the impression of what had passed, the whole evening. END
BEGIN NOW Poor Marianne! END
BEGIN NOW said her brother to Colonel Brandon, in a low voice, as soon as he could secure his attention,&mdash; She has not such good health as her sister,&mdash;she is very nervous,&mdash;she has not Elinor's constitution;&mdash;and one must allow that there is something very trying to a young woman who HAS BEEN a beauty in the loss of her personal attractions. END
BEGIN NOW You would not think it perhaps, but Marianne WAS remarkably handsome a few months ago; quite as handsome as Elinor.&mdash; Now you see it is all gone. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor's curiosity to see Mrs. Ferrars was satisfied.&mdash; She had found in her every thing that could tend to make a farther connection between the families undesirable.&mdash; She had seen enough of her pride, her meanness, and her determined prejudice against herself, to comprehend all the difficulties that must have perplexed the engagement, and retarded the marriage, of Edward and herself, had he been otherwise free;&mdash;and she had seen almost enough to be thankful for her OWN sake, that one greater obstacle preserved her from suffering under any other of Mrs. Ferrars's creation, preserved her from all dependence upon her caprice, or any solicitude for her good opinion. END
BEGIN NOW Or at least, if she did not bring herself quite to rejoice in Edward's being fettered to Lucy, she determined, that had Lucy been more amiable, she OUGHT to have rejoiced. END
BEGIN NOW She wondered that Lucy's spirits could be so very much elevated by the civility of Mrs. Ferrars;&mdash;that her interest and her vanity should so very much blind her as to make the attention which seemed only paid her because she was NOT ELINOR, appear a compliment to herself&mdash;or to allow her to derive encouragement from a preference only given her, because her real situation was unknown. END
BEGIN NOW But that it was so, had not only been declared by Lucy's eyes at the time, but was declared over again the next morning more openly, for at her particular desire, Lady Middleton set her down in Berkeley Street on the chance of seeing Elinor alone, to tell her how happy she was. END
BEGIN NOW The chance proved a lucky one, for a message from Mrs. Palmer soon after she arrived, carried Mrs. Jennings away. END
BEGIN NOW My dear friend, cried Lucy, as soon as they were by themselves, I come to talk to you of my happiness. END
BEGIN NOW Could anything be so flattering as Mrs. Ferrars's way of treating me yesterday? END
BEGIN NOW So exceeding affable as she was!&mdash;You know how I dreaded the thoughts of seeing her;&mdash;but the very moment I was introduced, there was such an affability in her behaviour as really should seem to say, she had quite took a fancy to me. END
BEGIN NOW Now was not it so?&mdash; You saw it all; and was not you quite struck with it? END
BEGIN NOW She was certainly very civil to you. END
BEGIN NOW Civil!&mdash;Did you see nothing but only civility?&mdash; I saw a vast deal more. END
BEGIN NOW Such kindness as fell to the share of nobody but me!&mdash;No pride, no hauteur, and your sister just the same&mdash;all sweetness and affability! END
BEGIN NOW Elinor wished to talk of something else, but Lucy still pressed her to own that she had reason for her happiness; and Elinor was obliged to go on.&mdash; Undoubtedly, if they had known your engagement, said she, nothing could be more flattering than their treatment of you;&mdash;but as that was not the case &mdash; I guessed you would say so, &mdash;replied Lucy quickly&mdash; but there was no reason in the world why Mrs. Ferrars should seem to like me, if she did not, and her liking me is every thing. END
BEGIN NOW You shan't talk me out of my satisfaction. END
BEGIN NOW I am sure it will all end well, and there will be no difficulties at all, to what I used to think. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Ferrars is a charming woman, and so is your sister. END
BEGIN NOW They are both delightful women, indeed!&mdash;I wonder I should never hear you say how agreeable Mrs. Dashwood was! END
BEGIN NOW To this Elinor had no answer to make, and did not attempt any. END
BEGIN NOW Are you ill, Miss Dashwood?&mdash;you seem low&mdash;you don't speak;&mdash;sure you an't well. END
BEGIN NOW I never was in better health. END
BEGIN NOW I am glad of it with all my heart; but really you did not look it. END
BEGIN NOW I should be sorry to have YOU ill; you, that have been the greatest comfort to me in the world!&mdash;Heaven knows what I should have done without your friendship. END
BEGIN NOW &mdash; Elinor tried to make a civil answer, though doubting her own success. END
BEGIN NOW But it seemed to satisfy Lucy, for she directly replied, Indeed I am perfectly convinced of your regard for me, and next to Edward's love, it is the greatest comfort I have.&mdash;Poor Edward!&mdash;But now there is one good thing, we shall be able to meet, and meet pretty often, for Lady Middleton's delighted with Mrs. Dashwood, so we shall be a good deal in Harley Street, I dare say, and Edward spends half his time with his sister&mdash;besides, Lady Middleton and Mrs. Ferrars will visit now;&mdash;and Mrs. Ferrars and your sister were both so good to say more than once, they should always be glad to see me.&mdash; They are such charming women!&mdash;I am sure if ever you tell your sister what I think of her, you cannot speak too high. END
BEGIN NOW But Elinor would not give her any encouragement to hope that she SHOULD tell her sister. END
BEGIN NOW Lucy continued. END
BEGIN NOW I am sure I should have seen it in a moment, if Mrs. Ferrars had took a dislike to me. END
BEGIN NOW If she had only made me a formal courtesy, for instance, without saying a word, and never after had took any notice of me, and never looked at me in a pleasant way&mdash;you know what I mean&mdash;if I had been treated in that forbidding sort of way, I should have gave it all up in despair. END
BEGIN NOW I could not have stood it. END
BEGIN NOW For where she DOES dislike, I know it is most violent. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor was prevented from making any reply to this civil triumph, by the door's being thrown open, the servant's announcing Mr. Ferrars, and Edward's immediately walking in. END
BEGIN NOW It was a very awkward moment; and the countenance of each shewed that it was so. END
BEGIN NOW They all looked exceedingly foolish; and Edward seemed to have as great an inclination to walk out of the room again, as to advance farther into it. END
BEGIN NOW The very circumstance, in its unpleasantest form, which they would each have been most anxious to avoid, had fallen on them.&mdash;They were not only all three together, but were together without the relief of any other person. END
BEGIN NOW The ladies recovered themselves first. END
BEGIN NOW It was not Lucy's business to put herself forward, and the appearance of secrecy must still be kept up. END
BEGIN NOW She could therefore only LOOK her tenderness, and after slightly addressing him, said no more. END
BEGIN NOW But Elinor had more to do; and so anxious was she, for his sake and her own, to do it well, that she forced herself, after a moment's recollection, to welcome him, with a look and manner that were almost easy, and almost open; and another struggle, another effort still improved them. END
BEGIN NOW She would not allow the presence of Lucy, nor the consciousness of some injustice towards herself, to deter her from saying that she was happy to see him, and that she had very much regretted being from home, when he called before in Berkeley Street. END
BEGIN NOW She would not be frightened from paying him those attentions which, as a friend and almost a relation, were his due, by the observant eyes of Lucy, though she soon perceived them to be narrowly watching her. END
BEGIN NOW Her manners gave some re-assurance to Edward, and he had courage enough to sit down; but his embarrassment still exceeded that of the ladies in a proportion, which the case rendered reasonable, though his sex might make it rare; for his heart had not the indifference of Lucy's, nor could his conscience have quite the ease of Elinor's. END
BEGIN NOW Lucy, with a demure and settled air, seemed determined to make no contribution to the comfort of the others, and would not say a word; and almost every thing that WAS said, proceeded from Elinor, who was obliged to volunteer all the information about her mother's health, their coming to town, &c. which Edward ought to have inquired about, but never did. END
BEGIN NOW Her exertions did not stop here; for she soon afterwards felt herself so heroically disposed as to determine, under pretence of fetching Marianne, to leave the others by themselves; and she really did it, and THAT in the handsomest manner, for she loitered away several minutes on the landing-place, with the most high-minded fortitude, before she went to her sister. END
BEGIN NOW When that was once done, however, it was time for the raptures of Edward to cease; for Marianne's joy hurried her into the drawing-room immediately. END
BEGIN NOW Her pleasure in seeing him was like every other of her feelings, strong in itself, and strongly spoken. END
BEGIN NOW She met him with a hand that would be taken, and a voice that expressed the affection of a sister. END
BEGIN NOW Dear Edward! END
BEGIN NOW she cried, this is a moment of great happiness!&mdash;This would almost make amends for every thing! END
BEGIN NOW Edward tried to return her kindness as it deserved, but before such witnesses he dared not say half what he really felt. END
BEGIN NOW Again they all sat down, and for a moment or two all were silent; while Marianne was looking with the most speaking tenderness, sometimes at Edward and sometimes at Elinor, regretting only that their delight in each other should be checked by Lucy's unwelcome presence. END
BEGIN NOW Edward was the first to speak, and it was to notice Marianne's altered looks, and express his fear of her not finding London agree with her. END
BEGIN NOW Oh, don't think of me! END
BEGIN NOW she replied with spirited earnestness, though her eyes were filled with tears as she spoke, don't think of MY health. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor is well, you see. END
BEGIN NOW That must be enough for us both. END
BEGIN NOW This remark was not calculated to make Edward or Elinor more easy, nor to conciliate the good will of Lucy, who looked up at Marianne with no very benignant expression. END
BEGIN NOW Do you like London? END
BEGIN NOW said Edward, willing to say any thing that might introduce another subject. END
BEGIN NOW Not at all. END
BEGIN NOW I expected much pleasure in it, but I have found none. END
BEGIN NOW The sight of you, Edward, is the only comfort it has afforded; and thank Heaven! END
BEGIN NOW you are what you always were! END
BEGIN NOW She paused&mdash;no one spoke. END
BEGIN NOW I think, Elinor, she presently added, we must employ Edward to take care of us in our return to Barton. END
BEGIN NOW In a week or two, I suppose, we shall be going; and, I trust, Edward will not be very unwilling to accept the charge. END
BEGIN NOW Poor Edward muttered something, but what it was, nobody knew, not even himself. END
BEGIN NOW But Marianne, who saw his agitation, and could easily trace it to whatever cause best pleased herself, was perfectly satisfied, and soon talked of something else. END
BEGIN NOW We spent such a day, Edward, in Harley Street yesterday! END
BEGIN NOW So dull, so wretchedly dull!&mdash;But I have much to say to you on that head, which cannot be said now. END
BEGIN NOW And with this admirable discretion did she defer the assurance of her finding their mutual relatives more disagreeable than ever, and of her being particularly disgusted with his mother, till they were more in private. END
BEGIN NOW But why were you not there, Edward?&mdash;Why did you not come? END
BEGIN NOW I was engaged elsewhere. END
BEGIN NOW Engaged! END
BEGIN NOW But what was that, when such friends were to be met? END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps, Miss Marianne, cried Lucy, eager to take some revenge on her, you think young men never stand upon engagements, if they have no mind to keep them, little as well as great. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor was very angry, but Marianne seemed entirely insensible of the sting; for she calmly replied, Not so, indeed; for, seriously speaking, I am very sure that conscience only kept Edward from Harley Street. END
BEGIN NOW And I really believe he HAS the most delicate conscience in the world; the most scrupulous in performing every engagement, however minute, and however it may make against his interest or pleasure. END
BEGIN NOW He is the most fearful of giving pain, of wounding expectation, and the most incapable of being selfish, of any body I ever saw. END
BEGIN NOW Edward, it is so, and I will say it. END
BEGIN NOW What! END
BEGIN NOW are you never to hear yourself praised!&mdash;Then you must be no friend of mine; for those who will accept of my love and esteem, must submit to my open commendation. END
BEGIN NOW The nature of her commendation, in the present case, however, happened to be particularly ill-suited to the feelings of two thirds of her auditors, and was so very unexhilarating to Edward, that he very soon got up to go away. END
BEGIN NOW Going so soon! END
BEGIN NOW said Marianne; my dear Edward, this must not be. END
BEGIN NOW And drawing him a little aside, she whispered her persuasion that Lucy could not stay much longer. END
BEGIN NOW But even this encouragement failed, for he would go; and Lucy, who would have outstaid him, had his visit lasted two hours, soon afterwards went away. END
BEGIN NOW What can bring her here so often? END
BEGIN NOW said Marianne, on her leaving them. END
BEGIN NOW Could not she see that we wanted her gone!&mdash;how teazing to Edward! END
BEGIN NOW Why so?&mdash;we were all his friends, and Lucy has been the longest known to him of any. END
BEGIN NOW It is but natural that he should like to see her as well as ourselves. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne looked at her steadily, and said, You know, Elinor, that this is a kind of talking which I cannot bear. END
BEGIN NOW If you only hope to have your assertion contradicted, as I must suppose to be the case, you ought to recollect that I am the last person in the world to do it. END
BEGIN NOW I cannot descend to be tricked out of assurances, that are not really wanted. END
BEGIN NOW She then left the room; and Elinor dared not follow her to say more, for bound as she was by her promise of secrecy to Lucy, she could give no information that would convince Marianne; and painful as the consequences of her still continuing in an error might be, she was obliged to submit to it. END
BEGIN NOW All that she could hope, was that Edward would not often expose her or himself to the distress of hearing Marianne's mistaken warmth, nor to the repetition of any other part of the pain that had attended their recent meeting&mdash;and this she had every reason to expect. END
BEGIN NOW Within a few days after this meeting, the newspapers announced to the world, that the lady of Thomas Palmer, Esq. END
BEGIN NOW was safely delivered of a son and heir; a very interesting and satisfactory paragraph, at least to all those intimate connections who knew it before. END
BEGIN NOW This event, highly important to Mrs. Jennings's happiness, produced a temporary alteration in the disposal of her time, and influenced, in a like degree, the engagements of her young friends; for as she wished to be as much as possible with Charlotte, she went thither every morning as soon as she was dressed, and did not return till late in the evening; and the Miss Dashwoods, at the particular request of the Middletons, spent the whole of every day in Conduit Street. END
BEGIN NOW For their own comfort they would much rather have remained, at least all the morning, in Mrs. Jennings's house; but it was not a thing to be urged against the wishes of everybody. END
BEGIN NOW Their hours were therefore made over to Lady Middleton and the two Miss Steeles, by whom their company, in fact was as little valued, as it was professedly sought. END
BEGIN NOW They had too much sense to be desirable companions to the former; and by the latter they were considered with a jealous eye, as intruding on THEIR ground, and sharing the kindness which they wanted to monopolize. END
BEGIN NOW Though nothing could be more polite than Lady Middleton's behaviour to Elinor and Marianne, she did not really like them at all. END
BEGIN NOW Because they neither flattered herself nor her children, she could not believe them good-natured; and because they were fond of reading, she fancied them satirical: perhaps without exactly knowing what it was to be satirical; but THAT did not signify. END
BEGIN NOW It was censure in common use, and easily given. END
BEGIN NOW Their presence was a restraint both on her and on Lucy. END
BEGIN NOW It checked the idleness of one, and the business of the other. END
BEGIN NOW Lady Middleton was ashamed of doing nothing before them, and the flattery which Lucy was proud to think of and administer at other times, she feared they would despise her for offering. END
BEGIN NOW Miss Steele was the least discomposed of the three, by their presence; and it was in their power to reconcile her to it entirely. END
BEGIN NOW Would either of them only have given her a full and minute account of the whole affair between Marianne and Mr. Willoughby, she would have thought herself amply rewarded for the sacrifice of the best place by the fire after dinner, which their arrival occasioned. END
BEGIN NOW But this conciliation was not granted; for though she often threw out expressions of pity for her sister to Elinor, and more than once dropt a reflection on the inconstancy of beaux before Marianne, no effect was produced, but a look of indifference from the former, or of disgust in the latter. END
BEGIN NOW An effort even yet lighter might have made her their friend. END
BEGIN NOW Would they only have laughed at her about the Doctor! END
BEGIN NOW But so little were they, anymore than the others, inclined to oblige her, that if Sir John dined from home, she might spend a whole day without hearing any other raillery on the subject, than what she was kind enough to bestow on herself. END
BEGIN NOW All these jealousies and discontents, however, were so totally unsuspected by Mrs. Jennings, that she thought it a delightful thing for the girls to be together; and generally congratulated her young friends every night, on having escaped the company of a stupid old woman so long. END
BEGIN NOW She joined them sometimes at Sir John's, sometimes at her own house; but wherever it was, she always came in excellent spirits, full of delight and importance, attributing Charlotte's well doing to her own care, and ready to give so exact, so minute a detail of her situation, as only Miss Steele had curiosity enough to desire. END
BEGIN NOW One thing DID disturb her; and of that she made her daily complaint. END
BEGIN NOW Mr. Palmer maintained the common, but unfatherly opinion among his sex, of all infants being alike; and though she could plainly perceive, at different times, the most striking resemblance between this baby and every one of his relations on both sides, there was no convincing his father of it; no persuading him to believe that it was not exactly like every other baby of the same age; nor could he even be brought to acknowledge the simple proposition of its being the finest child in the world. END
BEGIN NOW I come now to the relation of a misfortune, which about this time befell Mrs. John Dashwood. END
BEGIN NOW It so happened that while her two sisters with Mrs. Jennings were first calling on her in Harley Street, another of her acquaintance had dropt in&mdash;a circumstance in itself not apparently likely to produce evil to her. END
BEGIN NOW But while the imaginations of other people will carry them away to form wrong judgments of our conduct, and to decide on it by slight appearances, one's happiness must in some measure be always at the mercy of chance. END
BEGIN NOW In the present instance, this last-arrived lady allowed her fancy to so far outrun truth and probability, that on merely hearing the name of the Miss Dashwoods, and understanding them to be Mr. Dashwood's sisters, she immediately concluded them to be staying in Harley Street; and this misconstruction produced within a day or two afterwards, cards of invitation for them as well as for their brother and sister, to a small musical party at her house. END
