BEGIN NOW The consequence of which was, that Mrs. John Dashwood was obliged to submit not only to the exceedingly great inconvenience of sending her carriage for the Miss Dashwoods, but, what was still worse, must be subject to all the unpleasantness of appearing to treat them with attention: and who could tell that they might not expect to go out with her a second time? END
BEGIN NOW The power of disappointing them, it was true, must always be hers. END
BEGIN NOW But that was not enough; for when people are determined on a mode of conduct which they know to be wrong, they feel injured by the expectation of any thing better from them. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne had now been brought by degrees, so much into the habit of going out every day, that it was become a matter of indifference to her, whether she went or not: and she prepared quietly and mechanically for every evening's engagement, though without expecting the smallest amusement from any, and very often without knowing, till the last moment, where it was to take her. END
BEGIN NOW To her dress and appearance she was grown so perfectly indifferent, as not to bestow half the consideration on it, during the whole of her toilet, which it received from Miss Steele in the first five minutes of their being together, when it was finished. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing escaped HER minute observation and general curiosity; she saw every thing, and asked every thing; was never easy till she knew the price of every part of Marianne's dress; could have guessed the number of her gowns altogether with better judgment than Marianne herself, and was not without hopes of finding out before they parted, how much her washing cost per week, and how much she had every year to spend upon herself. END
BEGIN NOW The impertinence of these kind of scrutinies, moreover, was generally concluded with a compliment, which though meant as its douceur, was considered by Marianne as the greatest impertinence of all; for after undergoing an examination into the value and make of her gown, the colour of her shoes, and the arrangement of her hair, she was almost sure of being told that upon her word she looked vastly smart, and she dared to say she would make a great many conquests. END
BEGIN NOW With such encouragement as this, was she dismissed on the present occasion, to her brother's carriage; which they were ready to enter five minutes after it stopped at the door, a punctuality not very agreeable to their sister-in-law, who had preceded them to the house of her acquaintance, and was there hoping for some delay on their part that might inconvenience either herself or her coachman. END
BEGIN NOW The events of this evening were not very remarkable. END
BEGIN NOW The party, like other musical parties, comprehended a great many people who had real taste for the performance, and a great many more who had none at all; and the performers themselves were, as usual, in their own estimation, and that of their immediate friends, the first private performers in England. END
BEGIN NOW As Elinor was neither musical, nor affecting to be so, she made no scruple of turning her eyes from the grand pianoforte, whenever it suited her, and unrestrained even by the presence of a harp, and violoncello, would fix them at pleasure on any other object in the room. END
BEGIN NOW In one of these excursive glances she perceived among a group of young men, the very he, who had given them a lecture on toothpick-cases at Gray's. END
BEGIN NOW She perceived him soon afterwards looking at herself, and speaking familiarly to her brother; and had just determined to find out his name from the latter, when they both came towards her, and Mr. Dashwood introduced him to her as Mr. Robert Ferrars. END
BEGIN NOW He addressed her with easy civility, and twisted his head into a bow which assured her as plainly as words could have done, that he was exactly the coxcomb she had heard him described to be by Lucy. END
BEGIN NOW Happy had it been for her, if her regard for Edward had depended less on his own merit, than on the merit of his nearest relations! END
BEGIN NOW For then his brother's bow must have given the finishing stroke to what the ill-humour of his mother and sister would have begun. END
BEGIN NOW But while she wondered at the difference of the two young men, she did not find that the emptiness of conceit of the one, put her out of all charity with the modesty and worth of the other. END
BEGIN NOW Why they WERE different, Robert exclaimed to her himself in the course of a quarter of an hour's conversation; for, talking of his brother, and lamenting the extreme GAUCHERIE which he really believed kept him from mixing in proper society, he candidly and generously attributed it much less to any natural deficiency, than to the misfortune of a private education; while he himself, though probably without any particular, any material superiority by nature, merely from the advantage of a public school, was as well fitted to mix in the world as any other man. END
BEGIN NOW Upon my soul, he added, I believe it is nothing more; and so I often tell my mother, when she is grieving about it. END
BEGIN NOW 'My dear Madam,' I always say to her, 'you must make yourself easy. END
BEGIN NOW The evil is now irremediable, and it has been entirely your own doing. END
BEGIN NOW Why would you be persuaded by my uncle, Sir Robert, against your own judgment, to place Edward under private tuition, at the most critical time of his life? END
BEGIN NOW If you had only sent him to Westminster as well as myself, instead of sending him to Mr. Pratt's, all this would have been prevented.' END
BEGIN NOW This is the way in which I always consider the matter, and my mother is perfectly convinced of her error. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor would not oppose his opinion, because, whatever might be her general estimation of the advantage of a public school, she could not think of Edward's abode in Mr. Pratt's family, with any satisfaction. END
BEGIN NOW You reside in Devonshire, I think, &mdash;was his next observation, in a cottage near Dawlish. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor set him right as to its situation; and it seemed rather surprising to him that anybody could live in Devonshire, without living near Dawlish. END
BEGIN NOW He bestowed his hearty approbation however on their species of house. END
BEGIN NOW For my own part, said he, I am excessively fond of a cottage; there is always so much comfort, so much elegance about them. END
BEGIN NOW And I protest, if I had any money to spare, I should buy a little land and build one myself, within a short distance of London, where I might drive myself down at any time, and collect a few friends about me, and be happy. END
BEGIN NOW I advise every body who is going to build, to build a cottage. END
BEGIN NOW My friend Lord Courtland came to me the other day on purpose to ask my advice, and laid before me three different plans of Bonomi's. END
BEGIN NOW I was to decide on the best of them. END
BEGIN NOW 'My dear Courtland,' said I, immediately throwing them all into the fire, 'do not adopt either of them, but by all means build a cottage.' END
BEGIN NOW And that I fancy, will be the end of it. END
BEGIN NOW Some people imagine that there can be no accommodations, no space in a cottage; but this is all a mistake. END
BEGIN NOW I was last month at my friend Elliott's, near Dartford. END
BEGIN NOW Lady Elliott wished to give a dance. END
BEGIN NOW 'But how can it be done?' END
BEGIN NOW said she; 'my dear Ferrars, do tell me how it is to be managed. END
BEGIN NOW There is not a room in this cottage that will hold ten couple, and where can the supper be?' END
BEGIN NOW I immediately saw that there could be no difficulty in it, so I said, 'My dear Lady Elliott, do not be uneasy. END
BEGIN NOW The dining parlour will admit eighteen couple with ease; card-tables may be placed in the drawing-room; the library may be open for tea and other refreshments; and let the supper be set out in the saloon.' END
BEGIN NOW Lady Elliott was delighted with the thought. END
BEGIN NOW We measured the dining-room, and found it would hold exactly eighteen couple, and the affair was arranged precisely after my plan. END
BEGIN NOW So that, in fact, you see, if people do but know how to set about it, every comfort may be as well enjoyed in a cottage as in the most spacious dwelling. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor agreed to it all, for she did not think he deserved the compliment of rational opposition. END
BEGIN NOW As John Dashwood had no more pleasure in music than his eldest sister, his mind was equally at liberty to fix on any thing else; and a thought struck him during the evening, which he communicated to his wife, for her approbation, when they got home. END
BEGIN NOW The consideration of Mrs. Dennison's mistake, in supposing his sisters their guests, had suggested the propriety of their being really invited to become such, while Mrs. Jennings's engagements kept her from home. END
BEGIN NOW The expense would be nothing, the inconvenience not more; and it was altogether an attention which the delicacy of his conscience pointed out to be requisite to its complete enfranchisement from his promise to his father. END
BEGIN NOW Fanny was startled at the proposal. END
BEGIN NOW I do not see how it can be done, said she, without affronting Lady Middleton, for they spend every day with her; otherwise I should be exceedingly glad to do it. END
BEGIN NOW You know I am always ready to pay them any attention in my power, as my taking them out this evening shews. END
BEGIN NOW But they are Lady Middleton's visitors. END
BEGIN NOW How can I ask them away from her? END
BEGIN NOW Her husband, but with great humility, did not see the force of her objection. END
BEGIN NOW They had already spent a week in this manner in Conduit Street, and Lady Middleton could not be displeased at their giving the same number of days to such near relations. END
BEGIN NOW Fanny paused a moment, and then, with fresh vigor, said, My love I would ask them with all my heart, if it was in my power. END
BEGIN NOW But I had just settled within myself to ask the Miss Steeles to spend a few days with us. END
BEGIN NOW They are very well behaved, good kind of girls; and I think the attention is due to them, as their uncle did so very well by Edward. END
BEGIN NOW We can ask your sisters some other year, you know; but the Miss Steeles may not be in town any more. END
BEGIN NOW I am sure you will like them; indeed, you DO like them, you know, very much already, and so does my mother; and they are such favourites with Harry! END
BEGIN NOW Mr. Dashwood was convinced. END
BEGIN NOW He saw the necessity of inviting the Miss Steeles immediately, and his conscience was pacified by the resolution of inviting his sisters another year; at the same time, however, slyly suspecting that another year would make the invitation needless, by bringing Elinor to town as Colonel Brandon's wife, and Marianne as THEIR visitor. END
BEGIN NOW Fanny, rejoicing in her escape, and proud of the ready wit that had procured it, wrote the next morning to Lucy, to request her company and her sister's, for some days, in Harley Street, as soon as Lady Middleton could spare them. END
BEGIN NOW This was enough to make Lucy really and reasonably happy. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Dashwood seemed actually working for her, herself; cherishing all her hopes, and promoting all her views! END
BEGIN NOW Such an opportunity of being with Edward and his family was, above all things, the most material to her interest, and such an invitation the most gratifying to her feelings! END
BEGIN NOW It was an advantage that could not be too gratefully acknowledged, nor too speedily made use of; and the visit to Lady Middleton, which had not before had any precise limits, was instantly discovered to have been always meant to end in two days' time. END
BEGIN NOW When the note was shown to Elinor, as it was within ten minutes after its arrival, it gave her, for the first time, some share in the expectations of Lucy; for such a mark of uncommon kindness, vouchsafed on so short an acquaintance, seemed to declare that the good-will towards her arose from something more than merely malice against herself; and might be brought, by time and address, to do every thing that Lucy wished. END
BEGIN NOW Her flattery had already subdued the pride of Lady Middleton, and made an entry into the close heart of Mrs. John Dashwood; and these were effects that laid open the probability of greater. END
BEGIN NOW The Miss Steeles removed to Harley Street, and all that reached Elinor of their influence there, strengthened her expectation of the event. END
BEGIN NOW Sir John, who called on them more than once, brought home such accounts of the favour they were in, as must be universally striking. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Dashwood had never been so much pleased with any young women in her life, as she was with them; had given each of them a needle book made by some emigrant; called Lucy by her Christian name; and did not know whether she should ever be able to part with them. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Palmer was so well at the end of a fortnight, that her mother felt it no longer necessary to give up the whole of her time to her; and, contenting herself with visiting her once or twice a day, returned from that period to her own home, and her own habits, in which she found the Miss Dashwoods very ready to resume their former share. END
BEGIN NOW About the third or fourth morning after their being thus resettled in Berkeley Street, Mrs. Jennings, on returning from her ordinary visit to Mrs. Palmer, entered the drawing-room, where Elinor was sitting by herself, with an air of such hurrying importance as prepared her to hear something wonderful; and giving her time only to form that idea, began directly to justify it, by saying, Lord! END
BEGIN NOW my dear Miss Dashwood! END
BEGIN NOW have you heard the news? END
BEGIN NOW No, ma'am. END
BEGIN NOW What is it? END
BEGIN NOW Something so strange! END
BEGIN NOW But you shall hear it all.&mdash; When I got to Mr. Palmer's, I found Charlotte quite in a fuss about the child. END
BEGIN NOW She was sure it was very ill&mdash;it cried, and fretted, and was all over pimples. END
BEGIN NOW So I looked at it directly, and, 'Lord! END
BEGIN NOW my dear,' says I, 'it is nothing in the world, but the red gum&mdash;' and nurse said just the same. END
BEGIN NOW But Charlotte, she would not be satisfied, so Mr. Donavan was sent for; and luckily he happened to just come in from Harley Street, so he stepped over directly, and as soon as ever Mama, he said just as we did, that it was nothing in the world but the red gum, and then Charlotte was easy. END
BEGIN NOW And so, just as he was going away again, it came into my head, I am sure I do not know how I happened to think of it, but it came into my head to ask him if there was any news. END
BEGIN NOW So upon that, he smirked, and simpered, and looked grave, and seemed to know something or other, and at last he said in a whisper, 'For fear any unpleasant report should reach the young ladies under your care as to their sister's indisposition, I think it advisable to say, that I believe there is no great reason for alarm; I hope Mrs. Dashwood will do very well.' END
BEGIN NOW What! END
BEGIN NOW is Fanny ill? END
BEGIN NOW That is exactly what I said, my dear. END
BEGIN NOW 'Lord!' END
BEGIN NOW says I, 'is Mrs. Dashwood ill?' END
BEGIN NOW So then it all came out; and the long and the short of the matter, by all I can learn, seems to be this. END
BEGIN NOW Mr. Edward Ferrars, the very young man I used to joke with you about (but however, as it turns out, I am monstrous glad there was never any thing in it), Mr. Edward Ferrars, it seems, has been engaged above this twelvemonth to my cousin Lucy!&mdash;There's for you, my dear!&mdash;And not a creature knowing a syllable of the matter, except Nancy!&mdash;Could you have believed such a thing possible?&mdash; There is no great wonder in their liking one another; but that matters should be brought so forward between them, and nobody suspect it!&mdash;THAT is strange!&mdash;I never happened to see them together, or I am sure I should have found it out directly. END
BEGIN NOW Well, and so this was kept a great secret, for fear of Mrs. Ferrars, and neither she nor your brother or sister suspected a word of the matter;&mdash;till this very morning, poor Nancy, who, you know, is a well-meaning creature, but no conjurer, popt it all out. END
BEGIN NOW 'Lord!' END
BEGIN NOW thinks she to herself, 'they are all so fond of Lucy, to be sure they will make no difficulty about it;' and so, away she went to your sister, who was sitting all alone at her carpet-work, little suspecting what was to come&mdash;for she had just been saying to your brother, only five minutes before, that she thought to make a match between Edward and some Lord's daughter or other, I forget who. END
BEGIN NOW So you may think what a blow it was to all her vanity and pride. END
BEGIN NOW She fell into violent hysterics immediately, with such screams as reached your brother's ears, as he was sitting in his own dressing-room down stairs, thinking about writing a letter to his steward in the country. END
BEGIN NOW So up he flew directly, and a terrible scene took place, for Lucy was come to them by that time, little dreaming what was going on. END
BEGIN NOW Poor soul! END
BEGIN NOW I pity HER. END
BEGIN NOW And I must say, I think she was used very hardly; for your sister scolded like any fury, and soon drove her into a fainting fit. END
BEGIN NOW Nancy, she fell upon her knees, and cried bitterly; and your brother, he walked about the room, and said he did not know what to do. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Dashwood declared they should not stay a minute longer in the house, and your brother was forced to go down upon HIS knees too, to persuade her to let them stay till they had packed up their clothes. END
BEGIN NOW THEN she fell into hysterics again, and he was so frightened that he would send for Mr. Donavan, and Mr. Donavan found the house in all this uproar. END
BEGIN NOW The carriage was at the door ready to take my poor cousins away, and they were just stepping in as he came off; poor Lucy in such a condition, he says, she could hardly walk; and Nancy, she was almost as bad. END
BEGIN NOW I declare, I have no patience with your sister; and I hope, with all my heart, it will be a match in spite of her. END
BEGIN NOW Lord! END
BEGIN NOW what a taking poor Mr. Edward will be in when he hears of it! END
BEGIN NOW To have his love used so scornfully! END
BEGIN NOW for they say he is monstrous fond of her, as well he may. END
BEGIN NOW I should not wonder, if he was to be in the greatest passion!&mdash;and Mr. Donavan thinks just the same. END
BEGIN NOW He and I had a great deal of talk about it; and the best of all is, that he is gone back again to Harley Street, that he may be within call when Mrs. Ferrars is told of it, for she was sent for as soon as ever my cousins left the house, for your sister was sure SHE would be in hysterics too; and so she may, for what I care. END
BEGIN NOW I have no pity for either of them. END
BEGIN NOW I have no notion of people's making such a to-do about money and greatness. END
BEGIN NOW There is no reason on earth why Mr. Edward and Lucy should not marry; for I am sure Mrs. Ferrars may afford to do very well by her son, and though Lucy has next to nothing herself, she knows better than any body how to make the most of every thing; I dare say, if Mrs. Ferrars would only allow him five hundred a-year, she would make as good an appearance with it as any body else would with eight. END
BEGIN NOW Lord! END
BEGIN NOW how snug they might live in such another cottage as yours&mdash;or a little bigger&mdash;with two maids, and two men; and I believe I could help them to a housemaid, for my Betty has a sister out of place, that would fit them exactly. END
BEGIN NOW Here Mrs. Jennings ceased, and as Elinor had had time enough to collect her thoughts, she was able to give such an answer, and make such observations, as the subject might naturally be supposed to produce. END
BEGIN NOW Happy to find that she was not suspected of any extraordinary interest in it; that Mrs. Jennings (as she had of late often hoped might be the case) had ceased to imagine her at all attached to Edward; and happy above all the rest, in the absence of Marianne, she felt very well able to speak of the affair without embarrassment, and to give her judgment, as she believed, with impartiality on the conduct of every one concerned in it. END
BEGIN NOW She could hardly determine what her own expectation of its event really was; though she earnestly tried to drive away the notion of its being possible to end otherwise at last, than in the marriage of Edward and Lucy. END
BEGIN NOW What Mrs. Ferrars would say and do, though there could not be a doubt of its nature, she was anxious to hear; and still more anxious to know how Edward would conduct himself. END
BEGIN NOW For HIM she felt much compassion;&mdash;for Lucy very little&mdash;and it cost her some pains to procure that little;&mdash;for the rest of the party none at all. END
BEGIN NOW As Mrs. Jennings could talk on no other subject, Elinor soon saw the necessity of preparing Marianne for its discussion. END
BEGIN NOW No time was to be lost in undeceiving her, in making her acquainted with the real truth, and in endeavouring to bring her to hear it talked of by others, without betraying that she felt any uneasiness for her sister, or any resentment against Edward. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor's office was a painful one.&mdash;She was going to remove what she really believed to be her sister's chief consolation,&mdash;to give such particulars of Edward as she feared would ruin him for ever in her good opinion,-and to make Marianne, by a resemblance in their situations, which to HER fancy would seem strong, feel all her own disappointment over again. END
BEGIN NOW But unwelcome as such a task must be, it was necessary to be done, and Elinor therefore hastened to perform it. END
BEGIN NOW She was very far from wishing to dwell on her own feelings, or to represent herself as suffering much, any otherwise than as the self-command she had practised since her first knowledge of Edward's engagement, might suggest a hint of what was practicable to Marianne. END
BEGIN NOW Her narration was clear and simple; and though it could not be given without emotion, it was not accompanied by violent agitation, nor impetuous grief.&mdash;THAT belonged rather to the hearer, for Marianne listened with horror, and cried excessively. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor was to be the comforter of others in her own distresses, no less than in theirs; and all the comfort that could be given by assurances of her own composure of mind, and a very earnest vindication of Edward from every charge but of imprudence, was readily offered. END
BEGIN NOW But Marianne for some time would give credit to neither. END
BEGIN NOW Edward seemed a second Willoughby; and acknowledging as Elinor did, that she HAD loved him most sincerely, could she feel less than herself! END
BEGIN NOW As for Lucy Steele, she considered her so totally unamiable, so absolutely incapable of attaching a sensible man, that she could not be persuaded at first to believe, and afterwards to pardon, any former affection of Edward for her. END
BEGIN NOW She would not even admit it to have been natural; and Elinor left her to be convinced that it was so, by that which only could convince her, a better knowledge of mankind. END
BEGIN NOW Her first communication had reached no farther than to state the fact of the engagement, and the length of time it had existed.&mdash;Marianne's feelings had then broken in, and put an end to all regularity of detail; and for some time all that could be done was to soothe her distress, lessen her alarms, and combat her resentment. END
BEGIN NOW The first question on her side, which led to farther particulars, was,&mdash; How long has this been known to you, Elinor? END
BEGIN NOW has he written to you? END
BEGIN NOW I have known it these four months. END
BEGIN NOW When Lucy first came to Barton Park last November, she told me in confidence of her engagement. END
BEGIN NOW At these words, Marianne's eyes expressed the astonishment which her lips could not utter. END
BEGIN NOW After a pause of wonder, she exclaimed&mdash; Four months!&mdash;Have you known of this four months? END
BEGIN NOW Elinor confirmed it. END
BEGIN NOW What!&mdash;while attending me in all my misery, has this been on your heart?&mdash;And I have reproached you for being happy! END
BEGIN NOW &mdash; It was not fit that you should then know how much I was the reverse! END
BEGIN NOW Four months! END
BEGIN NOW &mdash;cried Marianne again.&mdash; So calm!&mdash;so cheerful!&mdash;how have you been supported? END
BEGIN NOW &mdash; By feeling that I was doing my duty.&mdash;My promise to Lucy, obliged me to be secret. END
BEGIN NOW I owed it to her, therefore, to avoid giving any hint of the truth; and I owed it to my family and friends, not to create in them a solicitude about me, which it could not be in my power to satisfy. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne seemed much struck. END
BEGIN NOW I have very often wished to undeceive yourself and my mother, added Elinor; and once or twice I have attempted it;&mdash;but without betraying my trust, I never could have convinced you. END
BEGIN NOW Four months!&mdash;and yet you loved him! END
BEGIN NOW &mdash; Yes. END
BEGIN NOW But I did not love only him;&mdash;and while the comfort of others was dear to me, I was glad to spare them from knowing how much I felt. END
BEGIN NOW Now, I can think and speak of it with little emotion. END
BEGIN NOW I would not have you suffer on my account; for I assure you I no longer suffer materially myself. END
BEGIN NOW I have many things to support me. END
BEGIN NOW I am not conscious of having provoked the disappointment by any imprudence of my own, I have borne it as much as possible without spreading it farther. END
BEGIN NOW I acquit Edward of essential misconduct. END
BEGIN NOW I wish him very happy; and I am so sure of his always doing his duty, that though now he may harbour some regret, in the end he must become so. END
BEGIN NOW Lucy does not want sense, and that is the foundation on which every thing good may be built.&mdash;And after all, Marianne, after all that is bewitching in the idea of a single and constant attachment, and all that can be said of one's happiness depending entirely on any particular person, it is not meant&mdash;it is not fit&mdash;it is not possible that it should be so.&mdash; Edward will marry Lucy; he will marry a woman superior in person and understanding to half her sex; and time and habit will teach him to forget that he ever thought another superior to HER. END
BEGIN NOW &mdash; If such is your way of thinking, said Marianne, if the loss of what is most valued is so easily to be made up by something else, your resolution, your self-command, are, perhaps, a little less to be wondered at.&mdash;They are brought more within my comprehension. END
BEGIN NOW I understand you.&mdash;You do not suppose that I have ever felt much.&mdash;For four months, Marianne, I have had all this hanging on my mind, without being at liberty to speak of it to a single creature; knowing that it would make you and my mother most unhappy whenever it were explained to you, yet unable to prepare you for it in the least.&mdash; It was told me,&mdash;it was in a manner forced on me by the very person herself, whose prior engagement ruined all my prospects; and told me, as I thought, with triumph.&mdash; This person's suspicions, therefore, I have had to oppose, by endeavouring to appear indifferent where I have been most deeply interested;&mdash;and it has not been only once;&mdash;I have had her hopes and exultation to listen to again and again.&mdash; I have known myself to be divided from Edward for ever, without hearing one circumstance that could make me less desire the connection.&mdash;Nothing has proved him unworthy; nor has anything declared him indifferent to me.&mdash; I have had to contend against the unkindness of his sister, and the insolence of his mother; and have suffered the punishment of an attachment, without enjoying its advantages.&mdash; And all this has been going on at a time, when, as you know too well, it has not been my only unhappiness.&mdash; If you can think me capable of ever feeling&mdash;surely you may suppose that I have suffered NOW. END
BEGIN NOW The composure of mind with which I have brought myself at present to consider the matter, the consolation that I have been willing to admit, have been the effect of constant and painful exertion;&mdash;they did not spring up of themselves;&mdash;they did not occur to relieve my spirits at first.&mdash; No, Marianne.&mdash;THEN, if I had not been bound to silence, perhaps nothing could have kept me entirely&mdash;not even what I owed to my dearest friends&mdash;from openly shewing that I was VERY unhappy. END
BEGIN NOW &mdash; Marianne was quite subdued.&mdash; Oh! END
BEGIN NOW Elinor, she cried, you have made me hate myself for ever.&mdash;How barbarous have I been to you!&mdash;you, who have been my only comfort, who have borne with me in all my misery, who have seemed to be only suffering for me!&mdash;Is this my gratitude?&mdash;Is this the only return I can make you?&mdash;Because your merit cries out upon myself, I have been trying to do it away. END
BEGIN NOW The tenderest caresses followed this confession. END
BEGIN NOW In such a frame of mind as she was now in, Elinor had no difficulty in obtaining from her whatever promise she required; and at her request, Marianne engaged never to speak of the affair to any one with the least appearance of bitterness;&mdash;to meet Lucy without betraying the smallest increase of dislike to her;&mdash;and even to see Edward himself, if chance should bring them together, without any diminution of her usual cordiality.&mdash; These were great concessions;&mdash;but where Marianne felt that she had injured, no reparation could be too much for her to make. END
BEGIN NOW She performed her promise of being discreet, to admiration.&mdash;She attended to all that Mrs. Jennings had to say upon the subject, with an unchanging complexion, dissented from her in nothing, and was heard three times to say, Yes, ma'am. END
BEGIN NOW &mdash;She listened to her praise of Lucy with only moving from one chair to another, and when Mrs. Jennings talked of Edward's affection, it cost her only a spasm in her throat.&mdash;Such advances towards heroism in her sister, made Elinor feel equal to any thing herself. END
BEGIN NOW The next morning brought a farther trial of it, in a visit from their brother, who came with a most serious aspect to talk over the dreadful affair, and bring them news of his wife. END
BEGIN NOW You have heard, I suppose, said he with great solemnity, as soon as he was seated, of the very shocking discovery that took place under our roof yesterday. END
BEGIN NOW They all looked their assent; it seemed too awful a moment for speech. END
BEGIN NOW Your sister, he continued, has suffered dreadfully. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Ferrars too&mdash;in short it has been a scene of such complicated distress&mdash;but I will hope that the storm may be weathered without our being any of us quite overcome. END
BEGIN NOW Poor Fanny! END
BEGIN NOW she was in hysterics all yesterday. END
BEGIN NOW But I would not alarm you too much. END
BEGIN NOW Donavan says there is nothing materially to be apprehended; her constitution is a good one, and her resolution equal to any thing. END
BEGIN NOW She has borne it all, with the fortitude of an angel! END
BEGIN NOW She says she never shall think well of anybody again; and one cannot wonder at it, after being so deceived!&mdash;meeting with such ingratitude, where so much kindness had been shewn, so much confidence had been placed! END
BEGIN NOW It was quite out of the benevolence of her heart, that she had asked these young women to her house; merely because she thought they deserved some attention, were harmless, well-behaved girls, and would be pleasant companions; for otherwise we both wished very much to have invited you and Marianne to be with us, while your kind friend there, was attending her daughter. END
BEGIN NOW And now to be so rewarded! END
BEGIN NOW 'I wish, with all my heart,' says poor Fanny in her affectionate way, 'that we had asked your sisters instead of them.' END
BEGIN NOW Here he stopped to be thanked; which being done, he went on. END
BEGIN NOW What poor Mrs. Ferrars suffered, when first Fanny broke it to her, is not to be described. END
BEGIN NOW While she with the truest affection had been planning a most eligible connection for him, was it to be supposed that he could be all the time secretly engaged to another person!&mdash;such a suspicion could never have entered her head! END
BEGIN NOW If she suspected ANY prepossession elsewhere, it could not be in THAT quarter. END
BEGIN NOW 'THERE, to be sure,' said she, 'I might have thought myself safe.' END
BEGIN NOW She was quite in an agony. END
BEGIN NOW We consulted together, however, as to what should be done, and at last she determined to send for Edward. END
BEGIN NOW He came. END
BEGIN NOW But I am sorry to relate what ensued. END
BEGIN NOW All that Mrs. Ferrars could say to make him put an end to the engagement, assisted too as you may well suppose by my arguments, and Fanny's entreaties, was of no avail. END
BEGIN NOW Duty, affection, every thing was disregarded. END
BEGIN NOW I never thought Edward so stubborn, so unfeeling before. END
BEGIN NOW His mother explained to him her liberal designs, in case of his marrying Miss Morton; told him she would settle on him the Norfolk estate, which, clear of land-tax, brings in a good thousand a-year; offered even, when matters grew desperate, to make it twelve hundred; and in opposition to this, if he still persisted in this low connection, represented to him the certain penury that must attend the match. END
BEGIN NOW His own two thousand pounds she protested should be his all; she would never see him again; and so far would she be from affording him the smallest assistance, that if he were to enter into any profession with a view of better support, she would do all in her power to prevent him advancing in it. END
BEGIN NOW Here Marianne, in an ecstasy of indignation, clapped her hands together, and cried, Gracious God! END
BEGIN NOW can this be possible! END
BEGIN NOW Well may you wonder, Marianne, replied her brother, at the obstinacy which could resist such arguments as these. END
BEGIN NOW Your exclamation is very natural. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne was going to retort, but she remembered her promises, and forbore. END
BEGIN NOW All this, however, he continued, was urged in vain. END
BEGIN NOW Edward said very little; but what he did say, was in the most determined manner. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing should prevail on him to give up his engagement. END
BEGIN NOW He would stand to it, cost him what it might. END
BEGIN NOW Then, cried Mrs. Jennings with blunt sincerity, no longer able to be silent, he has acted like an honest man! END
BEGIN NOW I beg your pardon, Mr. Dashwood, but if he had done otherwise, I should have thought him a rascal. END
BEGIN NOW I have some little concern in the business, as well as yourself, for Lucy Steele is my cousin, and I believe there is not a better kind of girl in the world, nor one who more deserves a good husband. END
BEGIN NOW John Dashwood was greatly astonished; but his nature was calm, not open to provocation, and he never wished to offend anybody, especially anybody of good fortune. END
BEGIN NOW He therefore replied, without any resentment, I would by no means speak disrespectfully of any relation of yours, madam. END
BEGIN NOW Miss Lucy Steele is, I dare say, a very deserving young woman, but in the present case you know, the connection must be impossible. END
BEGIN NOW And to have entered into a secret engagement with a young man under her uncle's care, the son of a woman especially of such very large fortune as Mrs. Ferrars, is perhaps, altogether a little extraordinary. END
BEGIN NOW In short, I do not mean to reflect upon the behaviour of any person whom you have a regard for, Mrs. Jennings. END
BEGIN NOW We all wish her extremely happy; and Mrs. Ferrars's conduct throughout the whole, has been such as every conscientious, good mother, in like circumstances, would adopt. END
BEGIN NOW It has been dignified and liberal. END
BEGIN NOW Edward has drawn his own lot, and I fear it will be a bad one. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne sighed out her similar apprehension; and Elinor's heart wrung for the feelings of Edward, while braving his mother's threats, for a woman who could not reward him. END
BEGIN NOW Well, sir, said Mrs. Jennings, and how did it end? END
BEGIN NOW I am sorry to say, ma'am, in a most unhappy rupture:&mdash; Edward is dismissed for ever from his mother's notice. END
BEGIN NOW He left her house yesterday, but where he is gone, or whether he is still in town, I do not know; for WE of course can make no inquiry. END
BEGIN NOW Poor young man!&mdash;and what is to become of him? END
BEGIN NOW What, indeed, ma'am! END
BEGIN NOW It is a melancholy consideration. END
BEGIN NOW Born to the prospect of such affluence! END
BEGIN NOW I cannot conceive a situation more deplorable. END
BEGIN NOW The interest of two thousand pounds&mdash;how can a man live on it?&mdash;and when to that is added the recollection, that he might, but for his own folly, within three months have been in the receipt of two thousand, five hundred a-year (for Miss Morton has thirty thousand pounds,) I cannot picture to myself a more wretched condition. END
BEGIN NOW We must all feel for him; and the more so, because it is totally out of our power to assist him. END
BEGIN NOW Poor young man! END
BEGIN NOW cried Mrs. Jennings, I am sure he should be very welcome to bed and board at my house; and so I would tell him if I could see him. END
BEGIN NOW It is not fit that he should be living about at his own charge now, at lodgings and taverns. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor's heart thanked her for such kindness towards Edward, though she could not forbear smiling at the form of it. END
BEGIN NOW If he would only have done as well by himself, said John Dashwood, as all his friends were disposed to do by him, he might now have been in his proper situation, and would have wanted for nothing. END
BEGIN NOW But as it is, it must be out of anybody's power to assist him. END
BEGIN NOW And there is one thing more preparing against him, which must be worse than all&mdash;his mother has determined, with a very natural kind of spirit, to settle THAT estate upon Robert immediately, which might have been Edward's, on proper conditions. END
BEGIN NOW I left her this morning with her lawyer, talking over the business. END
BEGIN NOW Well! END
BEGIN NOW said Mrs. Jennings, that is HER revenge. END
BEGIN NOW Everybody has a way of their own. END
BEGIN NOW But I don't think mine would be, to make one son independent, because another had plagued me. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne got up and walked about the room. END
BEGIN NOW Can anything be more galling to the spirit of a man, continued John, than to see his younger brother in possession of an estate which might have been his own? END
BEGIN NOW Poor Edward! END
BEGIN NOW I feel for him sincerely. END
BEGIN NOW A few minutes more spent in the same kind of effusion, concluded his visit; and with repeated assurances to his sisters that he really believed there was no material danger in Fanny's indisposition, and that they need not therefore be very uneasy about it, he went away; leaving the three ladies unanimous in their sentiments on the present occasion, as far at least as it regarded Mrs. Ferrars's conduct, the Dashwoods', and Edward's. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne's indignation burst forth as soon as he quitted the room; and as her vehemence made reserve impossible in Elinor, and unnecessary in Mrs. Jennings, they all joined in a very spirited critique upon the party. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings was very warm in her praise of Edward's conduct, but only Elinor and Marianne understood its true merit. END
BEGIN NOW THEY only knew how little he had had to tempt him to be disobedient, and how small was the consolation, beyond the consciousness of doing right, that could remain to him in the loss of friends and fortune. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor gloried in his integrity; and Marianne forgave all his offences in compassion for his punishment. END
BEGIN NOW But though confidence between them was, by this public discovery, restored to its proper state, it was not a subject on which either of them were fond of dwelling when alone. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor avoided it upon principle, as tending to fix still more upon her thoughts, by the too warm, too positive assurances of Marianne, that belief of Edward's continued affection for herself which she rather wished to do away; and Marianne's courage soon failed her, in trying to converse upon a topic which always left her more dissatisfied with herself than ever, by the comparison it necessarily produced between Elinor's conduct and her own. END
BEGIN NOW She felt all the force of that comparison; but not as her sister had hoped, to urge her to exertion now; she felt it with all the pain of continual self-reproach, regretted most bitterly that she had never exerted herself before; but it brought only the torture of penitence, without the hope of amendment. END
BEGIN NOW Her mind was so much weakened that she still fancied present exertion impossible, and therefore it only dispirited her more. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing new was heard by them, for a day or two afterwards, of affairs in Harley Street, or Bartlett's Buildings. END
BEGIN NOW But though so much of the matter was known to them already, that Mrs. Jennings might have had enough to do in spreading that knowledge farther, without seeking after more, she had resolved from the first to pay a visit of comfort and inquiry to her cousins as soon as she could; and nothing but the hindrance of more visitors than usual, had prevented her going to them within that time. END
BEGIN NOW The third day succeeding their knowledge of the particulars, was so fine, so beautiful a Sunday as to draw many to Kensington Gardens, though it was only the second week in March. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings and Elinor were of the number; but Marianne, who knew that the Willoughbys were again in town, and had a constant dread of meeting them, chose rather to stay at home, than venture into so public a place. END
BEGIN NOW An intimate acquaintance of Mrs. Jennings joined them soon after they entered the Gardens, and Elinor was not sorry that by her continuing with them, and engaging all Mrs. Jennings's conversation, she was herself left to quiet reflection. END
BEGIN NOW She saw nothing of the Willoughbys, nothing of Edward, and for some time nothing of anybody who could by any chance whether grave or gay, be interesting to her. END
BEGIN NOW But at last she found herself with some surprise, accosted by Miss Steele, who, though looking rather shy, expressed great satisfaction in meeting them, and on receiving encouragement from the particular kindness of Mrs. Jennings, left her own party for a short time, to join their's. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings immediately whispered to Elinor, Get it all out of her, my dear. END
BEGIN NOW She will tell you any thing if you ask. END
BEGIN NOW You see I cannot leave Mrs. Clarke. END
BEGIN NOW It was lucky, however, for Mrs. Jennings's curiosity and Elinor's too, that she would tell any thing WITHOUT being asked; for nothing would otherwise have been learnt. END
BEGIN NOW I am so glad to meet you; said Miss Steele, taking her familiarly by the arm&mdash; for I wanted to see you of all things in the world. END
BEGIN NOW And then lowering her voice, I suppose Mrs. Jennings has heard all about it. END
BEGIN NOW Is she angry? END
BEGIN NOW Not at all, I believe, with you. END
BEGIN NOW That is a good thing. END
BEGIN NOW And Lady Middleton, is SHE angry? END
BEGIN NOW I cannot suppose it possible that she should be. END
BEGIN NOW I am monstrous glad of it. END
BEGIN NOW Good gracious! END
BEGIN NOW I have had such a time of it! END
BEGIN NOW I never saw Lucy in such a rage in my life. END
BEGIN NOW She vowed at first she would never trim me up a new bonnet, nor do any thing else for me again, so long as she lived; but now she is quite come to, and we are as good friends as ever. END
BEGIN NOW Look, she made me this bow to my hat, and put in the feather last night. END
BEGIN NOW There now, YOU are going to laugh at me too. END
BEGIN NOW But why should not I wear pink ribbons? END
BEGIN NOW I do not care if it IS the Doctor's favourite colour. END
BEGIN NOW I am sure, for my part, I should never have known he DID like it better than any other colour, if he had not happened to say so. END
BEGIN NOW My cousins have been so plaguing me! END
BEGIN NOW I declare sometimes I do not know which way to look before them. END
BEGIN NOW She had wandered away to a subject on which Elinor had nothing to say, and therefore soon judged it expedient to find her way back again to the first. END
BEGIN NOW Well, but Miss Dashwood, speaking triumphantly, people may say what they chuse about Mr. Ferrars's declaring he would not have Lucy, for it is no such thing I can tell you; and it is quite a shame for such ill-natured reports to be spread abroad. END
BEGIN NOW Whatever Lucy might think about it herself, you know, it was no business of other people to set it down for certain. END
BEGIN NOW I never heard any thing of the kind hinted at before, I assure you, said Elinor. END
BEGIN NOW Oh, did not you? END
BEGIN NOW But it WAS said, I know, very well, and by more than one; for Miss Godby told Miss Sparks, that nobody in their senses could expect Mr. Ferrars to give up a woman like Miss Morton, with thirty thousand pounds to her fortune, for Lucy Steele that had nothing at all; and I had it from Miss Sparks myself. END
BEGIN NOW And besides that, my cousin Richard said himself, that when it came to the point he was afraid Mr. Ferrars would be off; and when Edward did not come near us for three days, I could not tell what to think myself; and I believe in my heart Lucy gave it up all for lost; for we came away from your brother's Wednesday, and we saw nothing of him not all Thursday, Friday, and Saturday, and did not know what was become of him. END
BEGIN NOW Once Lucy thought to write to him, but then her spirits rose against that. END
BEGIN NOW However this morning he came just as we came home from church; and then it all came out, how he had been sent for Wednesday to Harley Street, and been talked to by his mother and all of them, and how he had declared before them all that he loved nobody but Lucy, and nobody but Lucy would he have. END
BEGIN NOW And how he had been so worried by what passed, that as soon as he had went away from his mother's house, he had got upon his horse, and rid into the country, some where or other; and how he had stayed about at an inn all Thursday and Friday, on purpose to get the better of it. END
BEGIN NOW And after thinking it all over and over again, he said, it seemed to him as if, now he had no fortune, and no nothing at all, it would be quite unkind to keep her on to the engagement, because it must be for her loss, for he had nothing but two thousand pounds, and no hope of any thing else; and if he was to go into orders, as he had some thoughts, he could get nothing but a curacy, and how was they to live upon that?&mdash;He could not bear to think of her doing no better, and so he begged, if she had the least mind for it, to put an end to the matter directly, and leave him shift for himself. END
BEGIN NOW I heard him say all this as plain as could possibly be. END
BEGIN NOW And it was entirely for HER sake, and upon HER account, that he said a word about being off, and not upon his own. END
BEGIN NOW I will take my oath he never dropt a syllable of being tired of her, or of wishing to marry Miss Morton, or any thing like it. END
BEGIN NOW But, to be sure, Lucy would not give ear to such kind of talking; so she told him directly (with a great deal about sweet and love, you know, and all that&mdash;Oh, la! END
BEGIN NOW one can't repeat such kind of things you know)&mdash;she told him directly, she had not the least mind in the world to be off, for she could live with him upon a trifle, and how little so ever he might have, she should be very glad to have it all, you know, or something of the kind. END
BEGIN NOW So then he was monstrous happy, and talked on some time about what they should do, and they agreed he should take orders directly, and they must wait to be married till he got a living. END
BEGIN NOW And just then I could not hear any more, for my cousin called from below to tell me Mrs. Richardson was come in her coach, and would take one of us to Kensington Gardens; so I was forced to go into the room and interrupt them, to ask Lucy if she would like to go, but she did not care to leave Edward; so I just run up stairs and put on a pair of silk stockings and came off with the Richardsons. END
BEGIN NOW I do not understand what you mean by interrupting them, said Elinor; you were all in the same room together, were not you? END
BEGIN NOW No, indeed, not us. END
BEGIN NOW La! END
BEGIN NOW Miss Dashwood, do you think people make love when any body else is by? END
BEGIN NOW Oh, for shame!&mdash;To be sure you must know better than that. END
BEGIN NOW (Laughing affectedly. END
BEGIN NOW )&mdash;No, no; they were shut up in the drawing-room together, and all I heard was only by listening at the door. END
BEGIN NOW How! END
BEGIN NOW cried Elinor; have you been repeating to me what you only learnt yourself by listening at the door? END
BEGIN NOW I am sorry I did not know it before; for I certainly would not have suffered you to give me particulars of a conversation which you ought not to have known yourself. END
BEGIN NOW How could you behave so unfairly by your sister? END
BEGIN NOW Oh, la! END
BEGIN NOW there is nothing in THAT. END
BEGIN NOW I only stood at the door, and heard what I could. END
BEGIN NOW And I am sure Lucy would have done just the same by me; for a year or two back, when Martha Sharpe and I had so many secrets together, she never made any bones of hiding in a closet, or behind a chimney-board, on purpose to hear what we said. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor tried to talk of something else; but Miss Steele could not be kept beyond a couple of minutes, from what was uppermost in her mind. END
BEGIN NOW Edward talks of going to Oxford soon, said she; but now he is lodging at No. END
BEGIN NOW &mdash;, Pall Mall. END
BEGIN NOW What an ill-natured woman his mother is, an't she? END
BEGIN NOW And your brother and sister were not very kind! END
BEGIN NOW However, I shan't say anything against them to YOU; and to be sure they did send us home in their own chariot, which was more than I looked for. END
BEGIN NOW And for my part, I was all in a fright for fear your sister should ask us for the huswifes she had gave us a day or two before; but, however, nothing was said about them, and I took care to keep mine out of sight. END
BEGIN NOW Edward have got some business at Oxford, he says; so he must go there for a time; and after THAT, as soon as he can light upon a Bishop, he will be ordained. END
BEGIN NOW I wonder what curacy he will get!&mdash;Good gracious! END
BEGIN NOW (giggling as she spoke) I'd lay my life I know what my cousins will say, when they hear of it. END
BEGIN NOW They will tell me I should write to the Doctor, to get Edward the curacy of his new living. END
BEGIN NOW I know they will; but I am sure I would not do such a thing for all the world.&mdash; 'La!' END
BEGIN NOW I shall say directly, 'I wonder how you could think of such a thing? END
BEGIN NOW I write to the Doctor, indeed!' END
BEGIN NOW Well, said Elinor, it is a comfort to be prepared against the worst. END
BEGIN NOW You have got your answer ready. END
BEGIN NOW Miss Steele was going to reply on the same subject, but the approach of her own party made another more necessary. END
BEGIN NOW Oh, la! END
BEGIN NOW here come the Richardsons. END
BEGIN NOW I had a vast deal more to say to you, but I must not stay away from them not any longer. END
BEGIN NOW I assure you they are very genteel people. END
BEGIN NOW He makes a monstrous deal of money, and they keep their own coach. END
BEGIN NOW I have not time to speak to Mrs. Jennings about it myself, but pray tell her I am quite happy to hear she is not in anger against us, and Lady Middleton the same; and if anything should happen to take you and your sister away, and Mrs. Jennings should want company, I am sure we should be very glad to come and stay with her for as long a time as she likes. END
BEGIN NOW I suppose Lady Middleton won't ask us any more this bout. END
BEGIN NOW Good-by; I am sorry Miss Marianne was not here. END
BEGIN NOW Remember me kindly to her. END
BEGIN NOW La! END
BEGIN NOW if you have not got your spotted muslin on!&mdash;I wonder you was not afraid of its being torn. END
BEGIN NOW Such was her parting concern; for after this, she had time only to pay her farewell compliments to Mrs. Jennings, before her company was claimed by Mrs. Richardson; and Elinor was left in possession of knowledge which might feed her powers of reflection some time, though she had learnt very little more than what had been already foreseen and foreplanned in her own mind. END
BEGIN NOW Edward's marriage with Lucy was as firmly determined on, and the time of its taking place remained as absolutely uncertain, as she had concluded it would be;&mdash;every thing depended, exactly after her expectation, on his getting that preferment, of which, at present, there seemed not the smallest chance. END
BEGIN NOW As soon as they returned to the carriage, Mrs. Jennings was eager for information; but as Elinor wished to spread as little as possible intelligence that had in the first place been so unfairly obtained, she confined herself to the brief repetition of such simple particulars, as she felt assured that Lucy, for the sake of her own consequence, would choose to have known. END
BEGIN NOW The continuance of their engagement, and the means that were able to be taken for promoting its end, was all her communication; and this produced from Mrs. Jennings the following natural remark. END
BEGIN NOW Wait for his having a living!&mdash;ay, we all know how THAT will end:&mdash;they will wait a twelvemonth, and finding no good comes of it, will set down upon a curacy of fifty pounds a-year, with the interest of his two thousand pounds, and what little matter Mr. Steele and Mr. Pratt can give her.&mdash;Then they will have a child every year! END
BEGIN NOW and Lord help 'em! END
BEGIN NOW how poor they will be!&mdash;I must see what I can give them towards furnishing their house. END
BEGIN NOW Two maids and two men, indeed!&mdash;as I talked of t'other day.&mdash;No, no, they must get a stout girl of all works.&mdash; Betty's sister would never do for them NOW. END
BEGIN NOW The next morning brought Elinor a letter by the two-penny post from Lucy herself. END
BEGIN NOW It was as follows: Bartlett's Building, March. END
BEGIN NOW I hope my dear Miss Dashwood will excuse the liberty I take of writing to her; but I know your friendship for me will make you pleased to hear such a good account of myself and my dear Edward, after all the troubles we have went through lately, therefore will make no more apologies, but proceed to say that, thank God! END
BEGIN NOW though we have suffered dreadfully, we are both quite well now, and as happy as we must always be in one another's love. END
BEGIN NOW We have had great trials, and great persecutions, but however, at the same time, gratefully acknowledge many friends, yourself not the least among them, whose great kindness I shall always thankfully remember, as will Edward too, who I have told of it. END
BEGIN NOW I am sure you will be glad to hear, as likewise dear Mrs. Jennings, I spent two happy hours with him yesterday afternoon, he would not hear of our parting, though earnestly did I, as I thought my duty required, urge him to it for prudence sake, and would have parted for ever on the spot, would he consent to it; but he said it should never be, he did not regard his mother's anger, while he could have my affections; our prospects are not very bright, to be sure, but we must wait, and hope for the best; he will be ordained shortly; and should it ever be in your power to recommend him to any body that has a living to bestow, am very sure you will not forget us, and dear Mrs. Jennings too, trust she will speak a good word for us to Sir John, or Mr. Palmer, or any friend that may be able to assist us.&mdash;Poor Anne was much to blame for what she did, but she did it for the best, so I say nothing; hope Mrs. Jennings won't think it too much trouble to give us a call, should she come this way any morning, 'twould be a great kindness, and my cousins would be proud to know her.&mdash;My paper reminds me to conclude; and begging to be most gratefully and respectfully remembered to her, and to Sir John, and Lady Middleton, and the dear children, when you chance to see them, and love to Miss Marianne, I am, &c. As soon as Elinor had finished it, she performed what she concluded to be its writer's real design, by placing it in the hands of Mrs. Jennings, who read it aloud with many comments of satisfaction and praise. END
BEGIN NOW Very well indeed!&mdash;how prettily she writes!&mdash;aye, that was quite proper to let him be off if he would. END
BEGIN NOW That was just like Lucy.&mdash;Poor soul! END
BEGIN NOW I wish I COULD get him a living, with all my heart.&mdash;She calls me dear Mrs. Jennings, you see. END
BEGIN NOW She is a good-hearted girl as ever lived.&mdash;Very well upon my word. END
BEGIN NOW That sentence is very prettily turned. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, yes, I will go and see her, sure enough. END
BEGIN NOW How attentive she is, to think of every body!&mdash;Thank you, my dear, for shewing it me. END
BEGIN NOW It is as pretty a letter as ever I saw, and does Lucy's head and heart great credit. END
BEGIN NOW The Miss Dashwoods had now been rather more than two months in town, and Marianne's impatience to be gone increased every day. END
BEGIN NOW She sighed for the air, the liberty, the quiet of the country; and fancied that if any place could give her ease, Barton must do it. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor was hardly less anxious than herself for their removal, and only so much less bent on its being effected immediately, as that she was conscious of the difficulties of so long a journey, which Marianne could not be brought to acknowledge. END
BEGIN NOW She began, however, seriously to turn her thoughts towards its accomplishment, and had already mentioned their wishes to their kind hostess, who resisted them with all the eloquence of her good-will, when a plan was suggested, which, though detaining them from home yet a few weeks longer, appeared to Elinor altogether much more eligible than any other. END
BEGIN NOW The Palmers were to remove to Cleveland about the end of March, for the Easter holidays; and Mrs. Jennings, with both her friends, received a very warm invitation from Charlotte to go with them. END
BEGIN NOW This would not, in itself, have been sufficient for the delicacy of Miss Dashwood;&mdash;but it was inforced with so much real politeness by Mr. Palmer himself, as, joined to the very great amendment of his manners towards them since her sister had been known to be unhappy, induced her to accept it with pleasure. END
BEGIN NOW When she told Marianne what she had done, however, her first reply was not very auspicious. END
BEGIN NOW Cleveland! END
BEGIN NOW &mdash;she cried, with great agitation. END
BEGIN NOW No, I cannot go to Cleveland. END
BEGIN NOW &mdash; You forget, said Elinor gently, that its situation is not...that it is not in the neighbourhood of... END
BEGIN NOW But it is in Somersetshire.&mdash;I cannot go into Somersetshire.&mdash;There, where I looked forward to going...No, Elinor, you cannot expect me to go there. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor would not argue upon the propriety of overcoming such feelings;&mdash;she only endeavoured to counteract them by working on others;&mdash;represented it, therefore, as a measure which would fix the time of her returning to that dear mother, whom she so much wished to see, in a more eligible, more comfortable manner, than any other plan could do, and perhaps without any greater delay. END
BEGIN NOW From Cleveland, which was within a few miles of Bristol, the distance to Barton was not beyond one day, though a long day's journey; and their mother's servant might easily come there to attend them down; and as there could be no occasion of their staying above a week at Cleveland, they might now be at home in little more than three weeks' time. END
BEGIN NOW As Marianne's affection for her mother was sincere, it must triumph with little difficulty, over the imaginary evils she had started. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings was so far from being weary of her guests, that she pressed them very earnestly to return with her again from Cleveland. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor was grateful for the attention, but it could not alter her design; and their mother's concurrence being readily gained, every thing relative to their return was arranged as far as it could be;&mdash;and Marianne found some relief in drawing up a statement of the hours that were yet to divide her from Barton. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW Colonel, I do not know what you and I shall do without the Miss Dashwoods; &mdash;was Mrs. Jennings's address to him when he first called on her, after their leaving her was settled&mdash; for they are quite resolved upon going home from the Palmers;&mdash;and how forlorn we shall be, when I come back!&mdash;Lord! END
BEGIN NOW we shall sit and gape at one another as dull as two cats. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps Mrs. Jennings was in hopes, by this vigorous sketch of their future ennui, to provoke him to make that offer, which might give himself an escape from it;&mdash;and if so, she had soon afterwards good reason to think her object gained; for, on Elinor's moving to the window to take more expeditiously the dimensions of a print, which she was going to copy for her friend, he followed her to it with a look of particular meaning, and conversed with her there for several minutes. END
BEGIN NOW The effect of his discourse on the lady too, could not escape her observation, for though she was too honorable to listen, and had even changed her seat, on purpose that she might NOT hear, to one close by the piano forte on which Marianne was playing, she could not keep herself from seeing that Elinor changed colour, attended with agitation, and was too intent on what he said to pursue her employment.&mdash; Still farther in confirmation of her hopes, in the interval of Marianne's turning from one lesson to another, some words of the Colonel's inevitably reached her ear, in which he seemed to be apologising for the badness of his house. END
BEGIN NOW This set the matter beyond a doubt. END
BEGIN NOW She wondered, indeed, at his thinking it necessary to do so; but supposed it to be the proper etiquette. END
BEGIN NOW What Elinor said in reply she could not distinguish, but judged from the motion of her lips, that she did not think THAT any material objection;&mdash;and Mrs. Jennings commended her in her heart for being so honest. END
BEGIN NOW They then talked on for a few minutes longer without her catching a syllable, when another lucky stop in Marianne's performance brought her these words in the Colonel's calm voice,&mdash; I am afraid it cannot take place very soon. END
BEGIN NOW Astonished and shocked at so unlover-like a speech, she was almost ready to cry out, Lord! END
BEGIN NOW what should hinder it? END
BEGIN NOW &mdash;but checking her desire, confined herself to this silent ejaculation. END
BEGIN NOW This is very strange!&mdash;sure he need not wait to be older. END
BEGIN NOW This delay on the Colonel's side, however, did not seem to offend or mortify his fair companion in the least, for on their breaking up the conference soon afterwards, and moving different ways, Mrs. Jennings very plainly heard Elinor say, and with a voice which shewed her to feel what she said, I shall always think myself very much obliged to you. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings was delighted with her gratitude, and only wondered that after hearing such a sentence, the Colonel should be able to take leave of them, as he immediately did, with the utmost sang-froid, and go away without making her any reply!&mdash;She had not thought her old friend could have made so indifferent a suitor. END
BEGIN NOW What had really passed between them was to this effect. END
BEGIN NOW I have heard, said he, with great compassion, of the injustice your friend Mr. Ferrars has suffered from his family; for if I understand the matter right, he has been entirely cast off by them for persevering in his engagement with a very deserving young woman.&mdash; Have I been rightly informed?&mdash;Is it so?&mdash; Elinor told him that it was. END
BEGIN NOW The cruelty, the impolitic cruelty, &mdash;he replied, with great feeling,&mdash; of dividing, or attempting to divide, two young people long attached to each other, is terrible.&mdash; Mrs. Ferrars does not know what she may be doing&mdash;what she may drive her son to. END
BEGIN NOW I have seen Mr. Ferrars two or three times in Harley Street, and am much pleased with him. END
BEGIN NOW He is not a young man with whom one can be intimately acquainted in a short time, but I have seen enough of him to wish him well for his own sake, and as a friend of yours, I wish it still more. END
BEGIN NOW I understand that he intends to take orders. END
BEGIN NOW Will you be so good as to tell him that the living of Delaford, now just vacant, as I am informed by this day's post, is his, if he think it worth his acceptance&mdash;but THAT, perhaps, so unfortunately circumstanced as he is now, it may be nonsense to appear to doubt; I only wish it were more valuable.&mdash; It is a rectory, but a small one; the late incumbent, I believe, did not make more than L per annum, and though it is certainly capable of improvement, I fear, not to such an amount as to afford him a very comfortable income. END
BEGIN NOW Such as it is, however, my pleasure in presenting it to him, will be very great. END
BEGIN NOW Pray assure him of it. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor's astonishment at this commission could hardly have been greater, had the Colonel been really making her an offer of his hand. END
BEGIN NOW The preferment, which only two days before she had considered as hopeless for Edward, was already provided to enable him to marry;&mdash;and SHE, of all people in the world, was fixed on to bestow it!&mdash;Her emotion was such as Mrs. Jennings had attributed to a very different cause;&mdash;but whatever minor feelings less pure, less pleasing, might have a share in that emotion, her esteem for the general benevolence, and her gratitude for the particular friendship, which together prompted Colonel Brandon to this act, were strongly felt, and warmly expressed. END
BEGIN NOW She thanked him for it with all her heart, spoke of Edward's principles and disposition with that praise which she knew them to deserve; and promised to undertake the commission with pleasure, if it were really his wish to put off so agreeable an office to another. END
BEGIN NOW But at the same time, she could not help thinking that no one could so well perform it as himself. END
BEGIN NOW It was an office in short, from which, unwilling to give Edward the pain of receiving an obligation from HER, she would have been very glad to be spared herself;&mdash; but Colonel Brandon, on motives of equal delicacy, declining it likewise, still seemed so desirous of its being given through her means, that she would not on any account make farther opposition. END
BEGIN NOW Edward, she believed, was still in town, and fortunately she had heard his address from Miss Steele. END
BEGIN NOW She could undertake therefore to inform him of it, in the course of the day. END
BEGIN NOW After this had been settled, Colonel Brandon began to talk of his own advantage in securing so respectable and agreeable a neighbour, and THEN it was that he mentioned with regret, that the house was small and indifferent;&mdash;an evil which Elinor, as Mrs. Jennings had supposed her to do, made very light of, at least as far as regarded its size. END
BEGIN NOW The smallness of the house, said she, I cannot imagine any inconvenience to them, for it will be in proportion to their family and income. END
BEGIN NOW By which the Colonel was surprised to find that SHE was considering Mr. Ferrars's marriage as the certain consequence of the presentation; for he did not suppose it possible that Delaford living could supply such an income, as anybody in his style of life would venture to settle on&mdash;and he said so. END
BEGIN NOW This little rectory CAN do no more than make Mr. Ferrars comfortable as a bachelor; it cannot enable him to marry. END
BEGIN NOW I am sorry to say that my patronage ends with this; and my interest is hardly more extensive. END
BEGIN NOW If, however, by an unforeseen chance it should be in my power to serve him farther, I must think very differently of him from what I now do, if I am not as ready to be useful to him then as I sincerely wish I could be at present. END
BEGIN NOW What I am now doing indeed, seems nothing at all, since it can advance him so little towards what must be his principal, his only object of happiness. END
BEGIN NOW His marriage must still be a distant good;&mdash;at least, I am afraid it cannot take place very soon.&mdash; Such was the sentence which, when misunderstood, so justly offended the delicate feelings of Mrs. Jennings; but after this narration of what really passed between Colonel Brandon and Elinor, while they stood at the window, the gratitude expressed by the latter on their parting, may perhaps appear in general, not less reasonably excited, nor less properly worded than if it had arisen from an offer of marriage. END
BEGIN NOW Well, Miss Dashwood, said Mrs. Jennings, sagaciously smiling, as soon as the gentleman had withdrawn, I do not ask you what the Colonel has been saying to you; for though, upon my honour, I TRIED to keep out of hearing, I could not help catching enough to understand his business. END
BEGIN NOW And I assure you I never was better pleased in my life, and I wish you joy of it with all my heart. END
BEGIN NOW Thank you, ma'am, said Elinor. END
BEGIN NOW It is a matter of great joy to me; and I feel the goodness of Colonel Brandon most sensibly. END
BEGIN NOW There are not many men who would act as he has done. END
BEGIN NOW Few people who have so compassionate a heart! END
BEGIN NOW I never was more astonished in my life. END
BEGIN NOW Lord! END
BEGIN NOW my dear, you are very modest. END
BEGIN NOW I an't the least astonished at it in the world, for I have often thought of late, there was nothing more likely to happen. END
BEGIN NOW You judged from your knowledge of the Colonel's general benevolence; but at least you could not foresee that the opportunity would so very soon occur. END
BEGIN NOW Opportunity! END
BEGIN NOW repeated Mrs. Jennings&mdash; Oh! END
BEGIN NOW as to that, when a man has once made up his mind to such a thing, somehow or other he will soon find an opportunity. END
BEGIN NOW Well, my dear, I wish you joy of it again and again; and if ever there was a happy couple in the world, I think I shall soon know where to look for them. END
BEGIN NOW You mean to go to Delaford after them I suppose, said Elinor, with a faint smile. END
BEGIN NOW Aye, my dear, that I do, indeed. END
BEGIN NOW And as to the house being a bad one, I do not know what the Colonel would be at, for it is as good a one as ever I saw. END
BEGIN NOW He spoke of its being out of repair. END
BEGIN NOW Well, and whose fault is that? END
BEGIN NOW why don't he repair it?&mdash;who should do it but himself? END
BEGIN NOW They were interrupted by the servant's coming in to announce the carriage being at the door; and Mrs. Jennings immediately preparing to go, said,&mdash; Well, my dear, I must be gone before I have had half my talk out. END
BEGIN NOW But, however, we may have it all over in the evening; for we shall be quite alone. END
BEGIN NOW I do not ask you to go with me, for I dare say your mind is too full of the matter to care for company; and besides, you must long to tell your sister all about it. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne had left the room before the conversation began. END
BEGIN NOW Certainly, ma'am, I shall tell Marianne of it; but I shall not mention it at present to any body else. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW very well, said Mrs. Jennings rather disappointed. END
BEGIN NOW Then you would not have me tell it to Lucy, for I think of going as far as Holborn to-day. END
BEGIN NOW No, ma'am, not even Lucy if you please. END
BEGIN NOW One day's delay will not be very material; and till I have written to Mr. Ferrars, I think it ought not to be mentioned to any body else. END
BEGIN NOW I shall do THAT directly. END
BEGIN NOW It is of importance that no time should be lost with him, for he will of course have much to do relative to his ordination. END
BEGIN NOW This speech at first puzzled Mrs. Jennings exceedingly. END
BEGIN NOW Why Mr. Ferrars was to have been written to about it in such a hurry, she could not immediately comprehend. END
BEGIN NOW A few moments' reflection, however, produced a very happy idea, and she exclaimed;&mdash; Oh, ho!&mdash;I understand you. END
BEGIN NOW Mr. Ferrars is to be the man. END
BEGIN NOW Well, so much the better for him. END
BEGIN NOW Ay, to be sure, he must be ordained in readiness; and I am very glad to find things are so forward between you. END
BEGIN NOW But, my dear, is not this rather out of character? END
BEGIN NOW Should not the Colonel write himself?&mdash;sure, he is the proper person. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor did not quite understand the beginning of Mrs. Jennings's speech, neither did she think it worth inquiring into; and therefore only replied to its conclusion. END
BEGIN NOW Colonel Brandon is so delicate a man, that he rather wished any one to announce his intentions to Mr. Ferrars than himself. END
BEGIN NOW And so YOU are forced to do it. END
BEGIN NOW Well THAT is an odd kind of delicacy! END
BEGIN NOW However, I will not disturb you (seeing her preparing to write.) END
BEGIN NOW You know your own concerns best. END
BEGIN NOW So goodby, my dear. END
BEGIN NOW I have not heard of any thing to please me so well since Charlotte was brought to bed. END
BEGIN NOW And away she went; but returning again in a moment, I have just been thinking of Betty's sister, my dear. END
BEGIN NOW I should be very glad to get her so good a mistress. END
BEGIN NOW But whether she would do for a lady's maid, I am sure I can't tell. END
BEGIN NOW She is an excellent housemaid, and works very well at her needle. END
BEGIN NOW However, you will think of all that at your leisure. END
BEGIN NOW Certainly, ma'am, replied Elinor, not hearing much of what she said, and more anxious to be alone, than to be mistress of the subject. END
BEGIN NOW How she should begin&mdash;how she should express herself in her note to Edward, was now all her concern. END
BEGIN NOW The particular circumstances between them made a difficulty of that which to any other person would have been the easiest thing in the world; but she equally feared to say too much or too little, and sat deliberating over her paper, with the pen in her hand, till broken in on by the entrance of Edward himself. END
BEGIN NOW He had met Mrs. Jennings at the door in her way to the carriage, as he came to leave his farewell card; and she, after apologising for not returning herself, had obliged him to enter, by saying that Miss Dashwood was above, and wanted to speak with him on very particular business. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor had just been congratulating herself, in the midst of her perplexity, that however difficult it might be to express herself properly by letter, it was at least preferable to giving the information by word of mouth, when her visitor entered, to force her upon this greatest exertion of all. END
BEGIN NOW Her astonishment and confusion were very great on his so sudden appearance. END
BEGIN NOW She had not seen him before since his engagement became public, and therefore not since his knowing her to be acquainted with it; which, with the consciousness of what she had been thinking of, and what she had to tell him, made her feel particularly uncomfortable for some minutes. END
BEGIN NOW He too was much distressed; and they sat down together in a most promising state of embarrassment.&mdash;Whether he had asked her pardon for his intrusion on first coming into the room, he could not recollect; but determining to be on the safe side, he made his apology in form as soon as he could say any thing, after taking a chair. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings told me, said he, that you wished to speak with me, at least I understood her so&mdash;or I certainly should not have intruded on you in such a manner; though at the same time, I should have been extremely sorry to leave London without seeing you and your sister; especially as it will most likely be some time&mdash;it is not probable that I should soon have the pleasure of meeting you again. END
BEGIN NOW I go to Oxford tomorrow. END
BEGIN NOW You would not have gone, however, said Elinor, recovering herself, and determined to get over what she so much dreaded as soon as possible, without receiving our good wishes, even if we had not been able to give them in person. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings was quite right in what she said. END
BEGIN NOW I have something of consequence to inform you of, which I was on the point of communicating by paper. END
BEGIN NOW I am charged with a most agreeable office (breathing rather faster than usual as she spoke.) END
BEGIN NOW Colonel Brandon, who was here only ten minutes ago, has desired me to say, that understanding you mean to take orders, he has great pleasure in offering you the living of Delaford now just vacant, and only wishes it were more valuable. END
BEGIN NOW Allow me to congratulate you on having so respectable and well-judging a friend, and to join in his wish that the living&mdash;it is about two hundred a-year&mdash;were much more considerable, and such as might better enable you to&mdash;as might be more than a temporary accommodation to yourself&mdash;such, in short, as might establish all your views of happiness. END
BEGIN NOW What Edward felt, as he could not say it himself, it cannot be expected that any one else should say for him. END
BEGIN NOW He LOOKED all the astonishment which such unexpected, such unthought-of information could not fail of exciting; but he said only these two words, Colonel Brandon! END
