BEGIN NOW Edward heard with pleasure of Colonel Brandon's being expected at the Cottage, as he really wished not only to be better acquainted with him, but to have an opportunity of convincing him that he no longer resented his giving him the living of Delaford&mdash; Which, at present, said he, after thanks so ungraciously delivered as mine were on the occasion, he must think I have never forgiven him for offering. END
BEGIN NOW NOW he felt astonished himself that he had never yet been to the place. END
BEGIN NOW But so little interest had he taken in the matter, that he owed all his knowledge of the house, garden, and glebe, extent of the parish, condition of the land, and rate of the tithes, to Elinor herself, who had heard so much of it from Colonel Brandon, and heard it with so much attention, as to be entirely mistress of the subject. END
BEGIN NOW One question after this only remained undecided, between them, one difficulty only was to be overcome. END
BEGIN NOW They were brought together by mutual affection, with the warmest approbation of their real friends; their intimate knowledge of each other seemed to make their happiness certain&mdash;and they only wanted something to live upon. END
BEGIN NOW Edward had two thousand pounds, and Elinor one, which, with Delaford living, was all that they could call their own; for it was impossible that Mrs. Dashwood should advance anything; and they were neither of them quite enough in love to think that three hundred and fifty pounds a-year would supply them with the comforts of life. END
BEGIN NOW Edward was not entirely without hopes of some favourable change in his mother towards him; and on THAT he rested for the residue of their income. END
BEGIN NOW But Elinor had no such dependence; for since Edward would still be unable to marry Miss Morton, and his chusing herself had been spoken of in Mrs. Ferrars's flattering language as only a lesser evil than his chusing Lucy Steele, she feared that Robert's offence would serve no other purpose than to enrich Fanny. END
BEGIN NOW About four days after Edward's arrival Colonel Brandon appeared, to complete Mrs. Dashwood's satisfaction, and to give her the dignity of having, for the first time since her living at Barton, more company with her than her house would hold. END
BEGIN NOW Edward was allowed to retain the privilege of first comer, and Colonel Brandon therefore walked every night to his old quarters at the Park; from whence he usually returned in the morning, early enough to interrupt the lovers' first tete-a-tete before breakfast. END
BEGIN NOW A three weeks' residence at Delaford, where, in his evening hours at least, he had little to do but to calculate the disproportion between thirty-six and seventeen, brought him to Barton in a temper of mind which needed all the improvement in Marianne's looks, all the kindness of her welcome, and all the encouragement of her mother's language, to make it cheerful. END
BEGIN NOW Among such friends, however, and such flattery, he did revive. END
BEGIN NOW No rumour of Lucy's marriage had yet reached him:&mdash;he knew nothing of what had passed; and the first hours of his visit were consequently spent in hearing and in wondering. END
BEGIN NOW Every thing was explained to him by Mrs. Dashwood, and he found fresh reason to rejoice in what he had done for Mr. Ferrars, since eventually it promoted the interest of Elinor. END
BEGIN NOW It would be needless to say, that the gentlemen advanced in the good opinion of each other, as they advanced in each other's acquaintance, for it could not be otherwise. END
BEGIN NOW Their resemblance in good principles and good sense, in disposition and manner of thinking, would probably have been sufficient to unite them in friendship, without any other attraction; but their being in love with two sisters, and two sisters fond of each other, made that mutual regard inevitable and immediate, which might otherwise have waited the effect of time and judgment. END
BEGIN NOW The letters from town, which a few days before would have made every nerve in Elinor's body thrill with transport, now arrived to be read with less emotion than mirth. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings wrote to tell the wonderful tale, to vent her honest indignation against the jilting girl, and pour forth her compassion towards poor Mr. Edward, who, she was sure, had quite doted upon the worthless hussy, and was now, by all accounts, almost broken-hearted, at Oxford.&mdash; I do think, she continued, nothing was ever carried on so sly; for it was but two days before Lucy called and sat a couple of hours with me. END
BEGIN NOW Not a soul suspected anything of the matter, not even Nancy, who, poor soul! END
BEGIN NOW came crying to me the day after, in a great fright for fear of Mrs. Ferrars, as well as not knowing how to get to Plymouth; for Lucy it seems borrowed all her money before she went off to be married, on purpose we suppose to make a show with, and poor Nancy had not seven shillings in the world;&mdash;so I was very glad to give her five guineas to take her down to Exeter, where she thinks of staying three or four weeks with Mrs. Burgess, in hopes, as I tell her, to fall in with the Doctor again. END
BEGIN NOW And I must say that Lucy's crossness not to take them along with them in the chaise is worse than all. END
BEGIN NOW Poor Mr. Edward! END
BEGIN NOW I cannot get him out of my head, but you must send for him to Barton, and Miss Marianne must try to comfort him. END
BEGIN NOW Mr. Dashwood's strains were more solemn. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Ferrars was the most unfortunate of women&mdash;poor Fanny had suffered agonies of sensibility&mdash;and he considered the existence of each, under such a blow, with grateful wonder. END
BEGIN NOW Robert's offence was unpardonable, but Lucy's was infinitely worse. END
BEGIN NOW Neither of them were ever again to be mentioned to Mrs. Ferrars; and even, if she might hereafter be induced to forgive her son, his wife should never be acknowledged as her daughter, nor be permitted to appear in her presence. END
BEGIN NOW The secrecy with which everything had been carried on between them, was rationally treated as enormously heightening the crime, because, had any suspicion of it occurred to the others, proper measures would have been taken to prevent the marriage; and he called on Elinor to join with him in regretting that Lucy's engagement with Edward had not rather been fulfilled, than that she should thus be the means of spreading misery farther in the family.&mdash; He thus continued: Mrs. Ferrars has never yet mentioned Edward's name, which does not surprise us; but, to our great astonishment, not a line has been received from him on the occasion. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps, however, he is kept silent by his fear of offending, and I shall, therefore, give him a hint, by a line to Oxford, that his sister and I both think a letter of proper submission from him, addressed perhaps to Fanny, and by her shewn to her mother, might not be taken amiss; for we all know the tenderness of Mrs. Ferrars's heart, and that she wishes for nothing so much as to be on good terms with her children. END
BEGIN NOW This paragraph was of some importance to the prospects and conduct of Edward. END
BEGIN NOW It determined him to attempt a reconciliation, though not exactly in the manner pointed out by their brother and sister. END
BEGIN NOW A letter of proper submission! END
BEGIN NOW repeated he; would they have me beg my mother's pardon for Robert's ingratitude to HER, and breach of honour to ME?&mdash;I can make no submission&mdash;I am grown neither humble nor penitent by what has passed.&mdash;I am grown very happy; but that would not interest.&mdash;I know of no submission that IS proper for me to make. END
BEGIN NOW You may certainly ask to be forgiven, said Elinor, because you have offended;&mdash;and I should think you might NOW venture so far as to profess some concern for having ever formed the engagement which drew on you your mother's anger. END
BEGIN NOW He agreed that he might. END
BEGIN NOW And when she has forgiven you, perhaps a little humility may be convenient while acknowledging a second engagement, almost as imprudent in HER eyes as the first. END
BEGIN NOW He had nothing to urge against it, but still resisted the idea of a letter of proper submission; and therefore, to make it easier to him, as he declared a much greater willingness to make mean concessions by word of mouth than on paper, it was resolved that, instead of writing to Fanny, he should go to London, and personally intreat her good offices in his favour.&mdash; And if they really DO interest themselves, said Marianne, in her new character of candour, in bringing about a reconciliation, I shall think that even John and Fanny are not entirely without merit. END
BEGIN NOW After a visit on Colonel Brandon's side of only three or four days, the two gentlemen quitted Barton together.&mdash; They were to go immediately to Delaford, that Edward might have some personal knowledge of his future home, and assist his patron and friend in deciding on what improvements were needed to it; and from thence, after staying there a couple of nights, he was to proceed on his journey to town. END
BEGIN NOW After a proper resistance on the part of Mrs. Ferrars, just so violent and so steady as to preserve her from that reproach which she always seemed fearful of incurring, the reproach of being too amiable, Edward was admitted to her presence, and pronounced to be again her son. END
BEGIN NOW Her family had of late been exceedingly fluctuating. END
BEGIN NOW For many years of her life she had had two sons; but the crime and annihilation of Edward a few weeks ago, had robbed her of one; the similar annihilation of Robert had left her for a fortnight without any; and now, by the resuscitation of Edward, she had one again. END
BEGIN NOW In spite of his being allowed once more to live, however, he did not feel the continuance of his existence secure, till he had revealed his present engagement; for the publication of that circumstance, he feared, might give a sudden turn to his constitution, and carry him off as rapidly as before. END
BEGIN NOW With apprehensive caution therefore it was revealed, and he was listened to with unexpected calmness. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Ferrars at first reasonably endeavoured to dissuade him from marrying Miss Dashwood, by every argument in her power;&mdash;told him, that in Miss Morton he would have a woman of higher rank and larger fortune;&mdash;and enforced the assertion, by observing that Miss Morton was the daughter of a nobleman with thirty thousand pounds, while Miss Dashwood was only the daughter of a private gentleman with no more than THREE; but when she found that, though perfectly admitting the truth of her representation, he was by no means inclined to be guided by it, she judged it wisest, from the experience of the past, to submit&mdash;and therefore, after such an ungracious delay as she owed to her own dignity, and as served to prevent every suspicion of good-will, she issued her decree of consent to the marriage of Edward and Elinor. END
BEGIN NOW What she would engage to do towards augmenting their income was next to be considered; and here it plainly appeared, that though Edward was now her only son, he was by no means her eldest; for while Robert was inevitably endowed with a thousand pounds a-year, not the smallest objection was made against Edward's taking orders for the sake of two hundred and fifty at the utmost; nor was anything promised either for the present or in future, beyond the ten thousand pounds, which had been given with Fanny. END
BEGIN NOW It was as much, however, as was desired, and more than was expected, by Edward and Elinor; and Mrs. Ferrars herself, by her shuffling excuses, seemed the only person surprised at her not giving more. END
BEGIN NOW With an income quite sufficient to their wants thus secured to them, they had nothing to wait for after Edward was in possession of the living, but the readiness of the house, to which Colonel Brandon, with an eager desire for the accommodation of Elinor, was making considerable improvements; and after waiting some time for their completion, after experiencing, as usual, a thousand disappointments and delays from the unaccountable dilatoriness of the workmen, Elinor, as usual, broke through the first positive resolution of not marrying till every thing was ready, and the ceremony took place in Barton church early in the autumn. END
BEGIN NOW The first month after their marriage was spent with their friend at the Mansion-house; from whence they could superintend the progress of the Parsonage, and direct every thing as they liked on the spot;&mdash;could chuse papers, project shrubberies, and invent a sweep. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Jennings's prophecies, though rather jumbled together, were chiefly fulfilled; for she was able to visit Edward and his wife in their Parsonage by Michaelmas, and she found in Elinor and her husband, as she really believed, one of the happiest couples in the world. END
BEGIN NOW They had in fact nothing to wish for, but the marriage of Colonel Brandon and Marianne, and rather better pasturage for their cows. END
BEGIN NOW They were visited on their first settling by almost all their relations and friends. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Ferrars came to inspect the happiness which she was almost ashamed of having authorised; and even the Dashwoods were at the expense of a journey from Sussex to do them honour. END
BEGIN NOW I will not say that I am disappointed, my dear sister, said John, as they were walking together one morning before the gates of Delaford House, THAT would be saying too much, for certainly you have been one of the most fortunate young women in the world, as it is. END
BEGIN NOW But, I confess, it would give me great pleasure to call Colonel Brandon brother. END
BEGIN NOW His property here, his place, his house, every thing is in such respectable and excellent condition!&mdash;and his woods!&mdash;I have not seen such timber any where in Dorsetshire, as there is now standing in Delaford Hanger!&mdash;And though, perhaps, Marianne may not seem exactly the person to attract him&mdash;yet I think it would altogether be advisable for you to have them now frequently staying with you, for as Colonel Brandon seems a great deal at home, nobody can tell what may happen&mdash;for, when people are much thrown together, and see little of anybody else&mdash;and it will always be in your power to set her off to advantage, and so forth;&mdash;in short, you may as well give her a chance&mdash;You understand me. END
BEGIN NOW &mdash; But though Mrs. Ferrars DID come to see them, and always treated them with the make-believe of decent affection, they were never insulted by her real favour and preference. END
BEGIN NOW THAT was due to the folly of Robert, and the cunning of his wife; and it was earned by them before many months had passed away. END
BEGIN NOW The selfish sagacity of the latter, which had at first drawn Robert into the scrape, was the principal instrument of his deliverance from it; for her respectful humility, assiduous attentions, and endless flatteries, as soon as the smallest opening was given for their exercise, reconciled Mrs. Ferrars to his choice, and re-established him completely in her favour. END
BEGIN NOW The whole of Lucy's behaviour in the affair, and the prosperity which crowned it, therefore, may be held forth as a most encouraging instance of what an earnest, an unceasing attention to self-interest, however its progress may be apparently obstructed, will do in securing every advantage of fortune, with no other sacrifice than that of time and conscience. END
BEGIN NOW When Robert first sought her acquaintance, and privately visited her in Bartlett's Buildings, it was only with the view imputed to him by his brother. END
BEGIN NOW He merely meant to persuade her to give up the engagement; and as there could be nothing to overcome but the affection of both, he naturally expected that one or two interviews would settle the matter. END
BEGIN NOW In that point, however, and that only, he erred;&mdash;for though Lucy soon gave him hopes that his eloquence would convince her in TIME, another visit, another conversation, was always wanted to produce this conviction. END
BEGIN NOW Some doubts always lingered in her mind when they parted, which could only be removed by another half hour's discourse with himself. END
BEGIN NOW His attendance was by this means secured, and the rest followed in course. END
BEGIN NOW Instead of talking of Edward, they came gradually to talk only of Robert,&mdash;a subject on which he had always more to say than on any other, and in which she soon betrayed an interest even equal to his own; and in short, it became speedily evident to both, that he had entirely supplanted his brother. END
BEGIN NOW He was proud of his conquest, proud of tricking Edward, and very proud of marrying privately without his mother's consent. END
BEGIN NOW What immediately followed is known. END
BEGIN NOW They passed some months in great happiness at Dawlish; for she had many relations and old acquaintances to cut&mdash;and he drew several plans for magnificent cottages;&mdash;and from thence returning to town, procured the forgiveness of Mrs. Ferrars, by the simple expedient of asking it, which, at Lucy's instigation, was adopted. END
BEGIN NOW The forgiveness, at first, indeed, as was reasonable, comprehended only Robert; and Lucy, who had owed his mother no duty and therefore could have transgressed none, still remained some weeks longer unpardoned. END
BEGIN NOW But perseverance in humility of conduct and messages, in self-condemnation for Robert's offence, and gratitude for the unkindness she was treated with, procured her in time the haughty notice which overcame her by its graciousness, and led soon afterwards, by rapid degrees, to the highest state of affection and influence. END
BEGIN NOW Lucy became as necessary to Mrs. Ferrars, as either Robert or Fanny; and while Edward was never cordially forgiven for having once intended to marry her, and Elinor, though superior to her in fortune and birth, was spoken of as an intruder, SHE was in every thing considered, and always openly acknowledged, to be a favourite child. END
BEGIN NOW They settled in town, received very liberal assistance from Mrs. Ferrars, were on the best terms imaginable with the Dashwoods; and setting aside the jealousies and ill-will continually subsisting between Fanny and Lucy, in which their husbands of course took a part, as well as the frequent domestic disagreements between Robert and Lucy themselves, nothing could exceed the harmony in which they all lived together. END
BEGIN NOW What Edward had done to forfeit the right of eldest son, might have puzzled many people to find out; and what Robert had done to succeed to it, might have puzzled them still more. END
BEGIN NOW It was an arrangement, however, justified in its effects, if not in its cause; for nothing ever appeared in Robert's style of living or of talking to give a suspicion of his regretting the extent of his income, as either leaving his brother too little, or bringing himself too much;&mdash;and if Edward might be judged from the ready discharge of his duties in every particular, from an increasing attachment to his wife and his home, and from the regular cheerfulness of his spirits, he might be supposed no less contented with his lot, no less free from every wish of an exchange. END
BEGIN NOW Elinor's marriage divided her as little from her family as could well be contrived, without rendering the cottage at Barton entirely useless, for her mother and sisters spent much more than half their time with her. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Dashwood was acting on motives of policy as well as pleasure in the frequency of her visits at Delaford; for her wish of bringing Marianne and Colonel Brandon together was hardly less earnest, though rather more liberal than what John had expressed. END
BEGIN NOW It was now her darling object. END
BEGIN NOW Precious as was the company of her daughter to her, she desired nothing so much as to give up its constant enjoyment to her valued friend; and to see Marianne settled at the mansion-house was equally the wish of Edward and Elinor. END
BEGIN NOW They each felt his sorrows, and their own obligations, and Marianne, by general consent, was to be the reward of all. END
BEGIN NOW With such a confederacy against her&mdash;with a knowledge so intimate of his goodness&mdash;with a conviction of his fond attachment to herself, which at last, though long after it was observable to everybody else&mdash;burst on her&mdash;what could she do? END
BEGIN NOW Marianne Dashwood was born to an extraordinary fate. END
BEGIN NOW She was born to discover the falsehood of her own opinions, and to counteract, by her conduct, her most favourite maxims. END
BEGIN NOW She was born to overcome an affection formed so late in life as at seventeen, and with no sentiment superior to strong esteem and lively friendship, voluntarily to give her hand to another!&mdash;and THAT other, a man who had suffered no less than herself under the event of a former attachment, whom, two years before, she had considered too old to be married,&mdash;and who still sought the constitutional safeguard of a flannel waistcoat! END
BEGIN NOW But so it was. END
BEGIN NOW Instead of falling a sacrifice to an irresistible passion, as once she had fondly flattered herself with expecting,&mdash;instead of remaining even for ever with her mother, and finding her only pleasures in retirement and study, as afterwards in her more calm and sober judgment she had determined on,&mdash;she found herself at nineteen, submitting to new attachments, entering on new duties, placed in a new home, a wife, the mistress of a family, and the patroness of a village. END
BEGIN NOW Colonel Brandon was now as happy, as all those who best loved him, believed he deserved to be;&mdash;in Marianne he was consoled for every past affliction;&mdash;her regard and her society restored his mind to animation, and his spirits to cheerfulness; and that Marianne found her own happiness in forming his, was equally the persuasion and delight of each observing friend. END
BEGIN NOW Marianne could never love by halves; and her whole heart became, in time, as much devoted to her husband, as it had once been to Willoughby. END
BEGIN NOW Willoughby could not hear of her marriage without a pang; and his punishment was soon afterwards complete in the voluntary forgiveness of Mrs. Smith, who, by stating his marriage with a woman of character, as the source of her clemency, gave him reason for believing that had he behaved with honour towards Marianne, he might at once have been happy and rich. END
BEGIN NOW That his repentance of misconduct, which thus brought its own punishment, was sincere, need not be doubted;&mdash;nor that he long thought of Colonel Brandon with envy, and of Marianne with regret. END
BEGIN NOW But that he was for ever inconsolable, that he fled from society, or contracted an habitual gloom of temper, or died of a broken heart, must not be depended on&mdash;for he did neither. END
BEGIN NOW He lived to exert, and frequently to enjoy himself. END
BEGIN NOW His wife was not always out of humour, nor his home always uncomfortable; and in his breed of horses and dogs, and in sporting of every kind, he found no inconsiderable degree of domestic felicity. END
BEGIN NOW For Marianne, however&mdash;in spite of his incivility in surviving her loss&mdash;he always retained that decided regard which interested him in every thing that befell her, and made her his secret standard of perfection in woman;&mdash;and many a rising beauty would be slighted by him in after-days as bearing no comparison with Mrs. Brandon. END
BEGIN NOW Mrs. Dashwood was prudent enough to remain at the cottage, without attempting a removal to Delaford; and fortunately for Sir John and Mrs. Jennings, when Marianne was taken from them, Margaret had reached an age highly suitable for dancing, and not very ineligible for being supposed to have a lover. END
BEGIN NOW Between Barton and Delaford, there was that constant communication which strong family affection would naturally dictate;&mdash;and among the merits and the happiness of Elinor and Marianne, let it not be ranked as the least considerable, that though sisters, and living almost within sight of each other, they could live without disagreement between themselves, or producing coolness between their husbands.  END
BEGIN NOW Once upon a time (Do you see the town's circled walls, in black watercolor on sepia?) END
BEGIN NOW there was a king who had three daughters. END
BEGIN NOW (A man's desk, covered in papers. END
BEGIN NOW A man's shadow over the desk. END
BEGIN NOW Three smaller shadows beyond him.) END
BEGIN NOW He wished to know which daughter loved him best. END
BEGIN NOW (Oh, do you see? END
BEGIN NOW The shadows are puppets. END
BEGIN NOW Look how they move their arms at the joints.) END
BEGIN NOW To her he would give his whole kingdom. END
BEGIN NOW (The town again, its clock tower looming above the walls.) END
BEGIN NOW The eldest daughter said, I love you more than my life. END
BEGIN NOW (One puppet spins in a pirouette.) END
BEGIN NOW The second daughter said, I love you more than the sun and all the stars. END
BEGIN NOW (Another puppet leaps into the air.) END
BEGIN NOW But the third daughter said, I love you as meat loves salt. END
BEGIN NOW (The last puppet stands still.) END
BEGIN NOW Now, the king was very angry at his youngest daughter. END
BEGIN NOW But which of the daughters really deserved the kingdom? END
BEGIN NOW — Princess Tutu, The Chapter of the Egg: The Duke's Daughters. END
BEGIN NOW Overture, King Lear, M. Balakirev. END
BEGIN NOW — Let us have a tragedy today, declared the Man Without Hands. END
BEGIN NOW An old one. END
BEGIN NOW I'll make it new again. END
BEGIN NOW Set it on a winter's night, the coldest night of the year. END
BEGIN NOW It will be an excellent story, don't you think? END
BEGIN NOW Twelve marionettes rose to their feet obediently and pulled at the cranks of the great machine. END
BEGIN NOW Far above them, up in the town, clouds slid into the sky, and a chill wind dropped the last leaves from the trees. END
BEGIN NOW Oh, yes, said the Man Without Hands. END
BEGIN NOW There will be snow tonight. END
BEGIN NOW And you, he said, gesturing with his gloved arms at the thirteenth marionette, you know what you are doing, don't you, hmmm? END
BEGIN NOW The thirteenth marionette lifted a box and opened it. END
BEGIN NOW She arranged a set of jewels in neat rows inside the box. END
BEGIN NOW She closed the box, set it aside, and tested the tuning of her barrel organ. END
BEGIN NOW It was in perfect tune. END
BEGIN NOW (It was always in perfect tune.) END
BEGIN NOW Then the thirteenth marionette took the box and the barrel organ, stepped onto a slowly-spinning gear, and let it wheel her up through the machine and out, through a hidden doorway, into the town. END
BEGIN NOW The Man Without Hands waved his right arm as if it were a baton. END
BEGIN NOW Now then, music! END
BEGIN NOW Timpani and horns, there, and the violins, there, yes. END
BEGIN NOW Very good. END
BEGIN NOW The clockwork orchestra whirred and began to play. END
BEGIN NOW — The thirteenth marionette, whose name was Edel, wheeled up into the town and listened to all of its sounds. END
BEGIN NOW She was part of the great machine, after all, and so was the town. END
BEGIN NOW Edel heard the beginning ballet students chattering: A performance at the Duke's castle! END
BEGIN NOW Isn't it exciting? END
BEGIN NOW Lilie rested her right foot on the barre and stretched over her leg. END
BEGIN NOW Her friend Pique stretched as well, and slowly slid into a split. END
BEGIN NOW Only the advanced class will be dancing. END
BEGIN NOW I wish we were allowed to perform. END
BEGIN NOW Yes! END
BEGIN NOW Lilie's grin was more than a little alarming. END
BEGIN NOW Then our little Duck could dance too, and she would probably fall down in front of the Duke himself! END
BEGIN NOW I would not, answered the third girl in the beginner class, who was gamely, if inelegantly, attempting a straddle stretch routine. END
BEGIN NOW Edel knew her, of course; she was the Duck. END
BEGIN NOW I didn't even know we had a Duke. END
BEGIN NOW Oh, Duck, laughed Lilie, You don't know anything, do you? END
BEGIN NOW Edel glided past the windows of the salle. END
BEGIN NOW The Duck cried out, and lost her balance, but Edel thought that no one else had seen her pass by. END
BEGIN NOW From the west window, Edel saw the advanced ballet class practicing its routine for the performance: Yes, yes, Miss Rue, the Cat was saying to the Raven Princess, support your arm just like that and hold it. END
BEGIN NOW Do you see her perfect form, ladies? END
BEGIN NOW Imitate it. END
BEGIN NOW Now, Mytho and Fakir, remember that you are the Clock, and your only duty is to tell the time. END
BEGIN NOW Don't look sour, Fakir, look like a clock. END
BEGIN NOW Edel watched the Prince and the Knight move, the two arms of a great invisible clock. END
BEGIN NOW She watched the Raven Princess lead the other dancers around them. END
BEGIN NOW She watched them step and spin and stretch, a corps of marionettes, dancing as the puppetmaster commanded them. END
BEGIN NOW — Oh, it's a fine stage, the Duke's castle, the Man Without Hands had said. END
BEGIN NOW It will be a pleasure to use it properly. END
BEGIN NOW Edel came inside through the servants' door, when the butler and housekeeper weren't looking. END
BEGIN NOW She passed through the kitchen, up the back staircase, and into the ballroom without difficulty. END
BEGIN NOW Edel knew all the houses in Gold Crown Town, after all, and had no need to ask for directions. END
BEGIN NOW In the ballroom, she found an empty niche between two statues, and stood still, one more statue ornamenting the Duke's household. END
BEGIN NOW Edel saw the two elder daughters as they entered the ballroom: two tall rats in silk gowns, snarling and biting at each other's tails. END
BEGIN NOW But when the troupe of young dancers came in to take their places, with the rest of the audience behind them, the daughters stopped squabbling. END
BEGIN NOW They smiled bland smiles through their teeth. END
BEGIN NOW The old Duke, a gold circlet on his wrinkled head and thin white whiskers on his snout, settled in the seat of honor, with his youngest daughter on his left. END
BEGIN NOW The Cat and the beginner and intermediate ballet classes seated themselves on the floor, along with a dozen party guests from elsewhere in the town. END
BEGIN NOW Tonight, announced the Duke, is a special night. END
BEGIN NOW Tonight I choose which of my daughters will inherit my castle! END
BEGIN NOW The party guests murmured in excitement. END
BEGIN NOW (The Duck was whispering, Did you know they were rats? ) END
BEGIN NOW But before I make my decision, I have brought us an exciting treat. END
BEGIN NOW I have commissioned a small dance from Gold Crown Town's own brilliant Mr. Cat, Director of the Gold Crown Academy Ballet School, to be performed by his best students. END
BEGIN NOW The Cat stood and bowed, smiling with his mouth closed so as not to alarm his patron, the rat Duke. END
BEGIN NOW We are honored to serve you, sir, the Cat answered. END
BEGIN NOW May I present the Waltz of the Hours from Coppélia? END
BEGIN NOW Twelve danseuses danced in four precise lines (assemblé, balancé, changement), with the Raven Princess at the head of the first line.Two danseurs stood behind them, mimicking the clock as it struck: first position arms, third, tendue, and repeat. END
BEGIN NOW Edel knew the dance well. END
BEGIN NOW It was the dance of the great tower clock. END
BEGIN NOW The Prince and the Knight showed the time, while the twelve members of the corps were the automata running the clock, the gears and the pulleys that caused the hours to strike. END
BEGIN NOW In the great machine of Gold Crown Town, Edel's twelve sisters were doing the same work, stepping the same steps, as the dancers in the Duke's ballroom. END
BEGIN NOW The Duke applauded the performance politely. END
BEGIN NOW His daughters, and the other guests, clapped along with him. END
BEGIN NOW Among the ballet students, the Duck cheered wildly while her friends attempted to quiet her. END
BEGIN NOW The dancers curtsied or bowed and joined the audience. END
BEGIN NOW Then the Duke stood again. END
BEGIN NOW He was taller than Edel, and his paws trembled with age, but he was a dignified old rat. END
BEGIN NOW My thanks to Mr. Cat and the Ballet School. END
BEGIN NOW Daughters, will you come up and join me? END
BEGIN NOW The three daughters, in their three silk gowns with their tails sticking out from the backs, came to stand beside the As you all know, continued the Duke, I am very old now, and I am ready to give my castle away to one of my daughters. END
BEGIN NOW But to win the castle, my daughters must each answer one question. END
BEGIN NOW The Duke had been speaking quietly, but now his voice rang out through the hall, and he shook his white whiskers at the crowd. END
BEGIN NOW Tell me now: how much do each of you love me? END
BEGIN NOW (In the audience, the Raven Princess flinched and covered the flinch with a smile.) END
BEGIN NOW The Duke's eldest daughter smiled a toothy smile. END
BEGIN NOW How much do I love you? END
BEGIN NOW I love you as much as my very own life. END
BEGIN NOW I love you more than my dreams and more than my wishes. END
BEGIN NOW The Duke, satisfied, pointed to his second daughter. END
BEGIN NOW Now, you. END
BEGIN NOW The Duke's second daughter smiled an even toothier smile. END
BEGIN NOW How much do I love you? END
BEGIN NOW Just as much as my sister does, if not more. END
BEGIN NOW I love you like the sun in the morning. END
BEGIN NOW I love you like the moon at night. END
BEGIN NOW I love you as much as anyone has ever loved another person. END
BEGIN NOW Very good. END
BEGIN NOW Now, Rattelia, how much do you love me? END
BEGIN NOW But the Duke's third daughter was not smiling. END
BEGIN NOW She said, What do you want me to tell you? END
BEGIN NOW I love you as much as you deserve. END
BEGIN NOW That's all. END
BEGIN NOW No more. END
BEGIN NOW Do you want me to make silly comparisons like my sisters did? END
BEGIN NOW Should I tell you that I love you like the gates of Gold Crown Town, the ones that never open to let anyone out? END
BEGIN NOW Be silent! END
BEGIN NOW snapped the Duke. END
BEGIN NOW You are a heartless child and unworthy of the gift you are asking for! END
BEGIN NOW The party guests were staring at the Duke and his youngest daughter, so of course no one was watching Edel. END
BEGIN NOW In her niche by the wall, Edel opened her jewelry box and touched a ruby. END
BEGIN NOW It glowed red. END
BEGIN NOW A moment later, so did the Duck's pendant. END
BEGIN NOW A heartshard! END
BEGIN NOW whispered the Duck. END
BEGIN NOW Louder, to her friends, she said, I have to—er, I have to—I have to find the bathroom, yeah, that's right, the bathroom. END
BEGIN NOW The Duck ran past Edel and out of the room, managing not to trip over her own feet. END
BEGIN NOW Thirty seconds later, Princess Tutu danced into the room, serene and perfect, bringing a wind of pink flower petals along with her. END
BEGIN NOW Edel adjusted her vision for a moment, so she could see what the guests were seeing: a great white swan, flying in through an open window. END
BEGIN NOW The guests whispered to each other: how strange, a swan in a ballroom. END
BEGIN NOW Rattelia, said Tutu, reaching out her right hand in invitation, come dance with me. END
BEGIN NOW Obedient, if confused, Rattelia took Tutu's hand in her paw and stepped into a pas-de-deux. END
BEGIN NOW You told your father, Tutu said gently, that you only loved him as much as he deserved. END
BEGIN NOW But look how unhappy he is. END
BEGIN NOW Tell me, Rattelia, Tutu continued, leading Rattelia into a turn, is that how you really feel? END
BEGIN NOW Rattelia stopped still and pulled herself out of the dance. END
BEGIN NOW Yes! END
BEGIN NOW Yes, that is exactly how I really feel. END
BEGIN NOW Leave me alone! END
BEGIN NOW Tutu stopped mid-step, confused. END
BEGIN NOW She danced into the niche behind the nearest statue, and a moment later she was a small girl. END
BEGIN NOW Oh, hello, Miss Edel, said the Duck to the statue. END
BEGIN NOW Hello, Duck, replied Edel. END
BEGIN NOW Miss Edel, what did I do wrong? END
BEGIN NOW There's a heartshard here, I know it, and I thought Rattelia had it, but she doesn't, and I don't know what to do! END

BEGIN NOW She knelt down to allow Cordelia to climb up onto her back, her small arms grasped tightly around The first step down the slope was a little steep and “Delia! END
BEGIN NOW Don’t do that!” she scolded, “It’s fine, I’m not going to drop you!” “Sorry.” Cordelia whispered plaintively, pressing a small kiss of apology to her sister’s cheek. END
BEGIN NOW “Well … it’s fine. END
BEGIN NOW Just stay still from now on.” Regan followed with trepidation, having always hated that this was the only route down to the beach. END
BEGIN NOW She very delicately tested the solidity of the ground with each step with her toes before committing her foot to the step. END
BEGIN NOW Her eyes were firmly set on her feet with her arms stretched out at her sides for balance. END
BEGIN NOW Eventually they were all happily tucking into the ‘last minute picnic’ that as it turned out consisted of nothing but a variety of cakes and a couple of large bottles of pink lemonade. END
BEGIN NOW “I can’t believe you forgot the cups.” Regan said, wrinkling her nose at having to take a drink directly from the bottle. END
BEGIN NOW “It’s more to carry. END
BEGIN NOW We didn’t need them,” she explained. END
BEGIN NOW “It’s not polite to drink from the bottle.” “Well no-one’s around to see, are they? END
BEGIN NOW Just drink it or go thirsty!” The two glared at each other for a moment in stony silence which Regan was the first to break with a perturbed huff. END
BEGIN NOW “Can we go crabbing now?” Cordelia asked very softly, gently tugging on “Yes, let’s go have some fun!” They gathered their lines and bait and buckets and began trekking over the sands. END
BEGIN NOW At the far end of the beach was a natural pool hidden within the rocks. END
BEGIN NOW When the tide washed in it covered the rocks completely but when it receded it left still, salty waters contained in what was essentially a giant rock pool. END
BEGIN NOW Ideal for swimming and perfect for crabbing. END
BEGIN NOW The girls sat at the edge of the pool, feet dangling into the warm water; Cordelia watching the ripples with fascination whilst “Now, Delia, do you want to sit on my lap and help me catch some crabs?” Together they cast the line and felt the weight at the end drag their hook to the bottom. END
BEGIN NOW After a minute or two, Cordelia, whose hand was around “We got one!” “You think so? END
BEGIN NOW Is it tugging?” “Yes! END
BEGIN NOW Yes!” she giggled delightedly. END
BEGIN NOW “Alright then, get off me and I’ll pull it up.” “Quick! END
BEGIN NOW Quick! END
BEGIN NOW Here’s the bucket!” Regan prompted. END
BEGIN NOW As gently as she could, “He looks like Mr Kent.” Cordelia chuckled. END
BEGIN NOW “Cordelia!” Regan gasped, appalled, as ” “Why not? END
BEGIN NOW It’s funny!” ” “I suppose he does a bit,” Regan conceded, her lips pursing in an attempt not to smile, “Let’s see if we can find one that looks like Edmund. END
BEGIN NOW All cross and red!” “And he pinches.” Cordelia pouted. END
BEGIN NOW The laughter of the three little girls carried out across the sands, ringing out amidst the rocks. END
BEGIN NOW The day was hot and stifling. END
BEGIN NOW It was the perfect day to sneak out and find crabs that looked like mean little boys; nothing could have been finer.  END
BEGIN NOW  A Certain great King once did rule over this Land, Who had all the Pleasure a King cold commend And livd in great Splendor with Honour and Peae, He reignd many Years not without great Increase. END
BEGIN NOW He had three fine Daughters of Beauty most bright, In whom this same King he did take much Delight; For Virtue and Wisdom none could them come near, Which caused their Father to love them most dear. END
BEGIN NOW The King had a Fancy to try all their Love, Which pleased him well then this Question to move, To see which of them then did love him the best, So calld them before him the Truth to protest. END
BEGIN NOW For unto my Joy and Comfort I see Three beautiful Children do stand before me: Now which of you three will do most for my Sake, Suppose that my Life now should lie at the Stake? END
BEGIN NOW To which then the Elder did make this Reply, The worst of all Deaths for thy Sake I could die, With the greatest of Tortures that Nature can name; O this I will bear for your Majestys Fame! END
BEGIN NOW The second made Answer, My Love is more dear Than ever my Sisters, as it shall appear; Although she expresses much Fidelity, My Love shall be seen unto your Majesty! END
BEGIN NOW Well spoke, my dear Daughters, the aged King said, My Heart is enamourd, and merely betrayd: But what says my youngest Girl? END
BEGIN NOW Prithee tell me, I want to hear thy Love amongst all the Three. END
BEGIN NOW My Love, said the Youngest, that I to you owe, Is the abundant Duty a Child ought to show; To honour my Father until that I die, And neer in Extremity from you will fly. END
BEGIN NOW Thy Love is but small, said the King, I do find, That youll shew no more than what Nature doth bind; I thought you had Reason to be as sincere As your eldest Sister, who loves me most dear. END
BEGIN NOW Henceforth I do banish you quite from my Court, And charge you no more in my Presence resort: I justly may say, thou art no Child of mine, Because you in Love from the Rest do decline. END
BEGIN NOW So I will make over my Scepter and Crown To your eldest Sisters of Fame and Renown; And they shall be Heirs to my whole Land, For all that I have shall be at their Command. END
BEGIN NOW My pompous Estate, nay, and my noble Train, For those thy two Sisters shall be to maintain; That peaceable now I may pass my Time away, And live with my Daughters till my dying Day. END
BEGIN NOW PART II. END
BEGIN NOW The youngest Daughters Misfortune; of her travelling into France; and how the King of France made her his Queen, THEIR flattring Speeches at length won his Heart, But now mind at length how he had his Desert; For his youngest Daughters causeless Banishment, The which he had Reason eer long to repent. END
BEGIN NOW For his poor young Daughter he wanderd up and down, Through many a Village and brave English Town; Because that her Father held her in Disdain, She then did resolve for to cross oer the Main. END
BEGIN NOW At length to fair France then this fair Lady came, The King then perceiving this beautiful Dame, He quickly was wounded by young Cupids Dart, Which deeply did wound him to the very Heart. END
BEGIN NOW Likewise the King of her Virtues had heard, His Heart was more and more to her endeard: Said he, That my Love to her shall be seen, Before my whole Court I will make her my Queen. END
BEGIN NOW Her aged old Father is now all the While With his eldest Daughters, who soon did beguile Him of his whole Kingdom, nay, Scepter and Crown, And quickly their aged old Father pulld down. END
BEGIN NOW The King for a While in his Court did remain, But his eldest Daughter soon lessend his Train: Then after so done, she did quickly contrive Him of all his Riches and Means to deprive. END
BEGIN NOW Whereas twenty Men he was wont for to have, To wait and attend on his Majesty grave: She lessend his Number, and brought him to ten, And quickly reducd them to only three Men. END
BEGIN NOW Nay, one she thought much for her Father to have, So took him away, that her Father m ght leave The Court and be gone, and there no longer stay, Which grieved the King, and made him thus say, Am I thus rewarded, the King then replyd, To be of my own at this Rate so denyd? END
BEGIN NOW It grieveth my Heart to think what Ive done, But now to my second Child Ill make my Moan. END
BEGIN NOW PART III. END
BEGIN NOW How the King was dethrond by his two eldest Daughters; and how his youngest Daughter restored him again. END
BEGIN NOW MY second dear Daughter with Pity I know, Will quickly consider my Sorrow and Woe; Ill go now unto her, and tell her my Grief, I make no Doubt but shell afford me Relief. END
BEGIN NOW The King he full fast to the Court then did go, Desiring his Sorrows for to let her know: She made him this Answer, That she was much grievd For all these Repulses that he had receivd, But no Ways could help him in this his Distress, Nor yet in the least could afford him Redress; But if he a While in the Kitchen would stay, Shed order him such as the Scullions give away. END
BEGIN NOW The King made this Answer to his Daughter then, Surely I am served the worst of all Men; For doing as I did by my Daughter dear, Which makes me lament, and shed many a Tear. END
BEGIN NOW To my eldest Daughter again Ill return, Perhaps shell give Ear to my pitiful Moan. END
BEGIN NOW Then straitway he went again to the Court, In Hopes to find her in a better Sort. END
BEGIN NOW And when he came there she straitway gave Command, For to have him sent away out of Hand; And orderd them quickly to drive him away, Saying, That in her Court he no longe should stay. END
BEGIN NOW Then he to his second Child again did hie, To eat of her Scraps that her Scullion set by, For such as for Charity askd at the Door Which grieved the King to the Heart more and more. END
BEGIN NOW But there of her Promise he then was denyd, Which caused the King to be dissatisfyd For on his refusing her Offer most kind, She said, At her Gate he small Comfor;t should find. END
BEGIN NOW Calling to Remembrance his young Daughters Word. END
BEGIN NOW It did to his Grief new Sorrow afford; To think how he had this poor Creature beguild Of all her whole Fortune, and ruind the Child. END
BEGIN NOW Which made him be troubled, nay, to rave a d tear, And rending the Locks of his Silver Hair; Which was such an Ornament to his old Age, Yet nothing at all could his Trouble asswage. END
BEGIN NOW To Rocks, and to Rivers, and watry Founts, To Hills, and to Woods, and he highest of Mounts He made his Complaint, and his hourly Moan, Until at length all those Things seemd to Then being thus possest with Discontent, Being fully resolvd, he over Sea went, And soon found his Daughter, being Queen of Frnce, Which made him amazed at her noble Chance. END
BEGIN NOW Most virtuous Lady! END
BEGIN NOW when this she did hear, She sent for her Father in Duty most dear: Most welcome are you, my reverend Lord, To what my whole Kingdom and Court doth afford. END
BEGIN NOW Then her noble King, for to grace his Queen, Shewd him all the Honour and Love could be seen: He for his whole Court then of Noblemen sent, For great Acclamations of Joy they were bent. END
BEGIN NOW But as they in Banqueting merrily were, She said, My dear Father how goes your Affairs? END
BEGIN NOW Indeed, my dear Daughter, I quite am disownd By your eldest Sisters, who have me dethrond. END
BEGIN NOW Then she started up from the Table, and said, Of my cruel Sisters, who have the betrayd, I will be revenged, and that instantly, If that I am sure in the Battle to die. END
BEGIN NOW The King and his Nobles did soon Answer make, My honoured Queen, for your dear Fathers Sake, Well venture our Lives to see him on the Throne In Spight of all those that do him disown. END
BEGIN NOW Then straight unto England they came in great Haste, But now comes the Tragedy here at the last; The Fight was no sooner begun, to be plain, But this noble Queen in the Battle was slain. END
BEGIN NOW The Queen being dead, then her Father espyd, He laid himself by her, and instantly dyd: Then straightway seeing this sudden Event, They put the two Daughters to Death by Consent. END
BEGIN NOW The Crown was left vacant, for Want of an Heir, There being none equal the Crown for to wear: The Crown was left useless, being without King, So sad Disobedience is the wost of all Sin.  END
BEGIN NOW KING Lear once ruled in this land, With princely pride and peace: And had all things with content That might his joys increase: Amongst those things that nature gave, Three daughters fair had he, So princely seeming beautiful, As fairer could not be. END
BEGIN NOW So on a time it pleasd the king, A question thus to move: Which of his daughters to his grace Could shew the dearest love. END
BEGIN NOW For to my age you bring content; Quoth he, then let me hear Which of you three in plighted troth The kindest will appear. END
BEGIN NOW To this the eldest first began, Dear father mild, quoth she, Before your face to do you good My blood shall renderd be: And for your sake my bleeding heart Shall there be cut in twain, Ere that I see your reverend age The smallest grief sustain. END
BEGIN NOW And so will I, the second said, Dear father for your sake; The worst of all extremities For you Ill undertake. END
BEGIN NOW And serve your highness night and day, With diligen et content an pure delight, Discomfort may remove, In doing so, you glad my soul, The aged father replyd. END
BEGIN NOW But what sayist thou, my youngest girl, How stands thy love allyd! END
BEGIN NOW My love, quoth young Cordelia, then, Which to your grace I owe; Shall be the duty of a child, And that is all I shall bestow. END
BEGIN NOW And wilt thou show no more, said he, Than doth thy duty bind? END
BEGIN NOW I well perceive thy love is small, When as no more we find. END
BEGIN NOW Henceforth I banish thee my court, Thou art no child of mine: Nor any part of this my realm, By favour shall be thine. END
BEGIN NOW Thy eldest sister offer more Than well I can demand; To whom I equally bestow My kingdom and my land. END
BEGIN NOW My pompeous state and all my goods That lovingly I may With those thy sisters be mantaind, Until my dying day. END
BEGIN NOW Thus flattering speaches won renown, By these two sisters here: The third had causeless banishment. END
BEGIN NOW Yet was her love most dear. END
BEGIN NOW For poor Cordelia patiently Went wandering up and down, Upheld, unpityd gentle maid, Thro many an English town. END
BEGIN NOW Until at last in famous France, She gentle fortune found: Tho poor and bare, yet she was deemd The fairest on the ground, Where when the King her virtue heard, And this fair lady seen. END
BEGIN NOW With full consent of all the court, He made her his wife and queen. END
BEGIN NOW Her father, old king Lear, this while With his two daughters staid, Forgetful of their promisd loves. END
BEGIN NOW Full soon the same denyd. END
BEGIN NOW And living in Queen Regans court, The eldest of the twain, She took from him his chiefest means, And most of all his train, But whereas twenty men were wont To wait with bended knee; She gave allowance unto ten, And after scarce to three. END
BEGIN NOW Nay, one she thought to much for him So she took all away In hopes that in her court, good king! END
BEGIN NOW He would no longer stay. END
BEGIN NOW Am I rewarded thus, said he, For giving all I have Unto children? END
BEGIN NOW and to beg For what I want or crave. END
BEGIN NOW Ill go unto my Goneril, My second child, I know Will be more kind and beautiful, And will relieve my woe. END
BEGIN NOW Full fast he hies unto her court. END
BEGIN NOW Where when she hears his moan, Returnd him answer that she grievd That all his means were gone. END
BEGIN NOW But no ways could relieve his wants, Yet if that he would stay, Within her kitchen, he might have What scullions gave away. END
BEGIN NOW When he had heard with bitter tears, He made this answer then, In what I did let me be made Examples to all men. END
BEGIN NOW I will return again, said he, Unto my Regan court; She will not use me thus, I hope, But in a kinder sort. END
BEGIN NOW Where when he came she gave command To drive him thence away: When he was well within my court, Quoth she, he could not stay. END
BEGIN NOW Then back again to Goneril, The woeful king did hie: That in her kitchen he might have, What scullions did set by. END
BEGIN NOW But there of that he was denyd, Which he had promisd late; For once refusing he should not Come after to her gate. END
BEGIN NOW Thus twixt his daughters, for relief, He wanderd up and down, Being glad to feed on beggars food, That lately wore a crown. END
BEGIN NOW And calling to remembrance then His youngest daughters words, Who said the duty of a child Was all that love affords; But doubting to repair to her, Whom he had banishd so, Grew frantic mad, and in his mind, He bore the wounds of woe. END
BEGIN NOW Which made him rend his milk white locks, And tresses from his head: And all with blood bestaind his cheeks, With age and honor spread. END
BEGIN NOW To hills and woods and watery founts He made his hourly moan, To hills and woods and senseless things, Did seem to sigh and groan. END
BEGIN NOW Even thus pressd with discontent He passed oer to France. END
BEGIN NOW In hopes from kind Cordelia there, To find some gentler chance. END
BEGIN NOW Most virtuous dame! END
BEGIN NOW which when she heard Of this her fathers grief, As in duty bound, she quickly sent Him comfort and relief. END
BEGIN NOW And by a train of noble peers, In brave and gallant sort, She gave in charge he should be brought To Againipuss court; Whose royal king, whose noble mind, So freely gave consent To muster up his knights at arms, To fame and courage bent. END
BEGIN NOW And so to England came with speed, To repossess king Lear; And drive his daughters from their thrones By his Cordalia dear. END
BEGIN NOW Where she, true hearted noble queen, Was in the battle slain; Yet he, good king, in his old days Possessd his crown again. END
BEGIN NOW But when he heard of Cordelias death, Who dyd indeed for love Of her dear father in whose cause She did the battle move; He swooning fell upon her breast From whence he never parted; But on her bosom left his life, That was so truly hearted. END
BEGIN NOW The Lords and Nobles when they saw The end of these events, The other sisters unto death They doomed by consents. END
BEGIN NOW And being dead their crowns they left Unto the next of kin. END
BEGIN NOW Thus have you seen the fall of pride, And disobedient sin.  END

BEGIN NOW (Brief tableau.) END
BEGIN NOW Well, there was once a very rich gentleman, and he'd three darters. END
BEGIN NOW And he thought to see how fond they was of him. END
BEGIN NOW So he says to the first, How much do you love me, my dear? END
BEGIN NOW Why, says she, as I love my life. END
BEGIN NOW That's good, says he. END
BEGIN NOW So he says to the second, How much do you love me, my dear? END
BEGIN NOW Why, says she, better nor all the world. END
BEGIN NOW That's good, says he. END
BEGIN NOW So he says to the third, How much do you love me, my dear? END
BEGIN NOW Why, she says, I love you as fresh meat loves salt, says she. END
BEGIN NOW Well, he were that angry. END
BEGIN NOW You don't love me at all, says he, and in my house you stay no more. END
BEGIN NOW So he drove her out there and then, and shut the door in her face. END
BEGIN NOW Well, she went away, on and on, till she came to a fen. END
BEGIN NOW And there she gathered a lot of rushes, and made them into a cloak kind o', with a hood to cover her from head to foot, and to hide her fine clothes. END
BEGIN NOW And then she went on and on till she came to a great house. END
BEGIN NOW Do you want a maid? END
BEGIN NOW says she. END
BEGIN NOW No, we don't, says they. END
BEGIN NOW I hain't nowhere to go, says she, and I'd ask no wages, and do any sort o' work, says she. END
BEGIN NOW Well, says they, if you like to wash the pots and scrape the saucepans, you may stay, says they. END
BEGIN NOW So she stayed there, and washed the pots and scraped the saucepans, and did all the dirty work. END
BEGIN NOW And because she gave no name, they called her Cap o' Rushes. END
BEGIN NOW Well, one day there was to be a great dance a little way off, and the servants was let go and look at the grand people. END
BEGIN NOW Cap o' Rushes said she was too tired to go, so she stayed at home. END
BEGIN NOW But when they was gone, she offed with her cap o' rushes, and cleaned herself, and went to the dance. END
BEGIN NOW And no one there was so finely dressed as her. END
BEGIN NOW Well, who should be there but her master's son, and what should he do but fall in love with her, the minute he set eyes on her. END
BEGIN NOW He wouldn't dance with anyone else. END
BEGIN NOW But before the dance were done, Cap o' Rushes she stepped off, and away she went home. END
BEGIN NOW And when the other maids was back, she was framin' to be asleep with her cap o' rushes on. END
BEGIN NOW Well, next morning, they says to her, You did miss a sight, Cap o' Rushes! END
BEGIN NOW What was that? END
BEGIN NOW says she. END
BEGIN NOW Why the beautifullest lady you ever see, dressed right gay and ga'. END
BEGIN NOW The young master, he never took his eyes off of her. END
BEGIN NOW Well, I should ha' liked to have seen her, says Cap o' Rushes. END
BEGIN NOW Well, there's to be another dance this evening, and perhaps she'll be there. END
BEGIN NOW But come the evening, Cap o' Rushes said she was too tired to go with them. END
BEGIN NOW Howsumdever, when they was gone, she offed with her cap o' rushes, and cleaned herself, and away she went to the dance. END
BEGIN NOW The master's son had been reckoning on seeing her, and he danced with no one else, and never took his eyes off of her. END
BEGIN NOW But before the dance was over, she slipped off, and home she went, and when the maids came back, she framed to be asleep with her cap o' rushes on. END
BEGIN NOW Next day they says to her again, Well, Cap o' Rushes, you should ha' been there to see the lady. END
BEGIN NOW There she was again, gay an' ga', and the young master he never took his eyes off of her. END
BEGIN NOW Well there, says she, I should ha' liked to ha' seen her. END
BEGIN NOW Well, says they, there's a dance again this evening, and you must go with us, for she's sure to be there. END
BEGIN NOW Well, come the evening, Cap o' Rushes said she was too tired to go, and do what they would, she stayed at home. END
BEGIN NOW But when they was gone, she offed with her cap o' rushes, and cleaned herself, and away she went to the dance. END
BEGIN NOW The master's son was rarely glad when he saw her. END
BEGIN NOW He danced with none but her, and never took his eyes off her. END
BEGIN NOW When she wouldn't tell him her name, nor where she came from, he gave her a ring, and told her if he didn't see her again he should die. END
BEGIN NOW Well, afore the dance was over, off she slipped, and home she went, and when the maids came home she was framing to be asleep with her cap o' rushes on. END
BEGIN NOW Well, next day they says to her, There, Cap o' Rushes, you didn't come last night, and now you won't see the lady, for there's no more dances. END
BEGIN NOW Well, I should ha' rarely liked to ha' seen her, says she. END
BEGIN NOW The master's son he tried every way to find out where the lady was gone, but go where he might, and ask whom he might, he never heard nothing about her. END
BEGIN NOW And he got worse and worse for the love of her till he had to keep his bed. END
BEGIN NOW Make some gruel for the young master, they says to the cook. END
BEGIN NOW He's dying for love of the lady. END
BEGIN NOW The cook she set about making it, when Cap o' Rushes came in. END
BEGIN NOW What are you a' doin' on? END
BEGIN NOW says she. END
BEGIN NOW I'm going to make some gruel for the young master, says the cook, for he's dying for love of the lady. END
BEGIN NOW Let me make it, says Cap o' Rushes. END
BEGIN NOW Well, the cook wouldn't at first, but at last she said yes, and Cap o' Rushes made the gruel. END
BEGIN NOW And when she had made it, she slipped the ring into it on the sly, before the cook took it upstairs. END
BEGIN NOW The young man, he drank it, and saw the ring at the bottom. END
BEGIN NOW Send for the cook, says he. END
BEGIN NOW So up she comes. END
BEGIN NOW Who made this here gruel? END
BEGIN NOW says he. END
BEGIN NOW I did, says the cook, for she were frightened, and he looked at her. END
BEGIN NOW No, you didn't, says he. END
BEGIN NOW Say who did it, and you shan't be harmed. END
BEGIN NOW Well, then, 'twas Cap o' Rushes, says she. END
BEGIN NOW So Cap o' Rushes came. END
BEGIN NOW Did you make the gruel? END
BEGIN NOW says he. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, I did, says she. END
BEGIN NOW Where did you get this ring? END
BEGIN NOW says she. END
BEGIN NOW From him as gave it me, says she. END
BEGIN NOW Who are you then? END
BEGIN NOW says the young man. END
BEGIN NOW I'll show you, says she. END
BEGIN NOW And she offed with her cap o' rushes, and there she was in her beautiful clothes. END
BEGIN NOW Well, the master's son he got well very soon, and they was to be married in a little time. END
BEGIN NOW It was to be a very grand wedding, and everyone was asked, far and near. END
BEGIN NOW And Cap o' Rushes' father was asked. END
BEGIN NOW But she never told nobody who she was. END
BEGIN NOW But afore the wedding she went to the cook, and say she, I want you to dress every dish without a mite o' salt. END
BEGIN NOW That will be rarely nasty, says the cook. END
BEGIN NOW That don't signify, says she. END
BEGIN NOW Very well, says the cook. END
BEGIN NOW Well, the wedding day came, and they was married. END
BEGIN NOW And after they was married, all the company sat down to their vittles. END
BEGIN NOW When they began to eat the meat, that was so tasteless they couldn't eat it. END
BEGIN NOW But Cap o' Rushes father, he tried first one dish and then another, and then he burst out crying. END
BEGIN NOW What's the matter? END
BEGIN NOW said the master's son to him. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW says he, I had a daughter. END
BEGIN NOW And I asked her how much she loved me. END
BEGIN NOW And she said, 'As much as fresh meat loves salt.' END
BEGIN NOW And I turned her from my door, for I thought she didn't love me. END
BEGIN NOW And now I see she loved me best of all. END
BEGIN NOW And she may be dead for aught I know. END
BEGIN NOW No, father, here she is, says Cap o' Rushes. END
BEGIN NOW And she goes up to him and puts her arms round him. END
BEGIN NOW And so they was happy ever after.  END
BEGIN NOW O golden-tongued Romance with serene lute! END
BEGIN NOW Fair plumed Syren! END
BEGIN NOW Queen of far away! END
BEGIN NOW Leave melodizing on this wintry day, Shut up thine olden pages, and be mute: Adieu! END
BEGIN NOW for once again the fierce dispute, Betwixt damnation and impassion'd clay Must I burn through; once more humbly assay The bitter-sweet of this Shakespearian fruit. END
BEGIN NOW Chief Poet! END
BEGIN NOW and ye clouds of Albion, Begetters of our deep eternal theme, When through the old oak forest I am gone, Let me not wander in a barren dream, But when I am consumed in the fire, Give me new Phoenix wings to fly at my desire.  END
BEGIN NOW  King Leir once ruled in this land With princely power and peace; And had all things with hearts content, That might his joys increase. END
BEGIN NOW Amongst those things that nature gave, Three daughters fair had he, So princely seeming beautiful, As fairer could not be. END
BEGIN NOW So on a time it pleas'd the king A question thus to move, Which of his daughters to his grace Could shew the dearest love: For to my age you bring content, Quoth he, then let me hear, Which of you three in plighted troth The kindest will appear. END
BEGIN NOW To whom the eldest thus began; Dear father, mind, quoth she, Before your face, to do you good, My blood shall render'd be: And for your sake my bleeding heart Shall here be cut in twain, Ere that I see your reverend age The smallest grief sustain. END
BEGIN NOW And so will I, the second said; Dear father, for your sake, The worst of all extremities I'll gently undertake: And serve your highness night and day With diligence and love; That sweet content and quietness Discomforts may remove. END
BEGIN NOW In doing so, you glad my soul, The aged king reply'd; But what sayst thou, my youngest girl, How is thy love ally'd? END
BEGIN NOW My love (quoth young Cordelia then) Which to your grace I owe, Shall be the duty of a child, And that is all I'll show. END
BEGIN NOW And wilt thou shew no more, quoth he, Than doth thy duty bind? END
BEGIN NOW I well perceive thy love is small, When as no more I find. END
BEGIN NOW Henceforth I banish thee my court, Thou art no child of mine; Nor any part of this my realm By favour shall be thine. END
BEGIN NOW Thy elder sisters loves are more Then well I can demand, To whom I equally bestow My kingdome and my land, My pompal state and all my goods, That lovingly I may With those thy sisters be maintain'd Until my dying day. END
BEGIN NOW Thus flattering speeches won renown, By these two sisters here; The third had causeless banishment, Yet was her love more dear: For poor Cordelia patiently Went wandring up and down, Unhelp'd, unpity'd, gentle maid, Through many an English town: Untill at last in famous France She gentler fortunes found; Though poor and bare, yet she was deem'd The fairest on the ground: Where when the king her virtues heard, And this fair lady seen, With full consent of all his court He made his wife and queen. END
BEGIN NOW Her father king Leir this while With his two daughters staid: Forgetful of their promis'd loves, Full soon the same decay'd; And living in queen Ragan's court, The eldest of the twain, She took from him his chiefest means, And most of all his train. END
BEGIN NOW For whereas twenty men were wont To wait with bended knee: She gave allowance but to ten, And after scarce to three; Nay, one she thought too much for him; So took she all away, In hope that in her court, good king, He would no longer stay. END
BEGIN NOW Am I rewarded thus, quoth he, In giving all I have Unto my children, and to beg For what I lately gave? END
BEGIN NOW I'll go unto my Gonorell: My second child, I know, Will be more kind and pitiful, And will relieve my woe. END
BEGIN NOW Full fast he hies then to her court; Where when she heard his moan Return'd him answer, That she griev'd That all his means were gone: But no way could relieve his wants; Yet if that he would stay Within her kitchen, he should have What scullions gave away. END
BEGIN NOW When he had heard, with bitter tears, He made his answer then; In what I did let me be made Example to all men. END
BEGIN NOW I will return again, quoth he, Unto my Ragan's court; She will not use me thus, I hope, But in a kinder sort. END
BEGIN NOW Where when he came, she gave command To drive him thence away: When he was well within her court (She said) he would not stay. END
BEGIN NOW Then back again to Gonorell The woeful king did hie, That in her kitchen he might have What scullion boy set by. END
BEGIN NOW But there of that he was deny'd, Which she had promis'd late: For once refusing, he should not Come after to her gate. END
BEGIN NOW Thus twixt his daughters, for relief He wandred up and down; Being glad to feed on beggars food, That lately wore a crown. END
BEGIN NOW And calling to remembrance then His youngest daughters words, That said the duty of a child Was all that love affords: But doubting to repair to her, Whom he had banish'd so, Grew frantick mad; for in his mind He bore the wounds of woe: Which made him rend his milk-white locks, And tresses from his head, And all with blood bestain his cheeks, With age and honour spread. END
BEGIN NOW To hills and woods and watry founts He made his hourly moan, Till hills and woods and sensless things, Did seem to sigh and groan. END
BEGIN NOW Even thus possest with discontents, He passed o're to France, In hopes from fair Cordelia there, To find some gentler chance; Most virtuous dame! END
BEGIN NOW which when she heard, Of this her father's grief, As duty bound, she quickly sent Him comfort and relief: And by a train of noble peers, In brave and gallant sort, She gave in charge he should be brought To Aganippus' court; Whose royal king, with noble mind So freely gave consent, To muster up his knights at arms, To fame and courage bent. END
BEGIN NOW And so to England came with speed, To repossesse king Leir And drive his daughters from their thrones By his Cordelia dear. END
BEGIN NOW Where she, true-hearted noble queen, Was in the battel slain; Yet he, good king, in his old days, Possest his crown again. END
BEGIN NOW But when he heard Cordelia's death, Who died indeed for love Of her dear father, in whose cause She did this battle move; He swooning fell upon her breast, From whence he never parted: But on her bosom left his life, That was so truly hearted. END
BEGIN NOW The lords and nobles when they saw The end of these events, The other sisters unto death They doomed by consents; And being dead, their crowns they left Unto the next of kin: Thus have you seen the fall of pride, And disobedient sin.  END

BEGIN NOW THE years come on, the years go by, And in my Northern valley I, Withdrawn from life, watch life go by. END
BEGIN NOW But I have formed within my heart A state that does not thus depart, Richer than life, greater than being, Truer in feeling and in seeing Than outward turbulence can know; Where time is still, like a large, slow And lofty bird that moves her wings In far, invisible flutterings To gaze on every part of space Yet poise for ever in one place; Where line and sound, colour and phrase Rebuild in clear, essential ways The powers behind the veil of sense; While tragic things are made intense By passion brooding on old dread, Till a faint light of beauty shed From night-enfolded agony Shews in the ways men fail and die The deeps whose knowledge never cloys But, striking inward without voice, Stirs me to tremble and rejoice. END
BEGIN NOW For twenty years and more than twenty I have found my riches and my plenty In poets dead and poets living, Painters and music-men, all giving, By life shut in creative deeds, Live force and insight to my needs; And long before I came to stand And hear your voice and touch your hand In that great treasure-house new-known, Where in their tower above the Town The masters of The Dial sit, I loved in every word of it Your finely tempered verse that told me Of patient power, and still can hold me By its authentic divination Of the right knowledge of creation, Its grave, still beauty brought to day Tissue by tissue in nature's way, Petal by petal sure to shew Imagination's quiet glow That burns intenseliest at the core. END
BEGIN NOW And through that twenty years and more I have been envious of your reach In speaking form and plastic speech, Your double energy of hand That puts two arts at your command While I must be content with one And feel true life but half begun; So that by graver as by pen You can create earth, stars, and men, And prove yourself by more than rime A prince of poets in our time. END
BEGIN NOW For these delights, and the delight Of converse in a Surrey night After the deep sound had lapsed by Of ocean-haunted poetry, For counsel and another zest Added to beauty's life-long quest I, in acknowledgment, would bring The homage of an offering; And, being too poor to reach the height Of my conception or requite Your greater giving equally, I search in my capacity And, by my self-appointed trade, Find something I myself have made, That here I offer. END
BEGIN NOW Let it be A token betwixt you and me Of admiration and loyalty. END
BEGIN NOW February th, The scene is a bedchamber in a one-storied house. END
BEGIN NOW The walls consist of a few courses of huge irregular boulders roughly squared and fitted together; a thatched roof rises steeply from the back wall. END
BEGIN NOW In the centre of the back wall is a doorway opening on a garden and covered by two leather curtains; the chamber is partially hung with similar hangings stitched with bright wools. END
BEGIN NOW There is a small window on each side of this door. END
BEGIN NOW Toward the front a bed stands with its head against the right wall; it has thin leather curtains hung by thongs and drawn back. END
BEGIN NOW Farther forward a rich robe and a crown hang on a peg in the same wall. END
BEGIN NOW There is a second door beyond the bed, and between this and the bed's head stands a small table with a bronze lamp and a bronze cup on it. END
BEGIN NOW Queen MANY, many must die who long to live, Yet this one cannot die who longs to die: Even her sleep, come now at last, thwarts death, Although sleep lures us all half way to death.... END
BEGIN NOW I could not sit beside her every night If I believed that I might suffer so: I am sure I am not made to be diseased, I feel there is no malady can touch me— Save the red cancer, growing where it will. END
BEGIN NOW Taking her beads from her girdle, she kneels at the foot of the bed. END
BEGIN NOW O sweet Saint Cleer, and sweet Saint Elid too, Shield me from rooting cancers and from madness: Shield me from sudden death, worse than two death-beds; Let me not lie like this unwanted queen, Yet let my time come not ere I am ready— Grant space enow to relish the watchers' tears And give my clothes away and calm my features And streek my limbs according to my will, Not the hard will of fumbling corpse-washers. END
BEGIN NOW She prays silently. END

BEGIN NOW Sire, midnight should have ended Gormflaith's watch, But Gormflaith had another kind of will And ended at a godlier hour by slumber, A letter in her hand, the night-lamp out. END
BEGIN NOW She loitered in the hall when she should sleep. END
BEGIN NOW My duty has two hours ere she returns. END
BEGIN NOW The Queen should have young women about her bed, Fresh cool-breathed women to lie down at her side And plenish her with vigour; for sick or wasted women Can draw a virtue from such abounding presence, When night makes life unwary and looses the strings of being, Even by the breath, and most of all by sleep. END
BEGIN NOW Her slumber was then no fault: go you and find her. END
BEGIN NOW It is not strange that a bought watcher drowses; What is most strange is that the Queen sleeps Who would not sleep for all my draughts of sleep In the last days. END
BEGIN NOW When did this change appear? END
BEGIN NOW We shall not know—it came while When I awoke her and she saw the Queen She could not speak for fear: When the rekindling lamp showed certainly The bed-clothes stirring about our lady's neck, She knew there was no death, she breathed, she said She had not slept until her mistress slept And lulled her; but I asked her how her mistress Slept, and her utterance faded. END
BEGIN NOW She should be blamed with rods, as I was blamed For slumber, after a day and a night of watching, By the Queen's child-bed, twenty years ago. END
BEGIN NOW She does what she must do: let her alone. END
BEGIN NOW I know her watch is now: get gone and send her. END
BEGIN NOW Is it a portent now to sleep at night? END
BEGIN NOW What change is here? END
BEGIN NOW What see you in the Queen? END
BEGIN NOW Can you discern how this disease will end? END
BEGIN NOW Surmise might spring and healing follow yet, If I could find a trouble that could heal; But these strong inward pains that keep her ebbing Have not their source in perishing flesh. END
BEGIN NOW I have seen women creep into their beds And sink with this blind pain because they nursed Some bitterness or burden in the mind That drew the life, sucklings too long at breast. END
BEGIN NOW Do you know such a cause in this poor lady? END
BEGIN NOW There is no cause. END
BEGIN NOW How should there be a cause? END
BEGIN NOW We cannot die wholly against our wills; And in the texture of women I have found Harder determination than in men: The body grows impatient of enduring, The harried mind is from the body estranged, And we consent to go: by the Queen's touch, The way she moves—or does not move—in bed, The eyes so cold and keen in her white mask, I know she has consented. END
BEGIN NOW The snarling look of a mute wounded hawk, That would be let alone, is always hers— Yet she was sorely tender: it may be Some wound in her affection will not heal. END
BEGIN NOW We should be careful—the mind can so be hurt That nought can make it be unhurt again. END
BEGIN NOW Where, then, did her affection most persist? END
BEGIN NOW Old bone-patcher, old digger in men's flesh, Doctors are ever itching to be priests, Meddling in conduct, natures, life's privacies. END
BEGIN NOW We have been coupled now for twenty years, And she has never turned from me an hour— She knows a woman's duty and a queen's: Whose, then, can her affection be but mine? END
BEGIN NOW How can I hurt her—she is still my queen? END
BEGIN NOW If her strong inward pain is a real pain Find me some certain drug to medicine it: When common beings have decayed past help, There must be still some drug for a king to use; For nothing ought to be denied to kings. END
BEGIN NOW For the mere anguish there is such a potion. END
BEGIN NOW The gum of warpy juniper shoots is seethed With the torn marrow of an adder's spine; An unflawed emerald is pashed to dust And mingled there; that broth must cool in moonlight. END
BEGIN NOW I have indeed attempted this already, But the poor emeralds I could extort From wry-mouthed earls' women had no force. END
BEGIN NOW In two more dawns it will be late for potions.... END
BEGIN NOW There are not many emeralds in Britain, And there is none for vividness and strength Like the great stone that hangs upon your breast: If you will waste it for her she shall be holpen. END
