BEGIN NOW Where have you been, my falcon? END
BEGIN NOW I dreamt that I was swimming, shoulder up, And drave the bed-clothes spreading to the floor: Coldness awoke me; through the waning darkness I heard far hounds give shivering aëry tongue, Remote, withdrawing, suddenly faint and near; I leapt and saw a pack of stretching weasels Hunt a pale coney in a soundless rush, Their elfin and thin yelping pierced my heart As with an unseen beauty long awaited; Wolf-skin and cloak I buckled over this night-gear, And took my honoured spear from my bed-side Where none but I may touch its purity, And sped as lightly down the dewy bank As any mothy owl that hunts quick mice. END
BEGIN NOW They went crying, crying, but I lost them Before I stept, with the first tips of light, On Raven Crag near by the Druid Stones; So I paused there and, stooping, pressed my hand Against the stony bed of the clear stream; Then entered I the circle and raised up My shining hand in cold stern adoration Even as the first great gleam went up the sky. END
BEGIN NOW Ay, you do well to worship on that height: Life is free to the quick up in the wind, And the wind bares you for a god's descent— For wind is a spirit immediate and aged. END
BEGIN NOW And you do well to worship harsh men-gods, God Wind and Those who built his Stones with him: All gods are cruel, bitter, and to be bribed, But women-gods are mean and cunning as well. END
BEGIN NOW That fierce old virgin, Cornish Merryn, prays To a young woman, yes and even a virgin— The poorest kind of woman—and she says That is to be a Christian: avoid then Her worship most, for men hate such denials, And any woman scorns her unwed daughter. END
BEGIN NOW Where sped you from that height? END
BEGIN NOW Did Regan join you there? END
BEGIN NOW Does Regan worship anywhere at dawn? END
BEGIN NOW The sweaty half-clad cook-maids render lard Out in the scullery, after pig-killing, And Regan sidles among their greasy skirts, Smeary and hot as they, for craps to suck. END
BEGIN NOW I lost my thoughts before the giant Stones... And when anew the earth assembled round me I swung out on the heath and woke a hare And speared it at a cast and shouldered it, Startled another drinking at a tarn And speared it ere it leapt; so steady and clear Had the god in his fastness made my mind. END
BEGIN NOW Then, as I took those dead things in my hands, I felt shame light my face from deep within, And loathing and contempt shake in my bowels, That such unclean coarse blows from me had issued To crush delicate things to bloody mash And blemish their fur when I would only kill. END
BEGIN NOW My gladness left me; I careered no more Upon the morning; I went down from there With empty hands: But under the first trees and without thought I stole on conies at play and stooped at one; I hunted it, I caught it up to me As I outsprang it, and with this thin knife Pierced it from eye to eye; and it was dead, Untorn, unsullied, and with flawless fur. END
BEGIN NOW Then my untroubled mind came back to me. END
BEGIN NOW Leap down the glades with a fawn's ignorance; Live you your fill of a harsh purity; Be wild and calm and lonely while you may. END
BEGIN NOW These are your nature's joys, and it is human Only to recognize our natures' joys When we are losing them for ever. END
BEGIN NOW But why Do you say this to me with a sore heart? END
BEGIN NOW You are a queen, and speak from the top of life, And when you choose to wish for others' joys Those others must have woe. END
BEGIN NOW The hour comes for you to turn to a man And give yourself with the high heart of youth More lavishly than a queen gives anything. END
BEGIN NOW But when a woman gives herself She must give herself for ever and have faith; For woman is a thing of a season of years, She is an early fruit that will not keep, She can be drained and as a husk survive To hope for reverence for what has been; While man renews himself into old age, And gives himself according to his need, And women more unborn than his next child May take him yet with youth And lose him with their potence. END
BEGIN NOW But women need not wed these men. END
BEGIN NOW We are good human currency, like gold, For men to pass among them when they choose. END

BEGIN NOW Hard and unjust my father has been to me; Yet that has knitted up within my mind A love of coldness and a love of him Who makes me firm, wary, swift and secret, Until I feel if I become a mother I shall at need be cruel to my children, And ever cold, to string their natures harder And make them able to endure men's deeds; But now I wonder if injustice Keeps house with baseness, taught by kinship— I never thought a king could be untrue, I never thought my father was unclean.... BEGIN NOW She stands beside that crumbling mother in her hate, And, though we know so well—she and I, O we know— That she could love no mother nor partake in anguish, Yet she is flouted when the King forsakes her dam, She must protect her very flesh, her tenderer flesh, Although she cannot wince; she's wild in her cold brain, And soon I must be made to pay a cruel price For this one gloomy joy in my uncherished life. END

BEGIN NOW Goldilocks, when the crown is couching in your hair And those two mingled golds brighten each other's wonder, You shall produce a son from flesh unused— Virgin I chose you for that, first crops are strongest— A tawny fox with your high-stepping action, With your untiring power and glittering eyes, To hold my lands together when I am done, To keep my lands from crumbling into mouthfuls For the short jaws of my three mewling vixens. END

BEGIN NOW When she is dead I know you'll buy another Queen— Giving a county for her, gaining a duchy with her— And put me to wet nursing, leashing me with the thralls. END

BEGIN NOW She follows After a moments interval two elderly women, one a little younger than the other, enter by the same door: they wear black hoods and shapeless black gowns with large sleeves that flap like the wings of ungainly birds: between them they carry a heavy cauldron of hot water. END

BEGIN NOW Her pocket is empty; Hearken, and then begin: You have not touched a royal corpse before, But I have stretched a king and an old queen, A king's aunt and a king's brother too, Without much boasting of a still-born princess; So that I know, as a priest knows his prayers, All that is written in the chamberlain's book About the handling of exalted corpses, Stripping them and trussing them for the grave: And there it says that the chief corpse-washer Shall take for her own use by sacred right The coverlid, the upper sheet, the mattress Of any bed in which a queen has died, And the last robe of state the body wore; While humbler helpers may divide among them The under sheet, the pillow, and the bed-gown Stript from the cooling queen. END

A little blood is lightly washed away, A common stain that need not be remembered; And a hot spasm of rightness quickly born Can guide me to kill justly and shall guide. END

END
BEGIN NOW What will you say against me and my deed? END
BEGIN NOW That now you cannot save yourself from me. END
BEGIN NOW While your blind virgin power still stood apart In an unused, unviolated life, You judged me in my weakness, and because I felt you unflawed I could not answer you; But you have mingled in mortality And violently begun the common life By fault against your fellows; and the state, The state of Britain that inheres in me Not touched by my humanity or sin, Passions or privy acts, shall be as hard And savage to you as to a murderess. END

BEGIN NOW  Scene: - Britain. END
BEGIN NOW ACT I. END
BEGIN NOW Scene I. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Kent, Gloucester, and Edmund. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW I thought the King had more affected the Duke of Albany than Cornwall. END
BEGIN NOW It did always seem so to us; but now, in the division of the kingdom, it appears not which of the Dukes he values most, for equalities are so weigh'd that curiosity in neither can make choice of either's moiety. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Is not this your son, my lord? END
BEGIN NOW His breeding, sir, hath been at my charge. END
BEGIN NOW I have so often blush'd to acknowledge him that now I am braz'd to't. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW I cannot conceive you. END
BEGIN NOW Sir, this young fellow's mother could; whereupon she grew round-womb'd, and had indeed, sir, a son for her cradle ere she had a husband for her bed. END
BEGIN NOW Do you smell a fault? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW I cannot wish the fault undone, the issue of it being so proper. END
BEGIN NOW But I have, sir, a son by order of law, some year elder than this, who yet is no dearer in my account. END
BEGIN NOW Though this knave came something saucily into the world before he was sent for, yet was his mother fair, there was good sport at his making, and the whoreson must be acknowledged.- Do you know this noble gentleman, Edmund? END

BEGIN NOW My Lord of Kent. END

BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW I must love you, and sue to know you better. END

BEGIN NOW The King is coming. END
BEGIN NOW Enter one bearing a coronet; then Lear; then the Dukes of Albany and Cornwall; next, Goneril, Regan, Cordelia, with Followers. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Attend the lords of France and Burgundy, Gloucester. END
BEGIN NOW I shall, my liege. END
BEGIN NOW Exeunt Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Meantime we shall express our darker purpose. END
BEGIN NOW Give me the map there. END
BEGIN NOW Know we have divided In three our kingdom; and 'tis our fast intent To shake all cares and business from our age, Conferring them on younger strengths while we Unburthen'd crawl toward death. END
BEGIN NOW Our son of Cornwall, And you, our no less loving son of Albany, We have this hour a constant will to publish Our daughters' several dowers, that future strife May be prevented now. END
BEGIN NOW The princes, France and Burgundy, Great rivals in our youngest daughter's love, Long in our court have made their amorous sojourn, And here are to be answer'd. END
BEGIN NOW Tell me, my daughters (Since now we will divest us both of rule, Interest of territory, cares of state), Which of you shall we say doth love us most? END
BEGIN NOW That we our largest bounty may extend Where nature doth with merit challenge. END
BEGIN NOW Goneril, Our eldest-born, speak first. END
BEGIN NOW Sir, I love you more than words can wield the matter; Dearer than eyesight, space, and liberty; Beyond what can be valued, rich or rare; No less than life, with grace, health, beauty, honour; As much as child e'er lov'd, or father found; A love that makes breath poor, and speech unable. END
BEGIN NOW Beyond all manner of so much I love you. END
BEGIN NOW What shall Cordelia speak? END
BEGIN NOW Love, and be silent. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Of all these bounds, even from this line to this, With shadowy forests and with champains rich'd, With plenteous rivers and wide-skirted meads, We make thee lady. END
BEGIN NOW To thine and Albany's issue Be this perpetual.- What says our second daughter, Our dearest Regan, wife to Cornwall? END
BEGIN NOW Speak. END
BEGIN NOW Sir, I am made Of the selfsame metal that my sister is, And prize me at her worth. END
BEGIN NOW In my true heart I find she names my very deed of love; Only she comes too short, that I profess Myself an enemy to all other joys Which the most precious square of sense possesses, And find I am alone felicitate In your dear Highness' love. END
BEGIN NOW Then poor Cordelia! END
BEGIN NOW And yet not so; since I am sure my love's More richer than my tongue. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW To thee and thine hereditary ever Remain this ample third of our fair kingdom, No less in space, validity, and pleasure Than that conferr'd on - Now, our joy, Although the last, not least; to whose young love The vines of France and milk of Burgundy Strive to be interest; what can you say to draw A third more opulent than your sisters? END
BEGIN NOW Speak. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing, my lord. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing? END
BEGIN NOW Nothing. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing can come of nothing. END
BEGIN NOW Speak again. END
BEGIN NOW Unhappy that I am, I cannot heave My heart into my mouth. END
BEGIN NOW I love your Majesty According to my bond; no more nor less. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW How, how, Cordelia? END
BEGIN NOW Mend your speech a little, Lest it may mar your fortunes. END
BEGIN NOW Good my lord, You have begot me, bred me, lov'd me; I Return those duties back as are right fit, Obey you, love you, and most honour you. END
BEGIN NOW Why have my sisters husbands, if they say They love you all? END
BEGIN NOW Haply, when I shall wed, That lord whose hand must take my plight shall carry Half my love with him, half my care and duty. END
BEGIN NOW Sure I shall never marry like my sisters, To love my father all. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW But goes thy heart with this? END
BEGIN NOW Ay, good my lord. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW So young, and so untender? END
BEGIN NOW So young, my lord, and true. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Let it be so! END
BEGIN NOW thy truth then be thy dower! END
BEGIN NOW For, by the sacred radiance of the sun, The mysteries of Hecate and the night; By all the operation of the orbs From whom we do exist and cease to be; Here I disclaim all my paternal care, Propinquity and property of blood, And as a stranger to my heart and me Hold thee from this for ever. END
BEGIN NOW The barbarous Scythian, Or he that makes his generation messes To gorge his appetite, shall to my bosom Be as well neighbour'd, pitied, and reliev'd, As thou my sometime daughter. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Good my liege- Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Peace, Kent! END
BEGIN NOW Come not between the dragon and his wrath. END
BEGIN NOW I lov'd her most, and thought to set my rest On her kind nursery.- Hence and avoid my sight!- So be my grave my peace as here I give Her father's heart from her! END
BEGIN NOW Call France! END
BEGIN NOW Who stirs? END
BEGIN NOW Call Burgundy! END
BEGIN NOW Cornwall and Albany, With my two daughters' dowers digest this third; Let pride, which she calls plainness, marry her. END
BEGIN NOW I do invest you jointly in my power, Preeminence, and all the large effects That troop with majesty. END
BEGIN NOW Ourself, by monthly course, With reservation of an hundred knights, By you to be sustain'd, shall our abode Make with you by due turns. END
BEGIN NOW Only we still retain The name, and all th' additions to a king. END
BEGIN NOW The sway, Revenue, execution of the rest, Beloved sons, be yours; which to confirm, This coronet part betwixt you. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Royal Lear, Whom I have ever honour'd as my king, Lov'd as my father, as my master follow'd, As my great patron thought on in my prayers- Lear. END
BEGIN NOW The bow is bent and drawn; make from the shaft. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Let it fall rather, though the fork invade The region of my heart! END
BEGIN NOW Be Kent unmannerly When Lear is mad. END
BEGIN NOW What wouldst thou do, old man? END
BEGIN NOW Think'st thou that duty shall have dread to speak When power to flattery bows? END
BEGIN NOW To plainness honour's bound When majesty falls to folly. END
BEGIN NOW Reverse thy doom; And in thy best consideration check This hideous rashness. END
BEGIN NOW Answer my life my judgment, Thy youngest daughter does not love thee least, Nor are those empty-hearted whose low sound Reverbs no hollowness. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Kent, on thy life, no more! END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW My life I never held but as a pawn To wage against thine enemies; nor fear to lose it, Thy safety being the motive. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Out of my sight! END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW See better, Lear, and let me still remain The true blank of thine eye. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Now by Apollo- Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Now by Apollo, King, Thou swear'st thy gods in vain. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW O vassal! END
BEGIN NOW miscreant! END
BEGIN NOW , Dear sir, forbear! END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Do! END
BEGIN NOW Kill thy physician, and the fee bestow Upon the foul disease. END
BEGIN NOW Revoke thy gift, Or, whilst I can vent clamour from my throat, I'll tell thee thou dost evil. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Hear me, recreant! END
BEGIN NOW On thine allegiance, hear me! END
BEGIN NOW Since thou hast sought to make us break our vow- Which we durst never yet- and with strain'd pride To come between our sentence and our power,- Which nor our nature nor our place can bear,- Our potency made good, take thy reward. END
BEGIN NOW Five days we do allot thee for provision To shield thee from diseases of the world, And on the sixth to turn thy hated back Upon our kingdom. END
BEGIN NOW If, on the tenth day following, Thy banish'd trunk be found in our dominions, The moment is thy death. END
BEGIN NOW Away! END
BEGIN NOW By Jupiter, This shall not be revok'd. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Fare thee well, King. END
BEGIN NOW Since thus thou wilt appear, Freedom lives hence, and banishment is here. END
BEGIN NOW The gods to their dear shelter take thee, maid, That justly think'st and hast most rightly said! END
BEGIN NOW And your large speeches may your deeds approve, That good effects may spring from words of love. END
BEGIN NOW Thus Kent, O princes, bids you all adieu; He'll shape his old course in a country new. END
BEGIN NOW Exit. END
BEGIN NOW Flourish. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Gloucester, with France and Burgundy; Attendants. END
BEGIN NOW Here's France and Burgundy, my noble lord. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW My Lord of Burgundy, We first address toward you, who with this king Hath rivall'd for our daughter. END
BEGIN NOW What in the least Will you require in present dower with her, Or cease your quest of love? END
BEGIN NOW Most royal Majesty, I crave no more than hath your Highness offer'd, Nor will you tender less. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Right noble Burgundy, When she was dear to us, we did hold her so; But now her price is fall'n. END
BEGIN NOW Sir, there she stands. END
BEGIN NOW If aught within that little seeming substance, Or all of it, with our displeasure piec'd, And nothing more, may fitly like your Grace, She's there, and she is yours. END
BEGIN NOW I know no answer. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Will you, with those infirmities she owes, Unfriended, new adopted to our hate, Dow'r'd with our curse, and stranger'd with our oath, Take her, or leave her? END
BEGIN NOW Pardon me, royal sir. END
BEGIN NOW Election makes not up on such conditions. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Then leave her, sir; for, by the pow'r that made me, I tell you all her wealth. END
BEGIN NOW For you, great King, I would not from your love make such a stray To match you where I hate; therefore beseech you T' avert your liking a more worthier way Than on a wretch whom nature is asham'd Almost t' acknowledge hers. END
BEGIN NOW France. END
BEGIN NOW This is most strange, That she that even but now was your best object, The argument of your praise, balm of your age, Most best, most dearest, should in this trice of time Commit a thing so monstrous to dismantle So many folds of favour. END
BEGIN NOW Sure her offence Must be of such unnatural degree That monsters it, or your fore-vouch'd affection Fall'n into taint; which to believe of her Must be a faith that reason without miracle Should never plant in me. END
BEGIN NOW I yet beseech your Majesty, If for I want that glib and oily art To speak and purpose not, since what I well intend, I'll do't before I speak- that you make known It is no vicious blot, murther, or foulness, No unchaste action or dishonoured step, That hath depriv'd me of your grace and favour; But even for want of that for which I am richer- A still-soliciting eye, and such a tongue As I am glad I have not, though not to have it Hath lost me in your liking. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Better thou Hadst not been born than not t' have pleas'd me better. END
BEGIN NOW France. END
BEGIN NOW Is it but this- a tardiness in nature Which often leaves the history unspoke That it intends to do? END
BEGIN NOW My Lord of Burgundy, What say you to the lady? END
BEGIN NOW Love's not love When it is mingled with regards that stands Aloof from th' entire point. END
BEGIN NOW Will you have her? END
BEGIN NOW She is herself a dowry. END
BEGIN NOW Royal Lear, Give but that portion which yourself propos'd, And here I take Cordelia by the hand, Duchess of Burgundy. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing! END
BEGIN NOW I have sworn; I am firm. END
BEGIN NOW I am sorry then you have so lost a father That you must lose a husband. END
BEGIN NOW Peace be with Burgundy! END
BEGIN NOW Since that respects of fortune are his love, I shall not be his wife. END
BEGIN NOW France. END
BEGIN NOW Fairest Cordelia, that art most rich, being poor; Most choice, forsaken; and most lov'd, despis'd! END
BEGIN NOW Thee and thy virtues here I seize upon. END
BEGIN NOW Be it lawful I take up what's cast away. END
BEGIN NOW Gods, gods! END
BEGIN NOW 'tis strange that from their cold'st neglect My love should kindle to inflam'd respect. END
BEGIN NOW Thy dow'rless daughter, King, thrown to my chance, Is queen of us, of ours, and our fair France. END
BEGIN NOW Not all the dukes in wat'rish Burgundy Can buy this unpriz'd precious maid of me. END
BEGIN NOW Bid them farewell, Cordelia, though unkind. END
BEGIN NOW Thou losest here, a better where to find. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Thou hast her, France; let her be thine; for we Have no such daughter, nor shall ever see That face of hers again. END
BEGIN NOW Therefore be gone Without our grace, our love, our benison. END
BEGIN NOW Come, noble Burgundy. END
BEGIN NOW Flourish. END
BEGIN NOW Exeunt Lear, Burgundy, France. END
BEGIN NOW Bid farewell to your sisters. END
BEGIN NOW The jewels of our father, with wash'd eyes Cordelia leaves you. END
BEGIN NOW I know you what you are; And, like a sister, am most loath to call Your faults as they are nam'd. END
BEGIN NOW Use well our father. END
BEGIN NOW To your professed bosoms I commit him; But yet, alas, stood I within his grace, I would prefer him to a better place! END
BEGIN NOW So farewell to you both. END
BEGIN NOW Prescribe not us our duties. END
BEGIN NOW Let your study Be to content your lord, who hath receiv'd you At fortune's alms. END
BEGIN NOW You have obedience scanted, And well are worth the want that you have wanted. END
BEGIN NOW Time shall unfold what plighted cunning hides. END
BEGIN NOW Who cover faults, at last shame them derides. END
BEGIN NOW Well may you prosper! END
BEGIN NOW France. END
BEGIN NOW Come, my fair Cordelia. END
BEGIN NOW Exeunt France and Cordelia. END
BEGIN NOW Sister, it is not little I have to say of what most nearly appertains to us both. END
BEGIN NOW I think our father will hence to-night. END
BEGIN NOW That's most certain, and with you; next month with us. END
BEGIN NOW You see how full of changes his age is. END
BEGIN NOW The observation we have made of it hath not been little. END
BEGIN NOW He always lov'd our sister most, and with what poor judgment he hath now cast her off appears too grossly. END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis the infirmity of his age; yet he hath ever but slenderly known himself. END
BEGIN NOW The best and soundest of his time hath been but rash; then must we look to receive from his age, not alone the imperfections of long-ingraffed condition, but therewithal the unruly waywardness that infirm and choleric years bring with them. END
BEGIN NOW Such unconstant starts are we like to have from him as this of Kent's banishment. END
BEGIN NOW There is further compliment of leave-taking between France and him. END
BEGIN NOW Pray you let's hit together. END
BEGIN NOW If our father carry authority with such dispositions as he bears, this last surrender of his will but offend us. END
BEGIN NOW We shall further think on't. END
BEGIN NOW We must do something, and i' th' heat. END
BEGIN NOW Scene II. END
BEGIN NOW The Earl of Gloucester's Castle. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Thou, Nature, art my goddess; to thy law My services are bound. END
BEGIN NOW Wherefore should I Stand in the plague of custom, and permit The curiosity of nations to deprive me, For that I am some twelve or fourteen moonshines Lag of a brother? END
BEGIN NOW Why bastard? END
BEGIN NOW wherefore base? END
BEGIN NOW When my dimensions are as well compact, My mind as generous, and my shape as true, As honest madam's issue? END
BEGIN NOW Why brand they us With base? END
BEGIN NOW with baseness? END
BEGIN NOW bastardy? END
BEGIN NOW base, base? END
BEGIN NOW Who, in the lusty stealth of nature, take More composition and fierce quality Than doth, within a dull, stale, tired bed, Go to th' creating a whole tribe of fops Got 'tween asleep and wake? END
BEGIN NOW Well then, Legitimate Edgar, I must have your land. END
BEGIN NOW Our father's love is to the bastard Edmund As to th' legitimate. END
BEGIN NOW Fine word- 'legitimate'! END
BEGIN NOW Well, my legitimate, if this letter speed, And my invention thrive, Edmund the base Shall top th' legitimate. END
BEGIN NOW I grow; I prosper. END
BEGIN NOW Now, gods, stand up for bastards! END
BEGIN NOW Enter Gloucester. END
BEGIN NOW Kent banish'd thus? END
BEGIN NOW and France in choler parted? END
BEGIN NOW And the King gone to-night? END
BEGIN NOW subscrib'd his pow'r? END
BEGIN NOW Confin'd to exhibition? END
BEGIN NOW All this done Upon the gad? END
BEGIN NOW Edmund, how now? END
BEGIN NOW What news? END
BEGIN NOW So please your lordship, none. END
BEGIN NOW Why so earnestly seek you to put up that letter? END
BEGIN NOW I know no news, my lord. END
BEGIN NOW What paper were you reading? END
BEGIN NOW Nothing, my lord. END
BEGIN NOW No? END
BEGIN NOW What needed then that terrible dispatch of it into your pocket? END
BEGIN NOW The quality of nothing hath not such need to hide itself. END
BEGIN NOW Let's see. END
BEGIN NOW Come, if it be nothing, I shall not need spectacles. END
BEGIN NOW I beseech you, sir, pardon me. END
BEGIN NOW It is a letter from my brother that I have not all o'er-read; and for so much as I have perus'd, I find it not fit for your o'erlooking. END
BEGIN NOW Give me the letter, sir. END
BEGIN NOW I shall offend, either to detain or give it. END
BEGIN NOW The contents, as in part I understand them, are to blame. END
BEGIN NOW Let's see, let's see! END
BEGIN NOW I hope, for my brother's justification, he wrote this but as an essay or taste of my virtue. END
BEGIN NOW (reads) 'This policy and reverence of age makes the world bitter to the best of our times; keeps our fortunes from us till our oldness cannot relish them. END
BEGIN NOW I begin to find an idle and fond bondage in the oppression of aged tyranny, who sways, not as it hath power, but as it is suffer'd. END
BEGIN NOW Come to me, that of this I may speak more. END
BEGIN NOW If our father would sleep till I wak'd him, you should enjoy half his revenue for ever, and live the beloved of your brother, 'EDGAR.' END
BEGIN NOW Hum! END
BEGIN NOW Conspiracy? END
BEGIN NOW 'Sleep till I wak'd him, you should enjoy half his revenue.' END
BEGIN NOW My son Edgar! END
BEGIN NOW Had he a hand to write this? END
BEGIN NOW a heart and brain to breed it in? END
BEGIN NOW When came this to you? END
BEGIN NOW Who brought it? END
BEGIN NOW It was not brought me, my lord: there's the cunning of it. END
BEGIN NOW I found it thrown in at the casement of my closet. END
BEGIN NOW You know the character to be your brother's? END
BEGIN NOW If the matter were good, my lord, I durst swear it were his; but in respect of that, I would fain think it were not. END
BEGIN NOW It is his. END
BEGIN NOW It is his hand, my lord; but I hope his heart is not in the contents. END
BEGIN NOW Hath he never before sounded you in this business? END
BEGIN NOW Never, my lord. END
BEGIN NOW But I have heard him oft maintain it to be fit that, sons at perfect age, and fathers declining, the father should be as ward to the son, and the son manage his revenue. END
BEGIN NOW O villain, villain! END
BEGIN NOW His very opinion in the letter! END
BEGIN NOW Abhorred villain! END
BEGIN NOW Unnatural, detested, brutish villain! END
BEGIN NOW worse than brutish! END
BEGIN NOW Go, sirrah, seek him. END
BEGIN NOW I'll apprehend him. END
BEGIN NOW Abominable villain! END
BEGIN NOW Where is he? END
BEGIN NOW I do not well know, my lord. END
BEGIN NOW If it shall please you to suspend your indignation against my brother till you can derive from him better testimony of his intent, you should run a certain course; where, if you violently proceed against him, mistaking his purpose, it would make a great gap in your own honour and shake in pieces the heart of his obedience. END
BEGIN NOW I dare pawn down my life for him that he hath writ this to feel my affection to your honour, and to no other pretence of danger. END
BEGIN NOW Think you so? END
BEGIN NOW If your honour judge it meet, I will place you where you shall hear us confer of this and by an auricular assurance have your satisfaction, and that without any further delay than this very evening. END
BEGIN NOW He cannot be such a monster. END
BEGIN NOW Nor is not, sure. END
BEGIN NOW To his father, that so tenderly and entirely loves him. END
BEGIN NOW Heaven and earth! END
BEGIN NOW Edmund, seek him out; wind me into him, I pray you; frame the business after your own wisdom. END
BEGIN NOW I would unstate myself to be in a due resolution. END
BEGIN NOW I will seek him, sir, presently; convey the business as I shall find means, and acquaint you withal. END
BEGIN NOW These late eclipses in the sun and moon portend no good to us. END
BEGIN NOW Though the wisdom of nature can reason it thus and thus, yet nature finds itself scourg'd by the sequent effects. END
BEGIN NOW Love cools, friendship falls off, brothers divide. END
BEGIN NOW In cities, mutinies; in countries, discord; in palaces, treason; and the bond crack'd 'twixt son and father. END
BEGIN NOW This villain of mine comes under the prediction; there's son against father: the King falls from bias of nature; there's father against child. END
BEGIN NOW We have seen the best of our time. END
BEGIN NOW Machinations, hollowness, treachery, and all ruinous disorders follow us disquietly to our graves. END
BEGIN NOW Find out this villain, Edmund; it shall lose thee nothing; do it carefully. END
BEGIN NOW And the noble and true-hearted Kent banish'd! END
BEGIN NOW his offence, honesty! END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis strange. END
BEGIN NOW Exit. END
BEGIN NOW This is the excellent foppery of the world, that, when we are sick in fortune, often the surfeit of our own behaviour, we make guilty of our disasters the sun, the moon, and the stars; as if we were villains on necessity; fools by heavenly compulsion; knaves, thieves, and treachers by spherical pre-dominance; drunkards, liars, and adulterers by an enforc'd obedience of planetary influence; and all that we are evil in, by a divine thrusting on. END
BEGIN NOW An admirable evasion of whore-master man, to lay his goatish disposition to the charge of a star! END
BEGIN NOW My father compounded with my mother under the Dragon's Tail, and my nativity was under Ursa Major, so that it follows I am rough and lecherous. END
BEGIN NOW Fut! END
BEGIN NOW I should have been that I am, had the maidenliest star in the firmament twinkled on my bastardizing. END
BEGIN NOW Edgar- Enter Edgar. END
BEGIN NOW and pat! END
BEGIN NOW he comes, like the catastrophe of the old comedy. END
BEGIN NOW My cue is villainous melancholy, with a sigh like Tom o' Bedlam. END
BEGIN NOW O, these eclipses do portend these divisions! END
BEGIN NOW Fa, sol, la, mi. END
BEGIN NOW How now, brother Edmund? END
BEGIN NOW What serious contemplation are you in? END
BEGIN NOW I am thinking, brother, of a prediction I read this other day, what should follow these eclipses. END
BEGIN NOW Do you busy yourself with that? END
BEGIN NOW I promise you, the effects he writes of succeed unhappily: as of unnaturalness between the child and the parent; death, dearth, dissolutions of ancient amities; divisions in state, menaces and maledictions against king and nobles; needless diffidences, banishment of friends, dissipation of cohorts, nuptial breaches, and I know not what. END
BEGIN NOW How long have you been a sectary astronomical? END
BEGIN NOW Come, come! END
BEGIN NOW When saw you my father last? END
BEGIN NOW The night gone by. END
BEGIN NOW Spake you with him? END
BEGIN NOW Ay, two hours together. END
BEGIN NOW Parted you in good terms? END
BEGIN NOW Found you no displeasure in him by word or countenance None at all. END
BEGIN NOW Bethink yourself wherein you may have offended him; and at my entreaty forbear his presence until some little time hath qualified the heat of his displeasure, which at this instant so rageth in him that with the mischief of your person it would scarcely allay. END
BEGIN NOW Some villain hath done me wrong. END
BEGIN NOW That's my fear. END
BEGIN NOW I pray you have a continent forbearance till the speed of his rage goes slower; and, as I say, retire with me to my lodging, from whence I will fitly bring you to hear my lord speak. END
BEGIN NOW Pray ye, go! END
BEGIN NOW There's my key. END
BEGIN NOW If you do stir abroad, go arm'd. END
BEGIN NOW Arm'd, brother? END
BEGIN NOW Brother, I advise you to the best. END
BEGIN NOW Go arm'd. END
BEGIN NOW I am no honest man if there be any good meaning toward you. END
BEGIN NOW I have told you what I have seen and heard; but faintly, nothing like the image and horror of it. END
BEGIN NOW Pray you, away! END
BEGIN NOW Shall I hear from you anon? END
BEGIN NOW I do serve you in this business. END
BEGIN NOW Exit Edgar. END
BEGIN NOW A credulous father! END
BEGIN NOW and a brother noble, Whose nature is so far from doing harms That he suspects none; on whose foolish honesty My practices ride easy! END
BEGIN NOW I see the business. END
BEGIN NOW Let me, if not by birth, have lands by wit; All with me's meet that I can fashion fit. END
BEGIN NOW Exit. END
BEGIN NOW Scene III. END
BEGIN NOW The Duke of Albany's Palace. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Did my father strike my gentleman for chiding of his fool? END
BEGIN NOW Ay, madam. END
BEGIN NOW By day and night, he wrongs me! END
BEGIN NOW Every hour He flashes into one gross crime or other That sets us all at odds. END
BEGIN NOW I'll not endure it. END
BEGIN NOW His knights grow riotous, and himself upbraids us On every trifle. END
BEGIN NOW When he returns from hunting, I will not speak with him. END
BEGIN NOW Say I am sick. END
BEGIN NOW If you come slack of former services, You shall do well; the fault of it I'll answer. END
BEGIN NOW He's coming, madam; I hear him. END
BEGIN NOW Put on what weary negligence you please, You and your fellows. END
BEGIN NOW I'd have it come to question. END
BEGIN NOW If he distaste it, let him to our sister, Whose mind and mine I know in that are one, Not to be overrul'd. END
BEGIN NOW Idle old man, That still would manage those authorities That he hath given away! END
BEGIN NOW Now, by my life, Old fools are babes again, and must be us'd With checks as flatteries, when they are seen abus'd. END
BEGIN NOW Remember what I have said. END
BEGIN NOW Very well, madam. END
BEGIN NOW And let his knights have colder looks among you. END
BEGIN NOW What grows of it, no matter. END
BEGIN NOW Advise your fellows so. END
BEGIN NOW I would breed from hence occasions, and I shall, That I may speak. END
BEGIN NOW I'll write straight to my sister To hold my very course. END
BEGIN NOW Prepare for dinner. END
BEGIN NOW Scene IV. END
BEGIN NOW The Duke of Albany's Palace. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Kent, Kent. END
BEGIN NOW If but as well I other accents borrow, That can my speech defuse, my good intent May carry through itself to that full issue For which I raz'd my likeness. END
BEGIN NOW Now, banish'd Kent, If thou canst serve where thou dost stand condemn'd, So may it come, thy master, whom thou lov'st, Shall find thee full of labours. END
BEGIN NOW Horns within. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Lear, and Attendants. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Let me not stay a jot for dinner; go get it ready. END
BEGIN NOW How now? END
BEGIN NOW What art thou? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW A man, sir. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW What dost thou profess? END
BEGIN NOW What wouldst thou with us? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW I do profess to be no less than I seem, to serve him truly that will put me in trust, to love him that is honest, to converse with him that is wise and says little, to fear judgment, to fight when I cannot choose, and to eat no fish. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW What art thou? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW A very honest-hearted fellow, and as poor as the King. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW If thou be'st as poor for a subject as he's for a king, thou art poor enough. END
BEGIN NOW What wouldst thou? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Service. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Who wouldst thou serve? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW You. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Dost thou know me, fellow? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW No, sir; but you have that in your countenance which I would fain call master. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW What's that? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Authority. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW What services canst thou do? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW I can keep honest counsel, ride, run, mar a curious tale in telling it and deliver a plain message bluntly. END
BEGIN NOW That which ordinary men are fit for, I am qualified in, and the best of me is diligence. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW How old art thou? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Not so young, sir, to love a woman for singing, nor so old to dote on her for anything. END
BEGIN NOW I have years on my back forty-eight. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Follow me; thou shalt serve me. END
BEGIN NOW If I like thee no worse after dinner, I will not part from thee yet. END
BEGIN NOW Dinner, ho, dinner! END
BEGIN NOW Where's my knave? END
BEGIN NOW my fool? END
BEGIN NOW Go you and call my fool hither. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Steward. END
BEGIN NOW You, you, sirrah, where's my daughter? END
BEGIN NOW So please you- Exit. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW What says the fellow there? END
BEGIN NOW Call the clotpoll back. END
BEGIN NOW Where's my fool, ho? END
BEGIN NOW I think the world's asleep. END
BEGIN NOW How now? END
BEGIN NOW Where's that mongrel? END
BEGIN NOW He says, my lord, your daughter is not well. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Why came not the slave back to me when I call'd him? END
BEGIN NOW Sir, he answered me in the roundest manner, he would not. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW He would not? END
BEGIN NOW My lord, I know not what the matter is; but to my judgment your Highness is not entertain'd with that ceremonious affection as you were wont. END
BEGIN NOW There's a great abatement of kindness appears as well in the general dependants as in the Duke himself also and your daughter. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Ha! END
BEGIN NOW say'st thou so? END
BEGIN NOW I beseech you pardon me, my lord, if I be mistaken; for my duty cannot be silent when I think your Highness wrong'd. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Thou but rememb'rest me of mine own conception. END
BEGIN NOW I have perceived a most faint neglect of late, which I have rather blamed as mine own jealous curiosity than as a very pretence and purpose of unkindness. END
BEGIN NOW I will look further into't. END
BEGIN NOW But where's my fool? END
BEGIN NOW I have not seen him this two days. END
BEGIN NOW Since my young lady's going into France, sir, the fool hath much pined away. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW No more of that; I have noted it well. END
BEGIN NOW Go you and tell my daughter I would speak with her. END
BEGIN NOW Go you, call hither my fool. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Steward. END
BEGIN NOW O, you, sir, you! END
BEGIN NOW Come you hither, sir. END
BEGIN NOW Who am I, sir? END
BEGIN NOW My lady's father. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW 'My lady's father'? END
BEGIN NOW My lord's knave! END
BEGIN NOW You whoreson dog! END
BEGIN NOW you slave! END
BEGIN NOW you cur! END
BEGIN NOW I am none of these, my lord; I beseech your pardon. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Do you bandy looks with me, you rascal? END
BEGIN NOW I'll not be strucken, my lord. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Nor tripp'd neither, you base football player? END
BEGIN NOW [Trips up his heels. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW I thank thee, fellow. END
BEGIN NOW Thou serv'st me, and I'll love thee. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Come, sir, arise, away! END
BEGIN NOW I'll teach you differences. END
BEGIN NOW Away, away! END
BEGIN NOW If you will measure your lubber's length again, tarry; but away! END
BEGIN NOW Go to! END
BEGIN NOW Have you wisdom? END
BEGIN NOW So. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Now, my friendly knave, I thank thee. END
BEGIN NOW There's earnest of thy service. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Let me hire him too. END
BEGIN NOW Here's my coxcomb. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW How now, my pretty knave? END
BEGIN NOW How dost thou? END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Sirrah, you were best take my coxcomb. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Why, fool? END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Why? END
BEGIN NOW For taking one's part that's out of favour. END
BEGIN NOW Nay, an thou canst not smile as the wind sits, thou'lt catch cold shortly. END
BEGIN NOW There, take my coxcomb! END
BEGIN NOW Why, this fellow hath banish'd two on's daughters, and did the third a blessing against his will. END
BEGIN NOW If thou follow him, thou must needs wear my coxcomb.- How now, nuncle? END
BEGIN NOW Would I had two coxcombs and two daughters! END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Why, my boy? END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW If I gave them all my living, I'ld keep my coxcombs myself. END
BEGIN NOW There's mine! END
BEGIN NOW beg another of thy daughters. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Take heed, sirrah- the whip. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Truth's a dog must to kennel; he must be whipp'd out, when Lady the brach may stand by th' fire and stink. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW A pestilent gall to me! END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Sirrah, I'll teach thee a speech. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Do. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Mark it, nuncle. END
BEGIN NOW Have more than thou showest, Speak less than thou knowest, Lend less than thou owest, Ride more than thou goest, Learn more than thou trowest, Set less than thou throwest; Leave thy drink and thy whore, And keep in-a-door, And thou shalt have more Than two tens to a score. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW This is nothing, fool. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Then 'tis like the breath of an unfeed lawyer- you gave me nothing for't. END
BEGIN NOW Can you make no use of nothing, nuncle? END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Why, no, boy. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing can be made out of nothing. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Prithee tell him, so much the rent of his land comes to. END
BEGIN NOW He will not believe a fool. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW A bitter fool! END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Dost thou know the difference, my boy, between a bitter fool and a sweet fool? END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW No, lad; teach me. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW That lord that counsell'd thee To give away thy land, Come place him here by me- Do thou for him stand. END
BEGIN NOW The sweet and bitter fool Will presently appear; The one in motley here, The other found out there. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Dost thou call me fool, boy? END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW All thy other titles thou hast given away; that thou wast born with. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW This is not altogether fool, my lord. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW No, faith; lords and great men will not let me. END
BEGIN NOW If I had a monopoly out, they would have part on't. END
BEGIN NOW And ladies too, they will not let me have all the fool to myself; they'll be snatching. END
BEGIN NOW Give me an egg, nuncle, and I'll give thee two crowns. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW What two crowns shall they be? END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Why, after I have cut the egg i' th' middle and eat up the meat, the two crowns of the egg. END
BEGIN NOW When thou clovest thy crown i' th' middle and gav'st away both parts, thou bor'st thine ass on thy back o'er the dirt. END
BEGIN NOW Thou hadst little wit in thy bald crown when thou gav'st thy golden one away. END
BEGIN NOW If I speak like myself in this, let him be whipp'd that first finds it so. END
BEGIN NOW Fools had ne'er less grace in a year, For wise men are grown foppish; They know not how their wits to wear, Their manners are so apish. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW When were you wont to be so full of songs, sirrah? END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW I have us'd it, nuncle, ever since thou mad'st thy daughters thy mother; for when thou gav'st them the rod, and put'st down thine own breeches, Then they for sudden joy did weep, And I for sorrow sung, That such a king should play bo-peep And go the fools among. END
BEGIN NOW Prithee, nuncle, keep a schoolmaster that can teach thy fool to lie. END
BEGIN NOW I would fain learn to lie. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW An you lie, sirrah, we'll have you whipp'd. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW I marvel what kin thou and thy daughters are. END
BEGIN NOW They'll have me whipp'd for speaking true; thou'lt have me whipp'd for lying; and sometimes I am whipp'd for holding my peace. END
BEGIN NOW I had rather be any kind o' thing than a fool! END
BEGIN NOW And yet I would not be thee, nuncle. END
BEGIN NOW Thou hast pared thy wit o' both sides and left nothing i' th' middle. END
BEGIN NOW Here comes one o' the parings. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Lear. END
BEGIN NOW How now, daughter? END
BEGIN NOW What makes that frontlet on? END
BEGIN NOW Methinks you are too much o' late i' th' frown. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Thou wast a pretty fellow when thou hadst no need to care for her frowning. END
BEGIN NOW Now thou art an O without a figure. END
BEGIN NOW I am better than thou art now: I am a fool, thou art nothing. END
BEGIN NOW [To So your face bids me, though you say nothing. END
BEGIN NOW Mum, mum! END
BEGIN NOW He that keeps nor crust nor crum, Weary of all, shall want some.- That's a sheal'd peascod. END
BEGIN NOW Not only, sir, this your all-licens'd fool, But other of your insolent retinue Do hourly carp and quarrel, breaking forth In rank and not-to-be-endured riots. END
BEGIN NOW Sir, I had thought, by making this well known unto you, To have found a safe redress, but now grow fearful, By what yourself, too, late have spoke and done, That you protect this course, and put it on By your allowance; which if you should, the fault Would not scape censure, nor the redresses sleep, Which, in the tender of a wholesome weal, Might in their working do you that offence Which else were shame, that then necessity Must call discreet proceeding. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW For you know, nuncle, The hedge-sparrow fed the cuckoo so long That it had it head bit off by it young. END
BEGIN NOW So out went the candle, and we were left darkling. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Are you our daughter? END
BEGIN NOW Come, sir, I would you would make use of that good wisdom Whereof I know you are fraught, and put away These dispositions that of late transform you From what you rightly are. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW May not an ass know when the cart draws the horse? END
BEGIN NOW Whoop, Jug, I love thee! END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Doth any here know me? END
BEGIN NOW This is not Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Doth Lear walk thus? END
BEGIN NOW speak thus? END
BEGIN NOW Where are his eyes? END
BEGIN NOW Either his notion weakens, his discernings Are lethargied- Ha! END
BEGIN NOW waking? END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis not so! END
BEGIN NOW Who is it that can tell me who I am? END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Lear's shadow. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW I would learn that; for, by the marks of sovereignty, Knowledge, and reason, I should be false persuaded I had daughters. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Which they will make an obedient father. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Your name, fair gentlewoman? END
BEGIN NOW This admiration, sir, is much o' th' savour Of other your new pranks. END
BEGIN NOW I do beseech you To understand my purposes aright. END
BEGIN NOW As you are old and reverend, you should be wise. END
BEGIN NOW Here do you keep a hundred knights and squires; Men so disorder'd, so debosh'd, and bold That this our court, infected with their manners, Shows like a riotous inn. END
BEGIN NOW Epicurism and lust Make it more like a tavern or a brothel Than a grac'd palace. END
BEGIN NOW The shame itself doth speak For instant remedy. END
BEGIN NOW Be then desir'd By her that else will take the thing she begs A little to disquantity your train, And the remainder that shall still depend To be such men as may besort your age, Which know themselves, and you. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Darkness and devils! END
BEGIN NOW Saddle my horses! END
BEGIN NOW Call my train together! END
BEGIN NOW Degenerate bastard, I'll not trouble thee; Yet have I left a daughter. END
BEGIN NOW You strike my people, and your disorder'd rabble Make servants of their betters. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Albany. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Woe that too late repents!- O, sir, are you come? END
BEGIN NOW Is it your will? END
BEGIN NOW Speak, sir!- Prepare my horses. END
BEGIN NOW Ingratitude, thou marble-hearted fiend, More hideous when thou show'st thee in a child Than the sea-monster! END
BEGIN NOW Pray, sir, be patient. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Detested kite, thou liest! END
BEGIN NOW My train are men of choice and rarest parts, That all particulars of duty know And in the most exact regard support The worships of their name.- O most small fault, How ugly didst thou in Cordelia show! END
BEGIN NOW Which, like an engine, wrench'd my frame of nature From the fix'd place; drew from my heart all love And added to the gall. END
BEGIN NOW O Lear, Lear, Lear! END
BEGIN NOW Beat at this gate that let thy folly in And thy dear judgment out! END
BEGIN NOW Go, go, my people. END
BEGIN NOW My lord, I am guiltless, as I am ignorant Of what hath mov'd you. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW It may be so, my lord. END
BEGIN NOW Hear, Nature, hear! END
BEGIN NOW dear goddess, hear! END
BEGIN NOW Suspend thy purpose, if thou didst intend To make this creature fruitful. END
BEGIN NOW Into her womb convey sterility; Dry up in her the organs of increase; And from her derogate body never spring A babe to honour her! END
BEGIN NOW If she must teem, Create her child of spleen, that it may live And be a thwart disnatur'd torment to her. END
BEGIN NOW Let it stamp wrinkles in her brow of youth, With cadent tears fret channels in her cheeks, Turn all her mother's pains and benefits To laughter and contempt, that she may feel How sharper than a serpent's tooth it is To have a thankless child! END
BEGIN NOW Away, away! END
BEGIN NOW Exit. END
BEGIN NOW Now, gods that we adore, whereof comes this? END
BEGIN NOW Never afflict yourself to know the cause; But let his disposition have that scope That dotage gives it. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW What, fifty of my followers at a clap? END
BEGIN NOW Within a fortnight? END
BEGIN NOW What's the matter, sir? END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW I'll tell thee. END
BEGIN NOW Life and death! END
BEGIN NOW I am asham'd That thou hast power to shake my manhood thus; That these hot tears, which break from me perforce, Should make thee worth them. END
BEGIN NOW Blasts and fogs upon thee! END
BEGIN NOW Th' untented woundings of a father's curse Pierce every sense about thee!- Old fond eyes, Beweep this cause again, I'll pluck ye out, And cast you, with the waters that you lose, To temper clay. END
BEGIN NOW Yea, is it come to this? END
BEGIN NOW Let it be so. END
BEGIN NOW Yet have I left a daughter, Who I am sure is kind and comfortable. END
BEGIN NOW When she shall hear this of thee, with her nails She'll flay thy wolvish visage. END
BEGIN NOW Thou shalt find That I'll resume the shape which thou dost think I have cast off for ever; thou shalt, I warrant thee. END
BEGIN NOW Exeunt Do you mark that, my lord? END
BEGIN NOW I cannot be so partial, Goneril, To the great love I bear you - Pray you, content.- What, Oswald, ho! END
BEGIN NOW You, sir, more knave than fool, after your master! END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Nuncle Lear, nuncle Lear, tarry! END
BEGIN NOW Take the fool with thee. END
BEGIN NOW A fox when one has caught her, And such a daughter, Should sure to the slaughter, If my cap would buy a halter. END
BEGIN NOW So the fool follows after. END
BEGIN NOW Exit. END
BEGIN NOW This man hath had good counsel! END
BEGIN NOW A hundred knights? END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis politic and safe to let him keep At point a hundred knights; yes, that on every dream, Each buzz, each fancy, each complaint, dislike, He may enguard his dotage with their pow'rs And hold our lives in mercy.- Oswald, I say! END
BEGIN NOW Well, you may fear too far. END
BEGIN NOW Safer than trust too far. END
BEGIN NOW Let me still take away the harms I fear, Not fear still to be taken. END
BEGIN NOW I know his heart. END
BEGIN NOW What he hath utter'd I have writ my sister. END
BEGIN NOW If she sustain him and his hundred knights, When I have show'd th' unfitness- Enter Steward. END
BEGIN NOW How now, Oswald? END
BEGIN NOW What, have you writ that letter to my sister? END
BEGIN NOW Yes, madam. END
BEGIN NOW Take you some company, and away to horse! END
BEGIN NOW Inform her full of my particular fear, And thereto add such reasons of your own As may compact it more. END
BEGIN NOW Get you gone, And hasten your return. END
BEGIN NOW No, no, my lord! END
BEGIN NOW This milky gentleness and course of yours, Though I condemn it not, yet, under pardon, You are much more at task for want of wisdom Than prais'd for harmful mildness. END
BEGIN NOW How far your eyes may pierce I cannot tell. END
BEGIN NOW Striving to better, oft we mar what's well. END
BEGIN NOW Nay then- Well, well; th' event. END
BEGIN NOW Scene V. Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Lear, Kent, and Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Go you before to Gloucester with these letters. END
BEGIN NOW Acquaint my daughter no further with anything you know than comes from her demand out of the letter. END
BEGIN NOW If your diligence be not speedy, I shall be there afore you. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW I will not sleep, my lord, till I have delivered your letter. END
BEGIN NOW Exit. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW If a man's brains were in's heels, were't not in danger of kibes? END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Ay, boy. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Then I prithee be merry. END
BEGIN NOW Thy wit shall ne'er go slip-shod. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Ha, ha, ha! END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Shalt see thy other daughter will use thee kindly; for though she's as like this as a crab's like an apple, yet I can tell what I can tell. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW What canst tell, boy? END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW She'll taste as like this as a crab does to a crab. END
BEGIN NOW Thou canst tell why one's nose stands i' th' middle on's face? END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW No. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Why, to keep one's eyes of either side's nose, that what a man cannot smell out, 'a may spy into. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW I did her wrong. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Canst tell how an oyster makes his shell? END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW No. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Nor I neither; but I can tell why a snail has a house. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Why? END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Why, to put's head in; not to give it away to his daughters, and leave his horns without a case. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW I will forget my nature. END
BEGIN NOW So kind a father!- Be my horses ready? END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Thy asses are gone about 'em. END
BEGIN NOW The reason why the seven stars are no moe than seven is a pretty reason. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Because they are not eight? END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Yes indeed. END
BEGIN NOW Thou wouldst make a good fool. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW To tak't again perforce! END
BEGIN NOW Monster ingratitude! END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW If thou wert my fool, nuncle, I'ld have thee beaten for being old before thy time. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW How's that? END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Thou shouldst not have been old till thou hadst been wise. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW O, let me not be mad, not mad, sweet heaven! END
BEGIN NOW Keep me in temper; I would not be mad! END
BEGIN NOW How now? END
BEGIN NOW Are the horses ready? END
BEGIN NOW Ready, my lord. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Come, boy. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW She that's a maid now, and laughs at my departure, Shall not be a maid long, unless things be cut shorter ACT II. END
BEGIN NOW Scene I. END
BEGIN NOW A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Bastard and Curan, meeting. END
BEGIN NOW Save thee, Curan. END
BEGIN NOW And you, sir. END
BEGIN NOW I have been with your father, and given him notice that the Duke of Cornwall and Regan his Duchess will be here with him this night. END
BEGIN NOW How comes that? END
BEGIN NOW Nay, I know not. END
BEGIN NOW You have heard of the news abroad- I mean the whisper'd ones, for they are yet but ear-kissing arguments? END
BEGIN NOW Not I. Pray you, what are they? END
BEGIN NOW Have you heard of no likely wars toward 'twixt the two Dukes of Cornwall and Albany? END
BEGIN NOW Not a word. END
BEGIN NOW You may do, then, in time. END
BEGIN NOW Fare you well, sir. END
BEGIN NOW Exit. END
BEGIN NOW The Duke be here to-night? END
BEGIN NOW The better! END
BEGIN NOW best! END
BEGIN NOW This weaves itself perforce into my business. END
BEGIN NOW My father hath set guard to take my brother; And I have one thing, of a queasy question, Which I must act. END
BEGIN NOW Briefness and fortune, work! END
BEGIN NOW Brother, a word! END
BEGIN NOW Descend! END
BEGIN NOW Brother, I say! END
BEGIN NOW Enter Edgar. END
BEGIN NOW My father watches. END
BEGIN NOW O sir, fly this place! END
BEGIN NOW Intelligence is given where you are hid. END
BEGIN NOW You have now the good advantage of the night. END
BEGIN NOW Have you not spoken 'gainst the Duke of Cornwall? END
BEGIN NOW He's coming hither; now, i' th' night, i' th' haste, And Regan with him. END
BEGIN NOW Have you nothing said Upon his party 'gainst the Duke of Albany? END
BEGIN NOW Advise yourself. END
BEGIN NOW I am sure on't, not a word. END
BEGIN NOW I hear my father coming. END
BEGIN NOW Pardon me! END
BEGIN NOW In cunning I must draw my sword upon you. END
BEGIN NOW Draw, seem to defend yourself; now quit you well.- Yield! END
BEGIN NOW Come before my father. END
BEGIN NOW Light, ho, here! END
BEGIN NOW Fly, brother.- Torches, torches!- So farewell. END
BEGIN NOW Exit Edgar. END
BEGIN NOW Some blood drawn on me would beget opinion Of my more fierce endeavour. END
BEGIN NOW I have seen drunkards Do more than this in sport.- Father, father!- Stop, stop! END
BEGIN NOW No help? END
BEGIN NOW Enter Gloucester, and Servants with torches. END
BEGIN NOW Now, Edmund, where's the villain? END
BEGIN NOW Here stood he in the dark, his sharp sword out, Mumbling of wicked charms, conjuring the moon To stand 's auspicious mistress. END
BEGIN NOW But where is he? END
BEGIN NOW Look, sir, I bleed. END
BEGIN NOW Where is the villain, Edmund? END
BEGIN NOW Fled this way, sir. END
BEGIN NOW When by no means he could- Pursue him, ho! END
BEGIN NOW Go after. END
BEGIN NOW By no means what? END
BEGIN NOW Persuade me to the murther of your lordship; But that I told him the revenging gods 'Gainst parricides did all their thunders bend; Spoke with how manifold and strong a bond The child was bound to th' father- sir, in fine, Seeing how loathly opposite I stood To his unnatural purpose, in fell motion With his prepared sword he charges home My unprovided body, lanch'd mine arm; But when he saw my best alarum'd spirits, Bold in the quarrel's right, rous'd to th' encounter, Or whether gasted by the noise I made, Full suddenly he fled. END
BEGIN NOW Let him fly far. END
BEGIN NOW Not in this land shall he remain uncaught; And found- dispatch. END
BEGIN NOW The noble Duke my master, My worthy arch and patron, comes to-night. END
BEGIN NOW By his authority I will proclaim it That he which find, him shall deserve our thanks, Bringing the murderous caitiff to the stake; He that conceals him, death. END
BEGIN NOW When I dissuaded him from his intent And found him pight to do it, with curst speech I threaten'd to discover him. END
BEGIN NOW He replied, 'Thou unpossessing bastard, dost thou think, If I would stand against thee, would the reposal Of any trust, virtue, or worth in thee Make thy words faith'd? END
BEGIN NOW No. END
BEGIN NOW What I should deny (As this I would; ay, though thou didst produce My very character), I'ld turn it all To thy suggestion, plot, and damned practice; And thou must make a dullard of the world, If they not thought the profits of my death Were very pregnant and potential spurs To make thee seek it.' END
BEGIN NOW Strong and fast'ned villain! END
BEGIN NOW Would he deny his letter? END
BEGIN NOW I never got him. END
BEGIN NOW Tucket within. END
BEGIN NOW Hark, the Duke's trumpets! END
BEGIN NOW I know not why he comes. END
BEGIN NOW All ports I'll bar; the villain shall not scape; The Duke must grant me that. END
BEGIN NOW Besides, his picture I will send far and near, that all the kingdom May have due note of him, and of my land, Loyal and natural boy, I'll work the means To make thee capable. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Cornwall, Regan, and Attendants. END
BEGIN NOW How now, my noble friend? END
BEGIN NOW Since I came hither (Which I can call but now) I have heard strange news. END
BEGIN NOW If it be true, all vengeance comes too short Which can pursue th' offender. END
BEGIN NOW How dost, my lord? END
BEGIN NOW O madam, my old heart is crack'd, it's crack'd! END
BEGIN NOW What, did my father's godson seek your life? END
BEGIN NOW He whom my father nam'd? END
BEGIN NOW Your Edgar? END
BEGIN NOW O lady, lady, shame would have it hid! END
BEGIN NOW Was he not companion with the riotous knights That tend upon my father? END
BEGIN NOW I know not, madam. END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis too bad, too bad! END
BEGIN NOW Yes, madam, he was of that consort. END
BEGIN NOW No marvel then though he were ill affected. END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis they have put him on the old man's death, To have th' expense and waste of his revenues. END
BEGIN NOW I have this present evening from my sister Been well inform'd of them, and with such cautions That, if they come to sojourn at my house, I'll not be there. END
BEGIN NOW Nor I, assure thee, Regan. END
BEGIN NOW Edmund, I hear that you have shown your father A childlike office. END
BEGIN NOW 'Twas my duty, sir. END
BEGIN NOW He did bewray his practice, and receiv'd This hurt you see, striving to apprehend him. END
BEGIN NOW Is he pursued? END
BEGIN NOW Ay, my good lord. END
BEGIN NOW If he be taken, he shall never more Be fear'd of doing harm. END
BEGIN NOW Make your own purpose, How in my strength you please. END
BEGIN NOW For you, Edmund, Whose virtue and obedience doth this instant So much commend itself, you shall be ours. END
BEGIN NOW Natures of such deep trust we shall much need; You we first seize on. END
BEGIN NOW I shall serve you, sir, Truly, however else. END
BEGIN NOW For him I thank your Grace. END
BEGIN NOW You know not why we came to visit you- Thus out of season, threading dark-ey'd night. END
BEGIN NOW Occasions, noble Gloucester, of some poise, Wherein we must have use of your advice. END
BEGIN NOW Our father he hath writ, so hath our sister, Of differences, which I best thought it fit To answer from our home. END
BEGIN NOW The several messengers From hence attend dispatch. END
BEGIN NOW Our good old friend, Lay comforts to your bosom, and bestow Your needful counsel to our business, Which craves the instant use. END
BEGIN NOW I serve you, madam. END
BEGIN NOW Your Graces are right welcome. END
BEGIN NOW Flourish. END
BEGIN NOW Scene II. END
BEGIN NOW Before Gloucester's Castle. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Kent and Steward, severally. END
BEGIN NOW Good dawning to thee, friend. END
BEGIN NOW Art of this house? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Ay. END
BEGIN NOW Where may we set our horses? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW I' th' mire. END
BEGIN NOW Prithee, if thou lov'st me, tell me. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW I love thee not. END
BEGIN NOW Why then, I care not for thee. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW If I had thee in Lipsbury Pinfold, I would make thee care for me. END
BEGIN NOW Why dost thou use me thus? END
BEGIN NOW I know thee not. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Fellow, I know thee. END
BEGIN NOW What dost thou know me for? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW A knave; a rascal; an eater of broken meats; a base, proud, shallow, beggarly, three-suited, hundred-pound, filthy, worsted-stocking knave; a lily-liver'd, action-taking, whoreson, glass-gazing, superserviceable, finical rogue; one-trunk-inheriting slave; one that wouldst be a bawd in way of good service, and art nothing but the composition of a knave, beggar, coward, pander, and the son and heir of a mongrel bitch; one whom I will beat into clamorous whining, if thou deny the least syllable of thy addition. END
BEGIN NOW Why, what a monstrous fellow art thou, thus to rail on one that's neither known of thee nor knows thee! END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW What a brazen-fac'd varlet art thou, to deny thou knowest me! END
BEGIN NOW Is it two days ago since I beat thee and tripp'd up thy heels before the King? END
BEGIN NOW Draw, you rogue! END
BEGIN NOW for, though it be night, yet the moon shines. END
BEGIN NOW I'll make a sop o' th' moonshine o' you. END
BEGIN NOW Draw, you whoreson cullionly barbermonger! END
BEGIN NOW draw! END
BEGIN NOW Away! END
BEGIN NOW I have nothing to do with thee. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Draw, you rascal! END
BEGIN NOW You come with letters against the King, and take Vanity the puppet's part against the royalty of her father. END
BEGIN NOW Draw, you rogue, or I'll so carbonado your shanks! END
BEGIN NOW Draw, you rascal! END
BEGIN NOW Come your ways! END
BEGIN NOW Help, ho! END
BEGIN NOW murther! END
BEGIN NOW help! END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Strike, you slave! END
BEGIN NOW Stand, rogue! END
BEGIN NOW Stand, you neat slave! END
BEGIN NOW Strike! END
BEGIN NOW Help, ho! END
BEGIN NOW murther! END
BEGIN NOW murther! END
BEGIN NOW Enter Edmund, with his rapier drawn, Gloucester, Cornwall, Regan, Servants. END
BEGIN NOW How now? END
BEGIN NOW What's the matter? END
BEGIN NOW Parts Kent. END
BEGIN NOW With you, goodman boy, an you please! END
BEGIN NOW Come, I'll flesh ye! END
BEGIN NOW Come on, young master! END
BEGIN NOW Weapons? END
BEGIN NOW arms? END
BEGIN NOW What's the matter here? END
BEGIN NOW Keep peace, upon your lives! END
BEGIN NOW He dies that strikes again. END
BEGIN NOW What is the matter? END
BEGIN NOW The messengers from our sister and the King What is your difference? END
BEGIN NOW Speak. END
BEGIN NOW I am scarce in breath, my lord. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW No marvel, you have so bestirr'd your valour. END
BEGIN NOW You cowardly rascal, nature disclaims in thee; a tailor made thee. END
BEGIN NOW Thou art a strange fellow. END
BEGIN NOW A tailor make a man? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Ay, a tailor, sir. END
BEGIN NOW A stonecutter or a painter could not have made him so ill, though he had been but two hours at the trade. END
BEGIN NOW Speak yet, how grew your quarrel? END
BEGIN NOW This ancient ruffian, sir, whose life I have spar'd At suit of his grey beard- Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Thou whoreson zed! END
BEGIN NOW thou unnecessary letter! END
BEGIN NOW My lord, if you'll give me leave, I will tread this unbolted villain into mortar and daub the walls of a jakes with him. END
BEGIN NOW 'Spare my grey beard,' you wagtail? END
BEGIN NOW Peace, sirrah! END
BEGIN NOW You beastly knave, know you no reverence? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, sir, but anger hath a privilege. END
BEGIN NOW Why art thou angry? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW That such a slave as this should wear a sword, Who wears no honesty. END
BEGIN NOW Such smiling rogues as these, Like rats, oft bite the holy cords atwain Which are too intrinse t' unloose; smooth every passion That in the natures of their lords rebel, Bring oil to fire, snow to their colder moods; Renege, affirm, and turn their halcyon beaks With every gale and vary of their masters, Knowing naught (like dogs) but following. END
BEGIN NOW A plague upon your epileptic visage! END
BEGIN NOW Smile you my speeches, as I were a fool? END
BEGIN NOW Goose, an I had you upon Sarum Plain, I'ld drive ye cackling home to Camelot. END
BEGIN NOW What, art thou mad, old fellow? END
BEGIN NOW How fell you out? END
BEGIN NOW Say that. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW No contraries hold more antipathy Than I and such a knave. END
BEGIN NOW Why dost thou call him knave? END
BEGIN NOW What is his fault? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW His countenance likes me not. END
BEGIN NOW No more perchance does mine, or his, or hers. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Sir, 'tis my occupation to be plain. END
BEGIN NOW I have seen better faces in my time Than stands on any shoulder that I see Before me at this instant. END
BEGIN NOW This is some fellow Who, having been prais'd for bluntness, doth affect A saucy roughness, and constrains the garb Quite from his nature. END
BEGIN NOW He cannot flatter, he! END
BEGIN NOW An honest mind and plain- he must speak truth! END
BEGIN NOW An they will take it, so; if not, he's plain. END
BEGIN NOW These kind of knaves I know which in this plainness Harbour more craft and more corrupter ends Than twenty silly-ducking observants That stretch their duties nicely. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Sir, in good faith, in sincere verity, Under th' allowance of your great aspect, Whose influence, like the wreath of radiant fire On flickering Phoebus' front- What mean'st by this? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW To go out of my dialect, which you discommend so much. END
BEGIN NOW I know, sir, I am no flatterer. END
BEGIN NOW He that beguil'd you in a plain accent was a plain knave, which, for my part, I will not be, though I should win your displeasure to entreat me to't. END
BEGIN NOW What was th' offence you gave him? END
BEGIN NOW I never gave him any. END
BEGIN NOW It pleas'd the King his master very late To strike at me, upon his misconstruction; When he, conjunct, and flattering his displeasure, Tripp'd me behind; being down, insulted, rail'd And put upon him such a deal of man That worthied him, got praises of the King For him attempting who was self-subdu'd; And, in the fleshment of this dread exploit, Drew on me here again. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW None of these rogues and cowards But Ajax is their fool. END
BEGIN NOW Fetch forth the stocks! END
BEGIN NOW You stubborn ancient knave, you reverent braggart, We'll teach you- Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Sir, I am too old to learn. END
BEGIN NOW Call not your stocks for me. END
BEGIN NOW I serve the King; On whose employment I was sent to you. END
BEGIN NOW You shall do small respect, show too bold malice Against the grace and person of my master, Stocking his messenger. END
BEGIN NOW Fetch forth the stocks! END
BEGIN NOW As I have life and honour, There shall he sit till noon. END
BEGIN NOW Till noon? END
BEGIN NOW Till night, my lord, and all night too! END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Why, madam, if I were your father's dog, You should not use me so. END
BEGIN NOW Sir, being his knave, I will. END
BEGIN NOW This is a fellow of the selfsame colour Our sister speaks of. END
BEGIN NOW Come, bring away the stocks! END
BEGIN NOW Stocks brought out. END
BEGIN NOW Let me beseech your Grace not to do so. END
BEGIN NOW His fault is much, and the good King his master Will check him for't. END
BEGIN NOW Your purpos'd low correction Is such as basest and contemn'dest wretches For pilf'rings and most common trespasses Are punish'd with. END
BEGIN NOW The King must take it ill That he, so slightly valued in his messenger, Should have him thus restrain'd. END
BEGIN NOW I'll answer that. END
BEGIN NOW My sister may receive it much more worse, To have her gentleman abus'd, assaulted, For following her affairs. END
BEGIN NOW Put in his legs.- Come, my good lord, away. END
BEGIN NOW Exeunt I am sorry for thee, friend. END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis the Duke's pleasure, Whose disposition, all the world well knows, Will not be rubb'd nor stopp'd. END
BEGIN NOW I'll entreat for thee. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Pray do not, sir. END
BEGIN NOW I have watch'd and travell'd hard. END
BEGIN NOW Some time I shall sleep out, the rest I'll whistle. END
BEGIN NOW A good man's fortune may grow out at heels. END
BEGIN NOW Give you good morrow! END
BEGIN NOW The Duke 's to blame in this; 'twill be ill taken. END
BEGIN NOW Exit. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Good King, that must approve the common saw, Thou out of heaven's benediction com'st To the warm sun! END
BEGIN NOW Approach, thou beacon to this under globe, That by thy comfortable beams I may Peruse this letter. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing almost sees miracles But misery. END
BEGIN NOW I know 'tis from Cordelia, Who hath most fortunately been inform'd Of my obscured course- and 'shall find time From this enormous state, seeking to give Losses their remedies'- All weary and o'erwatch'd, Take vantage, heavy eyes, not to behold This shameful lodging. END
BEGIN NOW Fortune, good night; smile once more, turn thy wheel. END
BEGIN NOW Sleeps. END
BEGIN NOW Scene III. END
BEGIN NOW The open country. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Edgar. END
BEGIN NOW I heard myself proclaim'd, And by the happy hollow of a tree Escap'd the hunt. END
BEGIN NOW No port is free, no place That guard and most unusual vigilance Does not attend my taking. END
BEGIN NOW Whiles I may scape, I will preserve myself; and am bethought To take the basest and most poorest shape That ever penury, in contempt of man, Brought near to beast. END
BEGIN NOW My face I'll grime with filth, Blanket my loins, elf all my hair in knots, And with presented nakedness outface The winds and persecutions of the sky. END
BEGIN NOW The country gives me proof and precedent Of Bedlam beggars, who, with roaring voices, Strike in their numb'd and mortified bare arms Pins, wooden pricks, nails, sprigs of rosemary; And with this horrible object, from low farms, Poor pelting villages, sheepcotes, and mills, Sometime with lunatic bans, sometime with prayers, Enforce their charity. END
BEGIN NOW 'Poor Turlygod! END
BEGIN NOW poor Tom!' END
BEGIN NOW That's something yet! END
BEGIN NOW Edgar I nothing am. END
BEGIN NOW Exit. END
BEGIN NOW Scene IV. END
BEGIN NOW Before Gloucester's Castle; Kent in the stocks. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Lear, Fool, and Gentleman. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis strange that they should so depart from home, And not send back my messenger. END
BEGIN NOW As I learn'd, The night before there was no purpose in them Of this remove. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Hail to thee, noble master! END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Ha! END
BEGIN NOW Mak'st thou this shame thy pastime? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW No, my lord. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Ha, ha! END
BEGIN NOW look! END
BEGIN NOW he wears cruel garters. END
BEGIN NOW Horses are tied by the head, dogs and bears by th' neck, monkeys by th' loins, and men by th' legs. END
BEGIN NOW When a man's over-lusty at legs, then he wears wooden nether-stocks. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW What's he that hath so much thy place mistook To set thee here? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW It is both he and she- Your son and daughter. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW No. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Yes. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW No, I say. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW I say yea. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW No, no, they would not! END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, they have. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW By Jupiter, I swear no! END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW By Juno, I swear ay! END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW They durst not do't; They would not, could not do't. END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis worse than murther To do upon respect such violent outrage. END
BEGIN NOW Resolve me with all modest haste which way Thou mightst deserve or they impose this usage, Coming from us. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW My lord, when at their home I did commend your Highness' letters to them, Ere I was risen from the place that show'd My duty kneeling, came there a reeking post, Stew'd in his haste, half breathless, panting forth From Goneril his mistress salutations; Deliver'd letters, spite of intermission, Which presently they read; on whose contents, They summon'd up their meiny, straight took horse, Commanded me to follow and attend The leisure of their answer, gave me cold looks, And meeting here the other messenger, Whose welcome I perceiv'd had poison'd mine- Being the very fellow which of late Display'd so saucily against your Highness- Having more man than wit about me, drew. END
BEGIN NOW He rais'd the house with loud and coward cries. END
BEGIN NOW Your son and daughter found this trespass worth The shame which here it suffers. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Winter's not gone yet, if the wild geese fly that way. END
BEGIN NOW Fathers that wear rags Do make their children blind; But fathers that bear bags Shall see their children kind. END
BEGIN NOW Fortune, that arrant whore, Ne'er turns the key to th' poor. END
BEGIN NOW But for all this, thou shalt have as many dolours for thy daughters as thou canst tell in a year. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW O, how this mother swells up toward my heart! END
BEGIN NOW Hysterica passio! END
BEGIN NOW Down, thou climbing sorrow! END
BEGIN NOW Thy element's below! END
BEGIN NOW Where is this daughter? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW With the Earl, sir, here within. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Follow me not; Stay here. END
BEGIN NOW Exit. END
BEGIN NOW Made you no more offence but what you speak of? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW None. END
BEGIN NOW How chance the King comes with so small a number? END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW An thou hadst been set i' th' stocks for that question, thou'dst well deserv'd it. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Why, fool? END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW We'll set thee to school to an ant, to teach thee there's no labouring i' th' winter. END
BEGIN NOW All that follow their noses are led by their eyes but blind men, and there's not a nose among twenty but can smell him that's stinking. END
BEGIN NOW Let go thy hold when a great wheel runs down a hill, lest it break thy neck with following it; but the great one that goes upward, let him draw thee after. END
BEGIN NOW When a wise man gives thee better counsel, give me mine again. END
BEGIN NOW I would have none but knaves follow it, since a fool gives it. END
