BEGIN NOW That sir which serves and seeks for gain, And follows but for form, Will pack when it begins to rain And leave thee in the storm. END
BEGIN NOW But I will tarry; the fool will stay, And let the wise man fly. END
BEGIN NOW The knave turns fool that runs away; The fool no knave, perdy. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Where learn'd you this, fool? END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Not i' th' stocks, fool. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Lear and Gloucester Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Deny to speak with me? END
BEGIN NOW They are sick? END
BEGIN NOW they are weary? END
BEGIN NOW They have travell'd all the night? END
BEGIN NOW Mere fetches- The images of revolt and flying off! END
BEGIN NOW Fetch me a better answer. END
BEGIN NOW My dear lord, You know the fiery quality of the Duke, How unremovable and fix'd he is In his own course. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Vengeance! END
BEGIN NOW plague! END
BEGIN NOW death! END
BEGIN NOW confusion! END
BEGIN NOW Fiery? END
BEGIN NOW What quality? END
BEGIN NOW Why, Gloucester, Gloucester, I'ld speak with the Duke of Cornwall and his wife. END
BEGIN NOW Well, my good lord, I have inform'd them so. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Inform'd them? END
BEGIN NOW Dost thou understand me, man? END
BEGIN NOW Ay, my good lord. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW The King would speak with Cornwall; the dear father Would with his daughter speak, commands her service. END
BEGIN NOW Are they inform'd of this? END
BEGIN NOW My breath and blood! END
BEGIN NOW Fiery? END
BEGIN NOW the fiery Duke? END
BEGIN NOW Tell the hot Duke that- No, but not yet! END
BEGIN NOW May be he is not well. END
BEGIN NOW Infirmity doth still neglect all office Whereto our health is bound. END
BEGIN NOW We are not ourselves When nature, being oppress'd, commands the mind To suffer with the body. END
BEGIN NOW I'll forbear; And am fallen out with my more headier will, To take the indispos'd and sickly fit For the sound man.- Death on my state! END
BEGIN NOW Wherefore Should be sit here? END
BEGIN NOW This act persuades me That this remotion of the Duke and her Is practice only. END
BEGIN NOW Give me my servant forth. END
BEGIN NOW Go tell the Duke and 's wife I'ld speak with them- Now, presently. END
BEGIN NOW Bid them come forth and hear me, Or at their chamber door I'll beat the drum Till it cry sleep to death. END
BEGIN NOW I would have all well betwixt you. END
BEGIN NOW Exit. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW O me, my heart, my rising heart! END
BEGIN NOW But down! END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Cry to it, nuncle, as the cockney did to the eels when she put 'em i' th' paste alive. END
BEGIN NOW She knapp'd 'em o' th' coxcombs with a stick and cried 'Down, wantons, down!' END
BEGIN NOW 'Twas her brother that, in pure kindness to his horse, buttered his hay. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Cornwall, Regan, Gloucester, Servants. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Good morrow to you both. END
BEGIN NOW Hail to your Grace! END
BEGIN NOW Kent here set at liberty. END
BEGIN NOW I am glad to see your Highness. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Regan, I think you are; I know what reason I have to think so. END
BEGIN NOW If thou shouldst not be glad, I would divorce me from thy mother's tomb, Sepulchring an adultress. END
BEGIN NOW O, are you free? END
BEGIN NOW Some other time for that.- Beloved Regan, Thy sister's naught. END
BEGIN NOW O Regan, she hath tied Sharp-tooth'd unkindness, like a vulture, here! END
BEGIN NOW I can scarce speak to thee. END
BEGIN NOW Thou'lt not believe With how deprav'd a quality- O Regan! END
BEGIN NOW I pray you, sir, take patience. END
BEGIN NOW I have hope You less know how to value her desert Than she to scant her duty. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Say, how is that? END
BEGIN NOW I cannot think my sister in the least Would fail her obligation. END
BEGIN NOW If, sir, perchance She have restrain'd the riots of your followers, 'Tis on such ground, and to such wholesome end, As clears her from all blame. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW My curses on her! END
BEGIN NOW O, sir, you are old! END
BEGIN NOW Nature in you stands on the very verge Of her confine. END
BEGIN NOW You should be rul'd, and led By some discretion that discerns your state Better than you yourself. END
BEGIN NOW Therefore I pray you That to our sister you do make return; Say you have wrong'd her, sir. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Ask her forgiveness? END
BEGIN NOW Do you but mark how this becomes the house: 'Dear daughter, I confess that I am old. END
BEGIN NOW Age is unnecessary. END
BEGIN NOW On my knees I beg That you'll vouchsafe me raiment, bed, and food.' END
BEGIN NOW Good sir, no more! END
BEGIN NOW These are unsightly tricks. END
BEGIN NOW Return you to my sister. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Never, Regan! END
BEGIN NOW She hath abated me of half my train; Look'd black upon me; struck me with her tongue, Most serpent-like, upon the very heart. END
BEGIN NOW All the stor'd vengeances of heaven fall On her ingrateful top! END
BEGIN NOW Strike her young bones, You taking airs, with lameness! END
BEGIN NOW Fie, sir, fie! END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW You nimble lightnings, dart your blinding flames Into her scornful eyes! END
BEGIN NOW Infect her beauty, You fen-suck'd fogs, drawn by the pow'rful sun, To fall and blast her pride! END
BEGIN NOW O the blest gods! END
BEGIN NOW so will you wish on me When the rash mood is on. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW No, Regan, thou shalt never have my curse. END
BEGIN NOW Thy tender-hefted nature shall not give Thee o'er to harshness. END
BEGIN NOW Her eyes are fierce; but thine Do comfort, and not burn. END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis not in thee To grudge my pleasures, to cut off my train, To bandy hasty words, to scant my sizes, And, in conclusion, to oppose the bolt Against my coming in. END
BEGIN NOW Thou better know'st The offices of nature, bond of childhood, Effects of courtesy, dues of gratitude. END
BEGIN NOW Thy half o' th' kingdom hast thou not forgot, Wherein I thee endow'd. END
BEGIN NOW Good sir, to th' purpose. END
BEGIN NOW Tucket within. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Who put my man i' th' stocks? END
BEGIN NOW What trumpet's that? END
BEGIN NOW I know't- my sister's. END
BEGIN NOW This approves her letter, That she would soon be here. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Steward. END
BEGIN NOW Is your lady come? END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW This is a slave, whose easy-borrowed pride Dwells in the fickle grace of her he follows. END
BEGIN NOW Out, varlet, from my sight! END
BEGIN NOW What means your Grace? END
BEGIN NOW Enter Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Who stock'd my servant? END
BEGIN NOW Regan, I have good hope Thou didst not know on't.- Who comes here? END
BEGIN NOW O heavens! END
BEGIN NOW If you do love old men, if your sweet sway Allow obedience- if yourselves are old, Make it your cause! END
BEGIN NOW Send down, and take my part! END
BEGIN NOW Art not asham'd to look upon this beard?- O Regan, wilt thou take her by the hand? END
BEGIN NOW Why not by th' hand, sir? END
BEGIN NOW How have I offended? END
BEGIN NOW All's not offence that indiscretion finds And dotage terms so. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW O sides, you are too tough! END
BEGIN NOW Will you yet hold? END
BEGIN NOW How came my man i' th' stocks? END
BEGIN NOW I set him there, sir; but his own disorders Deserv'd much less advancement. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW You? END
BEGIN NOW Did you? END
BEGIN NOW I pray you, father, being weak, seem so. END
BEGIN NOW If, till the expiration of your month, You will return and sojourn with my sister, Dismissing half your train, come then to me. END
BEGIN NOW I am now from home, and out of that provision Which shall be needful for your entertainment. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Return to her, and fifty men dismiss'd? END
BEGIN NOW No, rather I abjure all roofs, and choose To wage against the enmity o' th' air, To be a comrade with the wolf and owl- Necessity's sharp pinch! END
BEGIN NOW Return with her? END
BEGIN NOW Why, the hot-blooded France, that dowerless took Our youngest born, I could as well be brought To knee his throne, and, squire-like, pension beg To keep base life afoot. END
BEGIN NOW Return with her? END
BEGIN NOW Persuade me rather to be slave and sumpter To this detested groom. END
BEGIN NOW At your choice, sir. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW I prithee, daughter, do not make me mad. END
BEGIN NOW I will not trouble thee, my child; farewell. END
BEGIN NOW We'll no more meet, no more see one another. END
BEGIN NOW But yet thou art my flesh, my blood, my daughter; Or rather a disease that's in my flesh, Which I must needs call mine. END
BEGIN NOW Thou art a boil, A plague sore, an embossed carbuncle In my corrupted blood. END
BEGIN NOW But I'll not chide thee. END
BEGIN NOW Let shame come when it will, I do not call it. END
BEGIN NOW I do not bid the Thunder-bearer shoot Nor tell tales of thee to high-judging Jove. END
BEGIN NOW Mend when thou canst; be better at thy leisure; I can be patient, I can stay with Regan, I and my hundred knights. END
BEGIN NOW Not altogether so. END
BEGIN NOW I look'd not for you yet, nor am provided For your fit welcome. END
BEGIN NOW Give ear, sir, to my sister; For those that mingle reason with your passion Must be content to think you old, and so- But she knows what she does. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Is this well spoken? END
BEGIN NOW I dare avouch it, sir. END
BEGIN NOW What, fifty followers? END
BEGIN NOW Is it not well? END
BEGIN NOW What should you need of more? END
BEGIN NOW Yea, or so many, sith that both charge and danger Speak 'gainst so great a number? END
BEGIN NOW How in one house Should many people, under two commands, Hold amity? END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis hard; almost impossible. END
BEGIN NOW Why might not you, my lord, receive attendance From those that she calls servants, or from mine? END
BEGIN NOW Why not, my lord? END
BEGIN NOW If then they chanc'd to slack ye, We could control them. END
BEGIN NOW If you will come to me (For now I spy a danger), I entreat you To bring but five-and-twenty. END
BEGIN NOW To no more Will I give place or notice. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW I gave you all- And in good time you gave it! END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Made you my guardians, my depositaries; But kept a reservation to be followed With such a number. END
BEGIN NOW What, must I come to you With five-and-twenty, Regan? END
BEGIN NOW Said you so? END
BEGIN NOW And speak't again my lord. END
BEGIN NOW No more with me. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Those wicked creatures yet do look well-favour'd When others are more wicked; not being the worst Stands in some rank of praise. END
BEGIN NOW I'll go with thee. END
BEGIN NOW Thy fifty yet doth double five-and-twenty, And thou art twice her love. END
BEGIN NOW Hear, me, my lord. END
BEGIN NOW What need you five-and-twenty, ten, or five, To follow in a house where twice so many Have a command to tend you? END
BEGIN NOW What need one? END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW O, reason not the need! END
BEGIN NOW Our basest beggars Are in the poorest thing superfluous. END
BEGIN NOW Allow not nature more than nature needs, Man's life is cheap as beast's. END
BEGIN NOW Thou art a lady: If only to go warm were gorgeous, Why, nature needs not what thou gorgeous wear'st Which scarcely keeps thee warm. END
BEGIN NOW But, for true need- You heavens, give me that patience, patience I need! END
BEGIN NOW You see me here, you gods, a poor old man, As full of grief as age; wretched in both. END
BEGIN NOW If it be you that stirs these daughters' hearts Against their father, fool me not so much To bear it tamely; touch me with noble anger, And let not women's weapons, water drops, Stain my man's cheeks! END
BEGIN NOW No, you unnatural hags! END
BEGIN NOW I will have such revenges on you both That all the world shall- I will do such things- What they are yet, I know not; but they shall be The terrors of the earth! END
BEGIN NOW You think I'll weep. END
BEGIN NOW No, I'll not weep. END
BEGIN NOW I have full cause of weeping, but this heart Shall break into a hundred thousand flaws Or ere I'll weep. END
BEGIN NOW O fool, I shall go mad! END
BEGIN NOW Exeunt Lear, Gloucester, Kent, and Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Storm and tempest. END
BEGIN NOW Let us withdraw; 'twill be a storm. END
BEGIN NOW This house is little; the old man and 's people Cannot be well bestow'd. END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis his own blame; hath put himself from rest And must needs taste his folly. END
BEGIN NOW For his particular, I'll receive him gladly, But not one follower. END
BEGIN NOW So am I purpos'd. END
BEGIN NOW Where is my Lord of Gloucester? END
BEGIN NOW Followed the old man forth. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Gloucester. END
BEGIN NOW He is return'd. END
BEGIN NOW The King is in high rage. END
BEGIN NOW Whither is he going? END
BEGIN NOW He calls to horse, but will I know not whither. END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis best to give him way; he leads himself. END
BEGIN NOW My lord, entreat him by no means to stay. END
BEGIN NOW Alack, the night comes on, and the bleak winds Do sorely ruffle. END
BEGIN NOW For many miles about There's scarce a bush. END
BEGIN NOW O, sir, to wilful men The injuries that they themselves procure Must be their schoolmasters. END
BEGIN NOW Shut up your doors. END
BEGIN NOW He is attended with a desperate train, And what they may incense him to, being apt To have his ear abus'd, wisdom bids fear. END
BEGIN NOW Shut up your doors, my lord: 'tis a wild night. END
BEGIN NOW My Regan counsels well. END
BEGIN NOW Come out o' th' storm. END
BEGIN NOW ACT III. END
BEGIN NOW Scene I. END
BEGIN NOW A heath. END
BEGIN NOW Storm still. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Kent and a Gentleman at several doors. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Who's there, besides foul weather? END
BEGIN NOW One minded like the weather, most unquietly. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW I know you. END
BEGIN NOW Where's the King? END
BEGIN NOW Contending with the fretful elements; Bids the wind blow the earth into the sea, Or swell the curled waters 'bove the main, That things might change or cease; tears his white hair, Which the impetuous blasts, with eyeless rage, Catch in their fury and make nothing of; Strives in his little world of man to outscorn The to-and-fro-conflicting wind and rain. END
BEGIN NOW This night, wherein the cub-drawn bear would couch, The lion and the belly-pinched wolf Keep their fur dry, unbonneted he runs, And bids what will take all. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW But who is with him? END
BEGIN NOW None but the fool, who labours to outjest His heart-struck injuries. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Sir, I do know you, And dare upon the warrant of my note Commend a dear thing to you. END
BEGIN NOW There is division (Although as yet the face of it be cover'd With mutual cunning) 'twixt Albany and Cornwall; Who have (as who have not, that their great stars Thron'd and set high?) END
BEGIN NOW servants, who seem no less, Which are to France the spies and speculations Intelligent of our state. END
BEGIN NOW What hath been seen, Either in snuffs and packings of the Dukes, Or the hard rein which both of them have borne Against the old kind King, or something deeper, Whereof, perchance, these are but furnishings- But, true it is, from France there comes a power Into this scattered kingdom, who already, Wise in our negligence, have secret feet In some of our best ports and are at point To show their open banner. END
BEGIN NOW Now to you: If on my credit you dare build so far To make your speed to Dover, you shall find Some that will thank you, making just report Of how unnatural and bemadding sorrow The King hath cause to plain. END
BEGIN NOW I am a gentleman of blood and breeding, And from some knowledge and assurance offer This office to you. END
BEGIN NOW I will talk further with you. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW No, do not. END
BEGIN NOW For confirmation that I am much more Than my out-wall, open this purse and take What it contains. END
BEGIN NOW If you shall see Cordelia (As fear not but you shall), show her this ring, And she will tell you who your fellow is That yet you do not know. END
BEGIN NOW Fie on this storm! END
BEGIN NOW I will go seek the King. END
BEGIN NOW Give me your hand. END
BEGIN NOW Have you no more to say? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Few words, but, to effect, more than all yet: That, when we have found the King (in which your pain That way, I'll this), he that first lights on him Holla the other. END
BEGIN NOW Exeunt Scene II. END
BEGIN NOW Another part of the heath. END
BEGIN NOW Storm still. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Lear and Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Blow, winds, and crack your cheeks! END
BEGIN NOW rage! END
BEGIN NOW blow! END
BEGIN NOW You cataracts and hurricanoes, spout Till you have drench'd our steeples, drown'd the cocks! END
BEGIN NOW You sulph'rous and thought-executing fires, Vaunt-couriers to oak-cleaving thunderbolts, Singe my white head! END
BEGIN NOW And thou, all-shaking thunder, Strike flat the thick rotundity o' th' world, Crack Nature's moulds, all germains spill at once, That makes ingrateful man! END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW O nuncle, court holy water in a dry house is better than this rain water out o' door. END
BEGIN NOW Good nuncle, in, and ask thy daughters blessing! END
BEGIN NOW Here's a night pities nether wise men nor fools. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Rumble thy bellyful! END
BEGIN NOW Spit, fire! END
BEGIN NOW spout, rain! END
BEGIN NOW Nor rain, wind, thunder, fire are my daughters. END
BEGIN NOW I tax not you, you elements, with unkindness. END
BEGIN NOW I never gave you kingdom, call'd you children, You owe me no subscription. END
BEGIN NOW Then let fall Your horrible pleasure. END
BEGIN NOW Here I stand your slave, A poor, infirm, weak, and despis'd old man. END
BEGIN NOW But yet I call you servile ministers, That will with two pernicious daughters join Your high-engender'd battles 'gainst a head So old and white as this! END
BEGIN NOW O! END
BEGIN NOW O! END
BEGIN NOW 'tis foul! END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW He that has a house to put 's head in has a good head-piece. END
BEGIN NOW The codpiece that will house Before the head has any, The head and he shall louse: So beggars marry many. END
BEGIN NOW The man that makes his toe What he his heart should make Shall of a corn cry woe, And turn his sleep to wake. END
BEGIN NOW For there was never yet fair woman but she made mouths in a glass. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW No, I will be the pattern of all patience; I will say nothing. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Who's there? END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Marry, here's grace and a codpiece; that's a wise man and a fool. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Alas, sir, are you here? END
BEGIN NOW Things that love night Love not such nights as these. END
BEGIN NOW The wrathful skies Gallow the very wanderers of the dark And make them keep their caves. END
BEGIN NOW Since I was man, Such sheets of fire, such bursts of horrid thunder, Such groans of roaring wind and rain, I never Remember to have heard. END
BEGIN NOW Man's nature cannot carry Th' affliction nor the fear. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Let the great gods, That keep this dreadful pudder o'er our heads, Find out their enemies now. END
BEGIN NOW Tremble, thou wretch, That hast within thee undivulged crimes Unwhipp'd of justice. END
BEGIN NOW Hide thee, thou bloody hand; Thou perjur'd, and thou simular man of virtue That art incestuous. END
BEGIN NOW Caitiff, in pieces shake That under covert and convenient seeming Hast practis'd on man's life. END
BEGIN NOW Close pent-up guilts, Rive your concealing continents, and cry These dreadful summoners grace. END
BEGIN NOW I am a man More sinn'd against than sinning. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Alack, bareheaded? END
BEGIN NOW Gracious my lord, hard by here is a hovel; Some friendship will it lend you 'gainst the tempest. END
BEGIN NOW Repose you there, whilst I to this hard house (More harder than the stones whereof 'tis rais'd, Which even but now, demanding after you, Denied me to come in) return, and force Their scanted courtesy. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW My wits begin to turn. END
BEGIN NOW Come on, my boy. END
BEGIN NOW How dost, my boy? END
BEGIN NOW Art cold? END
BEGIN NOW I am cold myself. END
BEGIN NOW Where is this straw, my fellow? END
BEGIN NOW The art of our necessities is strange, That can make vile things precious. END
BEGIN NOW Come, your hovel. END
BEGIN NOW Poor fool and knave, I have one part in my heart That's sorry yet for thee. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW He that has and a little tiny wit- With hey, ho, the wind and the rain- Must make content with his fortunes fit, For the rain it raineth every day. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW True, my good boy. END
BEGIN NOW Come, bring us to this hovel. END
BEGIN NOW Exeunt Fool. END
BEGIN NOW This is a brave night to cool a courtesan. END
BEGIN NOW I'll speak a prophecy ere I go: When priests are more in word than matter; When brewers mar their malt with water; When nobles are their tailors' tutors, No heretics burn'd, but wenches' suitors; When every case in law is right, No squire in debt nor no poor knight; When slanders do not live in tongues, Nor cutpurses come not to throngs; When usurers tell their gold i' th' field, And bawds and whores do churches build: Then shall the realm of Albion Come to great confusion. END
BEGIN NOW Then comes the time, who lives to see't, That going shall be us'd with feet. END
BEGIN NOW This prophecy Merlin shall make, for I live before his time. END
BEGIN NOW Exit. END
BEGIN NOW Scene III. END
BEGIN NOW Gloucester's Castle. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Gloucester and Edmund. END
BEGIN NOW Alack, alack, Edmund, I like not this unnatural dealing! END
BEGIN NOW When I desir'd their leave that I might pity him, they took from me the use of mine own house, charg'd me on pain of perpetual displeasure neither to speak of him, entreat for him, nor any way sustain him. END
BEGIN NOW Most savage and unnatural! END
BEGIN NOW Go to; say you nothing. END
BEGIN NOW There is division betwixt the Dukes, and a worse matter than that. END
BEGIN NOW I have received a letter this night- 'tis dangerous to be spoken- I have lock'd the letter in my closet. END
BEGIN NOW These injuries the King now bears will be revenged home; there's part of a power already footed; we must incline to the King. END
BEGIN NOW I will seek him and privily relieve him. END
BEGIN NOW Go you and maintain talk with the Duke, that my charity be not of him perceived. END
BEGIN NOW If he ask for me, I am ill and gone to bed. END
BEGIN NOW Though I die for't, as no less is threat'ned me, the King my old master must be relieved. END
BEGIN NOW There is some strange thing toward, Edmund. END
BEGIN NOW Pray you be careful. END
BEGIN NOW Exit. END
BEGIN NOW This courtesy, forbid thee, shall the Duke Instantly know, and of that letter too. END
BEGIN NOW This seems a fair deserving, and must draw me That which my father loses- no less than all. END
BEGIN NOW The younger rises when the old doth fall. END
BEGIN NOW Exit. END
BEGIN NOW Scene IV. END
BEGIN NOW The heath. END
BEGIN NOW Before a hovel. END
BEGIN NOW Storm still. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Lear, Kent, and Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Here is the place, my lord. END
BEGIN NOW Good my lord, enter. END
BEGIN NOW The tyranny of the open night 's too rough For nature to endure. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Let me alone. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Good my lord, enter here. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Wilt break my heart? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW I had rather break mine own. END
BEGIN NOW Good my lord, enter. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Thou think'st 'tis much that this contentious storm Invades us to the skin. END
BEGIN NOW So 'tis to thee; But where the greater malady is fix'd, The lesser is scarce felt. END
BEGIN NOW Thou'dst shun a bear; But if thy flight lay toward the raging sea, Thou'dst meet the bear i' th' mouth. END
BEGIN NOW When the mind's free, The body's delicate. END
BEGIN NOW The tempest in my mind Doth from my senses take all feeling else Save what beats there. END
BEGIN NOW Filial ingratitude! END
BEGIN NOW Is it not as this mouth should tear this hand For lifting food to't? END
BEGIN NOW But I will punish home! END
BEGIN NOW No, I will weep no more. END
BEGIN NOW In such a night 'To shut me out! END
BEGIN NOW Pour on; I will endure. END
BEGIN NOW In such a night as this! END
BEGIN NOW O Regan, Goneril! END
BEGIN NOW Your old kind father, whose frank heart gave all! END
BEGIN NOW O, that way madness lies; let me shun that! END
BEGIN NOW No more of that. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Good my lord, enter here. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Prithee go in thyself; seek thine own ease. END
BEGIN NOW This tempest will not give me leave to ponder On things would hurt me more. END
BEGIN NOW But I'll go in. END
BEGIN NOW In, boy; go first.- You houseless poverty- Nay, get thee in. END
BEGIN NOW I'll pray, and then I'll sleep. END
BEGIN NOW Exit Poor naked wretches, wheresoe'er you are, That bide the pelting of this pitiless storm, How shall your houseless heads and unfed sides, Your loop'd and window'd raggedness, defend you From seasons such as these? END
BEGIN NOW O, I have ta'en Too little care of this! END
BEGIN NOW Take physic, pomp; Expose thyself to feel what wretches feel, That thou mayst shake the superflux to them And show the heavens more just. END
BEGIN NOW Fathom and half, fathom and half! END
BEGIN NOW Poor Tom! END
BEGIN NOW Enter Fool Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Come not in here, nuncle, here's a spirit. END
BEGIN NOW Help me, help me! END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Give me thy hand. END
BEGIN NOW Who's there? END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW A spirit, a spirit! END
BEGIN NOW He says his name's poor Tom. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW What art thou that dost grumble there i' th' straw? END
BEGIN NOW Come forth. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Edgar Away! END
BEGIN NOW the foul fiend follows me! END
BEGIN NOW Through the sharp hawthorn blows the cold wind. END
BEGIN NOW Humh! END
BEGIN NOW go to thy cold bed, and warm thee. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Hast thou given all to thy two daughters, and art thou come to this? END
BEGIN NOW Who gives anything to poor Tom? END
BEGIN NOW whom the foul fiend hath led through fire and through flame, through ford and whirlpool, o'er bog and quagmire; that hath laid knives under his pillow and halters in his pew, set ratsbane by his porridge, made him proud of heart, to ride on a bay trotting horse over four-inch'd bridges, to course his own shadow for a traitor. END
BEGIN NOW Bless thy five wits! END
BEGIN NOW Tom 's acold. END
BEGIN NOW O, do de, do de, do de. END
BEGIN NOW Bless thee from whirlwinds, star-blasting, and taking! END
BEGIN NOW Do poor Tom some charity, whom the foul fiend vexes. END
BEGIN NOW There could I have him now- and there- and there again- and there! END
BEGIN NOW Storm still. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW What, have his daughters brought him to this pass? END
BEGIN NOW Couldst thou save nothing? END
BEGIN NOW Didst thou give 'em all? END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Nay, he reserv'd a blanket, else we had been all sham'd. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Now all the plagues that in the pendulous air Hang fated o'er men's faults light on thy daughters! END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW He hath no daughters, sir. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Death, traitor! END
BEGIN NOW nothing could have subdu'd nature To such a lowness but his unkind daughters. END
BEGIN NOW Is it the fashion that discarded fathers Should have thus little mercy on their flesh? END
BEGIN NOW Judicious punishment! END
BEGIN NOW 'Twas this flesh begot Those pelican daughters. END
BEGIN NOW Pillicock sat on Pillicock's Hill. END
BEGIN NOW 'Allow, 'allow, loo, loo! END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW This cold night will turn us all to fools and madmen. END
BEGIN NOW Take heed o' th' foul fiend; obey thy parents: keep thy word justly; swear not; commit not with man's sworn spouse; set not thy sweet heart on proud array. END
BEGIN NOW Tom 's acold. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW What hast thou been? END
BEGIN NOW A servingman, proud in heart and mind; that curl'd my hair, wore gloves in my cap; serv'd the lust of my mistress' heart and did the act of darkness with her; swore as many oaths as I spake words, and broke them in the sweet face of heaven; one that slept in the contriving of lust, and wak'd to do it. END
BEGIN NOW Wine lov'd I deeply, dice dearly; and in woman out-paramour'd the Turk. END
BEGIN NOW False of heart, light of ear, bloody of hand; hog in sloth, fox in stealth, wolf in greediness, dog in madness, lion in prey. END
BEGIN NOW Let not the creaking of shoes nor the rustling of silks betray thy poor heart to woman. END
BEGIN NOW Keep thy foot out of brothel, thy hand out of placket, thy pen from lender's book, and defy the foul fiend. END
BEGIN NOW Still through the hawthorn blows the cold wind; says suum, mun, hey, no, nonny. END
BEGIN NOW Dolphin my boy, my boy, sessa! END
BEGIN NOW let him trot by. END
BEGIN NOW Storm still. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Why, thou wert better in thy grave than to answer with thy uncover'd body this extremity of the skies. END
BEGIN NOW Is man no more than this? END
BEGIN NOW Consider him well. END
BEGIN NOW Thou ow'st the worm no silk, the beast no hide, the sheep no wool, the cat no perfume. END
BEGIN NOW Ha! END
BEGIN NOW Here's three on's are sophisticated! END
BEGIN NOW Thou art the thing itself; unaccommodated man is no more but such a poor, bare, forked animal as thou art. END
BEGIN NOW Off, off, you lendings! END
BEGIN NOW Come, unbutton here. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Prithee, nuncle, be contented! END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis a naughty night to swim in. END
BEGIN NOW Now a little fire in a wild field were like an old lecher's heart- a small spark, all the rest on's body cold. END
BEGIN NOW Look, here comes a walking fire. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Gloucester with a torch. END
BEGIN NOW This is the foul fiend Flibbertigibbet. END
BEGIN NOW He begins at curfew, and walks till the first cock. END
BEGIN NOW He gives the web and the pin, squints the eye, and makes the harelip; mildews the white wheat, and hurts the poor creature of earth. END
BEGIN NOW Saint Withold footed thrice the 'old; He met the nightmare, and her nine fold; Bid her alight And her troth plight, And aroint thee, witch, aroint thee! END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW How fares your Grace? END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW What's he? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Who's there? END
BEGIN NOW What is't you seek? END
BEGIN NOW What are you there? END
BEGIN NOW Your names? END
BEGIN NOW Poor Tom, that eats the swimming frog, the toad, the todpole, the wall-newt and the water; that in the fury of his heart, when the foul fiend rages, eats cow-dung for sallets, swallows the old rat and the ditch-dog, drinks the green mantle of the standing pool; who is whipp'd from tithing to tithing, and stock-punish'd and imprison'd; who hath had three suits to his back, six shirts to his body, horse to ride, and weapons to wear; But mice and rats, and such small deer, Have been Tom's food for seven long year. END
BEGIN NOW Beware my follower. END
BEGIN NOW Peace, Smulkin! END
BEGIN NOW peace, thou fiend! END
BEGIN NOW What, hath your Grace no better company? END
BEGIN NOW The prince of darkness is a gentleman! END
BEGIN NOW Modo he's call'd, and Mahu. END
BEGIN NOW Our flesh and blood is grown so vile, my lord, That it doth hate what gets it. END
BEGIN NOW Poor Tom 's acold. END
BEGIN NOW Go in with me. END
BEGIN NOW My duty cannot suffer T' obey in all your daughters' hard commands. END
BEGIN NOW Though their injunction be to bar my doors And let this tyrannous night take hold upon you, Yet have I ventur'd to come seek you out And bring you where both fire and food is ready. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW First let me talk with this philosopher. END
BEGIN NOW What is the cause of thunder? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Good my lord, take his offer; go into th' house. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW I'll talk a word with this same learned Theban. END
BEGIN NOW What is your study? END
BEGIN NOW How to prevent the fiend and to kill vermin. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Let me ask you one word in private. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Importune him once more to go, my lord. END
BEGIN NOW His wits begin t' unsettle. END
BEGIN NOW Canst thou blame him? END
BEGIN NOW Storm still. END
BEGIN NOW His daughters seek his death. END
BEGIN NOW Ah, that good Kent! END
BEGIN NOW He said it would be thus- poor banish'd man! END
BEGIN NOW Thou say'st the King grows mad: I'll tell thee, friend, I am almost mad myself. END
BEGIN NOW I had a son, Now outlaw'd from my blood. END
BEGIN NOW He sought my life But lately, very late. END
BEGIN NOW I lov'd him, friend- No father his son dearer. END
BEGIN NOW True to tell thee, The grief hath craz'd my wits. END
BEGIN NOW What a night 's this! END
BEGIN NOW I do beseech your Grace- Lear. END
BEGIN NOW O, cry you mercy, sir. END
BEGIN NOW Noble philosopher, your company. END
BEGIN NOW Tom's acold. END
BEGIN NOW In, fellow, there, into th' hovel; keep thee warm. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Come, let's in all. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW This way, my lord. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW With him! END
BEGIN NOW I will keep still with my philosopher. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Good my lord, soothe him; let him take the fellow. END
BEGIN NOW Take him you on. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Sirrah, come on; go along with us. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Come, good Athenian. END
BEGIN NOW No words, no words! END
BEGIN NOW hush. END
BEGIN NOW Child Rowland to the dark tower came; His word was still Fie, foh, and fum! END
BEGIN NOW I smell the blood of a British man. END
BEGIN NOW Scene V. Gloucester's Castle. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Cornwall and Edmund. END
BEGIN NOW I will have my revenge ere I depart his house. END
BEGIN NOW How, my lord, I may be censured, that nature thus gives way to loyalty, something fears me to think of. END
BEGIN NOW I now perceive it was not altogether your brother's evil disposition made him seek his death; but a provoking merit, set awork by a reproveable badness in himself. END
BEGIN NOW How malicious is my fortune that I must repent to be just! END
BEGIN NOW This is the letter he spoke of, which approves him an intelligent party to the advantages of France. END
BEGIN NOW O heavens! END
BEGIN NOW that this treason were not- or not I the detector! END
BEGIN NOW Go with me to the Duchess. END
BEGIN NOW If the matter of this paper be certain, you have mighty business in hand. END
BEGIN NOW True or false, it hath made thee Earl of Gloucester. END
BEGIN NOW Seek out where thy father is, that he may be ready for our apprehension. END
BEGIN NOW If I find him comforting the King, it will stuff his suspicion more fully.- I will persever in my course of loyalty, though the conflict be sore between that and my blood. END
BEGIN NOW I will lay trust upon thee, and thou shalt find a dearer father in my love. END
BEGIN NOW Scene VI. END
BEGIN NOW A farmhouse near Gloucester's Castle. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Gloucester, Lear, Kent, Fool, and Edgar. END
BEGIN NOW Here is better than the open air; take it thankfully. END
BEGIN NOW I will piece out the comfort with what addition I can. END
BEGIN NOW I will not be long from you. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW All the power of his wits have given way to his impatience. END
BEGIN NOW The gods reward your kindness! END
BEGIN NOW Exit Frateretto calls me, and tells me Nero is an angler in the lake of darkness. END
BEGIN NOW Pray, innocent, and beware the foul fiend. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Prithee, nuncle, tell me whether a madman be a gentleman or a yeoman. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW A king, a king! END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW No, he's a yeoman that has a gentleman to his son; for he's a mad yeoman that sees his son a gentleman before him. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW To have a thousand with red burning spits Come hizzing in upon 'em- The foul fiend bites my back. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW He's mad that trusts in the tameness of a wolf, a horse's health, a boy's love, or a whore's oath. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW It shall be done; I will arraign them straight. END
BEGIN NOW Thou, sapient sir, sit here. END
BEGIN NOW Now, you she-foxes! END
BEGIN NOW Look, where he stands and glares! END
BEGIN NOW Want'st thou eyes at trial, madam? END
BEGIN NOW Come o'er the bourn, Bessy, to me. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Her boat hath a leak, And she must not speak Why she dares not come over to thee. END
BEGIN NOW The foul fiend haunts poor Tom in the voice of a nightingale. END
BEGIN NOW Hoppedance cries in Tom's belly for two white herring. END
BEGIN NOW Croak not, black angel; I have no food for thee. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW How do you, sir? END
BEGIN NOW Stand you not so amaz'd. END
BEGIN NOW Will you lie down and rest upon the cushions? END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW I'll see their trial first. END
BEGIN NOW Bring in their evidence. END
BEGIN NOW And thou, his yokefellow of equity, Bench by his side. END
BEGIN NOW You are o' th' commission, Sit you too. END
BEGIN NOW Let us deal justly. END
BEGIN NOW Sleepest or wakest thou, jolly shepherd? END
BEGIN NOW Thy sheep be in the corn; And for one blast of thy minikin mouth Thy sheep shall take no harm. END
BEGIN NOW Purr! END
BEGIN NOW the cat is gray. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Arraign her first. END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis I here take my oath before this honourable assembly, she kicked the poor King her father. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Come hither, mistress. END
BEGIN NOW Is your name Goneril? END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW She cannot deny it. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW Cry you mercy, I took you for a joint-stool. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW And here's another, whose warp'd looks proclaim What store her heart is made on. END
BEGIN NOW Stop her there! END
BEGIN NOW Arms, arms! END
BEGIN NOW sword! END
BEGIN NOW fire! END
BEGIN NOW Corruption in the place! END
BEGIN NOW False justicer, why hast thou let her scape? END
BEGIN NOW Bless thy five wits! END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW O pity! END
BEGIN NOW Sir, where is the patience now That you so oft have boasted to retain? END
BEGIN NOW My tears begin to take his part so much They'll mar my counterfeiting. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW The little dogs and all, Tray, Blanch, and Sweetheart, see, they bark at me. END
BEGIN NOW Tom will throw his head at them. END
BEGIN NOW Avaunt, you curs! END
BEGIN NOW Be thy mouth or black or white, Tooth that poisons if it bite; Mastiff, greyhound, mongrel grim, Hound or spaniel, brach or lym, Bobtail tyke or trundle-tall- Tom will make them weep and wail; For, with throwing thus my head, Dogs leap the hatch, and all are fled. END
BEGIN NOW Do de, de, de. END
BEGIN NOW Sessa! END
BEGIN NOW Come, march to wakes and fairs and market towns. END
BEGIN NOW Poor Tom, thy horn is dry. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Then let them anatomize Regan. END
BEGIN NOW See what breeds about her heart. END
BEGIN NOW Is there any cause in nature that makes these hard hearts? END
BEGIN NOW You, sir- I entertain you for one of my hundred; only I do not like the fashion of your garments. END
BEGIN NOW You'll say they are Persian attire; but let them be chang'd. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Now, good my lord, lie here and rest awhile. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Make no noise, make no noise; draw the curtains. END
BEGIN NOW So, so, so. END
BEGIN NOW We'll go to supper i' th' morning. END
BEGIN NOW So, so, so. END
BEGIN NOW Fool. END
BEGIN NOW And I'll go to bed at noon. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Gloucester. END
BEGIN NOW Come hither, friend. END
BEGIN NOW Where is the King my master? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Here, sir; but trouble him not; his wits are gone. END
BEGIN NOW Good friend, I prithee take him in thy arms. END
BEGIN NOW I have o'erheard a plot of death upon him. END
BEGIN NOW There is a litter ready; lay him in't And drive towards Dover, friend, where thou shalt meet Both welcome and protection. END
BEGIN NOW Take up thy master. END
BEGIN NOW If thou shouldst dally half an hour, his life, With thine, and all that offer to defend him, Stand in assured loss. END
BEGIN NOW Take up, take up! END
BEGIN NOW And follow me, that will to some provision Give thee quick conduct. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Oppressed nature sleeps. END
BEGIN NOW This rest might yet have balm'd thy broken senses, Which, if convenience will not allow, Stand in hard cure. END
BEGIN NOW Come, help to bear thy master. END
BEGIN NOW Thou must not stay behind. END
BEGIN NOW Come, come, away! END
BEGIN NOW Exeunt When we our betters see bearing our woes, We scarcely think our miseries our foes. END
BEGIN NOW Who alone suffers suffers most i' th' mind, Leaving free things and happy shows behind; But then the mind much sufferance doth o'erskip When grief hath mates, and bearing fellowship. END
BEGIN NOW How light and portable my pain seems now, When that which makes me bend makes the King bow, He childed as I fathered! END
BEGIN NOW Tom, away! END
BEGIN NOW Mark the high noises, and thyself bewray When false opinion, whose wrong thought defiles thee, In thy just proof repeals and reconciles thee. END
BEGIN NOW What will hap more to-night, safe scape the King! END
BEGIN NOW Lurk, lurk. END
BEGIN NOW Scene VII. END
BEGIN NOW Gloucester's Castle. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Cornwall, Regan, Goneril, Bastard, and Servants. END
BEGIN NOW Post speedily to my lord your husband, show him this letter. END
BEGIN NOW The army of France is landed.- Seek out the traitor Gloucester. END
BEGIN NOW Hang him instantly. END
BEGIN NOW Pluck out his eyes. END
BEGIN NOW Leave him to my displeasure. END
BEGIN NOW Edmund, keep you our sister company. END
BEGIN NOW The revenges we are bound to take upon your traitorous father are not fit for your beholding. END
BEGIN NOW Advise the Duke where you are going, to a most festinate preparation. END
BEGIN NOW We are bound to the like. END
BEGIN NOW Our posts shall be swift and intelligent betwixt us. END
BEGIN NOW Farewell, dear sister; farewell, my Lord of Gloucester. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Steward. END
BEGIN NOW How now? END
BEGIN NOW Where's the King? END
BEGIN NOW My Lord of Gloucester hath convey'd him hence. END
BEGIN NOW Some five or six and thirty of his knights, Hot questrists after him, met him at gate; Who, with some other of the lord's dependants, Are gone with him towards Dover, where they boast To have well-armed friends. END
BEGIN NOW Get horses for your mistress. END
BEGIN NOW Farewell, sweet lord, and sister. END
BEGIN NOW Edmund, farewell. END
BEGIN NOW Exeunt Go seek the traitor Gloucester, Pinion him like a thief, bring him before us. END
BEGIN NOW Though well we may not pass upon his life Without the form of justice, yet our power Shall do a court'sy to our wrath, which men May blame, but not control. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Gloucester, brought in by two or three. END
BEGIN NOW Who's there? END
BEGIN NOW the traitor? END
BEGIN NOW Ingrateful fox! END
BEGIN NOW 'tis he. END
BEGIN NOW Bind fast his corky arms. END
BEGIN NOW What mean, your Graces? END
BEGIN NOW Good my friends, consider You are my guests. END
BEGIN NOW Do me no foul play, friends. END
BEGIN NOW Bind him, I say. END
BEGIN NOW Hard, hard. END
BEGIN NOW O filthy traitor! END
BEGIN NOW Unmerciful lady as you are, I am none. END
BEGIN NOW To this chair bind him. END
BEGIN NOW Villain, thou shalt find- By the kind gods, 'tis most ignobly done To pluck me by the beard. END
BEGIN NOW So white, and such a traitor! END
BEGIN NOW Naughty lady, These hairs which thou dost ravish from my chin Will quicken, and accuse thee. END
BEGIN NOW I am your host. END
BEGIN NOW With robber's hands my hospitable favours You should not ruffle thus. END
BEGIN NOW What will you do? END
BEGIN NOW Come, sir, what letters had you late from France? END
BEGIN NOW Be simple-answer'd, for we know the truth. END
BEGIN NOW And what confederacy have you with the traitors Late footed in the kingdom? END
BEGIN NOW To whose hands have you sent the lunatic King? END
BEGIN NOW Speak. END
BEGIN NOW I have a letter guessingly set down, Which came from one that's of a neutral heart, And not from one oppos'd. END
BEGIN NOW Cunning. END
BEGIN NOW And false. END
BEGIN NOW Where hast thou sent the King? END
BEGIN NOW To Dover. END
BEGIN NOW Wherefore to Dover? END
BEGIN NOW Wast thou not charg'd at peril- Wherefore to Dover? END
BEGIN NOW Let him first answer that. END
BEGIN NOW I am tied to th' stake, and I must stand the course. END
BEGIN NOW Wherefore to Dover, sir? END
BEGIN NOW Because I would not see thy cruel nails Pluck out his poor old eyes; nor thy fierce sister In his anointed flesh stick boarish fangs. END
BEGIN NOW The sea, with such a storm as his bare head In hell-black night endur'd, would have buoy'd up And quench'd the steeled fires. END
BEGIN NOW Yet, poor old heart, he holp the heavens to rain. END
BEGIN NOW If wolves had at thy gate howl'd that stern time, Thou shouldst have said, 'Good porter, turn the key.' END
BEGIN NOW All cruels else subscrib'd. END
BEGIN NOW But I shall see The winged vengeance overtake such children. END
BEGIN NOW See't shalt thou never. END
BEGIN NOW Fellows, hold the chair. END
BEGIN NOW Upon these eyes of thine I'll set my foot. END
BEGIN NOW He that will think to live till he be old, Give me some help!- O cruel! END
BEGIN NOW O ye gods! END
BEGIN NOW One side will mock another. END
BEGIN NOW Th' other too! END
BEGIN NOW If you see vengeance- Hold your hand, my lord! END
BEGIN NOW I have serv'd you ever since I was a child; But better service have I never done you Than now to bid you hold. END
BEGIN NOW How now, you dog? END
BEGIN NOW If you did wear a beard upon your chin, I'ld shake it on this quarrel. END
BEGIN NOW What do you mean? END
BEGIN NOW My villain! END
BEGIN NOW Draw and fight. END
BEGIN NOW Nay, then, come on, and take the chance of anger. END
BEGIN NOW Give me thy sword. END
BEGIN NOW A peasant stand up thus? END
BEGIN NOW She takes a sword and runs at him behind. END
BEGIN NOW O, I am slain! END
BEGIN NOW My lord, you have one eye left To see some mischief on him. END
BEGIN NOW O! END
BEGIN NOW He dies. END
BEGIN NOW Lest it see more, prevent it. END
BEGIN NOW Out, vile jelly! END
BEGIN NOW Where is thy lustre now? END
BEGIN NOW All dark and comfortless! END
BEGIN NOW Where's my son Edmund? END
BEGIN NOW Edmund, enkindle all the sparks of nature To quit this horrid act. END
BEGIN NOW Out, treacherous villain! END
BEGIN NOW Thou call'st on him that hates thee. END
BEGIN NOW It was he That made the overture of thy treasons to us; Who is too good to pity thee. END
BEGIN NOW O my follies! END
BEGIN NOW Then Edgar was abus'd. END
BEGIN NOW Kind gods, forgive me that, and prosper him! END
BEGIN NOW Go thrust him out at gates, and let him smell His way to Dover. END
BEGIN NOW Exit with Gloucester. END
BEGIN NOW How is't, my lord? END
BEGIN NOW How look you? END
BEGIN NOW I have receiv'd a hurt. END
BEGIN NOW Follow me, lady. END
BEGIN NOW Turn out that eyeless villain. END
BEGIN NOW Throw this slave Upon the dunghill. END
BEGIN NOW Regan, I bleed apace. END
BEGIN NOW Untimely comes this hurt. END
BEGIN NOW Give me your arm. END
BEGIN NOW Exit I'll never care what wickedness I do, If this man come to good. END
BEGIN NOW If she live long, And in the end meet the old course of death, Women will all turn monsters. END
BEGIN NOW Let's follow the old Earl, and get the bedlam To lead him where he would. END
BEGIN NOW His roguish madness Allows itself to anything. END
BEGIN NOW Go thou. END
BEGIN NOW I'll fetch some flax and whites of eggs To apply to his bleeding face. END
BEGIN NOW Now heaven help him! END
BEGIN NOW ACT IV. END
BEGIN NOW Scene I. END
BEGIN NOW The heath. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Edgar. END
BEGIN NOW Yet better thus, and known to be contemn'd, Than still contemn'd and flatter'd. END
BEGIN NOW To be worst, The lowest and most dejected thing of fortune, Stands still in esperance, lives not in fear. END
BEGIN NOW The lamentable change is from the best; The worst returns to laughter. END
BEGIN NOW Welcome then, Thou unsubstantial air that I embrace! END
BEGIN NOW The wretch that thou hast blown unto the worst Owes nothing to thy blasts. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Gloucester, led by an Old Man. END
BEGIN NOW But who comes here? END
BEGIN NOW My father, poorly led? END
BEGIN NOW World, world, O world! END
BEGIN NOW But that thy strange mutations make us hate thee, Life would not yield to age. END
BEGIN NOW Old Man. END
BEGIN NOW O my good lord, I have been your tenant, and your father's tenant, These fourscore years. END
BEGIN NOW Away, get thee away! END
BEGIN NOW Good friend, be gone. END
BEGIN NOW Thy comforts can do me no good at all; Thee they may hurt. END
BEGIN NOW Old Man. END
BEGIN NOW You cannot see your way. END
BEGIN NOW I have no way, and therefore want no eyes; I stumbled when I saw. END
BEGIN NOW Full oft 'tis seen Our means secure us, and our mere defects Prove our commodities. END
BEGIN NOW Ah dear son Edgar, The food of thy abused father's wrath! END
BEGIN NOW Might I but live to see thee in my touch, I'ld say I had eyes again! END
BEGIN NOW Old Man. END
BEGIN NOW How now? END
BEGIN NOW Who's there? END
BEGIN NOW O gods! END
BEGIN NOW Who is't can say 'I am at the worst'? END
BEGIN NOW I am worse than e'er I was. END
BEGIN NOW Old Man. END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis poor mad Tom. END
BEGIN NOW And worse I may be yet. END
BEGIN NOW The worst is not So long as we can say 'This is the worst.' END
BEGIN NOW Old Man. END
BEGIN NOW Fellow, where goest? END
BEGIN NOW Is it a beggarman? END
BEGIN NOW Old Man. END
BEGIN NOW Madman and beggar too. END
BEGIN NOW He has some reason, else he could not beg. END
BEGIN NOW I' th' last night's storm I such a fellow saw, Which made me think a man a worm. END
BEGIN NOW My son Came then into my mind, and yet my mind Was then scarce friends with him. END
BEGIN NOW I have heard more since. END
BEGIN NOW As flies to wanton boys are we to th' gods. END
BEGIN NOW They kill us for their sport. END
BEGIN NOW How should this be? END
BEGIN NOW Bad is the trade that must play fool to sorrow, Ang'ring itself and others.- Bless thee, master! END
BEGIN NOW Is that the naked fellow? END
BEGIN NOW Old Man. END
BEGIN NOW Ay, my lord. END
BEGIN NOW Then prithee get thee gone. END
BEGIN NOW If for my sake Thou wilt o'ertake us hence a mile or twain I' th' way toward Dover, do it for ancient love; And bring some covering for this naked soul, Who I'll entreat to lead me. END
BEGIN NOW Old Man. END
BEGIN NOW Alack, sir, he is mad! END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis the time's plague when madmen lead the blind. END
BEGIN NOW Do as I bid thee, or rather do thy pleasure. END
BEGIN NOW Above the rest, be gone. END
BEGIN NOW Old Man. END
BEGIN NOW I'll bring him the best 'parel that I have, Come on't what will. END
BEGIN NOW Exit. END
BEGIN NOW Sirrah naked fellow- Poor Tom's acold. END
BEGIN NOW I cannot daub it further. END
BEGIN NOW Come hither, fellow. END
BEGIN NOW And yet I must.- Bless thy sweet eyes, they bleed. END
BEGIN NOW Know'st thou the way to Dover? END
BEGIN NOW Both stile and gate, horseway and footpath. END
BEGIN NOW Poor Tom hath been scar'd out of his good wits. END
BEGIN NOW Bless thee, good man's son, from the foul fiend! END
BEGIN NOW Five fiends have been in poor Tom at once: of lust, as Obidicut; Hobbididence, prince of dumbness; Mahu, of stealing; Modo, of murder; Flibbertigibbet, of mopping and mowing, who since possesses chambermaids and waiting women. END
BEGIN NOW So, bless thee, master! END
BEGIN NOW Here, take this Purse, thou whom the heavens' plagues Have humbled to all strokes. END
BEGIN NOW That I am wretched Makes thee the happier. END
BEGIN NOW Heavens, deal so still! END
BEGIN NOW Let the superfluous and lust-dieted man, That slaves your ordinance, that will not see Because he does not feel, feel your pow'r quickly; So distribution should undo excess, And each man have enough. END
BEGIN NOW Dost thou know Dover? END
BEGIN NOW Ay, master. END
BEGIN NOW There is a cliff, whose high and bending head Looks fearfully in the confined deep. END
BEGIN NOW Bring me but to the very brim of it, And I'll repair the misery thou dost bear With something rich about me. END
BEGIN NOW From that place I shall no leading need. END
BEGIN NOW Give me thy arm. END
BEGIN NOW Poor Tom shall lead thee. END
BEGIN NOW Scene II. END
BEGIN NOW Before the Duke of Albany's Palace. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Welcome, my lord. END
BEGIN NOW I marvel our mild husband Not met us on the way. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Steward. END
BEGIN NOW Now, where's your master? END
BEGIN NOW Madam, within, but never man so chang'd. END
BEGIN NOW I told him of the army that was landed: He smil'd at it. END
BEGIN NOW I told him you were coming: His answer was, 'The worse.' END
BEGIN NOW Of Gloucester's treachery And of the loyal service of his son When I inform'd him, then he call'd me sot And told me I had turn'd the wrong side out. END
BEGIN NOW What most he should dislike seems pleasant to him; What like, offensive. END
BEGIN NOW Then shall you go no further. END
BEGIN NOW It is the cowish terror of his spirit, That dares not undertake. END
BEGIN NOW He'll not feel wrongs Which tie him to an answer. END
BEGIN NOW Our wishes on the way May prove effects. END
BEGIN NOW Back, Edmund, to my brother. END
BEGIN NOW Hasten his musters and conduct his pow'rs. END
BEGIN NOW I must change arms at home and give the distaff Into my husband's hands. END
BEGIN NOW This trusty servant Shall pass between us. END
BEGIN NOW Ere long you are like to hear (If you dare venture in your own behalf) A mistress's command. END
BEGIN NOW Wear this. END
BEGIN NOW Spare speech. END
BEGIN NOW Decline your head. END
BEGIN NOW This kiss, if it durst speak, Would stretch thy spirits up into the air. END
BEGIN NOW Conceive, and fare thee well. END
BEGIN NOW Yours in the ranks of death! END
BEGIN NOW Exit. END
BEGIN NOW My most dear Gloucester! END
BEGIN NOW O, the difference of man and man! END
BEGIN NOW To thee a woman's services are due; My fool usurps my body. END
BEGIN NOW Madam, here comes my lord. END
BEGIN NOW Exit. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Albany. END
BEGIN NOW I have been worth the whistle. END
BEGIN NOW O Goneril, You are not worth the dust which the rude wind Blows in your face! END
BEGIN NOW I fear your disposition. END
BEGIN NOW That nature which contemns it origin Cannot be bordered certain in itself. END
BEGIN NOW She that herself will sliver and disbranch From her material sap, perforce must wither And come to deadly use. END
BEGIN NOW No more! END
BEGIN NOW The text is foolish. END
BEGIN NOW Wisdom and goodness to the vile seem vile; Filths savour but themselves. END
BEGIN NOW What have you done? END
BEGIN NOW Tigers, not daughters, what have you perform'd? END
BEGIN NOW A father, and a gracious aged man, Whose reverence even the head-lugg'd bear would lick, Most barbarous, most degenerate, have you madded. END
BEGIN NOW Could my good brother suffer you to do it? END
BEGIN NOW A man, a prince, by him so benefited! END
BEGIN NOW If that the heavens do not their visible spirits Send quickly down to tame these vile offences, It will come, Humanity must perforce prey on itself, Like monsters of the deep. END
BEGIN NOW Milk-liver'd man! END
BEGIN NOW That bear'st a cheek for blows, a head for wrongs; Who hast not in thy brows an eye discerning Thine honour from thy suffering; that not know'st Fools do those villains pity who are punish'd Ere they have done their mischief. END
BEGIN NOW Where's thy drum? END
BEGIN NOW France spreads his banners in our noiseless land, With plumed helm thy state begins to threat, Whiles thou, a moral fool, sit'st still, and criest 'Alack, why does he so?' END
BEGIN NOW See thyself, devil! END
BEGIN NOW Proper deformity seems not in the fiend So horrid as in woman. END
BEGIN NOW O vain fool! END
BEGIN NOW Thou changed and self-cover'd thing, for shame! END
BEGIN NOW Bemonster not thy feature! END
BEGIN NOW Were't my fitness To let these hands obey my blood, They are apt enough to dislocate and tear Thy flesh and bones. END
BEGIN NOW Howe'er thou art a fiend, A woman's shape doth shield thee. END
BEGIN NOW Marry, your manhood mew! END
BEGIN NOW Enter a Gentleman. END
BEGIN NOW What news? END
BEGIN NOW O, my good lord, the Duke of Cornwall 's dead, Slain by his servant, going to put out The other eye of Gloucester. END
BEGIN NOW Gloucester's eyes? END
BEGIN NOW A servant that he bred, thrill'd with remorse, Oppos'd against the act, bending his sword To his great master; who, thereat enrag'd, Flew on him, and amongst them fell'd him dead; But not without that harmful stroke which since Hath pluck'd him after. END
BEGIN NOW This shows you are above, You justicers, that these our nether crimes So speedily can venge! END
BEGIN NOW But O poor Gloucester! END
BEGIN NOW Lose he his other eye? END
BEGIN NOW Both, both, my lord. END
BEGIN NOW This letter, madam, craves a speedy answer. END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis from your sister. END
BEGIN NOW One way I like this well; But being widow, and my Gloucester with her, May all the building in my fancy pluck Upon my hateful life. END
BEGIN NOW Another way The news is not so tart.- I'll read, and answer. END
BEGIN NOW Exit. END
BEGIN NOW Where was his son when they did take his eyes? END
BEGIN NOW Come with my lady hither. END
BEGIN NOW He is not here. END
BEGIN NOW No, my good lord; I met him back again. END
BEGIN NOW Knows he the wickedness? END
BEGIN NOW Ay, my good lord. END
BEGIN NOW 'Twas he inform'd against him, And quit the house on purpose, that their punishment Might have the freer course. END
BEGIN NOW Gloucester, I live To thank thee for the love thou show'dst the King, And to revenge thine eyes. END
BEGIN NOW Come hither, friend. END
BEGIN NOW Tell me what more thou know'st. END
BEGIN NOW Scene III. END
BEGIN NOW The French camp near Dover. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Kent and a Gentleman. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Why the King of France is so suddenly gone back know you the reason? END
BEGIN NOW Something he left imperfect in the state, which since his coming forth is thought of, which imports to the kingdom so much fear and danger that his personal return was most required and necessary. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Who hath he left behind him general? END
BEGIN NOW The Marshal of France, Monsieur La Far. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Did your letters pierce the Queen to any demonstration of grief? END
BEGIN NOW Ay, sir. END
BEGIN NOW She took them, read them in my presence, And now and then an ample tear trill'd down Her delicate cheek. END
BEGIN NOW It seem'd she was a queen Over her passion, who, most rebel-like, Sought to be king o'er her. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW O, then it mov'd her? END
BEGIN NOW Not to a rage. END
BEGIN NOW Patience and sorrow strove Who should express her goodliest. END
BEGIN NOW You have seen Sunshine and rain at once: her smiles and tears Were like, a better way. END
BEGIN NOW Those happy smilets That play'd on her ripe lip seem'd not to know What guests were in her eyes, which parted thence As pearls from diamonds dropp'd. END
BEGIN NOW In brief, Sorrow would be a rarity most belov'd, If all could so become it. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Made she no verbal question? END
BEGIN NOW Faith, once or twice she heav'd the name of father Pantingly forth, as if it press'd her heart; Cried 'Sisters, sisters! END
BEGIN NOW Shame of ladies! END
BEGIN NOW Sisters! END
BEGIN NOW Kent! END
BEGIN NOW father! END
BEGIN NOW sisters! END
BEGIN NOW What, i' th' storm? END
BEGIN NOW i' th' night? END
BEGIN NOW Let pity not be believ'd!' END
BEGIN NOW There she shook The holy water from her heavenly eyes, And clamour moisten'd. END
BEGIN NOW Then away she started To deal with grief alone. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW It is the stars, The stars above us, govern our conditions; Else one self mate and mate could not beget Such different issues. END
BEGIN NOW You spoke not with her since? END
BEGIN NOW No. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Was this before the King return'd? END
BEGIN NOW No, since. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Well, sir, the poor distressed Lear's i' th' town; Who sometime, in his better tune, remembers What we are come about, and by no means Will yield to see his daughter. END
BEGIN NOW Why, good sir? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW A sovereign shame so elbows him; his own unkindness, That stripp'd her from his benediction, turn'd her To foreign casualties, gave her dear rights To his dog-hearted daughters- these things sting His mind so venomously that burning shame Detains him from Cordelia. END
BEGIN NOW Alack, poor gentleman! END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Of Albany's and Cornwall's powers you heard not? END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis so; they are afoot. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Well, sir, I'll bring you to our master Lear And leave you to attend him. END
BEGIN NOW Some dear cause Will in concealment wrap me up awhile. END
BEGIN NOW When I am known aright, you shall not grieve Lending me this acquaintance. END
BEGIN NOW I pray you go Along with me. END
BEGIN NOW Scene IV. END
BEGIN NOW The French camp. END
BEGIN NOW Enter, with Drum and Colours, Cordelia, Doctor, and Soldiers. END
BEGIN NOW Alack, 'tis he! END
BEGIN NOW Why, he was met even now As mad as the vex'd sea, singing aloud, Crown'd with rank fumiter and furrow weeds, With hardocks, hemlock, nettles, cuckoo flow'rs, Darnel, and all the idle weeds that grow In our sustaining corn. END
BEGIN NOW A century send forth. END
BEGIN NOW Search every acre in the high-grown field And bring him to our eye. END
BEGIN NOW What can man's wisdom In the restoring his bereaved sense? END
BEGIN NOW He that helps him take all my outward worth. END
BEGIN NOW There is means, madam. END
BEGIN NOW Our foster nurse of nature is repose, The which he lacks. END
BEGIN NOW That to provoke in him Are many simples operative, whose power Will close the eye of anguish. END
BEGIN NOW All blest secrets, All you unpublish'd virtues of the earth, Spring with my tears! END
BEGIN NOW be aidant and remediate In the good man's distress! END
BEGIN NOW Seek, seek for him! END
BEGIN NOW Lest his ungovern'd rage dissolve the life That wants the means to lead it. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Messenger. END
BEGIN NOW Mess. END
BEGIN NOW News, madam. END
BEGIN NOW The British pow'rs are marching hitherward. END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis known before. END
BEGIN NOW Our preparation stands In expectation of them. END
BEGIN NOW O dear father, It is thy business that I go about. END
BEGIN NOW Therefore great France My mourning and important tears hath pitied. END
BEGIN NOW No blown ambition doth our arms incite, But love, dear love, and our ag'd father's right. END
BEGIN NOW Soon may I hear and see him! END
BEGIN NOW Scene V. Gloucester's Castle. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Regan and Steward. END
BEGIN NOW But are my brother's pow'rs set forth? END
BEGIN NOW Ay, madam. END
BEGIN NOW Himself in person there? END
BEGIN NOW Madam, with much ado. END
BEGIN NOW Your sister is the better soldier. END
BEGIN NOW Lord Edmund spake not with your lord at home? END
BEGIN NOW No, madam. END
BEGIN NOW What might import my sister's letter to him? END
BEGIN NOW I know not, lady. END
BEGIN NOW Faith, he is posted hence on serious matter. END
BEGIN NOW It was great ignorance, Gloucester's eyes being out, To let him live. END
BEGIN NOW Where he arrives he moves All hearts against us. END
BEGIN NOW Edmund, I think, is gone, In pity of his misery, to dispatch His nighted life; moreover, to descry The strength o' th' enemy. END
BEGIN NOW I must needs after him, madam, with my letter. END
BEGIN NOW Our troops set forth to-morrow. END
BEGIN NOW Stay with us. END
BEGIN NOW The ways are dangerous. END
BEGIN NOW I may not, madam. END
BEGIN NOW My lady charg'd my duty in this business. END
BEGIN NOW Why should she write to Edmund? END
BEGIN NOW Might not you Transport her purposes by word? END
BEGIN NOW Belike, Something- I know not what- I'll love thee much- Let me unseal the letter. END
BEGIN NOW Madam, I had rather- I know your lady does not love her husband; I am sure of that; and at her late being here She gave strange eliads and most speaking looks To noble Edmund. END
BEGIN NOW I know you are of her bosom. END
BEGIN NOW I, madam? END
BEGIN NOW I speak in understanding. END
BEGIN NOW Y'are! END
BEGIN NOW I know't. END
BEGIN NOW Therefore I do advise you take this note. END
BEGIN NOW My lord is dead; Edmund and I have talk'd, And more convenient is he for my hand Than for your lady's. END
BEGIN NOW You may gather more. END
BEGIN NOW If you do find him, pray you give him this; And when your mistress hears thus much from you, I pray desire her call her wisdom to her. END
BEGIN NOW So farewell. END
BEGIN NOW If you do chance to hear of that blind traitor, Preferment falls on him that cuts him off. END
BEGIN NOW Would I could meet him, madam! END
BEGIN NOW I should show What party I do follow. END
BEGIN NOW Fare thee well. END
BEGIN NOW Scene VI. END
BEGIN NOW The country near Dover. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Gloucester, and Edgar When shall I come to th' top of that same hill? END
BEGIN NOW You do climb up it now. END
BEGIN NOW Look how we labour. END
BEGIN NOW Methinks the ground is even. END
BEGIN NOW Horrible steep. END
BEGIN NOW Hark, do you hear the sea? END
BEGIN NOW No, truly. END
BEGIN NOW Why, then, your other senses grow imperfect By your eyes' anguish. END
BEGIN NOW So may it be indeed. END
BEGIN NOW Methinks thy voice is alter'd, and thou speak'st In better phrase and matter than thou didst. END
BEGIN NOW Y'are much deceiv'd. END
BEGIN NOW In nothing am I chang'd But in my garments. END
BEGIN NOW Methinks y'are better spoken. END
BEGIN NOW Come on, sir; here's the place. END
BEGIN NOW Stand still. END
BEGIN NOW How fearful And dizzy 'tis to cast one's eyes so low! END
BEGIN NOW The crows and choughs that wing the midway air Show scarce so gross as beetles. END
BEGIN NOW Halfway down Hangs one that gathers sampire- dreadful trade! END
BEGIN NOW Methinks he seems no bigger than his head. END
BEGIN NOW The fishermen that walk upon the beach Appear like mice; and yond tall anchoring bark, Diminish'd to her cock; her cock, a buoy Almost too small for sight. END
BEGIN NOW The murmuring surge That on th' unnumb'red idle pebble chafes Cannot be heard so high. END
BEGIN NOW I'll look no more, Lest my brain turn, and the deficient sight Topple down headlong. END
BEGIN NOW Set me where you stand. END
BEGIN NOW Give me your hand. END
BEGIN NOW You are now within a foot Of th' extreme verge. END
BEGIN NOW For all beneath the moon Would I not leap upright. END
BEGIN NOW Let go my hand. END
BEGIN NOW Here, friend, is another purse; in it a jewel Well worth a poor man's taking. END
BEGIN NOW Fairies and gods Prosper it with thee! END
BEGIN NOW Go thou further off; Bid me farewell, and let me hear thee going. END
BEGIN NOW Now fare ye well, good sir. END
BEGIN NOW With all my heart. END
BEGIN NOW Why I do trifle thus with his despair Is done to cure it. END
BEGIN NOW O you mighty gods! END
BEGIN NOW He kneels. END
BEGIN NOW This world I do renounce, and, in your sights, Shake patiently my great affliction off. END
BEGIN NOW If I could bear it longer and not fall To quarrel with your great opposeless wills, My snuff and loathed part of nature should Burn itself out. END
BEGIN NOW If Edgar live, O, bless him! END
BEGIN NOW Now, fellow, fare thee well. END
BEGIN NOW He falls Gone, sir, farewell.- And yet I know not how conceit may rob The treasury of life when life itself Yields to the theft. END
BEGIN NOW Had he been where he thought, By this had thought been past.- Alive or dead? END
BEGIN NOW Ho you, sir! END
BEGIN NOW friend! END
BEGIN NOW Hear you, sir? END
BEGIN NOW Speak!- Thus might he pass indeed. END
BEGIN NOW Yet he revives. END
BEGIN NOW What are you, sir? END
BEGIN NOW Away, and let me die. END
BEGIN NOW Hadst thou been aught but gossamer, feathers, air, So many fadom down precipitating, Thou'dst shiver'd like an egg; but thou dost breathe; Hast heavy substance; bleed'st not; speak'st; art sound. END
BEGIN NOW Ten masts at each make not the altitude Which thou hast perpendicularly fell. END
BEGIN NOW Thy life is a miracle. END
BEGIN NOW Speak yet again. END
BEGIN NOW But have I fall'n, or no? END
BEGIN NOW From the dread summit of this chalky bourn. END
BEGIN NOW Look up a-height. END
BEGIN NOW The shrill-gorg'd lark so far Cannot be seen or heard. END
BEGIN NOW Do but look up. END
BEGIN NOW Alack, I have no eyes! END
BEGIN NOW Is wretchedness depriv'd that benefit To end itself by death? END
BEGIN NOW 'Twas yet some comfort When misery could beguile the tyrant's rage And frustrate his proud will. END
BEGIN NOW Give me your arm. END
BEGIN NOW Up- so. END
BEGIN NOW How is't? END
BEGIN NOW Feel you your legs? END
BEGIN NOW You stand. END
BEGIN NOW Too well, too well. END
BEGIN NOW This is above all strangeness. END
BEGIN NOW Upon the crown o' th' cliff what thing was that Which parted from you? END
BEGIN NOW A poor unfortunate beggar. END
BEGIN NOW As I stood here below, methought his eyes Were two full moons; he had a thousand noses, Horns whelk'd and wav'd like the enridged sea. END
BEGIN NOW It was some fiend. END
BEGIN NOW Therefore, thou happy father, Think that the clearest gods, who make them honours Of men's impossibility, have preserv'd thee. END
BEGIN NOW I do remember now. END
BEGIN NOW Henceforth I'll bear Affliction till it do cry out itself 'Enough, enough,' and die. END
BEGIN NOW That thing you speak of, I took it for a man. END
BEGIN NOW Often 'twould say 'The fiend, the fiend'- he led me to that place. END
BEGIN NOW Bear free and patient thoughts. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Lear, mad, But who comes here? END
BEGIN NOW The safer sense will ne'er accommodate His master thus. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW No, they cannot touch me for coming; I am the King himself. END
BEGIN NOW O thou side-piercing sight! END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Nature 's above art in that respect. END
BEGIN NOW There's your press money. END
BEGIN NOW That fellow handles his bow like a crow-keeper. END
BEGIN NOW Draw me a clothier's yard. END
BEGIN NOW Look, look, a mouse! END
BEGIN NOW Peace, peace; this piece of toasted cheese will do't. END
BEGIN NOW There's my gauntlet; I'll prove it on a giant. END
BEGIN NOW Bring up the brown bills. END
BEGIN NOW O, well flown, bird! END
BEGIN NOW i' th' clout, i' th' clout! END
BEGIN NOW Hewgh! END
BEGIN NOW Give the word. END
BEGIN NOW Sweet marjoram. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Pass. END
BEGIN NOW I know that voice. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Ha! END
BEGIN NOW Goneril with a white beard? END
BEGIN NOW They flatter'd me like a dog, and told me I had white hairs in my beard ere the black ones were there. END
BEGIN NOW To say 'ay' and 'no' to everything I said! END
BEGIN NOW 'Ay' and 'no' too was no good divinity. END
BEGIN NOW When the rain came to wet me once, and the wind to make me chatter; when the thunder would not peace at my bidding; there I found 'em, there I smelt 'em out. END
BEGIN NOW Go to, they are not men o' their words! END
BEGIN NOW They told me I was everything. END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis a lie- I am not ague-proof. END
BEGIN NOW The trick of that voice I do well remember. END
BEGIN NOW Is't not the King? END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Ay, every inch a king! END
BEGIN NOW When I do stare, see how the subject quakes. END
BEGIN NOW I pardon that man's life. END
BEGIN NOW What was thy cause? END
BEGIN NOW Adultery? END
BEGIN NOW Thou shalt not die. END
BEGIN NOW Die for adultery? END
BEGIN NOW No. END
BEGIN NOW The wren goes to't, and the small gilded fly Does lecher in my sight. END
BEGIN NOW Let copulation thrive; for Gloucester's bastard son Was kinder to his father than my daughters Got 'tween the lawful sheets. END
BEGIN NOW To't, luxury, pell-mell! END
BEGIN NOW for I lack soldiers. END
BEGIN NOW Behold yond simp'ring dame, Whose face between her forks presageth snow, That minces virtue, and does shake the head To hear of pleasure's name. END
BEGIN NOW The fitchew nor the soiled horse goes to't With a more riotous appetite. END
BEGIN NOW Down from the waist they are Centaurs, Though women all above. END
BEGIN NOW But to the girdle do the gods inherit, Beneath is all the fiend's. END
BEGIN NOW There's hell, there's darkness, there's the sulphurous pit; burning, scalding, stench, consumption. END
BEGIN NOW Fie, fie, fie! END
BEGIN NOW pah, pah! END
BEGIN NOW Give me an ounce of civet, good apothecary, to sweeten my imagination. END
BEGIN NOW There's money for thee. END
BEGIN NOW O, let me kiss that hand! END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Let me wipe it first; it smells of mortality. END
BEGIN NOW O ruin'd piece of nature! END
BEGIN NOW This great world Shall so wear out to naught. END
BEGIN NOW Dost thou know me? END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW I remember thine eyes well enough. END
BEGIN NOW Dost thou squiny at me? END
BEGIN NOW No, do thy worst, blind Cupid! END
BEGIN NOW I'll not love. END
BEGIN NOW Read thou this challenge; mark but the penning of it. END
BEGIN NOW Were all the letters suns, I could not see one. END
BEGIN NOW I would not take this from report. END
BEGIN NOW It is, And my heart breaks at it. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Read. END
BEGIN NOW What, with the case of eyes? END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW O, ho, are you there with me? END
BEGIN NOW No eyes in your head, nor no money in your purse? END
BEGIN NOW Your eyes are in a heavy case, your purse in a light. END
BEGIN NOW Yet you see how this world goes. END
BEGIN NOW I see it feelingly. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW What, art mad? END
BEGIN NOW A man may see how the world goes with no eyes. END
BEGIN NOW Look with thine ears. END
BEGIN NOW See how yond justice rails upon yond simple thief. END
BEGIN NOW Hark in thine ear. END
BEGIN NOW Change places and, handy-dandy, which is the justice, which is the thief? END
BEGIN NOW Thou hast seen a farmer's dog bark at a beggar? END
BEGIN NOW Ay, sir. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW And the creature run from the cur? END
BEGIN NOW There thou mightst behold the great image of authority: a dog's obeyed in office. END
BEGIN NOW Thou rascal beadle, hold thy bloody hand! END
BEGIN NOW Why dost thou lash that whore? END
BEGIN NOW Strip thine own back. END
BEGIN NOW Thou hotly lusts to use her in that kind For which thou whip'st her. END
BEGIN NOW The usurer hangs the cozener. END
BEGIN NOW Through tatter'd clothes small vices do appear; Robes and furr'd gowns hide all. END
BEGIN NOW Plate sin with gold, And the strong lance of justice hurtless breaks; Arm it in rags, a pygmy's straw does pierce it. END
BEGIN NOW None does offend, none- I say none! END
BEGIN NOW I'll able 'em. END
BEGIN NOW Take that of me, my friend, who have the power To seal th' accuser's lips. END
BEGIN NOW Get thee glass eyes And, like a scurvy politician, seem To see the things thou dost not. END
BEGIN NOW Now, now, now, now! END
BEGIN NOW Pull off my boots. END
BEGIN NOW Harder, harder! END
BEGIN NOW So. END
BEGIN NOW O, matter and impertinency mix'd! END
BEGIN NOW Reason, in madness! END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW If thou wilt weep my fortunes, take my eyes. END
BEGIN NOW I know thee well enough; thy name is Gloucester. END
BEGIN NOW Thou must be patient. END
BEGIN NOW We came crying hither; Thou know'st, the first time that we smell the air We wawl and cry. END
BEGIN NOW I will preach to thee. END
BEGIN NOW Mark. END
BEGIN NOW Alack, alack the day! END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW When we are born, we cry that we are come To this great stage of fools. END
BEGIN NOW This' a good block. END
BEGIN NOW It were a delicate stratagem to shoe A troop of horse with felt. END
BEGIN NOW I'll put't in proof, And when I have stol'n upon these sons-in-law, Then kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill! END
BEGIN NOW Enter a Gentleman O, here he is! END
BEGIN NOW Lay hand upon him.- Sir, Your most dear daughter- Lear. END
BEGIN NOW No rescue? END
BEGIN NOW What, a prisoner? END
BEGIN NOW I am even The natural fool of fortune. END
BEGIN NOW Use me well; You shall have ransom. END
BEGIN NOW Let me have a surgeon; I am cut to th' brains. END
BEGIN NOW You shall have anything. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW No seconds? END
BEGIN NOW All myself? END
BEGIN NOW Why, this would make a man a man of salt, To use his eyes for garden waterpots, Ay, and laying autumn's dust. END
BEGIN NOW Good sir- Lear. END
BEGIN NOW I will die bravely, like a smug bridegroom. END
BEGIN NOW What! END
BEGIN NOW I will be jovial. END
BEGIN NOW Come, come, I am a king; My masters, know you that? END
BEGIN NOW You are a royal one, and we obey you. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Then there's life in't. END
BEGIN NOW Nay, an you get it, you shall get it by running. END
BEGIN NOW Sa, sa, sa, sa! END
BEGIN NOW Exit running. END
BEGIN NOW A sight most pitiful in the meanest wretch, Past speaking of in a king! END
BEGIN NOW Thou hast one daughter Who redeems nature from the general curse Which twain have brought her to. END
BEGIN NOW Hail, gentle sir. END
BEGIN NOW Sir, speed you. END
BEGIN NOW What's your will? END
BEGIN NOW Do you hear aught, sir, of a battle toward? END
BEGIN NOW Most sure and vulgar. END
BEGIN NOW Every one hears that Which can distinguish sound. END
BEGIN NOW But, by your favour, How near's the other army? END
BEGIN NOW Near and on speedy foot. END
BEGIN NOW The main descry Stands on the hourly thought. END
BEGIN NOW I thank you sir. END
BEGIN NOW That's all. END
BEGIN NOW Though that the Queen on special cause is here, Her army is mov'd on. END
BEGIN NOW I thank you, sir Exit You ever-gentle gods, take my breath from me; Let not my worser spirit tempt me again To die before you please! END
BEGIN NOW Well pray you, father. END
BEGIN NOW Now, good sir, what are you? END
BEGIN NOW A most poor man, made tame to fortune's blows, Who, by the art of known and feeling sorrows, Am pregnant to good pity. END
BEGIN NOW Give me your hand; I'll lead you to some biding. END
BEGIN NOW Hearty thanks. END
BEGIN NOW The bounty and the benison of heaven To boot, and boot! END
BEGIN NOW Enter Steward. END
BEGIN NOW A proclaim'd prize! END
BEGIN NOW Most happy! END
BEGIN NOW That eyeless head of thine was first fram'd flesh To raise my fortunes. END
BEGIN NOW Thou old unhappy traitor, Briefly thyself remember. END
BEGIN NOW The sword is out That must destroy thee. END
BEGIN NOW Now let thy friendly hand Put strength enough to't. END
BEGIN NOW Wherefore, bold peasant, Dar'st thou support a publish'd traitor? END
BEGIN NOW Hence! END
BEGIN NOW Lest that th' infection of his fortune take Like hold on thee. END
BEGIN NOW Let go his arm. END
BEGIN NOW Chill not let go, zir, without vurther 'cagion. END
BEGIN NOW Let go, slave, or thou diest! END
BEGIN NOW Good gentleman, go your gait, and let poor voke pass. END
BEGIN NOW An chud ha' bin zwagger'd out of my life, 'twould not ha' bin zo long as 'tis by a vortnight. END
BEGIN NOW Nay, come not near th' old man. END
BEGIN NOW Keep out, che vore ye, or Ise try whether your costard or my ballow be the harder. END
BEGIN NOW Chill be plain with you. END
BEGIN NOW Out, dunghill! END
BEGIN NOW They fight. END
BEGIN NOW Chill pick your teeth, zir. END
BEGIN NOW Come! END
