BEGIN NOW No matter vor your foins. END
BEGIN NOW Slave, thou hast slain me. END
BEGIN NOW Villain, take my purse. END
BEGIN NOW If ever thou wilt thrive, bury my body, And give the letters which thou find'st about me To Edmund Earl of Gloucester. END
BEGIN NOW Seek him out Upon the British party. END
BEGIN NOW O, untimely death! END
BEGIN NOW Death! END
BEGIN NOW He dies. END
BEGIN NOW I know thee well. END
BEGIN NOW A serviceable villain, As duteous to the vices of thy mistress As badness would desire. END
BEGIN NOW What, is he dead? END
BEGIN NOW Sit you down, father; rest you. END
BEGIN NOW Let's see his pockets; these letters that he speaks of May be my friends. END
BEGIN NOW He's dead. END
BEGIN NOW I am only sorry He had no other deathsman. END
BEGIN NOW Let us see. END
BEGIN NOW Leave, gentle wax; and, manners, blame us not. END
BEGIN NOW To know our enemies' minds, we'ld rip their hearts; Their papers, is more lawful. END
BEGIN NOW Reads the letter. END
BEGIN NOW 'Let our reciprocal vows be rememb'red. END
BEGIN NOW You have many opportunities to cut him off. END
BEGIN NOW If your will want not, time and place will be fruitfully offer'd. END
BEGIN NOW There is nothing done, if he return the conqueror. END
BEGIN NOW Then am I the prisoner, and his bed my jail; from the loathed warmth whereof deliver me, and supply the place for your labour. END
BEGIN NOW 'Your (wife, so I would say) affectionate servant, ' ' O indistinguish'd space of woman's will! END
BEGIN NOW A plot upon her virtuous husband's life, And the exchange my brother! END
BEGIN NOW Here in the sands Thee I'll rake up, the post unsanctified Of murtherous lechers; and in the mature time With this ungracious paper strike the sight Of the death-practis'd Duke, For him 'tis well That of thy death and business I can tell. END
BEGIN NOW The King is mad. END
BEGIN NOW How stiff is my vile sense, That I stand up, and have ingenious feeling Of my huge sorrows! END
BEGIN NOW Better I were distract. END
BEGIN NOW So should my thoughts be sever'd from my griefs, And woes by wrong imaginations lose The knowledge of themselves. END
BEGIN NOW A drum afar off. END
BEGIN NOW Give me your hand. END
BEGIN NOW Far off methinks I hear the beaten drum. END
BEGIN NOW Come, father, I'll bestow you with a friend. END
BEGIN NOW Scene VII. END
BEGIN NOW A tent in the French camp. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Cordelia, Kent, Doctor, and Gentleman. END
BEGIN NOW O thou good Kent, how shall I live and work To match thy goodness? END
BEGIN NOW My life will be too short And every measure fail me. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW To be acknowledg'd, madam, is o'erpaid. END
BEGIN NOW All my reports go with the modest truth; Nor more nor clipp'd, but so. END
BEGIN NOW Be better suited. END
BEGIN NOW These weeds are memories of those worser hours. END
BEGIN NOW I prithee put them off. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Pardon, dear madam. END
BEGIN NOW Yet to be known shortens my made intent. END
BEGIN NOW My boon I make it that you know me not Till time and I think meet. END
BEGIN NOW Then be't so, my good lord. END
BEGIN NOW How, does the King? END
BEGIN NOW Madam, sleeps still. END
BEGIN NOW O you kind gods, Cure this great breach in his abused nature! END
BEGIN NOW Th' untun'd and jarring senses, O, wind up Of this child-changed father! END
BEGIN NOW So please your Majesty That we may wake the King? END
BEGIN NOW He hath slept long. END
BEGIN NOW Be govern'd by your knowledge, and proceed I' th' sway of your own will. END
BEGIN NOW Is he array'd? END
BEGIN NOW Enter Lear in a chair carried by Servants. END
BEGIN NOW Ay, madam. END
BEGIN NOW In the heaviness of sleep We put fresh garments on him. END
BEGIN NOW Be by, good madam, when we do awake him. END
BEGIN NOW I doubt not of his temperance. END
BEGIN NOW Very well. END
BEGIN NOW Music. END
BEGIN NOW Please you draw near. END
BEGIN NOW Louder the music there! END
BEGIN NOW O my dear father, restoration hang Thy medicine on my lips, and let this kiss Repair those violent harms that my two sisters Have in thy reverence made! END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Kind and dear princess! END
BEGIN NOW Had you not been their father, these white flakes Had challeng'd pity of them. END
BEGIN NOW Was this a face To be oppos'd against the warring winds? END
BEGIN NOW To stand against the deep dread-bolted thunder? END
BEGIN NOW In the most terrible and nimble stroke Of quick cross lightning? END
BEGIN NOW to watch- poor perdu!- With this thin helm? END
BEGIN NOW Mine enemy's dog, Though he had bit me, should have stood that night Against my fire; and wast thou fain, poor father, To hovel thee with swine and rogues forlorn, In short and musty straw? END
BEGIN NOW Alack, alack! END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis wonder that thy life and wits at once Had not concluded all.- He wakes. END
BEGIN NOW Speak to him. END
BEGIN NOW Madam, do you; 'tis fittest. END
BEGIN NOW How does my royal lord? END
BEGIN NOW How fares your Majesty? END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW You do me wrong to take me out o' th' grave. END
BEGIN NOW Thou art a soul in bliss; but I am bound Upon a wheel of fire, that mine own tears Do scald like molten lead. END
BEGIN NOW Sir, do you know me? END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW You are a spirit, I know. END
BEGIN NOW When did you die? END
BEGIN NOW Still, still, far wide! END
BEGIN NOW He's scarce awake. END
BEGIN NOW Let him alone awhile. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Where have I been? END
BEGIN NOW Where am I? END
BEGIN NOW Fair daylight, I am mightily abus'd. END
BEGIN NOW I should e'en die with pity, To see another thus. END
BEGIN NOW I know not what to say. END
BEGIN NOW I will not swear these are my hands. END
BEGIN NOW Let's see. END
BEGIN NOW I feel this pin prick. END
BEGIN NOW Would I were assur'd Of my condition! END
BEGIN NOW O, look upon me, sir, And hold your hands in benediction o'er me. END
BEGIN NOW No, sir, you must not kneel. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Pray, do not mock me. END
BEGIN NOW I am a very foolish fond old man, Fourscore and upward, not an hour more nor less; And, to deal plainly, I fear I am not in my perfect mind. END
BEGIN NOW Methinks I should know you, and know this man; Yet I am doubtful; for I am mainly ignorant What place this is; and all the skill I have Remembers not these garments; nor I know not Where I did lodge last night. END
BEGIN NOW Do not laugh at me; For (as I am a man) I think this lady To be my child Cordelia. END
BEGIN NOW And so I am! END
BEGIN NOW I am! END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Be your tears wet? END
BEGIN NOW Yes, faith. END
BEGIN NOW I pray weep not. END
BEGIN NOW If you have poison for me, I will drink it. END
BEGIN NOW I know you do not love me; for your sisters Have, as I do remember, done me wrong. END
BEGIN NOW You have some cause, they have not. END
BEGIN NOW No cause, no cause. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Am I in France? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW In your own kingdom, sir. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Do not abuse me. END
BEGIN NOW Be comforted, good madam. END
BEGIN NOW The great rage You see is kill'd in him; and yet it is danger To make him even o'er the time he has lost. END
BEGIN NOW Desire him to go in. END
BEGIN NOW Trouble him no more Till further settling. END
BEGIN NOW Will't please your Highness walk? END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW You must bear with me. END
BEGIN NOW Pray you now, forget and forgive. END
BEGIN NOW I am old and foolish. END
BEGIN NOW Manent Kent and Gentleman. END
BEGIN NOW Holds it true, sir, that the Duke of Cornwall was so slain? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Most certain, sir. END
BEGIN NOW Who is conductor of his people? END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW As 'tis said, the bastard son of Gloucester. END
BEGIN NOW They say Edgar, his banish'd son, is with the Earl of Kent in Germany. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Report is changeable. END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis time to look about; the powers of the kingdom approach apace. END
BEGIN NOW The arbitrement is like to be bloody. END
BEGIN NOW Fare you well, sir. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END
BEGIN NOW My point and period will be throughly wrought, Or well or ill, as this day's battle's fought. END
BEGIN NOW Exit. END
BEGIN NOW ACT V. Scene I. END
BEGIN NOW The British camp near Dover. END
BEGIN NOW Enter, with Drum and Colours, Edmund, Regan, Gentleman, and Soldiers. END
BEGIN NOW Know of the Duke if his last purpose hold, Or whether since he is advis'd by aught To change the course. END
BEGIN NOW He's full of alteration And self-reproving. END
BEGIN NOW Bring his constant pleasure. END
BEGIN NOW Our sister's man is certainly miscarried. END
BEGIN NOW Tis to be doubted, madam. END
BEGIN NOW Now, sweet lord, You know the goodness I intend upon you. END
BEGIN NOW Tell me- but truly- but then speak the truth- Do you not love my sister? END
BEGIN NOW In honour'd love. END
BEGIN NOW But have you never found my brother's way To the forfended place? END
BEGIN NOW That thought abuses you. END
BEGIN NOW I am doubtful that you have been conjunct And bosom'd with her, as far as we call hers. END
BEGIN NOW No, by mine honour, madam. END
BEGIN NOW I never shall endure her. END
BEGIN NOW Dear my lord, Be not familiar with her. END
BEGIN NOW Fear me not. END
BEGIN NOW She and the Duke her husband! END
BEGIN NOW Enter, with Drum and Colours, Albany, I had rather lose the battle than that sister Should loosen him and me. END
BEGIN NOW Our very loving sister, well bemet. END
BEGIN NOW Sir, this I hear: the King is come to his daughter, With others whom the rigour of our state Forc'd to cry out. END
BEGIN NOW Where I could not be honest, I never yet was valiant. END
BEGIN NOW For this business, It toucheth us as France invades our land, Not bolds the King, with others whom, I fear, Most just and heavy causes make oppose. END
BEGIN NOW Sir, you speak nobly. END
BEGIN NOW Why is this reason'd? END
BEGIN NOW Combine together 'gainst the enemy; For these domestic and particular broils Are not the question here. END
BEGIN NOW Let's then determine With th' ancient of war on our proceeding. END
BEGIN NOW I shall attend you presently at your tent. END
BEGIN NOW Sister, you'll go with us? END
BEGIN NOW No. END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis most convenient. END
BEGIN NOW Pray you go with us. END
BEGIN NOW O, ho, I know the riddle.- I will go. END
BEGIN NOW If e'er your Grace had speech with man so poor, Hear me one word. END
BEGIN NOW I'll overtake you.- Speak. END
BEGIN NOW Exeunt Before you fight the battle, ope this letter. END
BEGIN NOW If you have victory, let the trumpet sound For him that brought it. END
BEGIN NOW Wretched though I seem, I can produce a champion that will prove What is avouched there. END
BEGIN NOW If you miscarry, Your business of the world hath so an end, And machination ceases. END
BEGIN NOW Fortune love you! END
BEGIN NOW Stay till I have read the letter. END
BEGIN NOW I was forbid it. END
BEGIN NOW When time shall serve, let but the herald cry, And I'll appear again. END
BEGIN NOW Why, fare thee well. END
BEGIN NOW I will o'erlook thy paper. END
BEGIN NOW Exit Enter Edmund. END
BEGIN NOW The enemy 's in view; draw up your powers. END
BEGIN NOW Here is the guess of their true strength and forces By diligent discovery; but your haste Is now urg'd on you. END
BEGIN NOW We will greet the time. END
BEGIN NOW Exit. END
BEGIN NOW To both these sisters have I sworn my love; Each jealous of the other, as the stung Are of the adder. END
BEGIN NOW Which of them shall I take? END
BEGIN NOW Both? END
BEGIN NOW one? END
BEGIN NOW or neither? END
BEGIN NOW Neither can be enjoy'd, If both remain alive. END
BEGIN NOW To take the widow Exasperates, makes mad her sister Goneril; And hardly shall I carry out my side, Her husband being alive. END
BEGIN NOW Now then, we'll use His countenance for the battle, which being done, Let her who would be rid of him devise His speedy taking off. END
BEGIN NOW As for the mercy Which he intends to Lear and to Cordelia- The battle done, and they within our power, Shall never see his pardon; for my state Stands on me to defend, not to debate. END
BEGIN NOW Exit. END
BEGIN NOW Scene II. END
BEGIN NOW A field between the two camps. END
BEGIN NOW Alarum within. END
BEGIN NOW Enter, with Drum and Colours, the Powers of France over the stage, Cordelia with her Father in her hand, and exeunt. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Edgar and Gloucester. END
BEGIN NOW Here, father, take the shadow of this tree For your good host. END
BEGIN NOW Pray that the right may thrive. END
BEGIN NOW If ever I return to you again, I'll bring you comfort. END
BEGIN NOW Grace go with you, sir! END
BEGIN NOW Exit Alarum and retreat within. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Edgar, Away, old man! END
BEGIN NOW give me thy hand! END
BEGIN NOW away! END
BEGIN NOW King Lear hath lost, he and his daughter ta'en. END
BEGIN NOW Give me thy hand! END
BEGIN NOW come on! END
BEGIN NOW No further, sir. END
BEGIN NOW A man may rot even here. END
BEGIN NOW What, in ill thoughts again? END
BEGIN NOW Men must endure Their going hence, even as their coming hither; Ripeness is all. END
BEGIN NOW Come on. END
BEGIN NOW And that's true too. END
BEGIN NOW Scene III. END
BEGIN NOW The British camp, near Dover. END
BEGIN NOW Enter, in conquest, with Drum and Colours, Edmund; Lear and Cordelia as prisoners; Soldiers, Captain. END
BEGIN NOW Some officers take them away. END
BEGIN NOW Good guard Until their greater pleasures first be known That are to censure them. END
BEGIN NOW We are not the first Who with best meaning have incurr'd the worst. END
BEGIN NOW For thee, oppressed king, am I cast down; Myself could else outfrown false Fortune's frown. END
BEGIN NOW Shall we not see these daughters and these sisters? END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW No, no, no, no! END
BEGIN NOW Come, let's away to prison. END
BEGIN NOW We two alone will sing like birds i' th' cage. END
BEGIN NOW When thou dost ask me blessing, I'll kneel down And ask of thee forgiveness. END
BEGIN NOW So we'll live, And pray, and sing, and tell old tales, and laugh At gilded butterflies, and hear poor rogues Talk of court news; and we'll talk with them too- Who loses and who wins; who's in, who's out- And take upon 's the mystery of things, As if we were God's spies; and we'll wear out, In a wall'd prison, packs and sects of great ones That ebb and flow by th' moon. END
BEGIN NOW Take them away. END
BEGIN NOW Lear. END
BEGIN NOW Upon such sacrifices, my Cordelia, The gods themselves throw incense. END
BEGIN NOW Have I caught thee? END
BEGIN NOW He that parts us shall bring a brand from heaven And fire us hence like foxes. END
BEGIN NOW Wipe thine eyes. END
BEGIN NOW The goodyears shall devour 'em, flesh and fell, Ere they shall make us weep! END
BEGIN NOW We'll see 'em starv'd first. END
BEGIN NOW Come. END
BEGIN NOW Exeunt Come hither, Captain; hark. END
BEGIN NOW Take thou this note Go follow them to prison. END
BEGIN NOW One step I have advanc'd thee. END
BEGIN NOW If thou dost As this instructs thee, thou dost make thy way To noble fortunes. END
BEGIN NOW Know thou this, that men Are as the time is. END
BEGIN NOW To be tender-minded Does not become a sword. END
BEGIN NOW Thy great employment Will not bear question. END
BEGIN NOW Either say thou'lt do't, Or thrive by other means. END
BEGIN NOW I'll do't, my lord. END
BEGIN NOW About it! END
BEGIN NOW and write happy when th' hast done. END
BEGIN NOW Mark- I say, instantly; and carry it so As I have set it down. END
BEGIN NOW I cannot draw a cart, nor eat dried oats; If it be man's work, I'll do't. END
BEGIN NOW Exit. END
BEGIN NOW Flourish. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Albany, Sir, you have show'd to-day your valiant strain, And fortune led you well. END
BEGIN NOW You have the captives Who were the opposites of this day's strife. END
BEGIN NOW We do require them of you, so to use them As we shall find their merits and our safety May equally determine. END
BEGIN NOW Sir, I thought it fit To send the old and miserable King To some retention and appointed guard; Whose age has charms in it, whose title more, To pluck the common bosom on his side And turn our impress'd lances in our eyes Which do command them. END
BEGIN NOW With him I sent the Queen, My reason all the same; and they are ready To-morrow, or at further space, t' appear Where you shall hold your session. END
BEGIN NOW At this time We sweat and bleed: the friend hath lost his friend; And the best quarrels, in the heat, are curs'd By those that feel their sharpness. END
BEGIN NOW The question of Cordelia and her father Requires a fitter place. END
BEGIN NOW Sir, by your patience, I hold you but a subject of this war, Not as a brother. END
BEGIN NOW That's as we list to grace him. END
BEGIN NOW Methinks our pleasure might have been demanded Ere you had spoke so far. END
BEGIN NOW He led our powers, Bore the commission of my place and person, The which immediacy may well stand up And call itself your brother. END
BEGIN NOW Not so hot! END
BEGIN NOW In his own grace he doth exalt himself More than in your addition. END
BEGIN NOW In my rights By me invested, he compeers the best. END
BEGIN NOW That were the most if he should husband you. END
BEGIN NOW Jesters do oft prove prophets. END
BEGIN NOW Holla, holla! END
BEGIN NOW That eye that told you so look'd but asquint. END
BEGIN NOW Lady, I am not well; else I should answer From a full-flowing stomach. END
BEGIN NOW General, Take thou my soldiers, prisoners, patrimony; Dispose of them, of me; the walls are thine. END
BEGIN NOW Witness the world that I create thee here My lord and master. END
BEGIN NOW Mean you to enjoy him? END
BEGIN NOW The let-alone lies not in your good will. END
BEGIN NOW Nor in thine, lord. END
BEGIN NOW Half-blooded fellow, yes. END
BEGIN NOW Let the drum strike, and prove my title thine. END
BEGIN NOW Stay yet; hear reason. END
BEGIN NOW Edmund, I arrest thee On capital treason; and, in thine attaint, This gilded serpent [points to For your claim, fair sister, I bar it in the interest of my wife. END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis she is subcontracted to this lord, And I, her husband, contradict your banes. END
BEGIN NOW If you will marry, make your loves to me; My lady is bespoke. END
BEGIN NOW An interlude! END
BEGIN NOW Thou art arm'd, Gloucester. END
BEGIN NOW Let the trumpet sound. END
BEGIN NOW If none appear to prove upon thy person Thy heinous, manifest, and many treasons, There is my pledge ! END
BEGIN NOW I'll prove it on thy heart, Ere I taste bread, thou art in nothing less Than I have here proclaim'd thee. END
BEGIN NOW Sick, O, sick! END
BEGIN NOW What in the world he is That names me traitor, villain-like he lies. END
BEGIN NOW Call by thy trumpet. END
BEGIN NOW He that dares approach, On him, on you, who not? END
BEGIN NOW I will maintain My truth and honour firmly. END
BEGIN NOW A herald, ho! END
BEGIN NOW A herald, ho, a herald! END
BEGIN NOW Trust to thy single virtue; for thy soldiers, All levied in my name, have in my name Took their discharge. END
BEGIN NOW My sickness grows upon me. END
BEGIN NOW She is not well. END
BEGIN NOW Convey her to my tent. END
BEGIN NOW Enter a Herald. END
BEGIN NOW Come hither, herald. END
BEGIN NOW Let the trumpet sound, And read out this. END
BEGIN NOW Sound, trumpet! END
BEGIN NOW A trumpet sounds. END
BEGIN NOW (reads) 'If any man of quality or degree within the lists of the army will maintain upon Edmund, supposed Earl of Gloucester, that he is a manifold traitor, let him appear by the third sound of the trumpet. END
BEGIN NOW He is bold in his defence.' END
BEGIN NOW Sound! END
BEGIN NOW First trumpet. END
BEGIN NOW Again! END
BEGIN NOW Second trumpet. END
BEGIN NOW Again! END
BEGIN NOW Third trumpet. END
BEGIN NOW Trumpet answers within. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Edgar, armed, at the third sound, a Trumpet before him. END
BEGIN NOW Ask him his purposes, why he appears Upon this call o' th' trumpet. END
BEGIN NOW What are you? END
BEGIN NOW Your name, your quality? END
BEGIN NOW and why you answer This present summons? END
BEGIN NOW Know my name is lost; By treason's tooth bare-gnawn and canker-bit. END
BEGIN NOW Yet am I noble as the adversary I come to cope. END
BEGIN NOW Which is that adversary? END
BEGIN NOW What's he that speaks for Edmund Earl of Gloucester? END
BEGIN NOW Himself. END
BEGIN NOW What say'st thou to him? END
BEGIN NOW Draw thy sword, That, if my speech offend a noble heart, Thy arm may do thee justice. END
BEGIN NOW Here is mine. END
BEGIN NOW Behold, it is the privilege of mine honours, My oath, and my profession. END
BEGIN NOW I protest- Maugre thy strength, youth, place, and eminence, Despite thy victor sword and fire-new fortune, Thy valour and thy heart- thou art a traitor; False to thy gods, thy brother, and thy father; Conspirant 'gainst this high illustrious prince; And from th' extremest upward of thy head To the descent and dust beneath thy foot, A most toad-spotted traitor. END
BEGIN NOW Say thou 'no,' This sword, this arm, and my best spirits are bent To prove upon thy heart, whereto I speak, Thou liest. END
BEGIN NOW In wisdom I should ask thy name; But since thy outside looks so fair and warlike, And that thy tongue some say of breeding breathes, What safe and nicely I might well delay By rule of knighthood, I disdain and spurn. END
BEGIN NOW Back do I toss those treasons to thy head; With the hell-hated lie o'erwhelm thy heart; Which- for they yet glance by and scarcely bruise- This sword of mine shall give them instant way Where they shall rest for ever. END
BEGIN NOW Trumpets, speak! END
BEGIN NOW Alarums. END
BEGIN NOW Fight. END
BEGIN NOW Save him, save him! END
BEGIN NOW This is mere practice, Gloucester. END
BEGIN NOW By th' law of arms thou wast not bound to answer An unknown opposite. END
BEGIN NOW Thou art not vanquish'd, But cozen'd and beguil'd. END
BEGIN NOW Shut your mouth, dame, Or with this paper shall I stop it. END
BEGIN NOW Hold, sir. END
BEGIN NOW [To No tearing, lady! END
BEGIN NOW I perceive you know it. END
BEGIN NOW Say if I do- the laws are mine, not thine. END
BEGIN NOW Who can arraign me for't? END
BEGIN NOW Most monstrous! END
BEGIN NOW Know'st thou this paper? END
BEGIN NOW Ask me not what I know. END
BEGIN NOW Exit. END
BEGIN NOW Go after her. END
BEGIN NOW She's desperate; govern her. END
BEGIN NOW What, you have charg'd me with, that have I done, And more, much more. END
BEGIN NOW The time will bring it out. END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis past, and so am I.- But what art thou That hast this fortune on me? END
BEGIN NOW If thou'rt noble, I do forgive thee. END
BEGIN NOW Let's exchange charity. END
BEGIN NOW I am no less in blood than thou art, Edmund; If more, the more th' hast wrong'd me. END
BEGIN NOW My name is Edgar and thy father's son. END
BEGIN NOW The gods are just, and of our pleasant vices Make instruments to scourge us. END
BEGIN NOW The dark and vicious place where thee he got Cost him his eyes. END
BEGIN NOW Th' hast spoken right; 'tis true. END
BEGIN NOW The wheel is come full circle; I am here. END
BEGIN NOW Methought thy very gait did prophesy A royal nobleness. END
BEGIN NOW I must embrace thee. END
BEGIN NOW Let sorrow split my heart if ever I Did hate thee, or thy father! END
BEGIN NOW Worthy prince, I know't. END
BEGIN NOW Where have you hid yourself? END
BEGIN NOW How have you known the miseries of your father? END
BEGIN NOW By nursing them, my lord. END
BEGIN NOW List a brief tale; And when 'tis told, O that my heart would burst! END
BEGIN NOW The bloody proclamation to escape That follow'd me so near (O, our lives' sweetness! END
BEGIN NOW That with the pain of death would hourly die Rather than die at once!) END
BEGIN NOW taught me to shift Into a madman's rags, t' assume a semblance That very dogs disdain'd; and in this habit Met I my father with his bleeding rings, Their precious stones new lost; became his guide, Led him, begg'd for him, sav'd him from despair; Never (O fault!) END
BEGIN NOW reveal'd myself unto him Until some half hour past, when I was arm'd, Not sure, though hoping of this good success, I ask'd his blessing, and from first to last Told him my pilgrimage. END
BEGIN NOW But his flaw'd heart (Alack, too weak the conflict to support!) END
BEGIN NOW 'Twixt two extremes of passion, joy and grief, Burst smilingly. END
BEGIN NOW This speech of yours hath mov'd me, And shall perchance do good; but speak you on; You look as you had something more to say. END
BEGIN NOW If there be more, more woful, hold it in; For I am almost ready to dissolve, Hearing of this. END
BEGIN NOW This would have seem'd a period To such as love not sorrow; but another, To amplify too much, would make much more, And top extremity. END
BEGIN NOW Whilst I was big in clamour, came there a man, Who, having seen me in my worst estate, Shunn'd my abhorr'd society; but then, finding Who 'twas that so endur'd, with his strong arms He fastened on my neck, and bellowed out As he'd burst heaven; threw him on my father; Told the most piteous tale of Lear and him That ever ear receiv'd; which in recounting His grief grew puissant, and the strings of life Began to crack. END
BEGIN NOW Twice then the trumpets sounded, And there I left him tranc'd. END
BEGIN NOW But who was this? END
BEGIN NOW Kent, sir, the banish'd Kent; who in disguise Followed his enemy king and did him service Improper for a slave. END
BEGIN NOW Enter a Gentleman with a bloody knife. END
BEGIN NOW Help, help! END
BEGIN NOW O, help! END
BEGIN NOW What kind of help? END
BEGIN NOW Speak, man. END
BEGIN NOW What means that bloody knife? END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis hot, it smokes. END
BEGIN NOW It came even from the heart of- O! END
BEGIN NOW she's dead! END
BEGIN NOW Who dead? END
BEGIN NOW Speak, man. END
BEGIN NOW Your lady, sir, your lady! END
BEGIN NOW and her sister By her is poisoned; she hath confess'd it. END
BEGIN NOW I was contracted to them both. END
BEGIN NOW All three Now marry in an instant. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Here comes Kent. END
BEGIN NOW Produce their bodies, be they alive or dead. END
BEGIN NOW This judgement of the heavens, that makes us tremble Touches us not with pity. END
BEGIN NOW O, is this he? END
BEGIN NOW The time will not allow the compliment That very manners urges. END
BEGIN NOW Kent. END

BEGIN NOW Once upon a time there lived a king who had two daughters, and he loved them with all his heart. END
BEGIN NOW When they grew up, he was suddenly seized with a wish to know if they, on their part, truly loved him, and he made up his mind that he would give his kingdom to whichever best proved her devotion. END
BEGIN NOW So he called the elder princess and said to her, How much do you love me? END
BEGIN NOW As the apple of my eye! END
BEGIN NOW answered she. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW exclaimed the king, kissing her tenderly as he spoke, you are indeed a good daughter. END
BEGIN NOW Then he sent for the younger, and asked her how much she loved him. END
BEGIN NOW I look upon you, my father, she answered, as I look upon salt in my food. END
BEGIN NOW But the king did not like her words, and ordered her to quit the court, and never again to appear before him. END
BEGIN NOW The poor princess went sadly up to her room and began to cry, but when she was reminded of her father's commands, she dried her eyes, and made a bundle of her jewels and her best dresses and hurriedly left the castle where she was born. END
BEGIN NOW She walked straight along the road in front of her, without knowing very well where she was going or what was to become of her, for she had never been shown how to work, and all she had learnt consisted of a few household rules, and receipts of dishes which her mother had taught her long ago. END
BEGIN NOW And as she was afraid that no housewife would want to engage a girl with such a pretty face, she determined to make herself as ugly as she could. END
BEGIN NOW She therefore took off the dress that she was wearing and put on some horrible old rags belonging to a beggar, all torn and covered with mud. END
BEGIN NOW After that she smeared mud all over her hands and face, and shook her hair into a great tangle. END
BEGIN NOW Having thus changed her-appearance, she went about offering herself as a goose-girl or shepherdess. END
BEGIN NOW But the farmers' wives would have nothing to say to such a dirty maiden, and sent her away with a morsel of bread for charity's sake. END
BEGIN NOW After walking for a great many days without being able to find any work, she came to a large farm where they were in want of a shepherdess, and engaged her gladly. END
BEGIN NOW One day when she was keeping her sheep in a lonely tract of land, she suddenly felt a wish to dress herself in her robes of splendor. END
BEGIN NOW She washed herself carefully in the stream, and as she always carried her bundle with her, it was easy to shake off her rags, and transform herself in a few moments into a great lady. END
BEGIN NOW The king's son, who had lost his way out hunting, perceived this lovely damsel a long way off, and wished to look at her closer. END
BEGIN NOW But as soon as the girl saw what he was at, she fled into the wood as swiftly as a bird. END
BEGIN NOW The prince ran after her, but as he was running he caught his foot in the root of a tree and fell, and when he got up again, she was nowhere to be seen. END
BEGIN NOW When she was quite safe, she put on her rags again, and smeared over her face and hands. END
BEGIN NOW However the young prince, who was both hot and thirsty, found his way to the farm, to ask for a drink of cider, and he inquired the name of the beautiful lady that kept the sheep. END
BEGIN NOW At this everyone began to laugh, for they said that the shepherdess was one of the ugliest and dirtiest creatures under the sun. END
BEGIN NOW The prince thought some witchcraft must be at work, and he hastened away before the return of the shepherdess, who became that evening the butt of everybody's jests. END
BEGIN NOW But the king's son thought often of the lovely maiden whom he had only seen for a moment, though she seemed to him much more fascinating than any lady of the court. END
BEGIN NOW At last he dreamed of nothing else, and grew thinner day by day till his parents inquired what was the matter, promising to do all they could to make him as happy as he once was. END
BEGIN NOW He dared not tell them the truth, lest they should laugh at him, so he only said that he should like some bread baked by the kitchen girl in the distant farm. END
BEGIN NOW Although the wish appeared rather odd, they hastened to fulfill it, and the farmer was told the request of the king's son. END
BEGIN NOW The maiden showed no surprise at receiving such an order, but merely asked for some flour, salt, and water, and also that she might be left alone in a little room adjoining the oven, where the kneading-trough stood. END
BEGIN NOW Before beginning her work she washed herself carefully, and even put on her rings; but, while she was baking, one of her rings slid into the dough. END
BEGIN NOW When she had finished she dirtied herself again, and let lumps of the dough stick to her fingers, so that she became as ugly as before. END
BEGIN NOW The loaf, which was a very little one, was brought to the king's son, who ate it with pleasure. END
BEGIN NOW But in cutting it he found the ring of the princess, and declared to his parents that he would marry the girl whom that ring fitted. END
BEGIN NOW So the king made a proclamation through his whole kingdom, and ladies came from afar to lay claim to the honor. END
BEGIN NOW But the ring was so tiny that even those who had the smallest hands could only get it on their little fingers. END
BEGIN NOW In a short time all the maidens of the kingdom, including the peasant girls, had tried on the ring, and the king was just about to announce that their efforts had been in vain, when the prince observed that he had not yet seen the shepherdess. END
BEGIN NOW They sent to fetch her, and she arrived covered with rags, but with her hands cleaner than usual, so that she could easily slip on the ring. END
BEGIN NOW The king's son declared that he would fulfill his promise, and when his parents mildly remarked that the girl was only a keeper of sheep, and a very ugly one too, the maiden boldly said that she was born a princess, and that, if they would only give her some water and leave her alone in a room for a few minutes, she would show that she could look as well as anyone in fine clothes. END
BEGIN NOW They did what she asked, and when she entered in a magnificent dress, she looked so beautiful that all saw she must be a princess in disguise. END
BEGIN NOW The king's son recognized the charming damsel of whom he had once caught a glimpse, and, flinging himself at her feet, asked if she would marry him. END
BEGIN NOW The princess then told her story, and said that it would be necessary to send an ambassador to her father to ask his consent and to invite him to the wedding. END
BEGIN NOW The princess's father, who had never ceased to repent his harshness towards his daughter, had sought her through the land, but as no one could tell him anything of her, he supposed her dead. END
BEGIN NOW Therefore it was with great joy he heard that she was living and that a king's son asked her in marriage, and he quitted his kingdom with his elder daughter so as to be present at the ceremony. END
BEGIN NOW By the orders of the bride, they only served her father at the wedding breakfast bread without salt, and meat without seasoning. END
BEGIN NOW Seeing him make faces, and eat very little, his daughter, who sat beside him, inquired if his dinner was not to his taste. END
BEGIN NOW No, he replied, the dishes are carefully cooked and sent up, but they are all so dreadfully tasteless. END
BEGIN NOW Did not I tell you, my father, that salt was the best thing in life? END
BEGIN NOW And yet, when I compared you to salt, to show how much I loved you, you thought slightingly of me and you chased me from your presence. END
BEGIN NOW The king embraced his daughter, and allowed that he had been wrong to misinterpret her words. END
BEGIN NOW Then, for the rest of the wedding feast they gave him bread made with salt, and dishes with seasoning, and he said they were the very best he had ever eaten.  END
BEGIN NOW Once upon a time there was a father who had two daughters. END
BEGIN NOW Calling them to him one day he said to them, What is the sweetest thing in the world? END
BEGIN NOW Sugar, said the elder daughter. END
BEGIN NOW Salt, said the younger. END
BEGIN NOW The father was angry at this last answer. END
BEGIN NOW But his daughter stuck to it, and so her father said to her, I won't keep a daughter in my house who believes that salt is the sweetest thing in the world. END
BEGIN NOW You must leave me and seek another home. END
BEGIN NOW So the younger daughter left her father's house and wandered here and there, suffering much hunger and cold, until t last she was befriended by the fairies. END
BEGIN NOW As she walked through a wood one day listening to the songs of the birds, a prince came hunting for deer, and when he saw her he fell in love with her at once. END
BEGIN NOW She agreed to marry him, and a great banquet was prepared at the prince's house. END
BEGIN NOW To this banquet the bride's father was bidden; but he did not know that the bride was his own daughter. END
BEGIN NOW Now, at the wish of the bride, all the dishes were prepared without salt. END
BEGIN NOW So when the guests began to eat they found that the food was tasteless. END
BEGIN NOW At last one of them said, There is no salt in the meat! END
BEGIN NOW And then all the guests said, There is no salt in the meat! END
BEGIN NOW And the bride's father spoke the loudest of all. END
BEGIN NOW Truly, salt is the sweetest thing in the world, he said, though, for saying so, I sent my own daughter away from my house, and shall never see her face again. END
BEGIN NOW Then the bride made herself known to her father, and fell on his neck and kissed him.  END
BEGIN NOW  Thou Nature art my Goddess, to thy Law My Services are bound, why am I then Depriv'd of a Son's Right because I came not In the dull Road that custom has prescrib'd? END
BEGIN NOW Why Bastard, wherefore Base, when I can boast A Mind as gen'rous and a Shape as true As honest Madam's Issue? END
BEGIN NOW why are we Held Base, who in the lusty stealth of Nature Take fiercer Qualities than what compound The scanted Births of the stale Marriage-bed? END
BEGIN NOW Well then, legitimate Edgar, to thy right Of Law I will oppose a Bastard's Cunning. END
BEGIN NOW Our Father's Love is to the Bastard Edmund As to Legitimate Edgar: with success I've practis'd yet on both their easie Natures: Here comes the old Man chaf't with th' Information Which last I forg'd against my Brother Edgar, A Tale so plausible, so boldly utter'd And heightned by such lucky Accidents, That now the slightest circumstance confirms him, And Base-born Edmund spight of Law inherits. END
BEGIN NOW Nay, good my Lord, your Charity O'reshoots it self to plead in his behalf; You are your self a Father, and may feel The sting of disobedience from a Son First-born and best Belov'd: Oh Villain Edgar! END
BEGIN NOW Be not too rash, all may be forgery, And time yet clear the Duty of your Son. END
BEGIN NOW Plead with the Seas, and reason down the Winds, Yet shalt thou ne're convince me, I have seen His foul Designs through all a Father's fondness: But be this Light and Thou my Witnesses That I discard him here from my Possessions, Divorce him from my Heart, my Blood and Name. END
BEGIN NOW It works as I cou'd wish; I'll shew my self. END
BEGIN NOW Ha Edmund! END
BEGIN NOW welcome Boy; O Kent see here Inverted Nature, Gloster's Shame and Glory, This By-born, the wild sally of my Youth, Pursues me with all filial Offices, Whilst Edgar, begg'd of Heaven and born in Honour, Draws plagues on my white head that urge me still To curse in Age the pleasure of my Youth. END
BEGIN NOW Nay weep not, Edmund, for thy Brother's crimes; O gen'rous Boy, thou shar'st but half his blood, Yet lov'st beyond the kindness of a Brother. END
BEGIN NOW But I'll reward thy Vertue. END
BEGIN NOW Follow me. END
BEGIN NOW My Lord, you wait the King who comes resolv'd To quit the Toils of Empire, and divide His Realms amongst his Daughters, Heaven succeed it, But much I fear the Change. END
BEGIN NOW I grieve to see him With such wild starts of passion hourly seiz'd, As renders Majesty beneath it self. END
BEGIN NOW Alas! END
BEGIN NOW 'tis the Infirmity of his Age, Yet has his Temper ever been unfixt, Chol'rick and suddain; hark, They approach. END
BEGIN NOW [Exeunt Gloster and Flourish. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Lear, Cornwall, Albany, Burgundy, Edgar, Cordelia, royal Fair, turn yet once more, And e're successfull Burgundy receive The treasure of thy Beauties from the King, E're happy Burgundy for ever fold Thee, Cast back one pitying Look on wretched Alas what wou'd the wretched Edgar with The more Unfortunate Cordelia; Who in obedience to a Father's will Flys from her Edgar's Arms to Burgundy's? END
BEGIN NOW Attend my Lords of Albany and Cornwall With Princely Burgundy. END
BEGIN NOW We do, my Liege. END
BEGIN NOW Give me the Mapp — know, Lords, We have divided In Three our Kingdom, having now resolved To disengage from Our long Toil of State, Conferring All upon your younger years; You, Burgundy, Cornwall and Albany Long in Our Court have made your amorous sojourn And now are to be answer'd — tell me my Daughters Which of you Loves Us most, that We may place Our largest Bounty with the largest Merit. END
BEGIN NOW Sir, I do love You more than words can utter, Beyond what can be valu'd, Rich or Rare, Nor Liberty, nor Sight, Health, Fame, or Beauty Are half so dear, my Life for you were vile, As much as Child can love the best of Fathers. END
BEGIN NOW Of all these Bounds, ev'n from this Line to this With shady Forests and wide-skirted Meads, We make Thee Lady, to thine and Albany's Issue Be this perpetual — What says Our Second Daughter? END
BEGIN NOW My Sister, Sir, in part exprest my Love, For such as Hers, is mine, though more extended; Sense has no other Joy that I can relish, I have my All in my dear Lieges Love! END
BEGIN NOW Therefore to thee and thine Hereditary Remain this ample Third of our fair Kingdom. END
BEGIN NOW Now comes my Trial, how am I distrest, [Aside. END
BEGIN NOW That must with cold speech tempt the chol'rick King Rather to leave me Dowerless, than condemn me To loath'd Embraces! END
BEGIN NOW Speak now Our last, not least in Our dear Love, So ends my Task of State, — Cordelia speak, What canst Thou say to win a richer Third Than what thy Sisters gain'd? END
BEGIN NOW Now must my Love in words fall short of theirs As much as it exceeds in Truth — Nothing my Lord. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing can come of Nothing, speak agen. END
BEGIN NOW Unhappy am I that I can't dissemble, Sir, as I ought, I love your Majesty, No more nor less. END
BEGIN NOW Take heed Cordelia, Thy Fortunes are at stake, think better on't And mend thy Speech a little. END
BEGIN NOW O my Liege, You gave me Being, Bred me, dearly Love me, And I return my duty as I ought, Obey you, Love you, and most Honour you! END
BEGIN NOW Why have my Sisters Husbands, if they love you All? END
BEGIN NOW Happ'ly when I shall Wed, the Lord whose Hand Shall take my Plight, will carry half my Love, For I shall never marry, like my Sisters, To Love my Father All. END
BEGIN NOW And goes thy Heart with this? END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis said that I am Chol'rick, judge me Gods, Is there not cause? END
BEGIN NOW now Minion I perceive The Truth of what has been suggested to Us, Thy Fondness for the Rebel Son of Gloster, False to his Father, as Thou art to my Hopes: And oh take heed, rash Girl, lest We comply With thy fond wishes, which thou wilt too late Repent, for know Our nature cannot brook A Child so young and so Ungentle. END
BEGIN NOW So young my Lord and True. END
BEGIN NOW Thy Truth then be thy Dow'r, For by the sacred Sun and solemn Night I here disclaim all my paternal Care, And from this minute hold thee as a Stranger Both to my Blood and Favour. END
BEGIN NOW This is Frenzy. END
BEGIN NOW Consider, good my Liege — Peace Come not between a Dragon and his Rage. END
BEGIN NOW I lov'd her most, and in her tender Trust Design'd to have bestow'd my Age at Ease! END
BEGIN NOW So be my Grave my Peace as here I give My Heart from her, and with it all my Wealth: My Lords of Cornwall and of Albany, I do invest you jointly with full Right In this fair Third, Cordelia's forfeit Dow'r. END
BEGIN NOW Mark me, My Lords, observe Our last Resolve, Our Self attended with an hundred Knights Will make Aboad with you in monthly Course, The Name alone of King remain with me, Yours be the Execution and Revenues, This is Our final Will, and to confirm it This Coronet part between you. END
BEGIN NOW Royal Lear, Whom I have ever honour'd as my King, Lov'd as my Father, as my Master follow'd, And as my Patron thought on in my Pray'rs — Away, the Bow is bent, make from the Shaft. END
BEGIN NOW No, let it fall and drench within my Heart, Be Kent unmannerly when Lear is mad: Thy youngest Daughter — On thy Life no more. END
BEGIN NOW What wilt thou doe, old Man? END
BEGIN NOW Out of my sight! END
BEGIN NOW See better first. END
BEGIN NOW Now by the gods — Now by the gods, rash King, thou swear'st in vain. END
BEGIN NOW Ha Traytour — Do, kill thy Physician, Lear, Strike through my Throat, yet with my latest Breath I'll Thunder in thine Ear my just Complaint, And tell Thee to thy Face that Thou dost ill. END
BEGIN NOW Hear me rash Man, on thy Allegiance hear me; Since thou hast striv'n to make Us break our Vow And prest between our Sentence and our Pow'r, Which nor our Nature nor our Place can bear, We banish thee for ever from our Sight And Kingdom; if when Three days are expir'd Thy hated Trunk be found in our Dominions That moment is thy Death; Away. END
BEGIN NOW Why fare thee well, King, since thou art resolv'd, I take thee at thy word, and will not stay To see thy Fall: the gods protect the Maid That truly thinks, and has most justly said. END
BEGIN NOW Thus to new Climates my old Truth I bear, Friendship lives Hence, and Banishment is Here. END
BEGIN NOW [Exit. END
BEGIN NOW Now Burgundy, you see her Price is faln, Yet if the fondness of your Passion still Affects her as she stands, Dow'rless, and lost In our Esteem, she's yours, take her or leave her. END
BEGIN NOW Pardon me, Royal Lear, I but demand The Dow'r your Self propos'd, and here I take Cordelia by the Hand Dutchess of Burgundy. END
BEGIN NOW Then leave her Sir, for by a Father's rage I tell you all her Wealth. END
BEGIN NOW Away. END
BEGIN NOW Then Sir be pleas'd to charge the breach Of our Alliance on your own Will Not my Inconstancy. END
BEGIN NOW [ Manent Edgar and Cordelia. END
BEGIN NOW Has Heaven then weigh'd the merit of my Love, Or is't the raving of my sickly Thought? END
BEGIN NOW Cou'd Burgundy forgoe so rich a Prize And leave her to despairing Edgar's Arms? END
BEGIN NOW Have I thy Hand Cordelia, do I clasp it, The Hand that was this minute to have join'd My hated Rivals? END
BEGIN NOW do I kneel before thee And offer at thy feet my panting Heart? END
BEGIN NOW Smile, Princess, and convince me, for as yet I doubt, and dare not trust the dazling Joy. END
BEGIN NOW Some Comfort yet that 'twas no vicious Blot That has depriv'd me of a Father's Grace, But meerly want of that that makes me rich In wanting it, a smooth professing Tongue: O Sisters, I am loth to call your fault As it deserves; but use our Father well, And wrong'd Cordelia never shall repine. END
BEGIN NOW O heav'nly Maid that art thy self thy Dow'r, Richer in Vertue than the Stars in Light, If Edgar's humble fortunes may be grac't With thy Acceptance, at thy feet he lays 'em. END
BEGIN NOW Ha my Cordelia! END
BEGIN NOW dost thou turn away? END
BEGIN NOW What have I done t'offend Thee? END
BEGIN NOW Talk't of Love. END
BEGIN NOW Then I've offended oft, Cordelia too Has oft permitted me so to offend. END
BEGIN NOW When, Edgar, I permitted your Addresses, I was the darling Daughter of a King, Nor can I now forget my royal Birth, And live dependent on my Lover's Fortune. END
BEGIN NOW I cannot to so low a fate submit, And therefore study to forget your Passion, And trouble me upon this Theam no more. END
BEGIN NOW Thus Majesty takes most State in Distress! END
BEGIN NOW How are we tost on Fortune's fickle flood! END
BEGIN NOW The Wave that with surprising kindness brought The dear Wreck to my Arms, has snatcht it back, And left me mourning on the barren Shore. END
BEGIN NOW This Baseness of th' ignoble Burgundy [Aside. END
BEGIN NOW Draws just suspicion on the Race of Men, His Love was Int'rest, so may Edgar's be And He but with more Complement dissemble; If so, I shall oblige him by Denying: But if his Love be fixt, such Constant flame As warms our Breasts, if such I find his Passion, My Heart as gratefull to his Truth shall be, And Cold Cordelia prove as Kind as He. END

BEGIN NOW Enter Bastard hastily. END
BEGIN NOW Brother, I've found you in a lucky minute, Fly and be safe, some Villain has incens'd Our Father against your Life. END

BEGIN NOW but oh! END
BEGIN NOW more Cruel! END

BEGIN NOW A Resolve so sudden And of such black Importance! END
BEGIN NOW 'Twas not sudden, Some Villain has of long time laid the Train. END

BEGIN NOW for Heav'ns sake Sir. END

BEGIN NOW Ha! END
BEGIN NOW ha! END
BEGIN NOW fond Man, such credulous Honesty Lessens the Glory of my Artifice, His Nature is so far from doing wrongs That he suspects none: if this Letter speed And pass for Edgar's, as himself wou'd own The Counterfeit but for the foul Contents, Then my designs are perfect — here comes Gloster. END
BEGIN NOW [Enter Gloster. END

BEGIN NOW What needed then that terrible dispatch of it Into your Pocket, come produce it Sir. END

BEGIN NOW 'Tis Edgar's Character. END
BEGIN NOW [Reads. END
BEGIN NOW This Policy of Fathers is intollerable that keeps our Fortunes from us till Age will not suffer us to enjoy 'em; I am weary of the Tyranny: Come to me that of this I may speak more: if our Father would sleep till I wak't him, you shou'd enjoy half his Possessions, and live beloved of your Brother Slept till I wake him, you shou'd enjoy Half his possessions — Edgar to write this 'Gainst his indulgent Father! END
BEGIN NOW Death and Hell! END
BEGIN NOW Fly, Edmund, seek him out, wind me into him That I may bite the Traytor's heart, and fold His bleeding Entrals on my vengefull Arm. END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps 'twas writ, my Lord, to prove my Vertue. END
BEGIN NOW These late Eclipses of the Sun and Moon Can bode no less; Love cools, and friendship fails, In Cities mutiny, in Countrys discord, The bond of Nature crack't 'twixt Son and Father: Find out the Villain, do it carefully And it shall lose thee nothing. END
BEGIN NOW [Exit. END
BEGIN NOW So, now my project's firm, but to make sure I'll throw in one proof more and that a bold one; I'll place old Gloster where he shall o're-hear us Confer of this design, whilst to his thinking, Deluded Edgar shall accuse himself. END
BEGIN NOW Be Honesty my Int'rest and I can Be honest too, and what Saint so Divine That will successfull Villany decline! END

BEGIN NOW Enter Kent disguis'd. END
BEGIN NOW Now banisht Kent, if thou canst pay thy duty In this disguise where thou dost stand condemn'd, Thy Master Lear shall find thee full of Labours. END
BEGIN NOW In there, and tell our Daughter we are here Now; What art Thou? END
BEGIN NOW A Man, Sir. END
BEGIN NOW What dost thou profess, or wou'dst with us? END
BEGIN NOW I do profess to be no less then I seem, to serve him truly that puts me in Trust, to love him that's Honest, to converse with him that's wise and speaks little, to fight when I can't choose; and to eat no Fish. END
BEGIN NOW I say, what art Thou? END
BEGIN NOW A very honest-hearted fellow, and as poor as the King. END
BEGIN NOW Then art thou poor indeed — What can'st thou do? END
BEGIN NOW I can keep honest Counsel, marr a curious Tale in the telling, deliver a plain Message bluntly, that which ordinary Men are fit for I am qualify'd in, and the best of me is Diligence. END
BEGIN NOW Follow me, thou shalt serve me. END

BEGIN NOW Dear Goddess hear, and if thou dost intend To make that Creature fruitfull, change thy purpose; Pronounce upon her Womb the barren Curse, That from her blasted Body never spring A Babe to honour her — but if she must bring forth, Defeat her Joy with some distorted Birth, Or monstrous Form, the Prodigy o'th' Time, And so perverse of spirit, that it may Live Her Torment as 'twas Born, to fret her Cheeks With constant Tears, and wrinkle her young Brow. END

BEGIN NOW Sir this old Ruffian here, whose Life I spar'd In pity to his Beard — Thou Essence Bottle! END
BEGIN NOW In pity to my Beard? END
BEGIN NOW — Your leave, my Lord, And I will tread the Muss cat into Mortar. END
BEGIN NOW Know'st thou our Presence? END
BEGIN NOW Yes, Sir, but Anger has a Privilege. END
BEGIN NOW Why art thou angry? END
BEGIN NOW That such a Slave as this shou'd wear a Sword And have no Courage, Office and no Honesty. END
BEGIN NOW Not Frost and Fire hold more Antipathy Than I and such a Knave. END
BEGIN NOW Why dost thou call him Knave? END
BEGIN NOW His Countenance likes me not. END
BEGIN NOW No more perhaps does Mine, nor His or Hers. END
BEGIN NOW Plain-dealing is my Trade, and to be plain, Sir, I have seen better Faces in my time Than stands on any Shoulders now before me. END
BEGIN NOW This is some Fellow that having once been prais'd, For Bluntness, since affects a sawcy Rudeness, But I have known one of these surly Knaves That in his Plainness harbour'd more Design Than twenty cringing complementing Minions. END
BEGIN NOW What's the offence you gave him? END
BEGIN NOW Never any, Sir. END
BEGIN NOW It pleas'd the King his Master lately To strike me on a slender misconstruction, Whilst watching his Advantage this old Lurcher Tript me behind, for which the King extold him; And, flusht with th' honour of this bold exploit, Drew on me here agen. END
BEGIN NOW Bring forth the Stocks, we'll teach you. END
BEGIN NOW Sir I'm too old to learn; Call not the Stocks for me, I serve the King, On whose Employment I was sent to you, You'll shew too small Respect, and too bold Malice Against the Person of my royal Master, Stocking his Messenger. END
BEGIN NOW Bring forth the Stocks, as I have Life and Honour, There shall he sit till Noon. END
BEGIN NOW Till Noon, my Lord? END
BEGIN NOW till Night, and all Night too. END
BEGIN NOW Why, Madam, if I were your Father's Dog You wou'd not use me so. END
BEGIN NOW Sir, being his Knave I will. END
BEGIN NOW Let me beseech your Graces to forbear him, His fault is much, and the good King his Master Will check him for't, but needs must take it ill To be thus slighted in his Messenger. END
BEGIN NOW Wee'l answer that; Our Sister may receive it worse to have Her Gentleman assaulted: to our business lead. END
BEGIN NOW [Exit. END
BEGIN NOW I am sorry for thee, Friend, 'tis the Duke's pleasure Whose Disposition will not be controll'd, But I'll entreat for thee. END
BEGIN NOW Pray do not, Sir — I have watcht and travell'd hard, Some time I shall sleep out, the rest I'll whistle: Fare-well t'ye, Sir. END
BEGIN NOW [Ex. END
BEGIN NOW All weary and o're-watcht, I feel the drowzy Guest steal on me; take Advantage heavy Eyes of this kind Slumber, Not to behold this vile and shamefull Lodging. END
BEGIN NOW [Sleeps. END
BEGIN NOW Enter I heard my self proclaim'd, And by the friendly Hollow of a Tree Escapt the Hunt, no Port is free, no place Where Guards and most unusual Vigilance Do not attend to take me — how easie now 'Twere to defeat the malice of my Trale, And leave my Griefs on my Sword's reeking point; But Love detains me from Death's peacefull Cell, Still whispering me Cordelia's in distress; Unkinde as she is I cannot see her wretched, But must be neer to wait upon her Fortune. END
BEGIN NOW Who knows but the white minute yet may come When Edgar may do service to Cordelia, That charming Hope still ties me to the Oar Of painfull Life, and makes me too, submit To th' humblest shifts to keep that Life a foot; My Face I will besmear and knit my Locks, The Country gives me proof and president Of Bedlam Beggars, who with roaring Voices Strike in their numm'd and mortify'd bare Arms Pins, Iron-spikes, Thorns, sprigs of Rosemary, And thus from Sheep-coats Villages and Mills, Sometimes with Prayers, sometimes with Lunatick Banns Enforce their Charity, poor Tyrligod, poor Tom That's something yet, Edgar I am no more. END
BEGIN NOW [Exit Kent in the Stocks still; Enter Lear attended. END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis strange that they shou'd so depart from home And not send back our Messenger. END

BEGIN NOW How? END

BEGIN NOW No. END

BEGIN NOW They durst not do't They cou'd not, wou'd not do't, 'tis worse then Murder To doe upon Respect such violent out-rage. END

BEGIN NOW My Lord, when at their Home I did commend your Highness Letters to them, E'er I was Ris'n, arriv'd another Post Steer'd in his haste, breathless and panting forth From Gonerill his Mistress Salutations, Whose Message being deliver'd, they took Horse, Commanding me to follow and attend The leisure of their Answer; which I did, But meeting that other Messenger Whose welcome I perceiv'd had poison'd mine, Being the very Fellow that of late Had shew'n such rudeness to your Highness, I Having more Man than Wit about me, Drew, On which he rais'd the House with Coward cries: This was the Trespass which your Son and Daughter Thought worth the shame you see it suffer here. END

BEGIN NOW Heart thou art too tough. END
BEGIN NOW I pray you, Sir, being old confess you are so, If till the expiration of your Month You will return and sojourn with your Sister, Dismissing half your Train, come then to me, I am now from Home, and out of that Provision That shall be needfull for your Entertainment. END
BEGIN NOW Return with her and fifty Knights dismist? END
BEGIN NOW No, rather I'll forswear all Roofs, and chuse To be Companion to the Midnight Wolf, My naked Head expos'd to th' merciless Air Then have my smallest wants suppli'd by her. END
BEGIN NOW At your choice, Sir. END
BEGIN NOW Now I prithee Daughter do not make me mad; I will not trouble thee, my Child, farewell, Wee'l meet no more, no more see one another; Let shame come when it will, I do not call it, I do not bid the Thunder-bearer strike, Nor tell Tales of thee to avenging Heav'n; Mend when thou canst, be better at thy leisure, I can be patient, I can stay with Regan, I, and my hundred Knights. END
BEGIN NOW Your Pardon, Sir. END
BEGIN NOW I lookt not for you yet, nor am provided For your fit welcome. END

BEGIN NOW Why not, my Lord? END

BEGIN NOW Hold now my Temper, stand this bolt unmov'd And I am Thunder-proof; The wicked when compar'd with the more wicked Seem beautifull, and not to be the worst, Stands in some rank of Praise; now, Gonerill, Thou art innocent agen, I'll go with thee; Thy Fifty yet, do's double Five and Twenty, And thou art twice her Love. END
BEGIN NOW Hear me, my Lord, What need you Five and Twenty, Ten, or Five, To follow in a House where twice so many Have a Command t'attend you? END

BEGIN NOW Blood, Fire! END
BEGIN NOW hear — Leaprosies and bluest Plagues! END
BEGIN NOW Room, room for Hell to belch her Horrors up And drench the Circes in a stream of Fire; Heark how th' Infernals eccho to my Rage Their Whips and Snakes — How lewd a thing is Passion! END
BEGIN NOW So old and stomachfull. END
BEGIN NOW [Lightning and Thunder. END
BEGIN NOW Heav'ns drop your Patience down; You see me here, ye Gods, a poor old Man As full of Griefs as Age, wretched in both — I'll bear no more: no, you unnatural Haggs, I will have such Revenges on you both, That all the world shall — I will do such things What they are yet I know not, but they shall be The Terrors of the Earth; you think I'll weep, [Thunder again. END
BEGIN NOW This Heart shall break into a thousand pieces Before I'll weep — O Gods! END

BEGIN NOW 'Tis a wild Night, come out o'th' Storm. END

BEGIN NOW A Desert Heath. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Lear and Kent in the Storm. END
BEGIN NOW Blow Winds and burst your Cheeks, rage louder yet, Fantastick Lightning singe, singe my white Head; Spout Cataracts, and Hurricanos fall Till you have drown'd the Towns and Palaces Of proud ingratefull Man. END
BEGIN NOW Not all my best intreaties can perswade him Into some needfull shelter, or to 'bide This poor slight Cov'ring on his aged Head Expos'd to this wild war of Earth and Heav'n. END
BEGIN NOW Rumble thy fill, fight Whirlwind, Rain and Fire: Not Fire, Wind, Rain or Thunder are my Daughters: I tax not you ye Elements with unkindness; I never gave you Kingdoms, call'd you Children, You owe me no Obedience, then let fall Your horrible pleasure, here I stand your Slave, A poor, infirm, weak and despis'd old man; Yet I will call you servile Ministers, That have with two pernicious Daughters join'd Their high-engendred Battle against a Head So Old and White as mine, Oh! END
BEGIN NOW oh! END
BEGIN NOW 'tis Foul. END
BEGIN NOW Hard by, Sir, is a Hovel that will lend Some shelter from this Tempest. END
BEGIN NOW I will forget my Nature, what? END
BEGIN NOW so kind a Father, I, there's the point. END
BEGIN NOW Consider, good my Liege, Things that love Night Love not such Nights as this; these wrathfull Skies Frighten the very wanderers o'th' Dark, And make 'em keep their Caves; such drenching Rain, Such Sheets of Fire, such Claps of horrid Thunder, Such Groans of roaring Winds have ne're been known. END

BEGIN NOW your raggedness defend you From Seasons such as These. END

BEGIN NOW what do I see? END

END

BEGIN NOW Pillicock sat upon Pillicock Hill; Hallo, hallo, hallo. END

BEGIN NOW Iudicious punishment, 'twas this Flesh begot Those Pelican Daughters. END
BEGIN NOW Take heed of the fow Fiend, obey thy Parents, keep thy Word justly, Swear not, commit not with Man's sworn Spouse, set not thy sweet Heart on proud Array: Tom's a Cold. END
BEGIN NOW What hast thou been? END
BEGIN NOW A Serving-man proud of Heart, that curl'd my Hair, us'd Perfume and Washes, that serv'd the Lust of my Mistresses Heart, and did the Act of Darkness with her. END
BEGIN NOW Swore as many Oaths as I spoke Words, and broke 'em all in the sweet Face of Heaven: Let not the Paint, nor the Patch, nor the rushing of Silks betray thy poor Heart to Woman, keep thy Foot out of Brothels, thy Hand out of Plackets, thy Pen from Creditors Books, and defie the foul Fiend — still through the Hawthorn blows the cold Wind — Sess, Suum, Mun, Nonny, Dolphin my Boy — hist! END
BEGIN NOW the Boy, Sesey! END
BEGIN NOW soft let him Trot by. END
BEGIN NOW Death, thou wert better in thy Grave, than thus to answer with thy uncover'd Body this Extremity of the Sky. END
BEGIN NOW And yet consider him well, and Man's no more than This; Thou art indebted to the Worm for no Silk, to the Beast for no Hide, to the Cat for no Perfume — ha! END
BEGIN NOW here's Two of us are Sophisticated; Thou art the Thing it self, unaccommated Man is no more than such a poor bare forkt Animal as thou art. END

BEGIN NOW Defend his Wits, good Heaven! END
BEGIN NOW One point I had forgot; what's your Name? END
BEGIN NOW Poor Tom that eats the swimming Frog, the Wall-nut, and the Water-nut; that in the fury of his Heart when the foul Fiend rages eats Cow dung for Sallets, swallows the old Rat and the Ditch-dog, that drinks the green Mantle of the standing Pool that's whipt from Tithing to Tithing; that has Three Suits to his Back, Six Shirts to his Body, Horse to Ride, and Weapon to wear, But Rats and Mice, and such small Deer Have been Tom's Food for Seven long Year. END

BEGIN NOW Right, ha! END
BEGIN NOW ha! END
BEGIN NOW was it not pleasant to have a Thousand with red hot Spits come hizzing in upon 'em? END

BEGIN NOW The little Dogs and all, Trey, Blanch and Sweet-heart, see they Bark at me. END

BEGIN NOW This is the foul Flibertigibet, he begins at Curfew and walks at first Cock, he gives the Web and the Pin, knits the Elflock, squints the Eye, and makes the Hair-lip, mildews the white Wheat, and hurts the poor Creature of the Earth; Swithin footed Thrice the Cold, He met the Night-mare and her Nine-fold, 'Twas there he did appoint her; He bid her alight and her Troth plight, And arroynt the Witch arroynt her. BEGIN NOW Speak, Sir; do you know me? END
BEGIN NOW I remember thy Eyes well enough: Nay, do thy worst, blind Cupid, I'll not Love — read me this Challenge, mark but the penning of it. END
BEGIN NOW Were all the Letters Suns I cou'd not see. END
BEGIN NOW I wou'd not take this from Report: wretched Cordelia, What will thy Vertue do when thou shalt find This fresh Affliction added to the Tale Of thy unparrallel'd Griefs. END
BEGIN NOW Read. END
BEGIN NOW What with this Case of eyes? END
BEGIN NOW O ho! END
BEGIN NOW are you there with me? END
BEGIN NOW no Eyes in your Head, and no money in your Purse? END
BEGIN NOW yet you see how this World goes. END
BEGIN NOW I see it Feelingly. END
BEGIN NOW What? END
BEGIN NOW art Mad? END
BEGIN NOW a Man may see how this World goes with no Eyes. END
BEGIN NOW Look with thy Ears, see how yon Justice rails on that simple Thief; shake'em together, and the first that drops, be it Thief or Justice, is a Villain. END
BEGIN NOW — Thou hast seen a Farmer's Dog bark at a Beggar. END
BEGIN NOW I, Sir. END
BEGIN NOW And the Man ran from the Curr; there thou mightst behold the great Image of Authority, a Dog's obey'd in Office. END
BEGIN NOW Thou Rascal, Beadle, hold thy bloody Hand, why dost thou Lash that Strumpet? END
BEGIN NOW thou hotly Lust'st to enjoy her in that kind for which thou whipst her, do, do, the Judge that sentenc'd her has been before-hand with thee. END
BEGIN NOW How stiff is my vile Sense that yields not yet? END
BEGIN NOW I tell thee the Usurer hangs the Couz'ner, through tatter'd Robes small Vices do appear, Robes and Fur-gowns hide All: Place Sins with Gold, why there 'tis for thee, my Friend, make much of it, it has the Pow'r to seal the Accuser's Lips. END
BEGIN NOW Get thee glass Eyes, and like a scurvy Politician, seem to see the Things thou dost not. END
BEGIN NOW Pull, pull off my Boots, hard, harder, so, so. END
BEGIN NOW O Matter and Impertinency mixt Reason in Madness. END
BEGIN NOW If thou wilt weep my Fortunes take my Eyes, I know thee well enough, thy Name is Gloster. END
BEGIN NOW Thou must be patient, we came Crying hither Thou knowst, the first time that We tast the Air We Wail and Cry — I'll preach to thee, Mark. END
BEGIN NOW Break lab'ring Heart. END
BEGIN NOW When we are Born we Cry that we are come To this great Stage of Fools. END
BEGIN NOW — O here he is, lay hand upon him, Sir, Your dearest Daughter sends — No Rescue? END
BEGIN NOW what, a Prisoner? END
BEGIN NOW I am even the natural Fool of Fortune: Use me well, you shall have Ransome — let me have Surgeons, Oh I am cut to th' Brains. END
BEGIN NOW You shall have any Thing. END
BEGIN NOW No Second's? END
BEGIN NOW all my Self? END
BEGIN NOW I will Die bravely like a smug Bridegroom, flusht and pamper'd as a Priest's Whore. END
BEGIN NOW I am a King, my Masters, know ye that? END
BEGIN NOW You are a Royal one, and we Obey you. END
BEGIN NOW It were an excellent Stratagem to Shoe a Troop of Horse with Felt, I'll put in proof — no Noise, no Noise — now will we steal upon these Sons in Law, and then — Kill, kill, kill, kill! END
BEGIN NOW [Ex. END
BEGIN NOW Running. END
BEGIN NOW A Sight most moving in the meanest Wretch, Past speaking in a King. END
BEGIN NOW Now, good Sir, what are you? END
BEGIN NOW A most poor Man made tame to Fortune's strokes, And prone to Pity by experienc'd Sorrows; give me your Hand. END
BEGIN NOW You ever gentle Gods take my Breath from me, And let not my ill Genius tempt me more To Die before you please. END
BEGIN NOW Enter A proclaim'd Prize, O most happily met, That Eye-less Head of thine was first fram'd Flesh To raise my Fortunes; Thou old unhappy Traytor, The Sword is out that must Destroy thee. END
BEGIN NOW Now let thy friendly Hand put Strength enough to't. END
BEGIN NOW Wherefore, bold Peasant, Darst thou support a publisht Traytor, hence, Lest I destroy Thee too. END

BEGIN NOW 'Chill not Let go Zir, without 'vurther 'Casion. END

BEGIN NOW Out, Dunghill. END
BEGIN NOW 'Chill pick your Teeth, Zir; Come, no matter vor your Voines. END

BEGIN NOW To Edmund Earl of Gloster. END
BEGIN NOW Let our Mutual Loves be remembred, you have many opportunities to Cut him off, if he return the Conqueror then I am still a Prisoner, and his Bed my Goal, from the loath'd Warmth of which deliver me, and supply the Place for your Labour. END

BEGIN NOW Still, still, far wide. END
BEGIN NOW Phys. END

BEGIN NOW O look upon me, Sir, And hold your Hands in Blessing o're me, nay, You must not kneel. END
BEGIN NOW Pray do not mock me. END
BEGIN NOW I am a very foolish fond Old Man, Fourscore and upward, and to deal plainly with you, I fear I am not in my perfect Mind. END

BEGIN NOW Methinks I shou'd know you, and know this Man, Yet I am Doubtfull, for I am mainly Ignorant What Place this is, and all the skill I have Remembers not these Garments, nor do I know Where I did Sleep last Night — pray do not mock me — For, as I am a Man, I think that Lady To be my Child Cordelia. END
BEGIN NOW O my dear, dear Father! END
BEGIN NOW Be your Tears wet? END
BEGIN NOW yes faith; pray do not weep, I know I have giv'n thee Cause, and am so humbled With Crosses since, that I cou'd ask Forgiveness of thee were it possible That thou cou'dst grant it, but I'm well assur'd Thou canst not; therefore I do stand thy Justice, If thou hast Poyson for me I will Drink it, Bless thee and Die. END
BEGIN NOW O pity, Sir, a bleeding Heart, and cease This killing Language. END

BEGIN NOW In your own Kingdom, Sir. END
BEGIN NOW Do not Abuse me. END

BEGIN NOW [They lead him off. END
BEGIN NOW The Gods restore you — heark, I hear afar The beaten Drum, Old Kent's a Man of's Word. END

BEGIN NOW That I cou'd shift my Sex, and die me deep In his Opposer's Blood, but as I may With Womens Weapons, Piety and Pray'rs, I'll aid his Cause — You never-erring Gods Fight on his side, and Thunder on his Foes Such Tempest as his poor ag'd Head sustain'd; Your Image suffers when a Monarch bleeds. END
BEGIN NOW 'Tis your own Cause, for that your Succours bring, Revenge your Selves, and right an injur'd King. END

BEGIN NOW A Camp. END
BEGIN NOW Enter Our Sisters Pow'rs already are arriv'd, And She her self has promis'd to prevent The Night with her Approach: have you provided The Banquet I bespoke for her Reception At my Tent? END
BEGIN NOW So, please your Grace, we have. END
BEGIN NOW But thou, my Poysner, must prepare the Bowl That Crowns this Banquet, when our Mirth is high, The Trumpets sounding and the Flutes replying, Then is the Time to give this fatal Draught To this imperious Sister; if then our Arms succeed, Edmund more dear than Victory is mine. END

BEGIN NOW Off. END

END
BEGIN NOW You bring a welcome Hearing; Each to his Charge. END

BEGIN NOW The Fight grows hot; the whole War's now at Work, And the goar'd Battle bleeds in every Vein, Whilst Drums and Trumpets drown loud Slaughter's Roar: Where's Gloster now that us'd to head the Fray, And scour the Ranks where deadliest Danger lay? END

END

END

END

BEGIN NOW Half-blooded Man, Thy Father's Sin first, then his Punishment, The dark and vicious Place where he begot thee Cost him his Eyes: from thy licentious Mother Thou draw'st thy Villany; but for thy part Of Gloster's Blood, I hold thee worth my Sword. END
BEGIN NOW Thou bear'st thee on thy Mother's Piety, Which I despise; thy Mother being chaste Thou art assur'd Thou art but Gloster's Son, But mine, disdaining Constancy, leaves me To hope that I am sprung from nobler Blood, And possibly a King might be my Sire: But be my Birth's uncertain Chance as 'twill, Who 'twas that had the hit to Father me I know not; 'tis enough that I am I: Of this one thing I'm certain — that I have A daring Soul, and so have at thy Heart Sound Trumpet. END

BEGIN NOW What says my Lord? END
BEGIN NOW Speak, for me thought I heard The charming Voice of a descending God. END
BEGIN NOW The Troops by Edmund rais'd, I have disbanded; Those that remain are under my Command. END
BEGIN NOW What Comfort may be brought to cheer your Age And heal your savage Wrongs, shall be apply'd; For to your Majesty we do Resign Your Kingdom, save what Part your Self conferr'd On Us in Marriage. END
BEGIN NOW Hear you that, my Liege? END
BEGIN NOW Then there are Gods, and Vertue is their Care. END
BEGIN NOW Is 't Possible? END
BEGIN NOW Let the Spheres stop their Course, the Sun make Hault, The Winds be husht, the Seas and Fountains Rest; All Nature pause, and listen to the Change. END
BEGIN NOW Where is my Kent, my Cajus? END
BEGIN NOW Here, my Liege. END
BEGIN NOW Why I have News that will recall thy Youth; Ha! END
BEGIN NOW Didst Thou hear 't, or did th' inspiring Gods Whisper to me Alone? END
BEGIN NOW Old Lear shall be A King again. END
BEGIN NOW The Prince, that like a God has Pow'r, has said it. END
BEGIN NOW Cordelia then shall be a Queen, mark that: Cordelia shall be Queen; Winds catch the Sound And bear it on your rosie Wings to Heav'n. END
BEGIN NOW Cordelia is a Queen. END
BEGIN NOW Re-enter Edgar with Gloster. END
BEGIN NOW Look, Sir, where pious Edgar comes Leading his Eye-less Father: O my Liege! END
BEGIN NOW His wondrous Story will deserve your Leisure: What He has done and suffer'd for your Sake, What for the Fair Cordelia's. END
BEGIN NOW Where is my Liege? END
BEGIN NOW Conduct me to his Knees to hail His second Birth of Empire; my dear Edgar Has, with himself, reveal'd the King's blest Restauration. END
BEGIN NOW My poor dark Gloster; O let me kiss that once more sceptred Hand! END
BEGIN NOW Hold, Thou mistak'st the Majesty, kneel here; Cordelia has our Pow'r, Cordelia's Queen. END
BEGIN NOW Speak, is not that the noble Suffring Edgar? END
BEGIN NOW My pious Son, more dear than my lost Eyes. END
BEGIN NOW I wrong'd Him too, but here's the fair Amends. END
BEGIN NOW Your leave, my Liege, for an unwelcome Message. END
BEGIN NOW Edmund (but that 's a Triflle) is expir'd; What more will touch you, your imperious Daughters Gonerill and haughty Regan, both are Dead, Each by the other poison'd at a Banquet; This, Dying, they confest. END
BEGIN NOW O fatal Period of ill-govern'd Life! END
BEGIN NOW Ingratefull as they were, my Heart feels yet A Pang of Nature for their wretched Fall; — But, Edgar, I defer thy Joys too long: Thou serv'dst distrest Cordelia; take her Crown'd: Th' imperial Grace fresh Blooming on her Brow; Nay, Gloster, Thou hast here a Father's Right; Thy helping Hand t' heap Blessings on their Head. END
BEGIN NOW Old Kent throws in his hearty Wishes too. END
BEGIN NOW The Gods and You too largely recompence What I have done; the Gift strikes Merit Dumb. END
BEGIN NOW Nor do I blush to own my Self o'er-paid For all my Suffrings past. END
BEGIN NOW Now, gentle Gods, give Gloster his Discharge. END
BEGIN NOW No, Gloster, Thou hast Business yet for Life; Thou, Kent and I, retir'd to some cool Cell Will gently pass our short reserves of Time In calm Reflections on our Fortunes past, Cheer'd with relation of the prosperous Reign Of this celestial Pair; Thus our Remains Shall in an even Course of Thought be past, Enjoy the present Hour, nor fear the Last. END
BEGIN NOW Our drooping Country now erects her Head, Peace spreads her balmy Wings, and Plenty Blooms. END
BEGIN NOW Divine Cordelia, all the Gods can witness How much thy Love to Empire I prefer! END
BEGIN NOW Thy bright Example shall convince the World (Whatever Storms of Fortune are decreed) That Truth and Vertue shall at last succeed. END

BEGIN NOW Omnes. END
BEGIN NOW FINIS. END
BEGIN NOW EPILOGUE, Spoken by Mrs. BARRY Inconstancy, the reigning Sin o' th' Age, Will scarce endure true Lovers on the Stage; You hardly ev'n in Plays with such dispense, And Poëts kill 'em in their own Defence. END
BEGIN NOW Yet One bold Proof I was resolv'd to give, That I cou'd three Hours Constancy Out-live. END
BEGIN NOW You fear, perhaps, whilst on the Stage w' are made Such Saints, we shall indeed take up the Trade; Sometimes we Threaten — but our Vertue may For Truth I fear with your Pit-Valour weigh: For (not to flatter either) I much doubt When We are off the Stage, and You are out, We are not quite so Coy, nor You so Stout. END
BEGIN NOW We talk of Nunn'ries — but to be sincere Whoever lives to see us Cloyster'd There, May hope to meet our Critiques at Tangier. END
BEGIN NOW For shame give over this inglorious Trade Of worrying Poëts, and go maule th' Alcade. END
BEGIN NOW Well — since y' are All for blustring in the Pit, This Play's Reviver humbly do's admit Your abs'lute Pow'r to damn his Part of it; But still so many Master-Touches shine Of that vast Hand that first laid this Design, That in great Shakespear's Right, He's bold to say If you like nothing you have seen to Day The Play your Judgment damns, not you the Play.  END
BEGIN NOW SO MANY FUCKING FEELINGS ABOUT THE FOOL IN KING LEAR I MUST PUT ON MY MOTLEY AND CRY BITTERSWEET TEARS  END
BEGIN NOW The servant who dies defending Gloucester grew up with Cornwall and, though he doesn’t have words to express it, is deeply in love with him. END
BEGIN NOW His decision to intervene stems from his desire to save Cornwall’s soul from his wife’s clutches rather than from any sense of duty toward Gloucester.  END
BEGIN NOW WE were a party of six, gathered together one winter evening at the house of an old college friend. END
BEGIN NOW The conversation turned on Shakespeare, on his types, and how profoundly and truly they were taken from the very heart of humanity. END
BEGIN NOW We admired particularly their truth to life, their actuality. END
BEGIN NOW Each of us spoke of the Hamlets, the Othellos, the Falstaffs, even the Richard the Thirds and Macbeths&mdash;the two last only potentially, it is true, resembling their prototypes&mdash;whom he had happened to come across. END
BEGIN NOW And I, gentlemen, cried our host, a man well past middle age, used to know a King Lear! END
BEGIN NOW How was that? END
BEGIN NOW we questioned him. END
BEGIN NOW Oh, would you like me to tell you about him? END
BEGIN NOW Please do. END
BEGIN NOW And our friend promptly began his narrative. END
BEGIN NOW ALL my childhood, he began, and early youth, up to the age of fifteen, I spent in the country, on the estate of my mother, a wealthy landowner in X&mdash;- province. END
BEGIN NOW Almost the most vivid impression, that has remained in my memory of that far-off time, is the figure of our nearest neighbour, Martin Petrovitch Harlov. END
BEGIN NOW Indeed it would be difficult for such an impression to be obliterated: I never in my life afterwards met anything in the least like Harlov. END
BEGIN NOW Picture to yourselves a man of gigantic stature. END
BEGIN NOW On his huge carcase was set, a little askew, and without the least trace of a neck, a prodigious head. END
BEGIN NOW A perfect haystack of tangled yellowish-grey hair stood up all over it, growing almost down to the bushy eyebrows. END
BEGIN NOW On the broad expanse of his purple face, that looked as though it had been peeled, there protruded a sturdy knobby nose; diminutive little blue eyes stared out haughtily, and a mouth gaped open that was diminutive too, but crooked, chapped, and of the same colour as the rest of the face. END
BEGIN NOW The voice that proceeded from this mouth, though hoarse, was exceedingly strong and resonant.\. END
BEGIN NOW Its sound recalled the clank of iron bars, carried in a cart over a badly paved road; and when Harlov spoke, it was as though some one were shouting in a high wind across a wide ravine. END
BEGIN NOW It was difficult to tell just what Harlov's face expressed, it was such an expanse.\. END
BEGIN NOW One felt one could hardly take it all in at one glance. END
BEGIN NOW But it was not disagreeable&mdash;a certain grandeur indeed could be discerned in it, only it was exceedingly astounding and unusual. END
BEGIN NOW And what hands he had&mdash;positive cushions! END
BEGIN NOW What fingers, what feet! END
BEGIN NOW I remember I could never gaze without a certain respectful awe at the four-foot span of Martin Petrovitch's back, at his shoulders, like millstones. END
BEGIN NOW But what especially struck me was his ears! END
BEGIN NOW They were just like great twists of bread, full of bends and curves; his cheeks seemed to support them on both sides. END
BEGIN NOW Martin Petrovitch used to wear&mdash;winter and summer alike&mdash;a Cossack dress of green cloth, girt about with a small Tcherkess strap, and tarred boots. END
BEGIN NOW I never saw a cravat on him; and indeed what could he have tied a cravat round? END
BEGIN NOW He breathed slowly and heavily, like a bull, but walked without a sound. END
BEGIN NOW One might have imagined that having got into a room, he was in constant fear of upsetting and overturning everything, and so moved cautiously from place to place, sideways for the most part, as though slinking by. END
BEGIN NOW He was possessed of a strength truly Herculean, and in consequence enjoyed great renown in the neighbourhood. END
BEGIN NOW Our common people retain to this day their reverence for Titanic heroes. END
BEGIN NOW Legends were invented about him. END
BEGIN NOW They used to recount that he had one day met a bear in the forest and had almost vanquished him; that having once caught a thief in his beehouse, he had flung him, horse and cart and all, over the hedge, and so on. END
