BEGIN NOW Harlov himself never boasted of his strength. END
BEGIN NOW 'If my right hand is blessed,' he used to say, 'so it is God's will it should be!' END
BEGIN NOW He was proud, only he did not take pride in his strength, but in his rank, his descent, his common sense. END
BEGIN NOW Our family's descended from the Swede Harlus, he used to maintain. END
BEGIN NOW In the princely reign of Ivan Vassilievitch the Dark (fancy how long ago!) END
BEGIN NOW he came to Russia, and that Swede Harlus did not wish to be a Finnish count&mdash;but he wished to be a Russian nobleman, and he was inscribed in the golden book. END
BEGIN NOW It's from him we Harlovs are sprung!\. END
BEGIN NOW And by the same token, all of us Harlovs are born flaxen-haired, with light eyes and clean faces, because we're children of the snow! END
BEGIN NOW But, Martin Petrovitch, I once tried to object, there never was an Ivan Vassilievitch the Dark. END
BEGIN NOW Then was an Ivan Vassilievitch the Terrible. END
BEGIN NOW The Dark was the name given to the great prince Vassily Vassilievitch. END
BEGIN NOW What nonsense will you talk next! END
BEGIN NOW Harlov answered serenely; since I say so, so it was! END
BEGIN NOW One day my mother took it into her head to commend him to his face for his really remarkable incorruptibility. END
BEGIN NOW Ah, Natalia Nikolaevna! END
BEGIN NOW he protested almost angrily; what a thing to praise me for, really! END
BEGIN NOW We gentlefolk can't be otherwise; so that no churl, no low-born, servile creature dare even imagine evil of us! END
BEGIN NOW I am a Harlov, my family has come down from'&mdash;here he pointed up somewhere very high aloft in the ceiling&mdash;'and me not be honest! END
BEGIN NOW How is it possible? END
BEGIN NOW Another time a high official, who had come into the neighbourhood and was staying with my mother, fancied he could make fun of Martin Petrovitch. END
BEGIN NOW The latter had again referred to the Swede Harlus, who came to Russia\. END
BEGIN NOW In the days of King Solomon? END
BEGIN NOW the official interrupted. END
BEGIN NOW No, not of King Solomon, but of the great Prince Ivan Vassilievitch the Dark. END
BEGIN NOW But I imagine, the official pursued, that your family is much more ancient, and goes back to antediluvian days, when there were still mastodons and megatheriums about. END
BEGIN NOW These scientific names were absolutely meaningless to Martin Petrovitch; but he realised that the dignitary was laughing at him. END
BEGIN NOW May be so, he boomed, our family is, no doubt, very ancient; in those days when my ancestor was in Moscow, they do say there was as great a fool as your excellency living there, and such fools are not seen twice in a thousand years. END
BEGIN NOW The high official was in a furious rage, while Harlov threw his head back, stuck out his chin, snorted and disappeared. END
BEGIN NOW Two days later, he came in again. END
BEGIN NOW My mother began reproaching him. END
BEGIN NOW It's a lesson for him, ma'am, interposed Harlov, not to fly off without knowing what he's about, to find out whom he has to deal with first. END
BEGIN NOW He's young yet, he must be taught. END
BEGIN NOW The dignitary was almost of the same age as Harlov; but this Titan was in the habit of regarding every one as not fully grown up. END
BEGIN NOW He had the greatest confidence in himself and was afraid of absolutely no one. END
BEGIN NOW Can they do anything to me? END
BEGIN NOW Where on earth is the man that can? END
BEGIN NOW he would ask, and suddenly he would go off into a short but deafening guffaw. END
BEGIN NOW MY mother was exceedingly particular in her choice of acquaintances, but she made Harlov welcome with special cordiality and allowed him many privileges. END
BEGIN NOW Twenty-five years before, he had saved her life by holding up her carriage on the edge of a deep precipice, down which the horses had already fallen. END
BEGIN NOW The traces and straps of the harness broke, but Martin Petrovitch did not let go his hold of the wheel he had grasped, though the blood spurted out under his nails. END
BEGIN NOW My mother had arranged his marriage. END
BEGIN NOW She chose for his wife an orphan girl of seventeen, who had been brought up in her house; he was over forty at the time. END
BEGIN NOW Martin Petrovitch's wife was a frail creature&mdash;they said he carried her into his house in the palms of his hands&mdash;and she did not live long with him. END
BEGIN NOW She bore him two daughters, however. END
BEGIN NOW After her death, my mother continued her good offices to Martin Petrovitch. END
BEGIN NOW She placed his elder daughter in the district school, and afterwards found her a husband, and already had another in her eye for the second. END
BEGIN NOW Harlov was a fairly good manager. END
BEGIN NOW He had a little estate of nearly eight hundred acres, and had built on to his place a little, and the way the peasants obeyed him is indescribable. END
BEGIN NOW Owing to his stoutness, Harlov scarcely ever went anywhere on foot: the earth did not bear him. END
BEGIN NOW He used to go everywhere in a low racing droshky, himself driving a rawboned mare, thirty years old, with a scar on her shoulder, from a wound which she had received in the battle of Borodino, under the quartermaster of a cavalry regiment. END
BEGIN NOW This mare was always somehow lame in all four legs; she could not go at a walking pace, but could only change from a trot to a canter. END
BEGIN NOW She used to eat mugwort and wormwood along the hedges, which I have never noticed any other horse do. END
BEGIN NOW I remember I always used to wonder how such a broken-down nag could draw such a fearful weight. END
BEGIN NOW I won't venture to repeat how many hundredweight were attributed to our neighbour. END
BEGIN NOW In the droshky behind Martin Petrovitch's back perched his swarthy page, Maximka. END
BEGIN NOW With his face and whole person squeezed close up to his master, and his bare feet propped on the hind axle bar of the droshky, he looked like a little leaf or worm which had clung by chance to the gigantic carcase before him. END
BEGIN NOW This same page boy used once a week to shave Martin Petrovitch. END
BEGIN NOW He used, so they said, to stand on a table to perform this operation. END
BEGIN NOW Some jocose persons averred that he had to run round his master's chin. END
BEGIN NOW Harlov did not like staying long at home, and so one might often see him driving about in his invariable equipage, with the reins in one hand (the other he held smartly on his knee with the elbow crooked upwards), with a diminutive old cap on the very top of his head. END
BEGIN NOW He looked boldly about him with his little bear-like eyes, shouted in a voice of thunder to all the peasants, artisans, and tradespeople he met. END
BEGIN NOW Priests he greatly disliked, and he would send vigorous abjurations after them when he met them. END
BEGIN NOW One day on overtaking me (I was out for a stroll with my gun), he hallooed at a hare that lay near the road in such a way that I could not get the roar and ring of it out of my ears all day. END
BEGIN NOW MY mother, as I have already stated, made Martin Petrovitch very welcome. END
BEGIN NOW She knew what a profound respect he entertained for her person. END
BEGIN NOW She is a real gentlewoman, one of our sort, was the way he used to refer to her. END
BEGIN NOW He used to style her his benefactress, while she saw in him a devoted giant, who would not have hesitated to face a whole mob of peasants in defence of her; and although no one foresaw the barest possibility of such a contingency, still, to my mother's notions, in the absence of a husband&mdash;she had early been left a widow&mdash;such a champion as Martin Petrovitch was not to be despised. END
BEGIN NOW And besides, he was a man of upright character, who curried favour with no one, never borrowed money or drank spirits; and no fool either, though he had received no sort of education. END
BEGIN NOW My mother trusted Martin Petrovitch: when she took it into her head to make her will, she asked him to witness it, and he drove home expressly to fetch his round iron-rimmed spectacles, without which he could not write. END
BEGIN NOW And with spectacles on nose, he succeeded, in a quarter of an hour, with many gasps and groans and great effort, in inscribing his Christian name, father's name, and surname and his rank and designation, tracing enormous quadrangular letters, with tails and flourishes. END
BEGIN NOW Having completed this task, he declared he was tired out, and that writing for him was as hard work as catching fleas. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, my mother had a respect for him.\. END
BEGIN NOW he was not, however, admitted beyond the dining-room in our house. END
BEGIN NOW He carried a very strong odour about with him; there was a smell of the earth, of decaying forest, of marsh mud about him. END
BEGIN NOW He's a forest-demon! END
BEGIN NOW my old nurse would declare. END
BEGIN NOW At dinner a special table used to be laid apart in a corner for Martin Petrovitch, and he was not offended at that, he knew other people were ill at ease sitting beside him, and he too had greater freedom in eating. END
BEGIN NOW And he did eat too, as no one, I imagine, has eaten since the days of Polyphemus. END
BEGIN NOW At the very beginning of dinner, by way of a precautionary measure, they always served him a pot of some four pounds of porridge, else you'd eat me out of house and home, my mother used to say. END
BEGIN NOW That I should, ma'am, Martin Petrovitch would respond, grinning. END
BEGIN NOW My mother liked to hear his reflections on any topic connected with the land. END
BEGIN NOW But she could not support the sound of his voice for long together. END
BEGIN NOW What's the meaning of it, my good sir! END
BEGIN NOW she would exclaim; you might take something to cure yourself of it, really! END
BEGIN NOW You simply deafen me. END
BEGIN NOW Such a trumpet-blast! END
BEGIN NOW Natalia Nikolaevna! END
BEGIN NOW benefactress! END
BEGIN NOW Martin Petrovitch would rejoin, as a rule, I'm not responsible for my throat. END
BEGIN NOW And what medicine could have any effect on me&mdash;kindly tell me that? END
BEGIN NOW I'd better hold my tongue for a bit. END
BEGIN NOW In reality, I imagine, no medicine could have affected Martin Petrovitch. END
BEGIN NOW He was never ill. END
BEGIN NOW He was not good at telling stories, and did not care for it. END
BEGIN NOW Much talking gives me asthma, he used to remark reproachfully. END
BEGIN NOW It was only when one got him on to the year &mdash;he had served in the militia, and had received a bronze medal, which he used to wear on festive occasions attached to a Vladimir ribbon&mdash;when one questioned him about the French, that he would relate some few anecdotes. END
BEGIN NOW He used, however, to maintain stoutly all the while that there never had been any Frenchmen, real ones, in Russia, only some poor marauders, who had straggled over from hunger, and that he had given many a good drubbing to such rabble in the forests. END
BEGIN NOW AND yet even this self-confident, unflinching giant had his moments of melancholy and depression. END
BEGIN NOW Without any visible cause he would suddenly begin to be sad; he would lock himself up alone in his room, and hum&mdash;positively hum&mdash;like a whole hive of bees; or he would call his page Maximka, and tell him to read aloud to him out of the solitary book which had somehow found its way into his house, an odd volume of Novikovsky's The Worker at Leisure, or else to sing to him. END
BEGIN NOW And Maximka, who by some strange freak of chance, could spell out print, syllable by syllable, would set to work with the usual chopping up of the words and transference of the accent, bawling out phrases of the following description: but man in his wilfulness draws from this empty hypothesis, which he applies to the animal kingdom, utterly opposite conclusions. END
BEGIN NOW Every animal separately, he says, is not capable of making me happy! END
BEGIN NOW and so on. END
BEGIN NOW Or he would chant in a shrill little voice a mournful song, of which nothing could be distinguished but: Ee\. END
BEGIN NOW eee\. END
BEGIN NOW ee.\. END
BEGIN NOW a.\. END
BEGIN NOW ee.\. END
BEGIN NOW a.\. END
BEGIN NOW ee.\. END
BEGIN NOW Aaa.\. END
BEGIN NOW ska! END
BEGIN NOW O.\. END
BEGIN NOW oo.\. END
BEGIN NOW oo.\. END
BEGIN NOW bee.\. END
BEGIN NOW ee.\. END
BEGIN NOW ee.\. END
BEGIN NOW ee.\. END
BEGIN NOW la! END
BEGIN NOW While Martin Petrovitch would shake his head, make allusions to the mutability of life, how all things turn to ashes, fade away like grass, pass&mdash;and will return no more! END
BEGIN NOW A picture had somehow come into his hands, representing a burning candle, which the winds, with puffed-out cheeks, were blowing upon from all sides; below was the inscription: Such is the life of man. END
BEGIN NOW He was very fond of this picture; he had hung it up in his own room, but at ordinary, not melancholy, times he used to keep it turned face to the wall, so that it might not depress him. END
BEGIN NOW Harlov, that colossus, was afraid of death! END
BEGIN NOW To the consolations of religion, to prayer, however, he rarely had recourse in his fits of melancholy. END
BEGIN NOW Even then he chiefly relied on his own intelligence. END
BEGIN NOW He had no particular religious feeling; he was not often seen in church; he used to say, it is true, that he did not go on the ground that, owing to his corporeal dimensions, he was afraid of squeezing other people out. END
BEGIN NOW The fit of depression commonly ended in Martin Petrovitch's beginning to whistle, and suddenly, in a voice of thunder, ordering out his droshky, and dashing off about the neighbourhood, vigorously brandishing his disengaged hand over the peak of his cap, as though he would say, For all that, I don't care a straw! END
BEGIN NOW He was a regular Russian. END
BEGIN NOW STRONG men, like Martin Petrovitch, are for the most part of a phlegmatic disposition; but he, on the contrary, was rather easily irritated. END
BEGIN NOW He was specially short-tempered with a certain Bitchkov, who had found a refuge in our house, where he occupied a position between that of a buffoon and a dependant. END
BEGIN NOW He was the brother of Harlov's deceased wife, had been nicknamed Souvenir as a little boy, and Souvenir he had remained for every one, even the servants, who addressed him, it is true, as Souvenir Timofeitch. END
BEGIN NOW His real name he seemed hardly to know himself. END
BEGIN NOW He was a pitiful creature, looked down upon by every one; a toady, in fact. END
BEGIN NOW He had no teeth on one side of his mouth, which gave his little wrinkled face a crooked appearance. END
BEGIN NOW He was in a perpetual fuss and fidget; he used to poke himself into the maids' room, or into the counting-house, or into the priest's quarters, or else into the bailiff's hut. END
BEGIN NOW He was repelled from everywhere, but he only shrugged himself up, and screwed up his little eyes, and laughed a pitiful mawkish laugh, like the sound of rinsing a bottle. END
BEGIN NOW It always seemed to me that had Souvenir had money, he would have turned into the basest person, unprincipled, spiteful, even cruel. END
BEGIN NOW Poverty kept him within bounds. END
BEGIN NOW He was only allowed drink on holidays. END
BEGIN NOW He was decently dressed, by my mother's orders, since in the evenings he took a hand in her game of picquet or boston. END
BEGIN NOW Souvenir was constantly repeating, Certainly, d'rectly, d'rectly. END
BEGIN NOW D'rectly what? END
BEGIN NOW my mother would ask, with annoyance. END
BEGIN NOW He instantly drew back his hands, in a scare, and lisped, At your service, ma'am! END
BEGIN NOW Listening at doors, backbiting, and, above all, quizzing, teasing, were his sole interest, and he used to quiz as though he had a right to, as though he were avenging himself for something. END
BEGIN NOW He used to call Martin Petrovitch brother, and tormented him beyond endurance. END
BEGIN NOW What made you kill my sister, Margarita Timofeevna? END
BEGIN NOW he used to persist, wriggling about before him and sniggering. END
BEGIN NOW One day Martin Petrovitch was sitting in the billiard-room, a cool apartment, in which no one had ever seen a single fly, and which our neighbour, disliking heat and sunshine, greatly favoured on this account. END
BEGIN NOW He was sitting between the wall and the billiard-table. END
BEGIN NOW Souvenir was fidgeting before his bulky person, mocking him, grimacing.\. END
BEGIN NOW Martin Petrovitch wanted to get rid of him, and thrust both hands out in front of him. END
BEGIN NOW Luckily for Souvenir he managed to get away, his brother-in law's open hands came into collision with the edge of the billiard-table, and the billiard-board went flying off all its six screws.\. END
BEGIN NOW What a mass of batter Souvenir would have been turned into under those mighty hands! END
BEGIN NOW I HAD long been curious to see how Martin Petrovitch arranged his household, what sort of a home he had. END
BEGIN NOW One day I invited myself to accompany him on horseback as far as Eskovo (that was the name of his estate). END
BEGIN NOW Upon my word, you want to have a look at my dominion, was Martin Petrovitch's comment. END
BEGIN NOW By all means! END
BEGIN NOW I'll show you the garden, and the house, and the threshing-floor, and everything. END
BEGIN NOW I have plenty of everything. END
BEGIN NOW We set off. END
BEGIN NOW It was reckoned hardly more than a couple of miles from our place to Eskovo. END
BEGIN NOW Here it is&mdash;my dominion! END
BEGIN NOW Martin Petrovitch roared suddenly, trying to turn his immovable neck, and waving his arm to right and left. END
BEGIN NOW It's all mine! END
BEGIN NOW Harlov's homestead lay on the top of a sloping hill. END
BEGIN NOW At the bottom, a few wretched-looking peasants' huts clustered close to a small pond. END
BEGIN NOW At the pond, on a washing platform, an old peasant woman in a check petticoat was beating some soaked linen with a bat. END
BEGIN NOW Axinia! END
BEGIN NOW boomed Martin Petrovitch, but in such a note that the rooks flew up in a flock from an oat-field near.\. END
BEGIN NOW Washing your husband's breeches? END
BEGIN NOW The peasant woman turned at once and bowed very low. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, sir, sounded her weak voice. END
BEGIN NOW Ay, ay! END
BEGIN NOW Yonder, look, Martin Petrovitch continued, proceeding at a trot alongside a half-rotting wattle fence, that is my hemp-patch; and that yonder's the peasants'; see the difference? END
BEGIN NOW And this here is my garden; the apple-trees I planted, and the willows I planted too. END
BEGIN NOW Else there was no timber of any sort here. END
BEGIN NOW Look at that, and learn a lesson! END
BEGIN NOW We turned into the courtyard, shut in by a fence; right opposite the gate, rose an old tumbledown lodge, with a thatch roof, and steps up to it, raised on posts. END
BEGIN NOW On one side stood another, rather newer, and with a tiny attic; but it too was a ramshackly affair. END
BEGIN NOW Here you may learn a lesson again, observed Harlov; see what a little manor-house our fathers lived in; but now see what a mansion I have built myself. END
BEGIN NOW This mansion was like a house of cards. END
BEGIN NOW Five or six dogs, one more ragged and hideous than another, welcomed us with barking. END
BEGIN NOW Sheep-dogs! END
BEGIN NOW observed Martin Petrovitch. END
BEGIN NOW Pure-bred Crimeans! END
BEGIN NOW Sh, damned brutes! END
BEGIN NOW I'll come and strangle you one after another! END
BEGIN NOW On the steps of the new building, there came out a young man, in a long full nankeen overall, the husband of Martin Petrovitch's elder daughter. END
BEGIN NOW Skipping quickly up to the droshky, he respectfully supported his father-in-law under the elbow as he got up, and even made as though he would hold the gigantic feet, which the latter, bending his bulky person forward, lifted with a sweeping movement across the seat; then he assisted me to dismount from my horse. END
BEGIN NOW Anna! END
BEGIN NOW cried Harlov, Natalia Nikolaevna's son has come to pay us a visit; you must find some good cheer for him. END
BEGIN NOW But where's Evlampia? END
BEGIN NOW (Anna was the name of the elder daughter, Evlampia of the younger.) END
BEGIN NOW She's not at home; she's gone into the fields to get cornflowers, responded Anna, appearing at a little window near the door. END
BEGIN NOW Is there any junket? END
BEGIN NOW queried Harlov. END
BEGIN NOW Yes. END
BEGIN NOW And cream too? END
BEGIN NOW Yes. END
BEGIN NOW Well, set them on the table, and I'll show the young gentleman my own room meanwhile. END
BEGIN NOW This way, please, this way, he added, addressing me, and beckoning with his forefinger. END
BEGIN NOW In his own house he treated me less familiarly; as a host he felt obliged to be more formally respectful. END
BEGIN NOW He led me along a corridor. END
BEGIN NOW Here is where I abide, he observed, stepping sideways over the threshold of a wide doorway, this is my room. END
BEGIN NOW Pray walk in! END
BEGIN NOW His room turned out to be a big unplastered apartment, almost empty; on the walls, on nails driven in askew, hung two riding-whips, a three-cornered hat, reddish with wear, a single-barrelled gun, a sabre, a sort of curious horse-collar inlaid with metal plates, and the picture representing a burning candle blown on by the winds. END
BEGIN NOW In one corner stood a wooden settle covered with a parti-coloured rug. END
BEGIN NOW Hundreds of flies swarmed thickly about the ceiling; yet the room was cool. END
BEGIN NOW But there was a very strong smell of that peculiar odour of the forest which always accompanied Martin Petrovitch. END
BEGIN NOW Well, is it a nice room? END
BEGIN NOW Harlov questioned me. END
BEGIN NOW Very nice. END
BEGIN NOW Look-ye, there hangs my Dutch horse-collar, Harlov went on, dropping into his familiar tone again. END
BEGIN NOW A splendid horse-collar! END
BEGIN NOW got it by barter off a Jew. END
BEGIN NOW Just you look at it! END
BEGIN NOW It's a good horse-collar. END
BEGIN NOW It's most practical. END
BEGIN NOW And just sniff it\. END
BEGIN NOW what leather! END
BEGIN NOW I smelt the horse-collar. END
BEGIN NOW It smelt of rancid oil and nothing else. END
BEGIN NOW Now, be seated,&mdash;there on the stool; make yourself at home, observed Harlov, while he himself sank on to the settle, and seemed to fall into a doze, shutting his eyes and even beginning to snore. END
BEGIN NOW I gazed at him without speaking, with ever fresh wonder; he was a perfect mountain&mdash;there was no other word! END
BEGIN NOW Suddenly he started. END
BEGIN NOW Anna! END
BEGIN NOW he shouted, while his huge stomach rose and fell like a wave on the sea; what are you about? END
BEGIN NOW Look sharp! END
BEGIN NOW Didn't you hear me? END
BEGIN NOW Everything's ready, father; come in, I heard his daughter's voice. END
BEGIN NOW I inwardly marvelled at the rapidity with which Martin Petrovitch's behests had been carried out; and followed him into the drawing-room, where, on a table covered with a red cloth with white flowers on it, lunch was already prepared: junket, cream, wheaten bread, even powdered sugar and ginger. END
BEGIN NOW While I set to work on the junket, Martin Petrovitch growled affectionately, Eat, my friend, eat, my dear boy; don't despise our country cheer, and sitting down again in a corner, again seemed to fall into a doze. END
BEGIN NOW Before me, perfectly motionless, with downcast eyes, stood Anna Martinovna, while I saw through the window her husband walking my cob up and down the yard, and rubbing the chain of the snaffle with his own hands. END
BEGIN NOW MY mother did not like Harlov's elder daughter; she called her a stuck-up thing. END
BEGIN NOW Anna Martinovna scarcely ever came to pay us her respects, and behaved with chilly decorum in my mother's presence, though it was by her good offices she had been well educated at a boarding-school, and had been married, and on her wedding-day had received a thousand roubles and a yellow Turkish shawl, the latter, it is true, a trifle the worse for wear. END
BEGIN NOW She was a woman of medium height, thin, very brisk and rapid in her movements, with thick fair hair and a handsome dark face, on which the pale-blue narrow eyes showed up in a rather strange but pleasing way. END
BEGIN NOW She had a straight thin nose, her lips were thin too, and her chin was like the loop-end of a hair-pin. END
BEGIN NOW No one looking at her could fail to think: Well, you are a clever creature&mdash;and a spiteful one, too! END
BEGIN NOW And for all that, there was something attractive about her too. END
BEGIN NOW Even the dark moles, scattered like buck-wheat over her face, suited her and increased the feeling she inspired. END
BEGIN NOW Her hands thrust into her kerchief, she was slily watching me, looking downwards (I was seated, while she was standing). END
BEGIN NOW A wicked little smile strayed about her lips and her cheeks and in the shadow of her long eyelashes. END
BEGIN NOW Ugh, you pampered little fine gentleman! END
BEGIN NOW this smile seemed to express. END
BEGIN NOW Every time she drew a breath, her nostrils slightly distended&mdash;this, too, was rather strange. END
BEGIN NOW But all the same, it seemed to me that were Anna Martinovna to love me, or even to care to kiss me with her thin cruel lips, I should simply bound up to the ceiling with delight. END
BEGIN NOW I knew she was very severe and exacting, that the peasant women and girls went in terror of her&mdash;but what of that? END
BEGIN NOW Anna Martinovna secretly excited my imagination\. END
BEGIN NOW though after all, I was only fifteen then,&mdash;and at that age!\. END
BEGIN NOW Martin Petrovitch roused himself again. END
BEGIN NOW Anna! END
BEGIN NOW he shouted, you ought to strum something on the pianoforte\. END
BEGIN NOW young gentlemen are fond of that. END
BEGIN NOW I looked round; there was a pitiful semblance of a piano in the room. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, father, responded Anna Martinovna. END
BEGIN NOW Only what am I to play the young gentleman? END
BEGIN NOW He won't find it interesting. END
BEGIN NOW Why, what did they teach you at your young ladies' seminary? END
BEGIN NOW I've forgotten everything&mdash;besides, the notes are broken. END
BEGIN NOW Anna Martinovna' s voice was very pleasant, resonant and rather plaintive&mdash;like the note of some birds of prey. END
BEGIN NOW Very well, said Martin Petrovitch, and he lapsed into dreaminess again. END
BEGIN NOW Well, he began once more, wouldn't you like, then, to see the threshing-floor, and have a look round? END
BEGIN NOW Volodka will escort you.&mdash;Hi, Volodka! END
BEGIN NOW he shouted to his son-in-law, who was still pacing up and down the yard with my horse, take the young gentleman to the threshing-floor.\. END
BEGIN NOW and show him my farming generally. END
BEGIN NOW But I must have a nap! END
BEGIN NOW So! END
BEGIN NOW good-bye! END
BEGIN NOW He went out and I after him. END
BEGIN NOW Anna Martinovna at once set to work rapidly, and, as it were, angrily, clearing the table. END
BEGIN NOW In the doorway, I turned and bowed to her. END
BEGIN NOW But she seemed not to notice my bow, and only smiled again, more maliciously than before. END
BEGIN NOW I took my horse from Harlov's son-in-law and led him by the bridle. END
BEGIN NOW We went together to the threshing-floor, but as we discovered nothing very remarkable about it, and as he could not suppose any great interest in farming in a young lad like me, we returned through the garden to the main road. END
BEGIN NOW I WAS well acquainted with Harlov's son-in-law. END
BEGIN NOW His name was Vladimir Vassilievitch Sletkin. END
BEGIN NOW He was an orphan, brought up by my mother, and the son of a petty official, to whom she had intrusted some business. END
BEGIN NOW He had first been placed in the district school, then he had entered the seignorial counting-house, then he had been put into the service of the government stores, and, finally, married to the daughter of Martin Petrovitch. END
BEGIN NOW My mother used to call him a little Jew, and certainly, with his curly hair, his black eyes always moist, like damson jam, his hook nose, and wide red mouth, he did suggest the Jewish type. END
BEGIN NOW But the colour of his skin was white and he was altogether very good-looking. END
BEGIN NOW He was of a most obliging temper, so long as his personal advantage was not involved. END
BEGIN NOW Then he promptly lost all self-control from greediness, and was moved even to tears. END
BEGIN NOW He was ready to whine the whole day long to gain the paltriest trifle; he would remind one a hundred times over of a promise, and be hurt and complain if it were not carried out at once. END
BEGIN NOW He liked sauntering about the fields with a gun; and when he happened to get a hare or a wild duck, he would thrust his booty into his game-bag with peculiar zest, saying, Now, you may be as tricky as you like, you won't escape me! END
BEGIN NOW Now you're mine! END
BEGIN NOW You've a good horse, he began in his lisping voice, as he assisted me to get into the saddle; I ought to have a horse like that! END
BEGIN NOW But where can I get one? END
BEGIN NOW I've no such luck. END
BEGIN NOW If you'd ask your mamma, now&mdash;remind her. END
BEGIN NOW Why, has she promised you one? END
BEGIN NOW Promised? END
BEGIN NOW No; but I thought that in her great kindness&mdash;- You should apply to Martin Petrovitch. END
BEGIN NOW To Martin Petrovitch? END
BEGIN NOW Sletkin repeated, dwelling on each syllable. END
BEGIN NOW To him I'm no better than a worthless page, like Maximka, He keeps a tight hand on us, that he does, and you get nothing from him for all your toil. END
BEGIN NOW Really? END
BEGIN NOW Yes, by God. END
BEGIN NOW He'll say, 'My word's sacred! END
BEGIN NOW '&mdash;and there, it's as though he's chopped it off with an axe. END
BEGIN NOW You may beg or not, it's all one. END
BEGIN NOW Besides, Anna Martinovna, my wife, is not in such favour with him as Evlampia Martinovna. END
BEGIN NOW O merciful God, bless us and save us! END
BEGIN NOW he suddenly interrupted himself, flinging up his hands in despair. END
BEGIN NOW Look! END
BEGIN NOW what's that? END
BEGIN NOW A whole half-rood of oats, our oats, some wretch has gone and cut. END
BEGIN NOW The villain! END
BEGIN NOW Just see! END
BEGIN NOW Thieves! END
BEGIN NOW thieves! END
BEGIN NOW It's a true saying, to be sure, don't trust Eskovo, Beskovo, Erino, and Byelino! END
BEGIN NOW (these were the names of four villages near). END
BEGIN NOW Ah, ah, what a thing! END
BEGIN NOW A rouble and a half's worth, or, maybe, two roubles, loss! END
BEGIN NOW In Sletkin's voice, one could almost hear sobs. END
BEGIN NOW I gave my horse a poke in the ribs and rode away from him. END
BEGIN NOW Sletkin's ejaculations still reached my hearing, when suddenly at a turn in the road, I came upon the second daughter of Harlov, Evlampia, who had, in the words of Anna Martinovna, gone into the fields to get cornflowers. END
BEGIN NOW A thick wreath of those flowers was twined about her head. END
BEGIN NOW We exchanged bows in silence. END
BEGIN NOW Evlampia, too, was very good-looking; as much so as her sister, though in a different style. END
BEGIN NOW She was tall and stoutly built; everything about her was on a large scale: her head, and her feet and hands, and her snow-white teeth, and especially her eyes, prominent, languishing eyes, of the dark blue of glass beads. END
BEGIN NOW Everything about her, while still beautiful, had positively a monumental character (she was a true daughter of Martin Petrovitch). END
BEGIN NOW She did not, it seemed, know what to do with her massive fair mane, and she had twisted it in three plaits round her head. END
BEGIN NOW Her mouth was charming, crimson and fresh as a rose, and as she talked her upper lip was lifted in the middle in a very fascinating way. END
BEGIN NOW But there was something wild and almost fierce in the glance of her huge eyes. END
BEGIN NOW A free bird, wild Cossack breed, so Martin Petrovitch used to speak of her. END
BEGIN NOW I was in awe of her.\. END
BEGIN NOW This stately beauty reminded one of her father. END
BEGIN NOW I rode on a little farther and heard her singing in a strong, even, rather harsh voice, a regular peasant voice; suddenly she ceased. END
BEGIN NOW I looked round and from the crest of the hill saw her standing beside Harlov's son-in-law facing the rood of oats. END
BEGIN NOW The latter was gesticulating and pointing, but she stood without stirring. END
BEGIN NOW The sun lighted up her tall figure, and the wreath of cornflowers shone brilliantly blue on her head. END
BEGIN NOW I BELIEVE I have already mentioned that, for this second daughter of Harlov's too, my mother had already prepared a match. END
BEGIN NOW This was one of the poorest of our neighbours, a retired army major, Gavrila Fedulitch Zhitkov, a man no longer young, and, as he himself expressed it, not without a certain complacency, however, as though recommending himself, battered and broken down. END
BEGIN NOW He could barely read and write, and was exceedingly stupid, but secretly aspired to become my mother's steward, as he felt himself to be a man of action. END
BEGIN NOW I can warm the peasant's hides for them, if I can do anything, he used to say, almost gnashing his own teeth, because I was used to it, he used to explain, in my former duties, I mean. END
BEGIN NOW Had Zhitkov been less of a fool, he would have realised that he had not the slightest chance of being steward to my mother, seeing that, for that, it would have been necessary to get rid of the present steward, one Kvitsinsky, a very capable Pole of great character, in whom my mother had the fullest confidence. END
BEGIN NOW Zhitkov had a long face, like a horse's; it was all overgrown with hair of a dusty whitish colour; his cheeks were covered with it right up to the eyes; and even in the severest frosts, it was sprinkled with an abundant sweat, like drops of dew. END
BEGIN NOW At the sight of my mother, he drew himself upright as a post, his head positively quivered with zeal, his huge hands slapped a little against his thighs, and his whole person seemed to express: Command!\. END
BEGIN NOW and I will strive my utmost! END
BEGIN NOW My mother was under no illusion on the score of his abilities, which did not, however, hinder her from taking steps to marry him to Evlampia. END
BEGIN NOW Only, will you be able to manage her, my good sir? END
BEGIN NOW she asked him one day. END
BEGIN NOW Zhitkov smiled complacently. END
BEGIN NOW Upon my word, Natalia Nikolaevna! END
BEGIN NOW I used to keep a whole regiment in order; they were tame enough in my hands; and what's this? END
BEGIN NOW A trumpery business! END
BEGIN NOW A regiment's one thing, sir, but a well-bred girl, a wife, is a very different matter, my mother observed with displeasure. END
BEGIN NOW Upon my word, ma'am! END
BEGIN NOW Natalia Nikolaevna! END
BEGIN NOW Zhitkov cried again, that we're quite able to understand. END
BEGIN NOW In one word: a young lady, a delicate person! END
BEGIN NOW Well! END
BEGIN NOW my mother decided at length, Evlampia won't let herself be trampled upon. END
BEGIN NOW ONE day&mdash;it was the month of June, and evening was coming on&mdash;a servant announced the arrival of Martin Petrovitch. END
BEGIN NOW My mother was surprised: we had not seen him for over a week, but he had never visited us so late before. END
BEGIN NOW Something has happened! END
BEGIN NOW she exclaimed in an undertone. END
BEGIN NOW The face of Martin Petrovitch, when he rolled into the room and at once sank into a chair near the door, wore such an unusual expression, it was so preoccupied and positively pale, that my mother involuntarily repeated her exclamation aloud. END
BEGIN NOW Martin Petrovitch fixed his little eyes upon her, was silent for a space, sighed heavily, was silent again, and articulated at last that he had come about something.\. END
BEGIN NOW which.\. END
BEGIN NOW was of a kind, that on account of.\. END
BEGIN NOW Muttering these disconnected words, he suddenly got up and went out. END
BEGIN NOW My mother rang, ordered the footman, who appeared, to overtake Martin Petrovitch at once and bring him back without fail, but the latter had already had time to get into his droshky and drive away. END
BEGIN NOW Next morning my mother, who was astonished and even alarmed, as much by Martin Petrovitch's strange behaviour as by the extraordinary expression of his face, was on the point of sending a special messenger to him, when he made his appearance. END
BEGIN NOW This time he seemed more composed. END
BEGIN NOW Tell me, my good friend, tell me, cried my mother, directly she saw him, what ever has happened to you? END
BEGIN NOW I thought yesterday, upon my word I did Mercy on us! END
BEGIN NOW I thought, 'Hasn't our old friend gone right off his head?' END
BEGIN NOW I've not gone off my head, madam, answered Martin Petrovitch; I'm not that sort of man. END
BEGIN NOW But I want to consult with you. END
BEGIN NOW What about? END
BEGIN NOW I'm only in doubt, whether it will be agreeable to you in this same contingency&mdash;- Speak away, speak away, my good sir, but more simply. END
BEGIN NOW Don't alarm me! END
BEGIN NOW What's this same contingency? END
BEGIN NOW Speak more plainly. END
BEGIN NOW Or is it your melancholy come upon you again? END
BEGIN NOW Harlov scowled. END
BEGIN NOW No, it's not melancholy&mdash;that comes upon me in the new moon; but allow me to ask you, madam, what do you think about death? END
BEGIN NOW My mother was taken aback. END
BEGIN NOW About what? END
BEGIN NOW About death. END
BEGIN NOW Can death spare any one whatever in this world? END
BEGIN NOW What have you got in your head, my good friend? END
BEGIN NOW Who of us is immortal? END
BEGIN NOW For all you're born a giant, even to you there'll be an end in time. END
BEGIN NOW There will! END
BEGIN NOW oh, there will! END
BEGIN NOW Harlov assented and he looked downcast. END
BEGIN NOW I've had a vision come to me in my dreams, he brought out at last. END
BEGIN NOW What are you saying? END
BEGIN NOW my mother interrupted him. END
BEGIN NOW A vision in my dreams, he repeated&mdash; I'm a seer of visions, you know! END
BEGIN NOW You! END
BEGIN NOW I. END
BEGIN NOW Didn't you know it? END
BEGIN NOW Harlov sighed. END
BEGIN NOW Well, so.\. END
BEGIN NOW Over a week ago, madam, I lay down, on the very last day of eating meat before St. Peter's fast-day; I lay down after dinner to rest a bit, well, and so I fell asleep, and dreamed a raven colt ran into the room to me. END
BEGIN NOW And this colt began sporting about and grinning. END
BEGIN NOW Black as a beetle was the raven colt. END
BEGIN NOW Harlov ceased. END
BEGIN NOW Well? END
BEGIN NOW said my mother. END
BEGIN NOW And all of a sudden this same colt turns round, and gives me a kick in the left elbow, right in the funny bone.\. END
BEGIN NOW I waked up; my arm would not move nor my leg either. END
BEGIN NOW Well, thinks I, it's paralysis; however, I worked them up and down, and got them to move again; only there were shooting pains in the joints a long time, and there are still. END
BEGIN NOW When I open my hand, the pains shoot through the joints. END
BEGIN NOW Why, Martin Petrovitch, you must have lain upon your arm somehow and crushed it. END
BEGIN NOW No, madam; pray, don't talk like that! END
BEGIN NOW It was an intimation\. END
BEGIN NOW referring to my death, I mean. END
BEGIN NOW Well, upon my word, my mother was beginning. END
BEGIN NOW An intimation. END
BEGIN NOW Prepare thyself man, as 'twere to say. END
BEGIN NOW And therefore, madam, here is what I have to announce to you, without a moment's delay. END
BEGIN NOW Not wishing, Harlov suddenly began shouting, that the same death should come upon me, the servant of God, unawares, I have planned in my own mind this: to divide&mdash;now during my lifetime&mdash;my estate between my two daughters, Anna and Evlampia, according as God Almighty directs me&mdash; Martin Petrovitch stopped, groaned, and added, without a moment's delay. END
BEGIN NOW Well, that would be a good idea, observed my mother; though I think you have no need to be in a hurry. END
BEGIN NOW And seeing that herein I desire, Harlov continued, raising his voice still higher, to be observant of all due order and legality, so humbly beg your young son, Dmitri Semyonovitch&mdash;I would not venture, madam, to trouble you&mdash;I beg the said Dmitri Semyonovitch, your son, and I claim of my kinsman, Bitchkov, as a plain duty, to assist at the ratification of the formal act and transference of possession to my two daughters&mdash;Anna, married, and Evlampia, spinster. END
BEGIN NOW Which act will be drawn up in readiness the day after to-morrow at twelve o'clock, at my own place, Eskovo, also called Kozulkino, in the presence of the ruling authorities and functionaries, who are thereto invited. END
BEGIN NOW Martin Petrovitch with difficulty reached the end of this speech, which he had obviously learnt by heart, and which was interspersed with frequent sighs.\. END
BEGIN NOW He seemed to have no breath left in his chest; his pale face was crimson again, and he several times wiped the sweat off it. END
BEGIN NOW So you've already composed the deed dividing your property? END
BEGIN NOW my mother queried. END
BEGIN NOW When did you manage that? END
BEGIN NOW I managed it\. END
BEGIN NOW oh! END
BEGIN NOW Neither eating, nor drinking&mdash;- Did you write it yourself? END
BEGIN NOW Volodka\. END
BEGIN NOW oh! END
BEGIN NOW helped. END
BEGIN NOW And have you forwarded a petition? END
BEGIN NOW I have, and the chamber has sanctioned it, and notice has been given to the district court, and the temporary division of the local court has\. END
BEGIN NOW oh!\. END
BEGIN NOW been notified to be present. END
BEGIN NOW My mother laughed. END
BEGIN NOW I see, Martin Petrovitch, you've made every arrangement already&mdash;and how quickly. END
BEGIN NOW You've not spared money, I should say? END
BEGIN NOW No, indeed, madam. END
BEGIN NOW Well, well. END
BEGIN NOW And you say you want to consult with me. END
BEGIN NOW Well, my little Dmitri can go; and I'll send Souvenir with him, and speak to Kvitsinsky.\. END
BEGIN NOW But you haven't invited Gavrila Fedulitch? END
BEGIN NOW Gavrila Fedulitch&mdash;Mr. Zhitkov&mdash;has had notice\. END
BEGIN NOW from me also. END
BEGIN NOW As a betrothed, it was only fitting. END
BEGIN NOW Martin Petrovitch had obviously exhausted all the resources of his eloquence. END
BEGIN NOW Besides, it always seemed to me that he did not look altogether favourably on the match my mother had made for his daughter; possibly, he had expected a more advantageous marriage for his darling Evlampia. END
BEGIN NOW He got up from his chair, and made a scrape with his foot. END
BEGIN NOW Thank you for your consent. END
BEGIN NOW Where are you off to? END
BEGIN NOW asked my mother. END
BEGIN NOW Stay a bit; I'll order some lunch to be served you. END
BEGIN NOW Much obliged, responded Harlov. END
BEGIN NOW But I cannot.\. END
BEGIN NOW Oh! END
BEGIN NOW I must get home. END
BEGIN NOW He backed and was about to move sideways, as his habit was, through the door. END
BEGIN NOW Stop, stop a minute, my mother went on. END
BEGIN NOW Can you possibly mean to make over the whole of your property without reserve to your daughters? END
BEGIN NOW Certainly, without reserve. END
BEGIN NOW Well, but how about yourself&mdash;where are you going to live? END
BEGIN NOW Harlov positively flung up his hands in amazement. END
BEGIN NOW You ask where? END
BEGIN NOW In my house, at home, as I've lived hitherto\. END
BEGIN NOW so hence-forward. END
BEGIN NOW Whatever difference could there be? END
BEGIN NOW You have such confidence in your daughters and your son-in-law, then? END
BEGIN NOW Were you pleased to speak of Volodka? END
BEGIN NOW A poor stick like him? END
BEGIN NOW Why, I can do as I like with him, whatever it is\. END
BEGIN NOW what authority has he? END
BEGIN NOW As for them, my daughters, that is, to care for me till I'm in the grave, to give me meat and drink, and clothe me.\. END
BEGIN NOW Merciful heavens! END
BEGIN NOW it's their first duty. END
BEGIN NOW I shall not long be an eyesore to them. END
BEGIN NOW Death's not over the hills&mdash;it's upon my shoulders. END
BEGIN NOW Death is in God's hands, observed my mother; though that is their duty, to be sure. END
BEGIN NOW Only pardon me, Martin Petrovitch; your elder girl, Anna, is well known to be proud and imperious, and&mdash;well&mdash;the second has a fierce look.\. END
BEGIN NOW Natalia Nikolaevna! END
BEGIN NOW Harlov broke in, why do you say that?\. END
BEGIN NOW Why, as though they\. END
BEGIN NOW My daughters\. END
BEGIN NOW Why, as though I\. END
BEGIN NOW Forget their duty? END
BEGIN NOW Never in their wildest dreams\. END
BEGIN NOW Offer opposition? END
BEGIN NOW To whom? END
BEGIN NOW Their parent\. END
BEGIN NOW Dare to do such a thing? END
BEGIN NOW Have they not my curse to fear? END
BEGIN NOW They've passed their life long in fear and in submission&mdash;and all of a sudden\. END
BEGIN NOW Good Lord! END
BEGIN NOW Harlov choked, there was a rattle in his throat. END
BEGIN NOW Very well, very well, my mother made haste to soothe him; only I don't understand all the same what has put it into your head to divide the property up now. END
BEGIN NOW It would have come to them afterwards, in any case. END
BEGIN NOW I imagine it's your melancholy that's at the bottom of it all. END
BEGIN NOW Eh, ma'am, Harlov rejoined, not without vexation, you will keep coming back to that. END
BEGIN NOW There is, maybe, a higher power at work in this, and you talk of melancholy. END
BEGIN NOW I thought to do this, madam, because in my own person, while still in life, I wish to decide in my presence, who is to possess what, and with what I will reward each, so that they may possess, and feel thankfulness, and carry out my wishes, and what their father and benefactor has resolved upon, they may accept as a bountiful gift. END
BEGIN NOW Harlov's voice broke again. END
BEGIN NOW Come, that's enough, that's enough, my good friend, my mother cut him short; or your raven colt will be putting in an appearance in earnest. END
BEGIN NOW O Natalia Nikolaevna, don't talk to me of it, groaned Harlov. END
BEGIN NOW That's my death come after me. END
BEGIN NOW Forgive my intrusion. END
BEGIN NOW And you, my little sir, I shall have the honour of expecting you the day after to-morrow. END
BEGIN NOW Martin Petrovitch went out; my mother looked after him, and shook her head significantly. END
BEGIN NOW This is a bad business, she murmured, a bad business. END
BEGIN NOW You noticed &mdash;she addressed herself to me&mdash; he talked, and all the while seemed blinking, as though the sun were in his eyes; that's a bad sign. END
BEGIN NOW When a man's like that, his heart's sure to be heavy, and misfortune threatens him. END
BEGIN NOW You must go over the day after to-morrow with Vikenty Osipovitch and Souvenir. END
BEGIN NOW ON the day appointed, our big family coach, with seats for four, harnessed with six bay horses, and with the head coachman, the grey-bearded and portly Alexeitch, on the box, rolled smoothly up to the steps of our house. END
BEGIN NOW The importance of the act upon which Harlov was about to enter, and the solemnity with which he had invited us, had had their effect on my mother. END
BEGIN NOW She had herself given orders for this extraordinary state equipage to be brought out, and had directed Souvenir and me to put on our best clothes. END
BEGIN NOW She obviously wished to show respect to her protégé. END
BEGIN NOW As for Kvitsinsky, he always wore a frockcoat and white tie. END
BEGIN NOW Souvenir chattered like a magpie all the way, giggled, wondered whether his brother would apportion him anything, and thereupon called him a dummy and an old fogey. END
BEGIN NOW Kvitsinsky, a man of severe and bilious temperament, could not put up with it at last. END
BEGIN NOW What can induce you, he observed, in his distinct Polish accent, to keep up such a continual unseemly chatter? END
BEGIN NOW Can you really be incapable of sitting quiet without these 'wholly superfluous' (his favourite phrase) inanities? END
BEGIN NOW All right, d'rectly, Souvenir muttered discontentedly, and he fixed his squinting eyes on the carriage window. END
BEGIN NOW A quarter of an hour had not passed, the smoothly trotting horses had scarcely begun to get warm under the straps of their new harness, when Harlov's homestead came into sight. END
BEGIN NOW Through the widely open gate, our coach rolled into the yard. END
BEGIN NOW The diminutive postillion, whose legs hardly reached halfway down his horses' body, for the last time leaped up with a babyish shriek into the soft saddle, old Alexeitch at once spread out and raised his elbows, a slight wo-o was heard, and we stopped. END
BEGIN NOW The dogs did not bark to greet us, and the serf boys, in long smocks that gaped open over their big stomachs, had all hidden themselves. END
BEGIN NOW Harlov's son-in-law was awaiting us in the doorway. END
BEGIN NOW I remember I was particularly struck by the birch boughs stuck in on both sides of the steps, as though it were Trinity Sunday. END
BEGIN NOW Grandeur upon grandeur, Souvenir, who was the first to alight, squeaked through his nose. END
BEGIN NOW And certainly there was a solemn air about everything. END
BEGIN NOW Harlov's son-in-law was wearing a plush cravat with a satin bow, and an extraordinarily tight tail-coat; while Maximka, who popped out behind his back, had his hair so saturated with kvas, that it positively dripped. END
BEGIN NOW We went into the parlour, and saw Martin Petrovitch towering&mdash;yes, positively towering&mdash;motionless, in the middle of the room. END
BEGIN NOW I don't know what Souvenir's and Kvitsinsky's feelings were at the sight of his colossal figure; but I felt something akin to awe. END
BEGIN NOW Martin Petrovitch was attired in a grey Cossack coat&mdash;his militia uniform of it must have been&mdash;with a black stand-up collar. END
BEGIN NOW A bronze medal was to be seen on his breast, a sabre hung at his side; he laid his left hand on the hilt, with his right he was leaning on the table, which was covered with a red cloth. END
BEGIN NOW Two sheets of paper, full of writing, lay on the table. END
BEGIN NOW Harlov stood motionless, not even gasping; and what dignity was expressed in his attitude, what confidence in himself, in his unlimited and unquestionable power! END
BEGIN NOW He barely greeted us with a motion of the head, and barely articulating Be seated! END
BEGIN NOW pointed the forefinger of his left hand in the direction of some chairs set in a row. END
BEGIN NOW Against the right-hand wall of the parlour were standing Harlov's daughters wearing their Sunday clothes: Anna, in a shot lilac-green dress, with a yellow silk sash; Evlampia, in pink, with crimson ribbons. END
BEGIN NOW Near them stood Zhitkov, in a new uniform, with the habitual expression of dull and greedy expectation in his eyes, and with a greater profusion of sweat than usual over his hirsute countenance. END
BEGIN NOW On the left side of the room sat the priest, in a threadbare snuff-coloured cassock, an old man, with rough brown hair. END
BEGIN NOW This head of hair, and the dejected lack-lustre eyes, and the big wrinkled hands, which seemed a burden even to himself, and lay like two rocks on his knees, and the tarred boots which peeped out beneath his cassock, all seemed to tell of a joyless laborious life. END
BEGIN NOW His parish was a very poor one. END
BEGIN NOW Beside him was the local police captain, a fattish, palish, dirty-looking little gentleman, with soft puffy little hands and feet, black eyes, black short-clipped moustaches, a continual cheerful but yet sickly little smile on his face. END
BEGIN NOW He had the reputation of being a great taker of bribes, and even a tyrant, as the expression was in those days. END
BEGIN NOW But not only the gentry, even the peasants were used to him, and liked him. END
BEGIN NOW He bent very free and easy and rather ironical looks around him; it was clear that all this procedure amused him. END
BEGIN NOW In reality, the only part that had any interest for him was the light lunch and spirits in store for us. END
BEGIN NOW But the attorney sitting near him, a lean man with a long face, narrow whiskers from his ears to his nose, as they were worn in the days of Alexander the First, was absorbed with his whole soul in Martin Petrovitch's proceedings, and never took his big serious eyes off him. END
BEGIN NOW In his concentrated attention and sympathy, he kept moving and twisting his lips, though without opening his mouth. END
BEGIN NOW Souvenir stationed himself next him, and began talking to him in a whisper, after first informing me that he was the chief freemason in the province. END
BEGIN NOW The temporary division of the local court consists, as every one knows, of the police captain, the attorney, and the rural police commissioner; but the latter was either absent or kept himself in the background, so that I did not notice him. END
BEGIN NOW He bore, however, the nickname the non-existent among us in the district, just as there are tramps called the non-identified. END
BEGIN NOW I sat next Souvenir, Kvitsinsky next me. END
BEGIN NOW The face of the practical Pole showed unmistakeable annoyance at our wholly superfluous expedition, and unnecessary waste of time.\. END
BEGIN NOW A grand lady's caprices! END
BEGIN NOW these Russian grandees' fancies! END
BEGIN NOW he seemed to be murmuring to himself.\. END
BEGIN NOW Ugh, these Russians! END
BEGIN NOW WHEN we were all seated, Martin Petrovitch hunched his shoulders, cleared his throat, scanned us all with his bear-like little eyes, and with a noisy sigh began as follows: Gentlemen, I have called you together for the following purpose. END
BEGIN NOW I am grown old, gentlemen, and overcome by infirmities.\. END
BEGIN NOW Already I have had an intimation, the hour of death steals on, like a thief in the night.\. END
BEGIN NOW Isn't that so, father? END
BEGIN NOW he addressed the priest. END
BEGIN NOW The priest started. END
BEGIN NOW Quite so, quite so, he mumbled, his beard shaking. END
BEGIN NOW And therefore, continued Martin Petrovitch, suddenly raising his voice, not wishing the said death to come upon me unawares, I purposed\. END
BEGIN NOW Martin Petrovitch proceeded to repeat, word for word, the speech he had made to my mother two days before. END
BEGIN NOW In accordance with this my determination, he shouted louder than ever, this deed (he struck his hand on the papers lying on the table) has been drawn up by me, and the presiding authorities have been invited by me, and wherein my will consists the following points will treat. END
BEGIN NOW I have ruled, my day is over! END
BEGIN NOW Martin Petrovitch put his round iron spectacles on his nose, took one of the written sheets from the table, and began: Deed of partition of the estate of the retired non-commissioned officer and nobleman, Martin Harlov, drawn up by himself in his full and right understanding, and by his own good judgment, and wherein is precisely defined what benefits are assigned to his two daughters, Anna and Evlampia&mdash;bow! END
BEGIN NOW &mdash;(they bowed), and in what way the serfs and other property, and live stock, be apportioned between the said daughters! END
BEGIN NOW Under my hand! END
BEGIN NOW This is their document! END
BEGIN NOW the police-captain whispered to Kvitsinsky, with his invariable smile, they want to read it for the beauty of the style, but the legal deed is made out formally, without all these flourishes. END
BEGIN NOW Souvenir was beginning to snigger.\. END
BEGIN NOW In accordance with my will, put in Harlov, who had caught the police captain's remark. END
BEGIN NOW In accordance in every point, the latter hastened to respond cheerfully; only, as you're aware, Martin Petrovitch, there's no dispensing with formality. END
BEGIN NOW And unnecessary details have been removed. END
BEGIN NOW For the chamber can't enter into the question of spotted cows and fancy drakes. END
BEGIN NOW Come here! END
BEGIN NOW boomed Harlov to his son-in-law, who had come into the room behind us, and remained standing with an obsequious air near the door. END
BEGIN NOW He skipped up to his father-in-law at once. END
BEGIN NOW There, take it and read! END
BEGIN NOW It's hard for me. END
BEGIN NOW Only mind and don't mumble it! END
BEGIN NOW Let all the gentlemen present be able to understand it. END
BEGIN NOW Sletkin took the paper in both hands, and began timidly, but distinctly, and with taste and feeling, to read the deed of partition. END
BEGIN NOW There was set forth in it with the greatest accuracy just what was assigned to Anna and what to Evlampia, and how the division was to be made. END
BEGIN NOW Harlov from time to time interspersed the reading with phrases. END
BEGIN NOW Do you hear, that's for you, Anna, for your zeal! END
BEGIN NOW or, That I give you, Evlampia! END
BEGIN NOW and both the sisters bowed, Anna from the waist, Evlampia simply with a motion of the head. END
BEGIN NOW Harlov looked at them with stern dignity. END
BEGIN NOW The farm house (the little new building) was assigned by him to Evlampia, as the younger daughter, by the well-known custom. END
BEGIN NOW The reader's voice quivered and resounded at these words, unfavourable for himself; while Zhitkov licked his lips. END
BEGIN NOW Evlampia gave him a sidelong glance; had I been in Zhitkov's shoes, I should not have liked that glance. END
BEGIN NOW The scornful expression, characteristic of Evlampia, as of every genuine Russian beauty, had a peculiar shade at that moment. END
BEGIN NOW For himself, Martin Petrovitch reserved the right to go on living in the rooms he occupied, and assigned to himself, under the name of rations, a full allowance of normal provisions, and ten roubles a month for clothes. END
BEGIN NOW The last phrase of the deed Harlov wished to read himself. END
BEGIN NOW And this my parental will, it ran, to carry out and observe is a sacred and binding duty on my daughters, seeing it is a command; seeing that I am, after God, their father and head, and am not bounden to render an account to any, nor have so rendered. END
BEGIN NOW And do they carry out my will, so will my fatherly blessing be with them, but should they not so do, which God forbid, then will they be overtaken by my paternal curse that cannot be averted, now and for ever, amen! END
BEGIN NOW Harlov raised the deed high above his head. END
BEGIN NOW Anna at once dropped on her knees and touched the ground with her forehead; her husband, too, doubled up after her. END
BEGIN NOW Well, and you? END
BEGIN NOW Harlov turned to Evlampia. END
BEGIN NOW She crimsoned all over, and she too bowed to the earth; Zhitkov bent his whole carcase forward. END
BEGIN NOW Sign! END
BEGIN NOW cried Harlov, pointing his forefinger to the bottom of the deed. END
BEGIN NOW Here: 'I thank and accept, Anna. END
BEGIN NOW I thank and accept, Evlampia!' END
BEGIN NOW Both daughters rose, and signed one after another. END
BEGIN NOW Sletkin rose too, and was feeling after the pen, but Harlov moved him aside, sticking his middle finger into his cravat, so that he gasped. END
BEGIN NOW The silence lasted a moment. END
BEGIN NOW Suddenly Martin Petrovitch gave a sort of sob, and muttering, Well, now it's all yours! END
BEGIN NOW moved away. END
BEGIN NOW His daughters and son-in-law looked at one another, went up to him and began kissing him just above his elbow. END
BEGIN NOW His shoulder they could not reach. END
BEGIN NOW THE police captain read the real formal document, the deed of gift, drawn up by Martin Petrovitch. END
BEGIN NOW Then he went out on to the steps with the attorney and explained what had taken place to the crowd assembled at the gates, consisting of the witnesses required by law and other people from the neighbourhood, Harlov's peasants, and a few house-serfs. END
BEGIN NOW Then began the ceremony of the new owners entering into possession. END
BEGIN NOW They came out, too, upon the steps, and the police captain pointed to them when, slightly scowling with one eyebrow, while his careless face assumed for an instant a threatening air, he exhorted the crowd to subordination. END
BEGIN NOW He might well have dispensed with these exhortations: a less unruly set of countenances than those of the Harlov peasants, I imagine, have never existed in creation. END
BEGIN NOW Clothed in thin smocks and torn sheepskins, but very tightly girt round their waists, as is always the peasants' way on solemn occasions, they stood motionless as though cut out of stone, and whenever the police captain uttered any exclamation such as, D'ye hear, you brutes? END
BEGIN NOW d'ye understand, you devils? END
BEGIN NOW they suddenly bowed all at once, as though at the word of command. END
BEGIN NOW Each of these brutes and devils held his cap tight in both hands, and never took his eyes off the window, where Martin Petrovitch's figure was visible. END
BEGIN NOW The witnesses themselves were hardly less awed. END
BEGIN NOW Is any impediment known to you, the police captain roared at them, against the entrance into possession of these the sole and legitimate heirs and daughters of Martin Petrovitch Harlov? END
BEGIN NOW All the witnesses seemed to huddle together at once. END
BEGIN NOW Do you know any, you devils? END
BEGIN NOW the police captain shouted again. END
BEGIN NOW We know nothing, your excellency, responded sturdily a little old man, marked with small-pox, with a clipped beard and whiskers, an old soldier. END
BEGIN NOW I say! END
BEGIN NOW Eremeitch's a bold fellow! END
BEGIN NOW the witnesses said of him as they dispersed. END
BEGIN NOW In spite of the police captain's entreaties, Harlov would not come out with his daughters on to the steps. END
BEGIN NOW My subjects will obey my will without that! END
BEGIN NOW he answered. END
BEGIN NOW Something like sadness had come over him on the completion of the conveyance. END
BEGIN NOW His face had grown pale. END
BEGIN NOW This new unprecedented expression of sadness looked so out of place on Martin Petrovitch's broad and kindly features that I positively was at a loss what to think. END
BEGIN NOW Was an attack of melancholy coming over him? END
BEGIN NOW The peasants, on their side, too, were obviously puzzled. END
BEGIN NOW And no wonder! END
BEGIN NOW The master's alive,&mdash;there he stands, and such a master, too; Martin Petrovitch! END
BEGIN NOW And all of a sudden he won't be their owner.\. END
BEGIN NOW A queer thing! END
BEGIN NOW I don't know whether Harlov had an inkling of the notions that were straying through his subjects' heads, or whether he wanted to display his power for the last time, but he suddenly opened the little window, stuck his head out, and shouted in a voice of thunder, obedience! END
BEGIN NOW Then he slammed-to the window. END
BEGIN NOW The peasants' bewilderment was certainly not dispelled nor decreased by this proceeding. END
BEGIN NOW They became stonier than ever, and even seemed to cease looking at anything. END
BEGIN NOW The group of house-serfs (among them were two sturdy wenches, in short chintz gowns, with muscles such as one might perhaps match in Michael Angelo's Last Judgment, and one utterly decrepit old man, hoary with age and half blind, in a threadbare frieze cloak, rumoured to have been cornet-player in the days of Potemkin,&mdash;the page Maximka, Harlov had reserved for himself) this group showed more life than the peasants; at least, it moved restlessly about. END
BEGIN NOW The new mistresses themselves were very dignified in their attitude, especially Anna. END
BEGIN NOW Her thin lips tightly compressed, she looked obstinately down\. END
BEGIN NOW her stern figure augured little good to the house-serfs. END
BEGIN NOW Evlampia, too, did not raise her eyes; only once she turned round and deliberately, as it were with surprise, scanned her betrothed, Zhitkov, who had thought fit, following Sletkin, to come out, too, on to the steps. END
BEGIN NOW What business have you here? END
BEGIN NOW those handsome prominent eyes seemed to demand. END
BEGIN NOW Sletkin was the most changed of all. END
BEGIN NOW A bustling cheeriness showed itself in his whole bearing, as though he were overtaken by hunger; the movements of his head and his legs were as obsequious as ever, but how gleefully he kept working his arms, how fussily he twitched his shoulder-blades. END
BEGIN NOW Arrived at last! END
BEGIN NOW he seemed to say. END
BEGIN NOW Having finished the ceremony of the entrance into possession, the police captain, whose mouth was literally watering at the prospect of lunch, rubbed his hands in that peculiar manner which usually precedes the tossing-off of the first glass of spirits. END
BEGIN NOW But it appeared that Martin Petrovitch wished first to have a service performed with sprinklings of holy water. END
BEGIN NOW The priest put on an ancient and decrepit chasuble; a decrepit deacon came out of the kitchen, with difficulty kindling the incense in an old brazen church-vessel. END
BEGIN NOW The service began. END
BEGIN NOW Harlov sighed continually; he was unable, owing to his corpulence, to bow to the ground, but crossing himself with his right hand and bending his head, he pointed with the forefinger of his left hand to the floor. END
BEGIN NOW Sletkin positively beamed and even shed tears. END
BEGIN NOW Zhitkov, with dignity, in martial fashion, flourished his fingers only slightly between the third and fourth button of his uniform. END
BEGIN NOW Kvitsinsky, as a Catholic, remained in the next room. END
BEGIN NOW But the attorney prayed so fervently, sighed so sympathetically after Martin Petrovitch, and so persistently muttered and chewed his lips, turning his eyes upwards, that I felt moved, as I looked at him, and began to pray fervently too. END
BEGIN NOW At the conclusion of the service and the sprinkling with holy water, during which every one present, even the blind cornet-player, the contemporary of Potemkin, even Kvitsinsky, moistened their eyes with holy water, Anna and Evlampia once more, at Martin Petrovitch's bidding, prostrated themselves to the ground to thank him. END
BEGIN NOW Then at last came the moment of lunch. END
BEGIN NOW There were a great many dishes and all very nice; we all ate terribly much. END
BEGIN NOW The inevitable bottle of Don wine made its appearance. END
BEGIN NOW The police captain, who was of all of us the most familiar with the usages of the world, and besides, the representative of government, was the first to propose the toast to the health of the fair proprietresses! END
BEGIN NOW Then he proposed we should drink to the health of our most honoured and most generous-hearted friend, Martin Petrovitch. END
BEGIN NOW At the words most generous-hearted, Sletkin uttered a shrill little cry and ran to kiss his benefactor.\. END
BEGIN NOW There, that'll do, that'll do, muttered Harlov, as it were with annoyance, keeping him off with his elbow\. END
BEGIN NOW But at this point a not quite pleasant, as they say, incident took place. END
BEGIN NOW SOUVENIR, who had been drinking continuously ever since the beginning of luncheon, suddenly got up from his chair as red as a beetroot, and pointing his finger at Martin Petrovitch, went off into his mawkish, paltry laugh. END
BEGIN NOW Generous-hearted! END
BEGIN NOW Generous-hearted! END
BEGIN NOW he began croaking; but we shall see whether this generosity will be much to his taste when he's stripped naked, the servant of God\. END
BEGIN NOW and out in the snow, too! END
BEGIN NOW What rot are you talking, fool? END
BEGIN NOW said Harlov contemptuously. END
BEGIN NOW Fool! END
BEGIN NOW fool! END
BEGIN NOW repeated Souvenir. END
BEGIN NOW God Almighty alone knows which of us is the real fool. END
BEGIN NOW But you, brother, did my sister, your wife, to her death, and now you've done for yourself\. END
BEGIN NOW ha-ha-ha! END
BEGIN NOW How dare you insult our honoured benefactor? END
BEGIN NOW Sletkin began shrilly, and, tearing himself away from Martin Petrovitch, whose shoulder he had clutched, he flew at Souvenir. END
BEGIN NOW But let me tell you, if our benefactor desires it, we can cancel the deed this very minute! END
BEGIN NOW And yet, you'll strip him naked, and turn him out into the snow\. END
BEGIN NOW returned Souvenir, retreating behind Kvitsinsky. END
BEGIN NOW Silence! END
BEGIN NOW thundered Harlov. END
BEGIN NOW I'll pound you into a jelly! END
BEGIN NOW And you hold your tongue too, puppy! END
BEGIN NOW he turned to Sletkin; don't put in your word where you're not wanted! END
BEGIN NOW If I, Martin Petrovitch Harlov, have decided to make a deed of partition, who can cancel the same act against my will? END
BEGIN NOW Why, in the whole world there is no power.\. END
BEGIN NOW Martin Petrovitch! END
BEGIN NOW the attorney began in a mellow bass&mdash;he too had drunk a good deal, but his dignity was only increased thereby&mdash; but how if the gentleman has spoken the truth? END
BEGIN NOW You have done a generous action; to be sure, but how if&mdash;God forbid&mdash;in reality in place of fitting gratitude, some affront come of it? END
BEGIN NOW I stole a glance at both Martin Petrovitch's daughters. END
BEGIN NOW Anna's eyes were simply pinned upon the speaker, and a face more spiteful, more snake-like, and more beautiful in its very spite I had certainly never seen! END
BEGIN NOW Evlampia sat turned away, with her arms folded. END
BEGIN NOW A smile more scornful than ever curved her full, rosy lips. END
BEGIN NOW Harlov got up from his chair, opened his mouth, but apparently his tongue failed him.\. END
BEGIN NOW He suddenly brought his fist down on the table, so that everything in the room danced and rang. END
BEGIN NOW Father, Anna said hurriedly, they do not know us, and that is why they judge of us so. END
BEGIN NOW But don't, please, make yourself ill. You are angered for nothing, indeed; see, your face is, as it were, twisted awry. END
BEGIN NOW Harlov looked towards Evlampia; she did not stir, though Zhitkov, sitting beside her, gave her a poke in the side. END
BEGIN NOW Thank you, my daughter Anna, said Harlov huskily; you are a sensible girl; I rely upon you and on your husband too. END
BEGIN NOW Sletkin once more gave vent to a shrill little sound; Zhitkov expanded his chest and gave a little scrape with his foot; but Harlov did not observe his efforts. END
BEGIN NOW This dolt, he went on, with a motion of his chin in the direction of Souvenir, is pleased to get a chance to tease me; but you, my dear sir, he addressed himself to the attorney, it is not for you to pass judgment on Martin Harlov; that is something beyond you. END
BEGIN NOW Though you are a man in official position, your words are most foolish. END
BEGIN NOW Besides, the deed is done, there will be no going back from my determination.\. END
BEGIN NOW Now, I will wish you good-day, I am going away. END
BEGIN NOW I am no longer the master of this house, but a guest in it. END
BEGIN NOW Anna, do you do your best; but I will go to my own room. END
BEGIN NOW Enough! END
BEGIN NOW Martin Petrovitch turned his back on us, and, without adding another word, walked deliberately out of the room. END
BEGIN NOW This sudden withdrawal on the part of our host could not but break up the party, especially as the two hostesses also vanished not long after. END
BEGIN NOW Sletkin vainly tried to keep us. END
BEGIN NOW The police captain did not fail to blame the attorney for his uncalled-for candour. END
BEGIN NOW Couldn't help it! END
BEGIN NOW the latter responded.\. END
BEGIN NOW My conscience spoke. END
BEGIN NOW There, you see that he's a mason, Souvenir whispered to me. END
BEGIN NOW Conscience! END
BEGIN NOW retorted the police captain. END
BEGIN NOW We know all about your conscience! END
BEGIN NOW I suppose it's in your pocket, just the same as it is with us sinners! END
BEGIN NOW The priest, meanwhile, even though already on his feet, foreseeing the speedy termination of the repast, lifted mouthful after mouthful to his mouth without a pause. END
BEGIN NOW You've got a fine appetite, I see, Sletkin observed to him sharply. END
BEGIN NOW Storing up for the future, the priest responded with a meek grimace; years of hunger were expressed in that reply. END
BEGIN NOW The carriages rattled up\. END
BEGIN NOW and we separated. END
BEGIN NOW On the way home, no one hindered Souvenir's chatter and silly tricks, as Kvitsinsky had announced that he was sick of all this wholly superfluous unpleasantness, and had set off home before us on foot. END
BEGIN NOW In his place, Zhitkov took a seat in our coach. END
BEGIN NOW The retired major wore a most dissatisfied expression, and kept twitching his moustaches like a spider. END
BEGIN NOW Well, your noble Excellency, lisped Souvenir, is subordination exploded, eh? END
BEGIN NOW Wait a bit and see what will happen! END
BEGIN NOW They'll give you the sack too. END
BEGIN NOW Ah, a poor bridegroom you are, a poor bridegroom, an unlucky bridegroom! END
BEGIN NOW Souvenir was positively beside himself; while poor Zhitkov could do nothing but twitch his moustaches. END
BEGIN NOW When I got home I told my mother all I had seen. END
BEGIN NOW She heard me to the end, and shook her head several times. END
BEGIN NOW It's a bad business, was her comment. END
BEGIN NOW I don't like all these innovations! END
BEGIN NOW NEXT day Martin Petrovitch came to dinner. END
BEGIN NOW My mother congratulated him on the successful conclusion of his project. END
BEGIN NOW You are now a free man, she said, and ought to feel more at ease. END
BEGIN NOW More at ease, to be sure, madam, answered Martin Petrovitch, by no means, however, showing in the expression of his face that he really was more at ease. END
BEGIN NOW Now I can meditate upon my soul, and make ready for my last hour, as I ought. END
BEGIN NOW Well, queried my mother, and do the shooting pains still tingle in your arms? END
BEGIN NOW Harlov twice clenched and unclenched his left arm. END
BEGIN NOW They do, madam; and I've something else to tell you. END
BEGIN NOW As I begin to drop asleep, some one cries in my head, 'Take care!' END
BEGIN NOW 'Take care!' END
BEGIN NOW That's nerves, observed my mother, and she began speaking of the previous day, and referred to certain circumstances which had attended the completion of the deed of partition.\. END
BEGIN NOW To be sure, to be sure, Harlov interrupted her, there was something of the sort\. END
BEGIN NOW of no consequence. END
BEGIN NOW Only there's something I would tell you, he added, hesitating&mdash; I was not disturbed yesterday by Souvenir's silly words&mdash;even Mr. Attorney, though he's no fool&mdash;even he did not trouble me; no, it was quite another person disturbed me&mdash;- Here Harlov faltered. END
BEGIN NOW Who? END
BEGIN NOW asked my mother. END
BEGIN NOW Harlov fastened his eyes upon her: Evlampia! END
BEGIN NOW Evlampia? END
BEGIN NOW Your daughter? END
BEGIN NOW How was that? END
BEGIN NOW Upon my word, madam, she was like a stone! END
BEGIN NOW nothing but a statue! END
BEGIN NOW Can it be she has no feeling? END
BEGIN NOW Her sister, Anna&mdash;well, she was all she should be. END
BEGIN NOW She's a keen-witted creature! END
BEGIN NOW But Evlampia&mdash;why, I'd shown her&mdash;I must own&mdash;so much partiality! END
BEGIN NOW Can it be she's no feeling for me! END
BEGIN NOW It's clear I'm in a bad way; it's clear I've a feeling that I'm not long for this world, since I make over everything to them; and yet she's like a stone! END
BEGIN NOW she might at least utter a sound! END
BEGIN NOW Bows&mdash;yes, she bows, but there's no thankfulness to be seen. END
BEGIN NOW There, give over, observed my mother, we'll marry her to Gavrila Fedulitch\. END
BEGIN NOW she'll soon get softer in his hands. END
BEGIN NOW Martin Petrovitch once more looked from under his brows at my mother. END
BEGIN NOW Well, there's Gavrila Fedulitch, to be sure! END
BEGIN NOW You have confidence in him, then, madam? END
BEGIN NOW I've confidence in him. END
BEGIN NOW Very well; you should know best, to be sure. END
BEGIN NOW But Evlampia, let me tell you, is like me. END
BEGIN NOW The character is just the same. END
BEGIN NOW She has the wild Cossack blood, and her heart's like a burning coal! END
BEGIN NOW Why, do you mean to tell me you've a heart like that, my dear sir? END
BEGIN NOW Harlov made no answer. END
BEGIN NOW A brief silence followed. END
BEGIN NOW What are you going to do, Martin Petrovitch, my mother began, in what way do you mean to set about saving your soul now? END
BEGIN NOW Will you set off to Mitrophan or to Kiev, or may be you'll go to the Optin desert, as it's in the neighbourhood? END
BEGIN NOW There, they do say, there's a holy monk appeared\. END
BEGIN NOW Father Makary they call him, no one remembers any one like him! END
BEGIN NOW He sees right through all sins. END
BEGIN NOW If she really turns out an ungrateful daughter, Harlov enunciated in a husky voice, then it would be better for me, I believe, to kill her with my own hands! END
BEGIN NOW What are you saying! END
BEGIN NOW Lord, have mercy on you! END
BEGIN NOW cried my mother. END
BEGIN NOW Think what you're saying! END
BEGIN NOW There, see, what a pretty pass it's come to. END
BEGIN NOW You should have listened to me the other day when you came to consult me! END
BEGIN NOW Now, here, you'll go tormenting yourself, instead of thinking of your soul! END
BEGIN NOW You'll be tormenting yourself, and all to no purpose! END
BEGIN NOW Yes! END
BEGIN NOW Here you're complaining now, and fainthearted\. END
BEGIN NOW This reproach seemed to stab Harlov to the heart. END
BEGIN NOW All his old pride came back to him with a rush. END
BEGIN NOW He shook himself and thrust out his chin. END
BEGIN NOW I am not a man, madam, Natalia Nikolaevna, to complain or be faint-hearted, he began sullenly. END
BEGIN NOW I simply wished to reveal my feelings to you as my benefactress and a person I respect. END
BEGIN NOW But the Lord God knows (here he raised his hand high above his head) that this globe of earth may crumble to pieces before I will go back from my word, or\. END
BEGIN NOW (here he positively snorted) show a faint heart, or regret what I have done! END
BEGIN NOW I had good reasons, be sure! END
BEGIN NOW My daughters will never forget their duty, for ever and ever, amen! END
BEGIN NOW My mother stopped her ears. END
BEGIN NOW What's this for, my good sir, like a trumpet-blast! END
BEGIN NOW If you really have such faith in your family, well, praise the Lord for it! END
BEGIN NOW You've quite put my brains in a whirl! END
BEGIN NOW Martin Petrovitch begged pardon, sighed twice, and was silent. END
BEGIN NOW My mother once more referred to Kiev, the Optin desert, and Father Makary.\. END
BEGIN NOW Harlov assented, said that he must\. END
BEGIN NOW he must\. END
BEGIN NOW he would have to\. END
BEGIN NOW his soul\. END
BEGIN NOW and that was all. END
BEGIN NOW He did not regain his cheerfulness before he went away. END
