BEGIN NOW From time to time he clenched and unclenched his fist, looked at his open hand, said that what he feared above everything was dying without repentance, from a stroke, and that he had made a vow to himself not to get angry, as anger vitiated his blood and drove it to his head.\. END
BEGIN NOW Besides, he had now withdrawn from everything. END
BEGIN NOW What grounds could he have for getting angry? END
BEGIN NOW Let other people trouble themselves now and vitiate their blood! END
BEGIN NOW As he took leave of my mother he looked at her in a strange way, mournfully and questioningly.\. END
BEGIN NOW and suddenly, with a rapid movement, drew out of his pocket the volume of The Worker's Leisure-Hour, and thrust it into my mother's hand. END
BEGIN NOW What's that? END
BEGIN NOW she inquired. END
BEGIN NOW Read\. END
BEGIN NOW here, he said hurriedly, where the corner's turned down, about death. END
BEGIN NOW It seems to me, it's terribly well said, but I can't make it out at all. END
BEGIN NOW Can't you explain it to me, my benefactress? END
BEGIN NOW I'll come back again and you explain it me. END
BEGIN NOW With these words Martin Petrovitch went away. END
BEGIN NOW He's in a bad way, he's in a bad way, observed my mother, directly he had disappeared through the doorway, and she set to work upon the Leisure-Hour. END
BEGIN NOW On the page turned down by Harlov were the following words: Death is a grand and solemn work of nature. END
BEGIN NOW It is nothing else than that the spirit, inasmuch as it is lighter, finer, and infinitely more penetrating than those elements under whose sway it has been subject, nay, even than the force of electricity itself, so is chemically purified and striveth upward till what time it attaineth an equally spiritual abiding-place for itself\. END
BEGIN NOW and so on. END
BEGIN NOW My mother read this passage through twice, and exclaiming, Pooh! END
BEGIN NOW she flung the book away. END
BEGIN NOW Three days later, she received the news that her sister's husband was dead, and set off to her sister's country-seat, taking me with her. END
BEGIN NOW My mother proposed to spend a month with her, but she stayed on till late in the autumn, and it was only at the end of September that we returned to our own estate. END
BEGIN NOW THE first news with which my valet, Prokofy, greeted me (he regarded himself as the seignorial huntsman) was that there was an immense number of wild snipe on the wing, and that in the birch-copse near Eskovo (Harlov's property), especially, they were simply swarming. END
BEGIN NOW I had three hours before me till dinner-time. END
BEGIN NOW I promptly seized my gun and my game-bag, and with Prokofy and a setter-dog, hastened to the Eskovo copse. END
BEGIN NOW We certainly did find a great many wild snipe there, and, firing about thirty charges, killed five. END
BEGIN NOW As I hurried homewards with my booty, I saw a peasant ploughing near the road-side. END
BEGIN NOW His horse had stopped, and with tearful and angry abuse he was mercilessly tugging with the cord reins at the animal's head, which was bent on one side. END
BEGIN NOW I looked attentively at the luckless beast, whose ribs were all but through its skin, and, bathed in sweat, heaved up and down with convulsive, irregular movements like a blacksmith's bellows. END
BEGIN NOW I recognised it at once as the decrepit old mare, with the scar on her shoulder, who had served Martin Petrovitch so many years. END
BEGIN NOW Is Mr. Harlov living? END
BEGIN NOW I asked Prokofy. END
BEGIN NOW The chase had so completely absorbed us, that up to that instant we had not talked of anything. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, he's alive. END

BEGIN NOW IN the middle of October, three weeks after my interview with Martin Petrovitch, I was standing at the window of my own room in the second storey of our house, and thinking of nothing at all, I looked disconsolately into the yard and the road that lay beyond it. END
BEGIN NOW The weather had been disgusting for the last five days. END
BEGIN NOW Shooting was not even to be thought of. END
BEGIN NOW All things living had hidden themselves; even the sparrows made no sound, and the rooks had long ago disappeared from sight. END
BEGIN NOW The wind howled drearily, then whistled spasmodically. END
BEGIN NOW The low-hanging sky, unbroken by one streak of light, had changed from an unpleasant whitish to a leaden and still more sinister hue; and the rain, which had been pouring and pouring, mercilessly and unceasingly, had suddenly become still more violent and more driving, and streamed with a rushing sound over the panes. END
BEGIN NOW The trees had been stripped utterly bare, and turned a sort of grey. END
BEGIN NOW It seemed they had nothing left to plunder; yet the wind would not be denied, but set to harassing them once more. END
BEGIN NOW Puddles, clogged with dead leaves, stood everywhere. END
BEGIN NOW Big bubbles, continually bursting and rising up again, leaped and glided over them. END

BEGIN NOW The cold pierced its way indoors through one's clothes to the very bones. END

BEGIN NOW Sick, precisely, not sad. END
BEGIN NOW It seemed there would never again in the world be sunshine, nor brightness, nor colour, but this rain and mire and grey damp, and raw fog would last for ever, and for ever would the wind whine and moan! END
BEGIN NOW Well, I was standing moodily at my window, and I remember a sudden darkness came on&mdash;a bluish darkness&mdash;though the clock only pointed to twelve. END

BEGIN NOW I was puzzled; I could not understand how it was that Harlov, who had endured the insults of his own family almost without a murmur, had lost all self-control, and been unable to put up with the jeers and pin-pricks of such an abject creature as Souvenir. END
BEGIN NOW I did not understand in those days what insufferable bitterness there may sometimes be in a foolish taunt, even when it comes from lips one scorns.\. END
BEGIN NOW The hated name of Sletkin, uttered by Souvenir, had been like a spark thrown into powder. END
BEGIN NOW The sore spot could not endure this final prick. END
BEGIN NOW About an hour passed by. END
BEGIN NOW Our coach drove into the yard; but our steward sat in it alone. END
BEGIN NOW And my mother had said to him&mdash; don't let me see you without him. END
BEGIN NOW Kvitsinsky jumped hurriedly out of the carriage, and ran up the steps. END
BEGIN NOW His face had a perturbed look&mdash;something very unusual with him. END
BEGIN NOW I promptly rushed downstairs, and followed at his heels into the drawing-room. END
BEGIN NOW Well? END
BEGIN NOW have you brought him? END
BEGIN NOW asked my mother. END
BEGIN NOW I have not brought him, answered Kvitsinsky&mdash; and I could not bring him. END
BEGIN NOW How's that? END
BEGIN NOW Have you seen him? END
BEGIN NOW Yes. END
BEGIN NOW What has happened to him? END
BEGIN NOW A fit? END
BEGIN NOW No; nothing has happened. END
BEGIN NOW How is it you didn't bring him? END
BEGIN NOW He's pulling his house to pieces. END
BEGIN NOW What? END
BEGIN NOW He's standing on the roof of the new building, and pulling it to pieces. END
BEGIN NOW Forty boards or more, I should guess, must have come down by now, and some five of the rafters too. END
BEGIN NOW ( They shall not have a roof over their heads. END
BEGIN NOW Harlov's words came back to me.) END
BEGIN NOW My mother stared at Kvitsinsky. END
BEGIN NOW Alone\. END
BEGIN NOW he's standing on the roof, and pulling the roof down? END
BEGIN NOW Exactly so. END
BEGIN NOW He is walking about on the flooring of the garret in the roof, and smashing right and left of him. END
BEGIN NOW His strength, you are aware, madam, is superhuman. END
BEGIN NOW And the roof too, one must say, is a poor affair; half-inch deal battens, laid wide apart, one inch nails. END
BEGIN NOW My mother looked at me, as though wishing to make sure whether she had heard aright. END
BEGIN NOW Half-inches wide apart, she repeated, obviously not understanding the meaning of one word. END
BEGIN NOW Well, what then? END
BEGIN NOW she said at last. END
BEGIN NOW I have come for instructions. END
BEGIN NOW There's no doing anything without men to help. END
BEGIN NOW The peasants there are all limp with fright. END
BEGIN NOW And his daughters&mdash;what of them? END
BEGIN NOW His daughters are doing nothing. END
BEGIN NOW They're running to and fro, shouting\. END
BEGIN NOW this and that\. END
BEGIN NOW all to no purpose. END

BEGIN NOW He's there too. END
BEGIN NOW He's making more outcry than all of them&mdash;but he can't do anything. END
BEGIN NOW And Martin Petrovitch is standing on the roof? END
BEGIN NOW On the roof\. END
BEGIN NOW that is, in the garret&mdash;and pulling the roof to pieces. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, yes, said my mother, half-inches wide apart. END
BEGIN NOW The position was obviously a serious one. END
BEGIN NOW What steps were to be taken? END
BEGIN NOW Send to the town for the police captain? END
BEGIN NOW Get together the peasants? END
BEGIN NOW My mother was quite at her wits' end. END
BEGIN NOW Zhitkov, who had come in to dinner, was nonplussed too. END
BEGIN NOW It is true, he made another reference to a battalion of military; he offered no advice, however, but confined himself to looking submissive and devoted. END
BEGIN NOW Kvitsinsky, seeing he would not get at any instructions, suggested to my mother&mdash;with the contemptuous respectfulness peculiar to him&mdash;that if she would authorise him to take a few of the stable-boys, gardeners, and other house-serfs, he would make an effort\. END
BEGIN NOW Yes, yes, my mother cut him short, do make an effort, dear Vikenty Osipitch! END

BEGIN NOW Kvitsinsky smiled coldly. END
BEGIN NOW One thing let me make clear, madam, beforehand; it s impossible to reckon on any result, seeing that Mr. Harlov's strength is so great, and he is so desperate too; he feels himself to have been very cruelly wronged! END

BEGIN NOW You'd better take plenty of cord, Mr. END
BEGIN NOW Steward, and some fire-escape tackle, Zhitkov brought out in his bass&mdash; and if there is such a thing as a net, it would be as well to take that along too. END
BEGIN NOW We once had in our regiment\. END
BEGIN NOW Kindly refrain from instructing me, sir, Kvitsinsky cut him short, with an air of vexation; I know what is needed without your aid. END
BEGIN NOW Zhitkov was offended, and protested that as he imagined he, too, was called upon\. END

BEGIN NOW Zhitkov was still more offended, while Kvitsinsky bowed and went out. END
BEGIN NOW I rushed off to the stable, hurriedly saddled my horse myself, and set off at a gallop along the road to Eskovo. END
BEGIN NOW THE rain had ceased, but the wind was blowing with redoubled force&mdash;straight into my face. END
BEGIN NOW Half-way there, the saddle almost slipped round under me; the girth had got loose; I got off and tried to tighten the straps with my teeth.\. END

BEGIN NOW Souvenir was running towards me across the green fields. END
BEGIN NOW What! END
BEGIN NOW he shouted to me from some way off, was your curiosity too much for you? END
BEGIN NOW But it's no use\. END
BEGIN NOW I went over there, straight, at Harlov's heels\. END
BEGIN NOW Such a state of things you never saw in your life! END
BEGIN NOW You want to enjoy what you have done, I said indignantly, and, jumping on my horse, I set off again at a gallop. END
BEGIN NOW But the indefatigable Souvenir did not give me up, and chuckled and grinned, even as he ran. END
BEGIN NOW At last, Eskovo was reached&mdash;there was the dam, and there the long hedge and willow-tree of the homestead\. END
BEGIN NOW I rode up to the gate, dismounted, tied up my horse, and stood still in amazement. END
BEGIN NOW Of one third of the roof of the newer house, of the front part, nothing was left but the skeleton; boards and litter lay in disorderly heaps on the ground on both sides of the building. END
BEGIN NOW Even supposing the roof to be, as Kvitsinsky had said, a poor affair, even so, it was something incredible! END

END
BEGIN NOW It was Harlov. END
BEGIN NOW He struck me as being exactly like a bear at this moment too; the head, and back, and shoulders were a bear's, and he put his feet down wide apart without bending the insteps&mdash;also like a bear. END

BEGIN NOW A few peasants huddled together in a separate group, a little way off. END

BEGIN NOW Beside the priest, stood Evlampia with her back against the wall, gazing fixedly at her father. END
BEGIN NOW Anna, at one moment, pushed her head out of the little window, then vanished, then hurried into the yard, then went back into the house. END
BEGIN NOW Sletkin&mdash;pale all over, livid&mdash;in an old dressing-gown and smoking-cap, with a single-barrelled rifle in his hands, kept running to and fro with little steps. END
BEGIN NOW He had completely gone Jewish, as it is called. END
BEGIN NOW He was gasping, threatening, shaking, pointing the gun at Harlov, then letting it drop back on his shoulder&mdash;pointing it again, shrieking, weeping.\. END

BEGIN NOW Look, look, what is going on here! END
BEGIN NOW he wailed&mdash; look! END
BEGIN NOW He's gone out of his mind, he's raving mad\. END
BEGIN NOW and see what he's doing! END
BEGIN NOW I've sent for the police already&mdash;but no one comes! END
BEGIN NOW No one comes! END
BEGIN NOW If I do fire at him, the law couldn't touch me, for every man has a right to defend his own property! END
BEGIN NOW And I will fire!\.\. END
BEGIN NOW By God, I'll fire! END
BEGIN NOW He ran off toward the house. END
BEGIN NOW Martin Petrovitch, look out! END
BEGIN NOW If you don't get down, I'll fire! END
BEGIN NOW Fire away! END
BEGIN NOW came a husky voice from the roof. END
BEGIN NOW Fire away! END
BEGIN NOW And meanwhile here's a little present for you! END
BEGIN NOW A long plank flew up, and, turning over twice in the air, came violently to the earth, just at Sletkin's feet. END
BEGIN NOW He positively jumped into the air, while Harlov chuckled. END
BEGIN NOW Merciful Jesus! END
BEGIN NOW faltered some one behind me. END
BEGIN NOW I looked round: Souvenir. END
BEGIN NOW Ah! END
BEGIN NOW I thought, he's left off laughing now! END
BEGIN NOW Sletkin clutched a peasant, who was standing near, by the collar. END
BEGIN NOW Climb up now, climb up, climb up, all of you, you devils, he wailed, shaking the man with all his force, save my property! END
BEGIN NOW The peasant took a couple of steps forward, threw his head back, waved his arms, shouted&mdash; Hi! END
BEGIN NOW here master! END
BEGIN NOW shifted from one foot to the other uneasily, and then turned back. END
BEGIN NOW A ladder! END
BEGIN NOW bring a ladder! END
BEGIN NOW Sletkin addressed the other peasants. END
BEGIN NOW Where are we to get it? END
BEGIN NOW was heard in answer. END
BEGIN NOW And if we had a ladder, one voice pronounced deliberately, who'd care to climb up? END
BEGIN NOW Not such fools! END
BEGIN NOW He'd wring your neck for you&mdash;in a twinkling! END
BEGIN NOW He'd kill one in no time, said one young lad with flaxen hair and a half-idiotic face. END
BEGIN NOW To be sure he would, the others confirmed. END
BEGIN NOW It struck me that, even if there had been no obvious danger, the peasants would yet have been loath to carry out their new owner's orders. END
BEGIN NOW They almost approved of Harlov, though they were amazed at him. END
BEGIN NOW Ugh, you robbers! END
BEGIN NOW moaned Sletkin; you shall all catch it\. END
BEGIN NOW But at this moment, with a heavy rumble, the last chimney came crashing down, and, in the midst of the cloud of yellow dust that flew up instantly, Harlov&mdash;uttering a piercing shriek and lifting his bleeding hands high in the air&mdash;turned facing us. END
BEGIN NOW Sletkin pointed the gun at him again. END

BEGIN NOW my delightful daughter! END

BEGIN NOW How d'ye do! END

BEGIN NOW rang out Evlampia's musical voice. END
BEGIN NOW Eh, daughter? END
BEGIN NOW answered Harlov; and he came down to the very edge of the wall. END
BEGIN NOW His face, as far as I could make it out, wore a strange smile, a bright, mirthful&mdash;and for that very reason peculiarly strange and evil&mdash;smile.\. END
BEGIN NOW Many years later I saw just the same smile on the face of a man condemned to death. END

BEGIN NOW We are in fault; we give everything back to you. END
BEGIN NOW Come down. END

BEGIN NOW Evlampia merely scowled more angrily. END
BEGIN NOW I give you back my share. END
BEGIN NOW I give up everything. END
BEGIN NOW Give over, come down, father! END
BEGIN NOW Forgive us; forgive me. END
BEGIN NOW Harlov still went on smiling. END
BEGIN NOW It's too late, my darling, he said, and each of his words rang out like brass. END
BEGIN NOW Too late your stony heart is touched! END
BEGIN NOW The rock's started rolling downhill&mdash;there's no holding it back now! END
BEGIN NOW And don't look to me now; I'm a doomed man! END
BEGIN NOW You'd do better to look to your Volodka; see what a pretty fellow you've picked out! END
BEGIN NOW And look to your hellish sister; there's her foxy nose yonder thrust out of the window; she's peering yonder after that husband of hers! END

BEGIN NOW yes, we were puffed up, we have sinned; come, forgive! END
BEGIN NOW Harlov shook his head. END
BEGIN NOW Talk away! END
BEGIN NOW Me believe you! END
BEGIN NOW Never again! END
BEGIN NOW You've murdered all trust in my heart! END
BEGIN NOW You've murdered everything! END
BEGIN NOW I was an eagle, and became a worm for you\. END
BEGIN NOW and you,&mdash;would you even crush the worm? END
BEGIN NOW Have done! END
BEGIN NOW I loved you, you know very well,&mdash;but now you are no daughter to me, and I'm no father to you\. END

BEGIN NOW Don't meddle! END
BEGIN NOW As for you, fire away, coward, mighty man of valour! END
BEGIN NOW Harlov bellowed suddenly at Sletkin. END
BEGIN NOW Why is it you keep aiming and don't shoot? END
BEGIN NOW Are you mindful of the law; if the recipient of a gift commits an attempt upon the life of the giver, Harlov enunciated distinctly, then the giver is empowered to claim everything back again? END

BEGIN NOW don't be afraid, law-abiding man! END
BEGIN NOW I'd make no claims. END
BEGIN NOW I'll make an end of everything myself.\. END
BEGIN NOW Here goes! END
BEGIN NOW Father! END
BEGIN NOW for the last time Evlampia besought him. END
BEGIN NOW Silence! END
BEGIN NOW Martin Petrovitch! END
BEGIN NOW brother, be generous and forgive! END
BEGIN NOW faltered Souvenir. END
BEGIN NOW Father! END
BEGIN NOW dear father! END
BEGIN NOW Silence, bitch! END
BEGIN NOW shouted Harlov. END
BEGIN NOW At Souvenir he did not even glance,&mdash;he merely spat in his direction. END
BEGIN NOW AT that instant, Kvitsinsky, with all his retinue&mdash;in three carts&mdash;appeared at the gates. END
BEGIN NOW The tired horses panted, the men jumped out, one after another, into the mud. END
BEGIN NOW Aha! END
BEGIN NOW Harlov shouted at the top of his voice. END
BEGIN NOW An army\. END
BEGIN NOW here it comes, an army! END
BEGIN NOW A whole army they're sending against me! END
BEGIN NOW Capital! END
BEGIN NOW Only I give warning&mdash;if any one comes up here to me on the roof, I'll send him flying down, head over heels! END
BEGIN NOW I'm an inhospitable master; I don't like visitors at wrong times! END
BEGIN NOW No indeed! END
BEGIN NOW He was hanging with both hands on to the front rafters of the roof, the so-called standards of the gable, and beginning to shake them violently. END
BEGIN NOW Balancing on the edge of the garret flooring, he dragged them, as it were, after him, chanting rhythmically like a bargeman, One more pull! END
BEGIN NOW one more! END
BEGIN NOW o-oh! END
BEGIN NOW Sletkin ran up to Kvitsinsky and was beginning to whimper and pour out complaints.\. END
BEGIN NOW The latter begged him not to interfere, and proceeded to carry out the plan he had evolved. END
BEGIN NOW He took up his position in front of the house, and began, by way of diversion, to explain to Harlov that what he was about was unworthy of his rank.\. END
BEGIN NOW One more pull! END
BEGIN NOW one more! END
BEGIN NOW chanted Harlov.\. END
BEGIN NOW That Natalia Nikolaevna was greatly displeased at his proceedings, and had not expected it of him.\. END
BEGIN NOW One more pull! END
BEGIN NOW one more! END
BEGIN NOW o-oh! END
BEGIN NOW Harlov chanted\. END
BEGIN NOW while, meantime, Kvitsinsky had despatched the four sturdiest and boldest of the stable-boys to the other side of the house to clamber up the roof from behind. END
BEGIN NOW Harlov, however, detected the plan of attack; he suddenly left the standards and ran quickly to the back part of the roof. END
BEGIN NOW His appearance was so alarming that the two stable-boys who had already got up to the garret, dropped instantly back again to the ground by the water-pipe, to the great glee of the serf boys, who positively roared with laughter. END
BEGIN NOW Harlov shook his fist after them and, going back to the front part of the house, again clutched at the standards and began once more loosening them, singing again, like a bargeman. END
BEGIN NOW Suddenly he stopped, stared.\. END
BEGIN NOW Maximushka, my dear! END
BEGIN NOW my friend! END
BEGIN NOW he cried; is it you? END
BEGIN NOW I looked round.\. END
BEGIN NOW There, actually, was Maximka, stepping out from the crowd of peasants. END
BEGIN NOW Grinning and showing his teeth, he walked forward. END
BEGIN NOW His master, the tailor, had probably let him come home for a holiday. END
BEGIN NOW Climb up to me, Maximushka, my faithful servant, Harlov went on; together let us rid ourselves of evil Tartar folk, of Lithuanian thieves! END
BEGIN NOW Maximka, still grinning, promptly began climbing up the roof.\. END
BEGIN NOW But they seized him and pulled him back&mdash;goodness knows why; possibly as an example to the rest; he could hardly have been much aid to Martin Petrovitch. END
BEGIN NOW Oh, all right! END
BEGIN NOW Good! END
BEGIN NOW Harlov pronounced, in a voice of menace, and again he took hold of the standards. END
BEGIN NOW Vikenty Osipovitch! END
BEGIN NOW with your permission, I'll shoot, Sletkin turned to Kvitsinsky; more to frighten him, see, than anything; my gun's only charged with snipe-shot. END
BEGIN NOW But Kvitsinsky had not time to answer him, when the front couple of standards, viciously shaken in Harlov's iron hands, heeled over with a loud crack and crashed into the yard; and with it, not able to stop himself, came Harlov too, and fell with a heavy thud on the earth. END
BEGIN NOW Every one shuddered and drew a deep breath.\. END
BEGIN NOW Harlov lay without stirring on his breast, and on his back lay the top central beam of the roof, which had come down with the falling gable's timbers. END
BEGIN NOW THEY ran up to Harlov, rolled the beam off him, turned him over on his back. END
BEGIN NOW His face was lifeless, there was blood about his mouth; he did not seem to breathe. END
BEGIN NOW The breath is gone out of him, muttered the peasants, standing about him. END
BEGIN NOW They ran to the well for water, brought a whole bucketful, and drenched Harlov's head. END
BEGIN NOW The mud and dust ran off his face, but he looked as lifeless as ever. END
BEGIN NOW They dragged up a bench, set it in the house itself, and with difficulty raising the huge body of Martin Petrovitch, laid it there with the head to the wall. END
BEGIN NOW The page Maximka approached, fell on one knee, and, his other leg stretched far behind him, in a theatrical way, supported his former master's arm. END

BEGIN NOW Anna and Sletkin did not come near him. END
BEGIN NOW All were silent, all, as it were, waited for something. END
BEGIN NOW At last we heard broken, smacking noises in Harlov's throat, as though he were swallowing.\. END
BEGIN NOW Then he feebly moved one, his right, hand (Maximka supported the left), opened one, the right eye, and slowly gazing about him, as though drunken with some fearful drunkenness, groaned, articulated, stammering, I'm sma-ashed\. END
BEGIN NOW and as though after a moment's thought, added, here it is, the ra.\. END
BEGIN NOW aven co.\. END
BEGIN NOW olt! END
BEGIN NOW The blood suddenly gushed thickly from his mouth\. END
BEGIN NOW his whole body began to quiver.\. END
BEGIN NOW The end! END
BEGIN NOW I thought.\. END
BEGIN NOW But once more Harlov opened the same eye (the left eyelid lay as motionless as on a dead man's face), and fixing it on Evlampia, he articulated, hardly above a breath, Well, daugh.\. END
BEGIN NOW ter\. END
BEGIN NOW you, I do not\. END
BEGIN NOW Kvitsinsky, with a sharp motion of his hand, beckoned to the priest, who was still standing on the step.\. END
BEGIN NOW The old man came up, his narrow cassock clinging about his feeble knees. END
BEGIN NOW But suddenly there was a sort of horrible twitching in Harlov's legs and in his stomach too; an irregular contraction passed upwards over his face. END
BEGIN NOW Evlampia's face seemed quivering and working in the same way. END
BEGIN NOW Maximka began crossing himself\. END
BEGIN NOW I was seized with horror; I ran out to the gates, squeezed myself close to them, not looking round. END
BEGIN NOW A minute later a soft murmur ran through the crowd, behind my back, and I understood that Martin Petrovitch was no more. END
BEGIN NOW His skull had been fractured by the beam and his ribs injured, as it appeared at the post-mortem examination. END
BEGIN NOW WHAT had he wanted to say to her as he lay dying? END
BEGIN NOW I asked myself as I went home on my cob: I do not\. END
BEGIN NOW forgive, or do not\. END
BEGIN NOW pardon. END
BEGIN NOW The rain had come on again, but I rode at a walking pace. END
BEGIN NOW I wanted to be alone as long as possible; I wanted to give myself up to my reflections, unchecked. END
BEGIN NOW Souvenir had gone back in one of the carts that had come with Kvitsinsky. END
BEGIN NOW Young and frivolous as I was at that time, the sudden sweeping change (not in mere details only) that is invariably called forth in all hearts by the coming of death&mdash;expected or unexpected, it makes no difference!&mdash;its majesty, its gravity, and its truthfulness could not fail to impress me. END
BEGIN NOW I was impressed too,\. END
BEGIN NOW but for all that, my troubled, childish eyes noted many things at once; they noted how Sletkin, hurriedly and furtively, as though it were something stolen, popped the gun out of sight; how he and his wife became, both of them, instantly the object of a sort of unspoken but universal aloofness. END
BEGIN NOW To Evlampia, though her fault was probably no less than her sister's, this aloofness did not extend. END
BEGIN NOW She even aroused a certain sympathy, when she fell at her dead father's feet. END
BEGIN NOW But that she too was guilty, that was none the less felt by all. END
BEGIN NOW The old man was wronged, said a grey-haired peasant with a big head, leaning, like some ancient judge, with both hands and his beard on a long staff; on your soul lies the sin! END
BEGIN NOW You wronged him! END
BEGIN NOW That saying was at once accepted by every one as the final judgment. END
BEGIN NOW The peasants' sense of justice found expression in it, I felt that at once. END
BEGIN NOW I noticed too that, at the first, Sletkin did not dare to give directions. END
BEGIN NOW Without him, they lifted up the body and carried it into the other house. END
BEGIN NOW Without asking him, the priest went for everything needful to the church, while the village elder ran to the village to send off a cart and horse to the town. END
BEGIN NOW Even Anna Martinovna did not venture to use her ordinary imperious tone in ordering the samovar to be brought, for hot water, to wash the deceased. END
BEGIN NOW Her orders were more like an entreaty, and she was answered rudely.\. END
BEGIN NOW I was absorbed all the while by the question, What was it exactly he wanted to say to his daughter? END
BEGIN NOW Did he want to forgive her or to curse her? END
BEGIN NOW Finally I decided that it was&mdash;forgiveness. END
BEGIN NOW Three days later, the funeral of Martin Petrovitch took place. END
BEGIN NOW The cost of the ceremony was undertaken by my mother, who was deeply grieved at his death, and gave orders that no expense was to he spared. END
BEGIN NOW She did not herself go to the church, because she was unwilling, as she said, to set eyes on those two vile hussies and that nasty little Jew. END
BEGIN NOW But she sent Kvitsinsky, me, and Zhitkov, though from that time forward she always spoke of the latter as a regular old woman. END
BEGIN NOW Souvenir she did not admit to her presence, and was furious with him for long after, saying that he was the murderer of her friend. END
BEGIN NOW He felt his disgrace acutely; he was continually running, on tiptoe, up and down the room, next to the one where my mother was; he gave himself up to a sort of scared and abject melancholy, shuddering and muttering, d'rectly! END
BEGIN NOW In church, and during the procession, Sletkin struck me as having recovered his self-possession. END
BEGIN NOW He gave directions and bustled about in his old way, and kept a greedy look-out that not a superfluous farthing should be spent, though his own pocket was not in question. END
BEGIN NOW Maximka, in a new Cossack dress, also a present from my mother, gave vent to such tenor notes in the choir, that certainly no one could have any doubts as to the sincerity of his devotion to the deceased. END
BEGIN NOW Both the sisters were duly attired in mourning, but they seemed more stupefied than grieved, especially Evlampia. END
BEGIN NOW Anna wore a meek, Lenten air, but made no attempt to weep, and was continually passing her handsome, thin hand over her hair and cheek. END
BEGIN NOW Evlampia seemed deep in thought all the time. END
BEGIN NOW The universal, unbending alienation, condemnation, which I had noticed on the day of Harlov's death, I detected now too on the faces of all the people in the church, in their actions and their glances, but still more grave and, as it were, impersonal. END
BEGIN NOW It seemed as though all those people felt that the sin into which the Harlov family had fallen&mdash;this great sin&mdash;had gone now before the presence of the one righteous Judge, and that for that reason, there was no need now for them to trouble themselves and be indignant. END
BEGIN NOW They prayed devoutly for the soul of the dead man, whom in life they had not specially liked, whom they had feared indeed. END
BEGIN NOW Very abruptly had death overtaken him. END
BEGIN NOW And it's not as though he had been drinking heavily, brother, said one peasant to another, in the porch. END
BEGIN NOW Nay, without drink he was drunken indeed, responded the other. END
BEGIN NOW He was cruelly wronged, the first peasant repeated the phrase that summed it up. END
BEGIN NOW Cruelly wronged, the others murmured after him. END
BEGIN NOW The deceased was a hard master to you, wasn't he? END
BEGIN NOW I asked a peasant, whom I recognised as one of Harlov's serfs. END
BEGIN NOW He was a master, certainly, answered the peasant, but still\. END
BEGIN NOW he was cruelly wronged! END
BEGIN NOW Cruelly wronged,\. END
BEGIN NOW I heard again in the crowd. END
BEGIN NOW At the grave, too, Evlampia stood, as it were, lost. END
BEGIN NOW Thoughts were torturing her\. END
BEGIN NOW bitter thoughts. END
BEGIN NOW I noticed that Sletkin, who several times addressed some remark to her, she treated as she had once treated Zhitkov, and worse still. END
BEGIN NOW Some days later, there was a rumour all over our neighbourhood, that Evlampia Martinovna had left the home of her fathers for ever, leaving all the property that came to her to her sister and brother-in-law, and only taking some hundreds of roubles.\. END
BEGIN NOW So Anna's bought her out, it seems! END
BEGIN NOW remarked my mother; but you and I, certainly, she added, addressing Zhitkov, with whom she was playing picquet&mdash;he took Souvenir's place, are not skilful hands! END
BEGIN NOW Zhitkov looked dejectedly at his mighty palms.\. END
BEGIN NOW Hands like that! END
BEGIN NOW Not skilful! END
BEGIN NOW he seemed to be saying to himself.\. END
BEGIN NOW Soon after, my mother and I went to live in Moscow, and many years passed before it was my lot to behold Martin Petrovitch's daughters again. END
BEGIN NOW BUT I did see them again. END
BEGIN NOW Anna Martinovna I came across in the most ordinary way. END
BEGIN NOW After my mother's death I paid a visit to our village, where I had not been for over fifteen years, and there I received an invitation from the mediator (at that time the process of settling the boundaries between the peasants and their former owners was taking place over the whole of Russia with a slowness not yet forgotten) to a meeting of the other landowners of our neighbourhood, to be held on the estate of the widow Anna Sletkin. END
BEGIN NOW The news that my mother's nasty little Jew, with the prune-coloured eyes, no longer existed in this world, caused me, I confess, no regret whatever. END
BEGIN NOW But it was interesting to get a glimpse of his widow. END
BEGIN NOW She had the reputation in the neighbourhood of a first-rate manager. END
BEGIN NOW And so it proved; her estate and homestead and the house itself (I could not help glancing at the roof; it was an iron one) all turned out to be in excellent order; everything was neat, clean, tidied-up, where needful&mdash;painted, as though its mistress were a German. END
BEGIN NOW Anna Martinovna herself, of course, looked older. END
BEGIN NOW But the peculiar, cold, and, as it were, wicked charm which had once so fascinated me had not altogether left her. END
BEGIN NOW She was dressed in rustic fashion, but elegantly. END
BEGIN NOW She received us, not cordially&mdash;that word was not applicable to her&mdash;but courteously, and on seeing me, a witness of that fearful scene, not an eyelash quivered. END
BEGIN NOW She made not the slightest reference to my mother, nor her father, nor her sister, nor her husband. END
BEGIN NOW She had two daughters, both very pretty, slim young things, with charming little faces, and a bright and friendly expression in their black eyes. END
BEGIN NOW There was a son, too, a little like his father, but still a boy to he proud of! END
BEGIN NOW During the discussions between the landowners, Anna Martinovna's attitude was composed and dignified, she showed no sign of being specially obstinate, nor specially grasping. END
BEGIN NOW But none had a truer perception of their own interests than she of hers; none could more convincingly expound and defend their rights. END
BEGIN NOW All the laws pertinent to the case, even the Minister's circulars, she had thoroughly mastered. END
BEGIN NOW She spoke little, and in a quiet voice, but every word she uttered was to the point. END
BEGIN NOW It ended in our all signifying our agreement to all her demands, and making concessions, which we could only marvel at ourselves. END
BEGIN NOW On our way home, some of the worthy landowners even used harsh words of themselves; they all hummed and hawed, and shook their heads. END
BEGIN NOW Ah, she's got brains that woman! END
BEGIN NOW said one. END
BEGIN NOW A tricky baggage! END
BEGIN NOW put in another less delicate proprietor. END
BEGIN NOW Smooth in word, but cruel in deed! END
BEGIN NOW And a screw into the bargain! END
BEGIN NOW added a third; not a glass of vodka nor a morsel of caviare for us&mdash;what do you think of that? END
BEGIN NOW What can one expect of her? END
BEGIN NOW suddenly croaked a gentleman who had been silent till then, every one knows she poisoned her husband! END
BEGIN NOW To my astonishment, nobody thought fit to controvert this awful and certainly unfounded charge! END
BEGIN NOW I was the more surprised at this, as, in spite of the slighting expressions I have reported, all of them felt respect for Anna Martinovna, not excluding the indelicate landowner. END
BEGIN NOW As for the mediator, he waxed positively eloquent. END
BEGIN NOW Put her on a throne, he exclaimed, she'd be another Semiramis or Catherine the Second! END
BEGIN NOW The discipline among her peasants is a perfect model.\. END
BEGIN NOW The education of her children is model! END
BEGIN NOW What a head! END
BEGIN NOW What brains! END
BEGIN NOW Without going into the question of Semiramis and Catherine, there was no doubt Anna Martinovna was living a very happy life. END
BEGIN NOW Ease, inward and external, the pleasant serenity of spiritual health, seemed the very atmosphere about herself, her family, all her surroundings. END
BEGIN NOW How far she had deserved such happiness.\. END
BEGIN NOW that is another question. END
BEGIN NOW Such questions, though, are only propounded in youth. END
BEGIN NOW Everything in the world, good and bad, comes to man, not through his deserts, but in consequence of some as yet unknown but logical laws which I will not take upon myself to indicate, though I sometimes fancy I have a dim perception of them. END
BEGIN NOW I QUESTIONED the mediator about Evlampia Martinovna, and learnt that she had been lost sight of completely ever since she left home, and probably had departed this life long ago. END
BEGIN NOW So our worthy mediator expressed himself but I am convinced that I have seen Evlampia, that I have come across her. END
BEGIN NOW This was how it was. END
BEGIN NOW Four years after my interview with Anna Martinovna, I was spending the summer at Murino, a little hamlet near Petersburg, a well-known resort of summer visitors of the middle class. END
BEGIN NOW The shooting was pretty decent about Murino at that time, and I used to go out with my gun almost every day. END
BEGIN NOW I had a companion on my expeditions, a man of the tradesman class, called Vikulov, a very sensible and good-natured fellow; but, as he said of himself, of no position whatever. END
BEGIN NOW This man had been simply everywhere, and everything! END
BEGIN NOW Nothing could astonish him, he knew everything&mdash;but he cared for nothing but shooting and wine. END
BEGIN NOW Well, one day we were on our way home to Murino, and we chanced to pass a solitary house, standing at the cross-roads, and enclosed by a high, close paling. END
BEGIN NOW It was not the first time I had seen the house, and every time it excited my curiosity. END
BEGIN NOW There was something about it mysterious, locked-up, grimly-dumb, something suggestive of a prison or a hospital. END
BEGIN NOW Nothing of it could be seen from the road but its steep, dark, red-painted roof. END
BEGIN NOW There was only one pair of gates in the whole fence; and these seemed fastened and never opened. END
BEGIN NOW No sound came from the other side of them. END
BEGIN NOW For all that, we felt that some one was certainly living in the house; it had not at all the air of a deserted dwelling. END
BEGIN NOW On the I contrary, everything about it was stout, and tight, and strong, as if it would stand a siege! END
BEGIN NOW What is that fortress? END
BEGIN NOW I asked my companion. END
BEGIN NOW Don't you know? END
BEGIN NOW Vikulov gave a sly wink. END
BEGIN NOW A fine building, eh? END
BEGIN NOW The police-captain of these parts gets a nice little income out of it! END
BEGIN NOW How's that? END
BEGIN NOW I'll tell you. END
BEGIN NOW You've heard, I daresay, of the Flagellant dissenters&mdash;that do without priests, you know? END
BEGIN NOW Yes. END
BEGIN NOW Well, it's there that their chief mother lives. END
BEGIN NOW A woman? END
BEGIN NOW Yes&mdash;the mother; a mother of God, they say. END
BEGIN NOW Nonsense! END
BEGIN NOW I tell you, it is so. END
BEGIN NOW She is a strict one, they say.\. END
BEGIN NOW A regular commander-in-chief! END
BEGIN NOW She rules over thousands! END
BEGIN NOW I'd take her, and all these mothers of God\. END
BEGIN NOW But what's the use of talking? END
BEGIN NOW He called his Pegashka, a marvellous dog, with an excellent scent, but with no notion of setting. END
BEGIN NOW Vikulov was obliged to tie her hind paws to keep her from running so furiously. END
BEGIN NOW His words sank into my memory. END
BEGIN NOW I sometimes went out of my way to pass by the mysterious house. END
BEGIN NOW One day I had just got up to it, when suddenly&mdash;wonderful to relate!&mdash;a bolt grated in the gates, a key creaked in the lock, then the gates themselves slowly parted, there appeared a large horse's head, with a plaited forelock under a decorated yoke, and slowly there rolled into the road a small cart, like those driven by horse-dealers, and higglers. END
BEGIN NOW On the leather cushion of the cart, near to me, sat a peasant of about thirty, of a remarkably handsome and attractive appearance, in a neat black smock, and a black cap, pulled down low on his forehead. END
BEGIN NOW He was carefully driving the well-fed horse, whose sides were as broad as a stove. END
BEGIN NOW Beside the peasant, on the far side of the cart, sat a tall woman, as straight as an arrow. END
BEGIN NOW Her head was covered by a costly-looking black shawl. END
BEGIN NOW She was dressed in a short jerkin of dove-coloured velvet, and a dark blue merino skirt; her white hands she held discreetly clasped on her bosom. END
BEGIN NOW The cart turned on the road to the left, and brought the woman within two paces of me; she turned her head a little, and I recognised Evlampia Harlov. END
BEGIN NOW I knew her at once, I did not doubt for one instant, and indeed no doubt was possible; eyes like hers, and above all that cut of the lips&mdash;haughty and sensual&mdash;I had never seen in any one else. END
BEGIN NOW Her face had grown longer and thinner, the skin was darker, here and there lines could be discerned; but, above all, the expression of the face was changed! END
BEGIN NOW It is difficult to do justice in words to the self-confidence, the sternness, the pride it had gained! END
BEGIN NOW Not simply the serenity of power&mdash;the satiety of power was visible in every feature. END
BEGIN NOW The careless glance she cast at me told of long years of habitually meeting nothing but reverent, unquestioning obedience. END
BEGIN NOW That woman clearly lived surrounded, not by worshippers, but by slaves. END
BEGIN NOW She had clearly forgotten even the time when any command, any desire of hers, was not carried out at the instant! END
BEGIN NOW I called her loudly by her name and her father's; she gave a faint start, looked at me a second time, not with alarm, but with contemptuous wrath, as though asking&mdash; Who dares to disturb me? END
BEGIN NOW and barely parting her lips, uttered a word of command. END
BEGIN NOW The peasant sitting beside her started forward, with a wave of his arm struck the horse with the reins&mdash;the horse set off at a strong rapid trot, and the cart disappeared. END
BEGIN NOW Since then I have not seen Evlampia again. END
BEGIN NOW In what way Martin Petrovitch's daughter came to be a Holy Virgin in the Flagellant sect I cannot imagine. END
BEGIN NOW But, who knows, very likely she has founded a sect which will be called&mdash;or even now is called&mdash;after her name, the Evlampieshtchin sect? END
BEGIN NOW Anything may be, anything may come to pass. END
BEGIN NOW And so this is what I had to tell you of my Lear of the Steppes, of his family and his doings. END
BEGIN NOW The story-teller ceased, and we talked a little longer, and then parted, each to his home.  END
